title: Bulova Watch
description: The Bulova Watch Company, the nation's largest producer and importer of jeweled lever watches and movements, reduced its yearly loss to $7 million from the $25.6 million deficit in its previous fiscal year ended March 31. The loss for that year included $12,6 million for inventories and other writedowns relating to a corporate restructuring program. Sales were $207.5 million, up 1.4 percent from $204.7 million the year before.

title: How to Get There
description: To reach the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket Township, Mass., take the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to the Massachusetts Turnpike and get off at the LeePittsfield exit. Then take Route 20, toward Springfield, and turn left on George Carter Road. By public transportation take Greyhound (5942000) or Bonanza Bus Lines (5648484) from the Port Authority Terminal to Lee. A oneway ticket is $12.40, roundtrip is $23.60. At Lee, take a taxi to the Pillow.

title: Stage: Gurdjieff's Life And Work in 6 Scenes
description: SOME WORKS OF ART reach out to everybody; others speak more privately to the initiated. It is a virtue of The Illustrated Journal'which runs for two more weekends, Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays at 9 P.M. at the Shared Forms Theaterthat it can speak directly to the followers of a particular cult and still be of interest to a more general audience.

title: Getting It All Together
description: As the Newport Jazz Festival moves into the final four days of its 11day run this weekend, it will be joined today by another festival, Jazz in the Afternoon, which will run through Monday.

title: Mystic Music
description: THE ILLUSTRATED JOURNAL, text by G. I. Gurdiieft, Maurice Nicoll; music by Chopin, Debussy and traditional; lighting by Jeff Davis; settings by Ron Janowich; costumes by Liltan Dugan. Presented by the Shared Forms Theater, at 17 White Street.

title: Johnson Connects Thrice in Toronto
description: TORONTO, June 30Cliff Johnson, referred to as a big gorilla last week by Mark (The Bird) Fidrych, assumed Konglike dimensions tonight.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline on a story in The Times yesterday about fraud in a summer program to feed needy children said erroneously that the project involved school lunches. The New York City Board of Education was not involved in the projects under investigation.

title: Yen Continues to Advance Sharply Against the Dollar
description: TOKYO, June 30 (UPI)The yen continued to appreciate sharply against the dollar in heavy trading today on the Tokyo foreign exchange market. The market finished at 266.50 yen to the dollar, down 2.40 yen from yesterday's closing price of 268.90 yen. The Japanese Government, thought to be bowing to pressures from the United States and Europe to reduce Japan's huge balanceofpayments surplus, shows no sign of intervening at the present level.

title: New Face: Maureen Moore
description: The petite blonde in the pewtery gown leans across the footlights and confides, with a fetching growl, Each night I get the mirruh, from off the shelf/Each night I'm getting queeruh, chasing myself! The lyric is from Cole Porter's song, Nobody's Chasing Me, written for the 1950 musical Out of This World, and its emphatic and funny delivery by the tiny but powerpacked Maureen Moore is one of the reasons Unsung Cole is doing a brisk trade at the Circle Repertory Theater off Sheridan Square.

title: NewMinted Mingus
description: CHARLES MINGUS'S quintet grew into a 15man band between the printing of the Newport Jazz Festival New York program and Mr. Mingus's appearance Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. In contrast to last year's Mingus program, which was a kind of retrospective of some of the composerbassist's extended works for small groups, Wednesday's concert featured allnew music.

title: For Children
description: THE FOREST WITCH AND THE LITTLE PRINCESS, a new musical based on an old Russian folktale, 2 P.M. on Saturday and Sunday, directed by Pat Kellis, at the Academy Arts Theater, 330 East 56th Street. Admission, 52. For information and reservations, call 4861431.

title: Carter Picks Envoy to Sri Lanka
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters)President Carter today nominated W. Howard Wriggins to be Ambassador to Sri Lanka and the Maldives. The 59 yearold Mr. Wriggins is director of the Southern Asian Institute at Columbia University and professor of public law and government.

title: How to Get There
description: Lyndhurst is situated south of ?arrytown, N. Y., on Broadway (J. S. Route 9) approximately onequarter mile south of the interchange of the New York State Thruway and the Tappan Zee Bridge. Open daily 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. from May 1 to Oct. 31, and 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. from Nov. 1 to April 30. Closed Christmas Day.

title: Market Place
description: Ordinarily, a company whose shares sell at a discount from net working capital current assets minus current liabilitiesmight be regarded as a bargain since the company presumably has substantial liquid assets behind each common share.

title: League Leaders;
description: Be The Associated Press

title: CRUDE IMPORTS UP IN WEEK 400,000 BARRELS A DAY
description: Crude oil imports for the week ended Tune 24 were up sharply to 7.2 million, barrels a day, compared to 6.8 million barrels in the preceding week, and well ahead of the 5.5 million barrels imported daily in the yearearlier level, according to the latest weekly supply statistics released by the American Petroleum Ins??????.

title: 1,500 at Funeral Hear Walter Kennedy Hailed As Man for All People
description: STAMFORD, Conn.,June 30Larry O'Brien, Pete Rozelle and Bowie Kuhn, the commissioners of basketball, football and baseball, respectfully, were among the 1,500 people attending the funeral mass for J. Walter Kennedy today at St. John's Roman Catholic Church. Several hundred more people were outside the church paying tribute to the former mayor of Stamford and commissioner of the National Basketball Association.

title: George Waugh Jr., 85, Retired In 44 as Borden Inc. Executive
description: George M. Waugh Jr., who retired in 1944 as executive vice president of Borden Inc., died Wednesday night in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Emergency Powers Ended
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 (UPI)Prime Minister Selim alHoss and his Cabinet decided today to give up the emergency powers by which they governed Lebanon in the six months since the civil war ended

title: The U.N. Today
description: July 1, 1977

title: New Accounting Rule Will Limit Retroactive Changes
description: Companies will be substantially limited in the retroactive adjustments they can make to income statements under a new accounting rule announced yesterday.

title: Books: In Pirandello's Realm
description: EVERY NOVEL by Leonardo Sciascia is an occasion. Sicily's bestknown and one of Italy's mostrespected novelists writes slowly, handstitching his books. And only half of his stories have been translated into English. The clue to his ideas can be found in one of his works that deserves to be translated: Pirandello e la Sicilia. Luigi Pirandello was one of the most original playwrights of the 20th century; his fellowSicilian, Leonardo Sciascia, covers the same metaphysical territory.

title: IMMUNITY IS LIMITED IN GRAND JURY CASES
description: TRENTON, June 30The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today in two cases that prosecutors had the power to require witnesses to testify against themselves in grand jury investigations even though their testimony could not be used against them at a subsequent trial.

title: Williams and Meehan to Merge
description: The merger of Blair S. Williams & Company and M. J. Meehan & Company, two specialist firms on the New York Stock Exchange, was approved yesterday by the exchange's market performance committee. The merger will become effective today.

title: TexasBritain Fare Cut Sought
description: DALLAS, June 30 (AP)Braniff International said today that it wanted to offer: a reducedfare Skytrain from Texas to Britain and asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to convene hearings on the propos al. The Dallasbased airline proposed a $250 oneway fire for a nofrills flight.

title: Two Steel Companies Sign Pollution Control Pacts
description: YOUNGSTOWN. Ohio, June 30 (AP)The Republic Steel Corporation and the United States Steel Corporation signed pollution control agreements today in what was described as a major step toward solving water pollution problems in the mahoning River.

title: Texas High Court Justice Indicted On Counts of Perjury and Forgery
description: HOUSTON, June 30A county grand jury in Austin today indicted Donald B. Yarbrough, an Associate Justice of the Texas Supreme Court, for perjury and forgery of an automobile title.

title: President Hopeful on Brezhnev Trip
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  Asserting that SovietAmerican relations were not in trouble, President Carter said today that he hoped to meet with Leonid I. Brezhnev this year so that the twoleaders could get to know one another.

title: HouseSenate Conferees Settle StripMining Bill; Passage Expected Soon
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP)  A HouseSenate conference committee completed action today on a compromise stripmining bill that would establish tough new reclamation standards for 60 percent of the nation's coal mine operators.

title: Cruise Missiles Can Be Launched By Plane or From Under the Sea
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The cruise missile, which President Carter is seeking to deploy on the nation's bombers, promises to emerge as one of the most versatile weapons in the American arsenal.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Justice Department Asks the F.B.I. To Renew New Haven Tap Inquiry
description: NEW HAVEN, June 30  The Department of Justice said today that it was asking the Federal Bureau of Investigation to reopen its inquiry into charges that F.B.I. agents were involved in an extensive illegal wiretap operation by the New Haven Police Department.

title: 45,000 Striking Copper Industry
description: PHOENIX, June 30 (UPI)Unions representing 45,000 workers in the United States copper industry voted today to strike all the major producers when contracts expired early tomorrow.

title: Max Roach A Different Drummer
description: Five years ago, Max Roach, the most influential young drummer to develop in the ferment of the bebop era of the 1940's, left the active jazz scene to join the music department of the University of Massachusetts. He is back in town this weekend, on leave from academia, and will appear with his quartet tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall as part of the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: Finding Levitt Buyer Is Judge's Top Priority
description: With the sale of Avis Inc. stock to Norton Simon Inc., out of the way, Federal District Judge M. Joseph Blumenfeld turned his attentions in Hartford yesterday to finding a buyer for the Levitt Corporation, the homebuilder.

title: Run in 9th Returns Expos to Cellar
description: MONTREAL, June 30The grand battle for last plate in the National League East began tonight, and the New York Mets lost the bottom spot by coming back in the seventh and ninth innings and winning their game against the Montreal Expos, 43.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: 1977 Corn Acreage Near Level of 1976, Pointing to Big Crop
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP)Farmers are expected to harvest 70.8 million acres of corn this year, only fourtenths of percent fewer than in 1976, when they produced a record crop of the foodproducing grain, the United States Department of Agriculture said today.

title: State Hopes to Raze Abandoned Hudson Piers
description: State officials hope work will begin in January to rid the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City of two dozen abandoned piers like those that burned here Wednesday night and yesterday morning.

title: Heavy Rains Postpone Start of Milwaukee Golf
description: MILWAUKEE, June 30 (UPI)With the course swept by heavy rain just after daybreak and with little hope of a letup, officials postponed today's opening round of the Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament.

title: A Women's College Resists The Campus Merger Trend
description: The battle lines have been drawn in Clinton, N.Y., where Kirkland College, a nineyearold school for women, is resisting a merger with its brother institution, the 165yearold Hamilton College.

title: RESULTS
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% municipal tax.)

title: Big Apple in 78
description: After six years in New York, the Newport Jazz Festival will move to Saratoga Springs next year. But New York will still have a jazz festival during the 11day period at the end of June and the beginning of July now occupied by the festival, said George Wein, producer of the Newport Festival, in announcing the change yesterday.

title: It's All Over for the Biltmore Bar
description: The man at the bar at the Biltmore Hotel finished his last martiniit may have been the bar's last one, toosurreptitiously stuffed a wad of monogrammed napkins into a pocket of his pinstriped suit and walked out the door with his memories.

title: Parks Aide Shifted After He Hires Son For a Summer Job
description: Thomas Mullany, the personnel director of the New York City Parks Department, has been reassigned to other duties by Martin Lang, the Commissioner of Parks and Recreation. The reassignment was made after Mr. Lang learned that Mr. Mullany had quietly hired his son as a summer park foreman.

title: No Caviar
description: Soviet authorities are accusing Anatoly Shcharansky of high treason and of being a C.I.A. accomplice. President Carter calls him a scapegoat and denies Mr. Shcharansky had C.I.A. ties.

title: $144 Million Budget Is Approved By Yonkers at a Raucous Session
description: YONKERS, June 30The City Council tonight approved a $144 million budget for the fiscal year that begins tomorrow. The budget did not include anticipated, but still unapproved, state aid that Yonkers hoped could be used to meet wage demands of its policemen, firemen and sanitation workers.

title: Auto Production to Date Seen Topping S Million; Weekly Output Up 16.2%
description: DETROIT, June 30 (AP)Domestic auto production for the year to date is expect; ed to top five million units this week, according to an industry journal.

title: I.F.M.S. Whirs Into Life, Greeting Beame and Goldin
description: Hello, Mayor Beam. Hello, Comptroller Goldin. I am the Integrated Financial Management System. I am ready to begin working for you and New York City. To start me, please depress the red T.

title: New Product Labels Will Aid Consumers
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  The Department of Commerce announced today a 12month pilot program of labeling products to provide consumers with information on the products performance.

title: Borg Is. Victor in 5 Sets, Connors in 4, As Both Move Into Final at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 30It will be Jimmy Connors versus Bjorn Borg in the men's singles final of the centennial Wimbledon championships Saturday.

title: No More Oil Rises in 1977, Venezuelan Says
description: The oil pricing split within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been settled with agreement that there will be no further price rises this year, Venezuela's President Carlos Andres Perez said yesterday.

title: XRay of Hitler's Head Brings $375 at Auction
description: An XRay of Adolf Hitler's head was purchased at auction for $375 last night by an unnamed collector, identified only as a doctor interested in the medical details of famous people, according to a spokesman for the Charles Hamilton Galleries.

title: Art: Turn of the Century at Whitney
description: THE VERY TITLE of the new exhibition at the Whitney MuseumTurnoftheCentury America, which opened yesterday and remains on view through Oct. 2suggests something easy on the eye and not too weighty for the mind, a show that is strong on graciousness and charm, on the undemanding appeals of nostalgia for an era of American life that was so much simpler and ever so much more genteel than our own. And there is certainly plenty to look at in this exhibitionnot only paintings but posters, mural designs, photographs, cartoons, drawings, prints, etc.that confirms this expectation of escape into another world.

title: P. K. Leberman, 77, Retired in 1968 As Head of Family Circle Magazine
description: Palmer K. Leberman, former board chairman and chief executive officer of Family Circle Magazine, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital, West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 77 years old and a resident of Manalapan, Fla.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: A.A.U.W. Takes Rights Stand
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 30(AP)The American Association of University Women has voted not to hold regional conventions in states that have not ratified the equal rights amendment to the Constitution. The vote at'the grounp's national convention yesterday was 2,613 in favor and 754 opposed.

title: Soccer
description: Cosmos at Vancouver. Toronto 2, Washington 1.

title: Shift to Coal Decreed By F.E.A. at 46 Plants
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters)The Federal Energy Administration today told 18 utilities and 28 factories to switch from oil, and natural gas to coal as their primary energy source.

title: Broadway
description: NATURALLY, you are worried that Joseph Papp, having withdrawn from Lincoln Center, will never be heard from again. Your fears are groundless. In September, the Shakespeare Festival will open a cabaret theater on the top floor of its headquarters downtown. This will be in Martinson Hall, and the plan is to redesign it, put in tables and chairs, serve liquor, and then hold theatrical events there. The phrase theatrical events is used advisedly because Gail Merrifield and Craig Zaden, who will run the cabaret theater, are talking about staging musicals, new plays, political satire, monologues, works in progress and virtually everything else. The idea is to keep things flexible.

title: Bache and Shields Merge
description: The previously announced merger of Bache Halsey Stuart and Shields Model Roland, two leading brokerage firms, will become effective at the close of business today. The merged firm, Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, is a subsidiary of the Bache Group Inc. and has total capital of about $156 million.

title: U.S. ORDERS AIR BAGS OR AUTOMATIC BELTS FOR ALL 1984 AUTOS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Transportation Secretary Brock Adams issued an order today requiring that air bags or automatic lap and shoulder restraints be installed in all standard and luxury automobiles by the 1982 model year and in all smaller cars by the 1984 model year.

title: 12 New York School Projects Cut, But $90 Million Saving Evaporates
description: Twelve school construction projects were abruptly suspended in 1975 on the recommendation of the Emergency Financial Control Board to produce a projected net cash savings for New York City of $90 million.

title: A Miss Universe Day Beguiles City Hall
description: For those who missed it, Wednesday was Miss Universe Day in New York City, Mayor Beame made it so, with an official proclamation and some goodnatured remarks, as he stood on the steps of City Hall surrounded by 47 of this year's contestants.

title: Dow Jones Gives Up on National Observer, Will Cease Publication
description: The National Observer, the 15yearold national weekly newpaper published by Dow Jones & Co., will cease Publication with its July 4 issue.

title: Soviet Explosion Reported
description: UPPSALA, Sweden,June 29(AP)The Uppsala Seismological Institution reported an underground explosion today in the Semipalatinsk area, the Soviet nuclear testing grounds in western Siberia. The institution said the explosion measured 6.2 on the Richter scale.

title: The Pop Life
description: THEOLOGIANS and philosophers have often had trouble with the arts, and with music in particular. Plato had little use for artists in his Republic, and the early Christian church was only willing to admit the sensuous strains of music into its services if it was strictly tamed. Luther made some amends for that sternness during the Reformation and by our own time gospel musicand especially black gospel musichas shown little restraint in enlisting every ounce of music's power in the service of the Lord.

title: Canada Stressing Unity on Birthday
description: OTTAWA, June 30A week of official emphasis on national unity, at a time when that unity is under the severest strain in Canadian history, will reach a climax here tomorrow in the most elaborate celebration of the nation's birthday since the centennial observance 10 years ago.

title: Carter Declines to Support Any Mayoral Candidates In Democratic Primary
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Trying to stay out of the line of fire in the Democratic mayoral primary in New York City, President Carter said today that he would not get involved even though Mayor Beame was one of his first major supporters in New York.

title: Publishing: Vintage Sevareid
description: ERIC SEVAREID'S Not So Wild a Dreamthe journey of a young man from Velva, N. D., to the wilderness of World War II as a correspondentfirst appeared in 1946. It wasand is a beautifully written, idealistically inclined book that captured the youthful dreams of America and the postwar world. Unlike so many spinoffs and ripoffs by television personanalities, Not So Wild a Dream did not depend on the familiarity of the author's face or the great holdup of the book jacket a talk show.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of post positions

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 30The head of the State Commission of Investigations said today that three of his 12 investigators who had applied for jobs with Resorts International Inc., which plans to open New Jersey's first gambling casino in Atlantic City later this year, were being separated from the agency to protect its integrity.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: DAYLIGHT SAVING TIME

title: Notes on People
description: Inmate No. 24171157, also known as John N. Mitchel? has been given a job at the Federal prison camp at Maxwell Air Force Base, outside Mont? gomery. Ala. It will be a clericaltype job within the camp, said Jim Fleagle, the prison's acting superintendent. Mr. Mitchell, who was Attorney General of the United States in the Nixon Administration, was assigned to a department that give inmates basic education. Most Maxwell inmates work on the Air Force base as janitors and groundskeepers, but officials said that Mr. Mitchell, 63 years old, was considered too old for such duty. Mr. Mitchell, the 25th Watergate figure to be imprisoned, is serving a sentence of 30 months to eight years for perjury and conspiracy.

title: TIGHTER BANK CURBS ASKED IN STOCK DEALS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today that Federal controls over banks involved ,in the stock market be tightened to assure investor protection.

title: Rambling Willie Takes Rich Hackensack Pace
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 30 The expected duel between Oil Burner, who recently was syndicated for $2.7 million, and Shadyside Trixie, the track's recordholder, in the $50.000 Hackensack Pace at the Meadowlands tonight failed to develop.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: A new business study that projects an ominous outlook for steel scrap supplies in the United States has generated considerable controversy in trade circles, If a serious shortage develops in this country's scrap availability over the next five years, as the study forecasts, it could have important implications not only for the world's steelmaking expansion but also for the United

title: SENATORS ELUCIDATE SHIFT ON ABORTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Several liberal and moderate Senators who changed their positions yesterday and voted to limit Federal funds for Medicaid abortions said today that they had been influenced by the Supreme Court, President Carter, public sentiment and especially by what they considered the liberal language of the bill.

title: GEORGE LYLE
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (UPI) George Lyle, a former Philadelphia sportswriter, editor and sports broadcaster, who was recently the public relations director for Lincoln University, died yesterday. He was 65 years old.

title: Black Activist Wins Tenure Battle
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 30Harry Edwards, an outspoken black sociology professor here who protested racism in the 1968 Olympics, has been granted a permanent position on the University of California faculty, ending six months of controversy over whether he was qualified for tenure.

title: The Intelligence Agencies: What Is to Be Done?
description: DAYTON, OhioPresident Carter is now reviewing the activities and organization of the nation's intelligence community, including the C.I.A. and portions of the Defense and State Departments, the F.B.I. and other agencies.

title: Chinese Drive to Purge Radicals Is Seen Building to a Conclusion
description: HONG KONG, June 30The eightmonth campaign against followers of China's radicals appears to have reached a crescendo that, in the view of analysts here, may signal an effort by Peking to conclude it before a national congress of the Chinese Communist Party is held later this year.

title: Obituary 1  No Title

AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Down On The Farm
description: On Feb. 15, 1949, six Administrations and nearly three decades ago, the price of wheat was $1.90 a bushel. Earlier this month, in Goodwin, Kan., wheat fell to $1.64 a bushel. Given inflation, that's only about half of what wheat was bringing in 1949, and less than a third of the current parity price, $5.03 a bushel. There's almost surely worse yet to come for the farmerand the result could be political disaster for the Democrats and a stubbornly budgetconscious Carter Administration.

title: SILENCE ON MIDEAST ORDERED BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  President Carter, seeking to prevent the rift between his Administration and Israel from growing, today imposed a moratoriumion on further comments about the details of a projected Middle East settlement before Prime Minister Menahem Begin visits Washington on July 19.

title: President Hopeful on Brezhnev Trip
description: WASHINGTON. June 30  Asserting that SovietAmerican relations were not in trouble, President Carter said ,today that he hoped to meet with Leonid I Brezhnev this year so. that the two leadcrs could get to Know one another.

title: Kenya Calls Association Dead
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 30 (Reuters)The East African Community, linking Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda in a range of communications and economic services, now is dead because no financial provision has been made for the new financial year that starts tomorrow, Kenyan Government officials said today.

title: Hancock's QuintetThe Top of the Scale
description: The jazz combo performing Sunday evening at Avery Fisher Hall bills itself simply as The Quintet. It assembled last summer for a V.S.O.P.Very Special OneTime Performanceat the NewportNew York Jazz Festival, and, explains Herbie Hancock, the pianist who is the group's nominal leader, it felt good.

title: Coastal Counties Ask to Join Suit To End Sludge Dumping Off State
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 30Officials of four New Jersey coastal counties sought today to join a. Federal Court suit aimed at forcing an end to dumping of sewage sludge in the New York Bight off Sandy Hook.

title: General Appeal
description: MACARTHUR, directed by Joseph Sargent; screenplay by Hal Barwood and Matthew Robbins; produced by Frank McCarthy; director of photography, Mario Tosi; music, Jerry Goldsmith; editor, George Jay Nicholson; a Richard D. ZanuckDavid Brown production, distributed by Universal Pictures. Running time: 122 minutes. At Radio City Music Hall, Avenue of the Americas at 50th Street. This film has been rated PG.

title: Stomach Pains Hospitalize 150 at Carolina Convention
description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 30 (AP)More than 150 persons attending a convention at a motel here were taken to hospitals today with severe stomach pains tentatively diagnosed as food poisoning.

title: Tribute to Garner
description: THIRTY YEARS ago, when George Shearing was the intermission pianist at the Three Deuces on 52d Street and Erroll Garner was the club's star, Mr. Garner, who liked to drop in and play at other clubs on the block during his intermissions, was frequently late getting back to the Deuces.

title: Italian Political Violence Leaves 1 Dead, 2 Wounded
description: ROME, June 30 (Reuters)Two Fiat car company executives were wounded by leftists and a night watchman was found shot dead in attacks today that followed a series of bombings.

title: Dance: Balasaraswati
description: BALASARASWATI, India's great classical dancer, is also one of the supreme performing artists in the world. It is difficult to write of her without falling into superlatives, and her performance in New London, Conn. Wednesday night at the American Dance Festival leaves the reviewer again in the same, happy quandary.

title: ROLAND S. WOOLSON JR.
description: Poland S. Woolson Jr., an engineering sciences editor in the WileyInterscience division of John Wiley and Sons Inc., New York City book publishers, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Woolson, formerly of Fair Haven, N. J., lived in the Hotel Dryden East. He was 47 years old.

title: Ford Calls B1 Ruling A Mistaken Gamble
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 (UPI) Former President Gerald R. Ford said today the decision by President Carter to cancel the B1 bomber was a mistake.

title: Charles C. Chang at 56, Served As Clinical Pediatrics Professor
description: Dr. Charles C. Chang, assistant clinical professor of pediatrics at Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, and a former president of the pediatrics section of the Kings County Medical Society, died Wednesday in Brookdale Hospital Medical Center after a short illness.

title: Strike Turns Mine Area Into a War Zone
description: STEARNS, Ky, June 29The handscrawled placards posted along the winding little roadway to Blue Diamond's Justus Mine in the wild Cumberland Mountains here announce that a strike is under way  Warning: the Stearns miners have determined that scabbing is dangerous to your health'but the area seems more like a war zone.

title: EXCHURCH AIDE HELD FOR SILENCE ON BOMBING
description: Pedro Archuleta, a former member of the Protestant Episcopal Church's National Commission on Hispanic Affairs, was ruled in contempt of court and ordered to jail yesterday for his refusal to answer a Federal grand jury's questions about the 1975 bombing of Fraunces Tavern.

title: Management
description: General Foods, Crown Zellerbach, Nestle, Borden, Quaker Oats, Sterling Drug, American Can, Pfizer and Scott Paper have all coordinated the distribution process in recent years under one executive.

title: Justice Irving H. Saypol, 7 1 , Dies; Rosenberg SpyTrial Prosecutor
description: Irving H. Saypol, who served as Federal prosecutor in the sabotage and conspiracy trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg and then sat as a New York State Justice for 26 years, died yesterday of cancer at his home. Justice Saypol, who was active on the State Supreme Court until a few days ago, was 71 years old and lived at 152 East 94th Street.

title: 16 Nations of E.E.C. and E.F.T.A. Ending Most Trade Curbs Today
description: BRUSSELS. June 30 (Reuters)  The world's largest industrial free trade area will be created tomorrow when the IC nations in the Common Market and European Free Trade Association remove 41most all customs tariffs and duties.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHY ISN'T New York City Paris? This is a pointless question, I know. Yet it struck me hard the other day, like a scene by Dufy or Bemelmans that wasn't there, as I was driving uptown on the East Side Drive. Looking east at about 45th Street, I found myself wondering why I was seeing awful, blocky apartment buildings instead of the Cathedral of Notre Dame.

title: Film: A Cuban 'Uncle Tom's Cabin'
description: "THE Other Francisco" the 1975 Cuban film that opened yesterday at the Jean Renoir Cinema, is an unusually fresh example of the sort of didactic movie making that often leaves a lot to be desired. Directed by Sergio Giral, "The Other Francisco" is both an adaptation of Anselmo Suarez Romero's "Francisco," a Cuban antislavery novel written before "Uncle Tom's Cabin," as well as a critique of the novel and of the methods and motives of 19th-century Cuban liberals and abolitionists.Mr. Giral cross-cuts between scenes from the novela sentimental story about a young slave who kills himself when his beloved is taken into the master's bedand scenes that attempt to show, what slavery was really like. There also are interludes in which the novelist discusses the writing of his book, which, he admits, attributes romantic motives to characters who were incapable of romantic notions.Photographed in black-and-white that has the quality of newsreel battle footage, the film both appreciates the novel's abolitionist sentiments and analyzes the distortions. Slaves, the movie says, were hardly as docile and passive as the novelist pictured. They might commit suicide to escape the system but never because of broken hearts. Women slaves were treated as badly as the men. Although Cuban liberals were against slavery, they were apprehensive about full independence from Spain, fearing a black-majority rule."The Other Francisco," which begins the Renoir Cinema's retrospective of Cuban films (including the superb "Memories of Underdevelopment"), is a stern, sober, opinionated work. It's also another demonstration of the great vitality of the contemporary Cuban film industry.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: 12 New York School Projects Cut, But $90 Million Saving Evaporates
description: Twelve school construction projects were abruptly suspended in 1975 on the recommendation of the Emergency Financial Control Board to produce a projected net cash savings for New York City of $90 million.

title: Official Hints South Korea Might Build Atom Bomb
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 30Foreign Minister Park Tong Jin has hinted that South Korea could develop nuclear weapons if the country's security was severely threatened.

title: SOVIET CAN'T AVOID DROP IN OIL OUTPUT, C.I.A. SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI)  The Soviet. Union will be unable to prevent downturn in domestic oil production that will start soon, according to a declassified Central Intelligency Agency report.

title: Retail Store Sales Rise 14%
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales last week were about $14.33 billion, up 14 percent from the yearearlier level of $12.55 billion. Department store sales were an estimated $1.37 billion, up 15 percent from last year's $1.19 billion.

title: Smiling Gerulaitis Looks Past Loss
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 30Already the owner of two RollsRoyces, a Mercedes and a Porsche, Vitas Gerulaitis has his sights set on yet another car from another country.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline on a story in The Times yesterday about fraud in a summer program to feed needy children said erroneously that the project involved school lunches. The New York City Board of Education was not involved in the projects under investigation.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Ballet: Marcia Haydee's Juliet
description: THE SWIFTNESS with which the late John Cranko made his ballets sweep forward was perhaps the special lift he brought to a full evening of narrative ballet. Even when working with a story like Romeo and Juliet, which is so intimately tied to its musical program, he found ways to leave his personal mark on the production.

title: Advertising
description: Foote, Cone & Belding, aware of the growing shortage of young creative people, has taken the unusual step of establishing a structured, eightweek course to train them.

title: C. R. HULSART TO RETIRE FROM TIMES FOUNDATION
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president of The New York Times Company, announced yesterday that C. Raymond Hulsart, president of the New York Times Foundation since 1974, would retire on July 31 at the mandatory age of 65.

title: Parents, Give Up Battle With Church Over Custody
description: FORT SMITH, Ark., June 30 (AP)The parents of four young members of a religious group say they will return to their homes in California and New York and abandon efforts to gain custody of their children.

title: Band Concerts at Jay Gould's Place
description: One of the handsomest and most inviting spots on the banks of the Hudson River in this area is Lyndhurst, the former Jay Gould estate in Tarrytown, where a summer music season starts tomorrow. A Gothic Revival mansion that dates back to 1838 is the focal point of the estate, which is now owned and administered by the National Trust for Historic Preservation, but the lawns and gardens of Lyndhurst's more than 60 acres are magnificent and have special appeal in summer. They are particularly beautiful in early evening when the sun is setting across the river and the heat of the day has begun to wane

title: Companies Affected By Decision on B1
description: Among the companies most affected by President Carter's decision to scrap the B1 bomber construction program, aside from Rockwell International and its Collins Radio subsidiary, which would have built tape recorders and radios for the aircraft, were the following, according to United Press International:

title: Security Council Appeals for Help For Mozambique
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.,June 30The Security Council decided unanimously today to ask member countries of the United Nations to give material assistance to Mozambique to help it defend itself against border attacks by forces 'f Rhodesia's whiteminority Government.

title: People and Business
description: Frank E. Barnett will retire Aug. as chairman and chief executive officer of the Union Pacific Corporation. Mr. Barnett, who will be 65 years of age on July 14, joined the railroad in 1951 as Eastern general counsel. He was elected a director in 1953 and became a vice president in 1955. Before becoming chairman in 1969, he was chief executive officer and chairman of the executive committee.

title: At the Movies
description: GENE SAKS is a prosperous, rapturously respected director, the recipient of a Tony for his staging of the musical I Love My Wife and a man who truly loves his offstage wife, Beatrice Arthur. Success, of course, is nothing new to him; he's tie whiz who whipped Same Time, Next Year and California Suite into diamondsmooth shape, thereby assuring them long runs on Broadway.

title: Sunfish Skipper Tells of Voyage 1,700 Miles Along the East Coast
description: James Lee MeadowsCaptain Meadows says the black lettering across the back of his pale yellow Tshirtclimbed out of the well of his tiny boat yesterday, and talked about sailing his 13foot10inch vessel 1,700 miles up the Eastern Seaboard from Florida.

title: About Real Estate
description: The green light of tax exemption flashed for CBS Inc., for Barclays Bank, for a Staten Island beer distributorship and for Kit Tzing Lee Kuan the other day.

title: Bad Language
description: Shocking reports of the exploitation of young children by pornographic moviemakers and publishers inspired the New York Legislature to ban the use of children in explicitly sexual films and books. It is a necessary and widely supported measure. Unfortunately, its overly broad language would tend to discourage the publication and distribution of reputable works.

title: How to Get There
description: By car, Goshen is best reached by taking the George Washington Bridge to the Palisades Interstate Parkway. Follow the parkway to Route 6 near Bear Mountain, and take Route 6 west to Route 17 (the Quickway). Exit at highway 207 for Goshen. An alternate way is by the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, until it runs into the Quickway at Harriman, N. Y.

title: Rockets Red Glare Tops It All Off
description: The spectacular finale to this year's Harbor 77 and Fourth of July in Old New York festivals will be a giant fireworks displaycourtesy of Macy'sthat will light up the western sky from 85th Street to 105th Street along the Hudson River.

title: Consumers Seek $1 Billion In Post Cereals Lawsuit
description: LOS ANGELES, June 30. (AP)A coal?tion of parents, minority groups and consumer organizations sued the General Foods Corporation for $1 billion today. contending that its Post Cereals division exploits trusting children in order to sell sugar concoctions as nutritious breakfast cereals

title: No More Oil Rises in 1977, Venezuelan Says
description: The oil pricing split within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been settled with agreement that there will be no further price rises this year, Venezuela's President Carlos Andres Perez said yesterday.

title: Art People
description: IN A MOVE to attract Arab petrodollars, the highpowered art firm of Knoedler's will combine forces with the Swiss art investment ?und, Modarco. The merger will put Modarco's $20.5million art inventory, bought strictly for investment, under joint management, creating combined assets of $40million, according to Dr. Armand Hammer, the West Coast oil magnate (Occidental Petroleum) who controls the 130year old gallery.

title: GASMAY BE RATIONED IN CONTINGENCY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON. June 30The Carter Administration is developing a contingency energy conservation program, including such mandatory provisions as gasoline rationing, import quotas and forced closings of service stations, Administration officials said today.

title: 47 Miss Universe Candidates Enchant City Hal?
Judge Voids Indictment of Groh; Sets Strict Rules for Any New One
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens yesterday threw out a bribery and grandjury indictment against Judge Robert T. Groh of Civil Court and required the special state anticorruption prosecutor to follow strict conditions in seeking a new indictment.

title: Among Cambodian Refugees, an Air of Resignation
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 30After more than two years in a refugee camp at Aranyaprathet, on the Cambodian border, where more than 4,000 Cambodians live, an elderly carpenter and his wife spoke with the resignation that distinguished the millions of displaced persons in Indochina during three decades of war.

title: SEAT0,23YEARS OLD, PULLSDOWNITS FLAGS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 30The Southeast Asia Treaty; Organization, one of the last vestiges of the cold war in Asia, dissolved itself today. There was only a brief flash as the colors of the remaining member countries were lowered at dusk to mark its end, as contrasted with the enthusiasm amid which it was born nearly 23 years ago as a bulwark against the further spread of Communism in Asia.

title: Rains in Midwest Depress Prices of Soybean Futures
description: CHICAGO, June 30 (AP)Soybean, soybean meal and oil futures posted sharp declines on the Chicago Board of Trade today under heavy selling pressure that was set off by widespread and abundant rains over the Middle West.

title: Soviet Confirms Soundings by U.S.
description: MOSCOW, June 30The Soviet Union, in a terse announcement, said today that the United States had proposed a meeting between Leonid I. Brezhnev and President Carter and there had been preliminary discussion about the matter.

title: Rock: Stevie Nicks Sparks Fleetwood Mac
description: FLEETWOOD MAC's debut Wednesday night at Madison Square Gardenthe first of two performances therewas a confirmation of its newly won status as this country's most popular and best poprock bandexcept for, maybe the Eagles. And by and large it was a superior show to the group's outing earlier this year at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. With one crucial exception.

title: Carter in the Role of Manager
description: WASHINGTON. June 30President Carter's'decision not to build an expensive fleet of B1 bombers shows vividly that he is a pragmatist not bound by ideology and an atypical politician who seems to prefer the role of manager

title: Dissident Priests Say Mass as Vatican Showdown Looms
description: ECONE, Switzerland, June 30The 14 priests ordained in a controversial ceremony yesterday at this center of Roman Catholic conservatism offered their first masses today.

title: Silver Futures Prices Slip
description: Silver futures closed down 4.50 to 4.80 cents an ounce on an estimated volume of 11,500 contracts. Traders cited market pressure as a result of of nervous moves in the copper market based on the outcome of labormanagement negotiations.

title: Swiss, With Regret, Say They're Not Joining U.N.
description: GENEVA, June 30Switzerland is not applying for membership in the United Nations at this time because most Swiss would not endorse the move, the Government said in a statement today

title: Leader of I.R.A. Group Sentenced To 30 Years for London Bombings
description: LONDON, June 30 (Reuters)The leader of an Irish Republican Army group that planted nine bombs in central London was was sentenced today to 30 years in prison.

title: Carter s Decision on Bomber jars Rockwell and Its Workers
description: LOS ANGELES, June 30In the insecure world of the aerospace industry,.some had feared the worst. But, today's decision by President Carter against production of the B1 bomber nevertheless hit workers at the Rockwell International Corporation plant here like a shell burst.

description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 30 (AP). The Rumanian Communist Party's Central Committee announced today that it had decided to shift from government censorship to selfcensorship of the nation's media.

title: Publicizing Fees
description: The Supreme Court's decision to ??ft the ban on the advertising of fees by lawyers was a major victory for consumers. It should lower the cost of some routine legal services. It may also lead to similar costcutting advertising in other professions.

description: The Palace Hotel, which was the ChalfonteHaddon Hall Hotel until a few weeks ago, changed names again, this, time to the Resorts International Hotel.

description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, founded by Ted Shawn, opens its 45th summer season tomorrow in Lee. Mass., with a previously unscheduled gala benefit that seeks out the roots of American dance.

title: Silkie Reaches Bermuda First
description: ST DAVID'S, Bermuda,June 30, (AP) H. D. Marcus of Needham, Mass., sailed his 41foot sloop, Silkie, to firstto finish honors today in the Blue Water cruising race from Marion, Mass., to Bermuda.

title: Kimombwa Wins 10,000 In 27:30.47, World Mark
description: HELSINKI, Finland, June 30(AP)Samson Kimombwa of Kenya set a world record in the 10,000meter run today with a clocking of 27 minutes 30.47 seconds.

description: WinniethePooh went round to his friend Christopher Robin, who lived behind a green door in another part of the forest.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation announced consummation of the sale of the Peabody Coal Company for $1.2 billion face amount of cash and securities, thus completing the largest Governmentordered divestiture in history. All shares of Peabody were sold to a new company, the Peabody Holding Company, which is made up of the Newmont Mining Corporation (27.5 percent), the Williams Companies (27.5 percent), the Bechtel Corporation (15 percent), the Boeing Company (15 percent), the Fluor Corporation (10 percent) and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States (5 percent).

title: Harbor Festival 77 Hoists Sail
description: Just because it won't compare with last year's extravaganza doesn't mean you won't have fun at the waterfront this weekend at the New York Harbor Festival 77. After all, when was the last time you saw half a dozen ocean liners parade down the Hudson River? Or a stately procession of nearly 100 notsotall, but nonetheless eyefilling, sloops, squareriggers, schooners, yawls and even a Chinese junk? Or 200 small sailboats racing around the lower Hudson in an event wags have dubbed Op Dunk?

title: Lincoln Hosts Power Lifters
description: LINCOLN, Neb., June 30 (AP)The 1977 Amateur Athletic Union junior national powerlifting championships will be conducted in Lincoln this Saturday and Sunday. Over 130 lifters from 32 states are entered.

title: 2,400Page Report to Congress Ends Bicentennial
description: WASHINGTON, June 30'4;America's Bicentennial ended today after 200 years of history, eight years of planning, one day of partying, a year of cleanup and 38 minutes of waiting for some of its chief backers to attend its wake.

description: They give you your lines, they give you clean clothes, they give you a place to work in and people to work with. All you have to do is pretend you don't see the camera, make that leap of faith. It's not so awfully hard to act in this particular movie.

description: PARIS, June 30(AP)Oun Sananikone, former president of the Laotian National Assembly and member of the original antiFrench rebel movement, died Monday of liver and kidney problems at his home outside Paris. He was 70.

title: Unpaid RealEstate Taxes Decline
description: For the first time in the last five years, there has been a decline in uncollected realestate taxes in New York City, Finance Commissioner Harry S. Tishelman reported yesterday.

title: Since 1942, WNYC Has Been Fighting To Reach the City
description: Because it broadcasts with low power, New York City's radio station WNYCAM cannot be heard in half of the city at night. In most of the Bronx, parts of Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan and all of Staten Island, interested citizens hear nothing but static when they try to tune in on WNYC's programs of consumer advice, health and nutrition, city services for the aged and many important city, state and Federal meetings, as well as United Nations sessions.

title: Thailand Finds Indochinese Refugees a Growing Problem
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 30More than 80,000 Indochinese refugees are killing time in camps throughout Thailand waiting for other countries to open their doors to them or Thailand to resettle them in this country. More arrive from Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam every day than leave for new homes.

title: College Baseball to Mark Its 118th Anniversary
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 30 (UPI)College baseball will mark its 118th anniversary tomorrow, but participants in the first game would have difficulty recognizing the game they founded.

title: Kenyan, at O.A.U. Talks, Charges Somali Invasion
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon. June 30 The Foreign Minister of Kenya today surprised the meeting of the Organization of African Unity here by reporting that his country had been invaded by thousands of armed men from Somalia.

title: Academic Intelligence
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has always found college teachers a valuable resource. Some are specialists in areas that touch on the national security. Some have contacts in other countries from whom they pick up interesting tidbits of information. Some are willing to recruit for the C.I.A. in their classrooms. The agency has for years maintained relations with academics on more than 100 campuses. But professors have periodically been embarrassed by revelations of their extracurricular activities, and critics have wondered about the subverting effects of a teacher's covert connection to the C.I.A.

title: Weekend TV: Busy Days in Fernwood
description: THE FOURTH OF JULY begins on television with an ending. The 325th and final episode of Mary Hartman. Mary Hartman will be shown on WNEW/Channel 5 at 11 P.M. Television's most spacedout characters are winding up their offthewall escapades in typical Fernwood fashion.

title: Dow Up 2.97;Rockwell's Issues Tumble on B1 News
description: The stock market shrugged off President Carter's surprise decision yesterday to end the B1 bomber production programan announcement that sent the shares of the plane's prime contractor. Rockwell International, down by more than 4 pointsto post its first advance of a drab week.

title: Assembly Increases 1977 Budget And Governor Signs the 1978 One
description: TRENTON, June 30The State Assembly increased today the 1977 state budget by almost $55 million while Governor Byrne signed into law the $4 billion state budget for 1978.

description: It may be a bit smaller in scale than last year's multilayer Bicentennial bash, but the city's Fourth of July in Old New York festivities, which will cap the threeday Harbor Festival 17, will easily be as enthusiastic.

title: U.S. ORDERS AIR BAGS OR AUTOMATIC BELTS FOR ALL 1984 AUTOS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Transportation Secretary Brock Adams issued an order today requiring that air bags or automatic lap and shoulder restraints be installed in all standard and luxury automobiles by the 1982 model year and in all smaller cars by the 1984 model year.

title: STOLEN SECURITIES CAUSE ARREST OF 5
description: Five members of a Mafiacontrolled ring that allegedly offered an undercover agent a shopping list of stolen securities worth $2 million were arrested this week as a sample sale was about to be consummated. They were charged with possession of stolen property.

description: A new trend among large companies is coordination of the distribution process under one executive. Such coordination has brought significant savings, according to an official of large management consulting firm. Page D5.

title: INDIA'S KASHMIR AREA HAS HEATED ELECTION
description: SPINAGAR, Kashmir, June 30A hotly contested election, something new for Kashmir, began today in this Indiancontrolled part of the Himalayan state.

title: Village Voice Employees Vote To Join a Local of District 65
description: Employees at The Village Voice voted yesterday to be represented by a union, for the first time in the paper's history. By a vote of 86 to 21, they voted to join the publishing local of District 65 of The Distributive Workers of America.

title: Auto Industry Expresses Reluctance, Resignation Over Air Bag Mandate
description: DETROIT, June 30The automobile industry today expressed attitudes ranging from resignation to skepticism to condemnation in the wake of the Federal Government's decision to require air bags or automatic seat belts in all passenger cars.

title: Eurocommunism : Watch but Don't Touch
description: Why is Santiago Carrillo, the leader of Spain's Comnunist Party, now at the head of the Kremlin's list of public enemies? Not because he refuses to carry out ?ome secret set of Soviet instructions. Not because he is complicating the Soviet Union's new relations with ?emocratic Spain. Not even because he is a Spaniard before he is a Communist. Rather, it is because, even more than his Italian and French comrades, who may attain executive powers next year, Mr. Carrillo holds Communism to be compatible with constitutional de?ocracy, That means he believes there is a higher law han the will of any Communist party, even in a Comnunist country. And if there are human and political fights that do not derive from a Communist party, then he totalitarian regimes of the Soviet Union and most ?f Eastern Europe are illegitimate. Eurocommunism, rom Madrid to Moscow, is the greatest heresy in Soviet loctrine and Mr. Carrillo is its newest champion.

title: Mrs. Paul's Kitchens Dividing Ad Duties
description: Mrs. Paul's Kitchens, Philadelphia, after a long but tireless search, has decided to split the advertising responsibility for its product lines between Compton Advertising and Isidore, Lefkowitz, Elgort. The company spent about $4.5 million in measured media last year.

title: Lawrence L. Halpern Weds Helene Lerner
description: Helene Dee Lerner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max K. Lerner of New York, was married at the Engineers Country. Club in Roslyn Harbor, L.I., yesterday to Lawrence Lee Halpern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Halpern of Great Neck. L.I.

title: Diamond Internatioal
description: The Diamond International Corporation, makers of packaging for consumer products, lumber and building materials, reported yesterday a decline of 6.3 percent for June quarter earnings and 16.3 percent for the first half of this year, despite increased sales.

title: COMPANY TC CLEAN UP UPSTATE POLLUTANTS
description: ALBANY, June 30Under its policy of getting polluters to clean up rather than just pay fines, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation said today that it had reached an agreement with an upstate fertilizer company to pump millions of gallons of ammoniacontaminated water from the ground around its Olean plant.

title: Drafter of Pension Items in Albany Included a Big Increase for Himself
description: ALBANY, June 30The counsel to the Assembly's Democratic majority, apparently with the knowledge of legislative leaders, included a substantial increase in his own pension in legislation that was supposed to finance the state's labor settlement with 150,000 public employees.

title: F.B.I. IN FLORIDA SEEKING GIRL ABDUCTED FROM CAMP
description: SARASOTA, Fla., June 30 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation formally entered today the search for Charlotte Grosse, who, was abducted from a Girl Scout camp and then allowed to call home to say she was about to be freed.

title: Stage: The Life of Plays
description: IT IS GENERALLY understood that July and August are the months when nothing happens on the New York stage. That is only partly true. There are no major openings, and when something closes, it does so as quietly as possible. But there is more to the biography of a play than its birth and death.

title: Talks on Southern Lebanon Urged
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30President EIias Sarkis was reported today to have proposed an emergency conference of major Arab leaders to discuss the fighting in southern Lebanon, near the Israeli border, that has forced tens of thousands of residents to flee.

title: Pace, Straub Gain Final Of Westchester P.G.A.
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 30Roy Pace of Wee Burn Country Club, Darien, Conn., and Austin Straub, assistant pro at Ridgeway C.C., White Plains, won two matches each today and will meet for the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship tomorrow. The 18hole final will be over the 6,530yard, par71 Elmwood C.C. course.

title: Egypt's Approach To Peace
description: Now that a new Government presided over by Mr. Menahem Begin is installed in Israel, it would be useful to reiterate the position of Egypt regarding a peaceful settlement of the Middle East problem.

title: Suburbs Celebrate With a Full Schedule
description: For those who hanker after a glorious Fourth of July in the old style, many small towns, villages and communities in the metropolitan area are offering fireworks, picnics, parades and patriotic observances over the weekend.

title: When City Revival Drives Out the Poor
description: The first law of urban dynamics is change, and the first law of change is that what helps some hurts others. The muchhopedfor miracle of revival in older city neighborhoods is having an unanticipated victim: the urban poor.

title: Bridge:
description: The defenders are often at a considerable disadvantage when a player who has made a descriptive opening, such as a weak twobid, becomes the dummy. They will see in the dummy the hand they know about, while the declarer's holding is likely to be shrouded in mystery,

title: L .I . R. R Strike Off; Dispute Is Submitted To Board of Inquiry
description: A strike threatened for tomorrow on the Long Island Rail Road was averted yesterday when most of the line's 17 unions and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority agreed to submit their disputes to a board of inquiry.

title: A Telethon Set as Aid For Pacers
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 30  Julius Erving and George McGinnis of the Philadelphia 76ers were among National Basketball Association players being asked today to join a sports telethon here this weekend for the purpose of keeping the financially ailing Indiana Pacers franchise In Indianapolis.

title: Screen: Old Stories Never Die
description: IT SAYS something about the traditional populism of Hollywood that all of us are inclined to feel a bit uneasy with movies that treat generals as seriously and/or as sentimentally as movies have always treated enlisted men.

title: F.B.I. Computer Project Is Blocked Pending Study By Justice Department
description: WASHINGTON,June 30The Justice Department has revoked an order authorizing the Federal Bureau of Investigation to go ahead with a computer project that had been rejected by the Ford Administration as a threat to individual privacy and civil liberties.

title: Six U.S. Eights Gain in Rowing On the Thames
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, June 30The American crews rowing in this year's Henley Royal Regatta came through today's opening round with flying colors. Six of the United States eight eightoared shells advanced.

title: Saban Has Heart Surgery
description: CLEVELAND, June 30 (UPI)  Lou Saban, recently named football coach at the University of Miami and a former coach of the Buffalo Bills, of the National Football League, successfully underwent a double coronary bypass operation at the Cleveland Clinic today, a clinic spokesman said.

title: New York to Add to Aid for Aged
description: ALBANY, June 30  Recipients of Federal Supplemental Security Income benefits who live in homes for the elderly or other congregate care facilities will receive personalcare allowances as a result of a legislative agreement that will add state funds to the Federal payments.

title: Chile Rejects U.S. Aid In Dispute on Rights
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 30 (UPI)President Augusto Pinochet, declaring that Chileans are not beggars, today rejected $11 million in United States aid that had been tied to Chilean observance of human rights.

title: E.P.A. AIDE BIDS CONGRESS KEEP 83 CLEAN WATER GOAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Carter Administration, rejecting repeated pleas from industry, urged Congress today to keep a 1983 deadline for cleaning up the nation's water supply to the point where it is drinkable, swimmable and fishable.

title: Brazil Opposition Leader Expelled From Congress
description: BRASILIA, Brazil, June 30 (AP)President Ernesto Geisel expelled a leader of Brazil's only legal opposition party from Congress today and stripped him of political rights for 10 years.

title: Iraq and Libya's Plans Unclear
description: Confusing reports continued to circulate in the Middle East yesterday as to the oilpricing intentions of Iraq and Libya. Of the 11 OPEC members that increased their prices by 10 percent last Jan. 1, only Iraq and Libya refused to join in the announcement in Vienna this week of an abandonment of an additional 5 percent price rise scheduled for July 1.

title: CRUISE MISSILE CITED
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  President Carter, in a surprise move, announced today that he was opposed to production of the B1 strategic bomber and said that the United States would depend on existing weapons systems for its nuclear deterrent.

title: .44 Killer's Victims Did Not All Have Long, Dark Hair
description: While investigators into the Son of Sam killings sought clues in every direction, Lieut. James C. Power of the special homicide task force warned yesterday that the gunman had chosen women with a variety of hair colors as victims.

title: Roosevelt

title: Spirit Sails to Victory In OneTon Yacht Race
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 30(AP)Louis A. Pocharski of Marblehead, Mass., skippered his OneTon racer, Spirit, to first place today in the third race of the Sail Cup series at the Ika Lewis Yacht Club. Jonathan Livingston Seagull, with Al Brainard and Carl Ament of Rye, N.Y., sharing the helm, was second. Harry Macklowe of New York City took third aboard Unfurled.

title: Anglers Are Biting Nails Round Montauk and Sound
description: There have been scores of frustrated saltwater anglers in Montauk and Long Island Sound in recent weeks, particularly on the Western end along the Connecticut shore, for good catches of bluefish, striped bass, weakfish and fluke have been rare.

title: Troy Concedes a Point at His Trial
description: Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. conceded from the witness stand at his perjury trial yesterday that he had signed documents listing himself as a partner in a law firm and that a reasonable person, having listened to the evidence and examined the documents, might conclude that he had represented himself as a partner.

title: MAY INVENTORIES UP 1.2% IN BIGGEST RISE SINCE DECEMBER 74
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPDInventories, rose by 1.2 percent in May for the biggest increase in more than two years and a signal of a potential sales explosion that could fuel. economic growth, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A Miss Universe Day Beguiles City Hall
description: For those who missed it, Wednesday was Miss Universe Day in New York City. Mayor Beame made it so, with an official proclamation and some goodnatured remarks, as he stood on the steps of City Hall surrounded by 47 of this year's contestants.

title: Tennis
description: MEN'S DOUBLES

title: Radio
description: 7:309 A.M., WNYCFM. Two Scenes from Die Meistersinger, Wagner; Harpsichord Concerto in G minor Vivaldi; Harpsichord Suite in F, Couperin; Orchestral Quartet in A. Stamitz; Sonata for Flute and Piano, Reif.

title: Rescuing the Region
description: WASHINGTONThere has been an increasing national awareness of regionalism  particularly as it has emerged in the socalled sunbeltsnowbelt controversy. As cochairmen of the largest regional group in Congress  the? NortheastMidwest Economic Advancement Coalitionwe are concerned about the direction and effect of that discussion. Unfortunately, Many of the coalition's recent actions have been interpreted by much of the press, and therefore perceived by the public, as a renewed War Between the States. Such attitudes can only be counterproductive and must be dispelled.

title: ESTHER HAAR
description: Dr. Esther Haar, a psychiatrist who was in private practice and an assistant professor in psychiatry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died Tuesday at the North Shore Hospital. Her age was 53.

title: Restaurants
description: HOW MUCH TIME does a restaurateur need to get a new establishment in shape? How long should it take for him to offer delicious, attractively presented food served by an efficient and friendly staff? Some restaurant owners insist six months is a minimum shakedown period. A few believe they should not be fair game for a year. Most would hope for a three months lapse before reviewers come in. Meanwhile the public pays full prices while the restaurant owner learns how it should be done. No wonder then that the average customer thinks everyone should be playing for keeps from the moment the doors open, allowing perhaps only for a few rough spots to be worked out in a week or two. Anyone who doubts that a new restaurant can be whipped into shape so quickly should go to the Rive Gauche on 58th Street between Second and Third Avenues, and learn how it can be done. Opened barely five weeks ago, this trim, chic dining spot, with its restful rosecolor walls, sparkling Art Deco lighting fixtures and slatebrown upholstered banquettes, exudes the obvious professionalism of the staff and management behind it. Right from the start, you know you are in good hands.

title: Driessen Gets 4 R.B.I.'s As Reds Top Giants, 115
description: For most of his major league career in Cincinnati, Dan Driessen had been one of the young hopefuls of the Reds president, Bob Howsam. He had all the ingredientsagility, speed.on the bases and batting power at the plate.

title: Red Smith
description: J. Walter Kennedy may not have been the only sports columnist ever elected mayor of anywhere but he probably was the only mayor who continued to write a sports column while managing the affairs of a thriving city. Even after he resigned as the chief executive of Stamford, Conn., to become commissioner of the National Basketball Association, he continued his regular commentary on the sports scene, and the Stamford Advocate continued to publish his views in a department captioned Splinters. This made him

title: Security Council Appeals for Help For Mozambique
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30The Security Council decided unanimously today to ask member countries of the United Nations to give material assistance to Mozambique to help it delend itself against border attacks by forces of Rhodesia's whiteminority Government.

title: Senate Compromises With Carter on Killing Da
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Senate apparently decided today that President Carter had it over a pork barrel and voted to compromise with him and kill nine of the 18 major water projects he wants eliminated.

description: THE OTHER FRANCISCO, directed by Sergio Giral; screenplay (English subtitles) by Mr. (Giral, based on the novel Francisco, by Anselmo Romero; director of photography, Livio Delgado; editor, Nelson Rodriguez; music, Leo Brouwer; produced by the Instituto Cubans del Arte e Industria Cinematograficos (the Cuban Film Istitute); distributed by Tricontinental Film Center. Running time: 100 minutes. At the Jean Renoir Cinema, 100 Seventh Avenue. This film has not been rated.
