description: Theater

title: Rangers Sign De Blois and 4 Other Draftees
description: The World Hockey Association may soon merge with the National Hockey League, but the bidding war for draft choices goes on. John Ferguson, the general manager of the New York Rangers, played his part this week in the international intrigue of secret offers, late night phone calls and quick plane trips. Yesterday he displayed the spoilsfive young Canadian hockey players whom the Rangers have signed to contracts for this coming season.

title: Common Market Leaders End London Meeting
description: LONDON, June 30 (UPI)European Common Market leaders ended a meeting here today with an expression of concern over crises in Africa and the Middle East and with a pledge to keep fighting unemplovment and inflation.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: NOT LONG AGO the Pulitzerprize winning playwright Frank Gilroy wrote in an essay on Goshen, N.Y., I glimpse an America I read about but never really thought existed. It's almost too pretty, too ideal. And of the horse racing fever that grips. Goshen, the birthplace of trotting, this holiday weekend and all next week, Mr. Gilroy said: I'm fascinated by the colors, the earnest huddles; those grim, weathered faces...

title: B1 Decision Seen as a Basic Shift in Strategic Doctrine
description: President Carter's decision not to proceed with production of the B1 bomber represents a basic shift in the United States strategic doctrine, built around threepart concept that has prevailed for the past 15 years.

title: HOUSE PANEL ADOPTS REVISED ENERGY BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 30(UPI)The House Ways and Means Committee completed action today on President Carter's energy tax package, approving a bill projected to save less energy than Mr. Carter had asked but not the drastically reduced program that some had feared.

title: Carey Asks That Police And News Organizations Not Use the Term Mafia
description: Governor Carey, acting on a request from the Order of the Sons of Italy in Queens, yesterday called upon news organizations and members of the criminaljustice system in New York State to refrain from using the term Mafia.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: I have a brief statement to make before we begin the questions.

title: Rive Gauche
description: 237 East 58th Street, 7522113.

title: A Top Commander, Punished in the Fall, Among 196 Policemen to Get Promotions
description: A police commander who was disciplined last fall for reportedly ignoring orders to arrest offduty police officers who were noisily demonstrating outside Gracie Mansion will be promoted today to post of chief of organized crime control.

title: CRUISE MISSILE CITED
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  President Carter, in a surprise move, announced today that he was opposed to production of the B1 strategic bomber and said that the United States would depend on existing weapons systems for its nuclear deterrent.

title: London's Beaverbrook Papers Sold
description: LONDON, June 30The three Beaverbrook newspapers in London, The Daily Express, The Sunday Express and The Evening Standard, were taken over today by Trafalgar House Investments, the owner of the Cunard Line, London's Ritz Hotel and other interests.

title: GENERAL MILLS NET UP 43% IN QUARTER
description: General Mills Inc. reported yesterday earnings gains for the final quarter and fiscal year ended May 29 in each of its major business areas led by nonfood items, particularly worldwide craft, game and toy operations. Foods and specialty chemicals had excellent sales gains, yesterday's report said, noting that more than threefourths of the gain came from volume increases, rather than inflation.

title: Tennis
description: MEN'S DOUBLES

title: Sale of Robert Hall's Inventory To Be Handled by Independent
description: United Merchants and Manufacturers said yesterday that the disposition of inventories of the closed Robert Hall clothing chain would be handled by independent professional concerns and would be coupled with the sale of fixed assets and leasehold interests. The announcement was viewed in the retail trade as a further indication that United Merchants has no plans to reopen the stores again as a company operated division.

title: Four Share Lead in Golf With 69's
description: MILWAUKEE, July 1 (AP)Mike Morley, Keith Fergus, Fuzzy Zoeller and Gary McCord, all of whom teed off after morning winds had tapered, forged threeunderpar 69's today and shared the firstround lead in the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JULY 2, 1977

title: U.S. Again Links South Africa Ties To Full Black Role
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Secretary of State Cyrus P. Vance warned South Africa anew today that relations with the United States will inevitably suffer steps are not taken soon to end racial discrimination and allow full political participation by black South Africans.

title: John P. Maguire, Factor, BoughtBy Irving Trust From Provident
description: The Irving Trust Company said yesterday that it had bought John P. Maguire & Company Inc., the New York factoring firm, from the Provident National Corporation.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, July 1,197

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Ethiopia Said to Free American Held a Month on Spying Charge
description: WARWICK, R. I., July 1 (AP)Leslie M. Fox, held in an Ethiopian jail for more than a month on suspicion of spying for the Central Intelligence Agency, was released today, according to the head of Foster Parents Plan International.

title: CORRECTION
description: In yesterday's Weekend section of The Times, a photograph illustrating the Art People column was captioned. Dr. Armand Hammer. Actually, the photograph was that of Peter Blake, architectcritic.

title: Bridge:
description: In the earliest days of the game, Ely Culbertson and his organization propagated a misleading notion concerning biddable suits. To be biddable, a fourcard suit had to be headed by the queenjack or, in a pinch, just the queen. Nowadays serious players have no inhibitions about bidding a suit consisting of four small cards, or even three small cards if the suit is a minor.

title: MAKERS OF U.S. CARS PLAN RECORD 3DPERIOD OUTPUT
description: DETROIT, July 1 (AP)Bolstered by strong spring sales, United States automakers plan to build a record 1.97 million new cars during the third quarter, 14 percent more than a year before, a trade journal reported today.

title: Samuel Schweizer Dies at 74; Swiss International Finance Expert
description: Samuel Schweizer, honorary president of the Swiss Bank Corporation, died June 19 in Basel, Switzerland,of a pulmonary embolism, it was reported here yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: Money
description: Friday, July 1, 1977

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Romeo Fails to Reach Juliet
description: The passion of the starcross'd lovers in Thursday evening's Romeo and Juliet was a little onesided. The Stuttgart Ballet's production, as well as the play it's based on, call for awakened love from both principals, but Birgit Keil found herself in what looked like a onesided affair with Vladimir Klos as Romeo.

title: Beaches Remain Banned
description: Public use of three beaches near the mouth of Kettle Creek continued to be prohibited because of high levels of sewage in the water, Brick Township health officials reported. The beaches, one at Cherry Quay and two at Shore Acres, are near the mouth of the creek, a tributary of Barnegat Bay. Township health officials said they were trying to determine the source of the sewage, which was more than four times above the danger point. The sawage was first noticed Thursday.

title: Harbor Festival Tug Pilot Loves His Craft
description: Grover A. Sanschagrin has a busy afternoon in store for him today. When six ocean liners parade majestically down the Hudson this afternoon, signaling the start of a threeday maritime Fourth of July celebration, the man on that spot will be that 57yearold commuter from Locust Valley, L.I., who likes to make furniture and worries about the algae in his swimming pool.

title: Korea: To Stay or Not to Stay
description: The unconditional withdrawal of the American Second Division from South Korea is ill advised for several reasons. First, it will weaken the deterrent against North Korean aggression. The North Korean border is an hour and a half jeep ride from Seoul; a massed armor attack by the North Koreans at night could have a good chance of reaching Seoul by dawn, even against American air opposition. The North Koreans are now deterred from such a gamble by the automatic involvement of American troops, who must be overcome before they get to Seoul.

title: Schedule of Festival Events
description: Beginning at 4:15 P.M. today the first of six ocean liners, the Olympic, will cast off from her West Side pier. She will be followed, in 15minute and 2,000foot intervals, by five other linersthe Doric, Rotterdam, Kazakhstan, Cunard Princess and Statendam. A seventh, the Queen Elizabeth 2, will depart at 6:45 P.M. to sail down the Hudson by herself.

title: 4 Beaches on Fire Island Reopened
description: MINEOLA, L.I.,July 1Four of the five bayside beaches on Fire Island that were closed earlier this week were reopened to swimming today by Suffolk County health officials.

title: Slaying Suspect Held
description: A Bayonne man arrested as a parole violator in New York City was charged with the murder of the 19yearold nephew of the Hoboken Mayor, Steve Cappiello, according to authorities.

title: Majority of Bangor Punta Sought By Canadian Pacific Investments
description: The possible purchase of a majority interest in the bangor punta corporation by canadian pacific investments Ltd, of Montreal is under discussion, the two companies said yesterday.

title: Newark Greets CrossCountry Horseman
description: NEWARK,July 1Billy Marks rode into downtown Newark shortly after noon today and created a traffic jam. He was ending a 6,000mile journey on horseback to dramatize the preblems of pollution, and automobiles were backed up, engines running, as he talked about environmental deterioration throughout the country.

title: Winnebago Earnings Slide 78.8% In Face of Energy Uncertainty
description: Sluggish demand for motor homes, partly because of uncertainty about the Administration's energy program, contributed to a 78.8 percent plunge in net income of Winnebago Industries to $701.4 million, or 3 cents a share, in the third fiscal quarter ended May 28.

title: Personal InvestingThe Only Indexed Mutual Fund
description: The men who manage the nation's mutual funds tend to hunt for sales opportunity in herds. When investors were enthusiastic about high shortterm interest rates, for example, moneymarket funds began to crop up everywhere.

title: Police Taxi Squad
description: Responding to pressure from the taxi drivers union following the murders of two cabbies last weekend, Mayor Beame announced the formation of a special police taxi squad. At a City Hall news conference attended by the leaders of the union, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd declined to specify how the 20 policemen in the new unit would function, but he indicated they might act as decoy drivers or any other presence we used to attack the problem.

title: Coming Down and Going Up In Smoke
description: It is after midnight, the hour of the flying saucer. One is descending on New York. It is shaped like a cigar box. The crew members are unhappy about this. When they reported to the saucerport for this mission they were told that all the latemodel cigarshaped flying saucers were already spaceborne.

title: Moscow Book Fair Poses Quandary For U.S. Houses Over Human Rights
description: The first Moscow International Book Fair, which begins Sept 6, has divided segments of the American book publishing community. Because it is being held in the main arena of disputed literary activity, the fair inevitably is a political happeningfor American and other Western publishers planning to attend, as well as for those who are staying away.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EASY DOES IT Not all New Yorkers require fireworks for a relaxing holiday span, with some leisurely patriotic thoughts as they sample a few Big Apple specialties  museums, parks and cinemas.

title: Senate's Unusual Closed Session Is Worthwhile,Participants Say
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI)  At 10:01 A.M. the tourists, the Press and most of the staff were sent out, the great oak doors were shut, guards were posted and the Senate went into its 76th closed session since 1884this time. to discuss the neutron bomb.

title: Personal Investing
description: While indexingkeying stocks in an investment portfolio to a major averageis the most popular thing in money management, there has been no rush to follow the first indexed mutual fund, which hopes to tap the individual market. Page 25.

title: About New York
description: Peter C. Goldmark Jr. finds that words are not enough, so he puts aside his wine and starts scribbling diagrams about the fiscal crisis on the tavern place mat, the State Budget Director resembling a stricken artist trying to draft out inner abstractions.

title: Golf
description: GREATER MILWAUKEE OPEN

title: Toshiba Introduces New Line of Calculators
description: Just two days after Rockwell International threw in the towel on electronic calculators, Toshiba America came out with 16 desktop and pocket calculators, its broadest line to date. The new line includes seven desktop models and includes a liquid crystal combination calculator and digital watch in a notebook with a suggested price of $49.95. Three other liquid crystal models range in price down to $9.95.

title: The American Army's Social Role
description: MONS, Belgium  United States armed forces have traditionally lagged behind more advanced elements of the social structure they are designed to defend, at least with respect to modernizing and liberalizing that structure as new ideas evolved in the nation itself.

title: BP Oil Supplying Data
description: BP Oil Inc., a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), said that it was responding to a request from the Justice Department antitrust division for information on its plan to buy 66 gasoline stations selling Scotbrand gasoline from a subsidiary of the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company. The stations, owned by the Petroleum Marketing Corporation, are throughout the midAtlantic, BP said.

title: $181.5 Million in World Bank Loans
description: WASHINGTON.July 1(UPI)The World Bank today announced loans totaling $181.5 million for development projects in India, Indonesia and Cameroon. The largest loan was $150 million to help develop India's Bombay High and Bassein oil and gas fields, which should yield up to the equivalent of 13 million tons of oil annually at full production.

title: NEUTRON BOMB FUND DEBATED BY SENATE IN A SECRET SESSION
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The Senate debated today in secret a proposal to develop an arsenal of exotic new weapons more detrimental to humans than to buildings. After nearly three hours, tentatively preserved funds for the plan.

title: CALIFORNIA DOBTFUL OVER SENTENCING LAW
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 A new state sentencing law took effect today with no one quite sure whether it would, as intended, make the criminal justice system here more equitable and more of a deterrent, or whether it would merely confuse those issues.

title: Peterson Plays Swinging Piano
description: Oscar Peterson may be one of the bestknown jazz pianists of the day, but he generally appears as a collaborating artist rather than as a solo performer. Indeed, his Thursday evening. Newport Jazz Festival appearance at Carnegie Hall eventually included duets with Joe Pass and Dizzy Gillespie. But the main interest of the evening centered on his solo playing.

title: NEUTRON BOMB FUND DEBATED BY SENATE IN A SECRET SESSION
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The Senate debated today in secret a proposal to develop an arsenal of exotic new weapons more detrimental to humans than to buildings. After nearly three hours, it tentatively preserved funds for the plan.

title: Brooklyn Family Says Harassment From Neighbors Is Forcing It Out
description: Two or three years ago, Elaine Henderson chided her neighbors in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn for not rallying. to the support of a racially mixed couple in the area whose house had burned down.

title: Ghana's Ruler Gives Plan For Elected Government
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 1 (Reuters)Ghana's military ruler, General Ignatius K. Acheampong, announced plans today to restore an elected government to this western African country.

title: Red Sox Lose 7th In Row, 82
description: The Boston Red Sox, who were bashing home runs out of ball parks early in June, suddenly lost all their power during a sixgame losing streak in New York and Detroit.

title: DealersCroupiers School
description: Atlantic County College in Mays Landing, N.J., set up a gambling school to train dealers and croupiers for Atlantic City's coming casino industry. Noncredit class will not begin until the state establishes its casino gaming regulations, but 600 people have applied since the college hinted last fall that it might offer such courses.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Ethiopia Declares Amnesty For Political Exiles
description: LONDON, July 1 (Reuters)Ethiopia's ruling military council has announced a full general amnesty for supporters of the antiGovernment Ethiopian Democratic Union who have fled to the bush or to the Sudan, the Addis Ababa radio said today.

title: Streaks, Title on Line For Borg and Connors
description: WIMBLEDON, England,July 1 Winning streaks will go on the line tomorrow afternoon when Jimmy Connors and Bjorn Borg, the world's top two tennis players, meet in the men's singles final at the centennial Wimbledon championships.

title: Jews for Jesus Sue to Bar Letter Disseminated by L.I. Church Council
description: Hineni ministries, the national Jews for Jesus organization, filed suit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday to stop the Long Island Council of Churches from disseminating negative information about the evangelical group.

title: Mural at the Harkness To Be Sold in 55 Pieces
description: When the curtain fell on the Harkness Theater two weeks ago, the liquidator brought in to sell its furnishings announced that the company was accepting sealed bids on the enormous and controversial mural that depicts Rebekah Harkness, the theater's former owner, surrounded by nude figures in various balletic poses. The mural, which was painted by the Spanish artist Enrique SenisOlivier, was described by Clive Barnes, dance critic of The New York Times, as one of the nastier things I have seen for a long time when it was unveiled in 1974.

title: Sperry Remington Is Laying Off 140 Workers at Bridgeport Unit
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.,July 1 (AP)Forty salaried employees and 100 hourly workers will be laid off as Sperry Rem ington's consumer product division phases out production of its personalcare items.

title: State Court Says Shavers Isn't Bound to Garden
description: Judge Joseph P. Sullivan of State Supreme Court yesterday vacated a State Athletic Commission ruling that said Madison Square Garden Boxing Inc. had a binding agreement obligating Earnie Shavers to fight Muhammad Ali in the Garden next fall.

title: A Bakery That Gets Them Coming and Going
description: See that man over there? asked Phil Zaro, the proprietor of Zaro's Bread Basket in Grand Central Station, as he pointed to a trim, dapper executive carrying a leather attache case. He shops in here three times a day, every day. I can't understand how he stays so thin.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Two men were arrested yesterday after they rented a couple of horses and, instead of sedately trotting along the bridle paths of Central Park, they continued across the East Side for some wild riding on Ward Island, the police reported.

title: Florida Girl Flees Kidnapper;  Suspect Is Arrested
description: SARASOTA, Fla., July 1 (AP)Charlotte Grosse scrambled through a window to freedom today, 52 hours after she was dragged screaming from a tent at a Girl Scout calm.

title: News  Analysis
description: CAIRO, July 1 Israel's Arab neighbors, grimly convinced that the Government of Premier Menahem Begin will not enter into serious negotiations, are saying more hotly than ever that President Carter has no choice but to exert strong open pressure on Israel. Anything short of decisive American action is likely to lead to a postponement of the Geneva conference and set the region on the road to war again, Arab officials say.

title: Budget Surplus In 1980 Termed Possible by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 The Carter Administration, formally outlining its longterm economic assumptions for the first time, estimated today that its budget could be in a small surplus as early as 1980, with both inflation and unemployment hovering around 5 percent.

title: COPPER STRIKE HITS 7 MAJOR PRODUCERS
description: PHOENIX, July 1 (UPI)Workers went on strike nationwide against seven of the eight major copper producers today, but a new contract offer from the Kennecott Copper Corporation raised hopes for a quick settlement.

title: Jazz Events
description: Following is a schedule of today's Newport Jazz FestivalNew York events:

title: BLACK AIDE CHARGES CARTER WITH RACISM
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  Charging president Carter with racism, a member of the Equal Employment, Opportunity Commission whose term expired last night defied a White House order today to vacate his office immediately.

title: FIRST WOMEN'S BANK GETTING EXPERTS AID ON CREDIT OPERATION
description: The troubled First Women's Bank has been temporarily lent the services of two bankers from larger, more experienced banks. it was announced yesterday.

title: Soybean Acreage Report Leads to Heavy Selling; Futures Down by Limit
description: The latest Department of Agriculture crop acreage report, issued after the close of trading Thursday, apparently caught soybean traders by surprise and they sold heavily yesterday on the. Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Ridgefield, Conn., Group Issues Medal Hailing Benedict Arnold
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn.,July 1  For the first time in many years, there will be no Independence Day celebration in this stately old town, where British troops and local militia fought through the long day of April 27, 1777.

title: Uniroyal Gains Retrial Of Suit by Miss Heldman
description: CLEVELAND, July 1 (UPI)A rearat has been ordered by Cuyahoga County Court of Appeals in a $67,000 jury verdict in favor of Julie Heldman against Uniroyal Inc., of New Jersey.

title: Americans Face Uncertainty at Italian Colleges
description: Tonight, Grace DiGioia, Martin Bergman, Augustine Moscatello and nearly 100 other students are scheduled to board a jetliner at Kennedy International Airport bound for Rome on a flight they all hope will take them a little closer to the fulfillment of their collective dream: to become doctors.

title: Tigers Rozema Tames Yankees With a 6Hitter, 51
Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, July 1,1977 Petition filed by:

title: Jersey Ball Club Likes Proximity to Big League New York
description: JERSEY CITYPuffs of clouds hover over the twin towers of the World Trade Center in New York. The towers, silvery and glistening even at this distance, seem to rise out of the trees lining the Perimeter of Roosevelt Stadium.

description: (Based on 165 at bats.)

title: CORRECTION
description: In yesterday's Weekend section of The Times, a photograph illustrating the Art People column was captioned Dr. Armand Hammer. Actually, the photograph was that of Peter Blake, architectcritic.

title: COLLEGE SETTING UP SCHOOL FOR GAMBLING
description: MAYS LANDING, July 1Atlantic County College established a gambling school today to train dealers and croupiers for Atlantic City casinos.

title: Police in Yonkers To Ask Arbitration On Their Contract
description: YONKERS,July 1 The head of the Yonkers Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, whose 450 members staged sickout two weeks ago, said today that the union would ask that contract negotiations, which had broken off but were resumed as part of the settlement of the job action, go to binding arbitration.

title: Contracts Awarded For Defense Systems
description: The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company has been awarded an initial contract for fullscale development of a Precision LocationStrike System that could eventually be valued at $120 million. The program is an electronic system designed to detect and strike a wide variety of targets in all kinds of weather.

title: Major League Scores
description: ECarbo. DPBaltimore 2, Boston 1. LOBBaltimore 6. Boston 5. 2BPaKel?? Bumbry 38Doyle. HRDempsey (3), DeCinces 2 (9). SBPaKeilv.

title: U.S. AGENCIES FAVOR A PIPELINE TO BRING GAS FROM ALASKA
description: WASHINGTON, July 1A proposed pipeline to carry Alaskan natural gas to the contiguous United. States passed another milestone today as a group of Federal agencies charged with evaluating the three contending proposals submitted their recommendations to the President.

title: Passes for Politicians
description: Nearly 100 of the 700 press cards issued last year by the Town of Hempstead in Nassau County were given to political figures, members of their families and others who were not representatives of news media, the town press secretary, Ralph Aviles, acknowledged.

title: ADM. CHESTER WARD; WARNED OF SOVIET MIGHT
description: HONOLULU, July 1 (UPI)Rear Adm. Chester Ward, retired, an outspoken conservative who frequently warned of growing Soviet military strength, died Wednesday night at a Honolulu hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Los Angeles Mandates Reduced Use of Water
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP)This desert city of three million people, which outstripped its locally available water supply at the turn of the century, began mandatory water restrictions today.

title: Yields Only Six Hits and Retires Last 10 in a Row
description: Unlike Mark Fidrych, Dave Rozema doesn't talk to baseballs and doesn't get on his knees and smooth out the dirt on the pitcher's mound. He doesn't even have a colorful nickname like The Bird. Some people call him Roze (as in rose), but chanting A Roze is a Roze is a Roze doesn't quite create the same excitement as Go, Bird, go.

title: New Line Triples Size of Capital's Subway System
description: WASHINGTON, July 1With a major extension of service today, the capital's smoothrunning but financially and politically troubled subway system is finally getting a chance to show whether rapid rail transit can reshape and help revive the nation's ninth largest metropolis, as planners here have promised. The signs are mixed.

title: Dublin Crew Beats Harvard Heavyweights at Henley
description: HENLEY  ON  THAMES, England, July 1Princess Anne paid a Silver Jubilee visit to the 138th Henley Royal Regatta today, and gave the crowds a chance to cheer as she was borne past the stewards enclosure in the royal barge, rowed by 10 of Queen Elizabeth's scarletclad watermen. To qualify as a waterman, each oarsman had to have won the annual Doggett's Coat and Badge race, which has been staged every year since 1715.

title: Fire Destroys Old Havana Theater
description: HAVANA, July 1 (Reuters)  One of Havana's oldest and largest theaters, the Amadeo Roldan, was destroyed by fire early today. The blaze, which began last night after a dance performance, caused the roof to collapse, but there were no injuries. The Amadeo Roldan, formerly the Pro Arte, was built early in the century.

title: Dollar, Up Abroad, Down Slightly Here; Gold Closes $1 an Ounce Lower in London
description: The dollar was narrowly lower against most other major world currencies in New York foreignexchange trading yesterday. It closed mostly higher abroad in quiet trading.

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: A traffic incident involving a car cutting off another in the Bronx led 15 minutes later to the fatal shooting of one of the drivers a few blocks from his home. The other driver then fled from the scene, East Mosholu Park North and Bainbridge Avenue in the Bedford Park section. The slain motorist was identified as Stephen J. Marinello, 22 years old, of 3318 Steuben Avenue . . . A 34yearold Brookryn pedestrian, the mother of four children, was shot dead during a dispute opposite 450 Pine Street in the New Lots section after leaving a nearby welfare center. She was identified as Alourdes Amy of 155 Wortman Avenue . . . An ongoing dispute between two men who lived in nearby hotels ended with one of them fatally stabbing the other. A suspect, James Harris, 37, of 315 West 99th Street, was arrested. The dead man was Roy Bell, 35, of 305 West 98th Street

title: F.B.I. Finds $1.67 Million Linked to Slain Heiress
description: PHOENIX, July 1 (AP)More than $1.6 million, believed stolen from the Indianapolis home of a slain heiress, has been found buried in the desert 20 miles north of here, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Soviet Looks to U.S. for Methods In Managers Computer Training
description: Moscow's planners, still struggling to computerize the vast Governmentrun Soviet economy, have been looking with unconcealed interest to the United States for a quick way to retrain management personnel in electronic data processing techniques.

title: Dead Menhaden in the Narrows May Drift to New York Beaches
description: EDISON, N.J., July 1 (AP)  Thousands of dead fish were spotted floating near the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge today and an environmentalist here said that some of them might wash up on New York beaches during the Independence Day weekend.

title: Critics Oppose Plan to Merge F.B.I., Drug Agency
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell's plan for a possible reorganization of Federal narcotics agencies has come under increasing attack in recent weeks from critics opposed to any major involvement in drug law enforcement by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: $43 MILLION IN BACK DUES IS PAID BY U.S. TO UNESCO
description: PARIS, July 1 (UPI)The United States has paid its back dues to UNESCO with a check for $43,115,039, the American delegation confirmed today.

title: U.S. Boat Wins Opener
description: STOCKHOLM, July 1 (AP)The first race of the SixMeter Class World Cup sailing event at Marstrand, Sweden, was won today by Razzle Dazzle, skippered by Scott Rohrer of the United States. Six races are scheduled.

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to priceearnings ratio, the number of times the company's latest 12month earnings can be divided Into the stock's closing price. All prices are In dollars. The letter ustands for new annual high and dindicates new low.

title: Arabs Feel U.S. Must Keep Israel on the Road to peace
51 Are in First Class to Graduate From Seminary of the Moon Sect
description: BARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 1The 51 members of the fitst graduating class of the Unification Theological Seminary stepped forward here today, on the campus of a former Roman Catholic high school seminary, as certified leaders of the controversial church of the Rev. Sun Myunz Moon.

title: Books of The Times
description: Richard Wright's hunger was for a life that could be lived with dignity and for a place where people might win some redeeming meaning for their having struggled and suffered here beneath the stars.

title: Quiz Answers

title: Big Burden for Small Business: Government Rules
description: A young clothing manufacturer in Harlem says she paid out $800 for various Government forms during the two brief years her business survived.

title: Burial Site in Doubt For Magda Lupescu
description: LISBON, July 1 (AP)Magda Lupescu, widow of former King Carol of Rumania, may be buried in a commoner's grave, family sources said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: New Line Triples Size of Capital's Subway System
description: WASHINGTON, July IWith a major extension of service today, the capital's smoothrunning but financially and politically troubled subway system is finally getting a chance to show whether rapid rail transit can reshape and help revive the nation's ninth largest metropolis, as planners here have promised. The signs are mixed.

title: 196 Members of the Police Force And a Civilian Promoted by Codd
description: The New York City Police Department promoted 197 men and women at a ceremony yesterday in the auditorium at Police. Headquarters. All were in uniforms, including A. Bernard Kellandbut his was a brown business suit.

title: The Standings
description: Saturday. July 2. 1977

title: PORT UNIT ADVANCES NEXT MEETING DATE
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that its commissioners would meet next Thursday,a week ahead of schedule, and that its courtchallenged ban against the Concorde supersonic jetliner's landings in New York was expected to be on the agenda.

title: Byrne and Bateman Stage Debate, First of Gubernatorial Campaign
description: ATLANTIC CITY,July 1Claques for both candidates kept busy today as Governor Byrne and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman staged the first debate of the 1977 gubernatorial election before the annual convention of the New Jersey Association of Counties. Each had a large number of supporters in the audience of 400, at the Howard Johnson Regency Hotel. Bursts of applause, laughter and cheers punctuated every comment.

title: Israel Repeats Warning on Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 1 (AP)Israel has warned anew it will intervene in southern Lebanon if the Palestinian guerrilla presence there increases, Lebanese Government sources said today.

title: 3d Piggyback Test Set After Repairs on Shuttle
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., July 1 (UPI)One more piggyback flight of the space shuttleorbiter Enterprise aboard a 747 is scheduled for July 28, a National Aeronautics and Space Administration spokesman said today.

title: The Flophouse as Landmark
description: The sheriff of San Francisco recently went to jail for five days for refusing to serve eviction notices on the nonrentpaying tenants of the International Hotel, a flophouse whose owners want to demolish it. When, finally, the sheriff's men did serve the notices, 5,000 protesters crowded the street. The City of San Francisco sought to delay the evictions and demolition by asking, successfully, that the Federal Government declare the building a landmark. It could become an even more notorious landmark if it is permitted to continue decaying around its residents until, all too possibly, it burns down, taking them with it.

title: Track
description: AT SOCHI, U.S.S.R.

title: DEFENSE CHIEF SEES A SAVING OF BILLIONS BY DROPPING THE B1
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Defense Secretary Harold Brown said today that President Carter's decision to halt production of the B1 bomber would save many billions of dollars in the next decade and reduce next year's defense budget.

title: Dogs Are Used to Break up Crowd
description: JOHANNESBURG,July 1 (AP)The police used clubs and dogs to drive off a crowd trying to bring food and clothing to black students held at Johannesburg's central police station, authorities said today.

title: U.S. Again Links South Africa   Ties To Full Black Role
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance warned South Africa anew today that relations with the United States will inevitably suffer if steps are not taken soon to end racial discrimination and allow full political participation by black South Africans.

title: A Sampling Of Adolfo's Versatility
description: You name it, Adolfo's got it. Smock jackets. Short dresses. Sumptuous evening clothes. And, of course, suits in the manner of Chanel.

title: M. W. FODOR IS DEAD AT 87, A FAMED CORRESPONDENT
description: TROSTBERG, West Germany, July 1 (UPI)M. W. Fodor, a wellknown American foreign correspondent of the 1920's to 1940's who specialized in reporting on the Balkans and Central Europe, died Friday at the age of 87.

title: Mercantile Traders Move to Trade Center and a New Place to Shout About
description: Standing behind a green felt table where moments earlier the platinum traders had been shouting and waving like a pack of football fans, Jacob Stern poured champagne yesterday.

title: Construction Outlay Rose by 2% in May
description: The rise compares with a 2 percent gain for April and pushed spending 15 percent ahead of a year earlier.

title: Carey Won't Sign Labor Measure Containing Hidden Pension Items
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that he would not sign the controversial bill that had hidden within it special pension benefits for some government officials and employees.

title: Kirkland Reverses Its Merger Vote
description: The Board of Trustees of Kirkland College, the women's school in Clinton, N.Y., has withdrawn from its agreement to merge with its coordinate institution, the allmale Hamilton College.

title: U.S. Exchanges Diplomats With Cuba on Sept. 1
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters)The exchange of diplomats by the United States and Cuba, after 16 years of hostility and tension, will take place on September 1, the State Department announced today.

title: Bill Rates Up a Bit; Yields Show Rises In Money Market
description: Treasury bill rates rose slightly yesterday in the government's sale of threemonth and sixmonth securities.an auction that took place yesterday instead of on Mondayas usual bacause of the Independence Day holiday.

title: Two Men Arrested For Ride on Wild Side
description: Article

title: Rhodesian Blacks Held in Roundup
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia,July 1 (Reuters) In a series of nationwide raids, Rhodesian policemen have arrested a number of officials of a black nationalist political organization that is linked with guerrillas operating from outside the country.

title: Telephone Voice Track Identifies Speaker
description: Marvin R. Sambur of Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., was granted Patent 4,032,711 this week for a speakerrecognition arrangement. With this device, a telephone caller can be identified from his voice. Unlike other recognition devices, this one does not require speech in a prearranged code, but identifies the speaker by the characteristics of his vocal track, no matter what he says.

title: Ohio Guard Called Out After Tornado Hits Town
description: FREMONT, Ohio, July 1 (AP)National Guardsmen were on duty here today to prevent looting and help supply emergency power after a tornadocarrying storm crossed northern Ohio, injuring 19 people and causing over $1 million damage.

title: Budget Surplus In 1980 Termed Possible by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 The Carter Administration, formally outlining its Iongterm economic assumptions for the first time, estimated today that its budget could be in a small surplus as early as 1980, with both inflation and unemployment hovering around 5 percent.

title: Haughton Bewails Poor Posts for Dexter Cup
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 1In Billy Haughton's vast and busy harness racing establishment, a qualifying horse can get as much attention as a stakes winner such as Green Speed.

title: The Dance: Coals to New London
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 1Britain's London Contemporary Dance Theater made its United States debut last night at the American Dance Festival and roused the audience at Connecticut College's Palmer Auditorium into an exuberant standing ovation.

title: Holiday Death Toll Estimated
description: The National Safety Council estimated yesterday that from 500 to 600 people might lose their lives in traffic accidents during the threeday fourth of July weekend. Last year, there were 497 highway deaths over the weekend, the council reported.

title: 3 Early Goals Foil Cosmos in Vancouver
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, July 1Scoring three goals in the first 17 minutes of play last night the Vancouver Whitecaps defeated the Cosmos, 53, in a North American Soccer League game before 30,277 people, the largest crowd to watch a soccer match in this city.

title: Princeton Tallies Gifts
description: Princeton University's Annual Giving Campaign, which seeks unrestricted funds from alumni for the university's use, closed yesterday with $5,003,629 raised, breaking last year's record of more than $4 million.

title: Tonry Pleads Guilty to Campaign Charges
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 1 (UPI)Richard Tonry, who said he had entered politics because of his disgust with Watergate but resigned from Congress because of allegations of vote, fraud, ?leaded guilty today to charges of campaign finance violations.

title: Straub, 34, Captures Westchester Title, 1 Up
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 1  Austin Straub, assistant at Ridgeway County Club in White Plains, defeated Roy Pace, the head pro at Wee Burn in Darien, Conn., 1 up, today to win. the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship at Elmwood Country Club.

title: 106Bed Park East Hospital Shuts; Code Violations, Money Ills Cited
description: Park East Hospital, a 106bed private hospital on East 83d Street that has been plagued by financial problems and state hospital code violations, closed yesterday. A formal declaration of bankruptcy is expected next week.

Hyland announced.

title: Strike in Britain Sets Off Debate Over Law and Rights of Individuals
description: LONDON, July 1 For the last two weeks British television has been presenting a widely discussed drama of violence on the picket line as an employer refuses to recognize a labor union at his small plant.

description: TRENTON, July 1 (AP)New Jersey was cited as the national leader in traffic safety for 1976, Gov. Byrne announced today.

title: Paul E. Fitzpatrick Is Dead at 79; A New York Democratic Chairman
description: BUFFALO, June 29 (UPI)Paul E. Fitzpatrick, New York State Democratic chairman from 1944 to 1953, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 1Allegations that the South African police use brutality to force statements and confessions from black detainees have surfaced again in a courtroom, this time at a terrorism trial considered by the Government to be one of the most important cases in years.

title: SOVIET SEEMS UNSURE ABOUT CARTER MOVES
description: MOSCOW,July 1 When President Carter conceded recently that he had not anticipated the extent of Moscow's unhappiness with his human rights policy, he identified only part of a problem souring SovietAmerican relations. More than five months after he took office, the signs are that the Russians still do not comprehend the President and their uncertainty has congealed into a sullen truculence that has increasingly left less room for accommodation.

The Federal Trade Commission contended that Safeway's ads for its Skylark diet bread implied that it was less fattening and lower in calories than other bread.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (UPI)Six hundred terrorist bombings caused $3.8 million damage to government offices, businesses and homes nationwide in the first four months of 1977, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said Yesterday.

title: $80,000 Left by Late Bishop Of Diocese in Paterson, N.J.

title: Anne DeRenzo, Teacher, Married to James Graves
description: Anne DeRenzo,a teacher at the village Community School in New York, was married yesterday to James Ashby Graves, a merchandiser with Oxford Industries Inc., manufacturer of women's and men's apparel.

description: The stock market, which typically moves higher in the session preceding Independence Day, broke with a treasured Wall Street tradition yesterday to show a grudging retreat.

title: Knicks Deal Not So Remote as Clyde
description: Quietly, the New York Knicks have had inquiries recently about Walt Frazier from both the Los Angeles Lakers and the Atlanta Hawks. Any trade would hinge on the willingness of another team to assume nearly $1.2 million in salary for the 32yearold guard over the next three National Basketball Association seasons. But in the three months since the takeover of Willis Reed as the Knicks coach, Clyde has been as remote as he was during the season, when he resigned the captaincy, with Earl Monroe succeeding him.

title: The Natural Gas Sweepstakes
description: After a very rough start, President Carter is making some progress in selling an energy plan to Congress. The House Ways and Means Committee has approved a wellhead oil tax to raise the price of fuel to its true replacement cost. And the House Commerce Committee has endorsedby a onevote marginthe Administration's proposed adjustment in the maximum price of newly discovered natural gas.

title: Microsystems Stock Sale
description: American Microsystems said that had completed the previously reported sale of 25 percent of its common stock to the Robert A. Bosch Company of West Germany for $14.2 million. The company said the proceeds would be used to pay debts outstanding of about $11 million. The German company is prohibited from increasing its 25 percent interest unless it is required to do so in order to remain American Microsystem's largest beneficial holder.

title: Safeway Stores to Pay Fine
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)Safeway Stores Inc. has agreed to pay a fine of $120,000 to settle charges of violating a Federal Trade Commission order on advertising diet bread. The commission had charged Safeway, which has its headquarters in Oakland, Calif., with advertising that its Skylark diet bread was less fattening and had fewer calories than other bread. The commission said that the bread was lower in calories than regular bread because it was sliced thinner.

title: French Atom Plant Leaks Toxic Gas
description: PIERRELATTE, France, (AP) July 1A slightly radioactive white cloud temporarily formed over this southeastern French city today after an accident in a big uranium processing plant. Officials said that nine employees who inhaled the gas were put under medical observation.

title: El Salvador Installs Romero as President

title: Stalking the Bostonia Stranglus
description: Three months ago I agreed to look after the apartment of a man who lives in my building while he was out of town on business. Looking after it meant watering the plants, which sounded innocuous enough. He had promised to leave a watering schedule and he had also rambled on a bit about trouble signs and misting and other arcana, but I didn't listen very hard, and, never having been in his apartment, was in no way prepared for what I found when I let myself in the door, squeezed past the large, spiny Anthraxia dementis that took the place of an umbrella stand and surveyed the infestation within.

title: Uganda Lifts Ban Against Britons

McDonald, 55 years old, was indicted on the charge that he murdered his wife in the bedroom of their Middlesex Home.

description: Harold L. McClinton, a retired advertising executive who had continued to be active with the International Executive Service Corps here, died Wednesday in his home, 25 East End Avenue, after short illness. His age was 79.

title: Reprise
description: THE B1 BOMBS  The President's decision to terminate the B1 program is a victory for a sound national defense policy. The B1 was the ultimate expression of the view in the militaryindustrial community that there is no limit to the nation's desire for the best weapons money will buy. But when two cheaper bombers can do more damage than one expensive one, the best weapon is not the best investment. The B1 termination emphasizes similar decisions the President already has made against the nuclear supercarrier and nuclearstrike cruiser in favor of more but smaller ships. How best to spend the nation's defense dollar was the main issue in the B1 controversy and, as we have argued, the combination of modified B52's and standoff bombers carrying cruise missiles is the most effective way.

title: Jazz: Coleman Glances Back, Forges Ahead
description: Ornette Coleman recalled his past, and looked toward his future in his Newport Jazz FestivalNew York concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening. The past was represented by an ensemble of musicians who played with him in the early 60's, when he, spearheaded the greatest challenge to the jazz establishment since Charlie Parker led the way into bebop in the 40's. The future was the debut of Prime Time, with which he is planning to tour.

title: NEW YORK CITY LIKELY TO WIN FEDERAL LOAN
description: The United States Treasury, which has been reviewing volumes of New York City financial material all week, has found no reason to deny the city's request for a loan to meet its cash needs next week, Treasury officials said yesterday.

title: Clarifying Speech for Computers
description: WASHINGTONAn invention patentedthi s week improves the clarity of human speech to computers and other equipment, so that vocal orders can be transmitted accurately to machines.

title: Dr. Luvia M. Willard Dies at 95; Began Queens Practice in 1912
description: Dr. Luvia M. Willard, one of the first women to have practiced as a physician in Queens, died Wednesday in Hollispark Gardens Nursing Home, Hollis, Queens. She was 95 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Margery Ann Tabankin, former president of the National Student Association, has been appointed director of the Volunteers in Service to America (VISTA) program, it was announced yesterday. The 29yearold Miss Tabankin was chosen by Sam Brown, director of ACTION, under which VISTA operates, for the job, which is to run the parent agency's education programs and oversee the work of 3,900 VISTA volunteers in poverty programs. Miss Tabankin, like Mr. Brown a former antiwar activist, is a native of Newark, and a graduate of the University of Wisconsin. She became the first female president of the N. S. A. in 1971.

title: Kennedy Presents His Proposals for Tax Reform
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 In a bid for a leadership role in revision of the tax laws, Senator Edward M. Kennedy issued a 41page, list of tax reform proposals today.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The state police were braced yesterday for the heaviest traffic weekend in New Jersey's history, with more than 3.8 million vehicles on the roads. Officials of the Garden State Parkway expected a record turnout of more than 2.2 million vehicles on the 173mile roadway, while New Jersey Turnpike officials estimated that more than 1.6 million vehicles would use that 142. mile road.

title: Grich Likely Out for Year
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 1 (AP)The California Angels said today that Bobby Grich, one of the free agents the Angels signed last winter, was suffering from a herniated lumbar disk that would require surgery and probably keep him out of baseball the rest of this season.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: CLOSE to 300,000 New Jersey residents could be in for disappointment or downright shock when Congress gets through with the latest version of the Stamp Act the Food Stamp Act, that is.

title: Elizabeth Keyser Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Adamson Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Adamson's daughter, Elizabeth Hambleton Keyser, to John Custis Evans, son of Lucius W. Evans of Lincoln and Marion, Mass., and the late Virginia E. Evans. The future bride is the daughter also of the late R. Brent Keyser of Baltimore. The wedding is planned for July 30.

title: We Should Be in the (Bus) Driver's Seat
description: AT the May meeting of the Westchester County Transit Board, cast the one dissenting vote against the proposed fiveyear contract between the county and the private bus companies.

title: Milltown Parents Find a Son
description: IN JULY 1974, armed with a sterilizer, vaporizer, one case of disposable diapers, four dozen nipples and bottles and anything else that one would need for an infant, Vincent and Dee Sica arrived in Colombia, South America, to pick up their baby.

title: Deaths
description: SAYPOLIrving H. Justice He was that rare person to whom the affairs of his many friends were as Important as his own; on whose ald, counsel &affection They could count In au times of trouble &distress. Few persons have fit that category for us, We will sorely miss him.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY of the houses in this area have cedar shakes or shingles around the outside, and the question of how to finish or coat these wood shingles is often a perplexing problem for the home owner. Should he use a paint or a stain or just a clear preservative? Or can he just leave the shingles untreated, since cedar is widely recommended as a rotresistant wood that really needs no protection?

title: Fashion
description: Fashion

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: MondaySports Car Club of America Kendall Cup national races at Lime Rock (Conn.) Park. Gates open 7 AM.; first of 10 halfhour national championship races at 9 A.M.; Village Sports Car Club race at 12:30 P.M. Information; phone track: (203) 4352572.

title: Beame Puts Off Selection of Convention Center Site Until After Vote
description: In an attempt to defuse a potentially touchyand a potentially damagingcampaign issue, Mayor Beame has decided to put off final selection of a site for the proposed New York City Convention Center until after the primary election in September.

title: Prosecution Nears Conclusion of Case In Trial of Hanafis
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Federal prosecutors are preparing to conclude their case as the trial of 12 Hanafi Moslems in the armed takeover of three buildings and seizure of 149 hostages here in March enters its sixth week. The proceedings are being held under tight security amid ??tense atmosphere marked by clashes between defense counsel and the judge.

title: Washington Gains Final At Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, July 2In glorious weather, record crowds turned out today for the semifinal rounds of the 138th Henley Royal Regatta. Seventysevenyearold Jack Blake, a 1914 Henley town sculling champion who for the 50th year is rowing regatta officials about the course, said, I can't get over today's spectatorsthere are more than I have ever seen.

title: FISHING
description: FISHING along the North Jersey coast hit the skids last week, and that can mean just one thing: it can only improve this week. Theoretically, fluke should be on the upswing because of the warm weather. In reality, fluke fishing in midweek ranged from good in some spots to disastrous in most.

title: Events Today
description: PARADE OF SAIL: Sailboats of many shapes and sizes will sail from the Throgs Neck Bridge around Governors Island and the Battery and up the Hudson to Piers 84 and 86, at 44th and 46th Streets; 10 A.M. start at Throgs Neck, ending about 2:15 P.M.

title: Summer Invades the Islands
description: THE SQUATTERS are returning to their summer camps on Cockenoe Island. On sunny days, noisy motorboats, swift catamarans and sleek sailboats flit around the island, which is shaped like a question mark, sometimes pausing while the weekend sailors take a stroll on the rocky beach or venture an ankle or two into the stillchilly waters of Long Island Sound. At night, fires for cooking and keeping warm dot the island, barely visible from the shore in Westport.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Adventures in a Produce Paradise
description: It's 6:38. We're heading south on the New England Thruway. We're not truckers, vacationers or commuters,We're shoppers. Our destinationHunts Point Market, the Bronx. Our missionto buy groceries for 20 families from Rye who are in the Platt Food Coop, one of at least three in the community.

title: COSTS OF INSURANCE PLAGUES L. L SCHOOLS
description: Responding to taxpayer opposition to everincreasing school taxes, Long Island school boards and administrators have cut costs by such actions as increasing classroom sizes and laying off teachers. Now, however, they face an increasing expense over which they have little controlthe rising cost of insurance.

title: Television This Week; OF SPECIAL INTEREST; Channel Information; TODAYSUNDAY, JULY 3; Morning; Afternoon; Evening; MONDAY, JULY 4; Morning; 12:00(2)The Young and the Restless; 6:00(2,7,41)News (5) My Three Sons; TUESDAY, JULY 5; Morning; Afternoon; Evening; WEDNESDAY, JULY 6; Morning; 12:00(2)The Young and the Restless; 6:00(2,7,41)News (5)My Three Sons; THURSDAY, JULY 7; Morning; Evening; FRIDAY, JULY 8; Morning; 12:00(2)The Young and the Rest; Evening 6:00(2,7,41)News; SATURDAY, JULY 9; Morning; (II); (5)The 5128,000 QuestionM
description: Today

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: IN a few days, 130,000 Long Island households will receive a new kind of mailing from their Congressman. Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of West Islip, is sending his constituents consumer survival kits, a shopping guide for items ranging from cars to pills.

title: Con Ed Refueling Delays Criticized
description: ALBANY,July 1Staff members of the Public Service Commission, in testimony released here this week, charged that unnecessary delays by the Consolidated Edison Company in refueling one of its nuclear plants in Westchester County last year had cost its customers $20.1 million, to about $1.85 each

title: U.S. and Mideast At Odds Over The Negotiables
description: IsraeliUnited States relations have been edgy since the new Government of Prime Minister Menahem Begin was elected last month. Last week, partly as a result of the Carter Administration's own doings, they reached a degree of rancor that led President Carter to call a halt to the public bickering.

title: Detroit Shows Drop in Homicides
description: DETROIT, July 2This city, called Murder Capital, U.S.A., in the urban folklore of the 1970's, may be on the way to its least homicidal year since the decade began.

title: Texas Judge Is Indicted
description: An Associate Justice of the Texas Supreme Court, the state's highest civil tribunal, Donald B. Yarbrough, was indicted last week on charges of perjury and forgery of an automobile title. The charges are only two of a number of legal actions pending against Mr. Yarbrough, who has been accused of a variety of misdeeds since he won the Democratic nomination for the judgeship in May of 1976. A Texas district attorney has charged him with having plotted to murder a former business associate, though there was insufficient evidence to indict him for the crime. Judge Yarbrough was found guilty of fraud in a bank stock transaction last June, and, at the time, there were 15 other Federal and state civil suits pending against him. The State Bar of Texas has filed an 84count disbarment petition against him, and a state panel has convened a hearing whether to him from the bench.

title: Students to Get Grumman Help
description: BETHPAGE

title: Editors Choice
description: AMERICAN HUNGER, by Richard Wright. (Harper Sc Row, $8.95.) The long lost continuation of Black Boy; enormously moving.

title: Best Sellers
description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores throughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

title: Busing, the Principle Problem
description: AMERICANS don't like their cities very much and in fact know very little about theman information gap that includes American Governments, past and present. The people of the cities and their rulers, who include more than just the politicians, share the blame, of course. One might

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: James Doyle was a press secretary for Watergate Special Prosecutors Archibald Cox and Leon Jaworski. His presence at such dramatic moments as the Saturday Night Massacre would have tempted any writer to turn his memories into a book, no matter how many Watergate books had been published.

title: Muncey, Despite Injury, Is Hydroplane Favorite
description: MADISON, Ind., July 3 (AP)Bill Muncey, the defender, will pilot his unbeaten unlimited hydroplane, Atlas Van Lines, with a broken foot in a bid for an unprecedented sixth victory in 'tomorrow's 30th Madison regatta.

title: Weddings
description: ChinitzKutner

title: Rule on Phone Records
description: Telephone companies are no longer required to tell customers when their records of Longdistance calls have been given to the police or prosecutors, New York's highest court has ruled.

title: Art That's All in the Family
description: JERICHO

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY of the houses in this area have cedar shakes or shingles around the outside, and the question of how to finish or coat these wood shingles is often a perplexing problem for the home owner. Should he use a paint or a stain or just a clear preservative? Or can he just leave the shingles untreated, since cedar is widely recommended as a rotresistant wood that really needs no protection?

title: Two Cultures in a Delicate Balance
description: MINEOLA

title: INTERVIEW
description: SIXTEEN years ago, in Manhattan's garment center, there were two detectives who knew each other only casually because they never worked the same shift. Once in a while they would meet at a Christmas party or at the annual picnic.

title: Kilroy, in Kialoa, Leading TransPacific Yacht Race
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2 (AP)John B. Kilroy, in Kialoa. grabbed the early lead today in the 2.225mile Los AngelestoHonolulu transpacific yacht race and led the 66boat fleet to the west end of Catalina Island, the first checkpoint in the race.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: The announcement of the appointment of Richard Bader as executive producer of the American Shakespeare Theater at Stratford recalls the recent correspondence in your pages on that company's failure to open this year.

title: Churches Still Face Uphill Struggle in Northwest, The Most Overtly Secular Section of the Country
description: PORTLAND, Ore.The wave of Blazermania that swept this area last month after the Portland Trail Blazers were crowned professional basketball champions left some preachers a Little envious.

title: Flowers to Grow in the Shade
description: Anybody can grow flowers in the shade with a sense of humus. That is soil enriched with decomposed organic matter peat moss, manure (well rotted), leaves, kitchen garbage such as tea leaves, coffee grounds, table leftovers, egg shells, vegetable peelings and grass cuttings. Humus is marvelous because it lightens the soil and retains water.

title: The Camper as Cook: Sky's the Limit
description: The turtle soup was simmering when the trailer broke loose from its traces and raced downhill. I dived through the screen door without opening it to sling a duffle bag of canned goods under a rear wheel. I squeezed the soup out of the tablecloth and served it with Swedish biscuits and chilled Chablisa memorable feast, and the mosquitoes (no screen) didn't eat much.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: South Street Seaport Theater is doing free lunchtime theater this summer on Pier 15, and the opening program on Tuesday promises good fun. Director Michael Fischetti has chosen the hoary melodrama East Lynne, which was originally a novel by Mrs. Henry Wood. The play will be given in serial form as a live soap opera (Part I on Tuesdays, Part II on Wednesdays, Part III on Thurs0days and Part IV on Fridays, through July 29). East Lynne has as its main characters Lady Isabel Vane, her husband Archibald Carlyle and his childhood sweetheart Barbara, and a villain who shall go nameless. Anyone can guess what could transpire by the lyrics of its theme song. The Years That Pass Away: As long as you are by my side / I'll face whate'er may be / Until in heaven we do abide / For all eternity. (See Theater)

title: Pink Floyd: Dreamy Rock and Nightmare Words
description: Let the Kraftwerks and Tangerine Dreams of this world come and go; there can be little doubt that Pink Floyd is the premier mindblower hypnorock ensemble of our time. The British quartet (occasionally augmented to a quintet or a sextet by extra guitar and saxophone players) opened a fournight run at Madison Square Garden Friday night, and wove a coldly perfect program of multimedia psychedelica.

title: INTERPRETATIONS OF DREAMS
description: Dreams  and what they represent  have puzzled poets, philosophers, scientists and savants for thousands of years.

title: Lantz of Lakers Retires
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 2 (UPI)Stu Lantz, veteran Los Angeles Lakers guard, has retired because of a chronic back problem, the club announced today.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now: James H. Tully Jr., New York State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.

title: EXKOREA AIDE SAYS PARK ENVOY TOLD HIM HE SHOULD BE SILENT
description: WASHINGTON, July 2kim Hyung Wook, the former director of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency who testified here on the Korean scandal, said today that President Park Chung Hee of South Korea sent a Cabinet minister to the United States last month to dissuade him from speaking out

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: OUR county newspaper recently ran a number of feature articles on dynamic, successful women with interesting life styles. These local women are nothing less than awesome in their achievements.

title: Refusing Robbers, Man at Times Sq. Is Stabbed to Death
description: A 23yearold man was stabbed to death early yesterday outside the IND subway station at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue by two men who tried to rob him, the police said. One suspect was arrested.

title: STAMPS
description: In celebration of Independence Day, the United States is paying philatelic tribute to the men and women behind the lines who kept the Continental Army fighting in the field.

title: Chicken Coop to Craft Center
description: COUNTLESS businessmen and women faced with Frus????????ons in corporate existence have wondered if life might not be much more rewarding down on the farm. Robert and Jane Wallace, who put that thought into action, would certainly say it is.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Because we live in a visual age in which almost everyone uses a camera to take pictures on various occasions, it is not surprising that many people at one time or another consider photography as a means of earning a livelihoodor at least as a means of augmenting income. One rewarding and exciting way of doing this is to work trough a photographic picture agency or a photographic stock house. Although different in many respects, these two types of photomarketing outlets also have some things in common.

title: Wimbledon Winners
description: MEN'S SINGLESBjorn Borg, Sweden, defeated Jimmy Connors, United States, 36, 62, 61, 57, 64.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTORS CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeThe Sunshine Boys. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through July 30). $3.90$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: POPE LAUDS REFORMS OF VATICAN COUNCIL
description: ROME, July 2Pope Paul VI today praised the reforms enacted in the early 1960's by the ecumenical council Vatican II, and his remarks were considered an oblique rerly to renewed criticism of the changes by the dissident Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre.

title: Traditional Sports Loyalty Eroding Under Modern Society's Pressures
description: Independence Day 1977, and gone from the New York sporting scene are Tom Seaver in baseball, Julius Erving in basketball and Joe Namath and the entire franchise of the Giants in football.

title: Spain Pledges Autonomy For Catalonia Region
description: MADRID, July 2 (Reuters)The Spanish Government pledged tonight an early return of autonomy to the heavily industrialized region of Catalonia.

title: Speculation in Stocks Increases in Israel Following Election
description: TEL AVIV, July 2 (UPI)Huge amounts of money pumped into the economy by the former Labor Government before the May 17 election are fueling a nationwide surge of speculation in Israel.

title: BROOKLYN DIOCESE ACTS TO REVERSE ITS DEFICITS
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, the largest diocese in the nation, will attempt to reverse several years of serious budget deficits by cutting costs, trimming programs and adopting stern fiscal policies.

title: CANADA IS ASSESSING RIGHT TO INFORMATION
description: OTTAWA, July 2A preliminary Government analysis of legislation to give the public more access to official documents has indicated that Canadians are unlikely to gain anything near the access Americans have under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Nancy McEwen Engaged to David Wax
description: Representative and Mrs. Robert C. McEwen of Ogdensburg, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Nancy Maclntyre McEwen, to David Louis Wax, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Wax of Lake Park, Fla.

title: EENThe Wellspring Of Quality Programming On Public TV
description: Television has never been able to compete with the sun. In the summer months, with their long hours of daylight, viewing levels are always the lowest of the year. This is why the most appealing programs usually have their premieres in the other seasons. But some publicTV stations are determined to make a run on the summer audiences of the commercial networks in hopes of cultivating new viewers. And so two major British seriesShades of Greene and Wodehouse Playhousewill be unveiled this week on WNET and 48 other stations around the country, to be followed in the coming weeks by a scattering of specials from abroad. A few of the stations will also be carrying the zany sixpart British situation comedy, Fawlty Towers.

title: His Business Is Second Nature
description: JOSEPH CAVERLY, the Westchester Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, has a simple but appealing explanation for what he's done all his life: It's the kind of work you'd do if you didn't get paid, he said recently.

title: A NEW VISION OF DREAMS
description: Researchers are probing the physiological basis of dreaming and coming up with important clues to our wellbeing.

title: A CORRECTION
description: In the June 19 Westchester Weekly, Manhattan College was incorrectly included in a list of outofcounty institutions with with offcampus programs in Westchester. Brother J. Stephen Sullivan, Manhattan's president, said the college does not conduct any form of offcampus program in the county.

title: Leslie Rood Fiance Of Roberta A. Cohen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cohen of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Roberta Ann Cohen, to Leslie Macrae Rood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie L. Rood of Atlanta. The wedding is planned for Aug. 27 at the Cohen home.

title: Rehnquist Son Pleads in Car Case
description: MARION, Mass., July 2 (AP)James Rehnquist, the 22yearold son of Supreme Court Justice William H. Rehnquist, pleaded not guilty today to charges of drunken driving and driving to endanger after a car accident in this resort town last night that injured one person slightly. Mr. Rehnquist was released on his own recognizance after spending the night in jail. His trial was set for July 21.

title: Engagements
description: BuffMarkowitz

title: A Jewel of a Festival
description: GRIMM with a grin, Berlioz with birds, Mozart in the rain. All were part of the total landscape last weekend as the 32d Cara moor season opened in Katonah. Caramoor is unquestionably the jewel of outdoor festivals in the area, so it was hardly surprising to find a sizable contingent of Connecticut musiclovers joining their Westchester counterparts to partake of the manifold joys, and occasional grievances, of the first three concerts.

title: GARDENING
description: EXPERIENCED vegetable gardeners in northern New Jersey counties are already preparing to plant late crops. Beginners who didn't get a garden started in the spring may be relieved to know that they have a second chance from now to the middle of July.

title: For Safer Operation of Home Yard Equipment
description: No one will argue with the fact that power mowers, hedge trimmers, grass edgers and other powerdriven yard and garden tools have made life a lot easier for most of today's homeownersbut these worksaving pieces of equipment have also taken their toll in injuriesover 200,000 persons are treated in hospitals each year for injuries caused by yard and garden equipment.

title: Miss Menz, Cole Werble Will Be Wed
description: Katherine Boyd Menz of Hyde Park, N. Y., curator at the National Park Service's RooseveltVanderbilt mansions there, and Cole Palmer Werble of Washington, where he is publisher of FDC Reports Inc., will be married Aug. 20 in Washington.

title: EXSHAPP AIDE IS ORDERED TO COURT FOR ARRAIGNING
description: SCRANTON, Pa.,July 2Harry J. Mier Jr., the former State Adjutant General who was forced to resign Feb. 17 from Gov. Milton J. Shapp's Cabinet, has been ordered to appear next Friday in Federal District Court here for arraignment on a charge that he used military aircraft for personal purposes.

title: Juan Trippe's Pan Am
description: Fifty years ago this October, a small chartered seaplane made a token round trip flight from Key West to Havana, on the day air mail service between the United States and Cuba was supnosed to begin.

title: CB's Channel 9 Aids Crime Fight
description: SCORES of municipalities and lawenforcement agencies in New Jersey are monitoring Channel 9, the universal emergency channel, on citizensband radio in a move designed to increase their areas of protection and provide faster service to the public.

title: Jeffrey J. Nicholson Fiance of Deborah Ernst
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger Ernst of Washington and Nantucket, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Susan Ernst, to Jeffrey John Nicholson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Nicholson 3d of Berwyn, Pa., and Nantucket.

title: Monzon, Valdes to Fight July 30 in Monte Carlo
description: ROME,July 2 (AP)The dollars of American television won the match against the pride of Monte Carlo. July 30 was set for Carlos Monzon's defense of his middleweight title against Rodrigo Valdes, of Colombia. as the needs of the CBS television network forced rescheduling of a performance of Monte Carlo's Chorus of the Opera.

title: Reid J. D. Dabney to Wed Martha Simpson Staniford
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rockwell Simpson Staniford of Fenwick, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Simpson Staniford, to Reid James Dickinson Dabney, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dickinson Dabney of Piedmont, Calif. A wedding is planned for Oct. 8.

title: Crum Weighs Offer To Coach at U.C.L.A.
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 2 (AP)Denny Crum, coach of the University of Louisville basketball team, confirmed today that he had beer offered the coaching position at the University of California. Los Angeles. He said he would decide by Tuesday whether to take the job.

title: PARADE OF 6 LINERS OPENS PORT FESTIVAL
description: Like an elegant procession of departing dowagers, six Caribbeanbound cruise liners edged out of their midtown Hudson River berths yesterday afternoon and sailed downriver through the Narrows, formally opening the threeday New York Harbor Festival 77.

title: CONNECTICUT AIDES CLASH ON GORMLEY
description: HARTFORD, July 2Longsimmering dissatisfaction with the state's top criminal prosecutor broke into the open here this week with an angry and highly unusual clash between two of the state's highest judges over the handling of the Peter Reilly case.

title: LETTERS;
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: YUGOSLAVS FORESEE CRISIS IN COMMUNISM
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 2Some Communists in Yugoslavia, which broke with the Soviet Union 29 yeares ago in defiance of Stalin's control, discern a new crisis for world Communism, with the Soviet and Spanish Communist Parties at opposite poles and with all the others facing the vital decision of which side to support.

title: Mr. Ambach Is Setting His Course
description: After years as the No. 2 man, Gordon M. Ambach took over last week as New York State's Commissioner of Education, giving him authority over all education, from nursery schools to doctoral programs, and over regulation of the professions. His predecessor, Ewald B. Nyquist, did not shrink from controversy; many, for instance, feel Mr. Nyquist's concern with school desegregation contributed to his ouster by the state's Board of Regents, which sets the policy carried out by the commissioner. Mr. Ambach identifies himself with the Nyquist policies, but in an interview with Gene I. Maeroff, The New York Times national education correspondent, he also indicated he would not seek disputes with the Regents. The policies of the board in all respects have my support, he said. He also gave some ideas of where his interests lie.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: If anyone is a born killer it is the sand tiger shark. After hatching within its mother's body it continues to swim around in there for the next year eating up the unhatched eggs. By the time the young shark finally emerges it is 30

title: Seaside Park Is Renamed for Asser Levy, a Dutch Jew Who Fought for His Rights in New Amsterdam
description: The struggle of Asser Levy for civil liberties and his major role in the establishment of New York's first Jewish community have been honored in a new memorial.

title: Letters
description: There is a good chance young Joe Kennedy could become a good Congressman ('Joe Kennedy Comes of Age by Hays Gorey, May 29) but there are hundreds of young men and women in Massachusetts equally or better qualified who might like a shot at it, too. I look forward to future profiles of some of the many young adults out there trying to build a better world with a rusty shovel instead of a silver spoon.

title: East Ramapo School Board Cuts Teacher Pay to Lower Tax Rate
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.Fulfilling a promise to lower school taxes, the East Ramapo School Board is reducing teachers salaries an average of 15 percent, with teachers at the upper level of the scale losing up to 19 percent of their annual pay.

title: Spencer, Hassler Show Two Sides of Baseball
description: Baseball is one of most intriguing games in the world because it can and does present, on the same day, such extreme opposites.

title: The High Stakes In a New Air Pact
description: A new agreement governing air travel between the United States and Britain will be signed later this summer, replacing the original Bermuda Agreement of February 1946, and the ground rules for civil aviation between the two countries will change.

title: To the Surf for the Perfect Ride
description: PERHAPS it is because we evolved from the sea in the first place that some of us feel the lure of it every summer. Each year we wait impatiently for the weather to get warm enough so we can launch into the surf. For body surfers, surf's up as soon as they can brave the waves off the Island without their lips turning blue.

title: 50 Sailing Ships to Start Race on Sound Thursday
