description: About 50 sailing ships, including a trio of square riggers, are expected to start Thursday in The New York Times New YorkNew London Invitational Sail Regatta, the final event in the East Coast Harbor Festival. An escort flotilla of 130 sail and power boats is scheduled to follow the ships along parts of the 80mile sail, which will begin at 5 P.M. in midLong Island Sound betweenLarchmont and Sea Cliff, L. I.

title: Lawyer Says Newton Will Fly to California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 (AP)Huey Newton, the Black Panther leader who fled the country after he was charged in a 1974 shooting, will return to California tomorrow night and go directly into custody, his lawyer said today.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Star stories. The novelizationthe film script rewritten to be read as a novelis a bit of literary legerdemain nearly as old as Hollywood, A friend of ours, cleaning out his attic recently, came across a crumbling copy of Manhandled, the novelization of a 1924 Gloria Swanson movie.

title: Who Will Watch The Policemen?
description: Law enforcement officers were in trouble last week in several cities, charged with serious crimes or misconduct. None of the cases were related, but all could present potential political problems for public officials ?? the various cities. They also rein?rced for many people a common notion that wrongdoing somehow is more objectionable when it involves law officers:

title: West Coast Debut for Seattle Slew
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 2 (AP)Seattle Slew. Triple Crown winner, makes his West Coast debut tomorrow in the $316,400 Swaps Stakes. He is expected to win without much trouble. A victory would increase his earnings by $194,900, if all seven 3yearolds who are entered go to the post at Hollywood Park for the 1mile event.

title: A Split in Rhodesia Ranks
description: Political dissension among its white constituency is posing more difficulties for the Rhodesian Government of Ian D. Smith. Following the expulsion of 12 rightwing opponents of Mr. Smith from the ruling Rhodesian Front party earlier this year, Des Frost, the party chairman, resigned yesterday.

title: Mother Could Hit a Curve Ball
description: BASEBALL is too often confused with the Major Leagues, or even with Joe Garagiola and the Game of the Week. But baseball is also college and Little League, high school and vacant lot and American Legion and Class A. A Season in the Sun takes its form from Roger Kahn's notion of baseball's scope. To make this book, Kahn spent last summer touching clown at the tour corners of the baseball world. A Season begins in spring with a wonderful visit to Wally Moon, who played for the Cardinals and the Dodgers in the 1950's and 60's, and now coaches baseball for John Brown University in Siloam Springs, Ark. After surveying a college team on which every player believes that he has a chance to make the Majors, Kahn in his next chapter jets to Walter O'Malley's office in Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles. Sitting in the center of baseball's richest franchise, O'Malley glowers a groundsman watering center field with a hose while a $600,000 sprinkler system goes unused.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Not only is the Atlantic Beach Bridge the only toll bridge in Nassau County [For Whom the Atlantic Beach Bridge Tolls?, June 19], but also it is one of the few bridges anywhere that charge pedestrians and bicyclists. Children go??g to the beach and recreational cyclists must fork up a nickel a trip.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: STOW, Mass.Like seeds that sprout at the very moment when great trees are toppling in a storm, Robert F. Collings and his burgeoning Data Terminal Systems Inc. are flourishing in a formidable marketplace that has already felled the likes of the General Electric Company and the Singer Company.

title: A Special Breed of Horseman
description: THERE are two things that fascinate me, said Thomas P. Whitney. One is the world of international politics, and the other is the world of international horse racing.

title: Keepers of the Greenwich Isles
description: GREAT CAPTAIN'S ISLAND

title: GARDENING
description: THERE is a ritual to follow for keeping that grassy mantle around the home green. Once learned, the lawn grows splendidly and all is serene. Yet, it may seem that there is some mystique about lawnsmanship, especially when the neighbor's grass always looks greener than yours. There isn't. The rules are simple. They iust have to be followed.

title: Their College Prep Course: Life
description: A 22year veteran of the New York City Fire Department. A commercial artist from Huntington. A mother of six children. A 29yearold Vietnam veteran. A registered nurse from Seaford. A 41yearold police lieutenant from Glen Cove. Who are these people and what do they have in common?

title: Nazis Drop July 4 March In Suburb of Chicago
description: CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)Frank Collin, leader of the Nazistyled National Socialist Party, said today that the party had abandoned plans to demonstrate in the predominantly Jewish suburb of Skokie on Monday, the Fourth of July.

title: Iranian Parliament Is Expected to Approve Legislation Guaranteeing the Rights of Political Dissidents
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 2The Iranian Parliament is expected to approve legislation shortly providing new guarantees of the rights of political dissidents.

title: Realty News
description: The Trib, a new weekday morning newspaper that plans to begin publishing in the fall, has leased 40,000 square feet of space at 711 Third Avenue for 10 years at an aggregate rent of $4 million.

title: Claudia Carter fiancee Of George C. Covington
description: Mr. and Mrs. Homer M. Carter Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia McGinnis Carter, to George Carruthers Covington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Nail Covington of Greensboro. N. C.

title: Richard Swift Fiance Of Teri Lee Ardleigh
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Ardleigh of Greenwich, Conn., and Key Biscayne, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Teri Lee Ardleigh, to Richard Parker Swift, son of Mrs. J. Frank Braceland of Villanova, Pa., and the late William F. Swift.

title: Deaths
description: MAURERPhyllis A. (ne? Auster). Of 1380 Pleasant Valley Way, West Orange, N.J. Beloved wife of Barry Mau?er, devoted mother of Shawn, Jennifer and Joshua Maurer. Loving daughter of Joseph and Estelle Auster, dear sister of Marc Auster, granddaughter of Anne Barbach, sisterinlaw of Sheryl and Mark Lerner and Evan and Naomi Maurer. Funeral from Temple B'nai Abraham, 300 East Northfield Road, Livingston, N.J. on Sunday, July 3, 1977 at 1:30 P.M. Interment B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, N.J. The period of mouring will be observed at the family residence through Wednesday evening. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Phyllis A. Maurer Fund for Mastectomy Therapy at N.B.I.M.C. For further Information please call Suburban Chapel of Philip Apter and Sons, 2017633505.

title: New Drive to Compensate Blacks For Past Injustice Perplexes Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 2After two decades of legislation and court decisions, marches and riots, the laws of the nation are colorblind. Now, the country is faced with another pressing civil rights question, more subtle, perhaps, but of enormous social importance.

title: School Insurance: Growing Burden
description: RESPONDING to taxpayer opposition to everincreasing school taxes, Long Island school boards and administrators have cut costs by such actions as increasing classroom sizes and laying off teachers. Now, however, they face an increasing expense over which they have little controlthe rising cost of insurance.

title: Saddened Player Skips Wimbledon
description: Three of the four female players for the New York Apples, like most teamtennis competitors, have spent the World Team Tennis midseason break competing at Wimbledon. But 20yearold Linda Siegelman did not accompany her teammates  Billie Jean King, Virginia Wade, and Lindsay Beaven  to England. Linda Siegelman stayed at her Roslyn, L. I., home and played in two local tournaments instead. It would seem that Linda should have been a likely candidate to have a go at Wimbledon. After all, she had an opportunity most players would give anything forthe chance to practice three hours a day, five days a week, with Billie Jean and Virginia, not to mention mixeddoubles practice time with the Apples men.

title: Fighting in South Lebanon
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon July 2A small town in southern Lebanon fell today to rightwing Christian forces but was later recaptured, according to the Palestinian press service Wafa.

title: Neutron, Pro and Con
description: The Senate met in rare secret session last week to debate a classified subject, the virtues and dangers of the neutron radiation bomb. After three hours of debate, and the start of a filibuster which opponents of the weapon threaten to resume after a 10days recess, money for the bomb is still in next year's budget.

title: Congress Is Flexing New Muscles in Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTONThe party was cheerful, the evening cool and quiet and the young, liberal Democratic Senator was asked what Congress would be doing the next week. We're going to find some new way to foul up foreign policy, he replied in a tone of disgust for his coworkers.

title: Rivals in Pakistan Agree Tentatively On New Elections
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan. July 2 (AP)Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto and opposition party negotiators agreed today on a plan for new elections designed to quell four months of political unrest.

title: Red Smith
description: Skaters who see Toller Cranston's The Ice Show at the Palace regard it as theater. To people of the theater it is figure skating. Both views are correct, for this enchanting blend of ballet and jive, ice skating and drama is superior skating and smashing show business. Probably it is not sport by the accepted definitions, for it is neither recreation nor a competitive game. but Cranston and his 14 costars are athletes in the purest sense.

title: 2 Alaska Locomotives Rescued by Donations
description: SEAT?LE, July 2 (AP)  Donations totaling $17,000 from railroad buffs have saved two 57yearold narrowgauge steam locomotives from the graveyard. The locomotives, among the last of their kind in the United States, are on their way to a new home in Tennessee.

title: ASSAULTS ON ELDERLY OFF 25% SINCE JAN 1.
description: Reported crimes against the elderly in New York City have declined more than 25 percent since the first of the year, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday.

title: Press Photographers Honor Ford For His Integrity in White House
description: VAIL, Colo.,July 2(AP)Former President Gerald R. Ford was honored tonight by the National Press Photographers Association for bringing honest integrity and openness to the White House in troubled times.

title: Marx Adds Junior Crown To Men's Adult Foil Title
description: PORTLAND. Ore., July 2 (AP)Michael Marx, of Portland, became the first man to claim the adult and junior men's foil championships today when he won the junior title at the national championships of the Amateur Fencers of America. Earlier this week, Marx, 18 years old, won the men't title.

title: Garden State Race Track May Not Reopen
Intentions Gone Astray
description: WASHINGTONThe complicated tale of Tris, which took yet another jog last week, is a classic tale of good intentionsand of the sad truth of the axiom that, too often, the road to Hell is paved with just such generous or compassionate impulses, at least for the Federal Government.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: When Dame Ninette de Valois, the founder Britain's Royal Ballet, was congratulated on her achievement, she would always maintain that the achievement could not be measured through the success of a company's first director but through the success of that director's successors. I was thinking of that remark in connection with the season of the Stuttgart Ballet which ended the Metropolitian Opera House last night.

title: The Games Politicians Play
description: ABIGAIL McCARTHY has written a political novel that is really more a novel of Washington and its insidious gentility than of politics per se, and it's very nice indeed.

title: Poles Warned to Expect New Shortages of Meat
description: WARSAW, July 2 (AP)The Polish people have been told to expect meat shortages this summer more severe than the shortages of a year ago. Polish newspapers printed the text of a speech yesterday by Prime Minister Piotr Jaroszewicz in which he said, We shall not be able to supply the market even with as much meat as this time last year.

title: Two Cheers for Desegregation
description: The potential for setback was clearly there, said Nathaniel R. Jones, general counsel of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and his apprehension seemed wellfounded. For the last year, in cases touching such key issues as jobs, schools and zoning, the record of the United States Supreme Court has been greeted unenthusiastically, to put it mildly, by civil rights leaders.

title: College Seeks Art Funds
description: WELCOME is the name of the 22foothigh aluminum figure with one arm raised in greeting and a long, outstretched leg. And if William White has his way, the graceful modern sculpture by William King may soon be standing in front of the library at Jersey City State College.

title: Washington Is Trying to Find Some Middle Ground; What Can The U.S. Expect of The Arabs?
description: In the course of his Middle Eastern shuttles, Henry Kissinger used to chat with the reporters aboard his plane about the asymmetrical nature of the deal he was trying to work out between Israel and its Arab neighbors. Israel, he observed, was being asked tq relinquish practical, tangible assets, such as territory, while the Arabs were being asked to concede intangible, almost psychological points, such as recognition and acceptance. Both were crucial to a successful negotiation, he noted; the difficulty was convincing each side it was not giving up more than the other.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Letters
description: We are pleased this Independence Day weekend to turn over more than the customary space to some of the more than customary number of letters evoked by an editorial two weeks ago on the case of The Regents of the University of California v. Allan Bakke. In a ratio of about 15 to 1, our correspondents disagreed with the editorial's judgment that while both sides assert some valid claims in law, the national interest would be best served if Mr. Bakke lostallowing the university's medical school at Davis to continue to give special consideration and reserved places to qualified applicants of racial or ethnic minorities, who would otherwise fail to gain admission in sufficient number.

title: DINING OUT
description: LITCHFIELD is a mostly unspoiled, authentic 18thcentury Colonial town. Cited as one of the best examples of its kind in the country, it has been declared a National Historic Landmark. On July 9 a number of historic Litchfield homes will be opened to the public as a benefit event. Visitors will stroll on the town green under ancient shade trees, admire the welltrimmed lawns and try to get a glimpse, past and present, of life within the stately Litchfield mansions. This is an annual event that regularly attracts history buffs, antiquelovers and the just plain curious.

title: In The Aviary With The Bird
description: In the tunnel leading to the Detroit Tigers dugout, Mark Fidrych yelled, New York Stadium, yeah. No, no, Mark, it's Yankee Stadium, always has been, always will be. But that's The Bird, that's Mark Fidrych, that's what makes him different, that's what makes him what he isthe most appealing personality in baseball. In the Tigers clubhouse earlier, The Bird was putting on his gray uniform when the man from Topps chewing gum handed him a white envelope. Inside it were two color photos of The Bird that Topps had determined it could not use on its baseball trading cards for a very valid reasonMark Fidrych had posed as a lefthanded pitcher instead of as the righthanded pitcher that he is.

title: Decisions, Decisions
description: ALL but the most complacent among us recognize that we are better at giving judicious advice to our friends than at following such advice ourselves. Lawyers also recognize this problem, insisting that the lawyer who handles his own case has a fool for a client. Doctors and other

title: Mental Health Plan Is Tested
description: COMMUNITY COMPANIONS, a new program designed to help former mental patients make their way back into the community, is now under way in five New Jersey counties. under way in five New Jersey counties.

title: 3 Hurt in TriMotor Plane Crash
description: PORT CLINTON, Ohio, July 2 (UPI)A Ford TriMotor passenger plane, considered the last of the corrugated queens still in use, crashed yesterday on South Bass Island in Lake Erie, injuring three persons aboard the plane. The pilot, David Martin, 40 years old, of Lakeside, was hospitalized with a broken hip and other injuries. Two passengers were treated and released.

title: 56,415 at Belmont See Our Mims, $19.60, Win
description: BOWIE, Md., July 2 (AP)Sally M. Gibson's Caesar's Wish overtook the favorite, Danger Bearing, in the final turn and went on to win by 3 lengths in the $26,850 Toddler Stakes for 2yearold fillies; at Bowie Race Course today.

title: Dining in Portuguese Style
description: LIKE every ethnic group that settles away from its homeland, the Portuguese on the Island have made sure they have something they like to eat. Mineola has had a grocery specializing in Portuguese products for over 30 years, and with the recent influx of Portuguese in that community, a couple of restaurants and more shops have opened.

title: Voters in a Cutback Mood
description: WASHINGTON

title: Ode To the Hippie
description: OAKLAND, N.J.This year three nostalgic souls celebrated the summer solstice. For me it ended a decade of solstice observances that began with LSD and psychedelia in San Francisco's HaightAshbury district and had its final, modest ceremony of grass and incense in New Jersey's Ramapo Mountains.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: Hubert Green's golf swing has inspired more downhome humor than the Texas Aggies.

title: Sudan, as O.A.U. Meeting Opens, Is Critical of Socialist Imperialism
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon, July 2President Gaafar alNimeiry of the Sudan told the summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity tonight that socialist imperialism threatens to turn the African continent into a vast arena of conflict.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on Public Officials Integrity bill, to promote the integrity of public officials and institutions, passed, 74 to 5, June 27.

title: Ships Officers Are Guests of Honor at Official Party
description: I'll see you on Monday, in St. George's, Capt. Patrick Fison, hotel officer of the Cunard Princess, called to Capt. Evgeny K. Balashov, master of the Soviet ship M. S. Kazakhstan.

title: Nehemiah Eclipses Milburn Mark
description: RICHMOND, July 2Renaldo Nehemiah, who has been acclaimed by some experts as the greatest highhurdler since Rod Milburn. upheld the judgment of his most enthusiastic supporters this afternoon. Nehemiah, from Scotch Plains, N.J.. broke Milburn's national high school record in winning the 110meter high hurdles at the sixth junior dual meet between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Fashion
description: Classy Classic or Funky Fun  in Southampton, it's more of the former, in Fire Island Pines, a lot of the latter. Here, snapshots taken at these two Long Island resorts, famous for making fashion trends, show that the way to go this summer ranges anywhere from silk crepedechine shorts to gold lame pants; from highheeled sandals with bobby socks to bare feet. And, whether the look is Classy Classic or Funky Fun, it's worn everywhere from the discotheque to. the beach.

title: What's Doing on MARTHA'S VINEYARD
description: SECESSIONISTSMartha's Vineyard is a 100squaremile island of ponds, harbors, inlets, windswept ocean beaches, pine woods and moors lying five miles off Cape Cod. For 285 years it has been part of Massachusetts, but this year the citizens in all six of its small towns voted to quit the commonwealth after a reduction of the legislature from 240 to 160 delegates placed the Vineyard and the neighboring island of Nantucket into a district with Cape Cod and left the 8,000 yearround residents of Martha's Vineyard without a representative of their own. Outside Alley's General Store in West Tisbury, where farmers mingle with Harvard professors, the Vineyard's flag of independencedeep blue with a sun and a seagullhas been snapping. Expressions of outrage can be heard throughout the island: in Edgartown, the Dukes County seat; in Gay Head, a village where 60 descendants of Wampanoag Indians are among the voters; in Oak Bluffs, summer community of gingerbread cottages; in Vineyard Haven, the island's business center, and in Chilmark, home of outspoken Yankees. The islanders are considering offers from other states (even Hawaii has made a bid) to annex the Vineyard if the Massachusetts legislature could be induced to give its consent, and there has even been talk, jocular at first, now more serious, of going it alone as a territory. Two years ago the Vineyard was the setting for the movie Jaws, and money poured in. This year land scenes for Jaws 2 have been filmed on the island, which has helped take minds off what some voters regard as taxation without representation. But an atmosphere of discontent prevails.

title: Notes: A Flying Force Called Friendship
description: The Friendship Force, an Atlantabased organization that is mounting an international peopletopeople exchange program endorsed by President and Mrs. Jimm? Carter, sends off its inaugural flight tomorrowto Newcastle, England. Threehundredandeighty one Georgians will fly from Atlanta on a chartered Pan American 747 and stay in the homes of Newcastle families. The net cost per head: $250. Before the Americans take off for their 10day stay the same jetliner will have landed with 381 visitors from the Newcastle area who will stay in private homes in and around Atlanta.

title: The Brilliant Briton Who Runs Canada's National Theater
description: STRATFORD, Ontario

title: Cold Comfort Is First In $166,555 Dexter Cup
description: WESTBURY, L.I.,July 2Delvin Miller went after a third straight Dexter Cup, one of the premier races for 3yearold trotters, tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Twelve horses, including Billy Haughten's favored threehorse entry of Green Speed, Gold Comfort and Haygood, went to the post in the onemile race with a purse of $166,655.

title: A Cornucopia Of Specialties
description: WHETHER you love to cook or hate it, always count calories or never do, Colonial Village on Weaver Street in the Heathcote section of Scarsdale beckons. In the clapboard and shingle shops sheltered by an arcade, purveyors of food specialties predominate: The Pastry Center, Paul's Fish Market, In Julie's Kitchen, The Diet Bazaar, Alpen Cheese Pantry, Gedney Wines and Liquors, Potpourri Restaurant. If you need flowers for a centerpiece (Heathcote Florist) or a bank for the wherewithal, you will find these, too.

title: Meetings Scheduled By Council This Week
description: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council committees this week:

title: Italy Closing Medical Schools To Outsiders
description: Between 8,000 and 15,000 Americans no one is sure exactly how manyare enrolled in medical schools abroad because they have been unable to gain admission to American schools. One door has now been closed to such students. Beginning with the academic year 19771978, foreigners will no longer be admitted to Italian universities. About 1,600 Americans are mow registered in Italian medical schools.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE is a sign on the door at Lao Lee that says: Come in. We're open. Without that sign, you might never know, for Lao Lee has to be the most understated restaurant in its part of the state. Housed in an old colonial building, it looks like it must have been a stagecoach station. There is almost nothing to indicate that it is now the site of an excellent Chinese restaurant.

title: Communing Commuters: Conviviality on Train
description: WE always knew we'd get married on the 8:13. Susan Steinman, a Mount Vernon resident and steady commuter, was joking about herself and her husband Lonny. A receptionist for a Manhattan real estate firm and a steady commuter, Mrs. Steinman met her husband two and a half years ago as a result of their travels on the train.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: LONDON

title: Food
description: And now, on the eve of the Fourth of July, let us celebrate good things American. The American eagle, the 50 states and the Grand Old Flag. Not to mention Cracker Jacks, clam chowder (Manhattan and Boston), fried chicken, shoofly pie, peanut butter, pepper pot, bubble gum, beans (Boston baked) and twofinger poi (now that Hawaii is one of the HalfHundred). But, particular, let us celebrate what is perhaps the most glorious Yankee contribution of all, Hotnarus arnericattus, which is to say, that sea creature better known as Maine or New England lobster. Long may they crawl beneath the sea and, at table, delight the taste buds of gastronomes throughout the country.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A June Swoon for Stripers
description: MONTAUK, L.J.A slice of moon washed the turbulent water over Shagwong Reef with its wan light, and the riding lights of a few other striped bass boats rose and fell through the gloom.

title: Aid to Handicapped: Laurels Not Enough
description: FREQUENTLY, on the national, state and local levels, much lipservice is given to aiding the handicapped. However, in reality, very little is done to insure that the quality of life for the handicapped is improved as advancements in technology are simultaneously made.

title: The Imported and Homespun Charms of Our Musical Past
description: Last year's Bicentennial inspired a furious amount of musical activitymore perhaps than we could all digest at the time. Even after the official celebrations had passed, records exploring all aspects of Americana past and present continued to pour forth. The following survey attempts to catch up with the bounty, which includes, among other surprises, a musical portrait of a Ford flivver automobile, one of America's noted painters in the unfamiliar role of country fiddler, and a tribute to the inimita. ble Henry Russell, a kind of protoBritish rock star who took the country by storm in the 1830's with his melodramatic and ballads.

title: Catholic Dissidence Is Often From the OldLine Traditionalists
description: Before the last decade of church renewal, a rebellion from the Roman Catholic right seemed quite improbable.Doctrine was firmly rooted in the early church fathers, theology revelved around Augustine and Aquinas and the main ecclesiastical features had been fixed by the 16th century CounterReformation. Trouble, when it came, was usually made by the left.

title: Dr. E. E. DePasquale And Dr. Agatha Nody Are Wed in Peekskill
description: Dr. Agatha Catherine Nody, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Nody of Peekskill, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Eugene Edward DePasquale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DePasquale of Flushing, Queens, and Southampton, L.I. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Peekskill by the Rev. Francis J. Ansbro.

title: Bringing Up Girls To Be Independent
description: LONG before she turned 15, Rana Dunn decided to become a lawyer. I wanted to be a doctor first but then when I got older thought I'd be a lawyer, said Rana, curled in an overstuffed chair in her jeans and a black shirt, and with a rose in her hair. I'm a fighter. I stand up for my rights.

title: Simple Service Held For Magda Lupescu
description: ESTORIL, Portugal,July 2(AP)Shunned by her royal neighbors, Magda Lupescu, the woman who was companion to King Carol in the last days of Rumania's monarchy, was eulogized at a simple Anglican funeral service today.

title: Home Style
description: What do tenants want, dear God what do they want?

title: Dance: Exciting London Contemporary Theater
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 2Whatever the London Contemporary Dance Theater is, it is differentdifferent from other moderndance companies and always exciting.

title: Margaret R. Healey Bride of David Lee
description: Margaret R. Healey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Healey of Lyon Mountain, N. Y., was married yesterday to David Currie Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Day Lee of Deerfield, Mass., and St. Huberts, N. Y. The ceremony was performed in St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church in Keene, N. Y., by the Rev. Earl Mayo.

title: Defending an Injured Reputation
description: IN the early 1870's John Henry Ingram began an obsessional quest for the El Dorado of the life of Poe as he actually lived it when he was highly regarded by a circle of friends and was far from being the corrupted character he had been made to seem in the malicious biography of a very mediocre and jealous poet, the Rev. Rufus Wilmot Griswold. As Poe's selfelected rival, Griswold's talents were small potatoes, indeed, with no amaranthine flowers such as may be found in the unfading. undying works of Poe.

title: God's Bouillabaisse
description: Eloquence Is variety, a character says toward the end of Gala, and if the equation is true then this autobiographical novel is wildly eloquent. Paul West, an English poet and novelist now living in the United States, has a style as full of exotic ingredients as God's bouillabaisse and, in its references to nature, as comprehensive as Noah's inventory.

title: Borg Defeats Connors for Wimbledon Title
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2Wimbledon's first 100 years wound up in a blaze of glory today as Bjorn Borg outlasted Jimmy Connors in five sets for his second consecutive men's singles tennis title.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: They are carrying 400 tons of rubbish out of the Shelton lintel on Lexington Avenue between 48th and 49th Streets, and the sign on the dusty colonnaded entrance announces that the new Halloran House Hotel is coming, courtesy of Howard Johnson. What the sign does not say is that this is one the most dramatic examples of the recycling of a major building in any city today, and that the remodeling and rehabilitation of this landmark New York skyscraper is being sponsored by a national chain that has dealt almost undeviatingly in new construction of plastic uniformity. Call it a bornagain hotel.

title: Radio
description: Midnight12:30, WNCN: Metropolitan Arts. Guest, Gerard Schwartz, conductor of the Waterloo Festival Orchestra.

title: POLL AT SYNOD FINDS LIBERAL VIEWS ON SEX
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Seventyeight percent of the 700 delegates polled at the biennial General Synod of the United Church of Christ here favored full and equal rights for homosexuals, and 80 percent said they did not feel uncomfortable discussing homosexuality.

title: REGINALD C. PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Reginald C. Price, a water resources engineer for Federal agencies here and international groups in the Far East, died of cancer today at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 66 years old.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Utile.

title: A Correction
description: In a chart showing the performance of municipal bond funds, Lipper Ana????? Services Inc., miscalculated the total return of the Nuveen Municipal Bond Fund. The total return for the Nuveen fund for the first five months of 1977 was 2.89 percent, fifth highest among the 14 funds listed.

title: Espinosa Is the Loser, Alcala the Victor
description: MONTREAL, July 2In what may have been the first confrontation between majorleague starting pitchers from the Dominican Republic, the Mets Nino Espinosa lost to the Montreal Expos Santo Alcala tonight. The score was 43, marking the Mets third straight loss to Montreal.

title: R. Peter Straus to Voice of America
description: R. Peter Straus, a major figure in New York broadcasting, has been named director of the Voice of America by President Carter. The appointment does not require Senate confirmation. The Voice is the overseas information conduit for the United States Information Agency, and critics have often charged that it has served as little more than a propaganda arm of the agency. Mr. Straus said it was his impression that the Voice was wholly free to do a firstrate job of public diplomacy and reporting in this Administration.

title: Carousal Parr Victor, Pays $53.20
description: YAPHANK, L.I., July 2Carousal, ridden by Julie Jel.vson, the only female jockey in the race, won the $86,000 Hamptons Derby at Parr Meadows tonight The event for 3yearolds was the richest ever offered for quarterhorse racing east of the Mississippi.

title: PCP, A DEADLY DRUG, THRIVES ON COAST
description: SAN DIEGO, July 2Laboratories hidden away like moonshiners stills in backcountry areas of southern California are supplying drug users, most of them teenagers, with a cheap but deadly substitute for heroin and other increasingly expensive narcotics. Known as pig outfits, the flybynight chemical plants are catering to a revived market for a potent drug, PCP, or phencyclidine, the popularity of which declined several years ago when young people turned to heroin, cocaine. LSD or methamphetamines for a quick mindbending trip.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Illegal Walkout
description: After a fiveday strike by 45,000 New York City teachers in September 1975, two arms of the state government moved to punish the strikers for what was an illegal action under the Taylor Law.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE is a ritual to follow for keeping that grassy mantle around the home green. Once learned, the lawn grows splendidly and all is serene. Yet, it may seem that there is some mystique about lawnsmanship, especially when the neighbor's grass always looks greener than yours. There isn't. The rules are simple. They just have to be followed.

title: Communism's Important Dates
description: Throughout its history, the Communist movement has been characterized by tactical changes and ideological splits. Following are the major such events since the Russian Revolution:

title: Main Event for Today Will Be Parade of Sail
description: A flotilla of festooned Shriner yachts will pass in review before the Shriner's imperial potentate at 10 A.M. today at the South Street Seaport Museum.

title: Slayings, Abduction Lead Girl Scouts To Tighten Security
description: MIAMI,July 2(AP)Security precautions at summer Girl Scout camps around the country have been tightened because of the abduction of a teenager at a Florida state park and the slayings of three girls in Oklahoma.

title: Bomb Damages Boston Tavern
description: BOSTON, July 2 (AP)A bomb blew in the front door of historic Warren Tavern about 3 A.M. today and damaged the restaurant's interior, the police said. There was no fire and no injuries were reported. The restaurant, in the Charlestown section, was recently restored. It dates from the Revolution and was named for Joseph Warren, a patriot who was killed in the Battle of Bunker Hill.

title: Zodiac
description: He was in some respects a killer like New York's present Son of Sam. He called himself the Zodiac, and he shot or stabbed victims at random in the San Francisco region, concentrating at first on young lovers. He taunted the police in letters to newspapers.

title: Buckner, Thompson in Kenya
description: NAIROBI,Kenya, July 2 (Reuters) Three American professional basketball players arrived last night to conduct coaching clinics in Kenya for one week. They were Quinn Buckner of the Milwaukee Bucks and Dave Thompson and Monte Towe of the Denver Nuggets.

title: Behind Closed Doors
description: WHEN THE first White House conference on handicapped people met in May, it focused national attention on the plight of 35 million Americans. Long embittered by neglect, groups of the handicapped demonstrated across the country last spring, even picketing the home of the Health, Education and Welfare Secretary, Joseph A. Califano Jr., to demand implementation of a law passed in 1973.

title: The Vexing Abortion Issue
description: THE impatient arguments that attended the abortion issue on its long, tortuous course over the last several years in Connecticut from the General Assembly to the courts and back to the General Assembly again were always perplexing, and, from all that could be seen and understood of them, irreconcilable.

title: She Casts Ballet Dancers In the Proper Light
description: If it weren't for Jennifer Tipton, a great many New York dancers and actors would find themselves whistling in the dark. You may not know her name, but if you attend dance or theater with any regularity, you've probably seen her work. In fact, her work allows you to see the work you paid to attend in the first place. For Jennifer Tipton is one of this country's most versatile and, dare one say, visible. lighting designers.

title: Jazz Events
description: Following is a schedule of today's Newport Jazz FestivalNew York events:

title: More Tuition Aid
description: THE odds are about even that a college student from a lowincome family in New Jersey, which in the world of colleges is identified as a family with an income of less than $12,000 a year, will not be getting taxpaid tuition assistance if the student is enrolled in a state school.

title: The Password Is Media at This Year's Documenta
description: KASSEL, West Germany

title: Laura Meyer Sets September Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stefan A. Meyer of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Lansing Meyer, to Edward W. Wellman Jr., son of Mr. Wellman of Weston, Conn., and the late Hazel Holmes Wellman. A September wedding is planned.

title: Lawyers Now May Advertise
description: Throughout this century, organizations of lawyers, doctors and other professionals have adopted rules against advertising and successfully pushed to write these strictures into state laws and regulations. Such prohibitions have recently fallen under attack from several quarters, and last week the United States Supreme Court struck down an Arizona rule forbidding advertising by lawyers. As it did in a similar decision on drug advertising last year, the Court ruled that such advertising is protected by First Amendment free speech guarantees,

title: AH, THE GOOD LIFE! GOOD FOOD, GOOD WINE, GOOD TALK.
description: (AND HOME DELIVERY Of THE NEW York TIMES.)

title: HEAD OF RHODESIAN FRONT QUITS AND ASSAILS SMITH
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 2 (Reuters) The chairman of the ruling Rhodesian Front quit the party today and bitterly attacked Prime Minister Ian D. Smith for lack of leadership.

title: Beirut's Children: They Survived the War, but Cannot Forget It
description: BEIRUT, LebanonThe children of Beirut collect shrapnel instead of stamps and talk about war as easily as they talk about soccer.

title: Youth, 19, Slain in Queens
description: A body found early yesterday in a parking lot on Woodhaven Boulevard in Forest Park in Richmond Hills, Queens, was identified as Fred Lopez, 19 years old, of 100 Jamaica Avenue, Brooklyn. The victim had been shot four times in the head at close range.

title: Poems and Personality
description: MARIANNE MOORE praises artists who know that egomania is not a duty. A large self will include realities outside the firstperson singular. In her first book Grace Schulman

title: BOOK ENDS
description: THINKING about literature and reportage rather than politics and poker, we talked recently with a Soviet authorKirill Bulychevand an American author who had actually worked in the People's Republic of ChinaOrville Schell. Both had something to say about the riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigmathe Churchill phrase about the Soviet Union that applies with equal force to the People's Republic. Both writers are respected by their own countrymen.

title: Seoul Assembly Weighs Protest on Its Foes in U.S.
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 2The South Korean National AssemblY is expected to approve two resolutions next week asking President Carter to reconsider his policy on withdrawal of American troops and demanding that he curb antiGovernment activities of South Koreans in the United States.

title: Firefighters in Baltimore Continuing Slowdown
description: BALTIMORE, July 2 (AP)Baltimore firefighters continued a work slowdown today, but those in Annapolis agreed to end their job action in a pay dispute.

title: Mariners with a Paintbrush
description: WHILE other American folk artists in the 19th century were turning out portraits of people who wanted a likeness of themselves, the Bard brothers were busy painting other kinds of portraits: portraits of steamers, schooners, towboats, ferries, yachts and sloops.

title: Mariners with a Paintbrush
description: WHILE other American folk artists in the 19th century were turning out portraits of people who wanted a likeness of themselves, the Bard brothers were busy painting other kinds of portraits: portraits of steamers, schooners, towboats. ferries. Yachts and sloops.

title: R. B. Wilson Fiance Of Melissa Moore
description: The engagement of Melissa Woodburn Moore to Robert Ballou Wilson has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Dongan Reynolds Moore of Westport, Conn. Mr. Wilson is the son of Mr. end Mrs. Everett Stuart Wilson of Pointe Claire, Quebec.

title: The Selling of The Deep
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Ellen S. Cardozo Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin M. Cardozo of New York and Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Schaffer Cardozo, to Isaac David Sonsino, son of Mrs. David Sonsino of Philadelphia, formerly of Cairo, and the late Mr. Sonsino.

title: Debbe Silverstein Is Married
description: Debbe Silverstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Silverstein of Forest Halls, Queens, was married last night to Steven Arnofsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Arnofsky of Brooklyn. Rabbi Irwin Isaacson performed the ceremony at the Oakland Jewish Center in Bayside, Queens.

title: Word of Caution For the G.O.P.
description: A MAN many consider to be a sort of elder statesman of the Nassau Republican Party warns that its leadership is overconfident of victory in the forthcoming threeway County Executive primary.

title: Laura Culley, John Meleney To Wed Aug. 6
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Culley of Cincinnati have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Marie Culley to John Alexander Meleney. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Meleney of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., and Vineyard Haven, Mass. The couple plan to be married on Aug. 6.

title: Aztecs Beat Cosmos As David Scores Two
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2 (AP)Steve David, the North American Soccer League's top scorer, tallied two goals and George Best had two assists today as the Los Angeles Aztecs defeated the Cosmos, 41, before 32,165 at the Los Angeles Coliseum.

title: A Fight Over Alaskan Pipeline Tariffs, a Settlement in OPEC
description: With the first crude oil from Prudhoe Bay inching its way through the TransAlaska pipeline and due to arrive at Valdez for loading into tankers by late July, the Interstate Commerce Commission last week rejected the pipeline tariffs proposed by the eight oil companies that are its joint owners.

title: Municipal Disclosure Law Eased
description: The law that requires full personal financial disclosure by New York City municipal employees who earn $25,000 a year or more has been amended by a unanimous court ruling that struck down the part of the law that granted public access to such financial reports.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY of the houses in this area have cedar shakes or shingles around the outside, and the question of how to finish or coat these wood shingles is often a perplexing problem for the home owner. Should he use a paint or a stain or just a clear preservative? Or can he just leave the shingles untreated, since cedar is widely recommended as a rotresistant wood that really needs no protection?

title: Letters: Why Should Travelers Dress Up?
description: To the Editor.

title: A Diet for Government Fat
description: REDUCED spending and increased productivity for state governmental agencies are watchwords for political candidates. However, sometime after election and before officetaking, these words are swept under the proverbial rug, along with such things as candor, honesty and integrity.

title: ART
description: ONE of the most exciting and important archeological sites in America lies between Trenton and Bordentown. It is known as the Abbott Farm Site and it is considered by leading archeologists to be a crucial area for the study of early North American inhabitants. Its rich soils have yielded countless artifacts and other objects which, it is hoped, will some day reveal the complexity of this ancient culture.

title: Taiwan Says U.S. Policy May Spur Peking Attack
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 2 (AP)Chinese Nationalist officials and leading newspapers said today that the Carter Administration's plan to try to establish normal relations with Peking would encourage Communist aggression against Taiwan.

title: Japan Bans Israeli Team In Karate
description: TOKYO, July 2 (AP)Israeli athletes marched today in the opening ceremony at the world karate championships despite a night of threatening telephone calls, theft of their flag and refusal by organizers to schedule them in matches.

title: FATAL KENTUCKY FIRE BRINGS PRECAUTIONS
description: NASHVILLEWhen the popular singing group Eagles made a performance here last month at the downtown Municipal Auditorium, it signaled the last time the huge facility would allow more people inside the building than fire regulations permit.

title: Births
description: Adelman

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Mr. Troy Acquitted, Cautioned
description: City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. has been acquitted of perjury in State Supreme Court in Queens. Mr. Troy had been accused of lying in a court hearing last November when he denied having represented himself as his brotherinlaw's partner in a law firm: Justice Howard A. Jones, who tried the case without a jury, said Mr. Troy should be more careful with the English language and told him, It just might be you don't possess the cunning or the guile to have perpetrated perjury in the full meaning or sense contemplated by the law. Mr. Troy, who is running for reelection, still faces a grand larceny trial on charges of appropriating for his own use money from estates he was handling as a lawyer.

title: When the Man in Charge Is Not the Man Who Knows
description: Ours is in many ways a very peculiar culture, and not the least peculiar thing about it is the assumptionnow so widespread that it rarely any longer occasions either surprise serious discussionthat, in the organization of our cultural institutions, it is both wise and efficient to divorce knowledge from power.

title: In Two Worlds: Weekend Farmers
description: Drive up Route 17, which winds its way through some of New York State's prettiest vacation country, and you will see a huge sign that says, Land Is Gold.

title: A Fast Commodity Option Game, at 10 Percent Down
description: Now that new Federal regulations governing commodity options have driven many shady dealers out of the business, oldline brokers find the public is taking a renewed interest in this market. And the interest is expected to widen substantially when trading in commodity options is resumed on United States exchanges (after a hiatus of four decades) by early 1978.

title: U.S. Plans to Sue New York State on Behalf of 3 Indian Tribes
description: The Federal Government plans to bring suit on behalf of three upstate New York Indian tribes that claim more than 270,000 acres of land, the Interior Department has announced.

title: A Love of Buildingsand Banter
description: THEIR names are Nino Luciano and Charles Givens, and though they seem at times to coalesce tout as well as oil and water, the discerning observer soon detects subtleties in the relationship. Actually they complement each otherMr. Luciano, the president of New Again Restorations, and Mr. Givens, vice president of the concern, which has won a reputation far above and beyond its modest office in Westbury.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: After nearly a solid month of rising prices, the stock market bumped into a rapidfire series of disquieting developments last week. As a result, as the saying goes on Wall Street, Prices headed South.

title: Light Up July 4
description: WHEN I was a child, the Fourth of July was the grandest, most exciting day of the year. At the risk of being accused of a flagwaving patriotism, I'd like to suggest that we try to make it that way again.

title: Under Cover Operation at House of Elizabeth
description: At first glance, the gray house at 103 Van Etten Boulevard in New Rochelle does not seem unusual. The only clue of some thing out of the ordinary is a sign on a tree near the door that reads The House of Elizabeth.

title: Juliette O. Roe, James Hopkins Are Betrothed
description: Mrs. Fred Nash Oliver of St. Hilaire, Quebec, and Mrs. James A. Roe of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their granddaughter, Juliette Oliver Roe, to James Michael Hopkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Hopkins of Utica, N.Y.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Tom Seaver's Signature
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hockey in July: Is Something Else Better?
description: Hockey in July. It sounds incongruous. The main purpose of ice in the summer should be to sit lazily at the bottom of a cocktail glass.

title: Menu Planning
description: The entire trick is to make everything you pack do at least double duty. Here, the basic ingredientsa large ham, fresh fruits and vegetables, assorted cheeses, dairy products, eggsshow up in a variety of dinner dishes. Most have seen service at other meals as well; the ham, for example, is also used as a garnish for scrambled eggs at breakfast and as julienne strips in a luncheon salad. Peel from breakfast oranges decorates Saturday night's cake; Friday night's marmalade reappears on Saturday morning's corn bread.

title: SURROUNDED, SUSPECT IN DEATHS IS SHOT
description: FAYETTEVILLE. Pa.. July 2(AP),A rifleman was shot and wounded late last night after being surrounded in an apple orchard by state troopers who were pursuing him in connection with the sniper killings of two persons who had run up to his burning cabin.

title: More Living Space? Goodbye, Garage;
description: Once upon a time it was a barn. Then it became a stable, then a carriage house. In the early suburbs it was detached and big enough to shelter a couple of roadsters and have an apartment on top. Then it shrank to an attachment big enough for only about 150 horsepower.

title: An Uneasy Campaign Alliance
description: THE leaders of Westchester's Republicans, Conservatives and Liberals seemed quite comfortable as they sat shoulder to shoulder with Assemblyman Gordon W. Burrows, their joint candidate for County Executive, but doubts persisted as to how long their unity would prevail.

title: Miss Hinshaw Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Veeder Hinshaw of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Veeder Hinshaw, to Miner Allen Crary, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miner Dunham Crary Jr. of Northport, L. I.

title: Architecture School Loses Some Forms of Radicalism
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  When the Southern California Institute of Architecture was started in 1972, its faculty intended a radical break from traditional architectural schools. The curriculum had little structure, and the catalogue was full of words like flexibility and process and phrases like the initiation and continuation of any course will depend upon mutual studentinstructor interest. The year after the school opened, Architectural Forum commented: It sounds like the Bennington of architecture schools.

title: Riverfront Hospital Is Rising
description: STRETCHING about 12 miles along the Palisades are a dozen communities in northern Hudson and southeastern Bergen counties that have had to do without a regional hospital.

title: What They Are Saying
description: A teammate of the Minnesota Twins Rod Carew was not surprised that Carew, hitting. over .400, was taking extra batting practice: Who knows? He might get better.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE BIRD & Bottle Inn had a fine reputation long before anyone thought restaurants were fair game for reviewers. The building, which housed a tavern in Revolutionary times, began its modern life as an inn in 1940. It has had many ups and an occasional down since then, through several changes in management. Now, under the ownership of Thomas Noonan, it seem to be regaining lost ground though there is still some to retrieve.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayDelOtse Nango Kennel Club all breed dog show and obedience trial, Damaschke Baseball Park, Oneonta, N.Y.; 1,186 dogs; 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: THE late L. E. Sissman, had he lived, would have been 50 years old on New Year's Day 1978. That he was a poet of unusual distinction was not widely appreciated when he died in the spring of 1976 of the illness that inspired some of his best writing. It was not that he was unknown. He had been a regular contributor to The New Yorker, which published 51 poems and 45 book reviews by him; he wrote a monthly column in The Atlantic; and he published three volumes of verse and one of prose in a period of seven years (19681975). But he had not yet acquired the kind of readership his work had earned him. Which was doubly ironic for he was not only an excellent poet, but also one of the most accessible poets of his generation. It was as if the very clarity of his writing acted to obscure its quality and power.

title: Feminist in Power
description: EVENTUALLY someone was bound to have the highly marketable idea of combining a doomsday saga with a new handle on the war between the sexes. Robert Merle, the author of The Day of the Dolphin and an old hand at such convenient amalgamations, does it here with the aplomb of an ambulancechasing lawyer.

title: Notes: 36Million Americans Like to Make Music
description: Do you know that piano players in this country are more likely than players of other instruments to be female and to be concentrated in the South? That electric guitar players tend to be concentrated in the East and acoustic guitar players in the West? That the banjo, recorder and ukulele are each played by about 300,000 Americans? And that one very appealing reason why people want to learn an instrument is so that they can play in discotheques or nightclubs? Do you care?

title: Parties Did Not Leave One Kremlin to Form Another
description: PARISMoscow's condemnation of Eurocommunism last month, aimed at the Spanish Communist leader, Santiago Carrillo, also spattered the French and Italian parties, which, although they profess a dislike for the name, espouse the broad principles of Eurocommunism. Yet the three parties differ sharply on many other issues. The Kremlin took some risk of bringing them closer together in defense of what they have in common, but it apparently considered the chances were better for splitting them and isolating Mr. Carrillo.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE CARTER ADMINISTRATION, in its first formal longterm economic projection, said the economy could begin showing a budget surplus by 1980, on the assumption that no new programs are introduced, and that by 1982 the budget surplus could hit $75 billion.

title: CLARA ORESKES DEMIHA, LONG A SOCIAL ACTIVIST
description: NEW HAVEN, July 1 (AP)Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Donnelly of Hartford, a highly regarded labor mediator for many years, died yesterday after suffering a seizure. He was 68 years old.

title: The Advantages Of Vitamin C
description: Attention, drinking men and women! According to a new study of drunken rats and mice, a shot of vitamin C prevents the worst effects of alcohol, at least in laboratory animals. A slug of zinc also serves to keep them from getting completely zonked.

title: KhashoggiThe Bridge to Arab Deals
description: Of all the arms salesmen's provinces in the emerging third world, it was the Middle East, from the mid60's onward, that held the most promise of profits, and it was Saudi Arabia that was developing into the richest of all the new customers, with its mounting revenues from oil.

title: Shareholders Chip Away at Mahoney's Salary
description: The settlement of a stockholders lawsuit that challenged the salary, bonus and fringe benefits paid to David J. Mahoney, the chairman of Norton Simon Inc., is more significant than its modest dollarsandcents impact on Mr. Mahoney might indicate.

title: Obedience Champion Title Is Added
description: The first obedience trial champion in the United States could become reality by the end of this holiday show weekend. Dogs with utility degrees became eligible Friday to compete for the new O.T.Ch. prefix and

title: OneCar Rule Chagrins Follmer
description: At one point, it looked as if George Follmer would drive three different cars in the various road races at Watkins Glen in upstate New York next weekend.

title: No Wedding Bells for Amex and Big Board
description: A major casualty of the efforts by the New York Stock Exchange to establish an options market by the end of this year has been the sevenmonth movement to merge the Big Board with its New York City neighbor, the American Stock Exchange.

title: The Liner United States Made History 25 Years Ago
description: Shipping history was made 25 years ago today. The new superliner United States sailed from here that day on her initial transAtlantic crossing. The first voyage of the $79 million vessel, on July 3. 1952, and the transAtlantic speed marks she established, created more worldwide attention than any other shiping story, with the exception, perhaps, of the sinking of the Titanic 40 years earlier. Among those who recalled that historic sailing last week was Margaret Truman Daniel.

title: Stampede for B.P.
description: Some 3.4 million additional shares of British Petroleum stayed in Britain last week as a result of an extraordinary demand from small investors in the Government's sale of B.P. stock. The demand was understandable since the shares, offered at the equivalent of $14.53, traded on the eve of the sale at a price equivalent to $15.89.

title: Summer Camps and Sports: Winning Becomes Too Vital
description: Now that the nation's school doors are firmly shut for a welldeserved twomonth breather, thousands of youngsters are temporarily bunked in a sort of supervised wilderness that has become an American sports phenomenon: summer camp.

title: Ann Marshak fiancee Of Dr. T. L. Rothstein
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Marshak have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Marshak to Dr. Thomas L. Rothstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Rothstein of Washington. The wedding is planned for Nov. 23.

title: 2 SUSPECTS IN OKLAHOMA HUNTED IN SLAYING OF 2
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 2 (AP)Five police airplanes patrolled over roads in eastern Oklahoma today looking for a pair of gunmen who, the authorities say have killed two men and may have killed two others, wounded a fifth and possibly kidnapped a sixth.

title: When the Earth Opens And Walls Move.. .
description: George Nemeth and Barbara Kuehl don't live here any more.

title: Children's Hospital Stresses Abilities
description: BY 10 A.M., the 92 beds in Blythedale Children's Hospital are virtually empty, and have been for an hour. All the schoolage patients and the preschoolers are dressed in street clothes in their classrooms and they are moving, with the help of braces, walkers, wheel chairs, and Blythemobiles (a special stretcher on wheels invented at Blythedale).

title: Nurses' 1941 Deposit Found in Bank Audit
description: HONG KONG (AP)A $140 account opened in 1941 by British nurses who later died or were imprisoned during World War II has been found in an audit at the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank.

title: Guild's Convention Backs Merger Step With Printers Union
description: HONOLULU, July 2Delegates at the closing session of the Newspaper Guild's convention in Waikiki have approved the drawing up of a blueprint for the proposed merger of the 33,000member guild with the 65.000member International Typographical Union.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: New Leaders Appointed By Defeated Irish Parties
description: DUBLIN, July 1 (Reuters)New leaders have been elected by the two parties that were defeated in last month's Irish election.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Everyone who has ever read a program note knows how Schubert composed. He sat in bedwith the covers pulled up because his room had no heatand wrote one piece after another as fast as he could scribble. When he blotted a page or made a mistake he didn't bother to correct; he simply threw away the whole piece and started another one. It all came out effortlessly, in a flood of unpremeditated song, Wilfred Mellers has put it. Everyone knows all that about Schubert.

title: Easyride Trips Aided
description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has authorized the use of Medicare funds to permit New York City to continue operation of its Project Easyride, which provides doortodoor transportation for the elderly and disabled. The project, initiated in 1976 by the Vera Institute of Justice, offers specially equipped buses to take residents from Manhattan's Lower East to other points in Manhattan and to nearby destinations in other boroughs. About half of the project's 1,000 trips each week are to healthcare destinations.

title: Kentucky Town Still Agonizing Over Club Fire
description: SOUTHGATE, Ky., July 2It has been more than a month sirt?e the Beverly Hills Supper Club fire, and life in this little town just across the Ohio River from.Cincinnati sometimes seems to have returned to normal.

title: Israelis Deny a London Paper's Charges of Torture
description: LONDON, July 2A fourpage article in The Sunday Times of London two weeks ago alleging that Israel tortures Arabs suspected of terrorism has evoked intense reactions of criticism and praise. Some readers expressed outrage and demanded an investigation by Britain's Press Council and the International Press Institute; other readers acclaimed the newspaper's courage.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: PITTSBURGHStorms were swirling over some sectors of the metals industry last week as the eventful first half of 1977 ended. But the dampness they brought, like that of many summer thunderheads, will prove to be fleeting. At least that is the unanimous view of top corporate officers here in the nation's steel capital.

title: Trying Times for Family Court?
description: WESTCHESTER'S Family Court has been depicted by a special state study as a model of organized efficiency whose effectiveness is often undermined by the arrogance, indifference and possible corruption of other agencies.

title: DINING OUT
description: THIS is the year of Gordon's renaissance. The cosy restaurant on Amagansett's Main Street had begun to lose its luster several years ago, probably because of an anachronistic insistence on skirts for women. By the time that rule was scrapped, the people who counted no longer cared. Now owned by George Polychronotoulos, heretofore the popular maitre d'hotel at the Spring Close House, Gordon's has been spruced up and tables are in demand.

title: Begin Shows Firm Hand in Israeli Regime
description: JERUSALEM, July 2In his nearly two weeks as Prime Minister, Merahem Begin appears to have firmly grasped the reins of office and to have left little doubt that he expects his coalition Government to be a tightly knit one devoid of the news leaks that typified Israel's Labor Party regimes.

title: Solar Power Radiating Interest
description: CITIZEN interest in solar energy has blossomed across the state and thousands of Connecticut home owners contacted the Department of Planning and Energy Policy this year seeking information on its residential uses.

title: Green, U.S. Open Victor, Aims at British Crown
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland. July 2In pursuit of a transAtlantic double, Hubert Green, the new United States Open golf champion, arrived today at nearby Prestwick Airport. He then made the short journey down the rocky coast of Scotland to prepare for the British Open, which begins Wednesday on the Ailsa Course of the Turnberry Hotel Golf Club.

title: Football, a Summer Game: Jets Open Camp Thursday.
description: Football so soon?

title: 207171 Triumph Is 12th in 15 Meets
description: SOCHI, U.S.S.R., July 2(AP)Robert Gaines, Bill Collins, Jodi Anderson and the American men's 1,600meter relay team won gold medals today, but the Soviet Union defeated the United States, 207171, in their 15th dual track and field meet.

title: Cancer: What The State Is Doing
description: NEW JERSEY has been making haste slowly in coming to grips with cancer caused by environmental factors. With industry, especially the chemical industry, refusing to accept charges that it has helped to cause the state's high cancer rate. the state government has delayed mounting any real campaign against the disease, which has been killing about 14,000 New Jerseyans a year.

title: Jazz: The Dynamic Basie Band
description: Count Basie's orchestra is such an established institution that one does not expect it to change. And, in fact, it does not change except in very subtle ways

title: Mr. Adams Says Air Bags Are In
description: Though Ralph Nader still had some complaints, consumer groups and the insurance industry were pleased. Secretary of Transportation Brock Adams has issued an order requiring all automobiles to be equipped with air bags or automatic lap and shoulder restraints. Congress has 60 days in which to overturn the order; if it does not act, the passive restraint systems would become mandatory in standard and luxury cars by the 1982 model year and in all others by two years later.

title: 10 Hurt in Blast on Tanker
description: Ten persons were slightly injured yesterday morning in a gas explosion aboard a small oil tanker docked at the Bushey shipyard on Gowanus Creek at Court Street in Brooklyn, the police said. Eight of the injured were taken to Long Island College Hospital, where a spokesman said ai lthe injuries were minor. Two others were treated at the scene, the police said. The ship did not sustain any major damage, a spokesman at the snlpyard said.

title: Cassidy's Hunters Excel In Smithtown Show
description: STONY BROOK, L.I.,July 2Hugh Cassidy, a professional trainerdealer from Dix Hills, L. I., dominated the hunter divisions today at the Smithtown Hunt Horse Show at the Old Field Club.

title: A Year Later Son of Sam Still On Loose
description: The psychopathic killer, a staple of Hollywood melodramas, is equally fascinatingand frighteningin real life. Such a killer has roamed New York City for almost a year, leaving five persons dead and six wounded, and warning in bizarre notes of his obsession to murder again.

title: Elizabeth Vinal Sinnott, Art Student, Bride Of Walter Armstrong 3d, Ph.D.,Candidate
description: The Mount Holyoke College Chapel was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Elizabeth Vinal Sinnott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Sinnott of Lawrenceville, N.J., to Walter Preston Armstrong 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Armstrong Jr. of Memphis.

title: Beame Extends Jobs For 1,380 Elderly
description: Mayor Beame has announced the extension until September 1978 of the jobs of 1,380 elderly persons, which had been scheduled to end last Thursday. He said the city would use discretionary funds to keep the elderly working in positions such as community aides, counselor clerks, accountants, teachers, security aides and helpers at museums, libraries and zoos. The employees work 15 to 20 hours a week and earn $60 to $75.

title: For Rape, No Death Penalty
description: The Supreme Court ruled that the death penalty for rape of an adult is cruel and unusual punishment and is therefore unconstitutional.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Auto Racing

title: A Legend and His Family at a Crossroad
description: IT'S ONLY a closing date on a house, but to the New England Whalers, July 15 will mark a milestone in the hockey team's sixyear history. That is the day the Howe family from Detroit by way of Houstontakes title to a house on 16 acres in the lovely old Hartford suburb of Glastonbury.

title: Portuguese On L.I Fear For Identity
description: MINEOLA, L.LThis village has a PortugueseAmerican club, two Portuguese restaurants, three Portuguese provision stores, two Portuguese soccer teams and a church where a Portuguese mass is said each Sunday.

title: Lake Placid Show Set With a New Timetable
description: The Lake Placid horse show, which in the short space of six years has developed into one of the leading equestrian events in the country, gets underway for six days on Tuesday. This time. however, there is a change in the proceedings. Instead of stretching over the better part of two weeks, the show will run for only six days. For the past four years, the event had been run as a split show in an unusual scheduling system. The show ran a week and then, after Monday and Tuesday off for rest days, resumed on Wednesday. It concluded on Sunday with the Grand Prix for jumpers.

title: California Plans to Seed Clouds to Bring Rain
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2 (AP)California will begin emergency cloudseeding next Wednesday to try to make rain for parched northern California counties and help prevent forest fires.

title: A1 on the B1
description: President Carter's decision not to build the B1 bomber provided the finest moment of his brief Administrationnot just because of the decision itself but also because of the way he made it.

title: Bacon From $7 to $22 a Pound
description: IT used to be that the Washington Novel was written by exreporters such as Allen Drury and Fletcher Knebel; there would be a President, and some Senators, and a Mystery  certainly a Problem. Now the Washington Novel seems to have fallen to the actual former participants in Washing

title: S. B. Frankel fiance Of Ellen Perecman
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. George Perecman of Orange, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Perecman, to Stephen Baskin Frankel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Frankel of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Deaths
description: BABCOCKGordon H., formerly of Syosset, L.I. and Martinsville, N.J. Died on June 26 in Pearce, Arizona. He was prec?ded in death by his late wife, Isabel Atwell Babcock, Mr. Babcock was a retired executive of Metal & Thermit, inc. and attended The Loomis School and Princeton University when he was a member of the Cottage Club. Mr. Babcock's father, John R. Babcock, was ? Vice President of the old Guaranty Trust Co. of NY. He is survived by one sister, Mrs. Antonin (Dallas) Babcock Thlollier, Paris, France.

title: Hooks Takes Over at N.A.A.C.P. With Rousing Speech
description: ST. LOUIS, July 2With a rousing, sermonlike speech last night, Benjamin L. Hooks assumed the leadership of the National Association for the Advancement Pf Colored People and sent home in an optimlstic mood the 3,000 delegates to Its amaze convention.

title: Fire Claims 164th Victim
description: CINCINNATI, July 2 (AP)The fire claimed its 164th victim yesterday. Clarence Gripshover, 48, of Covington, an engineer with the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad, died of lung damage at Cincinnati General Hosptal's burn center.

title: David McCullough: I Liked the Research
description: Wearing his only suit, his only tie and a succession of infectious smiles, David McCullough paced around his New York hotel room, bubbling over with enthusiasm for the city, for Martha's Vineyard, where he lives, or his editor, his pub lisher, his wife and five children and, most of all, for the larger  than  life figures who populate his latest sprawling, historical panorama, on the Panama Canal, The Path Between the Seas (reviewed June 19).

title: Courtside Gurus Shape Tennis Winners
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2They are called coaches, managers, mentors, teachers, even gurus. They sit in on all the strategy sessions, enjoy choice seats for the big matches and receive recognition and publicity.

title: Education Group Denies Teacher Surplus Exists
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 2(AP)There is no teacher surplus in the United States, according to the National Education Association.

title: N.A.S.L. Seeing an Exodus of Coaches
description: Dennis Viollet, the only coach in the fouryear history of the Washington Diplomats, resigned last week and became the fifth coach in the North American Soccer League to do so this season. Of the five coaches, Eddie Firmani of the Tampa Bay Rowdies was the only one who resigned while his team was winning. Along with Viollet. the coaches with losing records at the time of their departures were Eckhard Kratzum of the Vancouver Whitecaps; Bill Foulkes of the Chicago Sting and Bobby Thomson of the Connecticut Bi

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: ALL of us, at one time or another, have missed the brass ring. We have overlooked opportunities to be wealthy, happy, well thought ofall those important things.

title: Petition Filing This Week to Test Early Strength of Mayoral Hopefuls
description: In the first test of their organizational and electoral strength for the Sept. 8 priMary, seven Democratic and two Republicans mayoral hopefuls will be filing designating petitions this week to qualify for the primary ballot.

title: Popular Teacher Strives to Practice What He Teaches
description: He's known to father and son (he has taught both) for his quickie quiz. Through the years no one has known when to expect it because it is never announced

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIn a shift toward higher risks, the Government agency that insures corporate investments in developing countries is asking Congress to let it lend its own money for minerals development.

title: Lighting a Fire in the Barbecue Business
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill.  It resembles a cartoonist's fantasy of creature from outer space: three legs, no body, four eyes, bulging forehead and an antenna on top.

title: Seabrook Nuclear Foes to Meet
description: HAMPTON, N.H., July 2 (UPI)Memhers of the Clamshell Alliance will meet later this month to decide if they will stage another occupation of the Seabrook nuclear power plant site. The alliance, a coalition of New England groups opposed to nuclear power has organized two major occupations in the last 10 months that have resulted in the arrests of nearly 1,600 persons. Groups will meet July 1617 to discuss the possibility of a third major occupation.

title: Bistate Exchange On Culture Gains
description: INFORMAL talks have been initiated by a member of the State Council on the Arts with Mayor Beame of New York about an exchange program that would see the New Jersey Ballet performing in Manhattan and the New York City Ballet appearing in the Garden State.

title: GARDENING
description: GARDEN pests and diseases have obviously never heard of summer vacations. Their activity during the summer months necessitates careful observation to detect the first signs of their presence. If detected early, most are rather easily controlled, often without the need for pesticies.

title: GRUMMAN WILL AID AVIATION EDUCATION
description: BETHPAGE, La.The Board of Cooperative Educational Services and the Grumman Aerospace Corporation have joined in a program that will enable students in the aviation trades to obtain their training on the grounds of Grumman, one of the country's largest aircraft companies.

title: THE YANKEE FROM GEORGIA
description: In the unlikely setting of the deepest South, there stepped forth this Puritan in blue jeans, Jimmy Carter, an epitome of traits the nation had misplaced.

title: Arlene Levy Engaged To Timothy Leisman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm P. Levy of Lido Beach, L.I. and Hollywood, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Arlene Susan Levy, to Timothy Mark Leisman, son of William F. Leisman Jr. of Weston, Mass.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Every year, more than 45,000 lives are lost on our nation's roadways, including some 10,000 pedestrians and an estimated 1,000 bicyclists. In New Jersey alone, the grave statistics during the 1976 Fourth of July weekend involved 19 vehicular victims.

title: Group Says Citizens Demand Wider Role In Their Governance
description: WASHINGTON, July 2While Americans may not vote in great numbers they increasingly are directly involved in government and are seeking still more direct participation, according to a report released today.

title: Voters to Rule On Court Reform
description: It took months, of politics, but a court reorganization program finally was passed for the necessary second time by the New York State Legislature. Now the voters will decide how much change they want when the package is presented to them in November.

title: TV Blinks at the State
description: ONE cold Tuesday evening last January, the NBCTV news team was in stitches over a story about how ducks survived the winter. The next story was supposed to concern the settlement of a strike in New Brunswick, but the news team apparently felt that New Jersey stories were about as funny as duck stories.

title: Deborah Ross to Wed Sept.24
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Ross of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ross, to Philippe Dauman, son of Mr, and Mrs. Henri Dauman, also of New York.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I could not read your article on returning to college without adding my experiences, in hope of helping some other middleage student who might be contemplating a return.

title: The Santa Maria Is a Ship With a Cargo of History
description: History and nautical buffs and 2,000 schoolchildren glimpsed life before the mast in the 15th century when they toured a copy of the Santa Maria tied up at the National Maritime Historical Society at Brooklyn's Fulton Street in a fourday visit recently.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Am I getting old? Unreasonable? Irritable? Maybe even eccentric? Obviously I don't think so but I do have doubts. The thing is, I don't want to see any more World War II movies for at least a month. Make that six weeks and classify it as R & It This season I've slogged through the Allied defeat Anthem in Joseph E. Levine's A Bridge Too Far. In MacArthur I was holed up with the General on Corregidor for weeks before finally being forced (against my will) abandon the Rock to go into testy exile in Australia. I then fought my way up through New Guinea and the Philippines Japan where I decreed the formation of a labor movement and gave Japanese women the right to.vote.
