Just when I was getting bored by being so uplifting, I received a reprieve. That is, the Korean War or, as Mac himself calls it in the movie, One last gift to an old soldier.

title: Alan Kluger, Analyst, to Marry Nancy Gail Schrager
description: The engagement of Nancy Gail Schrager to Alan M. Kluger of New York, son of Mrs. Morris Kluger of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Kluger, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Schrager of Greenburgh, N. Y

title: INTERVIEW
description: SO FAR as Alfred N. Beadleston, the dean of the New Jersey Legislature, is concerned, the voters do not pay enough attention to Trenton. If they paid more, the Red Bank Republican says, some of the people running the government might not be there.

title: Soviet Yiddish Stories
description: Ashes Out of Hope, the fifth volume of Yiddish literature in translation on which Irving Howe and Eliezer Greenberg have collaborated, contains five stories by three SovietYiddish writers, David Ber

title: Computer Crime Costs $300 Million a Year
description: WASHINGTONThe increasing dependence of practically every element of society on computers to transfer funds and store information has in turn bred a new type of sophisticated thief who is presenting law enforceanent officials with a technological update of the calculated crime.

title: Day Care:A Business Proposal
description: ALL the talk today about equal rights for women in business saturates us to the point of boredom. What is being done inside the corporation to accomplish equal rights for women? A push for equal jobs with equal pay as well as quota hiring of mindrity workers.

title: The Cultural Cornucopia to the North
description: A few years ago, when Eugene Ormandy was conducting a series of performances by his Philadelphia Orchestra at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., the maestro complained that a nearby waterfall was drowning out soft passages of music. Eager to please, festival officials spent a quarter of a million dollars for a device to divert the stream during concerts, so that the waterfall can be, in effect turned off.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This analysis is based on reyorts from representative wholesalers and chains with more than 10,000 outlets in the United States.

title: Court Accord Is Anticlimax To Bitter Fight
description: ALBANY, July 2Talk about ending with a whimper. The twohouse agreement early this week to put the three proposed courtreorganization amendments on the November ballot has to rate as one of the great anticlimaxes of the session. It brought to a quiet, if temporary, end some 14 months of legislative maneuvering, countless perorations by Governor Carey and enough editorialpace ink to paint a black line down the middle of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.

title: American Derby Won By Silver
description: CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)Silver Series defeated Run Dusty Run by a head in the $104,800 American Derby at Arlington Park today to establish himself as No. 2 among 3yearolds behind undefeated Seattle Slew.

title: POLITICS
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE adopted the image of a toughminded loner during the recent primary election campaign, and he appears to be having a difficult time dropping the role.

title: Connecticut /This Week
description: ART

title: Jenifer Neils fiancee Of J. H. McInerney Jr.
description: Henry Eugene Neils of Wayzata, Minn., and Bozeman, Mont., and Mrs. Henry Doerr of Minnetonka Beach, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jenifer Neils, to James Harvey McInerney Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McInerney of Greenwich, Conn., and Wianrio, Mass.

title: The Energetic Role of the Energy Panel
description: WASHINGTONThe President was upset. He telephoned Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and asked whether he should go on television to denounce two House committees that he felt had gutted his energy package. Mr. O'Neill advised the President to relax because neither of the votes had come as a surprise to the House Democratic leadership, nor were they final. Both would probably be reversed, he told Mr. Carter, by the time the energy package emerged from the House's newly appointed Ad Hoc Select Committee on Energy.

title: News Summary
description: To show its support for the Government of President Elias Sarkis of Lebanon. the Carter Administration proposes to provide $100 million in military aid to help establish a Lebanese light infanty force that would be used to maintain internal order. The Administration has been holding unpublicized consultations with Congress. Alfred L. Atherton Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, said that the Administration was only consulting with Congress on the advisability of the proposal and had not definitely decided to go ahead with it. [Page 1, Col. 6.]

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY of the houses in this area have cedar shakes or shingles around the outside, and the question of how to finish or coat these wood shingles is often a perplexing problem for the home owner. Should he use a paint or a stain or just a clear preservative? Or can he just leave the shingles untreated, since cedar is widely recommended as a rotresistant wood that really needs no protection?

title: Mary Theo Tuomey And Stephen Hayes Planning Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. T. Douglas Tuomey Jr. of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Theo Tuomey, to Stephen Austin Hayes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Webb Cook Hayes 3d, of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: FRENCH APLANT LEAKAGE SAID TO POSE NO DANGER
description: PIERRELATTE, France, July 2 (Reuters) Officials of a nuclearfuel processing plant from which radioactive gas leaked yesterday said today that the gas had posed no serious danger.

title: OutofOrder Meters
description: Every day, about 20,000 of the parking meters on New York City streets are out of order, city auditors said. Harrison J. Goldin, the City Comptroller, said this deprives the city of about $4 million a year. So Mr. Goldin said he was withholding $554,000 in payments to the Mebco Maintenance Corporation, which receives $4.83 a month for maintaining each of the city's more than 67,000 onstreet meters, until the Department of Traffic calculates precisely what penalty should be imposed.

title: Molly's Booming Salute to July 4th
description: Tonight, under cover of darkness, the men of the New Boston (N. H.) Artillery Company will put Molly Stark back together again. Tomorrow morning, bright and early, they'll have all 1,300 pounds of her down at the intersection of State Routes 77 and 136, ready for the Grand Parade. And sometime before noon, on the field behind Town Hall, Molly will speak her piece in celebration of Independence Dayan earsplitting, windowrattling roar that was first heard two centuries ago.

title: Newport Jazz: Gato Barbieri Is Irresistible
description: Gato Barbieri, the tenor saxophonist from Argentina who was catapulted into the pop music limelight when he composed music for the film Last Tango in Paris, always seems to make something special of his NewportNew York Jazz Festival appearances. He does not play unusual repertory or add members to his group, as many other musicians do, but he does bring a particularly intense brand of energy to the festival, and energy is perhaps the central focus of his performances.

title: From Exile To Fame
description: His Life in Part

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Time off for the threeday holiday weekend.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: TASTES DIFFER. Lucretius, way back in the first century B.C., recognized that. What is food to one may be fierce poison to others, he agreed. And beauty is in the eye (or nose) of the beholder. Such bromides are old as the Berkshires, and as true. Take privet. My husband has an intense aversion to it. I feel a tenderness bordering on puppy love where it's concerned.

title: H. B. Lowell, Miss McClure Are Engaged
description: The engagement of Kathleen Louise McClure to Howard Brokaw Lowell has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Douglas O. McClure of Princeton, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is a son of Mrs. Harry A. Brooks of New York and Glen Head, L.L, and James R. Lowell Jr. of Manhasset, LI., and a descendant of James Russell Lowell, the poet.

title: SHOP TALK
description: SOMETIMES a shop has more to offer than the wares on display. Perhaps its something extra has meaning for the outsider, curious about a world beyond the seas, or for those whose reminiscences coincide with the items contained within its sphere.

title: J. Christian Sletvold Becomes the Fiance Of Patricia Bryant
description: Mr. and Mrs. John G. Bryant of Radnor, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Lee Bryant, to J. Christian Sletvold of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, son of Mrs. Kristian L. Sletvold of Oslo and the late Dr. Kristian L. Sletvold.

title: Suspect Is Denied Bail
description: SARASOTA, Fla.,July 2County Judge Edwin Cummer denied bond today for Wilfred Bannister, 33, who is charged with kidnaping and involuntary sexual battery in the Charlotte Grosse abduction. Arraignment was set for July 11.

title: Improving On Mother Nature
description: Photosynthesis, the process by which green plants make carbohydrates from carbon dioxide and water, is only about one to three percent efficient. New research into part of that process may offer promise of raising the efficiency of photosynthesis toward its theoretical maximum of about 13 percent.

title: ART
description: MATERIALS can be incidental to the expression an artist is attempting to achieve. The artist may simply use them as the best means to an end, but the means always remain subordinate in the essence of the completed work. This is not the case with Caroline Kaplowitz, whose sculptures are on view at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts.

title: Court Thwarts Bid To Block Tax Roll With 211 Ministers
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y.,July 2An attempt to prevent an upstate Town Assess?? who granted taxexempt status to 211 ordained ministers of the Universal Life Church from filing his final tax roll was thwarted this week by a decision of a State Supreme Court justice.

title: Patricia Ann Doran Wed To Gilles Oliver Einstein
description: Patricia Ann Doran, daughter of Maj. Thomas J. Doran, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Doran of Aurora, Colo., was married yesterday to Gilles Cliver Einstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst Einstein of Mountainside, N. J. The ceremony was performed in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church, Camp St. Malo, Allenspark, Colo.

title: A Touch of Classics
description: From Madame Bovary to Monsieur Beaucaire, filmmakers have demonstrated an enduring infatuation with the classicseven though literary purists customarily greet the results of their fervor with a mixture of disbelief and outrage. There have been exceptions to the rule of desecration, of course, such as David Lean's Oliver Twist, George Cukor's Little Women and Tony Richardson's Tom Jones, each of which managed to please both the academicians and the popcornmunchers.

title: I IN AMERICA
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif. he six young women, highschool juniors and seniors, sat on deep, cushy pillows in the room where, as volunteer counselors, they lead rap sessions on contraception for the Planned Parenthood Association of Marin County. They were talking in astonished tones about the sophistication in matters sexual manifested these days by eighth and ninth graders, some of whom turn up at the Planned Parenthood clinic here for contraceptive guidance. The world was certainly changing, they agreed. Long ago  two years or three  when they were that age, the undertow and currents and eddies of sex were not nearly as powerful or immediate as they've since become.

title: Carolyn De Witt Is Engaged
description: Mildred G. De Witt of Kingston, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Carolyn Kerr De Witt, to Robert Francis Koenig, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Koenig, of Jackson, Miss. The wedding is planned for Aug. 20 in St. John's Episcopal Church, Kingston. Miss De Witt is managing editor of National Petroleum News, a McGrawHill magazine. Her late father, John Warren De Witt was a lawyer in Kingston. Mr. Koenig is an industrial engineer who heads his own consulting firm.

title: Another Panther Comes Home
description: Once able to terrify white America and even many blacks with only their rhetoric, the Black Panthers now appear decidedly tame. Last week, the metamorphosis was underscored when Huey P. Newton. a cofounder of the Panthers, announced that he felt sufficiently comfortable with the political climate in the United States to return after 2 years in Cuba to stand trial for murder in California.

title: 4 Cases of Bubonic Plague Listed in U.S. This Year
description: ATLANTA, July 2 (AP)Four cases of human bubonic plague have been reported to the national Center for Disease Control this year.

title: Energy Bill Gains and Moves Along
description: After two months of debate and the close attentions of three committees (Ways and Means, Ccmmerce and Banking, the Carter energy package has emerged from the House in not too bad shape, despite the contradictory pressures of regional interests, political philosophy and industry lobbying.Last week the Administration gained some ground but also had some close calls.

title: TV VIEW
description: Ten years ago, the British Broadcasting Corporation unveiled a weekly series that ran for six months and, within the space of a few years, dramatically changed the terrain of TV entertainment. Based on the novels of John Galsworthy, The Forsyte Saga was produced by Donald Wilson. Its 26 episodes were eventually shown in 55 countries, from Russia to Zambia, where they generated an unprecedented degree of audience loyalty. In England, churches were obliged to reschedule traditional evening services to avoid overlapping with the TV serial. One canon genially explained: I am not saying that worship is less important than television, but there is no reason why we cannot enjoy both.

title: Without the B1, a Lot of Responsibility Rests With the Cruise
description: WASHINGTONOn Thursday morning, moments before Prsident Carter began his news conference, a short bespectacled figure opened the rear door of the auditorium and slipped inside. He walked toward the first row and sat in an empty seat next to a reporter. Defense Secretary Harold Brown, who helped initiate the design and study of the B1 bomber in the late 1960'sand was an early proponent of the planewas on hand to watch the decision to abort it. If Mr. Brown played the key role in the decision that some of his aides claim, the factor that swayed the Defense Secretary, and certainly President Carter, was a new, relatively inexpensive and oddshaped little weapon that can be launched from the air, ground or sea and can carry nuclear warheads: the cruise missile. It was cited by Mr. Carterand by Mr. Brown on Fridayas the fundamental reason for abandoning the B1 program, one of the most expensive, and most controversial weapons systems the Pentagon has undertaken.

title: Rookie Leads by 3 Shots InMilwaukee Golfat136
description: MILWAUKEE, July 2 (AP)Keith Fergus, a sandyhaired Texan bidding to become the first rookie to win on the Professional Golfers Association tour this year, carded a fiveunderpar 67 today and moved into a threestroke lead after two rounds of the Greater Milwaukee open.

title: Newport Is for Plebeians
description: NEWPORT, R.I.Staring idly at the tiny screen recently, I was interested to see that John Kenneth Galbraith and Richard M. Nixon had been thinking about Newport, the very place where I happened to be watching them. Neither of them liked it very much.

title: White Driver Rams Klan Rally in Plains, Injuring 30
description: PLAINS, Ga., July 2A young white man drove a speeding car into the speaker's platform. at a Ku Klux Klan rally in President Carter's home town tonight, injuring more than 30 persons.

title: THE OTHER CARY GRANT
description: Being handsome, elegant and everybody's favorite is not enough. Even this legendary leading man has problems he cannot seem to solve.

title: Harry Hairspray Will Not Do
description: DAN RATHER'S precocious autobiography and Ron Powers's indignant study of broadcast news as show business raise some perplexing questions about television journalism and what it may be doing to us all. Powers is chiefly concerned with the Harry Hairspray school of local broadcastingand how it got that way. Rather's province is the wide world. His own solid reporting achievements and his thoughts on the hazards of celebrity lend distinction to his account of a notable career. Now transformed from White House correspondent to anchorman on the CBS magazine programs, Sixty Minutes and Who's Who, Rather is made uneasy by his new status:

title: Shortstop Surprises Tigers With Clout
description: Fred Stanley has spent most of the season on the bench watching Bucky Dent play shortstop. Yesterday at the Stadium, Dent was on the bench watching as Stanley chipped a tworun homer into the leftfield seats to break a tie and propel the Yankees past the Detroit Tigers, 64.

title: FISHING
description: THE offshore fishing looks good this week. The first swordfish have been caught on hookandline off Shinnecock and this king of the sport fish should provide fine action for the next couple of weeks. White marlin have been spotted. The season's first mako sharks have been landed off the South Shore and shark fishing overall is super.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., July 2 (AP)Fred Dixon and Fred Samara, both of Closter, N.J., and both members of the 1976 United States Olympic team, head the entries for the Amateur Athletic Union's national decathlon championship next Saturday and Sunday at Indiana University.

title: Kotchian Calls Himself The Scapegoat
description: BURBANK, Calif.A. Carl Kotchian, who helped save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy and went on to become one of the central figures in an international bribery scandal that shook the governments of three countries is growing alfalfa and trying to raise funds for the Salvation Army these days.

title: Nixon Tapes No Longer Nixon's
description: The Supreme Court, in a decision that paves the way for ultimate public access to the Presidential papers and lape recordings of Richard M. Nixon, upheld a 1974 law giving the Government rather than Mr. Nixon control of the materials. The former President had challenged the law as unconstitutional.

title: U.S. IS WEIGHING PLAN TO PROVIDE WEAPONS FOR LEBANESE FORCE
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Carter Administration has begun unpublicized consultations with Congress on providing about $100 million in military aid to Lebanon to help the warravaged country create a light infantry force to maintain internal order.

title: CRIME
description: A few years ago there were several series of historical mysteries out at the same time. By now nearly all have disappeared, though Francis Selwyn's Sergeant Verity, the Victorian cop, is still around. A new entrant has just appeared: CAPTAIN NASH AND THE WROTH INHERITANCE by Ragan Butler (St. Martin's, $7.95). Additional Captain Nash books, says the Publisher, are in the works.

title: Gandhis, Long Holders of Power, Now Find It Used Against Them
description: NEW DELHI, July 2How the mighty have fallen commented an onlooker at the Delhi airport the other day as the police prevented Sanjay Gandhi, son of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, from boarding a flight to Bombay.

title: Hebrew, Arabic and Death
description: YEHUDA AMICHAI is Israel's bestknown living poet. His work is so volatileheartburdened, ironic, sometimes terribly funny, sometimes very gentle and tenderthat I was about call it archetypally Jewish. It isn't; it's archetypally poetic. In Amen, his third book to appear in English, Amichai reaches pure states of intimate, aroused awareness unusually often. As in, say, Plath or Esenin or Vallejo, the best poems present themselves with simple immediacy even when their sense is elusive or complex:

title: Questions/Answers
description: I would like to increase my plantings of thornless blackberries. How can I do it? M.I., Boiling Springs, Pa.

title: Bradley Is Sworn in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2 (UPI)Tom Bradley was sworn in yesterday for a second fouryear term of the nation's third largest city, and in an outdoor ceremony at City Hall he pledged to pursue continued racial harmony. Mr. Bradley, 59 years old, who wore a bulletproof vest for the ceremony on the advice of ms security detail, called on citizens to resolve here and now to devote our energies to peaceful and responsible compliance with any final court order on school integration.

title: Story of an East Side Policeman Who Turned In Fellow Officers
description: When Police Officer Robert Ellis took the witness stand to testify in a recent Manhattan robbery case he said he saw a fellow officer from the Ninth Precinct who was in the courtroom run a finger across his throat, threatening retaliatoin.

title: Slain Policeman
description: Officer Robert Mandel and a fellow New York plainclothes policeman were trying to arrest a man for narcotics sales at a Brooklyn tavern last April when the suspect fatally shot Officer MandeL The police charged 24yearold Carlos Antonio Edghill with the slaying and said that eight hours before the shooting he had been released on $500 bail on a gun charge.

title: David Schirmer Jr. Weds Valerie Calderon
description: Valerie Forbes Calderon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor M. Calderon of Sarasota, Fla., formerly of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to David Austin Schirmer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. David Austin Schirmer of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Shipshape for Centuries
description: THE maritime history of Connecticut's second largest urban area is well into its fourth century. To most of the 500,000 in habitants of the Greater New Haven area, the city's bustling waterfront is well off the beaten path. But to thousands whose livelihood depends directly or indirectly on the Port df New Haven's shipping traffic, the harbor, about three miles from Long Island Sound, is of extreme importance.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: TOMORROW is July 4, our 201st birthday. There will be considerably less fevered hoopla than we went through last year at this time when we celebrated the Bicentennial. As a matter of fact, we can get back to oldfashioned Fourths from now until 2026, when we will be 250 years old. You can file this piece as the first reminder of that great milestone in our national history.

title: West Germany, in Midlife, Fails to See Its Strength
description: BONNWest Germany has come of age not the prime of life, indeed, but premature middle age, a time of social and political aches and pains, reduced economic expectations and anxiety about the years to come.

title: A Startling No
description: At about 9:30 last Thursday morning President Carter called Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill. Secretary of Defense Harold Brown was on the phone to Gen. George S. Brown of the Joint Chiefs.

title: Fashion on the Run
description: I THINK it was the first warm weekend morning this year I discovered them. As I threw open the sash, I first thought an army of occupation had arrived from the Planet Dacron. Slowly I discerned familiar faces. Why, these are my normally mildmannered neighborsprancing about in the season's latest warmup fashions looking like upended, Italian racing cars; striped, twoand threetoned; top and bottom, shoes, goggles and metal flaked helmets. Joggers, bikers, tennis and squash aficionados, bedazzling bizarre in colors that can only he captured (and intensified) through the magic of polyester. The citizenry of Larchmont had been colorpolarized, as is done to photos on rock albums and posters.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: NAKED ANGELS, by John Tytell. (McGrawHill, $3.95.) A critic assesses the Beat Generation of the 50's by taking a close look at the lives and works of three of its most prominent writersWilliam Burroughs, Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg. Despite lapses into hagiography and blurbery, this Book Review's appraiser concluded, the result was strong, urgent, ultimately thrilling.

title: BRIDGE
description: IF MEMBERS of contract bridge teams had to be related to each. other, a Long Island family named Pollenz would have a very good chance of becoming world champions. Ralph Pollenz of Wantagh and Emmett Pollenz of East Meadow, who are brothers, have long been two of the topranked players in Nassau County. Emmett's wife, Joan, has also won many titles. And in the last few years the teenage members of the family have been making a powerful impact on tournaments in the metropolitan area.

title: Soviet Opens Maneuvers To 5 Western Countries
description: MOSCOW, July 2 (Reuters)Military observers from five Western European countries have been invited to watch Soviet Army and Air Force exercises in the western Ukraine later this month,it was officially announced today.

title: A Boy Grows Up And Renounces Fantasies of Youth
description: I recently came upon two photographs of myself at about age 7. In both I am dressed in a Brooklyn Dodgers uniform and standing in front of my house on Bedford Avenue, a few miles from Ebbets Field and the towering rightfield wall tend screen over which home runs soared so majestically.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In yesterday's Times, Rabbi Marc H. Tanenbaum was identified as the executive director of the American Jewish Committee. Rabbi Tanenbaum is actually national interreligious affairs director of the committee.

title: A Jewel of a Festival
description: GRIMM with a grin, Berlioz with birds, Mozart in the rain. All were part of the total landscape last weekend as the 32d Caramoor season opened in Katonah. Caramoor is unquestionably the jewel of outdoor festivals in the area, so it was hardly surprising to find a sizable contingent of Connecticut musiclovers joining their Westchester counterparts to partake of the manifold joys, and occasional grievances, of the first three concerts.

title: CHESS
description: Atough match competitor is a player undiscouraged by an early loss who continues to give his best in every game.

title: Touring Yesterday In Today's Peekskill
description: A JOYFUL play of shapes and forms, said Peekskill architect Frank Dushin as he walked along street of this old northern Westchester city, gesturing toward first one house and quickly to another as he talked about the city's architecture. The city's face, made up of scores of late 19th century houses, has sagged some over the years under the weight of age and illf itting aluminum siding and it has become a bit furrowed by adversity, he noted.

title: DONOR, 91, RECALLS HER FRESH AIR DAYS
description: When Minnie Nikola was 9 years old, she left her home in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn for the first time for a twoweek visit in the country with a Pennsylvania family she did not know.

title: BRIDGE
description: Some 15 years ago the American Contract Bridge League adopted a suggestion of mine which has since proved very popular. For certain pair contests, most notably the continentwide charity game, the hands are preanalyzed by experts and printed analysis sheets are available to all players immediately after play is concluded. Partners can go in search of refreshment and use the analysis sheet as a silent arbiter in their postmortems.

title: EIGHT FIREMEN INJURED AS A TENEMENT BURNS
description: Eight firemen were injured, one of them critically, yesterday afternoon in a fouralarm fire that raced through a vacant sixstory, tenement on Eighth Street, between Avenues C and D in lower Manhattan.

title: Abortion Bill: Not Yet Final
description: Proponents of abortionondemand expected little from the Senate, and that may turn out to he just about what they got. Voting two weeks after the House decided to ban the use of Federal funds for all abortions without exception, the Senate passed a less restrictive bill that permitted Medicaid to pay for the operation under three conditions: when the mother's life is in danger, in cases of rape or incest, and when the abortion is medically necessary.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The first Boy Scout merit badge for coin collecting was awarded in 1938, and recently that organization announced the awarding of the 300,000th merit badge for this activity.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Erma Bombeck
description: Erma Bombeck sounded both harried and amused. She had spent much of the morning, she said, trying to cajole her Yorkshire terrier, Murray, into swallowing a small yellow pill. But Murray had other ideas

title: The Logic of Illogic in France
description: PARIS Among French political characteristics now obtruding increasingly as the electoral season approaches are an obsession with logic, especially that derived from formulations of the philosopher Descartes, and a tacit recognition that this pleasant country only functions comfortably with a strong leader at the helm.

title: The Divisions In Communism
description: The Soviet Union's denunciation of Eurocommunism, an attempt to recapture ideological primacy for Moscow, may have only sharpened its differences with other European parties. The principal target of the condemnation, the Spanish Communist leader, Santiago Carrillo, compared Soviet policymakers with the 16th century inquisitors of the Roman Catholic Church and said they had forgotten that the Communist movement is no longer a church and Moscow is no longer Rome.

description: NORTHPORT

description: AT MILWAUKEE GREATER MILWAUKEE OPEN

title: Hoffman Defeats Boggs In Swedish Diving Final
description: RONNEBY, Sweden, July 3 (AP)Falk Hoffman of East Germany beat the Olympic champion, Phil Boggs, 633.90 points to 623.20, today in the men's final.of the Swedish Cup springboard diving event.

title: DONALD BASTIAN
description: DETROIT, July 3 (AP)Services will be held Thuriday for Donald Bastian, vice president of Ford Motor Company's manufacturing group, whO died yesterday at the eke of 62.

title: Guard Takes Over Struck Jails
description: MADISON, Wis., July 3 (UPI)  National guard troops were ordered to Wisconsin's prisons today to replace prison guards and maintain order because of a strike by the 24,000member Wisconsin State Employees Union. The union, representing employees who include clerks, bluecollar workers, prison guards, social workers and the State Patrol, struck at midnight after three days of mediation failed to produce a new contract.

title: 5% JOBLESSNESS GOAL HELD HARD FOR CARTER TO REACH
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI)  President Carter is unlikely to achieve his goal of cutting the unemployment rate to below 5 percent by 198], according to a Brookines Institution analysis released today.

title: 5% PRICE INCREASES BY SAUDIS AND U.A.E. END OIL CARTEL SPLIT
description: BEIRUT, July 3Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates today announced a 5 percent increase in the price of their oil, thus bringing to an end the oil price split that has plagued the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for the last six months.

title: Tennis
description: Second RoundJeff PaceII, Sands Point, L.I defeated Martin Mfcmorale, Stewart Manor, L.I., 6.0, 6.0; Raymond Nisi, New Rochelle. N.Y., defeated Mike Palumbo, Babylon, L.I., 3.6, 6.0, 62; Ed Raheb, Brooklyn, defeated Nick Viesti, Nov York, 64, 6.4; Steve Fink, Williamsville, N.Y., defeated Paul Williams, Westfield, N.J. 6.0, 6.1.

title: Water Surrounds Thirsty Town
description: RINGWOOD, N.J.Back when the Indians roamed this valley in the foothills of the Ramapos, they called the region Wyanockie, which meant sassafras place. Later, with the coming of the settlers and their big country homes and small summer bungalows, the place was renamed Lakeland, after all the rivers, streams, ponds and lakes that dot these rolling hills of northern New Jersey.

title: Diane C. Tannenbaum Bride Of Dr. Wayne H. Wertheim
description: In Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L.I., yesterday evening, Diane C. Tannenbaum, daughter of Mr. and.. Mrs. Paul H. Tannenbaum, became the bride of Dr. Wayne H. Wertheim, son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Marvin Wertheim. Both families live in East Hills; L. I. Rabbis Joseph Sternstein and Ario Hyams officiated.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST $5,000, pace, el., mile.

title: A Meaning for Europe
description: BRUSSELSIn a dangerous world, where our vision of freedom is often frustrated, many of us in the West have paid scant attention to iome genuine good news in Europe.. In the last few years three countries have shaken off authoritarian dictatorships. Greece, Portugal and Spain now have elected Democratic governments and live under the rule of law.

title: AS GOODMAN SEES IT MRS. ABM VS. HIM
description: Roy M. Goodman, the organization Republican candidate for Mayor of New York City, predicted the winner of the sevencandidate Demccratic primary yesterday and said he could beat her.

title: Britain Testing A Way to Teach Young Gypsies
description: DONN1NGTON, EnglandElvina Dent, a brighteyed, 9yearold gypsy, sat at a schoolroom table here, at the edge of Britain's industrial Midlands, turning over the pieces of a learning game. It may have been her first experience with school. No one knew for sure.

title: Israeli Ire About Orthodoxy Rises
description: TEL AVIV, July 3Renewed religious tensions among Jews were sparked this weekend when a 22yearold passenger in a jeep was killed as it crashed through a toad barrier closing off a street. on Saturday, the sabbath.

title: Pitkin Avenue: Its Old Glory Hard to Discern Amid Blight
description: There are days, more and more of them lately, when Dr. Karl Hirschfeld stands outside his optometrist's shop on Pitkin Avenue in. Brooklyn and remembers how things used to be.

title: Tenant Held in Murder
description: A 70yearold woman was raped and strangled by a man who lived in the basement of her home in Newtonville in Atlantic County, the police said. They reported that Robert Killing, 3g; entered the woman's room sometime late Friday and attacked Mrs. Patricia Speight. He was arrested yesterday.

title: Saturday Night's Games
description: MILWAUKEE (A.)

title: Turkish Premier Quits After Test
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 3 (AP) Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey resigned today after his 10dayold centerleft Government was defeated on its first vote of confidence in Parliament by a coalition of rightist parties.

title: Jazz: New York Repertory Unit In EldridgeHines Retrospective
description: The basic problem in recreating jazz groups of the past, particularly big bands, was pinpointed at the Newport Jazz Festival on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall when the New York Jazz Repertory Company presented a retrospective program dealing with the work of Rov Eldridge and Earl Hines.

title: MEDICAL EXAMINERS SCORE ALBANY BILL
description: A bill that was supposed to make it easier for medical schools to Wain cadavers is under attack by medical examiners around New York State, who contend that a lastminute rider added surreptitiously will make it difficult for them to conduct autopsies.

title: HARD LINE EXPECTED FROM CITY UNIONS
description: During its extended fiscal crisis, New York City receivedand the city administration has acknowledgedsignificant cooperation and assistance from its municipal unions, but Mayor Beame or new mayor may face difficult contract negotiations next year.

title: Soccer
description: Los Angeles 4, Cosmos 1. Connecticut 5, Las Vegas 4 (overtime). Dallas 2, Chicago 1. San Jose 3, Toronto 0. ATLANTIC CONFERENCE Eastern Division

title: 2 Nations Will Finance East African Community
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 3 (Reuters)Uganda and Tanzania have agreed to finance the continued operation of services of the East African Community for three months, the Uganda radio said today.

title: A Capitol Crime
description: Surely it is time to stop all the foolishness, once and for all, about extending the West Front of the Capitol. This dangerous Congressional boondoggle has now surfaced three times, and the idea doesn't improve with revival. The proposal is to expand the Capitol to gain some additional space by building a new front in front of the old front, which itself has structural problems.

description: 110foot Barba Negra, a Canadian Barkentine, passing World Trade Center

title: FIRE UNION ASKS INQUIRY ON RESPONSE TO A BLAZE
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association has called for an investigation into the time it took the Fire Department to respond to a blaze Saturday on the Lower East Side in which eight firemen were injured, one critically.

title: Jazz Events
description: Following is a schedule of todays Newport Jazz. FestivalNew York events:

title: News Summary
description: Permission from the White House to give shelter in the United States to 15,000 stranded Indochinese, who fled Vietnam, Cambodia and LaoS is being sought by the State Department. Officials said the White House was sympathetic to the urgent request, but had not made a response, apparentlyin deference to influential members of Congress who oppose further entry of Indochinese without specific legislation. The Attorney General could use his emergency parole authority to admit the refugees, but in practice this is not done without the consent of Senate and House leaders. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Grich Has Surgery
description: ORANGE, Calif., July 3 (UPI)Bobby Grich, California Angel shortstop, underwent a twohour operation at St. Joseph's Hospital today for removal of a herniated disk from his spine. Grich, 28 years old, is expected to be lost for the baseball season. He will spend five days in the hospital and two weeks at home resting, and then will begin therapy.

title: Houston Seeks to Save its Toad
description: HOUSTON, July 3A Government wildlife consultant has declared a 35squaremile area of Houston critical habitat for the Houston toad, an endangered species, placing the twoinch amphibian in conflict with real estate developers.

title: Pope Deplores Crime
description: ROME, July 3 (Reuters) Pope Paul VI today again ignored the defiance of Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre and spoke instead of crime that humiliates us and afflicts us.

title: Two More Women In Firecracker 400
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 3 (AP) Two European women drivers, Lelia Lombardi and Christine Beckers, were among 21 drivers who qualified their cars on the last day of qualifying today for tomorrow's $175,000 Firecracker 400 stock car race. A third female driver, Janet Guthrie, secured a berth in time trials yesterday.

title: Antiseptic Don Ellis Orchestra And an Infectious George Duke
description: Don Ellis's Orchestra appeared at the Newport Jazz Festival on Saturday night after an absence of several years, during which the leader fought and overcame a serious illness. The orchestra looked impressive on the stage, with all its members dressed in white, and complete string and percussion sections in addition to brass and woodwinds. Unfortunately, looks and ntiseptically clean ensemble playing were the most impressive things about it.

title: Brezhnev Sends Note On Independence Day
description: MOSCOW, July 3 (Routers) Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, today sent President Carter a message of congratulations and best wishes to the American People on Independence day.

title: 1,500 Welcome Huey Newton Before He Is Arrested
description: SOUTH SAN FRANCISCO, July 3A tumultuous crowd of nearly 1,500 people gave a hero's welcome tonight to Huey P, Newton, the Black Panther Party leader, upon his return to the United States after three years in Cuba.

title: WHITEHOUSE IS URGED TO AUTHORIZE ENTRY OF 15,000 INDQCHINESE
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 The State Department, in a potentially controversial move, has asked the White House to approve the emergency admission of 15,000 Indochinese refugees stranded in Thailand and throughout Southeast Asia, some of them still living on the vessels they used to escape from Vietnam.

title: Susan Halpern, Writer, Wed To Richard Caplan, Lawyer
description: Susan Halpern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sigmund Halpern of Laurelton, Queens, was married yesterday.afternoon to Richard Lewis Caplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Caplan of Princeton, NJ. Rabbi Reubin Siegel performed the ceremony at the East FiftyFifth Conservative Svnaaoaue.

title: EMERGENCY SERVICES TO BE COORDINATED
description: The New York City Health and Hospitalc: Corporation has been awarded $1 million Federal grant to establish the city's first fully coordinated system of emergency medical services.

title: EXTREMISTS IN EGYPT ABDUCT EXOFFICIAL
description: CAIRO, July 3 Members of an organization of Moslem religious extremists today kidnapped a former Egyptian Cabinet minister and threatened to execute him by noon tomorrow unless the Government released 30 of its members from prison.

description: 7.10 A.M., WKCR. Symphony No. 4,1Vfartinon.

title: Washington Wins Cup At Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England. July 3All the American victories of the 138th Henley Royal Regatta went to the University of Washington today. as the Huskies' pairs, rowing as a four without coxswain, won the Visitors' Challenge Plate, and the varsity heavyweights captured the Grand Challenge Before the Grand Challenge Cup, the oldest and most presitigious race in rowing, the British national team, rowing under Leander colors, broke an outrigger going down to the start. This forced a postponement of the race, originally scheduled for before the tea interval.

title: Australian Union Boycott Blocks Uranium Shipment
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, July 3 (Reuters)A West German ship carrying Australian uranium was stranded in port here today by a union boycott imposed after policemen broke up an antiuranium demonstration.

title: T.V.A., a Major Polluter, Faces Suit to Cut Sulfur Dioxide Fumes
description: ATLANTA, July 3 After years of almost futile legal battling on its own, the Environmental Protection Agency is now considering joining private citizens in a suit against the nation's No. 1 sulfur dioxide polluter, the Tennessee Valley Authority, another Federal agency.

title: Magoon, Crew Abandon 3,435Mile Ocean Trip
description: PONTA DELGADA, Azores, July. 3 (AP)Bob Magoon, the American powerboat driver, and his threeman crew decided to fly to Boston today after abandoning an attempt on the transAtlantic soeed record.

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: A Bronx woman about 25 years old was found with her throat cut after she had apparently been raped and robbed on a bench in a baseball field at 174th Street and the Sheridan Expressway in the Hunt's Point section. She was tentatively identified as Mary Bancey of 482 East 189th Streeta eCrispulo Pereira, 42, the owner of two bakeries, was shot to death in his apartment building at 664 West 161st Street in Washington Heights as he was about to get off the elevator on the fifth floor, where he lived. Mr. Pereira was found with $500 in his pocketsa. (1A clerk at St. Luke's Hospital was fatally shot by a shotgun blasted fred from a moving white van into a group of dice players opposite 157 East 103d Street. The dead man was identified as Roberto Andujar, 29.

title: Arraignment in Sniping
description: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., July 3 (AP)A former marine who was shot and captured after two sniper killings was arraigned today as the authorities tried to figure out what motivated the slayings.

title: 2 IN HOUSE SAY CHIEFS HINDER KOREA1NQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Two freshmen Congressmen from Pennsylvania have charged the leadership of the House of Representatives with impeding the investigation of the alleged South Korean bribery of Congressmen.

title: 400 Fight Forest Fires In Northeast Washington
description: COLVILLE, Wash., July 3 (UPI)Nearly 400 firefighters armed with axes and picks fought to control forest fires that have burned 1,600 acres in northeast Washington, causing house and trailer residents to flee.

title: Driver Faces 19 Assault Charges in Klan Incident
description: PLAINS, Ga., July 3  A 30yearold mechanic was held in Sumter County jail in nearby Americus today, charged with 19 counts of aggravated assault after he drove his sports car into a crowd at Ku Klux Klan rally here last night, injuring about 30 persons.

description: AT RIVERSIDE Y.C.

title: Inflation Fighters Tripartite Forum
description: The Carter Administration has begun working closely and confidentially with leaders of organized labor and business in an effort to develop a common understanding of the causes of inflation and more effective policies and programs for bringing clown The the rate of inflation without arresting the upward Economic course of the economy. The Scene new effort, launched at a tripartite meeting last Wednesday behind closed doors at the HayAdams Hotel in Washington, could evolve into a major economicpolicy instrument of the Carter Administration.

description: BOSTON, July 3 (AP)Antiabortion forces, in a chaotic session of the Massachusetts House, blocked final action on the $4.26 billion state budget today.

title: Markets Closed Today
description: All banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed today for Independence Day. All stock markets and commodity exchanges will also be closed.

title: My Easy Credit Takes Rainbow Derby in Mud
description: RUIDOSO DOWNS, N. M., July 3 My Easy Credit overcame a muddy track to splash his way to victory in today's 13th running of the $396,600 Rainbow Derby at Ruidoso Downs. The victory gives him triumphs in the first two legs of quarterhorse racing's triple crown for 3yearolds, since he had won the Kansas Derby earlier in the year.

title: Zimmer Secure as Red Sox Manager Despite NineGame Losing Streak
description: The outlook seemed bright for Manager Don Zimmer and his Boston Red Sox when they came to Yankee Stadium for a threegame series against the Yankees 10 days ago. They had won seven games in a row, 13 of their last 14 and were enjoying a fivegame lead over New York in the American League East race. Further, they had just set a major league record with 33 home runs in 10 games.

title: Jean A. Melford Married To Robert Stein. Broker
description: Jean Allison Melford, daughter of Dorothy Allison Melford of New York and the late J. Herbert Melford, was married yesterday to Robert Frederick Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Stein of Scarsdale, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Stein home by Rabbi Julius Rosenthal of Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Chess:
description: How do you combat a symmetrical formation such as the Petrov Defense in the hands of a very strong opponent content with a draw?

title: Report on Liquid Chlorine In Train Wreck Delayed
description: State environmental officials were unaware that tankers in the June 27 Metuchen freight train derailment carried deadly liquid chlorine until more than six hours after the accident.

Later, with the coming of the settlers and their big country homes and small summer bungalows, the place was renamed Lakeland, after all the rivers, streams, ponds and lakes that dot these rolling hills of northern New Jersey.

title: Haitian Envoy Is Slain in Brazil; Killers Hired by Aide, Police Say
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 3 (Reuters)Delorme Mehu, the Haitian Ambassador, was shot to death by two men today in Salvador, capital of the.northeastern state of Bahia, the police reported. He was 48 years old.

title: Walton Has Pin Removed From Repaired Wrist
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 3 (UPI)Surgery to remove a surgical screw from the wrist of Bill Walton, the Portland Trail Blazers center, was termed a success, by the team's trainer, Ron Culp.

title: Weiss Takes Yacht Race On Sound
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 3  Stephen Weiss's oneyearold Christopher Dragon, a, grayhulled Cuthbertson & Cassion42 custom sloop that won Larchmont Yacht Club's Edlu Trophy distance race this spring, was the overall winner of the Riverside Yacht Club's 46th annual Stratford Shoal overnight race on Long Island Sound; which ended here today.

title: Seattle Slew 4th In Race on Coast, His First Defeat
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 3Seattle Slew's phenomenal record of nine successive victories, including racing's Triple Crown, came to an abrupt end today as he ran a sorry fourth, 16 lengths back, in the fourth running of the $316,400 Swaps Sweepstakes for 3vearolds at Hollvwood Park.

title: Green Haven Curtails Privileges Of Inmates After Clashes Increase
description: State prison officials have begun to curtail privileges for inmates at Green Haven prison in Stormville as a result of a sharp rise in clashes between prisoners and between prisoners and guards. Officials are concerned also by an increase in makeshift weapons and homemade liquor at the prison.

title: 5,000 French Soldiers Put on Alert in Djibouti
description: DJIBOUTI, July 3 (Reuters) Leaves for the 5,000 French soldiers in the newly independent Red Sea state of Djibouti were canceled last night following reports of troop movements and distribution of arms in neighboring Somalia, French military sources said. The state of alert was lifted today.

title: Very Deep Thoughts
description: WASHINGTONLet's say that God gave the world and its riches to all mankind in common. How, then, did the idea of private property come to be? How could one person own what had been given to alland by. owning, deny his property tc others?

description: SECURE AT THE HELM: Don Zimmer, Red Sox manager, Saturday night had his contract renewed through 1978 season by Dick O'Connell, general manager.

description: The marriage of Mary Maximilian Morgenthau of Palatka, Fla., to John David Bachrach of White Plains took place yesterday in IrvingtononHudson, N. Y.

title: JOHN A. WILKENS
description: John A. Wilkens of 58 Crown Street; Brooklyn, who had been active in the printing and advertising fields for six decades, died Thursday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 92 years old.

description: With four sleek Navy yawls leading the way and dozens of tiny sailboats darting like gnats amid a caravan of lumbering brigantines and antique sloops, a 100craft Parade of Sail rounded the tip of Manhattan Island yesterday.

description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 3 Herve Filion, the leading driver in the world, demonstrated today he believes gallantry is not deadexcept.on a race track.

description: WASHINGTON, July 3 In pressing government agencies and industries to clean up the air and reduce pollutants that have been linked to cancer, Representative Andrew Maguire. Democrat of Bergen County, has often likened the offenders to insensitive obstructionists with asbestos hides.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 3Lou Thi Su stopped her work and said in halting Korean, I'm not happy but I'm not sad either.

title: Bhutto's Terms for Voting
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 3 (Reuters) Pakistan's opposition leaders today considered terms imposed by Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto for holding new elections but apparently found them unacceptable.

title: Miss Fuiks, 19, Wins
description: MADISON, Wis., July 3 (AP)  It was teenday for the national amateur women's publicLinks golf championships as 19yearold Kelly Fuiks of Phoenix, Arizona, defeated 17yearold Kathy Williams of La Crescent, Minn., 1 up, for the title.

title: Books of The Times
description: Lafcadio Hearn, that odd little literary gentleman who drifted to Japan in the 19th century, totally immersed himself in Japanese ways and became one of that country's leading interpreters to the West, wondered about the course in which his adopted country was heading. It appears inevitable, he wrote in the 1890's, that her approaching transformation must be coincident with a moral decline. Forced into the vast industrial competition of nations whose civilizations were never based on altruism, she must eventually develop those qualities of which the comparative absence made all the wonderful charm of her life. The national character must continue to harden, as it has begun to harden already.

title: Andretti's Charge on Final Circuit Nets French Grand Prix Victory
description: DIJON, France, July 3 (AP)Mario Andretti of Nazareth, Pa., trailing John Watson for much of the race, overtook the Briton on the final lap today and won the French Grand Prix auto race.
