title: Petty Captures 400 at Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.. July 4 (AP) Richard Petty stormed back into the lead after a twohour rain delay and scored a 17.7second victory over Darrell Waltrip in the Firecracker 400 brand National stockcar race today.

title: Shorter Wins, Captures Second Race in 2 Days
description: ATLANTA, July 4 (AP)Frank Shorter, running in his second longdistance event in two days, won the 6.2miles Peachtree road race today in 29 minutes 10.4 seconds. Bill Rodgers was second in 29.26.

title: A Strange Bacteria's Purple Pigment, Which Uses Light to Generate Energy, May Yield Scientific Gold Mine
description: SAN FRANCISCOFrom the air it looks as if someone had dumped red food coloring into the salt flats at the southern reed of San Francisco Bay. In fact, the orange hue of the drying salt is due to vast colonies of bacteria that seem to defy the laws of life: They can survive without protection in a dry salt crystal.

title: Pacers Reach Goal With Telethon
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 4 (AP)The National Basketball Association's Indiana Pacers, whose owners were threatening to move to another city, have reached their goal of 8,000 season tickets sold and will apparently remain here.

title: F. R. BUONO, 62, DIES; THE RIKERS WARDEN
description: Francis R. Buono, who presided over a 492acre empire in the East River as the supervising warden of Rikers Island for seven years died Sunday evening while playing volley ball in Lake Grove, L.I., with members of his family.

title: It has issued a directive that
description: It has issued a directive that writ go into effect in 1978 calling for equal treatment of women in vocational training, promotion, retraining, working conditions and access to employment. Member states were given 30 months to eliminate existing discriminatory clauses in working contracts, and to redraft their laws to conform with the directive. And the Council of Ministers is now looking at another measure that will bring equality for women in the area of social security.

title: 2d Class Postal Rates Rising
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)Postal rates for second class publications, books, records and nonprofit mailings arc increasing Wednesday. The Postal Service said the average rise for most publications was 21 percent. It was the sixth annual step in a plan approved by Congress to eliminate taxpayer subsidies for the rates used by publications. Letter mail and several other classes of mail are not affected.

title: Lebanese Editors Strongly Assail Latest Curbs on Press Freedom
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 4A new law imposing tighter restrictions on the Lebanese press has brought strong protests from editors here who said that if it was applied, it would end the freedom that the press in Lebanon has enjoyed for many decades.

title: Church Says That Broadcasters Exploit Sex and Violence on TV
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The 1.8millionmember United Church of Christ, meeting here in biennial general synod, accused the television industry today of exploiting sex and violence.

title: 12 Rhodesians Expelled By Smith Form New Party
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Tuesday, July 5 (Reuters)Twelve rightwing members of Parliament, expelled from Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's ruling Rhodesian Front, started a new political party today.

title: New Oil Ports On Gulf Create Rift on Controls
description: With millions of dollars at stake, as well as control over much of the nation's future oil imports, a fierce battle is being waged over crucial Government restrictions on the nation's first deepwater terminals proposed for the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Vladimir Nabokov, Author of Lolita And  Ada, Is Dead
description: Vladimir Nabokov, a giant in the world of literature, died Saturday at the age of 78. The author of such works as Lolita, Pnin and Ada succumbed to a virus infection in the suite at the Palace Hotel in Montreux, Switzerland, where he and his wife, Vera, had lived for the last 18 years.

title: The Standings
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES New York 7, Cleveland 5 (n.). Boston 9, Toronto 6.

title: Suspect in Killings Tries Suicide in Pennsylvania
description: CAMP HILL, Pa., July 4 (AP)Gary Rock, charged with shooting two men to death while shooting at firefighters at his cabin, slashed his neck and wrist today in an effort to commit suicide in a prison. infirmary, a state prison official said.

title: In Eeruntain
description: GERTLERRose R. In cherished memory of our dearly beloved wife and mother. Her Family.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Subcommittee on Small Territories3 P.M.

title: Sun Ra and Paul Bley Try Hands as Solo Pianists
description: Amid the NewportNew York Jazz Festival's final weekend, a coffeehouse called Axis in SoHo, which has been doing well with an intelligently eclectic jazz booking policy, presented two pioneering avantgardists, Sun Ra and Paul Bley, playing solo piano. Both men have been playing free jazz since the late 1950's. Sun Ra has directed a big band since that time; Mr. Bley led a quintet in 1958, which later dropped him and became the original Ornette Coleman Quartet.

title: Visitors to Federal Parks To Pay Deposit on Bottles
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI)  In move to reduce littering, the Interior Department said today that visitors to national parks must now pay a 5 cent deposit on all beverages sold in cans or bottles. The deposit will be refunded upon the return of the container to a designated point.

title: Massacres Threatened in Rome Unless Two Terrorists Are Freed
description: ROME, July 4 (Reuters)An urban guerrilla organization today threatened massacres in three of Rome's most popular. squares if two women prisoners were not released by Friday, the police said.

title: Red Sox Snap Out of Slump With 8Homer Barrage, Tying Record
description: The Boston Red Sox ended their ninegame losing streak yesterday with a bang.

title: Letters: On Parking and Pollution
description: To the Editor Your June 25 editorial on the Federal parking ban ignores actions the city has taken.

title: Syrian Units Move South in Lebanon Toward Israeli Line
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 4Truckloads of Syrian troops of the Arab peacekeeping force were heading south this evening as tension rose in the border area with Israel.

title: Abigail, Boston Terrier, Gains Second Top Award
description: JAMESBURG, N.J. July 4A breed that originated in America claimed the New Brunswick Kennel Club's first Independence Day Dog Show trophy today at Thompson Park. Ch. Jeffords Abigail, a seal brindle Boston terrier with white markings, captured her second allbreed best in a field of 1,118 dogs.

title: Will Our Humanity Also Be Aborted?
description: When they got around this year to focusing on abortions, the three branches of the American Government achieved a rare degree of unanimity. With, certain differences in shading, the Administration, the Congress and the Supreme Court decided against paying with nublic funds for abortions for poor women.

title: Drs. King and Salk Chosen to Receive Medal of Freedom
description: WASHINGTON. July 4 (UPI)President Carter said today that he was awarding the Presidential Medal of Freedom to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the conscience of his generation, and to Dr. Jonas E. Salk, whose vaccine helped wipe out polio epidemics.

title: Tinian's Rainbow Offers Wry Charm Alfresco
description: V. the musicals that Guy Lembwdo has been staging on Jones Ekach for the last 25 years, everything distracts equally.

title: BUS HIJACKER SEIZED AT KENNEDY AIRPORT AFTER HE SLAYS TWO
description: A gunman who diverted a Vermontbound bus with more than 25 passengers from the Bronx to Kennedy International Airport and killed two hostages surrendered on a runway late last night, ending a daylong siege of terror and gunfire.

title: Pentagon Chiefs, Supporting the Volunteer Army Admit It Has Faults, but Oppose Return to Draft
description: The health, present and future, of the volunteer Army is under continuing review in the Defense Department, according to senior officials, and, although the force has current problems and will encounter others, there is no tendency now to consider a return to the draft.

title: Estonian President at U.S. Party
description: MOSCOW, July 4 (AP)Arnbaisador Toon marked Independence Day with the traditional reception at his official reaidence. The highest ranking Soviet gueits. to accept invitations were. Artu vader President of Soviet Estonia and a Soviet Vice President, and Ignaty. T. Novikov, a Deputy Prime Minister ire charge of construction.

title: 33 Jersey Parachutists Make Forced Landing in Brick Town
description: It may have resembled a scene from A Bridge Too Far to the people of Brick Township, N.J., but for 33 parachute enthusiasts it was not far enough by a couple of miles when they blew into that pleasant Ocean County town yesterday morning, on the wrong side of the Garden State Parkway.

title: AMIN TELLS OF PLOT TO ASSASSINATE HIM
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon, July 4 (AP)President Idi Amin of Uganda, addressing the African summit conference with pistol strapped to his waist, said today he had foiled a Westerninspired conspiracy to murder him and several other African leaders.

title: Cuban at U.S. Party in Bonn
description: BONN, July 4 (AP)Ambassador Alberto Boza HidalgoGato of Cuba was among 2,000 guests attending the Fourth of July party today of Ambassador Walter J. Stoessel Jr. of the United States. It was the first time a Cuban envoy had been invited to I he celebration since Washington broke off diplomatic relations with Havana in January 1961.

title: Laetrile Backed in Oregon
description: SALEM, Ore., July 4 (AP)The Oregon Senate approved today and sent to Gov. Bob Straub a bill to legalize the sale of the artificial sweetener saccharin and laetrile, the controversial drug that has been used on cancer patients. Laetrile, made from apricot pits, has been banned from Interstate sale by the Federal Food and Drug Administration on the ground that there is no proof that it can cure or prevent cancer. The Federal agency plans to ban saccharin because it caused cancer in test mice.

title: Sole Casualty of Sloop's 2Day Sail: Thumb Caught in Taxi's Door
description: Everything went fine on the boat, Phyllis Egan said with a wry smile yesterday as she struggled with a bandaged right thumb to hang up her wash on the lines of the gaffrigged sloop Eleanor. It wasn't until we got ashore and into a taxi that the door slammed on me and smashed my thumb.

title: Padres Sign Winfield, Reportedly for $1.5 Million
description: SAN DIEGO, July 4 (AP)Dave Winfield, a 25yearold outfielder, has signed a multiyear contract with the San Diego Padres, the team announced today, an agreement that reportedly will pay him $1.5 million.

title: Day's Strike Slows Heathrow
description: LONDON, July 4 (Reuters)The Londonarea airport at Heathrow was disrupted today by a strike of air traffic control assistants protesting against the freezing of a pay award. Airport officials said transAtlantic flights were affected more than flights for Europe and other destinations and that some flights had been canceled.

title: Magoon Fails to Leave His Mark on the Ocean
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 4Dr. Robert Magoon, the peripatetic eye surgeon from Miami, was supposed to arrive here today by speedboat from Rota, Spain, having set a record for the fastest transAtlantic crossing by boat, 72 hours. Instead Magoon arrived last night by limousine and commercial airplane, having left the boat at Ponta Delgado in the Azores 2,500 miles from here.

title: Plane Safe as Engine Burns
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 4 (UPI)An Eastern Airlines Boeing 727 with 38 passengers on board had a fire in one of its three engines on takeoff from Douglas Municipal airport today. The fire was extinguished quickly and the plane taxied back to the terminal under its own power. The passengers left to wait for another craft to take them to Boston, flight 650's destination.

title: Job Help for Veterans
description: Thomas E. Mullaney interviews G. William Miller, chairman of Textron, who will spearhead a drive to find jobs for nearly a half million unemployed war veterans. Page 47.

title: Ernst Oster, 69, a Musicologist, Taught at Mannes Music College
description: Ernst Oster, a musicologist who taught at the Mannes College of Music in New York City and at the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston, died last Thursday while walking on Skunemunk Mountain.; near Mountainville in Orange County, N.Y. Mr. Oster, who was 69 years old,. was said to have suffered stroke.

title: Skydivers Make Forced Landing
description: It may have resembled a scene from A Bridge Too Far to the people of. Brick Township, but for 33 parachute enthusiasts it was not far enough by a couple of miles when they blew into that pleasant Ocean County town yesterday morning, on the wrong side of the Garden State Parkway.

title: FATE OF EXMINISTER IS IN DOUBT IN CAIRO
description: CAIRO. July 4The fate of an abducted former cabinet minister remained unclear tonight after persons claiming to represent the kidnappers called news organizations to say that he had been slain as a negotiating deadline passed. But the police later said no trace of a body had been found in an area specified by the kidnappers and the police termed the calls a hoax.

title: Race. Week Under Way At Goshen
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., July 4Old Home Week started at its usual leisurely pace this afternoon in this homey Orange County village as the countryfairflavored Historic Track, 60 miles from midtown Manhattan, opened its gates for its 139th year of harness racing. About 5,000 people attended.

title: Lost Child Found in Colorado
description: EVERGREEN, Colo., July 4 (UPI)Tracker dogs and mountain rescue workers, hurrying to beat an advancing cold front and impending thundershowers, today found Jessica. Ann Harmon, 21/2 years old, who wandered all night through the rugged canyons on the edge of the Rocky Mountains. She was reported. in good condition.

title: Turks Turn to Demirel as Leader
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 4 (AP)Suleyman Demirel, a conservative former Prime Minister, was asked today to form a new government.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 8 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 7:55 P.M.) Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia. (TelevisionChannel 9, 7:30 P.M.) (RadioWNEW, 7:20 P.M.)

title: Dave Anderson
description: When the Chicago White Sox hold their OldTimers Day on July 17, the current team will not be awed by the guests. For two reasons. One, the current White Sox are leading the American League West and two, the invited White Sox oldtimers never led anything, except perhaps themselves to slaughter. At most oldtimers games, many of the same races reappearJoe DIMaggio, hobby Thomson and Ralph Branca, Don Larsen, Stan Musial and Mickey Mantle. It's like, Bill Veeck says, they've got their own circuit. And so the White Sox entrepreSports neur, who had a reputation for doing things differently in baseball long before of Mark Fidrych even talked to his rattle, The Times will display names at OldTimers Day that are engraved only on the memory of those who frequent South Side taverns, not on Hall of Fame plaques. Paul LaPalme, for example, and Howard Judson and Marvin Rotblatt and Dave Nicholson and Zeke Bonura, a first baseman who once hit.345 for the White Sox and who 11Pc1 a career.307 average. But as a White Sox oldtimer, Zeke Bonura will be honored for all the grounders he never caught.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: For Week Ended July 1, 1977 UTILITY BONDS

title: EXTRA JOBLESS BENEFITS FOR WORKERS ON B1 ASKED
description: DETROIT, July 4 (AP)The United Automobile Workers union asked the Defense Department today to provide extra unemployment benefits for workers laid off after production of the B1 bomber was canceled.

title: RIGHTISTS ARE LINKED TO LAETRILE'S LOBBY
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Members of the John Birch Society and other rightwing groups who began the campaign for the legalization of laetrile are still active in the fight, but backers of the purported anticancer drug are increasingly persons who view their motives as more humanitarian than political.

title: Canada Energy Unit Backs $8.6 Billion Gas Pipeline
description: OTTAWA, July 4The National Energy Board of Canada announced its approval today of an application by a CanadianAmerican consortium. Foothills Pipes (Yukon) Ltd., to build an $8.6 billion natural gas pipeline across western Canada to connect with the proposed Alcan project in Alaska, giving American consumers access to large reserves of the fuel at Prudhoe Bay.

title: Sheik Abdullah Wins in Kashmir In Severe Setback for New Delhi,
description: NEW DELHI, July 4Kashmiris have chosen the local Moslem party of Sheik Mohammed Abdullah to govern their state for the next five years.

title: The Quintet Justifies Name By Its Playing
description: The allstar group that Herbie Hancock assembled last summer for the NewportNew York Jazz Festival and reactivated this summer for the festival and a brief tour does not sound much like an allstar group. Last summer, it sounded like a band that had been working together for years, and this was not surprising, since four of the musiciansMr. Hancock on piano, Tony Williams on drums, Ron Carter on bass and Wayne Shorter on saxophonesplayed together through the mid1960's as members of the Miles Davis Quintet and frequently recorded as a unit with the fifth member, Freddie Hubbard, the trumpeter.

title: Kimombwa, Nemeth Win 10,000, Javelin
description: STOCKHOLM, July 4 (AP)Samson Kimombwa. Kenya's middledistance star, won the 10,000meter run tonight in the third best time recorded for the distance.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HEY! LOOK ME OVER It's only natural to have favorite museum corners and haunts, because a thorough, exploration of a huge building is something that takes time and patience. The American Museum of Natural History, one of the Big Apple wonders, is simplifying this with a summerlong series of free guided tours providing an hour of Highlights and History.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DiPORT FREEDOM (A.E.L.). Naples July 12 and Genoa 25; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: News Summary
description: The United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Malcolm Toon, was not allowed to deliver a traditional Fourth of July speech over Soviet television when he declined to delete a passage alluding to the human rights policy of the Carter Administration. A passage that annoyed Soviet officials said that the United States was trying to live up to the fundamental and inalienable rights inherent in its founding principles. [Page 1, Columns 463

title: Bell Orders Aides to Limit Details When They Announce Indictments
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has disclosed that he has ordered the Department of Justice's publicity office to discontinue its practice of issuing detailed news releases to announce criminal indictments.

title: Soviet Bars U.S. Envoy's TV Talk Touching on Rights
description: MOSCOW, July 4  The United States ambassador to the Soviet Union was not allowed to deliver a traditional Fourth of July speech over Soviet television today after he had declined to delete a section alluding to the human rights policy of the Carter Administration.

title: New Oil Ports On Gulf Create Rift on Controls
description: With millions of dollars at stake, as well as control over much of the nation's future oil imports, a fierce battle is being waged over crucial Government restrictions on the nation's first deepwater.termina's proposed for the Gulf of Mexico.

title: How ElectionYear's Deficit Budget Works
description: TRENTON, July 4Governor Byrne's electionyear budget for the state government, which went into effect last Friday, spends $63 million more than the state expects to take in. But the political problems associated with this additional spending are more likely to devolve on State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, the Republican mndidate for Governor, than on Mr. Byrne, the Democratic candidate.

title: Attempts to Replace U.S. Attorney In New Jersey Stir Patronage Fight
description: An effort by powerful New Jersey Democrats to replace Jonathan L. Goldstein as United States Attorney for the state with a Newark bankruptcy lawyer has.led to a heated dispute over political patronage in one of the most acclaimed Federal law enforcement offices in the country.

title: Radio
description: 710 A.M., WKCR. Three Sonatas for Organ, Hindemith; Concerto for Harpsichord, Flute, Oboe, Clarinet, Violin and Cello, FaIla Piano Concerto, Carter; Concerto Champetre, Poulenc.

title: FRANK J. PIERCE
description: Frank J. Pierce, an industrial chemist who was president and owner of the Reiaoo Manufacturing Corporation, makers of lacquers in Brooklyn, died Saturday in Holy Name Hospital, Teaneck, N.J., following a heart attack. He was 59 years old and lived at 1782 Rensselaer Road in Teaneck.

title: Government Jobs Doubled in 20 Years, Study Shows
description: Government employment in the United StatesFederal, state and localhas more than doubled in the last 20 years, rising from 7,4 million to 15 million, according to a study by the Conference Board.

title: The Fed's Interest in Checking Accounts
description: The Federal Reserve Board, the nation's central bank, is so concerned about its institutional cohesion that may scuttle Congressional efforts to allow all banks, at last, to pay interest on checking accounts.

title: OverExpansion Threatens United Merchants Survival
description: From a modest collection of textile plants engaged in printing, converting and weaving cloth, United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc. enthusiastically joined the expansiondiversification binge of the last two decades and grew into diversified textile products giant.

title: Former Navy Captain Is Reported Korean Lobbyist's RightHand Man
description: WASHINGTON, July 4In the unfolding account of the covert and allegedly illegal South Korean lobby here, a retired United States Navy captain named Spencer E. Robbins has emerged as the righthand man to Park Tong Sun, reportedly the Korean Government's main agent of influence in Washington.

title: Fumes in Fatal Prison Fire Tied to Carbon Monoxide
description: COLUMBIA, Tenn., July 4 (UPD)Blood samples taken from 10 of the 42 victims of the June 26 Maury County Jail fire showed that they died from carbon monoxide asphyxiation and not from cyanide fumes as originally thought.

title: Dollar Slides Again In European Trade
description: LONDON, July 4 (AP)The dollar took plunged again on European money markets today and dealers said that its weakness was a holdover from selling in Asia last week.

title: 7,000 Shriners Frolic Down a Sunny Midtown Broadway
description: The treet of New York were dotted over ttic we, takend with men in maroon fezzes, and Ueste rday 7,000 of themShriners from the United States and Canadaconfigered oil Broadway for fourhour march under a hot summer sun.

title: A Familiar Sort of Fourth
description: This has been a Fourth of July weekend for fireworks, lying in the sun, eating hot dogs, watching via satellite a great men's finals from Wimbledon, mourning the loss of Seattle Slew's invincibility, and keeping an eye on relatively, close races in all four major league divisions (even the National League West, where, though 91/2 games behind, the Cincinnati Reds still can't be counted out).

title: Vladimir Nabokov, Author 01  Lolita And  Ada, Is Dead
description: Vladimir Nabokov, a giant in the world of literature, died Saturday at the age of 78. The author of such works as Lolita, Pnin and Ada succumbed to a virus infection in the suite at the Palace Hotel in Montreux, Switzerland, where he and his wife, Vera, had lived for the last 18 years.

title: Messersmith Disabled
description: ATIANTA. July 4 (AP)The Atlanta Braves have placed Andy Messersmith, a righthander who injured his pitching arm yesterday in Houston, on the 21day disabled list. Messersmith injured his right elbow when he fell while fielding a ground ball in the Astrodome. Further tests will he taken on the elbow, the Braves said.

title: Los Angeles Orders Precautionary Water Use Curb as Court Limits Pumping of Underground Supplies
description: LOS ANGFT.FS, July 4Los Angeles's efforts to augment its droughtshrunken water reserve received a severe setback lastweek when the State Court of Appeal blocked additional pumping from the city's vast underground water holdings in the Owens Valley, 300 miles to the north.

title: Girl's Body Found in Car Trunk
description: BANGOR, Mich. July 4 (AP)The body of Terri Wilson, the 18yearold Bangor Centennial queen, was discovered today stuffed in her car's trunk in a rural area, troopers reported. A 20yearold Bangor man was being held in the slaying. His name was withheld pending formal charges. Miss Wilson, a 1977 high school honors graduate, appeared yesterday in the community's centennial parade and at other festivities.

title: In Bell System's Minority Plan, Women Get Better Jobs, but Total Number of Female Workers Drops
description: Four and a half years ago the American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed to the most sweeping corporate effort ever to eliminate racism and sexism on the job.

title: Father Accused in Fatal Blaze.
description: CHICAGO, July 4 (UPI)Everett Bowen, 34 years old, of Northlake, III., who lost three children in a weekend fire, has been charged with arson and three counts of murder in connection with that blaze. He was arrested last night and charged with setting the fire that killed his two daughters and a son Saturday morning. His wife, Evelyn, recently separated from her husband, escaped with a second son.

title: Seoul Asks Renewal Of Talks With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 4South Korea asked North Korea today to resume political negotiations broken off by the North four years ago. A statement by the South Korean delegation to the suspended talks said that resumption of contacts was essential The statement commemorated the fifth anniversary of the signing of a communiqu that promised that the two Koreas would work for peaceful settlement of differences, and renewed a demand that a treaty of noninterference and nonaggression be signed.

title: Ethics for Company Doctors
description: A year ago, occupational medicine doctors adopted the first code of ethics in the 62year history of their specialty. They did so because a series of recent legislative, judicial, corporate and social changes had brought to the surface host of problems that further complicated a company'docNews tor's already delicate relaAnalysis tionship with his patients. Occupational medicine physicians are responsible, among other things, for screening the health status of prospective employees, treating workers for industrialrelated accidents and illnesses, and protecting the workers and the public's health by detecting and correcting hazards in the workplace.

title: Books of The Times
description: Ah, yes a the obsession of housebuilding. Peter Matson, a literary agent when he's in the city, describes it very well in A Place in the Country. Surely I am not unique in believing I can contain the complexities of our time by physical effort, he muses when his converted barn in the Berkshires is nearly completed. (But of A PLACE IN THE COUNTRY. A Narrative no the Imperfect Art of Homesteading and the Value of Ignorance. By Peter H. Matson. 235 pages. Random House. $8.95. course it will never be completed.) I am completely knowledgeable about this house, as if I had xray vision. It is disquieting at times, but when the electricity goes off I know that I can still make do, that the wood stoves will give out heat, that I can lift water from the well as countless farmers have done beforein a bucket. The preeminence of unmanageable, despotic technocracy, which breeds the paranoia of our times, is thus momentarily defeated.

title: People in Sports
description: Denny Crum, basketball coach at the University of Louisville, is to meet this morning with the school's athletic director, Dave Hart, and tell hint whether he will accept the coaching job* at the University of California, Los Angeles, which was vacated recently by Gene Bartow. Crum says the job was offered him by the U.C.L.A. athletic director, J. D. Morgan, last week. Morgan, reached by telephone, gave a terse no comment to all questions concerning Crum.

title: East German Trade: Fight To Win in Ways of the West
description: WEST BERLIN, July 4Some months ago, an East German clothing company won an order for 50,000 pieces of women's apparel. But the deal fell through on the delivery date because the company had not adhered to specifications and had made only one type of suit, each the same color and the same size.

title: Yanks Belt 4 Homers and Triumph, 75
description: Four times during the Yankees' game with Cleveland last night, Toby Wright played I'm a Yankee Doodle Dandy. Wright, the Yankee Stadium organist, wasn't saluting the country's 201st birthday. Nor was he celebrating the boss's 47th birthday. Instead, he was marking the four hothe runs the Yankees hit in defeating the Indians, 75.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 4Governor Byrne is expected to name this week the five members of the Casino Control Commission, which will supervise casino gambling in Atlantic City.

title: Thai Village Finds Tragedy on a Road Paved With. Lead
description: PHRA PRADAENG, Thailand, July 2 Twoyearold Samreng Muonthongsuk passed out in her rickety wooden home more than a year ago. It was the first hint of trouble in this tiny village on the outer fringe of Bangkok.

title: Nuclear Disarmament Called Vital By Speakers at Paris Conference
description: PARIS, July 4Looking ahead to the challenge of the year 2000, a group of intellectuals who met here last week have stressed the need for nuclear disarmament if the world is to survive.

title: 2 Oklahoma Escaped Prisoners Linked to Slaying in Arkansas
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 4 (AP)Two Oklahoma prison escapers were identified today by the Oklahoma Highway Patrol as suspects in the killings of an Arkansas marshal.

title: Holiday Death Toll in New York: How First 2 Died
description: Besides the sun, the fireworks and the celebrations, there is also a grim tradition associated with the annual Fourth of July weekend holiday: As we count our nation's birthdays, we also count our traffic dead.

title: Illegal Aliens Use Mexico As Gateway to U.S.
description: DOUGLAS, Ariz., July 4 (AP)Increasing numbers of illegal aliens from Central and South American countries are travel. ing through Mexico to get into the United States, according to United States Border Patrol officials.

title: MRS. NORTON TERMS LABOR ALLY ON BIAS
description: WASHINGTON July 4Eleanor Holmes! Norton, the new head of the Equal ployment Oppartunity Commission, beLieves, unlike some of her predecessors at the beleaguered agency, that organized labor is likely to be an ally and not a foe in efforts to end job discrimination against minority and women workers.

title: Infant Taken by Woman June 23 Found on Brooklyn Church Steps
description: A threemonth girl kidnapped June 23 from Lincoln Hospital was found in good health early yesterday on the steps of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in the Red Hook district of Brooklyn.

title: Lansky's Stepson Is Held in Miami On SecondNgree Murder Charge
description: MIAMI, July 4 (UPI)Richard B. Schwartz, 48yearold stepson of Meyer Lansky, reputed underworld financier, was held without bond today at the Dade County jai! on seconddegree murder charges.

title: Spearheading a Drive for Veterans Jobs
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I.With his nautical background, G. William Miller, the dynamic chairman of Textron Inc., thoroughly enjoyed his independence Day weekend a year *go and wished hP could have participated in some kind of reprise for iwri. The On July 4 last year. the former Coast Guard officer Economic stood as a guest on the Scene deck of that service's training bark. Eagle, as she cruised, fullmasted, into New York harbor with the parade of Tall Ships and other sailing vessels to mark the nation's Bicentennial.

title: F.A.O. EXPERTS PREDICT CEREALGRAIN SURPLUS
description: ROME, July 4 (AP)The Food and Agriculture Organization today predicted a world cereal grain surplus this year equal to about 18 percent of annual consumption. An increase in milk production over last year was also forecast by the specialized United Nations agency.

title: Bangkok Police Try, Then Doff, Air Masks
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 5Late last month traffic policemen at some of Bangkok's most polluted intersections showed up wearing white antipollution masks. Tests had recently shown that the air at the Yaowaraj, Rajprasong and Pratunam crossings was truly fetid60, 28 and 24 percent above the level that the World Health Organization considered a threat to human health.

title: Dollar Slips in Tokyo
description: TOXYO, July 4 (AP)The dollar slippei a fraction today on the Tokyo foreign exchange market and closed at 266.625 yen after moderate trading.

title: Systematic Approach To Ending Job Bias
description: Affirmative action at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is not simply a case of finding a few blacks or women to promote or hire.

title: HUTTO OVERTHROWN BY THE ARMED FORCES, PAKISTAN'S RADIO SAYS
description: NEW DELHI, Tuesday, July 5The army took control of Pakistan in a coup this morning and arrested Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto and other leading politicians supporting and opposing him, the Pakistan radio announced.

title: Admiral Says U.S. Navy Is Hindered by Illiteracy
description: SAN DIEGO, July 4 (UPI)Illiteracy among young Americans has become so widespread that the Navy is having trouble finding recruits who can read well enough to function, according to the chief of naval personnel, Vice Adm. James D. Watkins.

title: Advertising
description: Are agencyclient relationships in the fastfood arena becoming particularly volatile?

title: SAUL KIES
description: Saul Kies, a founder and past president of the National Association of Immigration and Nationality Lawyers, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 25 Central Park West.

description: Prob. FIRSTW.502, trot, Class C1..Mile. Odds

title: An Illustrator Who Works at the Art of 19thCentury Living
description: MARLBORO, Vt.  Tasha Tudor is is fond of saying she wishes she had lived in the 19th century. Actually, she almost does. Her farmhouse is set in a pine clearing reached by a narrow, rutted road no ordinary car can navigate. The house itself has had electricity for only two years and there is no running water in the kitchen; it is carried in buckets from the barn. In winter, the Tudor grandchildren go to school on snowshoes.

title: Ronan, Ending Asian Trip, Cites Efforts to Attract Industry to New York
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July. 4Dr. William J. Ronan, the former chairman of the Port Authority or New York and New Jersey, said today at the end of his controversial Asian tour that the authoritywas in the midst of crucial competition to attract Japanese manufacturers and Asian shippers to the New York metropolitan area.

title: 2 Men, Facing Trial for Releasing Dolphins, Say the Creatures Have a Right to Be Free
description: HONOLULU, July 4  The message written in white chalk signaled the opening of a controversy that appears destined to pit the scientific community here against the surfers and other free spirits who fill the Oahu beaches.

title: PROTESTERS DISRUPT KLAN'S RALLY IN OHIO
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Julys 4 (AP)Ku Klux Klansmen swinging flagstaffs like baseball bats fought off charging demonstrators at the State Capitol today when a Klan rally turned into a brawl.

title: Detroit Jury Deliberaing Fate Of 2 Nurses Gets Half a Holiday
description: DETROIT, July 4 (AP)Jurors charged with deciding whether two nurses poisoned patients in a Veterans Administration hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., put in a halfday of work today before getting the rest of the holiday off to be with their families.

title: News Summary
description: The United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Malcolm Toon, was not allowed to deliver a traditional Fourth of July speech over Soviet television when he declined to delete a passage alluding to the human rights policy of the Carter Administration. A passage that annoyed Soviet officials said that the United States was trying to live up to the fundamental and inalienable rights inherent in its founding principles. [Page 1, Columns 46.]

title: AUDIT REPORTS CHAOS IN MEASURES BUREAU
description: An audit of the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, whose job it is to protect the public against consumer fraud. has uncovered what Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin described as chaotic conditions that could lead to fraud and inequity in the Weights and Measures Bureau within the regulatory agency.

title: Ermarial Srruires
description: GREELEYBIR. Memorial Serykk Tuesday, July 5, 5:30 PM, Belasco Room, Sardis.

title: Something Different
description: When Jimmy Carter set out to be the Democratic candidate for President, he decided to do it by running against the Democratic Party.

title: TV: Opera House. That Blooms in Desert
description: Thqe indomitable few who wonder whatever happened to opera on television can discern a good part of the answer in a new WNET/13 summer series called Opera Theater. Money, or at least the lackof it, is what has happened to television opera. The grand schemes and dreams of Peter Herman Adler, the uncompromising director of the former NET Opera, have been placed in production limbo as public television points with righteousness to the prohibitive costs of doing original studio productions.

title: Bishop John M. A. F earns, An Aide to Cardinal Cooke And ExRectorof Seminciry
description: Bishop John Michael A. Fearns, auxiliary bishop to Terence Cardinal Cooke, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City after a long illness. He was SO years old.

title: Bridge:
description: At the midpoint in the final playoffs of the Von Zedtwitz double knockout team championship, all three competing teams are hopeful of victory. Each team is leading in one match, and all. the marlins are narrow.

title: New Subway Line in Washington Is Jammed With Holiday Riders
description: the July 4 (AP)We're the victims of our own success, an official of Metrorail, the new Washington subway system, said of a holiday crush today.

title: Film on Hemingway Taking His Wife to Cuba
description: Mary Hemingway will return to Cuba this week to do research for a movie based on the life of her late husband, Ernest Hemingway.
