title: 60 Ways to Connect With an OldFashioned 5Cent Phone Call
description: CHATHAM, N.Y.The New York Telephone Company wants to double the minimum charge for calls from its 184,200 10cent coin boxes but there are still 60 pay stations in this state where you can make a local call for a nickel.

title: Critics Praise Opera
description: LONDON, July 8The warmth of the reception that the firstnight audience gave to Sir MSchael Tippett's opera The Ice Break was echoed in this morning's newspapers. Most of the reviewers enthused over Sir Michael's score, his libretto and the work of the principal singers, chorus and orchestra conducted by Colin Davis. Sam Wanamaker's direction was also highly praised.

title: Public Criticism of Brazil Regime Growing
description: BRASILIA, July 8At the end of long wooden table or the kind seen in the finest of executive meeting rooms sat a Brazilian company manager. A view of his factory appeared through a window near his chair, which turned as the door to his office began to open uncertainly.

title: 111 Deaths Counted In SeoulArea Floods
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, July 9 (AP)Heavy rains caused floods and landslides that have taken at least III lives in an around the South Korean capital, the police reported today. Seventythree people were reported missing.

title: Hawaiian Alliance Fights Sugar Aid Limit
description: HONOLULU, July 8Hawaiian sugar industry executives, joined by officials from a union representing 9,600 cane plantation workers, have gained support of the state government and the islands Congressional delegation for an allout lobbying effort to avoid subsidy limitations on the 1.2 millionton crop.

title: The Standings
description: Saturday, July 9, 1977

title: Goodyear Tire Elects De Young As Executive Committee Chief
description: Russell De Young, a former chairman of the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, who has been on the executive committee of the Lykes Corporation since 1972, was elected chairman of the committee yesterday.

title: CALIFORNIA DROUGHT FORECAST FOR 3D YEAR
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 8California is preparing for a third year, of drought, which would require more drastic water rationing and cause more severe damage to the state's $9billionayear agriculture industry, the director of the state Department of Water Resources said here today.

title: Beame Renews His Plea to Public For Aid in Capturing Son of Sam
description: A renewed appeal to the pubic for help in capturing the Son of Sam was made yesterday by Mayor Beame, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd, the city's chief of detectives, the District Attorneys of Queens and the Bronx, the Borough President of Queens and other high city officials at a news conference in a police station in Flushing, Queens.

title: Chinese Art Show Is At Boston Airport
description: A show and sale of contemporary art from China opens Monday at Boston's Logan International Airport. The event, sponsored by the Massachusetts Port Authority, the South Terminal Corporation and the New China Arts Corporation, an importer, includes 90 objectsamong them oil paintings, watercolors on silk, needlepoint tapestries from Shanghai, and Huhsien woodblock prints.

title: Nicklaus and Watson Card 65's, Lead by 3
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland, July 8Jack Nicklaus, a twotime winner of the British Open, and Tom Watson, who won it two years ago, went at it headtohead today in the third round of the 106th Open and came out even at 65, five under par for the Ailsa course of the Turnberry Hotel resort. And each finished the day with an aggregate of 203, seven under par for 54 holes and three shots ahead of their closest pursuer.

title: U.S. Tax Shift Dismays Americans in Iran
description: TEHERAN, July 8High on the list of problems of Americans living in Iran is the new United States tax reform law. Its provisions affecting Americans abroad have made many think twice about staying on in Iran.

title: Louis J. Brecker, Who Fostered Romance at Roseland, Dies at 79
description: Louis J. Brecker, whose Roseland ballroom not only symbolized cheekocheek dancing but also sustained and nurtured it for more than 60 years, died of cancer yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 79 years, old and lived at 791 Park Avenue.

title: DuckEating `Monster Ends as Turtle Soup
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 8 (AP)The monster that ate Walter Fick's ducklings is in a lot of hot water. More precisely, it is at a Chinese restaurant being made into turtle soup,

title: THE REV. EMIL NOMMESEN
description: LONDON, Ontario, July 8 (Reuters)The Rev. Emil Nommesen, honored by King Frederik IX of Denmark for aiding Danish immigrants in Canada for 40 years, died yesterday at his home, it was announced today. He was 83 years old. Mr. Nommesen was inducted into the Order of Knight of the Flag in 1968 when he retired from the ministry. Born in Denmark, Mr. Nommesen left at the age of 19 for the United States, where he was educated in theology. At 27, he arrived in Canada, establishing permanent residence here in 1957.

title: Mass Shrimp Production Planned At Automated Factory
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., July 8A fully automated productionline factory is being planned here to massproduce shrimp in fresh water hatcheries.

title: 3 Armed Men Flee With $200,000 In Loot From Northport Jeweler
description: Three armed men wearing ski masks invaded a store specializing in precious stones and jewelry on Route 25A in Northport, LI., and escaped with loot valued at $200,000, the police reported yesterday.

title: Von Braun Memorial Fund Set
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)The National Space Institute says it has established the Wernher von Braun Memorial Fund at the request of the late rocket pioneer to promote space activities. Dr. von Braun, who died of cancer June 16, founded the nongovernment space institute in 1974 to tell the story of the benefits of space.

title: After Long Spell of Gloom, Sun Smiles Again on Britain
description: LONDON, July 8The spectators at Wimbledon, who had been polite and customarily quiet for nearly two weeks. ho;;ered and stomped like a football crowd at Ole Miss when Virginia Wade wen the women's singles tennis chainpionship last week.

title: GRAND CENTRAL GETS VOTE AS L.I.R.R. SITE
description: AUthority Drops Its 3d Ave. Plan, but Federal Approval Is Needed

title: Money
description: Friday, July 8

title: Food Stamp Eligibility Ceilings Raised for 45% of the Recipients
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP)The Agriculture Department raised the eligibility limits today for about 45 percent of the 5.37 million households receiving food stamps. The department also raised the monthly allotment of coupons by $2 for recipients living alone, to $52.

title: LOUIS B. JOHNSON
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 8 (UPI)Louis B. (Farmer) Johnson, a former University of Tennessee football player and coach, died today of a heart attackathis home. He was 73 years old.

title: Music at Fort Tryon Park
description: The United Nations Meditation Group will offer a program of music at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow outside the Cloisters Museum grounds in Fort Tryon Park, the group announced, not at the Cloisters as announced in yesterday's Times.

title: Miners Seek More Health Funds
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 8Arnold R. Miller, president of the United Mine Workers, called today for a reopening of the 277,000member union's contract in an apparent attempt to force the Bituminous Coal Operators Association to afflee to a reallocation of money within the union's Health and Retirement Fund. He said that a reallocation would allow the fund to rescind major cutbacks, in Miner medical benefits.

title: BARBARA J. LOGAN, AT 62, GYNECOLOGY SPECIALIST
description: Dr. Barbara J. Logan, a specialist in gynecology and obstetrics, died yesterday at her Manhattan home. She was 62 years and lived at 1080 Fifth Avenue.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Brother Duo Posts Upset In Anderson
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 8There is something about the golf courses built by the late A.W. Tillinghast that brings out the best in the Dee family of golfers from Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Manatee Caught in Utility Dispute
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., July 8The Florida Ida manatee, or sea cow, an endangered aquatic mammal, may be a casualty of an environmental battle between the Florida Power and Light Company and Federal agency.

title: Ford, Chrysler Cite 6% Rises in Prices
description: DETROIT, July 8The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corportion today followed the lead of the General Motors Corporation in telling dealers to plan for a 1978 model price increase in the 6 percent range.

title: An Unannounced Port Authority Aide Accompanied Ronan and Others on Paid RoundtheWorld Air Tour
description: Commissioners William J, Ronan and Milton A. Gilbert and their wives were accompanied on their recent roundtheworld air tour at the expense of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey ,by a previously unannounced supervisor of social services. His regular function is to pay bills, exchange currency, clear the way through customs and make other arrangements for traveling officials of the aeencv.

title: Unannounced Port Authority Aide Went on Paid Tour With Officials
description: Commissioners William J. Ronan and Milton A. Gilbert and their wives were accompanied on their recent roundtheworld air tour at the expense of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey by a previously unannounced supervisor of social services. His regular function is to pay bills, exchange currency, clear the way through customs and make other arrangements or traveling officials of the agency.

title: ESTIMATE IS RAISED FOR SOVIET GRAINS THIS YEAR BY 4.6%
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI)The Agriculture Department today increased its estimate of the Soviet Union's 1977 grain crop by 4.6 percent to a predicted new record of 225 million metric tons.

title: About New York
description: Herman Badillo, LongDistance Runner

title: 17 Pickets Arrested at Temple U.
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (UPI)Seventeen persons were arrested today by sheriff's deputies for violations of a court order limiting picketing at Temple university. Some 2,500 members of Local 1199c of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees struck yesterday after negotiations over a new contract broke down. Common Pleas Court Judge George Ivins limited pickets to four per door. The sherriff's office said the 17 were taken before Judge Ivins on charges of civil contempt, given lecture and released with a warning.

title: Ecevit Offers to Join Coalition
description: ANKARA, July 8 (Reuters)Bulent Ecevit offered today to join his main rival in a broadbased coalition.

title: Inmont Will Discuss Esmark Deal
description: The Inmont Corporation, up to now vigorously battling a $200 million takeover by Esmark Inc. as inadequate, has agreed to discuss the possibility of a mergeL between the two companies, Esmark disclosed yesterday in Chicago.

title: South African Province Planning Talks to. Weigh Multiracial Rule
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 8 (AP)  A provincial official in South Africa's Natal Province said today that white, black and Indian leaders would meet liter this month to discuss possible creation of multiracial government there.

title: Consumer Credit Expanded $2.53 Billion During May
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI)  Consumer credit expanded by $2.53 billion in May, a moderate slowdown from the preceding two months but still the thirdbiggest increase ever, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Green Haven Prisoner Strike Ends as Leaders Are Removed
description: Only two prisoners remained on strike at Green Raven Correctional Facility at Stormville, N.Y. The strike, which involved a third of the 1,800 inmates, according to officials, collapsed after strikers were confined to their cells Thursday afternoon and 40 of the alleged leaders of the action were transferred.

title: SCIENTIFIC PACT RENEWED BY U.S. AND SOVIET UNION
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP)The United States and the Soviet Union renewed today an agreement on scientific and technological cooAeration for a second fiveyear period.

title: A Church in the Village Is Looking for a Buyer
description: Does anyone want to buy a church?

title: 16% Rise Last Winter Makes New York Gas Costliest
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The price of natural gas used for home heating and cooking rose by 16 percent in the New York metropolitan area last winter, and residents of New York now pay the highest prices among major metropolitan areas in the nation, according to a new study.

title: Article Links News Chain to
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI)Penthouse magazine said today that the Californiabased Copley newspaper group and its domestic and Latin American news service for two decades acted as intelligence, arms of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONThe first of three fast new printers ordered by the Patent 4nd Trademark Office to meet annual demands for many millions of copies of patents has been installed and will begin operation next week.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Due to a typesetting error, a Washington dispatch in The Times Wednesday omitted the name of a participant at a meeting of American Jewish leaders with President Carter. The list should have included Matthew Schoenwald, chairman of the American Trade Union Council for Histadrut.

title: HUMANITAS PRIZES GO TO 4 TV WRITERS
description: The Human Family Institute has awarded its 1977 Humanitas Prizes totaling $50,000 to four writers of primetime television programs"Green Eyes, episodes of Roots and The Mary Tyler Moore Show.

title: ThreeJudge Panel Vows Early Ruling On March by Nazis
description: CHICAGO, July 8A three.judge appellate court panel promised today to rule quickly, possibly as soon as Monday, on whether to lift a ban on a Nazi march through the predominantly Jewish suburb of Skokie.

title: WHITE HOUSE BACKS SUBSIDY FOR ADOPTING UNWANTED CHILDREN
description: WASHINGTON, July 8.The Carter Administration plans to endorse next week legislation that would provide Government subsidies to families that adopt hardtoplace children.

title: Palestinians Said to Gainin South Lebanon  Fighting
description: BEIRUT, July 8Palestinian guerrillas have reportedly scored gains in fighting with Lebanese Christian forces in southern Lebanon.

title: Change in Presidency Blurs Succession
description: MOSCOW, July 8The accession of Leonid I. Brezhnev to the presidency last month has confirmed the Communist Party chief as the most powerful man in the Soviet Union, but it has thrown almost no light on the persistent question of who will one day succeed him. Indeed, the move may have complicated the problem of succession since it consolidates the party and government leadership in a way that could be increasingly difficult to disentangle.

title: FEDERAL AGENTS RAID SCIENTOLOGY CHURCH
description: WASHINGTON, July 8Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, carrying buzz saws, sledgehammers, crowbars and search warrants, entered offices of the Church of Scientology here and in Los Angeles this morning in an attempt to recover hundreds of documents allegedly stolen by church operatives from Government files.

title: Sandra Schoellkopf Is Bride of David Plowden Sandra Owen Wed
description: Sandra Oakes Schoellkopf, daughter of Mrs. J. Frederick Schoellkopf 4th of Buffalo and the late Mr. Schoellkopf, was married yesterday to David Plowden, son of Mrs. Roger Stanley Plowden of New York and Putney, Vt., and the late Mr. Plowden.

title: Bulgarian Given French Asylum
description: PARIS, July 8 (Reuters)The French Interior Ministry said today it had granted political asylum to a Bulgarian correspondent. Vladimir KostovBorisov of the Bulgarian radio and television service had been due to return to Bulgaria on June after a threeyear assignment in Paris, informed sources said.

title: Habib to Visit Seoul For Talks on Pullout
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 8South Korean officials said today that the United States Under Secretary of State, Philip C. Habib, would visit Seoul Sunday for discussions with Government officials. Although there was no official confimiaton, it was understood that his visit would be connected with the proposed withdrawal of 33,000 American ground troops from South Korea.

title: Belize Asks U.S. Support
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Prime Minister of Belize, the Central American territory held by Britain, claimed by Guatemala and hopeful of independence, today asked for United States support for independence and territorial integrity.

title: Bergman Loses Appeal; To Go to Jail Tuesday
description: Bernard Bergman, the 67yearold nursinghomes operator who was convicted in Federal and state courts of Medicaid frauds involving $1.2 million, lost the last round yesterday in his fight to avoid a oneyear state prison term. Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court turned down his request for a reprieve, and Mr. Bergman is to begin serving the sentence on Tuesday.

title: Pirates Outslug Phils, 87
description: Would you like to engage Pittsburg's huge Willie Stargell in a fist fight? That was the, choice offered to Tug McGraw, the Philadelphia relief pitcher, at Three Rivers Stadium last night. The fight never materialized, but the threat was ominous.

title: Shipping
description: Mails

title: Two Blazes on Roosevelt Island Being Investigated as Suspicious
description: Officials are investigating the cause of two blazes on Roosevelt Island earlier this week that prompted the Fire Department yesterday to order the building developers to install fireprevention devices on telephone cables connecting apartments.

title: 12 Hijack Plane To Kuwait, Ask Release of 300
description: KUWAIT, July 8 (AP)Twelve hijackers seized a Kuwait Airlines jet today and forced it to land in this Persian Gulf sheikdom. They were reported to have insisted that six Arab ambassadors negotiate their demands, which included freedom for 300 prisoners held in various Arab countries.

title: Letters: On Baseball
description: To the Editor:

title: BUILDING CASTLES IN THE SAND: The early morning rain in Sparta yesterday left the air a bit chilly for swimming at the Engle School day camp, but made the sand just right for sand sculpture. Later, there was wading.
Pilot Found Responsible For Israeli Copter Crash
description: TEL AVIV, July 8A military inquest into the death of 54 Israeli servicemen in a helicopter crash found today that pilot, Capt. Moshe Witner, was responsible because he had flown dangerously low in the darkness.

title: U.S. Moves to Recover Funds from Southern Town
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The Treasury Department said today that would take the first legal action ever to recover Federal revenuesharing funds from a North Carolina town that refused to provide water service to a black family.

title: Notes on People
description: Empress Farah of Iran, continuing her New York round of accepting awards and honors, told an interviewer yesterday that most of the demonstrators who had been plaguing her public appearances were not really Iranians. The protesters include groups opposed to the Iranian monarchy and to the reforms begun by the Shah, the Empress said. It's a small group which are helped by other organizations against what is happening in Iran, she said. There are obviously some Iranians among them, but there are obviously foreign people. The Empress, who was presented with Columbia University's presidential citation yesterday for her work promoting free public education in Iran, said that Communists and Socialists would always attack her husband because he brought about reforms that leftwing governments always promised but seldom delivered. This is a thing that has happened in Iran under a monarchy, she said. She planned to go to Washington the weekend.

title: Hawks Are Still Hooded
description: JERUSALEM  Israel's ballotbox revolution is not yet wholly over. Having attracted to his rightist cause the famous Gen. Moshe Dayan, Gen. Ezer Weizman, air force star and nephew of the first President, and Gen. Ariel Sharon, former Prime Minister Rabin's gungho military adviser, Prime Minister Begin is now trying to solder an alliance with Gen. Yigael Yadin's Democratic Movement for Change.

title: Pike Breakfasts With Carter And Gives the Meal No Stars
description: WASHINGTON, July 8It's pretty obvious now that Otis Pike could never become a member of Jimmy Carter's kitchen cabinet.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: California Air Unit Bans Gas
description: LOS ANGELES, July 8 (UPI)The California Air Resources Board has banned the gasoline additive MMT on the ground that it damages automobile antismog devices and endangers health. California is the first state to do so.

title: Change in Presidency Blurs Succession
description: MOSCOW, July 8The accession of Leonid I. Brezhnev to the presidency last month has confirmed the Communist Party chief as the most powerful man in the Soviet Union, but it has thrown almost no light on the persistent question of who will one day succeed him. Indeed, the move may have complicated the problem of succession since it consolidates the party and government leadership in a way that could be increasingly difficult to disentangle.

title: 1,000 Fire Alarms in Brooklyn Ignored in Screening False Ones
description: New York City's Fire Commissioner acknowledged yesterday that the Fire Department had screened and then declined to respond to more than a thousand street alarms in Brooklyn during more than 24 hours over the threeday Fourth of July weekend.

title: Rail Traffic Rises 9.4%
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled some 16.2 billion tonmiles, 9.4 percent above year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 467,768 cars, 7.6 percent above last year. Both years included the first week of the coal miners holiday. The American Trucking Associations reported intercity truck tonnage was 6.2 percent above fast year.

title: Jacques Duhamel Dies at 53; ExAgriculture Minister of France
description: PARIS, July 8 (Reuters )A former French Agriculture Minister, Jacques Duhamel, died here early today after long illness, officials said. He was 53 years old.

title: Young to Visit Caribbean
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 8An drew Young, the United States chief delegate here, plans to make a 12day trip in August to countries in the Caribben area at the request of President Carter. Mr. Young also was invited to Havana by Cuban officials, but there is no plan for such a visit.

title: Dangerous Lead Content Reported In Paint on McDonald's Glasses
description: BOSTON. July 8 (AP)Promotional drinking glasses distributed by the McDonald's hamburger chain contain dangerous amounts cf leadbased paint and should not be In the hands of children, state officials warned today.

title: Connors Out; Solomon, Dent Gain in W.C.T.
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 8 (AP)Jimmy Connors reinjured the thumb on his right hand during practice today and was forced to withdraw from the World Championship Tennis $200,000 Tournament of Champions.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, JULY 8, 1977

title: Legionnaire
description: ATLANTA, July 8 (AP)  Nineteen sporadic cases of pneumonia since Aug. 1, 1976, were apparently caused by the bacterium responsible for legionnaires disease, the national Center for Disease Control said today.

title: Social Security: The Worst Is Yet to Come
description: A saving of nearly $2.25 billion year is waiting to drop into the lap of the hardpressed Social Security system at no cost to the taxpayer. All that needs doing is for Congress to act on a bill that has been kicking around in the legislative hopper for years, The bill, sponsored by Representative Paul Findley, Republican of Illinois, and other Congressmen, would put an end to the widespread practice of mandatory retirement at 65.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FULL BLOOM SoHo, with several estimable jazz lairs, now has itself a real beauty in the restaurant, bar and music niche called W.P.A. This is a classy, comfortable place, where everything works, including a cavalcade of jazz musicians by the baby grand at the front window.

title: Landes Presses Fight on Petitions
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 8With his new petitions for the Nassau County Executive race properly submitted, Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes continued to fight on two fronts today for the acceptance of copies of his original petitions, which mysteriously disappeared from the Democratic campaign headquarters.

title: W, C. DOWLING DIES; RETIRED U.S.DIPLOMAT
description: Waiter C. Dowling, former ambassador to West Germany and South Korea, died July 1 at his home in Savannah, Ga. He was 71 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: An unusual tactic mat experts sometimes employ is to pass on the first round with a freak hand, hoping to emerge from the bushes later and surprise the opponents. Jeff Westheimer tried this maneuver with the South hand on the diagramed deal; played recently at the Cavendish Club in New York City, and the results were distinctly dramatic.

title: Books of The Times
description: Tolstoy notwithstanding, some families are happy, at least in recollection. Among them must be counted Willard R. Espey's immediate forbears in the village of Oysterville, Wash., of whose lives and relationships he has written this engaging softfocus chronicle. The family's center was a raindrenched peninsula at the southwestern corner of the state of Washington that guarded an estuary notable for its oyster beds.

title: United Press International
description: TRAINS COLLIDE IN CLEVELAND: Firefighter carrying boy from wreckage of two trains of Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority after, they collided headon at combined speed of 70 miles per hour. At least 44 persons were injured when an apparent signal malfunction caused the two trains to be switched onto same track.

title: 2 LongDisputed Projects to Begin
description: TRENTON, July 8One of the longest disputes over highway construction in the state's history ended today when New Jersey was granted a Federal permit to complete a section of State Route 18 in Middlesex County and to build a bridge over the Raritan River in New Brunswick.

title: JOBLESS RATE RISES; WHOLESALE PRICES SHOW A SHARP DROP
description: WASHINGTON, July 8Although the number of Americans with jobs increased for the eighth straight month in June, the unemployment rate edged upward to 7.1 percent of the labor force from 6.9 percent for May, the Government reported today.

title: Hanali Murder Trial Recesses for Weekend
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP)The trial of 12 Hanafi Moslems accused of murder, armed kidnapping and other crimes stemming from the takeover last March of three Washington buildings recessed for the weekend today, with the Hanafi leader expected to testify next week.

title: Y.R.A. Sail Canceled
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 9Lack of wind canceled today the start of the annual twoday Yacht Racing Association regatta sponsored by the Orienta Beach Club.

title: The County and the People
description: THE Environmental Conservation Law that was recently tabled by the Suffolk County Legislature raised an interesting conceptual question that transcends the immediate issue of protecting the environment: Namely, what is the proper role of county government?

title: The Target: Euro
description: Communism

title: New Haven Wonders Who Turned Ta psPn
description: NEW HAVENFor the last two weeks, the police Department of this city has gone through a form of soulsearching as it tries to determine to what extent its officers illegally wiretapped and otherwise spied on innocent citizens over the years. The findings may have consequences beyond New Haven.

title: INITRVIEW
description: LATE in 1945, fresh out of the Navy, a young man with a law degree from Columbia University found himself in Southampton, where his wife and two young sons had been living while waiting for him to come home from the war.

title: Preserve Our Farm Land
description: CONNECTICUT has more farms and grows more food than many people think. It meets 25 to 30 percent of its needs with stateproduced milk, eggs, fruit, vegetables and other foods.

title: Federal Prosecutors Are Completing Case Against Gov. Mandel
description: BALTIMORE, July 9Federal prosecutors have been exploring the complex and most crucial part of their case against Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five associates, before allowing the defense to present its case, probably late next week.

title: Across England on a Thumb
description: After three months of hitchhiking up, down and everywhichway through Englanda postscript to our college yearsDebra and I one night looked at our wellworn map and drew a line south from the Yorkshire town of Barnard Castle to the east coast ferry port of Harwich. Our plan: to set out bright and early the following morning, hitchhiking some 300 miles, almost the length of England, in time to catch the 8 P.M. ferry to the Hook of Holland.

title: Raul JuliaOut of The Ethnic Trap
description: Do not be alarmed by that man, flapping his arms wildly, with a glazed, agonized, popeyed expression on his face. It is only Raul Julia. Or rather, at this point in his career, let us say that it is Raul Julia himself, the focal point of beigeish, rather boring conference room at the Beaumont Theater, being bird. Or something like a bird, with an elephant's lower body. Trying to take off, trying to take off, Julia repeats, his doe eyes popping from their sockets.

title: West German Jesus
description: INSIDE every journalist, I suspect, there is book on Jesus struggling to get out. Rudolf Augstein is a superlative journalist who created almost singlehandedly that now established German institution, Der Spiegel, which has played an important role in giving postwar German democracy healthy and enduring democratic roots. He was born and brought up a Roman Catholic, watched his religion operate as the chief formative influence in Konrad Adenauer's regime and was, and is, determined that its pretentions should be well and truly exposed. It is at this point that his book on Jesus emerged from beneath his journalistic carapace. It is immensely readable, full of interest both intrinsic and personal, and it is valuable in the sense that no one, whether Catholic, Protestant, agnostic or atheist, can examine, it without in some way having his or her mental horizons extended.

title: Japanese Electing Part Of Upper House Today
description: TOKYO, July 9 (UPI)Half the seats in Japan's upper house of Partliament are at stake tomorrow in an election viewed as a test of strength for the governing LiberalDemocratic Party and its leader, Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda.

title: A Barometer of Contemporary Trends
description: ART

title: Watson, on 65 268, Wins British Open; Nicklaus 2d at 269
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland, July 9In an epic headtohead match even more gripping than yesterday's tie at 65, Tom Watson came from three strokes behind today to beat Jack Nicklaus by one shot for the British Open golf championship. Watson shot 65 on seven birdies and two bogeys while Nicklaus carded 66 on four birdies and no bogeys.

title: The Primary Primary
description: HARTFORD

title: Another Fregosi Walk Aids Pirates Triumph
description: The Philadelphia Phillies have seen just about enough of Pittsburgh's Jim Fregosi in the last two days. Fregosi, who never will be confused with Lou Brock on the basepaths, did not even has to demonstrate his lack of speed either.

title: U.C.L.A. Names Coach
description: LOS ANGELES, July 9 (AP)Gary Cunningham, who turned down chance two years ago to succeed John Wooden as the University of California, Los Angeles, basketball coach, was named to the position today, replacing Gene Bartow.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: A recent article in The Times on nuclear power in Connecticut (May 5, 1977), while not inaccurate, was certainly incomplete, as it failed to mention the massive hidden costs of nuclear power. It is vital, as the nuclear debate broadens and intensifies, that citizens clearly understand all the economic consequences associated with a program of nuclear expansion.

title: Dr. Alan Richman to Wed Dr. Tina Simpson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour D. Simpson of Harrison, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Tina Carol Simpson, to Dr. Alan Herbert Richman. He is a son of Mrs. Jack J. Richman of Little Neck, Queens, and the late Mr. Richman. A September wedding is planned.

title: 500 Families in Food Venture
description: VALERIE Mattey recited her list of culinary perversions with scorn: Waxed cucumbers, waxed green peppers, carrots that don't taste like carrots. Mrs. Mattey, accompanied oy ner year to son, Joshua, disdained what she considers the poor quality of most supermarket vegetables and headed for Way of Life, a natural foods cooperative in Pleasantville, four miles from her home in Briarcliff. At the cooperative, she and her son browsed contentedly among the fruits (and vegetables) of organic farming.

title: Scholar's Colleagues Upset by His Teaching in Chile
description: Resignations and protests have resulted at the Center for InterAmerican Relations over the acceptance by a staff director of a State Departmentsponsored teaching assignment in Chile, where academic and press freedoms have been sharply curtailed.

title: Judge Finds Alaska Is Horse Show Country
description: A decade ago, even the thought of a horse show in Alaska would have been greeted with laughs.

title: Helping People Who Hide
description: NLY a year ago, few could bearly even pronounce the word, let alone understand its meaning. Then people got interested in it, and now that mouthful of letters rolls easily off the lips. Agoraphobia.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: The Heart and Soul of New Orleans Rock
description: The rock and soul music of New Orleans, which is unlike the rock and soul of any other city, has been dominated by a single individual for at least 10 years now. The individual's name is Allen Toussaint, and he is a record producer, a songwriter, a pianist, a singer, and coowner, with his partner Marshall Sehorn, of a recording studio, a music publishing firm, and other, related ventures. He has made some of the most compelling and successful single records of the past two decades, from oldies such as Ernie KDoe's MotherInLaw to Labelle's Lady Marmalade, a record so spectacular, musically and commercially, that the group was unable to even come close to equaling it and had to disband.

title: Jimmy Jordan, Harness Driver, Won Messenger Stakes in 1958
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 9Jiminy Jordan, one of the first harnessracing drivers to compete at Roosevelt Raceway, since its inception in 1940, died this morning of an apparent heart attack. Mr. Jordan, 72 years old, was stricken outside the Roosevelt stable area and rushed to the Nassau County Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival.

title: Housing as the Key to the City
description: IN a rehabilitated centuryold redbrick building that was once Bridgeport corset factory, some 60 representatives of public and private agencies exchanged ideas and opinions recently on what might be done to improve the city's future.

title: Turkish Delight
description: IT strikes me as unfortunate that Turkey's neighbors, Greece and Iran, get such attention, while Turkey itself is pretty much disregarded. Perhaps it has something to do with the humiliation Europeans feel when they reflect that the Turkish Empire once included a large section of Europe. Or is it that whiff of Asiatic barbarity that Alexander Kinglake mentions at the beginning of his great travel book Eothen (1844), as he heads towards Constantinople? In our century, Lord Kinross and Freya Starkto mention but twohave described this astonishing country, but there is also a native witness who, in the halfdozen books of his that have been translated, has depicted his country with a close attention to detail and yet with a majestic, almost epic sweep.

title: Clammers: Sea Is Their Oyster
description: IT IS early in the morning, before light, and Ben Edwards is piloting the American Patriot, an 89foot clam boat, through the barely rippling inlet at the northern rim of Atlantic City, heading for the open sea.

title: New Sport Gives Ski Slopes A Piece of Summer Action
description: The temperature is in the 70's, the parking lot is coated with oil to keep down the dust and the prevailing color of the White Mountain countryside is a rich green. But cars by the hundreds are streaming into the Attitash ski area outside Bartlett, N.H., and there's a waiting line at the chairlift.

title: Exploring Nature's Fireworks
description: TOWARD the end of June and into the middle of July, when the evenings are warm and humid, the fireflies put on their annual fireworks display. Some people never notice them; others are charmed momentarily by the incessant phosphorescent glowing as each firefly puts out its own tiny starburst.

title: Kathleen Rachel Bride Of Laurence K. Ferguson
description: Kathleen Lynn Rachel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Murray Rachel of Spring Lake, N. J., was married there yesterday to Laurence Kevin Ferguson, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Joseph Ferguson of Brooklyn. The Rev. Jeremiah McGinley performed the ceremony in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Time+ Loves BookoftheMonth
description: Another romance in the mergerminded publishing world has blossomed into a decision to take the plunge. This time the partners are Time Inc. and the 51yearold BookoftheMonth Club. They have announced an agreement by which the Si billion magazine and boiik publishing giant will acquire the $65 million book club, the first to be established in the United States.

title: Baseball: Too Slow a Game in a Jet Age
description: Baseball is boring. Coming from a former sandlotter who spent most of his boyhood racing around the bases, that sounds like heresy. Maybe so, but in today's jetage society the Great American Pastime remains a slothfooted sport. The pace of play is deadening and maddening.

title: Miss Kauffman Sets Nuptials for Aug. 13
description: Mr. and Mrs. Garth Emerson Kauffman of Greenwich and Salisbury, Conn.. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tracy Carol Kauffman, to Robert Stewart Kinscherf. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kinscherf of Mount Carmel, Conn.

title: The Man With the Hoe
description: By now you can tell the gardener from the mere planter simply by looking at him. Has he a kink in his back? Has he a hoe in his hand? You don't have to look at his garden. If he is a gardener he is doing daily battle with the weeds.

title: Rep. Brademas, Mary E. Briggs Have Nuptials
description: Mary Ellen Briggs, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander S. Budd of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married yesterday to Representative John Brademas, Democrat of Indiana, at the First United Methodist Church in South Bend, Ind. Mr. Brademas, who Is the majority leader, is the son of Mrs. Stephen J. Brademas of South Bend and the late Mr. Brademas.

title: Catherine A. Ruane Sets Sept. 23 Bridal
description: Catherine A. Ruane Sets Sept. 23 Bridal

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: For the Handicapped, A Giant Step Forward
description: DECIDED to publish a newsletter for the physically handicapped in New Jersey after having a dream. Maybe it was because the question that haunted me that night while waiting for sleep was: Well, Dorothy, now that DAVID is written and published, what's next? When the predawn light crept through my window, the idea came. Why don't I help others who are handicapped like my son David?

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Pfister and Tim Gullikson Reach Newport Net Final
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 9 (AP)California's Hank Pfister gained the final of the $50,000 Hall of Fame grass tennis tournament today by defeating Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia, 63, 16, 64.

title: Alaska Pipeline Flow Is Indefinite After Explosion at Pumping Station
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 9The $7.7 billion TransAlaska Pipeline was a little more than twothirds full of motionless oil today after a pumping station explosion near here that killed a technician and injured five workmen.

title: The Petroboom Slows
description: JIDDAH, Saudi ArabiaAfter nearly four years of heady and sometimes uncontrolled growth, the economies of the oilexporting countries that border the Persian Gulf have begun to slow down. Building is moving less rapidly, governments are tightening their purse strings, controls are being placed on the growth of the money supply, inflation has become more of a concern than the gross national product and efficiency is being increased.

title: More Harmony Than Dissonance
description: FIORELLO LA GUARDIA once said that there was neither a Republican nor a Democratic way to collect garbage. His point was that fundamental ideological and political differences were more likely to surface at the state and national levels of government than in localities.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: WRITING in Harper's magazine in 1965twelve years after Bellow's The Adventures of Augie March, nine years after Seize The Day, seven years after Malamud's The Magic BarrelKatherine Anne Porter, that living symbol of the Southern literary tradition, proclaimed, I am an old North American. My people came to Virginia in 1648, so we have had time to become acclimatized. . . Truly, the South and the West . . . have made and are making American literature. We are in the direct, legitimate line; we are people based in English as our mother tongue, and we do not abuse it or misuse it, and when we speak a word, we know what it means. These others have fallen into a curious kind of argot, more or less originating in New York, a deadly mixture of academic, guttersnipe, gangster, fakeYiddish, and dull old worneut dirty wordsan appalling bankruptcy in language, as if they hate English and are trying to destroy it along with all other living things they touch.

title: FISHING
description: IT'S A tossup this week for New Jersey fishermen. Fluke fishing is sporadicgood one day, off the next. Off North Jersey, look for the bluefish to move closer to shore, especially if the warm weather continues.

title: Books for a Cause
description: ANY BOOK that sells more than a million copies is a best seller, but you may not necessarily find the books published by the Fleming H. Revell Company of Old Tappan on the weekly bestseller lists. However, the people at Revell are among the thost effective and most competitive publishers today.

title: IN BRIEF
description: PRESIDENT CARTER met with his energy adviser James R. Schlesinger and ordered the preparation of a comprehensive standby gasoline rationing (proposal to be presented soon to Congress  Carter Administration atilclais said that changes that Borne committees nave mace in tne neseeident's energy plan over the last two weeks could produce $30 billion no $40 billion in additional budget deficits, between now and 1988... The Federal Power Commission charged Texaco Inc. with violating the Natural Gas Act in using gas from Federal offshore leases in a refinery and ordered the company to halt the practice and pay back the gas and other liabilities.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: BigFamily Bind: Finding a Home That Fits
description: The truly large family is going the way of the truly large house.

title: Elizabeth W. Lozier Is Married
description: The marriage of Elizabeth W. Lozier, daughter of Mrs. William S. Walcott 3d of Middlebury, Conn., and the late John W. M. Lozier, to John C. Chapin Jr. took place yesterday in Watertown, Conn. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. Chapin of Manchester, Vt., and Mrs. Arthur Smith Jr. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and a grandson of the late Roy D. Chapin founder and president of the Hudson Motor Company and Secretary of Commerce in the Hoover Administration.

title: Patricia Tidwell Married
description: Patricia Ruth Tidwell daughter of Brig. Gen. William A. Tidwell.S.A., retired, a Washington, Mrs. Tidwell of was married yesterday to Shaw David Kinsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wynn C. Kinsley of Boulder, Colo. The ceremony was performed at the couple's home in New York by Civil Court Judgd Eugene Nardelli. The bride is an account executive with Ted Bates & Company. Her husband, an importer of antique scientific instruments, heads his own concern, Shaw Kinsley & Company.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JULY 10, 1977

title: United Parcel Granted 7% Increae in Rates
description: ALBANY, July 9 (UPI)The State Transportation Commissioner, William C. Hennessy, has granted United Parcel Service a 7 percent increase in its rates within the state, department officials announced today.

title: Rome's Wealthy Use Pawnshops for Summer Storage
description: ROME, July 9A shabbily dressed woman stepped out of a snail Fiat the other day carrying a stuffed laundry bag. She walked into a 16thcentury palazzo near the Piazza Farnese, went up to teller in one of Europe's biggest pawnshops, pulled a mink coat out of the bag and received $75 in exchange. With the nowempty bag under her arm, having hedged against burglars and moths, she drove off, perhaps to a prosperous residential section.

title: Julia Chase, Teacher, Wed
description: Julia Chase; an assistant professor of biology at Barnard College, was married yesterday to George Howard Brand, visiting assistant professor of political science at Barnard.

title: Joan Maria Leslie Becomes Bride
description: Joan Maria Leslie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Leslie Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church to George Dorr Wadsworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Y. Wadsworth of Lincoln, Mass. The Rev. George W. R. MacCray performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, N.J.

title: GARDENING
description: ORGANIC gardening is at once the oldest and most controversial gardening practice. In simpler times past, all gardeners were organic gardeners. It was taken for granted that the manure from the livestock, including the family cow or the horse of the villager, was to be applied to the garden. Any kitchen scraps uneaten by the family chickens, dog or cat were added to the manure pile by the barn.

title: United Press International
description: LOSES FAMILY IN MUDSLIDE: A South Korean man knelt in despair near site of mudslide ten miles south of Seoul as rescue workers sifted through the mud and rubble. Torrential rains triggered flooding and slides that have claimed more than 180 lives. At least 150 others are still missing. Flooding In southwestern France has claimed eight lives, with 16 missing, as rains there inundated several villages and washed out bridges.

title: L.I. Clinic Reports Success in Treatment OfAgoraphobia Panicat Thought ofTravel
description: Only a year ago, few could barely even pronounce the word, let alone understand its meaning. Then people got interested in it, and now the mouthful of letters rolls easily off the lips: agoraphobia.

title: Clashes With Insurgents In Mindanao Continue
description: COTABATO CITY, Philippines, July (AP)Armed bands have engaged Government forces in a series of clashes on the island of Mindanao in the southern Philippines during the last five weeks.

title: STAMPS
description: Anew series of multicolored postal cards with indicia devoted to Historic Preservation is being launched by the United States this year, while next year will bring series paying tribute to performing arts and artists.

title: JailTerm Guidelines Agreed to by Leaders
description: ALBANY, July 9Legislative leaders and Governor Carey have agreed on measure that would substantially alter the way New York State's Parole Board decides how long a criminal must stay in prison and when he can be released. The measure would also separate the Parole Board from the Department of Correctional Services.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: In the Introduction to the second edition of Albert Pick's Standard Catalog of World Paper Money. which has just been published, the author speaks of the growing trend to thematics in collecting. A num ber of countries have helped stimulate this interest by issuing currency with definite esthetic motifsfor example, the book mentions the birds on New Zealand's currency, some African states that picture animals, and Israel and Indonesia showing flowers.

title: Customer's Option: Where to Watch the Market
description: TAPEWATCHING, or interpreting the stock market by reading the tape that reports each trade, is an old and honorable activity. Many investors look forward to retirement, holidays and even unemployment as time to spend happy hours tapewatching in a neighborhood brokerage.

title: Pope May Again Discipline Rebel
description: ROME, July 9The Vatican said today it was considering, with caution, canonical sanctions on Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the leader of a conservative movement within the Roman Catholic Church who has disobeyed Pope Paul VI.

title: The Government Payroll Moves in One Direction
description: The number of Americans working for governmentFederal, state, and, localmore than doubled in the last 20 years, largely because of increased state and local activity in education, health and public welfare. Most of the increase in government employment, from 7.4 million in 1955 to 15 million in 1975, was concentrated at state and local levels; Federal employment actually declined during some years in the late 1960's and early 1970's.

title: CHESS
description: It is curious, if not also mysterious, how a whole series of tournaments in one place can acquire one character, while a series in another place produces an altogether different impression.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayLake Placid, Lake Placid, N.Y. Grand Prix for jumpers. 2 P.M.

title: Education
description: The American Library Association, a group of 35,000 librarians that traditiorially has opposed censorship in any form, is involved in a controversy over whether the active support of good causes can, in fact, be a kind of censorship. The causes are antiracism and antisexism.

title: Tariff Walls Tumble in Europe
description: A quiet milestone in European economic history was passed on July 1, when the last remaining customs duties on industrial goods produced by 15 European nations were finally dismantled. Removal of tariffs between the nine members of the Common Market and the seven members of the European Free Trade Association creates a powerful West European market of more than 300 million customers, giving industries in any of these countries, from Portugal to Norway and from Finland to Italy, a vast new free trade area of which to expand.

title: The Medawars
description: WHEN one of Britain's most renowned and articulate scientists collaborates with his scarcely less wellpublicized wife to produce a book [The Life Science, reviewed May 22] which sets to expand contemporary ideas concerning the nature and mechanisms of living things, and when they do this for the particular benefit of sociologists, anthropologists, philosophers, psychologists and literary folk, the result should be worth reading and it is. It might also be expected that the text would be a trifle recondite in placesand it is that too. For this is no pedagogical attempt to present predigested, plasticpackaged, portions of nutritious knowledge to the intellectual starvelings of this world. It is, instead, a matter of like calling unto like. It is a lofty work written by a couple who are, quite consciously, delivering their message from somewhere near the peak of Mount Parnassus.

title: Ian McLaughlin to Wed Mary Makriailes
description: Mr. and Mrs. James K. Makrianes Jr. of New York and East Hampton, Li., have announced the engagement of Mr. Makrianes's daughter, Mary Gill Makrianes, to Ian Malcolm Watson McLaughlin, son of Mrs. Malcolm McLaughlin of New York and Linconyille, Me., and the late Mr. McLaughlin.

title: Paul Leach, Retired Correspondent In Capital for the Knight Papers
description: ORMOND BEACH, Fla., July 9 (AP)Paul R. Leach, a retired Washington correspondent for Knight Newspapers, died here today after a short illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Summer Action

title: Products To Make Things Easier Around the Home
description: To eliminate the need for throwing batteries away and buying new ones each time the old ones are exhausted, General Electric has introduced a new rechargeable battery system. Available from hardware, photo supply and electronics stores, the system consists of a miniature plugin recharging transformer that accepts a variety of different modules for popular sizes of nickel cadmimum rechargeable batteries. The modules, which hold the batteries while they are being recharged, simply snap onto the bottom end of the tiny recharger.

title: What's Doing in ISTANBUL
description: EAST MEETS WESTNear the Blue Mosque in the Old City of Istanbul, there are two signs taped to the window of the Magic Bus Company. One advertises a bus leaving at 5 P.M. for Teheran, Kabul and New Delhi; the other, bus an hour later for Athens, Munich and London. For many Westerners, Istanbul provides first glimpse of the East: mosques and minarets, bazaars and belly and not enough dignity. But for many Turks, the city is their first view of the West: modern hotels, short skirts and supermarkets, the chance for a better education and a better job. Above all, Istanbul is cultural crossroads, and this gives the city its special sort of juicy, jangling vitality. The great minarets of the Suleytnaniye Mosque, Horn,

title: Lefebvre to Consecrate Texas Church
description: DICKINSON, Tex., July 9 (UPI)Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, whose campaign to restore traditional rites in the Roman Catholic Church is threatening a schism, will consecrate his first American church tomorrow in this suburb of Houston.

title: Marital Arbitration: No Clients
description: IT MAY be too early to conclude that the Island's marital wars have cooled and have been replaced by conjugal bliss, but after almost year of operation in Garden City, the AMerican Arbitration Association's new service, designed to help squabbling douples bury the hatchet and break out the champagne, has had precisely no customers. Zero?

title: Hospital Strike Talks Broken Off
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP)Talks between Temple University Hospital and the hospital workers union, which has been on strike sincetThursday, broke off early today due to a lack of progress, a union spokesman said.

title: Does Power Bring Happiness? Not in Squabbling Bonn
description: BONNFor most of the past quarter century, West German political coalitions have been like a collection stable, conventional middleciass marriages. This year, almost all of them are troubled and fractious, if not actually on the rocks. Paradoxically, at a time when West Germany has become the most powerful country in. Western Europe, it is preoccupied with petty domestic spats instead of entering a new era of economic and political leadership.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Robert Ludlum
description: September 1975. The Palm Restaurant. Robert Ludlum took a sip of his martini, then peered across the table at his dining companion and editor, Richard Marek. What would you think, Mr. Ludlum asked, if I told you J. Edgar Hoover didn't die of natural causes, but was assassinated for his files?

title: Indian Kashmir Government Sworn
description: NEW DELHI, July 9A new Government headed by the Kashmiri Moslem leader, Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, was sworn in today in Srinagar, capital of Kashmir. In state elections a week ago, the sheik's party, the National Conference, swept the polls winning 46 seats of the 76seat State Assembly, trouncing both the Congress Party and the Janata Party, which is now ruling from New Delhi.

title: Police Are Curbing Street Crimes With Decoys Disguised as Victims
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9  Street criminals in a growing number of American cities have recently been shocked to find that the pregnant woman or elderly pensioner they have just mugged is actually a police officer.

title: The Nation
description: Continued

title: John Mortimer Schiff
description: John Mortimer Schiff, born in Roslyn, LI., 74 years ago this Aug. 26, is the son of Mortimer L. Schiff and Adele G. Neustadt and is the grandson of Jacob H. Schiff, Soninlaw of Solomon Loeb, the Loeb in Kuhn, Loeb & Company. Solomon Loeb arrived in this country from Germany in 1849. His brotherinlaw, Abraham Kuhn, the other half of Kuhn, Loeb, had arrived here a few years earlier.

title: Fire Commissioner O'Hagan Reports 119,026 false Marin
description: John T. O'Hagan, the New York CAT Fire Commissioner, said in a report released yesterday that the Fire Department received 119,026 false alarms in the first six months of this year.

title: GARDENING
description: PERENNIAL plants are a boon and a blessing to the serious gardener. Among my hardy perennials, bearded irises are among the most dependable, satisfying and widely adaptable. And they were at their impressive best this season, probably because of last winter's unusually good snow cover.

title: A FAMILY'S AFFAIR WITH JAPAN
description: TOKYO. What my family and I didn't know about Japan 18 months ago when we arrived here is what we are only beginning to understand about Japan now: The honesty that keeps a man from picking up a forgotten coin in a phone booth because it's not mine. The personal security that makes fear in the city a fiction. A service philosophy that makes a dentist phone a patient several days after an appointment to make sure a new tooth cap is still fine. The values that turn a common boulder into a decorative object of great worth. The traditions that prompt a shopkeeper to doublecheck an electronic calculator with an ancient wooden abacus. The language based on vagueness where a single word like hakitai carries three meanings: to sweep, to put on shoes and to vomit.

title: Births and the State Budget
description: THE recent closing in Copiague of Lakeside Hospital's maternity ward and plans by the Stat Health Department to consol date the obstetrics services of four Nassau and Suffolk County hospitals into two units are causing concern and anxiety among hospital administrators, physicians and patients.

title: A Doomful Daughter
description: When troubled, tomboyish Emily Fielding is expelled from Quaker school for shooting a cappistol in Meeting, the family maid remarks grimly, Someday there's gonna be more than caps shooting around here.

title: President Assad Is a Member of the Alawite Moslem Sect
description: BEIRUT, LebanonIn his seven years in power, President Hafez alAssad has given Syria the longest period of internal stability in its 33 years of independence. But recent political murders have drawn attention to ancient divisions among the nation's eight million people that threaten President Assad's domestic policies and could affect the search for a wider Middle East peace.

title: Stavriani Papadopoulos Wed to Bruce Stewart
description: Stavriani Papadopoulos, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Papadopoulos, of Athens, was married there yesterday in St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox Church to Bruce Norman Stewart, son of Norman W. Stewart and Dr. Ann Roberts Stewart of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.X.

title: SELECTION
description: SO NOW Pierre turned his attention to another kind of courtship. As soon as she entered he noted how she moved, how she took her coat and hat off, how she shook her hair, what rings she wore. He thought that from all these signs he could detect her mood. Then this mood became his ground for conquest. Today she was childlike, pliant, with her hair loose, her head bowing easily with the weight of all her life. She had on less makeup, an innocent expression, she wore a light dress of bright colors. Today he would caress her gently, with tenderness, observing the perfecazn of her toes, for instance, as free as the fingers of a hand; observing her ankles, on which paleblue veins showed through; observing the little ink spot forever tattooed below her knee, where, when she was fifteena girl in school and 7:oaring black stockingsshe had covered a little hole in the stockings with ink. The pen point had broken during the process, wounding her and marking her skin for good. He would look for a broken fingernail so that he might deplore its loss, its pathetic truncated look among her other long, pointed ones. He worried over all her little miseries. He held close to him the little girl in her, whom he would have liked to know. He asked questions: So you wore black cotton stockings?

title: Andrea Suarez Is Wed To Robert K. Erlanger
description: Andrea Maria Suarez, daughter of Mrs. Holcomb P. Alderman of Essex, Conn., and Joseph A. Suarez Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Keith Erlanger, son of Mrs. Marilyn J. Guarch and Dr. Herbert L. Erlanger, both of New York. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's father and stepmother by Dr. Michael Grupp of the Ethical Culture School.

title: Zambia Reports Gun Duel With Rhodesian Force
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 9 (Reuters)Zambia said tonight that its artillery units fought a 10hour battle with Rhodesian forces across the Zambezi River on their troubled border Thursday night.

title: Insult to Money
description: Social note: Muhammad Ali of Chicago, Louisville, Deer Lake, Pa., and Berrien Springs, Mich.. departs Tuesday to visit friends in England. In Newcastle, he said yesterday, there was this guy came over needs money for boys clubs so I'm going over. Be back in about a week and I'll start training for Shavers in about two weeks. I'm only running now but I'm in good shape, around 222, about a pound over fighting weight. I'd been up around 235, 245, but not since my last fight. No Lawdy, no, I been keeping my weight down. I'll train in Berrien Springs, Mich., where got a farm, a 88acre farm. That's Bhow do you spell Berrien Springs? The question was an aside, followed by a brief silence. Then the familiar voice was back on the Berrien.

title: Progress, But Far to Go
description: NEWARKKenneth A. Gibson is up at 6 every morning to allow plenty of jogging time before he goes to his office in City Hall. I've got to stay in shape for this job, he explains.

title: Publisher of The Washington Post Meets With President of Rumania
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 9 (AP)Katherine Graham, the publisher of The Washington Post and journalists from the Post and Newsweek magazine, which owned by The Post, met today with President Nicolee Ceausescu of Rumania.

title: Letters
description: The B1 Decision and the Arms Race

title: How to Save on Electric Bills in the Summer
description: HOME CLINIC

title: REFUGEES WHO REACH HONG KONG ARE LUCKY
description: HONG KONG, July 9When Le Dung. a 50yearold fisherman, set out to escape from Vietnam last week, his thought was to steer directly for the United States. A simpl9 uneducated man who has spent most of his life on his small boat, Mr. Dung said he had decided he would rather risk death on the ocean than live any longer under the everIncreasing restrictions the Communists were imposing on him.

title: Indonesia Works To Save a Gem Of Buddhist Art
description: JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, July 5Like a gigantic jigsaw puzzle of inestimable value, one of Asia's great proponents of art is being taken apart stone by stone and put together again. By 1982, when the enormous task is expected to be completed, 1.2 million stones will have been disassembled, cleaned, chemically treated and replaced.

title: Deborah L. Voss Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Voss of Islip and Montauk. L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Lynn Voss to J. Richard Koch, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Koch of Reading, Pa.

title: Collector's Item
description: ANAIS NIN'S famous erotica (only brief excerpts of which appeared in Diary III), written in the early 1940's for a private collector, have now become public under the suggestive title of Delta of Venus.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1NASA

title: The Downtown Cabaret's Restless Spirit
description: ON OPENING night of The Sixties, which is at the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport through July 24, Claude McNeal, who conceived and directed the show, got part of the cast together. He warned them of a dangerous exit they would have to make in the dark against incoming cast members for the next number. To show how the exit should be taken, he turned, missed the steps, fell off the stage, and broke his arm.

title: Britain Assembles Aid Package
description: LONDON, July 9 (Reuters)Britain is putting together an economic development aid package for Guatemala that hopes will induce the Central American republic to agree to the full independence of the neighboring British colony of Bet ize, British officials said today.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: If the international tanker industry is in a crisis at the moment, Ravi Tikkoo certainly doesn't show it. At a time when many of his European competitors have their ships laid up in moth balls or are negotiating the cancellation of shipbuilding contracts because of the glut of world tanker capacity, Mr. Tikkoo talks boldly of ordering three huge nuclear tankers from an American shipyard in a size class never before built.

title: WE WANT TO MAKE THESE KIDS NEUROTIC
description: That is the goal of an extraordinary nursery in Yonkers which was established to help violent and disturbed children.

title: One Ride on Powerboat Convinced Aoki
description: It was his first trip in a boat and he was scared . 85 miles an hour across the ocean . no life jacket .and he couldn't swim. So he hung on, tightly.

title: U.N. Begins Preparing For Its 1979 Program, The Year of the Child
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 8The United Nations, having worked its way through International Refugee Year, Population, Women's Year and a few other years, Is gearing up for another: International Year of the Child.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today Championship racing at Watkins Glen. N.Y. Warmups at 1:05 P.M.; 50mile Super Vee Bosch Gold Cup race at 2:15; 165mile S.C.C.A. Citicorp CanAm race at 3:30.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Stripers on the Surface
description: Although more striped bass are probably taken on the East Coast by trolling with subsurface lures, there is no other angling excitement like the strike of a striper on a topwater plug.

title: Ideas From Moving Water
description: THE dance critic Edwin Denby once wrote of Frederick Ashton's choreography, The more trivial the subject matter, the deeper and more oeautiful is Ashton's poetic view of it. Among the nearly 100 ballets the great British choreographer has made since 1926, many of the most enduring ones like The Dream, La Fille Mal Garde, Enigma Variations, and Cinderella have gentle, even trivial scenarios; yet tney reveal mucn about people and their feelings for each other and the landscapes they inhabit.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: Most people can save on fuel during the heating season by setting thermostats a bit lower, and, if necessary, by dressing warmer. Now that warm weather has arrived, the consumption of energy by home airconditioners can be cut by an even greater amount by setting thermostats on home airconditioners slightly higher.

title: Vietnam Lessons
description: DOES historic truth exist plain and immutable? Is the floodlight that makes its discovery possible forever fixed and impervious to revision? Is a cause just, once and for all, and an opponent's error irreversible as proved? Can revelations produced oy a tleeISIVe eventby the mere tact of its having happened and of its opening a vista until then hidden from viewmodify the perspective of an observer, a journalist, a historian? Must the right always be considered wholly right and the wrong definitively cast into outer darkness? Is the modern world, in sum, no more than a poor imitation of the Old Testament?

title: New York and Federal Agencies in Dispute on Medicaid Inspectors
description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has told the Carey administration to remove its Medicaid inspectors from New York hospitals and accept the authority of the Federal Government in determining the medical necessity and appropriateness of hospital care paid with Medicaid funds.

title: DINING OUT
description: ROTHMANN'S in East Norwich is one of those large old farmhousesturnedrestaurants that dot the Island. The recycling is natural. You imagine a mellow, cozy place, touched gently by time, with simple, fresh, homecooked food to delight the palate. Unfortunately, it doesn't always work out that way. Rothmann's is set in an expanse of asphalt relieved by borders of shrubs, trees and flowers. Inside, wall paneling and acoustical ceiling modernizations have been applied with restraint. The bar area just to the left of the entrance, a warmly rustic, darkwoodandglass retreat, is certainly the most appealing area the restaurant. It was once the original 1732 carriage house. If there are no children in your party, reserve table in the bar.

title: Good Old Days Stay At Mahopac Hotel
description: AT THE TURN of the century, welltodo women spent summer evenings there, fanning themselves on the veranda. In 1936, it was the site of the convention of the Socialist Party of America at which Norman Thomas was nominated for President.

title: Five Die in Ohio Auto Crash
description: EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio, July 9 (UPI) Five persons from East Liverpool were killed and one injured early today in onecar accident just north of here. The Ohio Highway Patrol said that the car, driven by Michael Jordon, 16 years old, had gone off the road, struck a tree and split in half. The victims were identified as Leigh Ann Page, 13, Christopher Far.ich, 19, Robert Laughlin, 14, Kathy Laughlin, 15, and Roy Harvey, 20.

title: New Hours at Library Units
description: Starting July 18, branches of thel Queens Borough Public Library that were on a threeday schedule will be open five days a week, Milton S. Byam, library director, announced. Each branch will have its own staff, instead of sharing personnel with another community. The Central Library will maintain its schedule of 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. daily and 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Saturdays.

description: MOSCOW, July 9A Soviet commenta 1 for today denounced a proposed American neutron bomb as inconsistent with President Carter's stand on human rights, and said that development of such a weapon could jeopardize SovietAmerican 1 talks on strategic arms limitation.

Manuscripts, accompanied by a stamped, selfaddressed envelope, should be sent by October 1, 1977 to: Anthology, The New York City Affiliate of the National Council on Alcoholism, 4th Floor, 730 Fifth Avenue, N.Y., N.Y. 10019. Honorariums of $100 will be paid for each accepted story or play, and $25 for

title: If You Go
description: camping in New Brunswick, you may choose among 68 provincial and two national parks. Entrance fees for provincial parks are a uniform $4.50 per vehicle this year, and include the use of showers, cookhouses and wood; electrical hookups are available for an additional 50 cents. Entrance to Kouchibouguac National Park is free; Fundy National Park charges $3 per automobile. Both parks offer threeway hookupselectricity, water and sewagefor $3 per trailer per night.

title: DINING OUT
description: SHERMAN'S Taverne, a new restaurant near the New Haven Green, is truly exquisite. It's hard to keep from bursting into spontaneous applause for the impeccable taste (and, appar ently, limitless funds) that went into this inspired renovation of New Haven's Union League Club, built in the 1890's on the site of patriot Roger Sherman's home.

That was in the 1930's and 40's. In July 1976, business had so slipped that the McAlpin closed. The new owners said they would convert to apartments. Some 20 tenants balked at moving.

description: When the woods are empty of other voices, you can hear the foresf music that the Scots call soughing, the surflIke sound of wind passing through evergreen boughs. For a week last August, that sound lulled us to sleep as we camped in the parks of maritime New Brunswick.

title: For Dissenters at Home or Abroad, Human Rights Is a Very Human Issue

Her gift is restricted two pounds each of sausage and biscuits, a pound each of sugar and cheese and a little more than four pounds of fruit and vegetables.

description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)The Federal Government cannot guarantee that black colleges will survive the newly ordered desegregation of universities in six Southern states, an official at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare saidtoday.

description: Francis X. Shea, the former chancellor or administrative head of Antioch College's undergraduate campus at Yellow Springs, Ohio, died of a heart attack yesterday at Greene County Memorial Hospital, Xenia, Ohio. He was 51 years old.

title: New York State Women's Meeting Attracts 7,000
description: ALBANY, July 9By 5 o'clock this morning, women had begun lining up outside the Palace Theater and the Convention Hall at the Empire State Plaza to make sure they would be able to nominate their favorite candidates to represent them at the National Women sConference in Houston in the fall. But even arriving shortly after dawn was no guarantee.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Perdurable lady. A long line of quiz kids have popped up and disappeared since the paperback changed the style of U.S. book publishing, but there's only one person whose influence in the genre has remained indisputably great through all its years.

title: Discovery of Carew
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 8America was beautiful before Columbus arrived in 1492 and gold sparkled in California streams before 1849, just as Rod Carew was winning five American League batting titles before now. But for the Minnesota Twins first baseman, this is the year of discovery. Suddenly it's fashionable to ap plaud Rod Carew as baseball's best hitter because his batting average is around .400 approaching the AllStar Game break. Suddenly he's a national subject, almost a national treasure. Time magazine, Sports Illustrated and Sport are planning cover stories on him. People magazine will display him and Newsweek has already done a piece on him. ABC News had TV cameramen following him around.

title: 20 Report Tomorrow As Knicks Open Training
description: The New York Knicks and their new coach, Willis Reed, will open training camp tomorrow at Monmouth College, West Long Branch, N.J. Twenty rookies and free agents will report for physical examinations.

title: Orioles Down Yanks, 65, on 3 Unearned Runs in 8th
description: BALTIMORE, July 9  Why, Jim Palmer was asked before he pitched against the Yankees tonight, are the Baltimore Orioles still in the pennant race when everyone knows they should have disappeared weeks, perhaps months, ago?

title: Love And / or Die
description: WE have been led to believe, since Descartes, that our bodies are mere machines. After all, the final common pathways of disease end death are physical: plugged filters here, sludge in the tubes there, a leaking valve somewhere else. With electron microscopes, at a finer level of definition, we visualize crumbling slums of damaged cells, junlcyards of wrecked molecules. Therefore we believe the causes of disease and death must De physical.

title: Edenwald And Its Children
description: ACHILD with an I.Q. of 60 can be taught, given huge amounts of time, resources and patience. An emotionally disturbed child can be trained, with arduous effort. But when a child is both retarded and emotionally disturbed, where can he go?

description: The old adage about fat people being jolly was probably not invented by anyone fat or anyone jolly. Certainly, 14yearold Bobby Marks would not find it an accurate remark.

description: Mary Deborah Diggs Duke, an its sistant editor at Mademoiselle maga:. zinc, was married yesterday to Robert MacLean Davis Jr., an accounting officer with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: BRIDGE
description: Wh??? a session is over ???? bridge expebts tend to be better at talking than listening. Like the Ancient Mariner at the feast they will buttonhole some unfortunate and tell a story of woe. They may concentrate on the fixes they suffered, explaining how the iniquitous opponents lucked out in a series of undesirable contracts or made hands by misplaying when the correct play would have failed. They may expatiate on their wretched teammates, who went down in a series of easy gamesneglecting to mention the games were only easy when looking at all four hands. Or they may belabor the stupidity of their partners who went astray repeatedly in the bidding: Their own contributions in creating the bidding problems are, of course, never mentioned. And if nothing else serves, the losing expert will castigate the computer, or the fate, that was responsible for a set of deals with builtin traps. The winning expert, be it noted, is not talkinghe has nothing to explain away.

title: Deliberately Random
description: THE fact that Yannis Ritsos is Greece's most popular poet, with a healthy worldwide following as well, should not call forth invidious comparisons. He is rarely superficial or sentimental, and his political and nationalistic poems escape narrow partisanship through their deeper commitment to the intricacies of human consciousness and his struggle to render them artistically. At 68, he is surety one of the world's most prolific poets, having published over 40 bookswrite, write or die, says the She of H.D.'s Hermetic Definition. Because Ritsos has written and lived through years of political exile and imprisonment, he has acquired the status in some quarters of a kind of culture hero. But this does not seem to have affected himwhich is quite consistent with the sense of priority

title: And Mr. Brezhnev Is Not Adjusting Too Well

He took the applause of the audience from his spot in the main box ostentatiously flanked by Yuri Andropov, the, head of the secret police, and Dmitri Ustinov, the Defense Minister.
