title: Does Raising the Floor Raise BuiltIn Unemployment?; New Elements in the Minimum Wage Debate
description: WASHINGTONThey are dishwashers and domestics, messengers, mailroom clerks, farm laborers, factory hands, fastfood cooks, security guards, stockroom workers, delivery boys and department store trainees. They are workers who earn the minimum wage$2.30 an hour, or $2.20, if they work in agricultureor half of what manufacturing workers average and 60 cents an hour below the poverty line drawn by the Federal Government. They are, almost by definition, at the margin of the nations economic life.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: MY FRIEND Wally, the educator, called the other day to talk about schools. He was excited, he said, because he had just figured out a way to desegregate the schools this fall in the New Jersey town where he is a very big educator, and he had figured out how to do it without buses. He figured it could be done with magnets.

title: The Language of the Lawns
description: IF IT weren't for the language of the lawns, we would know next to nothing of our neighbors. For though we know of them, it cannot be said that we know them. We don't speak to each other very much, and One of the proudest boasts of our affluent area is that we don't live in each other's pocketswe are neighbors in the nicest suburban sense, we live adjacent to each other.

title: Dixon Leads by 34 Points After 5 Decathlon Events
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., July 9 (AP)Fred Dixon took over first place from Bob Coffman and Fred Samara after the high jump today and held a 34point lead over John Warkentin halfway through the 59th National Amateur Athletic Union decathlon championships.

title: Help for Abusive Mothers
description: SEVEN mothers and two counselors meet weekly in Yonkers to discuss why the mothers beat their childrenand how they can learn to break the habit. The Abusive Mothers Group got its name for a reason. It is a harsh title, but I like worded that way, said Carolyn Mallory, a social worker who is active in the program at the Yonkers Mental Health Clinic. Our members must accept what their disciplinary pattern had been before they can adapt to new behavior.

title: Fashion
description: They were designed to be worn in the bedroom, for intimate moments  not for the world to see. But, this summer, when everything is so relaxed, seems right to wear boudoir underthings out in the open. In fact, it's another extension of the mood of fashion today the frankly sexy feel of silk against the skin the slip of satin against the body. So its correct to wear a silk crepedechine wrapper or a satin peignoir to a cocktail party or to someone's house for dinner. But give a second thought to appearing in a nightgown at a big restaurant or a formal occasion  it just might be too racy. Another caution: Shopping in the lingerie department doesn't necessarily imply finding areal fashion for little money. Though most of the lovely looks are reasonable. some can cost as much as shopping in designer salons

title: Hammond Museum's Personal Touch
description: It's tiny as museums go, but its fame is large. In fact, it's not an art museum at all, but a Museum of the Humanities. It is the Hammond Museum, set on a high hill in North Salem in the northeast corner of Westchester County, and is the personal creation of Natalie Hays Hammond, who has hovered over it with loving care since its opening in 1958.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: They come out of college with a degree, a kit of tools, and they're put at a desk beside the Harvard M.B.A. whose father knows the chairman at PepsiCola, and there's this feeling that, I'm not going to do itthere's too much working against me.

title: The Old Guard Changes
description: Wall Street's old guard has virtually disappeared during the troublesome 1970's, victims of change in the securities business and old age, but there are two prominent holdouts whose names have commanded instant respect in American finance for generations.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I read Chinese Study Their Heritage (June 5) with great delight. It reminds me of an episode involving my son when he was a thirdgrade student at Greenvale School in Eastchester a year ago. One day he confided in my husband and me that he had not only taught his best friend, Jimmy, how to write his name in Chinese, but also let Jimmy use the name as his secret name. . Later, on my son's birthday, Jimmy sent him a birthday card on which the sender's signature appeared in two big Chinese charactersmy son's name! I murmured to myself then, If every one of us could imaginatively change our names and try to be like the other person for a few minutes, perhaps all the fighting and conflict among people could be avoided.

title: Bernstein Leads Bach Magnificat At Tanglewood
description: LENOX, Mass., July 8It rained most: a1 today in Lenox, and although the deuge stopped before tonight's Prelude concert, the puddles and the threet of inclemencies held the crowd for theopening activities of this summer's Berkshire Music Festival to disappointing 7,835.

title: Editors Choice
description: AMEN, by Yehuda Amichai. Translated by the author and Ted Hughes. (Harper & Row, Cloth, $7.95. Paper, $4.95.) Poems by Israels bestknown living poet, on war, death, sensuality, love: a harshly lovely, exhilarating book.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WE ARE girding for a fourday stay on the Island's South Fork, and already the strain is showing. We are in the prepacking stage. My wife is the complete packer and although I have assured her that if we forget anything vital, we can always drive home and get it in a couple of hours, she is behaving as though we are off on a Governmentsponsored expedition to Prudhoe Bay.

description: Alice Paul a pioneer of the women's movement who helped lead the fight for women's suffrage and who, more than 50 years ago, helped draft the forerunner to today's proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution, died yesterday at the Quaker Greenleaf Extension Home in Moorestown, N.J. She was 92 years old.

title: CRIME
description: Mark Washburn's THE ARMAGEDDON GAME (Putnam's, $8.95) has a plot that by now is pretty old hata homemade atomic bomb in the hands of terrorists. It seems, these days, that every third book off the presses deals with this particular Armageddon (only a few weeks ago we had Ziggurat by Robert Katz, in which blackmailers threatened to set off a bomb at the polar cap). But this book is much better than most, for several reasons.

title: Alice Entertained the Wives
description: TO Ernest Hemingway, in A Moveable Feast, she was Gertrude Stein's companion, and Lytton Strachey remembered her only as a SpanishJewAmerican lady who interfered with his efforts to hear what George Moore was saying at a luncheon party. Alice B. Toklas, Gertrude Stein's lover for almost 40 years, was hardly a flamboyant figure at 27 rue de Fleurus where Miss Stein held court for so many years, surrounded by a magnificent array of Picassos, Braques and Matisses. Of course, it was no easy matter to impose oneself in the presence of such an imperious woman; the two best memoirs of the Stein salon, Allen Tate's Miss Toklas American Cake and James Lord's Where the Pictures Were (both published in the magazine Prose) evoke a stifling atmosphere of obeisance to that autocratic legend. Superlative collections of art almost always dominate the personalities of their possessors, Lord noted; but not at rue de Fleurus, where Gertrude Stein dominated her collection, her guests, and above her

title: Article 5  No Title
description: New Turns. The worthy portrayed by Vincent Van Gogh in the picture to the left is Pere Tanguy, in whose Paris shop the Dutchborn painter late in 1887 became acquainted with such Impressionists as Pissarro, Cezanne, Renoir, Seurat and Signac and their workan experience that gave his own art a new and more colorful turn. It is one of the 154 illustrations (45 in full color) reproduced in IMPRESSIONISM (Harry N. Abrams, $7.95), a crisp account of the movement from such forerunners as Turner and Delacroix through the NeoImpressionists, written by the French authority Pierre Courthion.

title: Mary B. Simon, Teacher, Bride Of D. D. Streep
description: Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in New Vernon, N.J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mary Beth Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Simon of New Vernon, to Dana David Streep, of Bethlehem, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Streep Jr. of Mason's Island, Mystic, Conn.

title: Mahwah: Are Propane Tanks a Threat?
description: THE fear of an explosion has spurred resistance by residents of Mahwah, in Bergen County, where the Ford Motor Company is moving to install three 90,000gallon tanks for the storage of propane gas within 700 feet of residential property. Ford believes that the fear is unrealistic and it has just received court permission to proceed with its plans, despite their rejection by the Mahwah Township Committee. The company expects to have tanks installed and tested within five months.

title: Frances Glennon Betrothed
description: Mrs. Stephen P. Glennon of Rye, N. Y.., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Frances C. Glennon of Washington, to Jeffrey F. Dunlop, alco of Washington, son of Mr. and firs. Harold R. Dunlop of Norwalk, Crmn. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Mr. Glennon. The wedding is planned for October.

title: A NEW VISIONARY IN GERMAN FILMS
description: Weaving man and nature into strange and poetic fables, director Werner Herzog presents a fresh and profound view of the human condition.

title: Harold Brown to Visit Seoul July 25
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (Reuters)Defense Secretary Harold Brown will go to South Korea on July 25 instead of July 19 for a twoday visit to present plans for the withdrawal of 32,000 troops over the next five years. Washington was understood to have requested the delay because Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel starts his visit on July 19 and President Carter wanted Mr. Brown to be on hand.

title: Lance Griswold Fiance Of Ann Elizabeth Zech
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Zech of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Elizabeth Zech, to Lance Charles Griswold, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. W. Griswold of Chester, N. J. The wedding is planned for Aug. 27.

title: Comedy Is My Way of Coping
description: When Gilda Radner opened Wednesday night in the Philip DunningGeorge Abbott 1926 melodrama Broadway at the Berkshire Theater Festival in Stockbridge, Mass., she was not wearing an outsized saltandpepper flip wig, solemnly discoursing on the state of the nation with a speech pattern reminiscent of some feminine Elmer Fudd. The gawky, pugfaced comedienne may have made a name for herself this year on NBC's lateevening comedy series Saturday Night impersonating a certain milliondollarayear ABC anchorwoman who pronounces her r's as w's, but Miss Radner doesn't want to be known as Babwa Wawa forever.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Record Soccer Crowd
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Outlook for Cities: All Is Not Dismal
description: WHILE MANY New Jersey cities continue to lose jobs, revenue and middleclass residents, some of them have shown growth in the last two decades, according to a study just released by the Regional Plan Association.

title: W. G. Bergh Fiance Of Linda B. Staniar
description: The engagement of Linda Burton Staniar to William Glasgow Bergh has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. Burton Staniar of Pennington, N.J. Mr. Bergh is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bergh of Essex, Conn., and Oyster Bay, L.I. The weddina is nlanned for next winter.

title: Around the Nation
description: KENT, Ohio, July 9 (AP)Deinonstrators rejected an ultimatum today that ordered them to pack up and leave the site of the 1970 Kent State University student shootings. Meanwhile, the university was preparing to get a court injunction to remove them.

title: NotOrious Ensemble at Ali's Alley
description: Zahir Batin's Notorious Ensemble is not really a group in the traditional sense. Mr. Batin, a drummer, assembles it periodically from the pool of available jazzmen in New York. But because the allaround quality of New York jazzmen is the highest in the world, and because Mr. Batin has a talent for putting gifted players together in compatible combinations, his Notorious Ensemble is usually well worth hearing.

title: Mint Award for Waterbury
description: SHINY new blank pennies, enough for two for every person in the United States, are symbolic of the rebirth of a Waterbury business that was almost dead at the beginning of 1976. Today it is the city's largest employer and taxpayer.

title: FUNERAL SCHEDULED TODAY FOR SLAIN YALE STUDENT
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 9Bonnie Jean Garland, the 20yearold Yale senior who was fatally bludgeoned early Thursday morning at her home here, allegedly by boyfriend from whom she was trying to break off, will be buried tomorrow after services at 4:30 P.M. at the Scarsdale Congregational Church.

title: The Nation
description: In Summary

title: Laura Naylor Bride Of Whitney R. Shaw
description: Laura Day Naylor, daughter of Mr. arid Mrs. John Lewis Naylor Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married yesterday in the Church of the Saviour (United Methodist) in Cleveland Heights, Ohio, to Whitney Ray Shaw. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Ray Shaw of Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Home Style
description: HomeSwap Clubs Flourishing

title: East Germany, U.S.S.R. Reach Final at Lucerne
description: LUCERNE. Switzerland. July 9Cyalifying heats for tomorrow's grand finals of the Lucerne international rowregatta got under way today at Potsee Lake.

title: Margo Ann Florea, Thomas Mohr Plan September Nuptals
description: The engagement of Margo Ann Florea to Thomas Martin Mohr has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Arthur Florea of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sigo Mohr Jr. of Hewlett, L.I.

title: Regalado, Pooley Tied In Golf at 200
description: COAL VALLEY, III., July 9 (AP)Don Pooley sank a 35foot birdie putt to pull into a tie with Victor Regalada at 200 after three rounds of the $125,000 Quad Cities open golf tournament today.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: You will doubtless recall the famous story of the conductor who became more and more concerned about the disappearance of his orchestra during rehearsals. Players would appear and then disappear. Substitutes became the rule rather than the exception. The final rehearsal came, and the conductor noticed that at least one somewhat elderly, wispy member of the second violins had not missed a rehearsal. He congratulated the man, only to have the hero admit shamefacedly that he wouldn't actually be there for the performance.

title: Deborah Plummer Bride
description: Deborah Ann Plummer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Plummer of Hollis, Queens., was married yesterday morning to Bradford Brown, son of Julie J. Brown of South Ozone Park, Queens, and the late James W. Brown. The Rev. Roderick R. Caesar performed the ceremony in the Bethel Gospel Tabernacle in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Suffrage Leader Dies
description: Alice Paul, a leader in the women's suffrage movement who was called the author of the equal rights amendment, is dead at 92 in New Jersey. Page 42.

title: Authority Seeks to Buy 2 Race Tracks in Jersey
description: TRENTON, July 9Legislation supported by Governor Byrne is expected to be introduced next week to permit the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to buy and rebuild Garden State Park and to buy Atlantic City Race Course. The purchases would be made through bond issues.

title: Saturation Point For Indoor Tennis?
description: THE indoor tennis center that a sportscenter owner opened in Buchanan in northern Westchester in 1972, expecting it to be making money within two years, is now a warehouse. The parking lot where the New Rochelle Development Council thought of building indoor courts is still a parking lot.

title: Calm Breaks Out in Belize
description: HOLDFAST, Belize, July 9The issue from the beginning in tnis week's bit of trouble between Belize and Guatemala was whether the tension would develop into a shooting war in which someone actually got hurt or instead would bog down into something slightly preposterous. Unlike some memorable Central American standoffs, this episode had somehow dragged in actual British combat troops, gunboats and verticaltakeoff jump jets.

title: LETTERS
description: A natural followup to Why Have More Than One? (by Anne Roiphe, June 5) would be Why Have One?, slanted to the increasing numbers of us who are uncomfortable in an overstuffed world and envision a stable, unpolluted, nonviolent and uncrowded environment with longing. As a novelty, let's applaud noparenthood.

title: A Bitter End for a Fire Island Enclave
description: They paved Paradise and put up a parking lot

title: INTERVIEW
description: IT WOULD not be difficult to ignore the fact that Wallace M. Alston Jr. is considered by many whu know him to be one of the country's great preachers. At a church social, if he gets a chance, he is likely to whip out his guitar and sing country songs. At parties, he can talk about almost anything, including politics, sometimes blind spot with most members of the clergy.

title: A String Quartet: TheAristocrats of Amateur. Musicians
description: Often when Dr. Pauline Hecht, a surgeon, has finished her day, she wants to do something relaxing, yet challengjng, and so she calls up her dentist, Dr. Henry Radon; he rounds up a couple of others and they all settle down to an evening of playing string quartets.

title: JEWISH ANTICRIME PATROL BRINGS PROTEST BY BLACKS
description: About 500 black residents of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn demonstrated peacefully in front of the 71st Precinct station house on Empire Boulevard yesterday to protest alleged brutality by an Orthodox Jewish civilian anticnme patrol in the area.

title: Carter Rejects a Sporting Offer
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)President Carter, disclosing a tongueincheek superstitious streak and a little political vengeance, has declined to play softball against Representative Morris K. Udall because, he said, the odds are against him.

title: Mother Dies in Pennsylvania Fire
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Pa., July 9 (AP)Sandra Rumpf, 36 years old, died of smoke inhalation today while trying to rescue her children from their burning home near this Lebanon County community, the police said. The children escaped injury. The cause of the fire was unknown.

title: Newark One Decade Later
description: THIS is no ordinary summer in Newark. True, the noonday heat rises from the blacktop with its usual ferocity, and porches and parks throng with refugees from steamagartments. But old nightmares revive as the press and television prepare to cover the city on the 10th anniversary of the July 1967 riots.

title: Deaths
description: ALPERNAnna beloved mother of Bernard and Jack, cherished grandmother of Lloyd, Laura and Edward, loving greatgrandmother of Marilyn, MarK and Brad. Services Sunday, July 10, 12:30 P.M. at The. Riverside', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Is there a crisis in the performing arts? The question is obviously rhetorical, and the various foundation officers, artistic directors, managing directors, board members, advocacy chairmen and agency officials whom I interviewed recently over a period of weeks confirmed an impression that the problem is fast approaching the critical point.

title: Susan Westerfield Wed to James Johnson
description: Susan B. Westerfield, a freelance writer, was married yesterday to James Doyle Johnson, vice president and management service director of the Marchalk Company, an advertising agency.

title: Tito Plans to Visit Soviet in August, Then Go to North Korea and China
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 9 (Reuters)President Tito of Yugoslavia will pay an official visit to the Soviet Union in the second half of next month, it was officially announced here today. No details were given.

title: Secession Efforts Renewed
description: RESIDENTS of Mount Kisco, who voted two years ago to secede from the surrounding Towns of Bedford and New Castle, will soon consider whether to remain a village or reorganize their area as a town or what is called a coterminus townvillage.

title: Judo Foulup Nearly Puts U.S. on Shelf for Games
description: The three female judo players who are representing the United States this week at the Maccabiah Games in Israel were each issued two patches, denoting their nationality, to be worn on their uniforms. But the players and their coach had not been issued uniforms. Nor plane tickets. Nor international travel permits. Nor food and expense money. In fact, the four women had not been given anything but a runaround from the United States Committee Sports for Israel, the organization that, among other things, helps gather funds to support Jewish athletes competing in the games.

title: U.S. Water Is Still the Best, But That's Not Good Enough
description: Every year or two, many people suffer a bout of wnat is colloquially called intestinal flu'', a malaise involving combinations of headaches, fever, nausea and diarrhea. The customary explanation is: I picked up a bug somewhere.

title: HOKE NORRIS, WRITER AND JOURNALIST, DIES
description: CHICAGO, July 9 (AP)Hoke Norris, author and journalist, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital here. He was 63 years old.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Abright yellow house in the middle of Bedford Hills has sprouted plants on the sunporch, silver jewelry in the living room and decoupage ostrich eggs on an upstairs landing.

title: FILM VIEW
description: VINCENT CANBY

title: New England or New Jersey?
description: I'LL be leaving Connecticut soon, after 25 years of newspapering in the state. During this time I have watched the state undergo vast change, and not always for the better.

title: IN AMERICA
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y. Shmuel Katz was on his 11th visit to America but his first to that state of mind, rather than nature, known as the Mountains. As the car from the Israeli Consulate passed the billboards on Route 17, his eye fell on one that wasn't pressing an invitation to gluttony. Keep Israel Strong, it urged. Enemy territory the Mountains weren't.

title: Backing Senate Plan, New York Awaits Vote on U.S. Housing Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Already virtually assured of nearly $1 billion in Federal aid for housing and community development during the next three years, New York State will be watching closely in the next few days to see if the House of Representatives accepts a Senate plan to add an additional $150 million.

title: Author's Query
description: I am at work on a biography of Richard P. Blackmur (190465), American poet, and should be grateful for any recollections, copies of letters and biographical information.

title: Psychiatric Program At Kings Unit Faces Loss of Accreditation
description: Psychiatric Program At Kings Unit Faces Loss of Accreditation

title: Pro Golfers, Says One, Are Spoiled
description: The average touring golf pro today is living off the fat of the land and thinks the world owes him $200,000 a year. Most pros couldn't do anything else for a living, but they always have their hands out looking for a freebie, Instead of saying Thank you, they want to know what time the next plane is leaving.

title: Joan de Garmo Wed To Randal Walker
description: Joan de Garmo, a senior assitant buyer with the gift department of Lord & Taylor, and Randal Keith Walker, who is with the treasurer's department of the Felmont Oil Corporation, were married yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., by the Rev. Frederick T. Bender.

title: Design
description: A terrace garden can be costly to install, and requires daily care  but, oh, the rewards. People who make the commitment soon lose the urge to leave town on weekends. But few city terraces start out perfect. Most present real challenges  how to enhance slivers of views; what plants will thrive. Here, two problem terraces that were dramatically transformed into sky gardens.

title: Law Students Spending Summer As Aides in U.S. Attorney's Office
description: I'm a complete goofoff in law school. I'm not learning any law there. Here, I'm learning law every day. The main element missing in law school is motivation. Here, there is competition aganst an opposing counsel.

title: Being an Incumbent Has Its Drawbacks
description: LIKE many public officials before him, Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, has found that while incumbency has its advantages, it also makes him target for political brickbats.

title: Getting Edgy
description: Communist polemics are not known for their Subtlety. Last week, after condemning Eurocommunism as an anti  Soviet bourgeois heresy, the Kremlin abruptly denied that it ever intended to excommunicate any other Communist party. Blaming the dispute on deliberate misinterpretation by the nonCommunist press, the Government declared: The Soviet Communist Party has not organized any campaigns against any fraternal party. The new line, by no means representing ideological accommodation, was nevertheless a tactical retreat. The basis for it apparently lay in the response of other Communist parties.

title: Exploring Slavic Music in Aspen
description: Given the proposition that any serious musical organization owes some debt to the present, it would seem that the Aspen Music Festival is healthily in the black. The picturesque Colorado town's festival runs this year from June 24 to Aug. 21, and its programs overall, both in terms of performance and of performertraining, are of an extent rivaled only in this country by Tanglewood. And within the Aspen activities, the 19th annual Conference on Contemporary Music, founded by Darius Milhaud and directed now (for eight years running) by Richard Dufallo, holds a special place.

title: HorseAuction Night In Upstate New York
description: Unadilla by daylight is a common, quiet little place. The main street of this mildmannered town off Route in upstate New York is lined with large drafty houses that reek of lost affluence, big families and wellmannered turnofthecentury life. The facades are wellpainted, the lawns kempt; but inside, the heat's been turned off in half the rooms. Most travelers to the Binghamton/Oneonta area pass Unadilla by: I suppose they spend their Fridays antiquing, or visiting the Howe Caverns and Baseball HIM of Fame in Cooperstown or, as I've been tempted, touring the derelict and refurbished train depots (in Bainbridge, a police department; outside of Greene, a saddlery).

title: Randle's Homer in 17th Ends 11/lets Losing Streak
description: A sigh of relief rose mightily from Shea Stadium last night. At 8:25 P.M. the Mets ended their losing streak at nine games by defeating the Montreal Expos, 75.

title: Judith Karlen, E. B. Gardner 3d Wed in Vermont
description: Judith Anne Karlen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Karlen of Poultney, Vt., formerly of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday in St. Denis Chiirch in Pittsfield, Vt., to E. Benjamin Gardner 3d. He is the son of Mr; and Mrs. Gardner Jr. of Darien, Conn. The Rev. C. Dean Knapp of Nogales, Ariz., a cousin of the bride, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Associated Press and United Press International

title: When Is a Right a Right?
description: On June 27, the House of Representatives approved without debate an amendment that would prevent Federal funds from being used to provide legal assistance in any proceeding or litigation arising out of disputes or controversies on the issue of homosexuality or socalled gay rights.

title: Not to the Zapateado Born
description: IN 1951 an Italian exbaker's assistant, theaterticket runner, art student and dishwasher burst onto the American theater scene, his name in lights on the marquee of New York's Shubert Theater. Crosscountry tours followed, as well as appearances in films and on all the big television variety shows

title: LEAVE WELL ENOUGH ALONE
description: Not since Dorothy was whisked off to Oz have I encountered a Dorothy as impressionable and thoroughly sympathetic as the heroine of Rosemary Wells's Leave Well Enough Alone. In this novel,

title: ANDREW AND THE ALCHEMIST
description: By Barbara Ninde Byfield. Illustrated by Deanne Hollinger. 103 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $5.95. (Ages 9 to 13)

title: A Barometer of Contemporary Trends
description: THE ALDRICH MUSEUM of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield has been performing an eminently valuable and rewarding service in the last six years. It has annually assembled an exhibition of the work of young artists who have not yet been represented in a major metropolitan gallery, and the exhibitionwhich is the result of lengthy examinations of slides, visits to artists studios, considerable looking and ambitious exercises of judgmenthas usually been of outstandingly high'quality.

title: DINING OUT
description: IT was a turning point in their lives, thought the young owners, when they decided a year ago open a restaurant. They hoped, too, that it would be a turning point for Piermont, a Hudson River village that time had passed by. For a visitor, the name of their restaurant might symbolize even more, the starting point for a new wave of restaurants.

title: John Langeloth Loeb
description: John Langeloth Loeb, born in St. Louis 74 years ago last November, is the son of a Germanborn father, Carl M. Loeb, and an Americanborn mother, the former Adeline Moses of Montgomery, Ala., the daughter of a Southern banker, whose American lineage has been traced to preRevolutionary times.

title: Jet's Hijackers Are Off to Southern Yemen After Releasing 28 in Kuwait
description: KUWAIT, Sunday, July 10 (Reuters)Nine Arabs who hijacked a Kuwait Airways airliner on a flight here Friday flew off to South Yemen early today, five hours after exchanging the passengers) and crew they had been holding captive for two new hostages.

title: INVESTING
description: The common stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company sold last week within a point of its 1977 low of 61. On Friday, the shares closed at 62

title: U.S. Businessmen's Special Problems
description: DUBAI, United Arab EmiratesThe office of J. Ray McDermott & Company here will soon have 20 fewer American employees. The company, a major supplier of oilfield equipment, has decided to send the Americans home and replace them with Europeans. Because of a recent change in the tax law, the Americans have become too expensive for McDermott to keep on the payroll.

title: Silverman, Ring Promoter, Killed
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 9 (AP)Sam Silverman, a boxing promoter for almost 40 years who gave Rocky Marciano most of his early bouts, died today after his car ran off the road on Route 2 here, the police said. He was 64 years old.

title: Discovering The West, Recalling Russia
description: Discovering The West, Recalling Russia

title: Beanie Shuffle Gets New Twist In 7778 Budget
description: In the beginning, there was the Beanie Shuffle, a device that once saved the transit fare. This year there was the CUNY Shuffle, a classic as shuffles go. The CUNY Shuffle blossomed in the spring as one of Mayor Beanie's clever budgetbalancing deCity vices  some would say Ha gimmick  and it provokes a goodsized fight during Notes the debate over the $13.9 billion budget for the new fiscal year. Somehow this brouhaha over the CUNY shuffle got smothered in the clamor to pass the budget at the beginning of last month. But the way the issue was quietly resolved showed a great deal about how the process of compromise has adjusted to new fiscal realities.

title: Paris Opens a Drive For Cleaner Streets
description: PARIS, July 9 (Reuters) Mayor Jacques Chirac has decided that the capital is so filthy that it must be tidied up. In particular he has asked Parisians to nominate cleanliving dogs for medals.

title: Sponsors Breach Prison Walls
description: NIANTIC

title: Edison College Gains Accreditation
description: THERE IS no campus, no classrooms, nor any professors. And there are not any students around, either. But that did not stop Thomas A. Edison College from becoming the first institution of higher education without a formal instruction program to be awarded full academic accreditation by the Commission on Higher Education of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools. The commission is the formal accreditation body for educational institutions in five eastern Atlantic states and the District of Columbia.

title: George Henry Linck, A Lawyer, Marries. Penelope J. Wisner
description: Penelope Jane Wisner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Horner Wisner of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to George Henry Linck. The Rev. Dr. C. Michael Thornburg of the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Weston, performed the ceremony in the garden at the Wisner home.

title: Every Pitch Counts For ExFree Agent
description: It was last November, and Wayne Garland was in Tennessee, visiting his parents, when his agent, Jerry Kapstein, telephoned.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: A Treasure Revived, Along With a Dud

title: Bergen Acts to Put Jobless to Work
description: APPLICATIONS for the financing of 103 community projects have been received by the Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders as part of the board's efforts to provide jobs for the longterm unemployed and limitedincome individuals.

title: Eileen Mary FitzGerald Married to Peter Sudler
description: Eileen Mary FitzGerald and Peter David Sudler, both Assistant United States Attorneys for the Southern District of New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents. Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sudler of South Orange, N.J.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: In Summary

title: United Press International
description: UP THE WALL: Jim Rice of the Red Sox watching as teammate, Fred Lynn, climbed the wall for ball hit by Brewers Robin Yount at Milwaukee yesterday. Lynn couldn't get it and hit went for a double. Brewers won, 32.

title: Carol Hoffberger Plans To Be Married in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herold C. Hoffberger of Riderwood, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Hoffberger, to Alan McCarthy of Athens, Ga., son of Milton Sensendiver of Daytona Beach, Fla., and the late Leah Hale McCarthy. The future bridegroom's surname was changed.

title: If You Go
description: to Unadilla from New York City, take Route 81 north to Binghampton, and then Route 7 east to Unadilla. Turn left at the third of Unadilla's four stoplights: D. R. Chambers and Sons, Incorporated, is at 38 Maple Avenue. Wear old clothes; the stands are dusty. And never wear opentoed sandals. The men chew tobacco and, in a tight crowd, can't always tell the difference between your untanned toes and a clear area of sawdust.

title: The Tennis Clinic
description: Remember not long ago when playing mixed doubles generally used to be a mild form of torture for everyone on court?

title: The Downtown Cabaret's Restless Spirit
description: ON OPENING night of The Sixties, which is at the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport through July 24, Claude McNeal, who conceived and difected the show, got part of the cast together. He warned them of a dangerous exit they would have to make in the dark against incoming cast members for the next number. To show how the exit should be taken, he turned, missed the steps, fell off the stage, and broke his arm.

title: Of Special Interest
description: The South Street Seaport Museum has moved to newly remodeled quarters in a landmark 1868 warehouse building on Water Street, its inaugural display consisting of objects from its own collection and other institutions which describe New York's commercial history as it relates to the South Street neighborhood. Yet the people connected with the museum don't think of themselves as a museum but as a total environment revivifying the city's commercial history, since, in fact, the art gallery is merely one of seven buildings operated by the South Street enterprise: a book and chart store, a model shop, a printers and stationers, and the like. Lately, they are calling themselves New York's only 29hour exhibit, too, with a new outdoor exhibit of posters and placards (silk screens, actually, designed by the museum) mounted on various buildings within a sixblock radius, with illustrations and quotations describing 19thcentury New York port life. A free brochure with a map pinpointing where everything can be found is available at the book store (25 Fulton Street), at the visitors center (16 Fulton Street) and at the information booth on Pier 16. (See Art)

title: A Short, Unhappy Motor Trip
description: Since Bloomsbury long ago nosed out the Lost Generation in the Literary Nostalgia Sweepstakes, this seems strangely inopportune time to produce a novel in which the major characters are Scott Fitzgerald and Ernest Hemingway. But then, One Last Glimpse is a very strange novel indeed.

title: Klansmen Burn Cross at Rally Amid Protests in Hamilton. N.Y.
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., July 9 (UPI)About a dozen protectors chanted antiKu Klux Klan slogans but Were ignored by Klansmen tonightas a flaming cross lighted a barnyard near this Madison County village.

title: Regina Nimphius Married
description: Regina Marie Nimphius, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertrand J. Nimphius of White Plains, was married there yesterday in St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church to Michael G. Grant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Grant of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. William Rogers performed the ceremony. The bride graduated from Wheelock College. Mr. Grant is a junior at the University of Rhode Island.

title: By Jove! If It Isn't the Wacky World of Wodehouse
description: This evening at 10, Channel 13 will present the first halfhour installment of Wodehouse Playhouse, a 13part series of adaptations of P.G. Wodehouse's Mulliner, Golf, and Drones Club collections of short stories. The following essay by the British novelist William Trevor details his reactions to the series, which was originally telecast on the BBC.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE woman next to me was saying to her friend, as she tore up a losing ticket, Why did they have to build a race track in my backyard? As I ripped up my own loser, I had to agree with the sentiment. Why couldn't they have left the Meadowlands alone?

title: Births
description: Adlman

title: NyeWest, Van IngenSmith Gain Anderson Final
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 9Gerald P. Nye Jr., the 34yearold son of the late United States Senator from North Dakota, became a golfing hero today. His recovery, shortly after it appeared he could not do anything right, came during the semifinals cf the 41st annual John G. Anderson fourball invitation at the Winged Foot Golf Club's famed west course.

title: 3 Armed Men Flee With $200,000 In Loot From Northport Jeweler
description: Three armed men wearing ski masks invaded a store specializing in precious stones and jewelry on Route 25A in Northport, L.I., and escaped with loot valued at $200,000, the police reported Friday.

description: WASHINGTON, July 9The Carter Administration, alarmed by widespread Soviet eavesdropping on telephone conversations across the United States, completing a topsecret plan designed to protect both Government and private calls from intrusion by foreign powers, by corporations or by criminal groups.

description: Frederick F. Robinson, chairman emeritus of the National Aviation and Technology Corporation, died Friday at his home at 110 East End Avenue. He was 73 years old.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: AT FIRST glance, impaction seems to be just another one of those $2 words that Congressmen and Federal officials throw around in talking about the way some complex Federal aid formula works.

title: TV VIEW
description: In the perverse world of TV strategems, it probably makes some kind of lunatic sense that the success of 60 Minutes could be disastrous for other areas of electronic journalism, especially the longform documentary. 60 Minutes, nestled in the primetime slot of Sundays at 7 P.M., is a hit, often climbing into the charmed rating circle of the week's Top 10 programs. Of course, it took more than five years for the CBS news series to reach its present eminence, but that doesn't seem to matter to most envious onlookers. They see a magazine format that has made it, in terms of solid profitability, and their immediate, indeed inevitable response is to call for more of the same. The magazine concept is currently an object of slackjawed veneration at all three networks. News department chiefs, it seems, are no less immune to cookiecutter mentalitieS than their regimented counterparts in entertainment.

title: A Museum's Treasure Hunt

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: AS the Carter Administration continues its discussions with numerous interested parties on the elements that ought to be included in its forthcoming taxreform package, the debate seems to be sharpening in business and economic circles on the size of the gar, that exists between the American economy's potential productive ability and its actual performance now and in the next few years. It couldand shouldhave an important bearing on policymaking in Washington.

description: WASHINGTON, July 9More than 40 of the nation's governors, concluding two days of discussions on energy matters here, were told by President Carter today that he might change his energy plan as a result of the discussions.

description: UNTIL this year, the Milbank family's philanthropies, described by T. A. Wise in The Insiders as the least publicized of the mature great fortunes of America, had concentrated on educational, social and medical institutions. This year, an unusual grant went to the arts. The product of that gift is the Green Gate Theater, the repertory company in residence at Sarah Lawrence College providing a showcase for new playwrights and classics, for student actois and Equity performers.

description: THE SCENE is an elementary school on a Monday morning. The usual activities are going on, except that down the corridor, outside the lavatories, sits an easel. The scene is completed by a paint box, canvas partly completed, and a painter at work.

title: Dobes and Huskies Dominate a Circuit
description: Doberman pinschers and Siberian huskies dominate an overall entry of 6,799 dogs on the fiveday New England Scenic Circuit, starting Thursday with the Holyoke Kennel Club's allbreed show at Three County Fair Grounds, Northampton, News of Dogs Mass. The opener has 90 Dobes and 84 Siberians in an entry of 1,522. The Woodstock Dog Club is host for the second event on Friday, featuring 1,481 canines, at Woodstock Union Junior High School in West Woodstock, Vt. Siberians lead with 109, Dobermans number 97 and the National Border carrier specialty lists 50.

description: THE vegetable gardens look great. The combination of a cool, moist growing summerso farhas given food crops an extra boost. The leafy vegetables especially are doing quite well. Spinach, lettuce, chard, all the herbs are thriving. The cabbage family is going strong and the peas, which were abundant, are just coming to an end.

There are estimates that welfare costs in the state could be increased by as much as $30 million a year, and that the indirect cost could be much more.

This means being able to instantaneously translate the elements and values of a scene into the desired photograph.

title: 2 Pilots Crash in Fog Off Jersey Beaches
description: ATLANTIC art, N.J., July 9 (UPI)ed Two small airplanes flying in fog two hours apart crashed into the Atlantic Ocean here and 10 miles away off Ocean City yesterday. The pilot of one plane was killed and the other critically injured.

description: TO JERUSALEM AND BACK, by Saul Bellow. (Avon, $1.95.) Through sketches and vignettes, based on an extended trip to Israel late in 1975, America's newest Nobel Prize winner evokes the look and feel of the young republic and considers in passing its significance to Jews of various backgrounds, to Palestinian Arabs, to the intellectual world. A best seller in hardcover last year.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: In a way, the most interesting group of color photographs in the current exhibition Some Color Photographs. . . at Castelli Graphics (4 East 77th Street, through July 14) is the almost random sampling of typically awful commerical photographs laid out in two vitrines.

title: Food; Voorish Delight
description: One of the great main courses of this world is a buttery, fragilecrusted pigeon pie that comes from Morocco. It is a curious dish but infinitely gratifying. Curious because it contains, in addition to the shredded cooked meat of pigeons (Cornish game hens make an admirable substitute), ground almonds, confectioners sugar and cinnamon. It is called basteeya or pastilla. We first sampled it and became enamored of it about 30 years ago in Morocco and, in the ensuing period, on a brief visit to Casablanca. Our most recent tasting was at the much admired Moroccan restaurant, the Dar Maghreb Restaurant in Beverly Hills. The dish would seem, on reading the recipe, to he complicated in its preparation. Actually it isn't and is well worth the effort. It is admirably complemented by two Moroccan salads, recipes for which we obtained from a friend, Mrs. Ralph Elmatch, a native of Agadir, who now lives in Cedarhurst, L.I. One is an orange salad; the other, tomato salad. Both are spectacularly good and spicy.

title: Sacrificing Song for Speech
description: WITH his penchant for tucking a credo into a wisecrack, Ezra Pound once insisted that poetry should he at least as well written as prose. Throughout the history of English poetry, revolutions have been made by poets who envied the suppleness, fluency and vigor of good prose. Chaucer, Dryden, Wordsworth, Eliot and iouna were all reacting in one way or another the florid, gorgeous poeticism of a previous generation. Wordsworth even invoked Chaucer, hardly his contemporary, as Eliot would later pay homage Dryden, in making his case for language really used by men, plainer and more emphatic language, and against what he called poetic diction. Yet another modern example has just arrived in translation, Cesare Pavese's great book of poems, Hard Labor, which offered delicate modulations of setting and narrative in place of the facile and sloppy lyricism of D'Annunzio and his school.

description: Alpine Slides are operating at the following locations this summer.

description: Mary Lynn Almquist and William Rembrandt Dimeling, both of Philadelphia, were married yesterday in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Paoli, Pa. The Rev. Frederick A. Breuninger, the rector, and the Rev. Michael L. Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ecumenical ceremony.

title: Cosmos' New Coach Asserts No Interference
description: After Eddie Firmani's Rowdies had beaten the Cosmos in Tampa May 29 in a nationally televised game, spoiling Franz Beckenbauer's debut in the United States, Firmani was asked if he would coach a team of individual stars like the Cosmos. Oh, I News don't know about that, they have a lot of good of players, don't they? was Soccer Firmani's reply in the locker room.

He accepted condefences from a passerby and whispered almost to himselfa tragedy.

description: WASHINGTONAny bank with a national charter must join the Federal Reserve System. But, to drop out, all the bank hasto do is order its lawyers to draft a new state charter. A state usually welcomes the switcher with open arms.

title: A Colloquy of Contrasts
description: JERUSALEMPresident Carter and Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel should get along well personally when they meet in Washington next week, and that in itself would be considered an achievement by Mr. Begin, who rates a good personal rapport first among the priorities of his initial official United States trip as chief of government.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: When I let loose, [it] made a lovely free circle in the air, came spinning back, made a second small circle, and landed close by. Benjamin Ruhe's first boomerang throw was a softly whirring, exhilarating success.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: According to Semester in the Sun (Letter From Stony Brook, Opinion Page, June 26], Stony Brook is a veritable stage for spontaneity and amusement. The implication of such remark is that residents of the State University of New York at Stony Brook have reasonably comfortable, inexpensive and pleasant surroundings complete with continual entertainment and plentiful numbers of diversions, both cheap and easily accessible. The facts appear to diverge slightly from this account.

description: We were on our way south trom tne mountaintop monasteries of Meteora, of an October Sunday afternoon, and getting hungry. Ann spotted a sign along the highway: Metsovon. And turned our rented car down the steep gravel road.

description: Most people can save on fuel during the heating season by setting thermostats a bit lower, and, if necessary, by dressing warmer. Now that warm weather has arrived, the consumption of energy by home airconditioners can be cut by an even greater amount by setting thermostats on home airconditioners slightly higher.

title: Casting Off a Remnant of Racism

It decided that the death penalty for the rape of an adult constitutes cruel and unusual punishment, in violation of the Eighth Amendment.

description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, earned $25,000 above his senatorial salary last year by giving speeches before collegesZbusiness groups and union and lobbying organizations. The sum is the maximum allowable under Senate rules.

description: Concern about the durability of the business recovery hung like a cloud over the stock market last week and pushed prices modestly lower.

description: After an interim of almost four years, the issue of public housing appears to be coming back to life in Westchester County.

description: Public approval of President Carter's performance in office has been markedly uniform ever since the first surge of popularity subsided after his inauguration, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: What's Troubling Mr. Brezhnev
description: Have United StatesSoviet relations gone sour? President Brezhnev of the Soviet Union thinks so, as his publicized lecture to the American Ambassador, Malcolm Toon, made clear last week. Mr. Brezhnev's news agency said he noted a number of aspects in . . . United States policy which do not accord with the aim of a constructive development of relations, which should be based on the principles of equality, mutual benefit and noninterference into each other's internal affairs.

title: INTERVIEW
description: IF Dr. Sung Yen Feng seems to be neglecting his investigations into The Response of Oysters to the Introduction of Soluble and Particulate Materials and the Factors Modifying the Response, it's not because the 48yearold marine biologist has lost interest in the research he began as a young doctoral candidate.

title: Most of Us Are Kept on a Short Leash
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.The economic fate of most of us is not within our control but is, rather, intertwined with that of countless others. This means that at least seven out of ten families are economically vulnerable, with at least an even chance of spend ing some years of their lives in financial distress. It is not merely some vague minority called the poor who stand in economic peril; it is the majority of Americans.

description: Lyons, that mystical village with three riversthe Rhene. the Saone and the Beaujolais.

title: 11 Are Dead and 40 Hurt In Polish Rail Crash
description: WARSAW, July 9 (Reuters)Eleven people were killed and about 40 injured when the PragueWarsawMoscow train crashed into a diesel locomotive today on the outskirts of Wroclaw in southwestern Poland, the Polish press agency reported.

title: Return to Sender
description: To Postmaster General Benjamin Bailar, facing pay raises that will throw his Postal Service budget into deficit, it must have seemed like a political windfall: revenue proposal from the President himself and one that would preserve the 13cent stamp for the ordinary citizen. Mr. Bailar moved swiftly to capitalize on the President's interest. In a new package of revenue measures, he would now charge 16 cents for a oneounce business letter while holding the cost of personal mail to 13 cents. It's the kind of illusion likely to appeal those who retain faith in the tooth fairy but not to those uncomfortable with demagogy. It comes up Monday before the Postal Board of Governors and we hope they revise it.

title: Letters_
description: In Tibet

title: Joseph Philipp Fiance Of Mary E. Hayford
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren J. Hayford of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Hayford, to Joseph Harding Philipp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Philipp of Bristol, Conn. The wedding is planned for Aug. 13.

title: New Phone Rate Rewards Brevity
description: The New York State Public Service Commission has decided to give laconic customers of New York Telephone the opportunity to pay less for their basic telephone service than their more talkative neighbors.

title: Why Does a Healthy Economy Feel So Bad?
description: At a recent luncheon meeting prominent forecaster brought with him an impressive array of charts, all indicating that the American economy is brimming with health and vigor. But instead of confidently predicting clear sailing ahead, he announced, almost apologetically, that he could see nothing negative for at least another year, perhaps longer.

title: Portugal's Socialists Are Curbing Communist Collectives in South
description: ESTREMOZ, PortugalJulio Bastos, a lanky 56yearold scion of Portugal's demoralized aristocracy, swam in his pool recently for the first time since the fury of the April 1974 revolution was unleashed on the great estates of the southern Alentejo.

title: A Woman for S.E.C. Vacancy
description: The Carter Administration's continuing search for highlevel women officials succeeded again last week with the news that the White House has decided to nominate a Park Avenue lawyer to serve on the Securities and Exchange Commission. Roberta S. Karmel (right), 40, a securities attorney and partner in the New York firm of Rogers & Wells, is the Administration's choice to become the first woman to serve on the commission, although the decision is not expected to be announced for several weeks.

title: What's New and Different in Opera Recordings?
description: While waiting for another season to begin, opera buffs have plenty of new recordings to keep them occupied over the summer months, many of them featuring works rarely ever encountered in the repertories of our major houses. Here, for instance, is the first complete recording of an opera by Jean Baptiste Lully, a 17thcentury French master more honored in history books than on the stage. We can also at last assess the merits of Gilbert and Sullivan's final collaborative effort, The Grand Duke, never before recorded. And how many people knew that Rachmaninoff wrote an opera on the Fransesca da Rimini legendwith singing parts for both Dante and Vergil? There is obviously a lot of fresh operatic territory ripe for phonographic exploration, and the companies seem more than to take the plunge. Here is a run down, alphabetically by composer.

title: A Message for the Class of 77
description: IF YOU have built castles in the air, your work need not be lost; that is where they should be. Now put the foundation under them. Henry David Thoreau wrote these words in 1854, but they are just as relevant today, especially at this, our high school graduation.

title: Three Novels
description: IT was inevitable after all the bogus historical novels of the Bicentennial that someone would show the Revolution from the other sidenot just the British side, but that of the fence straddlers who regarded the events with an eye to main chance. Hieronymous Poxe, for instance, editor or the New Boston Times, recognizing there's nothing like a war of national liberation to boost circulation, sent out his reporters not so much to cover the rebellion as to guarantee t would erupt.

title: Pope Paul and Waldheim Discuss Middle East
description: ROME, July 9Pope Paul VI, discussing the Middle East situation during a onehour talk today with Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations, expressed interest in the coming visit to the United States by Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel.

title: English Cricketers Lead Australians by 139 Runs
description: MANCHESTER, England, July 9 (Reuters)England ground its way to a commanding position against Australia on the third day of the second cricket test today, reaching 436 runs for nine wickets at the closea firstinnings lead of 139.

title: 41 Safe in Tokyo Plane Engine Fire
description: TOKYO, July 9 (Reuters)An engine on an Air India Boeing 707 burst into flames as the fourengine plane was preparing to take off on a flight to Bombay from Tokyo's Haneda International Airport today. The plane, with 28 passengers and a crew of 13, managed to stop on the runway and the fire was promptly extinguished. No casualties were reported.

title: John Sebastian Fits Tunes to Occasions
description: Rain began to fall halfway through John Sebastian's second set at the Dr. Pepper music festival in Central Park Friday evening, and Mr. Sebastian had the perfect song for the occasion, Rain on the Roof. He was under roof, although the crowd was not: Still, it was a quick summer shower, and nobody seemed to mind.

title: Ickx, Mass Win as Porsche Dominates at Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 9 Porsche, undefeated and still champion, captured the first 12 places in the Six Hours of Endurance sportscar race here today and is ready for new worlds to conquerand one newworld capital is probably going to be Indianapolis.

title: INTERIM PITTSBURGH MAYOR WILL SEEK ELECTION TO JOB
description: PITTSBURGH, July 9Interim Mayor Richard S. Caligiuri has announced that he will seek a full fouryear term in the November general election, presaging an intraDemocratic Party battle.

title: Potpourri Preserves the Scents of Summer's Flowers
description: Potpourri is one of the most delightful ways to preserve the fragrance of a garden. Pronounced pohpoohree and meaning rotten pot in French, it is a mixture of dried flower petals, herbs, spices, essential oils and natural fixatives to provide a pleasant aroma.

title: Time to Listen to the Listeners
description: ALTHOUGH the University of Bridgeport has decided not to yield control of WPKNFM, its widely popular alternative radio station, to a National Public Ratio affiliate, the controversy over who will operate the station, and with what sort of programming, has not been resolved.

title: Planned Parenthood Begins Abortion Aid Drive
description: The Planned Parenthood Federation of America, alarmed by recent Supreme Court and Congressional actions limiting the availability of abortions, announced yesterday a $3 million fundraising drive to campaign against further restrictions and to supply money for abortions in especially needy cases.

title: He Writes Carter's Jokes
description: JEROME Doolittle, a speech writer for President Carter, commutes on weekends to West Cornwall, in the rural northwest corner of the state, to his wife and five sons, to his 1948 fire engine and to his old 21room inn, where a family of Vietnamesehe is not sure exactly how manylives on the bottom floor.

title: Dr. Sarah Jones Wed To Dr. Wyatt Kirk Jr.
description: Dr. Sarah Virgo Jones, an assistant professor at the School of Social Work at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond, was married there yesterday to Dr. Wyatt Douglass Kirk Jr.. assistant professor in education and a counseling psychologist at Western Michigan University in Kalamazoo. The Rev. James A. Haggins performed the ceremony in St. Phillip's Episcopal Church.

title: Headliners
description: A Chinese Air Force pilot, Fan Yuanyen, has defected to Taiwan. Mr. Fan broke away from a routine mission and flew his MIG19 to a Taiwan airbase, outracing pursuing MIG'S. He told officers who greeted him that, Life on the mainland is too miserable. The plane itself is of little value to western intelligence, since it is an outmoded type given to the Chinese by the Soviet Union before SinoSoviet relations deteriorated around 1960. But there were reports that Mr. Fan provided some documents on Chinese coastal installations and other defense information. Taiwanese officials were apparently more elated at the political value of the defection. Mr. Fan is eligible for about $800,000 to be paid in gold, Taiwan's standing reward for mainland defectors.

title: Finally, Time Runs Out on Parole
description: WASHINGTONAny concept in criminal justice that has the opposition of Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, the American Civil Liberties Union knd former Senator Roman L. Hruska, the very conservative Nebraska Republican, is obviously in some basic difficulty. So it is with parole. The only defense for it in three weeks of Senate hearings on tale revision of the criminal code that ended last month came from the United States Parole Commission, presenting an argument for preserving their own'jobs, and as the bill that would phase out parole is prepared for the floor in markup later this session, even that defense may be absent.

title: Manpower Shortage Is Predicted By U.S. Merchant Marine Survey
description: The American deepsea merchant marine is likely to be sailing into a manpower shortage by the beginning of the next decade. This was the principal conclusion of a study by the Maritime Administration, which has been Keeping a sharp eye on maritime manpower supply and demand since 1969. The massive study, made available here late last month, said that a rapid convergence of deck and engine officer demand will occur through the remainder of the decade.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This analysis is based on reports from representative wholesalers and chains with more than 10,000 outlets in the United States.

description: To the Editor.

title: Fears After Danbury Prison Fire Bring Removal of Plastic Paneling
description: DANBURY, Conn., July 9Workers at the Danbury Federal Correctional Institution today began tearing out all the fiberglass paneling from dormitories at the request of prisoners who fear a recurrence of Thursday morning's blaze, which killed five inmates and injured 66.others.

description: Continued

title: Italian Reds See Problems for East
description: ROME, July 10The Italian Communist Party said today that Eurocommunism, based on independence and respect for human rights, would create serious political problems for the ruling parties in Eastern Europe.

title: Father Accused of Killing Daughters
description: CHICAGO, July 10 (UPI)  Dwight Battles, 25 years old, was charged today with murder in the deaths of his two young daughters whose decomposed bodies were found yesterday in their South Side apartment. Mr. Battles told the police that he beat the children one week earlier while he had been drinking because their crying for food disturbed him. He said that he did not have enough money to buy food. The children's mother had left Mr. Battles, the police said.

title: Carter Family Attends Church
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)President Carterh is wife and daughter, Amy, attended Bible class and a church service today. It was Mrs. Carter's first visit to the First Baptist Church since May 22.

title: Prime Time Is Victor
description: DIX HILLS, L.I., July 10  Prime Time, owned by Reinhart J. Peters of Brookville, L.I., captured two classes and finished second in another to score 13 points and win the regular working hunter championship today at the Hunting Hollow horse show.

title: ScARSDALE SERVICE MOURNS GIRL VICTIM
description: SpARSDALE, N.Y., July 10  A funeral service for Bonnie Joan Garland, a 20yearold Yale student who was bludgeoned to death in her home Thursday, was _held in a white village church here today as her family and friends gathered tripray and quietly share their grief.

title: Laura Bishop Crandon, at 99; Taught at Horace Mann School
description: Laura Bishop Crandon, who taught at the Horace Mann School in Manhattan from 1910 to her retirement in 1942, died yesterday in a nursing home in Portsmouth, N.H. She was 99 years old.

title: Miff FEUD IS SETTLED; TWO ACADEMIES SET UP
description: The HollywoodversusNew York battle within the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences is over. Henceforth, there will be two organizations and two sets of Enuny awards.

title: Bomb ExplosionKills 2, Hurts 53 in Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, July 10 (Reuters) At least two people were killed and 53 wounded when a bomb explosion rocked the center of Damascus today.

title: Coast Killings: Bizarre Case Widens
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10When 17yearold John Lamay failed to return to his home in El Segundo one Sunday night in March, his mother began to worry. He'd spent the night at a friend's house a couple of times before without telling me, Patricia Lamay said, but never on a school night, and she sensed that something had gone wrong.

title: RUSSIANS WARN 11. S. ABOUT NEW WEAPONS
description: MOSCOW, July 10The Soviet press warned today that every new United States weapons development would be matched in kind and it charged that Washington had embarked on an old, bankrupt policy of imperialism.

title: Music: Dan Fogelberg Mines Familiar in Soft Rock
description: Dan Fogelberg and his band, Fools Gold, performed separately and together at the Dr. Pepper Festival in Central Park on Saturday. The capacity crowd was unusually young and unusually attentive. The opening guitar or piano chords of aImost every one of Mr: Fogelberg's songs drew warm applause.

title: Five Thais Are Reported Wounded In Clash With Cambodian Troops
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 10 (AP)Four Thai soldiers and a villager were shot and seriously wounded during threehour clash with Cambodian troops in eastern Thailand, the border police headquarters in Bangkok said today.

title: New York Fireman Dies From Injuries
description: A 25yearold fireman, Martin CeUc, died early yesterday of injuries he suffered July 2 fighting a fire on the loWer East Side that marshals have said was a result of arson.

title: Eritrean Rebel Army Set for Decisive Test
description: ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF BARENTU, Ethiopia  After nearly 16 years of fighting, the war for independence in Eritrea has reached a decisive stage, with rebel forces braced to meet a Major offensive by Ethiopian troops.

title: Bomb Damages Car at Penn State
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., July 10 (UPI)An explosive device detonated about 5 A.M. today in a car parked in a graduate student residence area of Pennsylvania State University, heavily damaging the car and hurling the car's bumper through a window of a residence unit, the university officials said. No one was injured. They said that the device had apparently been planted between the radiator and grillwork of the car belonging to John C. Thompson, a graduate student.

title: Groundbreaking in Norwood Marks Start of 7Home Solar Heating Job
description: NORWOOD, July 9Representative Harold C. Hollenbeck, Republican of Bergen,County, broke ground today for the first private solarheated home development in the state.

title: TWO RUSSIANS HIJACK JETLINER TO FINLAND
description: HELSINKI, Finland Monday, July 11A Soviet airliner carrying 72 people on a domestic flight was hijacked last night by two men, armed with grenades and pistols, who forced it to land at Helsinki.

title: New Hampshire Governor Threatens Budget Veto
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 10 (AP)After calling the New Hampshire legislature back in special session to pass a budget, Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. now says he may veto the only budget that the lawmakers have seriously considered,

title: Michigan Project Helping a Threatened Songbird Make a Comeback
description: LOVELLS, Mich., July 10The Kirtland's warbler,. whose world population totaled only 400 lest year, may be pulling back from the brink of extinction.

title: Fighting TripleDigit Inflation
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 10Argentine inflation, which led the world with a 350 percent increase in living costs last year, still has the wage earner by the throat.

title: 1,300 in Japan Struck By Food Poisoning
description: TOKYO, July 10 (UPI)More than 1,300 people who ate box lunches today at a trade fair in Osaka, Japan's second largest city, were stricken with food poisoning.

title: Morley Scores By 2 Shots in Illinois Golf
description: COAL VALLEY, III., July 10 (AP)Mike Morley overtook Victor Regalado with four straight birdies today and won the $125,000 Quad Cities open golf tournament by 2 strokes with a 17under bar 267.

title: Allison Arvanitis Is Married
description: Allison Edna Arvanitis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Arvanitis of Flushing, Queens, was married there yesterday in St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church to John Francis Savage, son of Mrs. Peter Paul Savage, also of Flushing, and the late Mr. Savage. The Rev. Constantine Volaitis performed the ceremony. The bride, an alumna of Queens College, is with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. Her husband, who is with the New York Life Insurance Company, graduated from Fordham University.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: West, Nye Win 4Ball Golf Event
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 10A long, slow day of golf on Winged Foot's West Coast ended with the perfect execution of a most difficult and delicate shot as Marty West and Gerald P. Nye Jr. beat Peter Van Ingen and Stephen Smith, 6 and 5, in the final of the 41st annual John G. Anderson memorial fourball tournament

title: Bridge:
description: A New Jersey expert emerged from retirement to win the open pair championship at the Greater New York Bridge Association's sectional tournament at the Statler Hilton Hotel in Manhattan Saturday. Alan Messer of Upper Montclair, NJ., who once made headlines for calling Pancho Gonzales for footfaulting at Forest Hills, won the title with Kpn Gorfkle of Redmond, Wash., who has recently settled in New York City.

title: Moynihan Urges That U.S. Act to Stop Soviet Phone Monitoring
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a member of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said today that the Soviet Union was violating the constitutional rights of millions of Americans by secretly intercepting their telephone calls.

title: Leonard Silk
description: The new reports on jobs and prices released late last week in Washington point up the dilemma facing United States economic policy: The economic forces that push down the rate of inflation seem to push up the rate of unemployment  and vice versa. In June, wholesale prices fell at a seasonally adjusted rate of sixtenths of 1 percent  the biggest drop in nearly four years. But unemployment rose to 7.1 percent from 6.9 percent for May.

title: PRM10 and Era Two
description: WASHINGTONNissms, they used to be called, from the acronym for National Security Study Memorandum. These detailed analyses sometimes led to historic changes in policy; in the Nixon Administration, NSSMI was a reassessment of policy toward China.

title: Penn A.C. Eight Wins National Title
description: COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., July 10The Penn Athletic Club of Philadelphia upset the Potomac and Vesper Boat Clubs in the elite eightoared final of the national rowing championships on the Cooper River today. The Penn crew, under Coach Dietrich Rose boated four members of the 1976 Olympic team and overtook the leading Potomac shell in the last 500 meters, crossing the line with a halflength victory in 6 minutes 32.1 seconds against a strong headwind

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Q. You frequently state in recipes to cover the contents of ring mold with a round of wax paper Is there an easy way to shape a round of paper?

title: Market Place
description: A Government suit brought last weel in a Federal court in Hartford involv ing the fight by United Technologies ti obtain control of Babcock & raises imponderables for investors.

title: James G. Schaefer, 73, ExExecutive Of Uniroyal Company Subsidiary
description: James George Schaefer, a former president of Private Brands, a subsidiary of the Uniroyal Tire Company, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y., after a heart attack. He was 73 years old and a resident of Bronxville, for 40 years.

title: 83 CHILD DEATHS TIEDTO ABUSE BY PARENTS',
description: Eightythree children died last year in New Yorx City as a result of parental abuse, officials reported yesterday, warning that child abuse has become an alarming problem.

title: Selling Out at Moscow's Book Fair
description: The nation's leading publishers disagree about whether they should participate in Moscow's first International Book Fair, which begins Sept. 6. The mood of those who shave decided not to go is summed up by the chairman of Random House, Robert Bernstein: You really can't talk to the Russians about publishing if you know that they turn around and put people in jail. But other major publishers, such as Harper & Row, are preparing to attend. Winthrop Knowlton, the firm's president, offers three reasons: some writers will gain a chance for a new market; American publishers will demonstrate a desire to encourage international communication, and Americans will have an opportunity to talk with Soviet officials about liberalizing their publishing practices.

title: Dixon Places First In A.A.U. Decathlon
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., July 10 (AP)Fred Dixon regained the lead by winning the javelin, then withstood a challenge by John Warkentin in the 1,500meter run to win the Amateur Athletic Union national decathalon championship today by 6 points.

title: ETHICS PANELFINDS MORE CONGRESSMEN TOOK KOREANFAVORS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10A survey or the House of Representatives by the House ethics committee has turned up a pattern of South Korean favors for senior House members that was more extensive than had been reported, according to Connressional sources.

title: SCIENCE PROGRAM TO HELP MINORITYGROUP STUDENTS
description: WASHINGTON. July 10 (AP)The National Science Foundation has awarded $762,750 in grants to 16 colleges and universities to plan centers to help g more members of disadvantaged minority groups get advanced science education.

title: LIBERALS NOMINATE BLYN FOR BOROUGH SURROGATE
description: The Liberal Party of New York County has nominated Civil Court Judge Arthur Blyn for the post of Manhattan Surrogate.

title: Habib Arrives in Seoul for Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 10 (Reuters) Under Secretary of State Philip C. Habib arrived here today for talks with American officials on the planned withdrawal of United States ground troops from South Korea and other questions between the two countries.

title: Advertising
description: Needham and the Pursuit of Privacy

title: Thora Kathryn O'Keefe Is Wed to Matthew Zale
description: Thora Kathryn O'Keefe and Matthew Ivan Zale were married yesterday afternoon by Criminal Court Judge Jerome Vale at the St. Reeis Roof.
