description: This article was reported and written by Selwyn Raab and Nathaniel Sheppard Jr.

title: Sadat and Hussein Agree on Link Between Palestinians and Jordan
description: CAIRO, July 10 (UPI)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan agreed today to assure a Palestinian role in Middle East peace talks by an explicit link between Jordan and the guerrillas, Foreign Minister IsMail Fahmy said.

title: Shih Tzu Gets Best, in Show At New Paltz
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y., July 10Victor Doris, the New York fashion designer, raised his arms to the sky and said, I'm. speechless, or pretty much so. after Sunshine, his gold and white Shih Tzu, took his third beStinshow trophy in a field of 1,382 dogs today. The victory came at the Wallkill Ken. nel Club's allbreed show and trial on the grounds of the New Paltz Central High School.

title: JEWISH ANTICRIME PATROL BRINGS PROTEST BY BLACKS
description: About 500 black residents of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn demonstrated peacefully in front of the 71st Precinct station house on Empire Boulevard Saturday to protest alleged brutality by an Orthodox Jewish civilian anticrime patrol in the area.

title: Basques Demonstrate for Amnesty
description: MADRID, July 10 (Reuters)Four columns of demonstrators began a march today in the Basque provinces in support of demands for a full amnesty forpolitical prisoners and autonomy for the Basque region.

title: Balbuco Places First In Lake Placid Show
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 10Balbuco defeated 15 rivals in a jumpoff to win the Adirondack Grand Prix today at the concluding session of the sixday Lake Placid horse show.

title: E.E.C. Team Sets Up Peking Trade Talks
description: PEKING, July 10 (Reuters)A European Common Market team leaves tomorrow after six days of exploratory talks that apparently have cleared the way for negotiations on a trade agreement with China, delegation sources said today.

title: Huntington Poloists Score
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., July 10Peter Rizzo scored four goals and led the Huntington polo team to a 74 victory over Jericho today at Bethpage State Park. Frank Rice added two goals for Huntington. Bob Stackler and Paul Rizzo paced Jericho with two goals each.

title: Helen Finegold Is Bride of Jeffrey Friedman
description: Helen Finegold, chairman of the music department at Hunter College High School, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Franklin Friedman, a vice president and investment officer with the Dreyfus Corporation. The ceremony was performed at the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I., by Rabbi Martin Rosenberg. He was assisted by Cantor Jacob Yaron.

title: Mennonites, Important Factor in Economy of Belize, Fear Independence Will Force Them to a New Home
description: SPANISH LOOKOUT, Belize, July 10Not far from a British Army outpost, established near the Guatemalan border to protect this former British colony from invasion, gently rolling fields of grain and shoulderhigh corn grow thickly on the edge of the jungle.

title: Miss McIngvale Triumphs
description: VIENNA, July 10 (AP)  Cynthia McIngvale of the United States won the threemeter springboard event at an international diving tournament today with 426.60 points, 12 points ahead of East German's Beata Rothe, who placed second. In the men's division, David Ambartsumyan of the Soviet Union edged Mexico's Carlos Giron in the platform competition.

title: CHILE'S LEADER OUTLINES A PLAN FOR CIVILIAN RULE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 10 (AP)Nearly four years after the military assumed power, President Augusto Pinoohet has announced plans for a slow return to civilian rule under which Chileans would not be likely to vote before 1985.

title: ALBANY SENATE DUE TO RECONVENE TODAY
description: ALBANY, July 10With the State Assembly in indefinite recess, the Senate returns alone to the Capitol tomorrow to faCe an unfinished agenda of major issues including nofault automobile insurance, increases in unemployment benefits and substantial revisions in the state parole system.

title: The Systematic Distribution of Disadvantages
description: PRINCETON, N. J.The central issues in Regents of California v. Bakke have been discussed widely, and recently were argued in this newspaper. One pertinent consideration though has been overlooked, and deserves a sort of a footnotemaybe more. It concerns the element of uncertainty (chance, measurement error) in selecting strong applicants for postgraduate study.

title: Vote in Japan Threatens Control Of UpperHouse by Ruling Party
description: TOKYO, Monday, July 11Japan's ruling LiberalDemocratic Party, which has dominated politics in this island nation since 1955, appeared on the verge here today of losing its control of the upper house of Parliament.

title: ANTHONY A. MIANO
description: Anthony A. Miano, a vice president and counsel for the New York Bank for Savings, died Saturday at his home in Northport, L. I. He was 53 years old.

title: Candace Brown Lerman Bride of Dr. Barry Cohen
description: Candace Brown Lerman, daughter of Mrs. Samuel L. Lerman of Springfield, N.J., and the late Dr. Lerman, was married yesterday to Dr. Barry Howard Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Cohen of Huntington Station. L.I.

title: Exiled Thai Official Returns to Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 10 (AP)Narong Kittikachorn, the son of former Prime Minister Thanom Kittikachorn and one of three leaders exiled when Mr. Thanom's Government fell in 1973, returned to Thailand today, an airline spokesman said.

title: Tambay Easily Takes CanAm Race At Glen as Klausler Is Forced Out
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 10The CanAm series (19661974) did not rest in peace. This motor racing series, looking suspiciously like the Formula 5000 series that died last year, returned to the Glen today, and fots of spectators left early.

title: Orioles Win by 60 Behind Grimsley
description: BALTIMORE, July 10In the space of 18 hours in this heatstruck city, the Yankees showed everyone why they weren't ready to start a streak that would turn the American League's Eastern Division race into a oneteam attraction.

description: Laker Airways, which plans to institute a nofrills $135 bargain fare to London this fall, is running into tough competitiontougher perhaps than it originally bargained for.

title: Book's of The Times
description: Here is Louis Auchincloss' s 27th book at least, his 20th work of fiction, his 12th novel. And like the pen that keeps turning them outwhile its energetic masfer sustains a fulltime law career, helps raise a family, presides over the Museum of the City of New York, and does God knows what else the plot of The Dark Lady goes licketysplit.

title: Meadowlands Fires Bring Appeal By 13 Communities for Assistance
description: LYNDHURST, July 10  Firefighting forces in 13 communities abutting the Hackensack Meadowlands have appealed to Bergen County and state officials for help in combating fires that start in the gaseous marshland.

title: 2 Civil Suits Filed Against F.B.I. Agents Accused of Illegal Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Two civil suits have been filed against agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who took part in allegedly illegal breakins, wiretaps and mailopenings in New York, and more are expected to be filed in the weeks ahead, attorneys for several of the targets of the bureau's action said recently.

title: Two Die in Fire on Tugboat
description: SEATTLE, July 10 (AP)Two men were killed yesterday ands even others were burned, one critically, in a flash fire in the engine room of a Washington Army National Guard tugboat. Crewmen of another boat put out the fire aboard the tug 500 yards off Three Tree Point near Burien, Wash., the Coast Guard said.. The dead men were identified as Richard Arnold, 48 years old, of Tacoma, and William Kramer, 42, of Parkland, Wash.

description: STOCKHOLM, July 10 (AP)  The Swedish Government is considering making an apology to the film director Ingmar Bergman, who left the country after a tax dispute, a Government spokesman says.

description: Music

title: Trustees Tell Kent State President To Seek Injunction Against Protest
description: KENT, Ohio. July 10The trustees of Kent State University voted today to order their president to take legal action to remove more than 300 persons encamped on the site where the university plans to construct a $6 million gymnasium.

title: Bidders Carry Home Pieces Of Atlantic City Grandeur
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 10The money changed hands freely yesterday as crowds of buyers bid on the faded furniture that once gave the Claridge Hotel its glamour and grace.

description: ENTRIES

title: Masses of Matter Discovered That May Help Bind Universe
description: Astronomers at the HarvardSmithsonian Center for Astrophysics believe that, through Xray observations from space, they have found a significant fraction of the mass needed to reverse expansion of the universe before it becomes infinitely dispersed. The mass is in the form of very hot gas clouds associated with superclusters of galaxies far beyond the outer limits of the Milky Way. They are the largest assemblages of matter that can be observed.

title: Chess in America Is Showing Signs Of Shaking PostFischer Slump
description: American chess is finally pulling out of its postBobby Fischer depression. Recovery appears imminent.

title: Muskie Garage Sale Besieged by Hundreds
description: KENNEBUNK, Me., July 10 (AP)Senator Edmund S. Muskie and his wife, Jane, held a garage sale at their new home and immediately found themselves besieged by hundreds of bargain hunters. Even before the sale started yesterday, more than 100 people gathered at the entrance to the Muskie home and at least 60 dashed in when the sale began.

title: OnePerson Patrols Predicted by Codd
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday that he expected oneperson cars to be on patrol in New York City before the end of the summer. He said that they would eventually be in 43 precincts which, because of local conditions, lent themselves to that type of patrol.

title: Bond Offerings
description: In this week's schedule of bond sales, the following issues are expected:

title: Brooklyn Woman, 70, Fatally Shot In Apartment by Man in Ski Mask
description: A 70yearold Brooklyn woman died early yesterday after a man wearing green ski mask forced his ivay into her apartment and shot her three times, according to the polie.

title: Reaction in Wall St. To Data on Money Is Called Overdone
description: Lawrence Kudlow. a vice president at Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., says that Wall Street's weekly preoccupation with the latest money supply figures is blowing the data out of proportion.

title: More Than a Dozen Ku Klux Klan Factions Compete For Membership and Feud Over Predominance
description: ATLANTA, July 10Although the Ku Klux Klan, or, more accurately, the Ku Klux Klans, since there are more than a dozen generally competitive groups, has become highly visible after a decade of obscurity, there !s no hard evidence that its membership or influence is significantly expanding.

title: F.D.A. Orders More Tests On McDonald's Glasses
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  (AP)The Food and Drug Administration confirmed today that the painted cartoons on McDonald's glasses contained lead, but said it was not ordering a recall because there was no indication of an acute health hazard.

title: New Ships Speed Bulky Cargo for Mideast
description: BALTIMOREA new type of vessel designed to bypass shipping jams at Middle Eastern ports through the ability to handle and land large items of bulk cargo quickly ai ports or beaches has begun service fromtwo East Coast ports.

title: Bubble Yum Rumors Fade After Campaign
description: For Mack Morris, president of Life Savers, the gamble appears to have paid off.

title: Martian Dust Storms More Frequent Than Expected
description: The winds of Mars have kicked up global dust storm that has been observed by Viking spacecraft for the last month. It is the second such storm in six months and another indication to scientists that dustblinding weather is more common on Mars than had been expected.

title: Raymond Bauer, 60; Business Professor Taught at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 10 (AP)Raymond A. Bauer, a pioneer in the application of behavioral sciences, and holder of the Joseph C. Wilson professorship at the Harvard School of Business Administration, died yesterday at his home here. He was 60 years old.

title: Cascapedia Takes Vanity Carrying 129
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 10 (UPI)Cascapedia joined the ranks of the nation's outstanding fillies and mares today when she carried top weight of 129 pounds to a nose victory in the 36th running of the Vanity Handicap at Hollywood Park.

title: Hard Trip Ends in Welcothe by Eritreans
description: ALET, EthiopiaThe border crossing into Eritrea, from the point of view of formalities, is the easiest in Africa. There are no visa forms, no customs declarations, and, on showing of one's passport, only a gnint ft= a 3tidanese policeman who waves a flashight beam into the cab of a Lan&Rover.

title: ENERGY ISSUES HIGH ON BYRNES AGENDA
description: WASHINGTON, July 10After mixing energy and politics on a weekend visit to the White House, Governor Byrne was scheduled to sign legislation in Trenton tomorrow to help New Jersey gear 1'0 a regional attack on the problems of ever gy shortages and high energy costs.

title: Prison Privileges Under Investigation By State Prosecutor
description: The special state prosecutor, John F. Keenan, has been looking into allegations that criminals in New York City's jails have received special privileges. The charges, which were first made in 1972, were inherited by Mr. Keenan when he succeeded Maurice H. Nadjari as special prosecutor a year ago.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BEYOND THE HORIZON Poetry reading events on the local scene are plentiful. But few sessions delve into Balkan sources, a cultural terrain that remains unfamiliar to many New Yorkers.

title: Columbia to Distribute `You Light. Up My Life
description: You Light Up *My Life, a feature film about the world of pop music, written, prodded and directed in New York by Joseph Brooks, has been acquired for distribution in the United States and Canada by Columbia Pictures.

description: TOKYO, Monday, July 11Japans ruling LiberalDemocratic Party, which has dominated politics in this island nation since 1955, appeared on the verge here today of losing sole control of the upper house of Parliament.

title: SEARCH FOR VICTIMS: Rescue workers and relatives combing through rubblestrewn mud for victims of Saturday's flood and landslide in Anyang, South Korea, near
description: Associated Press Seoul. Officials put the death toll at 188, with 147 persons reported as missing. Many houses were destroyed or damaged leaving almost 20,000 persons homeless.

title: ABRAHAM PAVENICK
description: Abraham Pavenick, former president of the Stanford. Mirror and Metal Products Company, now known as Algem Products, died Friday at Parkway General Hospital, North Miami Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old and, until his retirement four years ago, he had lived all his life in New York City.

title: End of Auto Air Bags Predicted
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 10 (UPI)Dr. John D. States, a specialist on human tolerance to injury, predicts that air bags will fade from use after 1980 because they are expensive and must be replaced often. Dr. States, of Rochester General Hospital, made the prediction in a speech prepared for the Fifth International Con greys on Automotive Safety, which opens here tomorrow at the Hyatt Regency Hotel.

title: Two Tony Winners Act in Legal Twilight in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURGTwo years after they left Broadway with Tony awards as the best actors of the 197475 sea son, John Kani and Winston Ntshona are back on the South African stage, performing in the legal twilight zone reserved for black actors, particularly those who use their talents to mock the country's racial laws.

title: Punk Rock, Britain's. Latest Fad, Leaves Trail of Violence in Wake
description: LONDON, July 10Punk rock, the sociomusical phenomenon that is now spreading in the United States, seems to be in trouble in the land of its birth.

title: V.A. Plans Research Unit For Mobility Problems
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)The Veterans Administrator, Max Cleland, announced today plans for a V.A. research center to develop new technology in an effort to overcome the mobility problems of amputees and patients with spinal cord injuries.

title: Chicago to Train Police To Handle Civil Disorders
description: CHICAGO, July 10Chicago police commanders, supervisors and patrolmen will begin training tomorrow in the handling of civil disorders, according to denartment officials.

title: Chinese Oil Output Rises
description: HONG KONG, July 10 (Reuters)China's crudeoil production In the first six months this year showed a 10.6 percent increase over the same period last year, Radio Peking reported today. The broadcast, monitored here, said both crudeoil and coal production in the first half of this year set an historic new high. Total industrial output in the first six months was also up, according to the broadcast

title: Visit by Taiwan Leadei to Saudis Underlines Bond Between Nations
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 10Taiwan's ties with Saudi Arabia have become increasingly important at a time when the Carter Administration appears td be moving closer toward switching its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Peking.

description: The drop in soybean prices dominated commodity markets last week as index of futures prices dropped almost six points. Page 37.

title: Miss Bradley 2Shot Victor
description: ROCHESTER, July 10 (AP)Pat Bradley shot a threeunderpar 70 today and won a $75,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament with a 54hole total of 213.

title: Manhattan Light Opera Sets Summer Schedule
description: The Light Opera of Manhattan,, which specializes in the Gilbert and Sullivan repertory, is including three, of its operetta productions in its current summer season: Lehar's The, Merry Widow, July 1331; Herbert's Naughty Marietta, Aug. 314, and Friml's The Vagabond King, Aug.. 1728.

title: Officials Say the Alaska Pipeline May Resume Operation This Week
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 10Unless some damage occurred to the 48inch main line, the TransAlaska pipeline could resume operation this week, officials said today in assessing effects of Friday's explosion and fire at a pumping station 33 miles south of here.

title: Weaver Again Triumphs In Prefontaine 5,000 Run
description: Tim Weaver, a former Fordham tniversity runner, won the third annual Steve Prefontaine Memorial Run yes, terday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. The 23yearold winner, who also triumphed in, the two other Prefontaine races, covered'the 5,000meter course in 15 minutes 22.9 seconds, finishing 85 yards ahead of Victor Idavi of the Philippines, who was second in the field of 280 starters..

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Any normal New York cynic will tell you that whatever isn't nailed down (or together) in this city gets stolen, and that includes buildings. Some buildings even get stolen twice. That is what happened to the landmark structure by James Bogardus that stood at the corner of Washington and Murray Streets from 1849 to the 1960's, when the Washington Market was leveled for antiseptic urban renewal.

title: French Prelate Celebrates Latin Mass in Texas as He Defies Pope
description: DICKINSON, Tex., July 10Despite fresh warnings from the Vatican, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre continued his open defiance of Pope Paul VI today by consecrating a Roman Catholic chapel here and celebrating an unauthorized mass in Latin.

description: ADLERHorace Nat, on July 10, devoted husband of Renee, loving father of Karen, Alan and Randeo, beloved son ef Rose and the late Simon Adler, dear brother of Dr. Sheldon Adler and the late Dr. Joel Adler, cnerlshed sonInlaw of Mary and Irving Streit. Services today, 2 P.M., Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Progress Reported in Parley on Rhodesia, But Effort Is Attacked by Guerrilla Group
description: SALISBURY, Moaesia, July A (Reuters)British and American representatives conferred today with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and sources familiar with the situation said that efforts toward peaceful transition to black majority rule in Rhodesia had made considerable progress.

title: CASINOCONTROL PANEL MAY BE APPOINTED TODAY,
description: TRENTON, July 10 (AP)The Legislature returns to Trenton tomorrow with a list of 97 bills waiting for action, but most attention will be focused on Governor Byrne and his expected appointments.. to the Casino Control Commission.

title: NORMAN PARIS, ARRANGER, PIANIST AND CONDUCTOR, 51
description: Norman Paris, the arranger and pianist, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He had been hospitalized about a week, suffering from diabetes and a heart ailment. He was 51 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Six Hijackers Surrender in Syria After Talks With Al Fatah Leaders
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, July 10 (Reuters)Arab hijackers who had commandeered a Kuwaiti airliner, then forced it to fly to Damascus after hours of negotiations on the ground at Kuwait's airport, surrendered today to Syrian authorities. The surrender came after long negotiations between the six hijackers and Palestinian leaders here.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial Ilst scheduled for week follows: MONDAY

title: Uganda Says Canadian Confers With Amin
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 10 (Reuters)The Uganda radio said today that Gerald titting, a reporter for The Toronto Star, missing in Uganda since June 22 and reported in detention there, was having discussions today with President Idi Amin at Cape Town View, the president's residence on Lake Victoria.

title: ETHICS PANEL FINDS MORE CONGRESSMEN TOOK KOREAN FAVORS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10A survey of the House of Representatives by the House ethics committee has turned up a pattern of South Korean favors for sen. for House members that was more extensive than had been reported, according to Congressional sources.

title: Freehold Reportedly Part Of N.J. Track Acquisition
description: TRENTON, N.J., July 10Freehold Raceway, a 128yearold daytime harness track, would be included in New Jersey's plan to purchase some of the state's race tracks, reports indicated today. Freehold and Garden State Park would be purchased by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority legislation is passed permitting the authority to finance the project by means of a bond issue.

title: Pop: High Wire
description: When Trude Heller opened the club bearing her name at Ninth Street and Avenue of the Americas 20 years ago, the first performer to appear there was Morgana King. To celebrate a mutual anniversary, Miss King returned to Trude Heller's last week and will be there for two more weeks.

title: Borg Is Key to Victory of East AllStars
description: SAN DIEGO, July 10Just when it seemed that the West had a lock on the match, Bjorn Borg, the Wimbledon champion, and Billie Jean King engineered a 2318 victory for the East last night in the World Team Tennis allstar match.

title: Sterling Forest Gardens Are Shut, but Their Lure Persists
description: TUXEDO, N.Y.The roses are blooming at Sterling Forest Gardens. The, huge bronze Time and Fates sundial near the center of the 60 acres of lawn, flower beds and interconnecting ponds tells the time. It is peace and beauty in this isolated enclave in southeastern Orange County. There is only one big difference this year. There are no Deonle.

title: Received Doctorate in 1948 By FARNSWORTH FOWLE
description: Dr. Bitter, a social psychologist, was a native of Chicago and a 1953 graduate of Northwestern University. He was a Navy lieutenant (junior grade) in World War II before coming to Harvard, where he became a university fellow and a fellow at the Russian Research Center while earning his doctorate in 1948.

title: Waldheim Visiting Poland
description: WARSAW, July 10 (AP)Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations arrived here toda for a fourday visit to Poland, during which he is scheduled to meet with Edward Gierek, the Communist Party leaner, and receive an honorary doctorate from Warsaw Univer; city.

title: Koch, Murphy in Mimeograph War on Rights
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Two New York City Democratic Congressmen lobbed verbal and written brickbats at each other last week in their own little war over how to protect human rights in the republics of Central America.

title: A Study of Daytime Network TV Finds It Geared to the Housewife
description: Daytime television is geared to accompany the woman 18 years or older with situation comedies and game shows as she performs her morning household chores and then, according to a major advertising agency, to sit her down for concentrated viewing of the afternoon soap operas.

title: Authorized Spying
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass.Proposed legislation on a revised national security wiretap bill, enthusiastically supported by the C.I.A., the F.B.I. and the military, would require the Government to obtain judicial warrants before tapping the phones or bugging the premises of foreign powers or foreign agents.

title: Papua New Guinea's Ruling Party Seen Winning General Election
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea, July 10 (AP)Papua New Guinea's governing coalition of the Pangu and People's Progress Parties was headed for four more years in power today in the nation's first general election since independence from Australia in 1975.

title: Nearby Dog Show
description: AT NEW PALTZ, N.Y.

title: Bombings in France
description: RENNES, France, July 10 (Reuters)Explosions rocked the offices of the French Electricity Board in the Breton 7fishing port of SaihtMalo and destroyed another electricity board building Dinan early today, the police said. The bombs were placed by a local group objecting to the building of nuclear power stations in the area by the board, a state ment to a Dinan newspaper said.

title: Bernard King Is Arrested
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.,. July 10 (AP)Bernard King, the Nets first draft pick and a'former University of Tennessee basketball star, was arrested early today on charges of breaking into a campus athletics building and stealing a television set, the nolice said. A July 19 trial date in General Sessions Court was set after King was released from Knox County jail 55.000 bond.

title: Zachry's Victory His First Since Trade
description: When you're hot, you're hot. The Mets won again yesterday, beating the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium, 21.

title: President Rejects Proposal to Sell Alaska Oil to Japan in an Exchange
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  President Carter has decided against attempting to sell some of the new Alaska pipeline oil to Japan in exchange for oil more readily available to the East Coast and the Middle West.

title: Jet Stuck in Mud Closes Airport in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 10 (AP) DC10 airliner with 60 people aboard slid into the mud as it landed tonight, blocking a runway and closing New Orleans International Airport. No injuries were reported.

title: New York's Armenian Neighborhoods Feel a Surge Of Ethnic Pride as New Immigrant Wave Arrives
description: The exotic sounds of spoken Armenian have been spreading in the homey sidestreets of Sunnyside, Queens. ArmenianAmerican scholars have been turning to the riches of Armenian literature at Columbia University. Armenian folkdance rhythms have been pulsing in a Manhattan meeting hall.

title: Gordon C. Bill, 51, a Vice President In A.T.&T.'s Long Lines Department
description: Gordon C. Bill, a vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company died Sunday in the SloanKettering Memorial Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Califon, N.J.

title: Violence by Religious Extremists in Egypt Poses a New Challenge to Sadat Regime.
description: CAIRO, July 10The ritual murder or a respected Moslem dignitary and onetime Cabinet minister and the explosion of a few dynamite sticks in public places have jolted Egyptians, who thought that urban terrorism was the monopoly of young revolutionaries in Western societiesthe Weathermen in the United States, the BaaderMeinhof gang in West Germany, the urban guerrillas in Argentina and ultraleftist students in Italy.

title: East German Oarsmen Dominant at Lucerne Regatta
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland, July 10The Lucerne International rowing regatta concluded today with more surprises than had been anticipated. What had been heralded as a battle of the giants, between the Soviet Union and East Germany turned into a onesided affair for the East Germans.

title: Royal Ballet Stages Swan Lake With a Young but Unexciting Cast
description: LONDON, July 7The cost of ballet tickets in Britain (and also opera tickets, for that matter) is surprisingly high in relationship to similar goods and services and people's earning capacity. Ballet seats frequently cost more in London than in New York, particularly for visiting companies. Londoners have apparently gotten used to this state of affairs, because London is still the only possible rival to New York as dance capital of the world. At present three major companies are playing here, all, it seems, to aped houses.

title: Eritrean Rebel Army Set for Decisive Test
description: ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF BARENTU, Ethiopia  After nearly 16 years of fighting, the war for independence in Eritrea has reached a decisive stage, with rebel forces braced to meet a major offensive by Ethiopian troops.

title: Women at AlbanyMeetingVoteto Support Abortion
description: ALBANY, July 10A platform supporting the Equal Rights Amendment and the right of women to choose legal abortion was voted by participants in the first New York women's conference today in the concluding sessions of the threeday conference here, one of 56 such meetings mandated by Congress in connection with the International Women's Decade.

title: Merlin Assumes Lead in TransPacific Yacht Race
description: HONOLULU, July 10 (AP)Merlin and Drifter were engaged in a close duel as they headed for the finish line today, and the victor was assured of breaking the record in the transPacific yacht race.

title: Katherine Stinson Otero, 86, Dies; Pioneer Aviator and Stunt Flier
description: Katherine Stinson Otero, a pioneer in American aviation, died Friday at her home in Sante Fe, N. M., after a long illness. She was 86 years old.

title: More Women Risk the Big Switth: Changing Career in Midlifei
description: Carol Rinzler, writer end editor, enrolls in law school. Rosemary Masters, already a lawyer, begins studying for a degree in social work. Margaret Lewin, former aerospace engineer, decides to be a doctor. Carol Reich turns from interior design to child psychology.

title: Hunters Asked to Help Enforce Wildlife Laws
description: ALBANYNew York State is asking hunters, fishermen and hikers to turn in poachers and any colleagues who break the rules.

title: Loren Eiseley, Anthropologist, 69; Eloquent Writer on Man and Nature
description: Loren Eiseley, anthropologist, educator and author, died Saturday of cardiac arrest following a recent series of operations at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Trust Democracy by Enlarging It
description: Lance Tarrance, a Republican student of political statistics, has discovered the political party which truly won the last election: It was the NonVoters, by a landslide: Looking at the total votingage population in 1976, he finds that Democrats won support from 27 percent and Republicans from 26 percent. What he calls the NonVoter Party won 47 percent. What is more, the NonVoters have since 1928 outdistanced both Democrats and Republicans in every Presidential election except 1964, when they finished in a dead heat with Lyndon Johnson.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JULY 11, 1977

title: Severe Heat Wave Hits Greece and Turkey
description: ATHENS, July 10 (UPI)An eastern Mediterranean heat wave today boosted temperatures to the highest levels ever recorded in Greece and caused hospitalization of several people in Turkey. One tourist died of sunstroke in Crete.

title: Firmani Debut a Loss for Co, srnos
description: In their fifth appearance on national television, yesterdayand their fifth without a victorythe Cosmos proved again that wellknown names dont win games in the North American Soccer League.

title: No TV Show Too Good to Botch
description: As children, television directors are taught that if they., permit viewers a glimpse of a golfer walking between shots in a tournament or studying his lie or committing harakiri by falling on his putter, they will surely go to hell.. In screen credits shown by AmeriCan Broadcasting Companies after its coverage of that extraordinary final round in the British Open championship, Chuck Howard was identified as producer and Jim Jennett as director. They are going to heaven. By keeping the camera's eye discreetly averted from the principal actors except Sports for momentary flashes, they managed of invest a classic duel with all the drama of the first round of the Greater Greensboro open. Through the miracles of electronic and space technology, ABC was able to pick up the action from the British Broadcasting Company, bounce the signal off a satellite and deliver to millions of Americans who, like, golf fans everywhere else in the world, were interested exclusively in the epic confrontation of Jack Nicklaus and Tom Watson. Every now and then the watchers did see Nicklaus or Watson make a shot, though they were not always shown or told where the ball landed. Instead the scene would shift with panicky haste to show stragglers named Tommy Horton and Ben Crenshaw hacking out scores of 75, or else coverage would give way to commercials. Ah, those commercials, sometimes five six of them between shots.

title: Black Composers To Be Honored By Philharmonic
description: The New York Philharmonic will present a Celebration of Black Composers Week at Lincoln Center from Aug. 29 through Sept. 2. The orchestra will play three programs of works by black composers in Avery Fisher Hall, and there will be one prografn each of piano and vocal music in the LibraryMuseum Auditorium. Various American orchestras have held symposiums on black music in the past, but this will be the first festival of this kind and size to be sponsored by a major symphony.

title: Pakistan Military Decrees Traditional Punishments
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan. July 10 (UPI) The military ruler of Pakistan decreed today traditional harsh punishments for thieves and for anyone insulting a woman.

title: INVESTOR PRESSURE HELPS SPUR TREND TO HIGHER DIVIDENDS
description: If the hectic pace of the first six months is any guide, 1977 may well go down as the year of the dividend.

title: High Prices Are Said to Be Slowing Boom in Atlantic City Real Estate
description: ATLANTIC CITY. July 10Realtors here say that unrealistically sigh asking prices for property may be holding down a realestate boom in this resort city.

title: Efforts by Rockland Police End Harassment ofHasidim
description: MONSEY, N.Y., July 10  Orthodox Jews in Hasidic communities clustered near the center of Rockland County were free this weekend, for the first time in years, from the harassmentand sometimes brutal assaults  they encountered as they walked at dusk through country lanes to Sabbath services in their small synagogues.

title: Tim Gullikson Captures Newport Final
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 10Tim Gullikson, a 25yearold tennis player striving to become a somebody on the pro circuit, won the Hall of Fame tournament today on the center court of the Casino.

title: Pirates Pull Same Trick on Phils, Winning Twice for FourGame Sweep
description: Last Friday, after winning four games from the Pittsburgh Pirates and then four from the New York Mets, the Philadelphia Phillies seemed ready to put some pressure on the Chicago Cubs, the seasonlong leaders of the National Leagues Eastern Division. The eight

title: Chess:
description: Of course, I am dead, but... is a frequent introduction by the Argentine grandmaster Oscar Panno to one of his numerous escapes.

title: Portugal, in Exhausted Mood, Drifts to Right
description: LISBONAfter one year in power together, President Antonio Ramalho Eanes, an unsmiling soldier, and Prime Minister Mario Soares, an ebullient Socialist, have brought a stagnant stability to Portugal.

description: TUESDAY, JULY 12, 1977

title: F.E.A. to Hold Public Discussion On Plan to Check Oil Finance Data
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Federal, Energy Administration announced today that it would hold a public discussion later this month on the proposal to require oil companies to provide the Federal Government with detailed financial infor mation.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JULY 11, 1977

title: WHIRLPOOL PROFITS DOUBLE IN QUARTER
description: The Whirlpool Corporation, a leading appliance manufacturer, reported yesterday that its profits had more than doubled in the second quarter and risen 81.7 percent for th half year.

title: Akita, 21:60 Rallies to Take the Astoria at Belmont
description: Marie A. Moore's Akita made a big rush through the stretch and won the 71st running of the, $36;450 Astoria Stakes for 2yearold fillies at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Taxes &
description: JerOME Kurtz, the new commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, is bemused by, the furor over his proposal that corporate and wealthy taxpayers flag questionable items on their returns. All he intended, he says, is more disclosure of already public information.

description: BASEBALL

title: Nassau Plans a More Representative
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 11In an effort to make the Nassau County Police Department more representative of the community it serves, Commissioner Daniel P. Guido announced today a drive to recruit minoritygroup members and women to nolice work.

title: Merlin Finishes First, Sets Pacific Race Mark
description: HONOLULU, July 11 (UPI)  The 67foot yacht, Merlin smashed the transPacific yacht race record time by almost a full day yesterday, crossing the Diamond Head finish line 2,225 miles from Los Angeles in eight days 11 hours 1 minute 46 seconds.

title: SENATE SNUBS CARTER IN BACKING REACTOR
description: WASHINGTON, July 11In a major setback for President Carter, the Senate refused tonight to cut funding for the Clinch River Breeder Reactor to the low level sought by the Administration.

title: Newark Since 67 Riots: Hope and Despair
description: NEWARK, July 11Neglected Springfield Avenuethe battle corridor of the racial riots that began here 10 years ago tomorrowattests to that uprising and to this 311yearold city's deterioration. But Ferry Street, only a mile away, attests to its residential rebirth and commercial vitality.

title: Carier Is Said to Bick Lance
description: WASHINGTON,. July 11 (AP)President Carter does not consider the personal financial dilemma facing his budget director, Thomas B. Lance, a very serious problem, and Mr. Lance will not resign, Mr. Powell said today..

title: Red Sox Hot Streak Victimizes Indians
description: Despite a recent ninegame losing akeak, which might well have taken them out of contention in the American League East's pennant race, the Boston Red Sox have righted themselves nicely and are occupying the division's top spot by half a game.

title: Dollar Of Against Mark
description: The dollar fell to a near record bow against the West German mark and continped to slide against other, major currencies in foreign exchange trading at home alid abroad today, The Associated Press renorted_ t

title: A Cautious Administration and the PriceWage Spiral
description: WASHINGTON, July IIDespite the good news of the June drop in wholesale prices, the Carter Administration apparently has yet to come to grips with breaking a deeply entrenched pricewage spiral that has been running 6 to 7 percent a year_

title: A New Weapon to Think (and Worry) About
description: TACONIC, Conn.The nuclear weaponeers have unfolded a new brainchild, the neutron bomb, which will kill people while preserving buildings, tanks and artillery. They believe such weapons would be a better deterrent against aggression because their firstuse would by more credible than standard atomic bombs.

title: Carter Would Ship More imported Oil On Tankers of U.S
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Carter Administration confirmed today that would support legislation designed to insure that more of America's oil imports are carried in Americanflag tankers. The decision is intended to benefit the United States merchant marine and the maritime unions, both of which have been suffering from foreign competition.

title: 2 Charges Against NBCDropped In Suit Over Scottsboro Film
description: WINCHESTER, Tenn., July 11 (AP). Mender and invasion of privacy charges against NBC were dismissed today by Federal District Court Judge Charles G. Neese. A libel charge remained against: th network in connection with the airing of the TV film, Judge Horton and the Scottsboro Boys.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ALBANYClifford E. Wilson, who ceases being a freshman legislator any day now, has acquired some scars in the course of his maiden session, and he has already decided that his political future does not lie in the Assembly.

title: Richard Kelly, 66, the Designer Of LiRhtifIR for Seagram Building
description: Richard Kelly, a leading figure in architectural lighting, died Sunday of a heart attack on a train returning from Fire Island, L.I., to his home in the city. He was 66 years old and lived at 1140 Fifth Avenue.

title: STRAUSS HOPES MKS ON TRADE WILL BRING AN ACCORD BY SPRING
description: BRUSSELS, July 11 (AP)Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's trade negotiator, laid down a timetable with Common Market leaders today for worldwide trade negotiations and said he hoped they would be concluded by spring with an agreement that would last a decade.

title: Samuel Schwartz, Producer, Dies; Manager for Jujamcyn Theaters
description: Samuel H. Schwartz, a theatrical business manager since 1927, who recently retired as chief operating officer of Jujamcyn Theaters, owners of the St. James and Martin Beck Theaters in New York and of the Colonial and Wilbur Theaters in Boston, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home at 12 East 86th Street. He was 69 years old.

title: Satie's Socrate Being Revived in Fall
description: Erik Satie's Socrate, a symphonic drama for four sopranos and chamber orchestra, will be revived in a stage version with a setting by the late Alexander Calder on Nov. 10 and 11 at the Beacon Theater. It will be presented on a double bill with the Gertrude SteinVirgil Thomson opera, Four Saints in Three Acts, by the Orchestra of Our Time of the Philandelphia Composers Forum, of which Joel Thome is music director.

title: 3 More Bodies of Missing Youths Identified by California Authorities
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., July 11 (UP1)1110 identities of three more bodies possibly connected to the socalled trashbag murders in whit victims were mutilated and trussed in plastic bags, were released yesterday.

title: Topics
description: CIGARETTES  Add to the everlengthening list of reasons for not smoking the recent research findings that the more a woman smokes, the earlier she is likely to become menopausal. Even more significant, earlier studies linking menopause and heart disease may simply be additional evidence of the role of cigarette smoking in heart disease. Will this latest news have much impact on smokers? We are skeptical. More than a decade ago

title: Floridian Ordered to Stand Trial In Kidnapping of Gitl Scout, 15
description: SARASOTA, Fla., July 11. (UPI)Wilfred Bannister pleaded not guilty today to charges of kidnapping 15yearold Charlotte Grosse from a Girl Scout camp and sexually molesting her during the 52 hours before she escaped July 1.

title: Vaults Robbed of $1.1 Million
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., July 11 (UPI)Bandits made off with more than $1.1 million in gold and silver bullion, coins and currency from two vaults at a storage concern over the weekend. The police said yesterday that they believed four or five persons were involved in the Saturday afternoon robbery, in which more than four tons of loot was taken.

title: DayCare Head Accused in Suffolk
description: NORTHPORT, L.I. July 11The chairman of the Suffolk County Legislature's Finance Committee charged today that the director of a strinab of countyfinanced daycare centers of the Young Men's Christian Association in Nassau and Suffolk used county funds to furr'sh his own office and to provide a luxury car and extensive air travel for himself while slighting the needs of the children under his care.

title: Cash Receipts on Bond Sales
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)The Treasury Department announced today that net cash receipts from sales of United States savings bonds reached $510 million during the first six months of this year the biggest total in 28 years.

title: AmmanNew York Air Route Ooens
description: AMMAN, July 11 (Reuters)King Hussein of Jordan today inaugurated the first direct air link between Amman and New York. An Alia Royal Jordanian Airline jumbo jet left on the weekly flight with 200 passengers on board. It stops in  Damascus and Amsterdam.

title: A.A. SCHILLER, AT 74, RETIRED LAW EXPERT
description: A. Aithur Schiller, a retired Columbia University Law professor and an authority on Roman law, died of cancer Sunday at Fox Memorial Hospital in Oneonta, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Oneonta.

title: SOVIET JEW DELIVERS CHALLENGE ON RIGHTS
description: MOSCOW, July 31Dr. Veniamin G. Levich, a Soviet Jewish scientist denied permission to emigrate, said today that it was a bad sign for the future that he had also been kept from attending an international conference now being held in his honor at Oxford University.

title: Congress Muddies Its Dirty Water
description: It is becoming more difficult each day to figure out who In Congress was gullible and who was culpable in dealing with the influencepeddling agents of the Government of South Korea. The names of the innocent and the names of some who winked at the unethical are obviously being mixed together in the information dribbling out of Washington. The House of Representatives has only itself to blame. Its leaders have hidden behind the Ethics Committee, and the committee has hidden in a procedural fog to justify a most leisurely pace.

title: A Dirty Business
description: Electronic eavesdropping, once touted as an indispensable weapon in the fight against serious crime and threats to the national security, has put a lot of bookies in jail, invaded the privacy of thousands of Americans and threatened the rights of thousands more. That's about all.

title: SOME DOUBTS PERSIST OVER CRUISE MISSILE
description: The Administration's acceptance of the cruise missile as a substitute for an advanced manned bomber has accelerated the Air Force and Navy development programs but failed to still doubts within the defense community over the weapon's effectiveness.

title: TV: Stir Over Soap
description: Soap is being seized upon by some broadcasters as just the product that, inadvertently, could clean up television programming content. The ABCTV series, described as a radically new and outrageous adult comedy, won't begin until midSeptember, but its offbeat content already has broadcasters talking and worrying about the series generating a widespread backlash against the new permissiveness.

title: Dow Drops 2.46 in Bearish Market
description: Now that most etonomists have begun to perceive what equity and commodity prices may have been indicating since early last Aprila slowing of the economic growth rate later this yeartheir followers in the stock market have apparently become more bearish.

title: Counsel Criticizes Head of House Inquiry on Korea
description: WASHINGTON, July IIPhilip A. Lacovara, special counsel to the House ethics committee, in a confidential memorandum to other members of the committee, has criticized its chairman, Representative John J. Flynt Jr., for his handling of the investigation of the Korean lobby, Congressional officials disclosed today.

title: Memorial to Signers Backed
description: WASHINGTON, July II (UPI)The House today approved an authorization for a memorial to honor the 56 signers of the Declaration of Independence. Under the bill, which was sent to the Senate, the Interior Department will establish the memorial to be in Constitution Gardens in Washington. The cost, not to exceed $500,000, will be paid for from sale of bicentennial year medals.

title: About New York
description: At 261 Madison Avenue. in office suite 1102, in tiny subleased room No. 12, sits Maxwell Laskin, ready to sell you on the $99 divorce ($106.92 with tax nlus $75 in court fees).

title: CASHIER'S CHECK RULING IS REVERSED BY COURT
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn held yesterday that payment may not be stopped on cashier's check issued by a bank, in the absence of a court order or an indemnification bond.

title: 12 Rescued in Niagara River
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., July 11 (AP)  Twelve persons were rescued early today from a 40foot cabin cruiser that hung on a reef in the Niagara River about a mile upstream from the falls. AU of the boat's passengers were unhurt. The twinengine cruiser struck the reef late last night and sheared off both its pro. pellers. The boat's owner, Walter A. Rozicki, 26 years old, of Buffalo said an anchor was then thrown out, which held until three park policemen used rescue boat to remove the stranded people.

title: Rookie Named Reed Is Off and Coaching
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 11 This morning at 9:30, the hulking 6foot9inch figure of Willis Reed lumbered onto the court at Monmouth College and a new era in Knick coaching began.

title: BOXING FIGURES ATTEND FUNERAL FOR SILVERMAN
description: BROOKLINE Mass., July 11 (AP)A crowd of 500 boxers, referees, fans and friends attended the funeral today of Sam Silverman, a promoter who arranged matches in New England for nearly 40 years. He died at the age of 64 on Satur1 day in an automobile accident.

title: CONTROVERSY GROWS OVER CARTER'S MOVE TO SELL IRAN PLANES
description: WASHINGTON, July 11A decision by the Carter Administration to sell seven highly complex airborne radar systems to Iran is under Congressional attack amid allegations that the Defense Department blocked all competition and failed to offer the Shah of Iran a less expensive option.

title: Chancellor Gets Contract For Several More Years As Anchorman With NBC
description: John Chancellor, the leading anchorman of NBC News, has negotiated a new contract with the network and will continue to be a coanchorman of the NBC Nightly News, network officials said yesterday.

title: Soybeans Weaker; Ruin Spurs Selling 01 OldCrop Futures
description: Mare rain late Friday and yesterday over the Middle Western growing areas apparently induced heavy selling of soybean contracts yesterday. The price of the oldcrop deliveries of July and August plunged the daily 30centsabushel limit on the Chicago,Board of Trade_.

title: CONTROVERSY GROWS OVER CARTER'S MOVE TO SELL IRAN PLANES
description: WASHINGTON, July 11A decision by the Carter Administration to sell seven highly complex airborne radar systems to Iran is under Congressional attack amid allegations that the Defense Department blocked all competition and failed to offer the Shah of Iran a less expensive option.

title: In Phoenix Hospital, Birthing Room Offers HomeStyle Delivery
description: PHOENIXThe walls are bright with yellow and brown sunflowers, the bed is covered with a cheerful quilted spread and a nearby lamp, with colorful Mexican pottery base, gives off a soft flow in the room.

title: FUKUDA PARTY KEEPS UPPER HOUSE CONTROL
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, July 12Japan's LiberalDemocratic Party, the political grouping of conservative factions that has governed the nation with comfortable legislative majorities foi 22 years, lost its majority in the upper house of Parlia ment, according to final results tallied today from the election Sunday.

title: Staten Island Piers Impress Visiting Oil Executives
description: We're amazed. We never thought you had space like this for us in New York. It's lust great.

title: The HallMarks of the Annie Look
description: Take a hatslouchy, too big for the head it's on, and slightly punchy looking. Better still, take a man's hat that pulls down deep and covers the forehead. The hat is a crucial ingredient, one of the keys to the Annie Hall look.

title: HUMBERT J. PIZZICA
description: SYRACUSE, July 11 (AP)Humbert Pizzica, a Canadian professional lightweight boxing champion in the 1920's, will he buried here Wednesday. Mr. Pizzica, who fought under the name of Humbert Brady, died in a hospital Saturday at the age of 75.

title: BERGMAN WINS DELAY IN 1YEAR JAIL TERM
description: Bernard Bergman, who was scheduled to begin serving a oneyear prison sentence for Medicaid fraud today, was given a reprieve yesterday until at least July 21. A judge set that date for a hearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan on the nursinghome operator's contention that his plea bargain had been violated.

title: Renault Car in Debut
description: PARIS, July 11 (UPI)  Renault's turbocharged Formula One challenger, the RenaultElf RS01, will have its first race Saturday at Silverstone in .the British Grand Prix, the RenaultSport team manager, Jean Sage, announced today. The car, the first turbocharged Formula One entry, will be driven by JeanPierre Jabouille of France.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JULY 12, 1977

title: Fiat Aide in France, Held for 3 Months; Is Freed by Captors
description: PARIS, July 11 (AP)The kidnapped head of the Fiat automobile company's operations in France and Brazil was freed today after nearly three months in captivity. A group calling itself the Committee for Socialist Revolutionary Unity said it had been responsible for Ms abduction.

title: G.A.O. Studies Tax On Americans Abroad
description: HONG KONG, July 11 (UPI)The United States General Accounting Office began here today a study of the impact of tax increases on Americans living abroad.

title: Norwegian Opposes Preference
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)Norwegian Foreign Secretary Knut Fryden lund today reaffirmed his country's opposition to the Carter Administration plan to guarantee United States tankers 9.5 percent of the nation's oil import market.

title: Bridge
description: The trend to youth noticeable in the Eastern Regionals here a month ago continued in the Greater New York Dridge Association's sectional tournament at the Stetler Hilton Hotel last weekend.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Monday, July 11, 1977

title: Abbott Laboratories
description: With the hospital and pediatric groups showing the best growth, all major areas of Abbott Laboratories contributed to the record results reported yesterday for the quarter and six months ended June 30. Net income for the quarter gained 32.7 percent to $28 million, or 94 cents a share on a sales gain of 21.4 percent to $304.9 million. This lifted the sixmonth net by 30.1 percent to $53.2 million, or $1.79 a share over a year earlier on sales of $588.4 million, up 11.7 percent.

title: Duped AutoRepair Patrons Fail To Win Satisfaction Under Law
description: Hundreds of New York motorists who bad counted on help from the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles with fraudulent or deceptive auto repairs have received no satisfaction, even when the department has found a shop guilty of violatine the law.

title: Air Force Refines Its Process To Curb Accidental Missile Shots
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI)  The Air Force said today it had refined the failsafe process designed to make it impossible for a minuteman intercontinental missile to be fired without an order from the White House.

title: Train AccidentClaims 4th Victim
description: Iynwood, Calif., (UPI)Holly Kline, an 8yearold girl who was critically injured when she and three other children inexplicably continued to walk in the path of a freight train Friday, despite the train's whistles, died late today. Her sister and two friends were killed instantly.

title: In Memoriam
description: ALEXANDERRussell C. Lovingly remembered always. MINA AND LINDA

title: Massive Security Rings the Delegates
description: STOCKHOLM, July 11The summer meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is being held behind a massive security screen in a luxury hotel where many famous economic decisions have been made.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gambling Panel Named

title: NEW PUBLISHER IS NAMED BY THE OAKLAND TRIBUNE
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 11 (AP)G. Gordon Strong, chairman of the board of Thomson Newspapers Inc., was named publisher of The Oakland Tribune today.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: BOSTON  Two years ago, shortly after the trough of the last recession bad passed, the economic picture and outlook for the Northeast appeared grim. A year later, the data indicated some improvement, though the pattern was erratic throughout the nine states involved. Their overall performance on the comeback trail seemed to lag considerably behind the rest of the country. Now this region finally has caught up with the pace of many of the leaders, after the generally strong level of American economic activity during the first six months of 1977 and the fruition of determined rebuilding efforts in this area.

title: U. S. Asks Banks to Submit Data For Survey of Loans. Made Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Comptroller of the Currency announced today that Federal bank regulators were conducting a comprehensive survey of banks overseas loans.

title: Nabokov Memorial on July 21
description: A memorial for Vladimir Nabokov, who died on July 2, will be held on. July 21 at 11 A.M. in the McGrawHill auaitorium, 1221 Avenue of the Americas. The memorial is open to the public. McGrawHill had been Nabokov's American publisher since 1968. John Updike and Julian Moynihan will be among the speakers. The writer's son, Dmitri, is expected to attend.

title: World News Briefs
description: CAIRO, July 11 (Reuters)Eightyone members of a Moslem extremist group accused of planning a campaign of terror have been arrested in a continuing crackdown on the sect, the semiofficial daily newspaper Al Ahram reported today.

title: ADDABBO MAY HEAD DEFENSE FUNDS PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queens, a critic of military spending who led the successful floor fight in 1973 to end the bombing of Cambodia, is expected to assume the chairmanship of the Defense Subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee, one of the most powerful Congressional subcommittees.

title: SOVIET JEW DELIVERS CHALLENGE ON RIGHTS
description: MOSCOW, July 11Dr. Veniamin G, Levich, a Soviet Jewish scientist denied permission to emigrate, said today that it was a bad sign for the future that he had also been kept from attending ar international conference now being held in his honor at Oxford University.

title: Buying an gducational Bargain
description: There is still time for the New York State Legislature to help hardpressed private colleges and their students. T,A.P., the state's tuitionassistance program, provides grants of as much as $1500 a year to undergraduates. The family income of any recipient must be less than $20,000, the amount of aid varying with income level and tuition. Qualified students are thus helped to higher education at a lower total cost to the taxpayer than in publiclYowned colleges and universities.

title: Castro Adamant on Angola Troops
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 11 (Reuters)President Fidel Castro says he will never agree to withdraw Cuban troops from Angola as a condition for Washington's lifting its blockade of his country or resuming diplomatic relations with Havana.

title: More Moves on Nets
description: Governor Byrne said Monday that New Jersey would intervene in the legal fight between the Knicks and the Nets over the proposed move of the Nets from the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., to New Jersey. The Knicks are opposing the move, claiming a violation of territorial rights.

title: STEEL OUTPUT OFF 5.9% FOR WEEK ENDED. JULY 9
description: Stet: production for the holidayshortened week ended July 9 fell by 5.9 percent to 2.39 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was the sixth consecutive week in which output fell behind the preceding week. The percentage decline was the largest since Jan. 22, when output fell by 6.3 percent in the midst of the extreme cold weather in the Eastern half of the nation.

title: Norway Aiding Burma on Opium
description: GENEVA, July 11 (Reuters)Norway has given $.14 million from its aid funds to help reduce illicit opium production in Burma by deVeloping other forms of agriculture there, it was announced today. Jacobus de Beus of Holland, executive director of the United Nations Fund for Drug Abuse Control, said the gift was the biggest since 1971 apart from the annual Uniizei States contribution covering 75 percent of the fund's budget.

title: Reward Offered for Fanfreluche
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 11 (AP)A $25,000 reward has been offered jointly by Claiborne Farm in Paris, Ky., and the Canadian horseman JeanLouis Levesque in the latest effort to recover Levesque's stolen mare, Fanfreluche.

title: Money
description: Monday, July 11, 1977

title: 3 IN CONGRESS CITE STUDY ON ENDING GAS PRICE CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI)Shree Congressmen said today that removing all price controls from natural gas would be $48 billion cheaper over the net 13 years than President Carter's plan to modify existing controls.

title: Roots
description: FRAMLINGHAM, EnglandIt was a combination Roots and royaltyan event that mixed history, religion, and amateur genealogy in a way the Duke of Norfolk never anticipated when he scheduled it.

title: Age and Ability Are Unrelated, Witnesses Over 65 Insist
description: Poignant and sometimes feisty testimony was heard yesterday at a hearing on a proposed Federal law that would bar mandatory retiremeint before age 70 in private business and virtually eliminates mandatory retirement in the Federal Civil Service.

title: CARTER IS EXPECTED TO BACK UNION DRIVE FOR NEW LABOR LAWS
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  President Carter is expected to send a message to Congress late this week calling for broad changes in labor laws to make it easier and quicker for unions to organize and to recruit new members, well placed Administration and labor officials said today.

title: 2 in Bolles Murder Case. Go on Trial in Phoenix; Conspiracy Is Charged
description: PHOENIX, July 11The trial of two men charged with the murder of Don Bolles, a reporter for The Arizona Republic, opened today with the selection of 120 prospective jurors in Maricopa County Sunerior Court.

title: Actors Upstage Machinery In Role of Scenery Changer
description: LONDONWe all know about shipboard conversations and the odd turns they're apt to take, but I was surprised, nonethelessen route to England on the Queen Elizabeth 2to find myself confronted with a friendly soul who had just one emphatic complaint to make about the theater he'd been seeing. He'd grown sick to death of having to watch trie actors doing the scenechanging themselves, scurrying about like so many blind mice as they hoisted sofas and tree stumps and thrones and what have you up into the air and off into nonexistent wings.

title: Orioles Beat Yanks On Run in Ninth. 43
description: BALTIMORE, July 11 Don't tell me how many storms you, encountered, the ship owner said to the captain, tell me if you brought the ship home safely.

description: Tennis

title: Carter Is Reported Set To Ask Stopgap Funding For Neutron Warhead
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  rrestaent Carter is set to ask Congress for temporary funding of the socalled neutron bomb, according to Administration officials. The request is to be made tomorrow or Wednesday, when the Senate discusses the issue.

title: People and Business
description: The Natomas Company of San Francisco announced yesterday a management reorganization of its subsidiary, the American President Lines, in which Dorman L. Commons, Natomas president and chief executive officers, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the oceancargo carrier.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, July 11, 1977

title: PESETA IS DEVALUED BY SPANISH CABINET; RATE NOT RELEASED
description: MADRID, July 11 (AP)The Government devalued the peseta today and coupled the move with a series of tax reform proposals designed to end a slowdown in the Spanish economy, an official snokesman announced.

title: Lakeland, Fla., Editorial Writer Wins Bar Association's Gavel Award
description: John R. Harrison, president of The Ledger of Lakeland, Fla., and a vice president of The New York Times Company, was named yesterday as the recipient of the American Bar Association's 1977 Gavel Award for newspapers with a circulation of 50.000 or under.

title: North Sea Oil Drilling
description: LONDON, July 11 (UPI)North Sea oilfield activity is at a new high, according to the London firm of. Eggar Forrester. The concern's index of field activity found no drilling .platforms were idle at the beginning of July. Good weather conditions in the spring and early summer have helped speed planned construction program, the firm said;

title: Excerpts From Statement
description: I am addressing you on a most sol emn and at the same time most grievous day of my life. A high honor is conferred on me which I appreciate very muchan international scientific conference held on the occasion of my 60th birthday.

title: Klan Leader Sues to Keep F.B.I. From Destroying Political Files
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 11 (AP)A Ku Klux Klan leader has asked a Federal court for an injunction to prevent the Federal Bureau of Investigation from destroying its files on private citizens who have been involved in political activity.

title: IERBERT CUTE, TEACHER AND WATERCOLORIST, 69
description: Herbert Gute, a watercolorist who taught at the Yale School of Fine Arts until his retirement in 1973, died Saturday in the Yale House Services Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that after four years of development it was ready to introduce a graphite motor oil product that said could save the nation's motorists million gallons of gasoline a day.

title: Dave Garcia
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 11 (UPI)The California Angels dismissed Norm Sherry as their manager today and hired the third base coach, Dave Garcia, to replace him.

title: Do Tell George Is Winner
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 11 (AP)Ralph Davis's Do Tell George, with an apprentice jockey, William Mize, scoring the first victory of his career, posted a surprising halflength victory in the feature allowance race at Monmouth Park..

title: Kohn's Dramatically Tilted Forms
description: WASHINGTON  Behind every personal style in art there is a history of other styles; other alternatives, that have been rejected or. transformed. The final result,. even, when most decisive, may rest on a history of indecisiveness.

title: Watkins Glen Weekend Reflects Declining State of Road.Racing
description: The Bog Lives, proclaimed the Tshirts at Watkins Glen, N. Y., but the infamous mud hole at the roadracing capital of the United States seemed to be suffering from the same ennui as the sport itself last weekend.

title: Newark Since 67 Riots: Hope and Despair
description: NEWARK, July 11Neglected Springfield Avenuethe battle corridor of the racial riots that began here 10 years ago tomorrowattests to that uprising and to this 311yearold city's deterioration. But Ferry Street, only a mile away, attests to its residential rebirth and commercial vitality.

title: Max Rheinstein, Law. Professor, 78
description: Max Rheinstein, professor emeritus of comparative law at the University of Chicago, which last year named a chair for him, died Saturday in Bad Gastein, Austria, where he was vacationing. He was 78 years old and had moved to Palo Alto, Calif.,. last December.

title: 12 Win $1.1 Million in Damages in 19 71 Blast in New Rochelle
description: WHITE PLAINS; July 11 (UPI)Twelsp persons were awarded S1.1 million today in a damage settlement arising from 1971 New Rochelle, N.Y., explosion and fire that blew apart two automobile dealerships, killed three people and injured 31.

title: Central Banks'
description: BASEL, Switzerland, July 11 (Reuters) Concern about sharp and rapid fluctuations in the foreign exchange market in recent weeks dominated the monthly meeting today of central bank governors, banking sources said. .

title: Tropicana and Kellogg Start Talks For aT hirdTime on Merger Accord
description: For the third time in a little over three years, two breakfast table namesTropicana and Kelloggare discussing a merger. The announcement came yesterday in a brief, 26word statement from Tropicana:

title: The Neutron Weapon
description: All nuclear weapons can kill. That ugly fact should be kept in mind in evaluations of the current argument over deployment of the socalled neutron warheadthe enhanced radiation weapon, in Pentagon parlance. An eminent Soviet physicist charges that the development of neutron weapons in the U.S.A. has exposed the true policy of the American Administration as antihumane and directed on a worldwide scale against the main human right, the right to life. The allegation, if seriously meant, applies with equal force to Soviet nuclear weapons, or those of any other country.

title: Counsel Criticizes Head of House Inquiry on Korea
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Philip A. Lacovara, special counsel to the House ethics committee, in a confidential memorandum to other members of the committee, has criticized its chairman, Representative John J. Flynt Jr., for his handling of the investigation of the Korean lobby, Consressional officials disclosed today.

title: Freshman Legislator Fast Becomes Jaded By Albany Routine
description: ALBANYClifford E. Wilson, who ceases being a freshman legislator any day now, has acquired some scars in the course of his maiden session, and he has already decided that his political future does not lie in the Assembly.

title: An Inquiry Into the Coming Excess
description: After many an artful dodge, our leaders have finally come clean about where they really stand on abortion. They are against it for poor people.

title: Revisions in NoFault Insurance Passed by New York Legislature
description: ALBANY, July 11The Republicancontrolled Senate tonight gave final passage, by the barest possible margin, to a revision of the state's nofault automobile insurance.

title: Laetrile User Dies
description: WALTHAM, Mass., July 11 (AP)A woman who went to court last month to win the right to use laetrile is dead of cancer. Victoria Assarian, 60, of Watertown, Mass., died of throat and lymph cancer Saturday night at Waltham Hospital after more than three weeks of treatment with the controversial drug, a hospital spokesman said. Middlesex Superior Court Judge Samuel Adams ordered the hospital to allow the treatments June 17.

title: Chinatown Mayor
description: Man Bun Lee, a prominent Chinatown businessman who has been aiding police efforts to combat youth gangs terrorizing the community, was critically wounded early yesterday by a young man who lured him out of a restaurant, attacked him with a knife and escaped.

title: 70 Held in Clashes at British Plant; Parliament Members Join Pickets
description: LONDON, July 11Seventy people were arrested in incidents of fighting outside a small photographprocessing plant today as nearly 4,000 policemen there confronted 11,000 pickets from around the country.

title: Racers, Without NewFunds, Bar Any Bid to Join N.H.L.
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 11 (UPI)Owners of the Indianapolis Racers announced today that the team would not be able to apply for membership in an expanded National Hockey League. David Givens, general counsel for Indiana National Bank, creditor of the team's assets, signaled the apparent demise of the Racers, who led the World Hockey Association in attendance last season.

title: Angels Drop Pro Football Violence Sherry, Pick Defendedin Slander Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 11Football is a form of legalized combat, said Willie L. Brown Jr., lawyer for George Atkinson of the Oakland Raiders, whose suit for slander against the Pittsburgh Steelers and Coach Chuck Noll began today.

title: ROY CRANE, 75, CREATED SEVERAL COMIC STRIPS
description: Roy Crane, the creator of such widely syndicated comic strips as Wash Tubbs, Captain Easy, Buzz Sawyer and Roscoe Sweeny, died Thursday at Orange Memorial Hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Orlando.

title: U.S. Cuts $327 Million From Estimated Cost of Westway Project
description: The Federal Highway Administration has deducted $327 million from the estimated $1.16 billion federally aided construction cost of Westway, with the result that New York City or the state could end up having to pay part of the difference for the planned new West Side superhighway.

description: WASHINGTON, July 11The House of Representative's Ethics Committee is investigating charges that Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of Brooklyn, tried to use public funds to put four women on a staff payroll so they could accompany him on trips overseas, sources close to the committee said yesterday.

description: The horse was trying to commit suicide. Horses do, you know. If a horse is suffering from pain it cannot tolerate, it will roll in its stall and slam its head against the wall until it's dead. And that's what Big Towner was trying to do until he was saved. title: Scarlet Rivera And John Mayall Are Off Beat
description: John Mayall, the seasoned exponent of English blues, and Scarlet Rivera, the violinist who made her mark in rock with Bob Dylan's band, led new groups at the Bottom Line on Sunday night. Their approaches were wildly divergent, but they did have one thing in common. Neither musician is working in a style compatible with the present rock mainstream.

title: Rise in Housing Aid for Northeast Is Spurned by Conferees in House
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Using terms like plunder and too much tilt to the Northeast, House conferees today rejected a Senate plan to add still more money for Northeastern cities in the new threeyear $12.4 billion housing and communitydevelopment program.

title: Federal Aide Urges Banning of Vehicles From Fire. Island
description: The Superintendent of the Fire Island National Seashore yesterday proposed regulations that would effectively ban the use of most motor vehicles on the island.

title: INITIATING OF LAWS BY PUBLIC PROPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  Senator James Abourezk. Democrat of South Dakota, introduced today a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow citizens to initiate Federal laws and enact them through a national election.

title: Carter's News Parley will Be on TV Today
description: President Carter will conduct a news conference in Washington at 2:30 P.M. today. It will be televised live by the CBS, NBC and ABC networks and their local stationsChannels 2, 4 and 7. The following local radio stations also have scheduled live coverage: WCBSAM, WINS, WMCA, WNBC and WNYCAM.

title: Dances of India Prove Dramatic OneMan Shows
description: NEW LONDON, Corm., July 11Long. ago, Western society dictated a separation between dance and drama, which has caused each to go its separate way, leaving mime as a sort of missing link between them. Eastern societies have never seen the need for such an enforced parting of the diciplines and have mingled the strains unselfconsciously throughout their history.

description: Federal bank regulators are conducting a comprehensive survey of banks overseas loans. The banks have been asked to report in August on their lending abroad. Page 41.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 11 (AP)A Los Angeles attorney said today that Carroll Rosenbloom, owner of the Los Angeles Rams, gave John Hadl $400,000 to consent to be traded to the Green Bay Packers in 1975.

description: HELSINKI, Finland, Tuesday, July 12 (AP)The last three hostages aboard a hijacked Soviet airliner slipped away from their captors early today, and a few hours later the two hijackers surrendered to Finnish authorities.

title: 6th Person In Mind
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI)Attor. ney General Griffin B. Bell said today that President Carter has a sixth person in the back of his mind for director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation none of the five current finalists proved to be satisfactory. He refused to identify the candidate when he emerged from the weekly Cabinet meeting at the White House and was questioned by reporters. The present director, Clarence M. Kelley, is retiring Jan. I.

title: Senate G.O.P. Balks on Bill to Bar Long. Beach Default
description: ALBANY, July 11The Senate Republicans, raising the stakes in their effort to get the Democrats to agree to give $40 million in state grants to upstate counties, are refusing to pass a technical bill that the City of Long Beach, L.I. needs to avert a default on Friday.

title: Attorneys for Chowchilla Defendants Seek to Suppress Evidence
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 11Attorneys for the three men accused of kidnapping 26 school children and their school bus driver in the central California town of Chowchilla a year ago this week said today at a pretrial hearing that they would fight to suppress 4,800 items of prosecution evidence.
