title: Blast Rocks School in Madrid
description: MADRID, Spain (AP)A powerful explosion rocked the French high school here today. Three persons were injured, one of them seriously, and damage was extensive, the police said. The students are on summer vacation.

title: 24Pacer Field Vying Tonight For $425,000
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 11The charge of the sulky brigade, the $425,000 Meadowlands Pace, finally moves into focus at this standardbred stronghold tomorrow night. The general feeling today was that all 24 horses scheduled to start would be at their appointed posts.

title: Iran Is Investing in Joint Ventures Around World
description: TEHERAN, IranIn joint ventures around the world Iran is popping upin an automotiveparts factory in Brazil, a new port in Senegal, a fertilizer plant in India, a textile mill in Egypt, a slaughter house in Australia.

title: Notes on People
description: Christina Onassis, the only surviving child of the late Aristotle Onassis, and her second husband, Alexandros Andreadis, have been granted a divorce in Athens. Both had filed petitions, but the Greek Orthodox Church intervened in an effort to effect a reconciliation. However, a spokesman for Mr. Andreadis's family said that the divorce, with civil and church sanctions, was granted Saturday. The Andreadises were married two years ago in Athens, not long after Mr. Onassis's death in March 1975, and separated a few months later. Christina, who inherited the bulk of her father's estate, had been married before, briefly, to Joseph Boker, a real estate operator in Los Angeles.

title: People in Sports
description: James Harris, the Los Angeles Rams quarterback who was traded to the San Diego Chargers last month after the Rams acquired Joe Namath, has signed a fiveyear contract with the Chargers. The pact is said to be for $170,000 a year, a sizable increase compared with his earnings during his five years with the Rams.

title: Areas Taken by Eritrean Rebels Show Wounds of 16 Years of War
description: TESSENEI, EthiopiaIn the Eritrean area that nationalist guerrillas have wrested from the Ethiopian Army, entire villages have been bombed and burned and nearly a million people have been displaced or turned into refugees.

title: Carter Asks Senate Unit to Waive Deadline on Lance's Sale of Stock

The President said that the deadline had contributed to a sub stantial artificial lowering of the stock's price.

description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI)  The United States Parole Commission granted today an early release to G. Gordon Liddy, who drew the longest sentence of any Watergate conspirator for refusing to discuss the scandal that toppled a President.

title: Dancing the Dan Patch TwoStep

Tobin the Swaps Stakes at Hollywood Park, but drew the applause his quality merits when he was paraded, before the Pacific Northwest breed of horseplayer at Longacres near the SeattleTacoma Airport. It remains to be seen how much, any, his pull as a drawing card and his value as a marketing commodity have been reduced by the first defeat of his life.

title: Ike Golf Won By Giacini In Playoff

title: DEATHPENALTY BILL IS VETOED BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, July 12Governor Carey, as he had promised repeatedly, today vetoed the broad deathpenalty bill passed by the Legislature last month. The bill would have restored capital punishment for all premeditated murders and most murders committed in connection with other crimes.

title: Soft Rock at Festival Lacks (Muscle) Tone
description: SOFT ROCK does not have to be flabby, but much of the music heard at the Dr. Pepper Festival in Central Park on Monday was badly in need of muscle tone. Firefall, the headliner, was the Poffender. The rhythm section sagged and the three, four and five part harmonies tended to waver in and out of tune. Only some guitarled raveups saved the day.

title: Film: Herzog's Pilgrims Hit the U.S. Road
description: WERNER HERZOG, the young German director of "The Mystery of Kasper Hauser," "The Great Ecstasy of the Sculptor Steiner" and "Aguirre, the Wrath of God," doesn't make movies that are easy to describe, "Kasper Hauser," Mr. Herzog's variation on the "wild child" story, is a beautiful, ghostly movie, a parable almost too refined for mortal comprehension.In his short film about Walter Steiner, Mr. Herzog demonstrates the ecstasy of the champion ski-jumper in sports footage so breathtakingly, we see doom in every triumph."Aguirre," about the mad, power-obsessed Spanish conquistador, is a meditation upon human futility photographed in Peru and Brazil in some of the world's most spectacular scenery. Among other things, Mr. Herzog visually dazzles us while he's pulling the rug from under our feet.In a Herzog film we have to keep checking what we are hearing against what we're seeing. They are seldom the same things, but forcing us to reconcile contradictions is one of the ways in which he works."Stroszek," which opened yesterday at the Cinema Studio, is described by Mr. Herzog as a ballad, which is probably as good a way as any to categorize it initially. It's a "road" picture. In some distant way it reminds me of "Easy Rider," but it's an "Easy Rider" without sentimentality or political paranoia. It's terrifically, spontaneously funny and, just as spontaneously, full of unexpected pathos."Stroszek" is the tale of three mismatched friendseach a loserwho set out from Berlin to find El Dorado in northern Wisconsin, in winter, with very little money and hardly any knowledge of English. It would be difficult to imagine three people less fit for such a journey.Scheitz (Clemens Scheitz) is in his 70's, small, frail, modest, a fellow who seems always to be suffering from a chill. Eva (Eva Mattes) is a buxom but none-to-bright Berlin streetwalker, the sort that pimps can beat up and double-cross endlessly without seriously damaging her dogged dependence on them.Most importantly there is Stroszek, played by Bruno S., the Berlin street musician who played the title role in "Kasper Hauser." Stroszek, 40-ish, is a worldly innocent who, when we first meet him, seems to be simple-minded. He is being released from prison by a not-unsympathetic warden who warns him to stay out of bars and to try to remember to shave and keep his fly zipped. It's not that Stroszek has tendencies. He simply doesn't pay attention to minor details. Something is missing from Stroszek, but what it is is not intelligence.As an actor, Bruno S. is a found object. Much of the tension of the early scenes of "Stroszek" is created by our attempting to fit Bruno S. into some normal scheme of things. Is he acting? Is he following Mr. Herzog's directions like a trained dog? Is he improvising, sometimes with immense wit? I suspect it must be a combination of all three.In whatever way the performance is created, it's an extraordinarily compelling one, and one that is virtually a physical manifestation of what the film is about. The Stroszek we get to know is a compassionate, patient, common-sensical man incapable of rage or physical assertiveness. This small, curious personality is imprisoned within a large, stocky, man-sized body that seems too big for him, a vehicle that can maneuver with only the utmost effort and concentration. When he glances around him, he looks like a child peering apprehensively out of the pilot's seat of a 747.The adventures of these three contemporary pilgrims as they attempt to settle into what they believe to be the American way of life are both bleak and uproariously funny. Eva, who works as a waitressfor a whileand Stroszek, who gets a job as a mechanic, buy a huge mobile home of an indescribably fancy awfulness. Scheitz, who appears to shrink even smaller in the Wisconsin cold, becomes politely disoriented and decides he has discovered the means to measure "animal magnetism" by using a conventional ammeter.Constantly working against Mr. Herzog's very cool view of the human condition is not only the humor"Stroszek" contains one of the shortest, funniest holdups I've ever seen in a moviebut also the physical beauty of the landscapes, the cityscapes and the squalid interiors. This visual lyricism, which at first seems at odds with the subject, eventually becomes a further celebration of Stroszek's survival.That the pilgrims must eventually be disappointed is a foregone conclusion, but the way it happens is anything but predictable. Among the dozens of images in the film I'll remember for a very long time is one near the end of a chicken that can't stop dancing and another of a premature baby, hardly bigger than a man's hand, whose capacity to hang on is nothing less than ferocious. It's this mixture of feelings and attitudes that gives the Herzog works their haunting lives.

description: AT A TIME when loudness seems to be the primary goal in the amplification of music, one must be grateful for an amplification system that does not assault the ears. But this reversal can be carried too far.

description: WASHINGTON, July 12  President Carter conceded today that denial of Federal aid for abortions could discriminate against poor women, but he said that there are many things in life that are not fair and that the Government should not attempt to make opportunities precisely equal when morality was at issue.

title: Canadian Unemployment Declines
description: OTTAWA, July 12, (Reuters)The number of unemployed persons in Canada dropped in June for the second successive month to a total of 814,000, Statistics Canada reported today. The Government agency said that while the actual number of persons without jobs declined in June, the unemployment rate when adjusted for seasonal variations was up slightly to percent, from 7.9 percent for May. In May, there were 824,000 unemployed and a year earlier there were 792,000.

title: Personal Health
description: ONE OF THE most frequent challenges presented to cancer spscialists these days concerns the unproven cancer drug, laetrile. When a doctor advises a patient against taking it, the rejoinder is likely to be, But how do you know it doesn't work? How can you be so sure?

Abzug traded broadsides yesterday on the first serious issue of the New York City Democratic mayoral primary campaign  Mrs. Abzug's assertion that policemen and firemen have a c stitutional right to strike and that the state's Taylor Law, barring strikes by civil servants, should be repealed.

title: P.O.W.'s Fear Traitor
description: GASH DISTRICT, EthiopiaThe prisonerofwar camp called Mogoraibe, next to a dry riverbed in this scorching lowland district of Eritrea, has no walls or guarded watchtowers to prevent escape, but the hundreds of captured Ethiopian soldiers it contains rarely try.

title: Pop: Betty Wright With Soul
description: BETTY WRIGHT, who performed at the Bottom Line on Monday and Tuesday, is one of the great soul singers. She was making millionselling singles as early as 1971, when she recorded Clean Up Woman while still in her teens. She received a Grammy last year for tier version or Where Is the Love? But unlike Aretha Franklin, Gladys Knight and Cissy Houston, who have applied their gospelrooted styles and impressive vocal equipment to pop and middleoftheroad material, Miss Wright has remained in the soul camp. She is a favorite of white soul aficionados, and black audiences know her, but she has yet to break into the mainstream.

title: New Statewide Program Seeks Reversal of Early, Compulsory Retirement
description: CHERRY HILL, July 12The director of New Jersey Work, Education and Leisure Initiative, the country's first statewide program aimed at determining how education, training and jobs can be more effectively linked, discussed today the possibility of an expansion of the working life of the state's labor force.

title: Israelis Bringing a List of Specific Mideast Proposals to Washington
description: JERUSALEM, July 12Prime Minister Menahem Begin is bringing a list of specific proposals to his first meeting with President Carter in Washington next week that he hopes will facilitate an IsraeliAmerican effort to convene direct peace talks between the Arabs and Israelis and end the Middle East stalemate.

description: SCARSDALE, July 12Richard James Herrin, the 23yearold man accused of bludgeoning to death Bonnie Joan Garland, told the upstate police officer who had *arrested him  that he had planned to kill his girlfriend and then commit suicide, the policeman said at a hearing today.

title: $100,000 Given For Free Press Committee
description: The Frank E. Gannett Newspaper Foundation has contributed $100,000 to the World Press Freedom Development Committee, which is trying to raise $1 million. The committee was formed earlier this year as an effort to head off a trend among underdeveloped countries toward increased government control of publishing and broadcast facilities. The chairman of the executive committee is Jack R. Howard, chairman of the executive committee of ScrippsHoward Newspapers. Other members include executives. of major newspaper and broadcast companies in the United States.

title: The Boeing Shuffle and the Shah
description: The Carter Administration proposes to sell Iran seven enormously expensive radar aircraft, running great risks for just one reason: to enable the United States Air Force to buy some too. The risks are that Soviet spies could gain easier access to some of the most secret and sophisticated American tecnnology and that American personnel could become hostages to the service of those craft in Iran. The only immediate benefit is that if Iran buys three aircraft a year, Boeing will keep open its production line and deliver three others to the Air Force as well.

description: CINCINNATI, July 12 (UPI)Harold Solomon made quick work of Francisco Gonzales, 61, 62, as firstround play continued today in the $100,000 Western tennis championships.

title: Retail Sales Down in June For Third Straight Month
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)Consumer purchasing dipped in June for the third consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the most serious signal yet that the economy may be headed for a significant slowdown in months ahead.

description: The financially pressed New York Public Library is turning to a fundraiser and to a foundation executive to give new thrust to a languishing $52 million capital fund drive begun in 1975.

description: LONDON, July 12, (Reuters)A private bill to ban compliance by British companies with foreign trade boycotts such as that maintained by Arab states against Israel was introduced in Parliament today.

title: YOUTH, 19, PLEADS GUILTY IN SLAYING OF CAB DRIVER
description: George Adorno, 19 years old, of 215 West 111th Street, pleaded guilty yesterday to murdering Steven Robinson, college student who was working as cab driver, last Feb. 23.

description: DUDLEY, Mass., July 11 Joe Nemeth sits under a tree and talks of wanting his life to be mellow, but he realizes that in a few days he is, again, going to be a center of controversy.

title: Family Waiting in Bleakness For a City Approval to Move
description: The heat and hot water went off seven months ago in the Coney Island home of Mr. and Mrs. Juan Lopez at 1910 Mermaid Avenue, and the stove in the nearly abandoned building no longer works. The family has a nicer apartment a tew blocks awaywhich a concerned neighbor helped findwhere there is heat, hot water and working stove, but the Lopezes cannot get approval from the welfare department to move.

description: There will be a Borough of Queens Day at the United States Open at Forest Hills in September. Four Queens players who have distinguished themselves this year will be honored: Vitas Gerulaitis; his sister Ruta; John McEnroe and Mary Carillo.

description: When Judge. Carmelo J. Tavormina called Carl Johnson to come forward yesterday in Brooklyn Criminal Court to be sentenced for possession of stolen property, a misdemeanor, Mr. Johnson's brother and sister, who were in the courtroom, shook their. heads. It wasn't their brother.

Officials said Mr. Carter had privately sought these gestures to improve the climate for Middle East negotiations.

description: CINCINNATI, July 12Dr. George B. Barbour, internationally known geologist and educator, died in his sleep last night. He was 86 years old.

description: Kmart, in a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission, agreed to forbid its collection agencies to file haddebt suits in courts far from the homes of defendants.

title: Black Pupils a Plurality in Boston
description: BOSTON, July 12 (AP)Black students outnumber whites in Boston public schools for the first time. Statistics based on student assignment applications for the fall term show registration of 28,385 blacks, 27,678 whites, 6,737 HispanicAmericans, 1,944 Orientals and 286 American Indians.

title: French Bicyclist Is First
description: ROUBAIX, France, July 12 (AP)JeanPierre Danguillaume of France won today's 11th stage of the Tour de France ,bicycle race over 150.7 miles from Rouen in another sprint finish in the Roubaix velodrome. Danguillaume finished the stage in 7 hours 7 minutes 10 seconds. Leading the tour standing was Dietrich Thurau of Germany in 68 hours 28 minutes 16 seconds, followed by Eddie Merckx of Belgium, 51 seconds behind.

title: Health Food Store Butters
description: Alta Dena  Made in California of certified raw cultured cream that is churned. Available at several health food stores; my sample was purchased at Down to. Earth, 33B Seventh Avenue, near 12th Street. It is an extraordinary, almost white uncolored butter .and: one that buffs should try. Definitely sour and as thick as homemade ice cream on the tongue, with just a faint flavor and aroma of newmown hay, it has so much flavor it would not pass unnoticed on any table. Seemed to have a very high fat content considering its emolliency; I have a feeling it would make excellent sauces and puff paStry. I would rate it very good, even at $3.12 a pound.

title: Shadowy Look At Patriotism
description: AS A POLITICAL DRAMATIST, Manuel Perez, the writerdirector of The Man From Maisinicu, the Cuban featurethat opened at the Jean Renoir Theater yesterday, is forthright in his dedication to Fidel Castro's Marxism, but confusingly elliptical in dramatizing it. The aims and politics of the man from Maisinicu may be properly shrouded in mystery, but the tortuous flashbacks and flashforwards on the violent road he travels tend to obscure rather than spotlight the film's heroes and villains and their goals,

description: WASHINGTON, July .12 (AP)The Federal agency charged with protecting the civil rights of minority workers has adopted a narrow interpretation of a Supreme Court ruling on seniority systems in employment discrimination.

title: Two Colorado Forests Burning
description: CRAIG, Colo., July 12 (UPI)  Two forest fires fanned by gusty winds burned out of control across nearly 1,200 acres of land in northwest Colorado today. Officials of the Bureau of Land Management doubted that they would be able to bring the blazes quickly under control.

title: A Growing Flotilla Of Industrial Cargoes Moving Up Hudson
description: ALBANYWhen the Erie Canal opened in 1825, the Hudson River here became the waterway from the southern part of the state that helped unlock the way to the Middle West. Today, it is unlocking a way to maritime trade and industrial commerce never envisioned a century and a half ago.

title: Merrill and Hutton Show Profit Drops
description: Battling against a drop in brokerage fees and a rise in operating costs, the parent companies of Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith and E. F. Hutton & Company, two of the nation's leading stock brokers, reported yesterday that secondquarter profits were down.

title: LEO MEISSNER, 82, KNOWN FOR WOOD ENGRAVINGS
description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., July 12Leo Meissner, former art director for Motor Boating magazine and an artist known for his wood engravings, died yesterday while driving in Portland. He was 82 years old.

title: Simon Joins Board Of Interpublic Group
description: William E. Simon, Secretary of the Treasury in both the Nixon and  Ford Administrations, was elected to the board of the Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday. He was also chairman of the Economic Policy Board under President Ford.

title: Business Executives Ask Tax Shifts
description: The Business Roundtable, a group of chief executives of the nation's major cornpaniq, called yesterday for a permanent cut in the corporate tax rate and elimination of double taxation on dividends.

title: Your Honor, I Plead With You for My Son
description: Your Honor:

title: Carrie Didn't Get Carrie
description: CARRIE FISHER, hot but not a blazing star, home but not quite at home now, is wondering where to fit herself in. She is staying temporarily at the Sherry Netherland because her West Side apartment is messy and the hotel isn't. Riding high with Star Wars, she is living through an unremitting publicity stint that demands suites and accompanies successful movies. She tells outrageous stories on local television talk shows to relieve the tedium of traveling from town to town. Everywhere, every day, she is asked about science fiction and special cinematic effects.

title: Alvin Zakin Dies in New York; Founded Advertising Company
description: Alvin Zakin of New York, founder and president of Zakin Company Advertising, died of cancer Monday in New York )4osnital. He was 53 years old.

title: Tigers Win
description: Mark Fidrych, the star righthander of the Detroit Tigers, threw just 15 pitches against the Toronto Blue Jays in Tiger Stadium last night, then left the mound complaining of a sore shoulder.

title: Pump Station Loss To Cut Delivery Of Alaska Oil 400,000 Barrels Dail
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 12The loss of a pump station on the Trans Alaska Pipeline will cut by 400,000 barrels a day the delivery of oil from the Alaska Arctic until repairs are made, a spokesman for the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company said today.

title: Mergers in First Half Declined 16% to 1,061
description: W. T. Grimm & Company, Chicagobased merger specialists, said yesterday that merger announcements in the first six months of the year had declined 16 percent to 1,061 but that the size of individual mergers had grown.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Environmentalists and New York City officials offered differing testimony at a City Council hearing on pollution problems. Robert A. Low, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, told the Council's Committee on Environmental Protection that the city's air quality had improved markedly in recent years and that the main airpollution problem involved carbon monoxide.

title: Phelps Dodge Elects L. W. Seidman to Post
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation announced yesterday that L. William Seidman, former assistant to the President for economic affairs in the ad ministration of former President Gerald R. Ford, has been elected a director and will also join the company as a senior vice president.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: CORRECTIONS

title: The Symbolism of the Breeder
description: During the years when it was feared that the world Would soon run short of uranium to fuel nuclear power plants, the breeder reactor became a symbol of modern technological magic. It would, using plutonium instead of uranium, not only make energy but would at the same time breed more plutonium fuel. Recently, as estimates of uranium supply have risen and projections of uranium demand have dropped, the breeder reactor has become, instead, an ominous symbol. Plutonium, unlike uranium, is easy to convert from fuel into weapons. As long as uranium remains plentiful, it seems reckless to encourage the manufacture of plutonium lest it fall into the hands of militarists or terrorists.

title: Caterpillar Tractor Posts 10.7% Profit Rise in Quarter
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the world's largest producer of earthmoving equipment, reported yesterday profit increases of 10.7 percent for the second quarter and 3.9 percent for the halfyear, following a year of earnings declines.

title: PROSECUTOR DENIES BEAME AIDE'S CLAIM

title: GreatGrandson of Kaiser Dies After Being Hurt on Maneuvers
description: BREMEN, West Germany, July 12 (AP) Prince Louis Ferdinand Christian Oskai of Prussia, a greatgrandson of the lasi German Kaiser, died late last night frorr injuries received during military maneu vers, a spokesman for the Hohenzollerr family said. The prince was 32 years old, The apprentice officer was injured when he was caught between two armored vehicles when they were loaded onto freight cars in Northern Germany two months ago. He was taken to Bremen hospital where one of his legs was amputated.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Moscow dispatch yesterday incorrectly stated that the late Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer was denied the chance to continue working as a nuclear physicist after he lost his security clearance as a result of a political investigation instigated by the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. Actually, Dr. Oppenheimer's clearance WRS suspended by the Atomic Energy Commission after a series of A.E.C. hearings, and he continued work afterwards as a nuclear physicist at Institute for Advanced Study in Princoton, N.J.

title: BANKING BY COMPUTER FOUND PRIVACY PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The Privacy Protection Study Commission reported today that an experimental electronic banking project now operated with the computer of the Federal Reserve System could develop into an unparalleled threat to personal privacy.

title: Make Concordes, Not War
description: LONDONAfter all the passionate arguments on ochalf of the Concorde, the most important case, I believe, has not yet been stated (perhaps because it would embarrass AngloFrench diplomats). It is this. Whatever the extravagance, the wastefulness and environmental danger of the plane, it is much less harmful than the likely alternativea much greater pressure to sell weapons abroad.

title: United Merchants, Citing Losses, Files Voluntary Bankruptcy Action
description: In 1977's largest bankruptcy action, forced by losses at its Robert Hall Clothes chain, United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., yesterday filed for protection under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, listing debts of $381 million.

title: Elevator Repairmen Strike
description: CHICAGO, July 12 (UPI)The International Union of Elevator Constructors, which represents 1,500 elevator repairmen and installers in the Chicago area, has struck the Westinghouse Elevator Company. The union began selective

title: Cost of Concorde Vibration Gauge Is Put at $500,000 to $1 Million
description: A leading noise expert testified yesterday that it would take six to 12 months, and between $500,000 and $1 million, to devise a vibration standard that officials might use to decide whether the Concorde should be allowed to use Kennedy International Airport.

title: Hope for Rhodesia Accord Dwindles
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 12 (Reuters)Hopes of a peaceful Rhodesian settlement dwindled today when black and white leaders made flatly contradictory demands.

title: OKLAHOMA BUSINESSMEN PLEAD GUILTY ON FRAUD
description: Three Oklahoma businessmen pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to fraud charges in a Federal indictment that accused them of defrauding the Chemical Bank and others of more than $5 million.

title: PAROLE BILL IS VOTED IN ALBANY BY SENATE
description: ALBANY, July 12A bill requiring firm guidelines for granting parole to prisoners and giving independence to the State Division of Parole was passed unanimously by the New York Senate today. The action, removing the parole agency from the Department of torrectIon, came as the Legislature faltered toward final adjournment, possibly later this week.

title: PRESIDENT REPORTS CONCILIATORY STEPS BY SADAT ON ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 12President Carter, preparing for talks next week with Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel, disclosed today that President Anwar elSadat of Egypt had made conciliatory gestures. Officials said Mr. Carter had privately sought these gestures to improve the climate for MiddleEast negotiations.

title: Carter Asks Senate Unit to Waive Deadline on Lance's Sale of Stock
description: ATLANTA, July 12President Carter has asked the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee to free Bert Lance, head of the Office of Management and Budget, from his pledge to sell all of his stock in the National Bank of Georgia by the end of.this year. The President said that the deadline had contributed to a substantial artificial lowering of the stock's price.

title: Orantes Wins in Comeback
description: KITZBUHEL, Austria, July 12 (UPI) Manuel Orantes of Spain, playing in his first tournament since undergoing elbow surgery five weeks ago, narrowly defeated the hardhitting ADstralian, Paul Kronk, 67, 76, 75, in the first round of a $75,000 Grand Prix clay court tournament today. Kronk led by 53 in the final set.

title: About Real Estate
description: Blue Hill Office Complex in Rockland Is Now Attracting Tenants

title: Carter and Labor Back a 35c Rise To Make the Minimum Wage $2.65
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The Carter Administration and organized labor reached a compromise agreement today to support a 35centanhour increase in the minimum wage this year, raising it to $2.65.

title: Careers

title: I.C.C. SAYS ALASKA PIPELINE CAN SUBMIT NEW RATES
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 12 (AP)The Interstate Commerce Commission's special counsel for pipelines says owner companies of the transAlaska pipeline can submit new tariff rate proposals because of the explosion last week that destroyed Pump Station No. 8.

title: Morgan Stanley Plans to Merge With Shuman, Agnew
description: Marking its first step into the retail stock brokerage business, Morgan Stanley & Company, the big New York investment banking house, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to merge with Shuman, Agnew & Company, a West Coast brokerage firm.

Minnesota dairy cooperative contains no coloring and is a pale, creamy white with a neutral sweet cream flavor. It was the most consistent of the lot. An added benefit: Because of its packaging, it is the least likely to take on foreign odors and flavors. Tastes wonderfully light and creamy when melted. Excellent.

title: Iran Joins in Bid for 78 Oil Price Freeze
description: STOCKHOLM, July 12Iran, traditionally an oil price hawk, joined Saudi Arabia today In calling for a price freeze during 1978, citing doubts about the economic health of the Western industrial nations.

title: FIGHTS AT SAN QUENTIN LEAVE 3 DEAD, 5 HURT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 (AP)Three convicts were killed and five were injured in racial fighting among inmates at San Quentin prison today, the authorities said.

title: Notes on People
description: The new president of National Public Radio is Frank F. Man kiewicz, who was press secretary to Room F. Kennedy at the time of his assassination and later Presidential campaign director for Senator George McGovern. Mr. Mankiewicz, who will also serve as vice chairman of the agency's board of directors, will earn $65,000 a year. He recently wrote a syndicated column with Tom Braden and has worked for Washington radio and television stations, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, British Broadcasting Corporation, and the European Broadcast Union.

title: Randolph Homers as Yanks Win
description: MILWAUKEE, July 12Don Gullett and Mike Torrez are two Yankee pitchers who have shied away from the squabbles, politics and ego clashes that have dominated the team's season.

title: Moscow Charges Toth Accepted Assignments From. U.S. Agencies
description: MOSCOW, July 12The Soviet Union today accused Robert C. Toth, former Moscow correspondent of The Los Angeles Times, of having received assignments from unspecified American special agencies.

It can scarcely be stated too often that in the interest of good cookingwhether it requires less than an hour or The better part of a weekendorganization is i primary consideration. It is, of course, more vital to do what must be r.ailed hasty cookery. Assemble the ingredients for a dish, chop what must be chopped, shred what must be shredded, measure what must be measured and relax. This will make you flexible, and flexibility yields to dexterity. With all the ingredients at your disposal, ready for a skillet or pot, you can work on alternate dishes with facility

title: France II Gets Her Feet Wet
description: NEWPORT, R. 1., July 12 (AP)France II, one of two French 12Meter yachts bidding for the challenger's role in the America's Cup competition, took its first sail in United States waters today, The yacht, owned by Baron Marcel

title: Yacht Phantom Finishes Los AngelesHawaii Run
description: HONOLULU, July 12 (UPI)The 66foot yacht Phantom out of Los Angeles became the sixth finisher of the Los AngelesHonolulu TransPacific race today. She breezed across the Diamond Head finish line at 6:59 A.M. for an elapsed time of 9 days 20 hours 59 minutes 2 seconds in the 2,225mile race.

title: No Fault, but Some Warts
description: ALBANY, July 12When Governor Carey unveiled his proposal to revise the nofault automobile insurance system in April, it was touted as a plan to cut premiums by onethird within two years.

title: NewYorkers, etc.
description: BY ANY objective standards, we are going kaput, which means down the drain, out the tube, and into a terminal discomfort. Even the Department of Sanitation is saying that some of our streets are filthy, while the Fire Department freely admits that it must be so judicious in answering alarms that some of the alarms don't 2et answered at all. The taxis no longer have springs, and comes 8 P.M. the storekeepers along mactison and Lexington Avenues bolt the doors, drop the gates, and get the hell home before the Huns come on them under cover of darkness.

title: U.S. Directs That Poverty Aides Be Narned Rather Than Elected
description: The director of the Federal Community Service Agency has told Mayor Beame to provide for the selection of poverty representatives through appointment by existing local antipoverty organizations rather than:by election.

title: Penn National Dispute Ends
description: GRANTVILLE, Pa., July 12 (UPI)Thoroughbred racing at Penn National Race Course will resume tomorrow night following settlement of a dispute that halted racing for six days. Lieut. Gov. Ernest Kline intervened to help settle the dispute, which involved a demand by horsemen that the track's security director be discharged and which led to the horsemen's boycotting the facility for six racing days.

title: Backers of Laetrile Charge a Plot Is Preventing the Cure of Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The leaders of the laetrile movement took their crusade to legalize the purported anticancer, drug to a Senate hearing today, charged that an international conspiracy was preventing the cure of cancer and heard theInselves called purveyors of false hopes.

title: Committee Approves Blyn as Surrogate
description: ALBANY, July 12The Senate Judiciary Committee, after an unusual week's delay, voted tonight to confirm Judge Arthur E. Blyn of the New York City Civil Court to be the new surrogate of New York County. The nomina tion will go to the fulr Senate tomorrow, where heated debate is possible, although Judge Blyn is expected to be confirmed.

title: Law Places Few Curbs on Tactics Bail Bondsmen Use to Catch Skips
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 12 (AP)Like modern day bounty hunters, bail bondsmen seek out their wayward Clients and haul them back to jail, often without respect to state lines.

title: C.I.A. FRONT COMPANY SOLD FOR FAR UNDER NET WORTH
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)The Central Intelligence Agency sold one of its front companies for $1.5 million less than its net worth, Government documents show.

title: Apples Polished for Virginia Wade
description: Virginia Wade, the Wimbledon champion, was welcomed back to New York yesterday with a party at Cleo's restaurant across from Lincoln Center. The Apples, for whom she plays in World Team Tennis, provided an 18by24inch cake with red icing that read, Congratulations, Virginia, Welcome Home Little Apple.

title: Spain Devalues Peseta by 24.9% To Curb Inflation
description: MADRID, July 12Spain devalued the peseta by 24.9 percent today to control inflation and spur exports, a move that will prove a boon to tourists. The Government allowed the peseta to float downward to its new rate.

title: Housewares Show Opens In Chicago
description: CHICAGO, July 12  The 67th semiannual trade show of the National Housewares Manufacturers Association opened yesterday in the McCormick Place Exhibition Hall, and before the show ends Thursday, 60,000 visitors are expected to view the wares of 1,502 exhibitors spread out over 725,000 square feet.

title: Officials in Finland End Secrecy On Hijackers of Soviet Jetliner
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 12 (AP)Hours after the two hijackers of a Soviet airliner had surrendered here, Finland today for the first time made public their identities and other closely held details of the incident.

title: Mrs. Abzug's Opponents Denounce Defense of Right of Police to Strike
description: Mayor Beame and Bella S. Abzug traded broadsides yesterday on the first serious issue of the New York City Democratic mayoral primary campaign  Mrs. Abzug's assertion that policemen and firemen have a constitutional right to strike and that the state's Taylor Law, barring strikes by civil servants, should be repealed.

title: Comment on Inequities Recalls Kennedy View
description: WASHINGTON, July 12President Carter's comment today about inequities in life brought to mind a similar remark, in different circumstances, made 15 years earlier by President Kennedy.

title: DEATHPENALTY BILL IS VETOED BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, July l.Governor Carey, as he had promised repeatedly, today vetoed the broad deathpenalty bill passed by the Legislature last month. The bill would have restored capital punishment for all premeditated murders and most murders committed in connection with other crimes.

title: Carter and Labor Back a 35c Rise To Make the Minimum Wage $2.65
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The Carter Administration and organized labor reached a compromise agreement today to support a 35centanhour increase in the minimum wage this year, raising it to $2.65.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 (Cunard). Lett Southampton July 9; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Talks on Indochina Refugees Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 12A key House Democrat called on President Carter today to convene an international conference on Indochinese refugees, but he avoided taking a position on whether the Administration should approve a State Department proposal to admit 15,000 of them on an emergency basis.

title: Judson Poets
description: The Judson Poets Theater will present Camp Meeting, a new version of Al Carmines's Camp Meeting 1840, which was given as an oratoric last spring at the Judson Memorial Church.

title: Carter Says Deregulation of Gas Would Add $70 Billion to Costs
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  President Carter today assailed proponents of the theory that deregulation of newly produced natural gas would cost little or nothing, deepening the controversy over how much removal of price controls would cost.

title: Henderson Clout Beats Cubs for Matlack, 42
description: An unwed rookie and a veteran getting his game back together added up to a 42 victory for the Mets over the firstplace Chicago Cubs last night at Shea Stadium.

title: 3 States Vary on Abortion Ruling
description: The three states in the metropolitan area have reacted in a variety of ways to the Supreme Court decision that said states were not required to pay for elective abortions.

title: Dallas Paper Names Publisher
description: DALLAS, July 12 (UPI)Lee J. Guittir president and general manager of The Detroit Free Press, will become publishe and chief operating officer of The DengTimes Herald on Aug. 8. Mr. Guittar, 46 years old, will succeed Tom Johnson who will become president Of The Los kngeles Times Aug. 1.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)The McDonald's Corporation and glass manufacturers filed suit today against Massachusetts officials who said that promoional glasses distributed by the hamburger chain could pose a health hazard from lead contamination.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 35yearold woman in Hackensack. whose twostory house has been used for six years as an informal shelter for socalled battered wives was permanently blocked by a Bergen County Court judge from allowing more than eight persons to live in the house.

description: BASEBALL

title: W. J. HOBBS IS DEAD AT 73; FORMER COCACOLA CHIEF
description: William J. Hobbs, a former president of the CocaCola Company, died yesterday at Kennestone Hospital in Marietta, Ga., following a lengthy illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Texaco Offers Gas Settlement
description: Texaco Inc., accused by the Federal Power Commission of improperly diverting offshore gas supplies from the interstate market to its own refinery, said yesterday it had filed a motion to resolve the issue. Without admitting any illegal activities, the company proposed to stop transporting offshore gas from Federal leased areas for steam generation at its Port Arthur, Tex., refineryprovided an incentive option was given to convert the steam equipment to other fuels. Texaco also proposed a sharp cutback in deliveries from the leases involved for other uses at the Port Arthur facility and commitment to put not less than 200 billion cubic feet of reserves into the pricecontrolled interstate market within six months.

title: Oils Dominate a Cautious Market; Dow, at 903.41, Loses 2.12 Points
description: Petroleum shares dominated a cautious market yesterday as traders focused on the meeting of oilexporting countries in Sweden and the debate over naturalgas deregulation in Washington as well as news of the extent of the damage to the Alaska pipeline.

title: J. P. Morgan and Mellon National Show Gains in Operating Profit
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, which operates the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, reported yesterday an 11.3 percent gain in secondquarter operating earnings.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 12Environmentalists said today that a court ruling yesterday upholding a permit to build another nuclear generating power plant in the state had all but destroyed the Coastal Area Facility Review Act, which Was passed several years ago to protect the New Jersey coast.

title: Chess:
description: An Unknown Becomes Known And Moves Up in the Ranks

description: Does Change Always Mean Displacement?

description: Dow Index vs. the Other Averages

title: Rhodesian Rebels Disrupt Outing
description: SHANGANI, Rhodesia, July 12 (AP)Black nationalist guerrillas opened fire at a recreation club barbecue late yesterday, killing two black men and wounding three white children, two other black men and a black nursemaid, club members said today. They said the guerrillas, who escaped, had opened fire MUM CILISK with automatic rifles. Other attackers struck at two gasoline stations, holding up the attendants, and looted a store.

title: Ruling Due In KnickNet Court Case
description: A Federal Judge will decide today whether his court in Newark would retain jurisdiction in the dispute over the Nets intended move to New Jersey. The Knicks have opposed the Nets shift from Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., claiming they are protected for a 75mile area under a $4million indemnification agreement the Nets had signed with them when the Nets joined the National Basketball Association in June 1976. The Nets have challenged the wording of the agreement.

title: E.P.A. to Join Lawsuits Seeking To Reduce Pollution by T.V.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would join lawsuits against the Tennessee Valley Authority seeking to make the utility reduce sulfur dioxide emissions from 10 power plants in three states.

title: Carter Aides Voice Deep Concern On Conditions in Western Europe
description: WASHINGTON, July 12At the highest level or the Carter Administration, officials are expressing deep concern over what they see as a political and economic deterioration in many Western European countries.

title: Whipped HandPacked Butters
description: With one exception, all those sampled seemed so similar it was hard to believe all did not originate at the same creamery. Both the J. J. Farms Creamery in Ozone Park, Queens, and the Farmstead Dairy in Roselle, N. J., said they packed several and did the whipping but did not make the butter. This was received from dairies all over the country, just as is done with more standard types of butter. None were officially graded. Whipped butter spreads more evenly and has a sweet flavor because it is diluted with air. More by volume is required in recipes because of the air.

title: Carter Says He Backs Production of Neutron Arms
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  President Carter, calling the use of nuclear weapons a horrifying prospect, said today that he supported production of the controversial neutron warhead but had not yet decided whether to deploy the weapon.

title: TOP GENERAL SAYS ISRAEL MAY YIELD OCCUPIED LAND
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, July 12 (UPI)Ierael's Chief of Staff, Gen. Mordechai Gur, said today that Israel was ready to give up occupied Arab land for peace despite an Arab military buildup that included three new airfields along Saudi Arabia's northern border.

title: Moderate Black Leaders Rejecting Vorster Policy
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 11The South African Government's latest moves in its policy of offering limited political rights to blacks are foundering on the resistance of the very people who are supposed to make the Policy workmoderate leaders in black urban centers like Soweto, and tribal leaders in the rural homelands.

title: U.S. Rules Out Plan to Purchase Opium to Keep It Out of Markets
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The Carter Administration rejected today a proposal that the United States or the United Nations spend $36 million over six years to buy and destroy the Southeast Asian opium crop to prevent it from reaching American and foreign markets.

title: Suit Claims Decision on Aliens Deprived Farm Workers of Jobs
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., July 12 (AP)The Texas Rural Legal Aid has filed suit on behalf of 29 migrant farmworkers, claiming they were deprived of jobs because Mexican laborers were allowed to work in the Presidio Valley.

title: Draths
description: ADLERHorace Nat. The Officers, Board of Directors and Members of the Young Men's Philanthropic League are deeply saddened to announce the Passing of Mr. Horace Net Adler, sonInlaw of our dear member, Irving Streit. All of us at the League extend our sincerest condolences. to the family.

title: Canada Is Expected To Resume Sending Uranium to Europe
description: OTTAWA, July 12Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany said today that he and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau had reached agreement on an arrangement for temporarily lifting Canadian embargo on supplying Western European countries with uranium ore.

title: 4 in Eritrea Tell How War Has Engulfed Their Lives
description: BARKA DISTRICT, EthiopiaA dedicated doctor, a peasant with a bomb lishelter, a 14yearold fighter, an Italian ving alone in a deserted hotelthese are some of the people of Eritrea whose lives have been altered by a war for indeoendence nearly 16 years old.
