title: KATHARINE FROLINE PRIOR
description: Mrs. Howard A. Prior, who under the name of Katharine Froline Prior was faslYion reporter and editor on Women's Wear Daily, died July 7 in Frederich, Ind. She was 69 years old. Besides her husband, she is survived by a son, Dennis; brother, Dr. William C. Froline. and two sisters, Nancy F. Stephenson and Joan F. Abbott.

title: U.S. Acts to Foreclose Brooklyn Project's Mortgage
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has begun court action to foreclose a $9.5 million mortgage on Noble Drew Ali Plaza I, a major housing project in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, amid reports of an investigation into the management of the project.

title: Best Buys
description: FRUITS and vegetables are not only this week's most alluring buys; they're also the foods that have shown steep declines in price since the beginning of June.

title: Disclosure System Of S .E.C. Supported
description: WASHINGTON, July 12After a 17month investigation of the Securities and Exchange Commission's corporate disclosure system, a blue ribbon advisory panel has concluded that the system of disclosure works well and should not be radically altered.

title: Files Shows Summa Chief Balked At Discussing Hughes's Medication
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12 (AP)John Holmes, director of the late Howard B. Hughes's Summa Corporation has refused to answer questions about medication taken by the industrialist, according to documents filed yesterday in Superior Court.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHATEVER HAPPENED to Youth? The pangs of adolescence, the torrents of spring? Has the sturm und drang blown over? Has the politicization of the 60's made it obsoleteor the Vietnam War, irrelevant? Or now has it retreated into careerism or drugs? Or been renounces in exchange fur the peace of mind of Jesus or even the Rev. Sun Myung Moon?

title: Black Colleges Called Unafraid of Integration
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI)Historicaliy black colleges don't feel threatened and are not afraid of courtordered desegregation in six Southern states, representatives of 107 black colleges said today.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
description: (Includes races of July 12)

title: UNION REQUEST TO REOPEN MINERS' PACT IS REJECTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 13(UPI)Bituminous coal mine operators rejected a request by the President of the United Mine Workers, Arnold R. Miller, to reopen their existing contract to discuss a recent cutback in health benefits for miners.

title: RingingDoorbells Day and Night InCeaselessHunt Of Son of Sam
description: When the 8 P.M.to5 A.M. detective shift begins in a tworoom office at the 109th Precinct station in Flushing, queens, a day's clues have already piled upreports from astrologers, neighbors, patrolmen, parole officers and cranks.

title: DeCiphering Workers
description: WASHINGTONThe union contract dogs not cover most personal problems workers face. Even those agreements which provide fringe benefits, such as insurance coverage for health care, do not deal with the real and often tragic family needs of employees in the interrelated worlds of the home and the workplace. Yet it is those human problems that often affect production and labormanagement relations.

title: KATHARINE FROLINE PRIOR
description: Mrs. Howard A. Prior, who under the, name of Katharine Froline Prior was a fashion reporter and editor on Women's Wear Daily, died July 7 in Frederich, Ind. She was 69 years old. Besides her husband, she is survived by a son, Dennis; a brother, Dr. William C. Froline. and two sisters, Nancy F. Stephenson and Joan F. Abbott.

title: Topics
description: DEATH AND BIRTH  Sometimes acts of political decency are obscured by the cynicism that surrounds much of public life. New Yorkers ought to pierce that fog and gaze admiringly upon two recent acts by their Governor and their junior United States Senator. The Governor vetoed, as promised, the death penalty bill despite the pressures arrayed against that decision. He took the course dictated by his conscience and spoke good sense when he said that the death penalty Is no proven deterrent to crime We must have the stamina to take the hard road of Improving and perfecting the everyday administration of criminal justice.

title: 1977, a Year of Weather Extremes, Causing Concern Among Experts
description: HOUSTON, July 13The year began with a blizzard of superlatives: It was among the coldest winters tin history in the East, the driest in the West. People froze in New York, tomatoes glaciated in Florida,. streams ??n dry in Oregon and bears sweated in Alaskain January.

title: DR. FRANK L. ALLAN
description: NEWTON. Mass., July 13 (AP)Frank N. Allan, an internationally known recearcher in diabetes, died at his home here yesterday. He was 78 years old.

title: Books: Ralletomania
description: Balletomania is a lover's declaration to the world and like all such missives, it is full of superlatives, hyperbole and purple passages. But, written 43 years ago, it remains unsurpassed in infectious enthusiasm, passionate advocacy and informed judgment.

title: Ways and Means Unit Passes Program of Energy Taxation
description: WASHINGTON, Jury 13 (AP) The House Ways and Means Committee have float approval today to the energy tax program, which includes higher price for fuel and for gasguzzling cars.

title: STATES URGED TO USE U.S. SAFETY PROGRAM
description: CHERRY HILL N. J. July 13The Federal Government urged the states today to take advantage of a new Federal program to protect public employees against health and accident hazards.

title: Ethics Chairman Scores Charge Scheuer Kept a Mistress on Staff
description: WASHINGTON. July 13 (AP)The chairman of the House Ethics Committee said today that news accounts accusing Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of Queens of having a paid mistress on his staff earlier this year were grossly inaccurate.

title: Custodian Suspended
description: The Board of Education suspended school custodian without pay on charges of neglect of duty and insubordination for refusing to permit an audit.

title: Ballet: Neumeier's Dream Is a Rouser
description: HAMBURG, West Germany WE have had George Balanchine's A Midsummer Night's Dream and Frederick Ashton's The Dream. And that, one would have thought, would have been that. Shakespeare has already had this particular comedy translated into dance by the two greatest choreographers of the 20th century: not to mention a classic staging of the play itself by Peter Brook that frequently verged on ballet. What else could be new? John Neumeier's Ein Sommemachtstraum, which had a stormily received premiere at the Hamburg Opera House on Sunday, as the highlight of the Hamburg Ballet's current Ballet Festival.

title: Profits Declined 4% in First Quarter For Building Supply Manufacturers
description: Firstquarter profits of many building supply manufacturers went down with January and February's temperatures, an industry survey said yesterday.

title: Western Scientists Protest to Soviet on Levich
description: OXFORD, England, July 13More than 100 Western scientists concluded today a threeday conference here designed to draw attention to the plight of Veniantin Levich and to discuss new developments in his fields of interest.

title: 3 U.S. Servicemen Killed, 9 Hurt In 2 Helicopter Crashes in Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July la (AP)A United States Army helicopter crashed last night as it was taking part in the rescue of men injured in a Marine helicopter crash earlier in the night. A United States military spokesman said three Americans had been killed and nine injured in the two crashes.

title: Csonka, Still Nursing Knee, Reports As Troubled Giants Begin Training
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., July 13The Giants opened their National Football League training camp today with 73 players and almost as many questions.

title: 'Dr. Moreau' Film Is Creepily Good
description: WHAT SOMEONE should always refer to at some point as "the ???cred mystery of life" is being interfered with ???gh old style in Don Taylor's creep??? new film ad???ptation of H. G. We???'s ??? novel. "The Island of Dr. Moreau." The horror movie, which belongs to the man-made-monster subcategory, opened yesterday at the Cine??? and other theaters.The film sticks to its turn-of-the-century period and is beautifully set ??? ???a tropical Pacific i??? (actually St. Crotx without golfers)??? where Dr. Moreau (actually ??? Lancaster with a ???board) continues the invidious experiments that earlier got him tossed out of every medical society from Boston ??? P???t Said. The doctor, like Baron ???kenstein, is positively obs???d with the sacred mystery of l???fe, which ??? wants to control through chromo???.To this end, he has set up his laboratory on a remote ???land where, with the comp???ship of??? a beautiful, now ???, ex-???nlan where named Ma???a (??? Carre???s) and a hired??? named Montgomery (N??? Davenport)??? he injects what appears to be ???re mountain spring water into ???, ??? hyenas, wolves and such.After 11 years of hard work Dr. Moreau has a whole???Island full of near??? that the film calls "humanimals," ??? term that has been trade-marked with an eye??? I suppose to the toy and T-shirt markets. The hu???mals are slow-w???tted, ma??? beasts who walk a???nd on their hi??? legs, m???aco strangers??? but??? with Dr. Moreau, behave with??? the sort of tense overpolit???ness ??? would expect ??? a Friday night ??? designed to allow inmates to meat and get to know their prison guard???.Dr. Moreau might still be carrying on his work, populating the world with his mistakes, ???if there hadn't arrived at the island a shipwrecked sailor named ???dock (Michael York), who had ???ruples about the sacred mystery of life but non??? when it came to grabbing Mar???a, who still remembered a trick or two.This is more or less the plot of "The Island of Dr. Moreau," which, according to my research, was also the general outline of the ???1933 screen adaptation that starred Charles Laughton and was called "Island of Lost Sou???." Having neither read the novel nor ???n the earlier film directed by Er???e Kenton??? I feel no sense of loss in the mostly clever foolishness that Mr. Taylor has directed.Mr. Lancaster is a very be???gn madman??? courtly, gentle-mannered, a perfect host to the uninvited guest until Mr. York goes poking around and stirring up trouble with the homemade help. Then, but only then, does the doctor decide he must take "steps." That is??? he is forced to begin some new experiments with the younger man.The Island of Dr. Moreau" is a Saturday night movie that needn't be ashamed to come out the rest of the week. The screenplay, by John Herman Sha???er and A??? Ramrus, sounds as if it would have been fun to write. Though it's never fa???tious, it??? enjoys such extravagances as the doctor's saying, ???"If they [the humanimals] spill just one??? drop of blood, it will drown us all."The performers display a kind of disciplined intelligence that keeps them from bursting through the style of the film into comic limbo. These include Mr. D???venport as the foreman who, to relax??? listens to an amazingly high-quality recording of "The Magic Fluts," and Richard Baschart as the most intelligent, most p???ce-loving of the human???mals, a follow who winds up like Neville Chamberlaintotally discredited.Most of the work, though, is done by John Chambers, Dan Striepeke and Tom Burman, who designed the makeup, and by Mr. Lancaster and Mr. York, who are steadfast. Miss Carrera is so beautiful she's a scared mystery of life all by herself."The Island of Dr. Moreau," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") contains some mild, very fleeting female nudity and some violence that doesn't dwell on gore more than is necessary in what's supposed to be, after all, a scary movie.

title: Leonard Silk
description: A new Brookings report, Setting National Priorities. The 1978 Budget, strives to come to grips with an unresolved conflict within the economic philsophy of President Carter. That conflict is between what may be called Mr. Carter's programmat tic and managerial approaches to economic policy. It was evident throughout his campaign for the Presidency and has persisted since he took office. On the programmatic side, Mr. Carter ha's set himself a long list of objectives: end ing unemployment reducing inflation, strenthening national defense, aiding the cities expanding education programs reforming welfare, improving the tax system solving the nergy crisis an dgetting the economy growing faster again.

title: Big Sleep Ending Long Slumber
description: The Big Sleep, which was filmed in 1946 with Humphrey Bogart playing Philip Marlowe, the private detectivehero of Raymond Chandler's novel, will be remade by the British ITC Entertainment company, headed by Lord Lew Grade. Michael Winner will direct from his own screenplay, starting Aug. 1 in England, with Robert Mitchum portraying Marlowe and Sarah Miles, Joan Collins, John Mills, Oliver Reed, Candy Clark, Colin Blakely and Diana Quick in featured roles.

title: High School Math Wizards Do It by Numbers and U.S. Is No. 1
description: Subduing the angularities of geometry, conquering zeros, eight American high school students have won the International Mathematical Olympiad in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.

title: Educators Visit the Work World Give Pupils Glimpse of Future
description: Fannie P. Finch donned hard hat and, slacks and visited a construction site yesterday so that when she returns to teaching in the fall she can give her fourthgrade students at Public School 163 in Manhattan some firsthand information about the construction industry.

title: Spate of Late Buying Buoys Dow To 902.99 After Dips Below 900
description: A late burst of buying enabled the Dow Nines industrial average to close above the 900 level yesterday. The widely watched stock market indicator had dipped below that level several times during the session.

title: U.S. Seeks Steel Data in Inquiry on Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Government has begun an investigation into whether 10 of the nation's biggest steel companies have been fixing prices on products used in such items as kitchen appliances and cars.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: EastWest Accord Appears Near On Procedure for Belgrade Talks
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 13 (Reuters)Western diplomats said today that the Soviet bloc and the Western countries were near agreement at the preparatory stage of the EastWest conference here.

title: F. W. Husserl, 63, Psychiatrist, Served at Jersey Medical Center
description: Dr. Franz W. Husserl. a psychiatrist, died Tuesday at Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, N.J. He was 63 years old and a resident of Ocean Township. N.J.

title: Film Stirs Nassau Political Furor
description: GARDEN CITY, LI., July 13A 60second movieindustry film that will soon he playing at 150 Long Island theaters caused a political stir here today because of its starRalph G. Caso.

title: Cleveland Tabulates First Returns Of Survey to Determine Obscenity
description: CLEVELAND, July 13City employees here today began tabulating the results of a community survey on obscenity in the first attempt by a major city to define community standards as prescribed by the Supreme Court.

title: Army Head Says Service Chiefs Opposed Plan for Korea Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI)  The Joint Chiefs of Staff did not want to withdraw all United States ground forces from Korea within a fiveyear period, as decided by President Carter, Gen Bernard W. Rogers testified today.

title: EMILY DE FOREST WHITE
description: ??nd educational affairs, died Tuesday al ??er home in St. Huberts, N.Y. She was ?? years old.

title: 2 ARE HELD HOSTAGE IN JERSEY ROBBERY
description: KINNELON, N.J., July 13 (UPI)Four suspected robbers held a 12yearold boy and a servicestation attendant hostage at gunpoint for eight hours today before releasing them unharmed after a long talk with authorities about racial prejudice.

title: Israeli Cabinet Gets Peace Plan Begin Will Show Carter
description: TEL AVIV, July 13Prime Minister Menahem Begin disclosed to his Cabinet today the proposals for a Middle East settlement that he intends to present to President Carter next week, and later an official announcement said that he had received unanimous approval to proveed.

title: The Altalena Docks
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 They tell a story in Israel these days about the Altalena, a ship carrying guns to the Irgun in 1948 that was sunk on Tel Aviv by David BenGurion's Haganah, in a demonstration of who was running the newly independent nation.

title: Order Restraining Knicks In Nets' Move Continued
description: the lawyers for both aides to prepare maps delineating the disputed territorial areas or make oral arguments.

title: London Catholic Bishops To Sell Stock in Company With South African Mines
description: LONDON, Thursday, July 14 (AP)The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Westminster announced today that it was selling $27,000 worth of stock in a British company that the archdiocese accuses of responsibility for racial injustices at its mines in South Africa.

title: Yanks New Woe: Gullett's Shoulder
description: MILWAUKEE, July 13The latest Yankee problem emerged today as George Steinbrenner, principal owner in charge of receiving criticism, arrived for a meeting with Manager Billy Martin and his coaches.

title: Study Finds Prospects Are Remote For Inflation Rate Below 5 to 6%
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Brookings Institution said today that the outlook for inflation is not encouraging because the Carter Administration's announced antiinflation measures gave little promise of making milch of a dent in the basic underlying rate of 5 to 6 percent.

title: Meadowlands Drivers
description: (Includes races of July 12)

title: ScofflawFine Fraud
description: A former New York City Parking Violations Bureau clerk was charged with pocketing $3,910 in fines sent in by scofflaws.

title: Crim Drops Sharply in Pakistan After Setting of Harsh Penalties
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, July 13 (AP) Serious crime has dropped sharply since Pakistan's new military Government announced severe anticrime measures, including the orthodox Moslem punishment of amputating the hands of thieves, looters and armed robbers.

title: Riders Safely Flee the Subway Though Some Swelter Hours
description: Thousands of homebound tr??ers were trapped in subway tunnels and along suburban railroad lines by last night's blackout.

title: U.S. NEW CAR SALES ROSE IN EARLY JULY BY 15.4% T0 192,805
description: DETROIT, July 13American new car sales increased 15.4 percent in early July, slightly below estimates by analysts but still the second best total for the period on record.

title: Halpern's Powerboat Wins Off Jersey
description: POINT PLEASANT N.J., July 13Beep Beep, driven by Joel Halpern of Bronxsville, N.Y., roared out of the dark haze draped across the choppy Atlantic Ocean today and crossed the finish line 17 minute ahead of the rest of the open boat fleet for a nesounding victory in the Benthana Grand Prix.

title: The Mayor, the Policeand Mrs. Abzug
description: The Beame administration's efforts to write a new labor contract with New York City's police have reached a critical point. The last contract expired a year ago. Failure to get the city to accept its demands led the police union to seek arbitration instead. The arbitrator has now supported the city on the critical issues, finding that it has the right to reduce radiocar manning to one officer and that it need not make a $1,200 annual raise retroactive beyond July 1.

title: Ohio Educator Named to H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)Peter D. Relic, superintendent of schools in Hamilton, Ohio, was named today the deputy assistant secretary for education in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. In his new job, Mr. Relic will deal with student suspensions and problems of energy in the nation's schools, a spokesman said.

title: Ronan Issues a Report Detailing Asian Trip and Citing Its Value
description: Responding to criticism of his recent Far Eastern trip at the expense of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Dr. William J. Ronan, former chairman of the Port Authority, has issued a 15page report detailing his activities on the trip and expressing a range of opinions about the importance of the World Trade Centers Association Inc., the future of Thailand's economy and the importance of bringing wives along on such trios.

title: Bridge:
description: CHICAGO, July 13The Grand National Team Championship, in which some 8,000 teams have competed during the last eight months, reaches its climax here during the next three days, and serves as a curtainraiser to the Summer National Championships, which begin Friday.

title: Order Restraining Knicks In Nets' Move Continued
description: While the National Basketball Association club owners struggled to solve the dispute between the Knicks and the Nets at an emergency meeting in Chicago the Knicks lost the first round of the court battle yesterday in Newark.

title: Soviet Charges Wanton Beating On East Side of Russian Official
description: SOVIET ASSERTIONS THAT AN AOFFICIAL OF THE SOVIET Mission to the United Nations was attacked last Thursday will be discussed today at a meeting of the Unitd Nations Comiee on Relations with the Host Country.

title: U.S. Protests Attack in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, July 13 (AP)  The United States Embassy has lodged a protest with the Soviet Foreign Ministry over an attack yesterday on a CBS correspondent and his cameraman, an embassy spokesman said today. The correspondent, Bernard Redmont., and the German cameraman, Kurt Hoefle, were accosted by two men as they were filming in a Soviet beer garden. The assailants tried to smash Mr. Hoefle's camera and struggled with Mr.Redmont over possession of a tripod. There were no injuries.

title: More Free Travels By Port Aides Found
description: An examination of travelexpense accounts of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has disclosed a pattern of paid overseas trips for officials and often their wives vastly more systematic and extensiveand expensive than previously reported.

title: VIKTOR ALEKSEYEV
description: MOSCOW, July 13 (AP)Viktor Alekseyev, a wellknown Soviet track andfield coach has died at the age of 62, Tass reported today. The Soviet press agency said Mr. Alekseyev died of a heart attack in Leningrad.

title: Accord Is Near in Albany On Bill to Let Prosecutors Hold Subpoenaed Records
description: ALBANY, July 13Leaders of both houses of the Legislature were near agreement tonight on a bill, urgently sought by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, to allow prosecutors to continue to keep possession of business records they obtain under subpoena from witnesses in investigations.

title: Angry Chinaglia Punches Hunt at Cosmos Drill
description: PARAMUS, N.J., July 13Glorgie Chinagila punched a teammate, Steve Hunt, today with a right uppercut to the jaw that would have made any heavyweliht envious.

title: U.S.Soviet Citizens' Parley Held; Carter Policies Baffling Russians
description: MOSCOW, July 13A citizen's conference of Soviet and American public figures ended today amid strong new suggestions from the Soviet side that the Kremlin was baffled by the Carter Administration and had growing doubts about the future of dtente.

title: Lightning Apparently to Blame  Some Suburbs Affected
description: A vast power failure plunged New York City and Westchester County into darkness last night, disrupting the lives of nearly nine million people.

title: Princeton Selects Coach
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 13Jane Barkman Tyler, a twotime Olympic gold metal winner, has been named head coach of the women's swimming team at Princeton University. Mrs. Tyler, how head coach at the University of Tennessee was a member of the victorious United States 400meter freestyel relay teams in 1963 and 1972. She also won a bronze medal in the 200meter freestyle in 1968. Mrs, Tyler will replace Dave Garretson, who led the Tigers to an Ivy League title 1stseason.

title: Kent State Protesters Vow To Demonstrate Again
description: KENT, Ohio, July 13 (AP)The May 4th Coalition promised today to stage another demonstration in an effort to block construction of a Kent State University gymnasium near the spot where four young antiwar demonstrators were shot to death by Ohio National Guardsmen in 1970.

title: STATE'S SAVINGS BANKS SHOW DEPOSIT OUTFLOW
description: Savings banks in New York State had a $13 million net outflow of deposits in June, the Savings Banks Association of New York State reported yesterday, after a large$329 millioninflow in May.

title: Metropolitan
description: Agreement on stiffer sentences for serious crimes by juveniles, particularly against the elderly, came reluctantly from leaders of the Democraticcontrolled New York State Assembly. Their hope was to gain a concession from the Republicancontrolled Senate on extending the temporary release program for adult prisoners. The compromise assumed that Governor Carey would approve the Senate measure, which seemed uncertain. [A1:3.]

title: Eoff Cards 69 to Lead Jersey Open by Stroke
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.J. July 13Jim (Spike) Eoff is one of many good golfers who played for Oklahoma State in their college days. But he never tried the pro tour, and does not even play much local tournament golf these days.

title: Business/Finance
description: Whether there is pricefixing in steel is under investigation by the Department of Justice. The Government is ??quiring into whether 10 of the nation's biggest steel companies have been doing this on products used in items such as kitchen appliances and cars. One issue is whether the suspected pricefixing was conducted through public statements, which in turn raises a constitutional question of free speech. [47:36.]

title: William Adelman, 69, an Authority In HealthCare Services for Aged
description: William Adelman, an authori in health care for the aged and chronically ill, died Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at 166 Kneeland Avenue in Yonkers.

title: ADM. S. M. LOBOV OF SOVIET;. ONCE HEADED FLEET
description: MOSCOW. July 13 (AP)Fleet Adm. Semyon M. Lohov, former commander of the Soviet Northern fleet, died yesterday at the age of 64, the press agency Tass reported.

title: Democrats Are Nearly Bankrupt While the G.O.P. Is Prospering
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Democratic Party has control of the White House, Congress and the great majority of governorships and state legislatures, but it is very nearly bankrupt.

title: Cholesterol in the Blood of Americans Believed Down
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI)First results from a nationwide study suggest that cholesterol levels in the blood of Americans have dropped in recent years, but that young women using birth control pills have more fats in their blood than nonusers do.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SUMMER SPREAD There may be something for everyone who is Octoberfestminded at the celebration that begins today and will run through July 24 at the Queens Botanical Garden in Flushing, adjacent to grounds of the former, World's Fair. Spread over 39 acres, this Rig Apple Oktoberfest will feature traditional entertainment bell ringers, strolling players and ownpah music  along with dancing, di??play of arts and crafts and a ??er garden, plus carnival amusements and guided tours of the Gardens.

title: Boz Scaggs: Eclectic Pop In Mainstream Style
description: BOZ SCAGGS'S CAREER has been a long time getting off the ground. He left the Steve Miller Band during the late 1960's to go solo, but as recently as two years ago he gave only one performance at the Beacon Theater when he visited New York. Tonight he gives the last of three shows at Avery Fischer Hall.

title: North Carolinians in a Town Facing Fund Cutoff Donate Money for Utilities for Two Black Families
description: CLAREMONT, N.C., July 13The short ride down Oxford Street in the far west corner of this small, semirural North Carolina town seems a bit like a ride down a country road.

title: Coop City Talks Delayed
description: The deadline for reaching an agreement in the protracted financial dispute involving the huge Coop City housing project in the Bronx has been postponed once againfrom tomorrow until July 29as intense negotiations continued between project leaders and New York State officials. One participant in the talks said there was some optimism that an agreement might be worked out that would bring financial stability to the development for at least the next year or two. A 13month residents strikeover an increase in apartmentmaintenance charges at the 15,000family, stateaided projectended last summer with an interim agreement that has threatened to fall apart in recent weeks.

title: State Troopers Sent Into City As Crime Rises
description: Within minutes after the power failed last night, police radios around the city began to crackle with reports of crime.

title: A Joyous La Fille
description: THERE COULDN'T HAVE been a happier way for the National Ballet of Canada to open its new twoweek season at the Metropolitan Opera House Tuesday than with as joyous a masterpiece as Sir Frederick Ashton's La File Mal Garde.

title: BOBODZHAN GAFUROV
description: MOSCOW, July 13 (AP)Bobodzhan Gafurov, a Soviet historian and director of the Soviet Institute of Oriental Studies, has died at the age of 69, the press agency Tass reported today.

title: Wilkes Goes To Lakers as A Free Agent
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 13The Los Angeles Lakers strengthened their front court today with the signing of Jamaal Wilkes, who played last season for the Golden State Warriors.

title: Sports Today
description: BASESALL

title: U.S Copter Down Over North Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday July 14 An American cargo helicopter with three crewmen aboard was forced down over North Korea yesterday, the White House reported this morning.

title: Jazz: Art Farmer As Original as Ever
description: ART FARMER is a jazz musician who quietly and unostentatiously, goes his own way. He is the only prominent man who devotes himself completely to the flugelhorn an instrument usually played by trumpeters as a double. Since 1968 he has lived in Vienna, which is not notable as a gathering place for American jazz musicians, although he spends most of cash year traveling through Europe, Japan and this country. And his choice of material is distinctly removed from the things that other jazz musicians play.

title: No Panic Reported in Subways Among Trapped Passengers
description: Thousands of homebound travelers were trapped in subway tunnels and along suburban railroad lines by last night's blackout.

title: French Site in Madrid Hit Again
description: MADRID. July 12 (Reuters),Another bomb exploded before dawn today in a building used by the French Embassy's cultural services. A leftist urban guerrilla group claimed responsibility. The blast came 12 hours after one struck the building's library, injuring two persons. An anonymous caller said the First of October Group of AntiFascist Resistance was responsible for the blasts. which he said were aimed at the monopolistic government of France.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Wednesday /July 12, 1977

title: Major League Box Scores
description: HOME RUNS ??GScott Boston, 25; Rice, Boston, 214. Nettles, New York, 20; Zisk, Chicago, 19; Hisle, Minnesota 19.

title: Yale Theater Names Serban a Director
description: Andrei Serban, the 34yearold Rumanian director whose staging of The Cherry Orchard has been one of the most talked about productions of the theater season, has been named an associate director of the Yale Repertory Theater, it was announced by Robert Brustein, director of the theater. Walt Jones, a resident director of the theater for the last two years, was also named an associate director by Mr. Brustein.

title: Carter Plans Jersey Trip to Help Byrne in Campaign for Reelection
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  President Carter said today that he would visit New Jersey to campaign for Governor Byrne's reelection.

title: Radio
description: 76 A.M., WNCN. Six Preludes, Ponce; Galop, Kay; Antigone and Oedipus, Schubert; Spring Night, SchumannLiszt ; Konzertstuck. Fantasia Appassionata, Vieuxtemps; Dance of the Moorish Slaves and Ballet March from Aida. Verdi; Age of Gold Polka, Shostakovich.

title: SENATE VOTES FUNDS FOR NEUTRON BOMBS, HEEDING CARTER PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Senate approved funds tonight for the neutron bomb, supporting President Carter's appeal for money to develop the controversial nuclear warhead.

title: SOME IN OPEC RESIST SAUDI AND IRANIAN BID FOR '78 PRICE FREEZE
description: STOCKHOLM, July 13Representatives of some of the small and more radical oil exporting countries indicated today that they would resist yesterday's call by Saudi Arabia and Iran for an oil price freeze next year.

title: Watt's Watt in Public Transport
description: New York City and its inhabitants suffer much of the time from an unacceptable level of air pollution, yet no practical course of action has been set forth to solve this increasingly crucial problem.

title: Leading Contender for Joe Papp's Place at Lincoln Center?
description: LOS ANGELES THE MARK TAPER FORUM of Los Angeles announced its 197778 season recently. Characterislially, two of the four plays to be mounted will be world premieres. They are, Attica a dramatization of the 1971 prison uprising, by Robert Alan Arthur, and Black Angel, a play about a Nazi war criminal by Michael Cristofer.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Temple University Strike Ended
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (AP)Striking Temple University Hospital workers have ratified a new twoyear contract and are expected hack on the job today after a weeklong strike. Members of District 1199C of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees overwhelmingly ratified the new pact in voting yesterday, a union spokesman said. The contract calls for a 12 percent wage increase over two years and an increase from 8.5 percent to 10 percent in Temple's contributions to the union's pension fund, the spokesman said.

title: Companies List Reports Covering Their Sales and Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended June 30 unless other wise indicated. (N) Indicates stock traded on the New York Stock Exchange (A) American Stock Exchange and (O OvertheCounter

title: Bill to Broaden Right to Sue In PriceFixing Set for Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 13A bill to broaden the right to sue for damages under the Clayton Act is scheduled to be introduced in Congress tomorrow by the chairman of the House and Senate antitrust subcommittees, Representative Peter W. Rodin Jr. of New Jersey and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Mamachusetts, both Democrats.

title: Lightning Bolt: How It Struck
description: The blackout had its beginning in the thunderclouds that gathered last night over Westchester County. Lightning struck in the vicinity of Consolidated Edison's Indian Point Nuclear Power Plant 3, and major power transmission lines were shortcircuited.

title: Two for the Legislature
description: Long Beach, Long Island, stands on the brink of sinking its credit rating, only lately risen from the municipal cellar. Th ecity faces financial doom on Friday when $700,000 in bond anticipation notes come due. Although its bankers are prepared to lend now at 5 percentonly half the previous interestthe city cannot take up the offer without approval from the New York State Legislature.

title: Living Costs Increase in Canada
description: OTTAWA. July 13 (UPI)The cost of living increased seventenths of 1 percent in June, bringing Canada's rate of inflation over the last 12 months to 7.8 percent, Statistics Canada said today. The Government agency said the rise in the Consumer Price Index was mainly attributable to a 1,1 percent increase in the food index, while Meier housing charges added to the overall increase.

title: 3M Extends Bid for Van Dyk
description: The Van Dyk Research Corporation, now in Chapter XI bankruptcy proceedings, said yesterday that the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Corporation had agreed to a further extension to Aug. 13 of the termination date of an agreement for the sale of Van Dyk to 3M. Van Dyk, which marketed a plain paper copier. has agreed to sell its assets to 3M for $14 million in cash.

title: State Troopers Sent Into City As Crime Rises
description: Thousands of looters, emboldened by darkness and confusion, ranged through the city last night and early today in wave of lawlessness.

title: House Ethics Panel to Speed Korean Influence Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The chairman of the House ethics committee, John J. Flynt Jr., ordered a speedup today in the investigation of the Korean influencebuying scandal in response to accusations that the committee had been stalling.

title: No. 2 C.I.A. Man Resigns

For the first half, the world's largest papermaking enterprise earned $107.7 million. or $2.30 a share, down 26.8 percent from the initial six months of 1976 Sales were $1.86 billion, only 1.7 percent ahead of last year.

Seeking to ease widespread European concern over the impact of the human rights campaign on overall EastWest relations, he assured Mr. Schmidt of his desire for a fruitful and productive conference. This prospect often lures a player into taking extraordinary steps to keep his winning chances alive. However, in the struggle to turn around a difficult game, it is easy to forget that simply saving the gammon (or double game) can in itself be considered a victory.

title: Never on Sunday for A.L. Starters
description: Billy Martin, Gene Mauch and Whitey Herzog agree that it's a bad rule. Earl Weaver calls it stupid and Don Zimmer thinks it's terrible. Of the managers with teams currently in contention in both the American League East and West, only Bob Lemon of the Chicago White Sox doesn't sound disturbed, saying, I don't think the rule makes that much difference. The rule they're talking about is an American League commandment that one starting pitcher from each teem, designated three weeks in advance for possible selection to the AllStar squad; shall not be permitted to perspire the Sunday Sports before the AllStar Game, which will be of held at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night.

title: Labor Contract in Detroit Narrowly Wins Approval

title: Commodities Options Talk Set
description: LONDON, July 13 (UPI)The Commodities Futures Trading Commission and the London Metal Exchange began informal discussions today on the trading of London metal options in the United States. John Rainbolt, vice chairman of the C.F.T.C., said representatives of the two groups woul discuss transAtlantic option trading procedures and regulations, but he said it was not a negotiating session.

title: Nicaraguans Potest in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, July 13 (Reuters)Seven Nicaraguans invaded a United Nalions office in Mexico City today and started a hunger strike to protest the detention of two men they said were political prisoners in their country. Officials al the office of the United Nations High Commission for Refugees said the strikers also handed over a message for Secretary General Kurt Waldheim. The message asked for a United Nations mission to visit Nicaragua to investigate alleged violations of human rights there and the conditions in which political prisoners were being kept.

title: Westchester Dark; Long Islands Power Interrupted Briefly
description: Although all of Westchester County was without power last night, no serious traffic or crime problems were reported.

title: Topps and Alexander's End Talks
description: Topps & Trowsers, a San Francisco based retail chain saidyesterday that it had terminated discussions with Alexander's Inc., New York, about the possible acquisition of Topps & Trowsers by Alexander's. The California company a retailer of young??men's apparel, had said several weeks ago that it was talking about a takeover with the New York concern.

title: Omaha Busing Is Ordered Despite High Court Ruling
description: OMAHA, July 13 (AP)Omaha's courtordered school busing plan must remain in effect into the 197778 school year, despite a United States Supreme Court decision vacating the order on which it is based, the Federal Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in St. Louis ruled today.

title: Quake Jolts Pakistan Province
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 13 (AP)An earthquake today jolted Quetta, the capital of Baluchistan province, which borders Iran. The quake shook buildings and people rushed out into the streets in panic. No loss of life or property was reported.

title: British Unions End Voluntary Restraint On Wage Increases
description: LONDON. July 13Leaders of Britain's labor movement told the Government tonight that they would no longer be bound by the voluntary restraints under which wages and prices have been regulated for the last two years.

title: India Renounces Nuclear Tests
description: NEW DELHI, July 13 (UPI)India's Government announced today that it would conduct no further nuclear test explosions. There is no question now of nuclear explosions for peaceful purposes, Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai told Parliament. No such explosion is necessary.

title: Making and Breaking the Lance Pledge
description: If it ain't broke, don't fix it, was the winning advice offered about a bank regulatory problem this spring by Bert Lance, head of the Carter Administration's Office Management and Budget. Now Mr. Lance is involved in a bankrelated controversy of his own. He may or may not be broke; but he and President Carter are moving prudently to try to fix it.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEKING ALBANY COMPROMISE
description: ALBANY, July 13Leaders of the Democraticcontrolled Assembly reluctantly agreed today to stiffer sentences for serious crimes by juveniles, particularly crimes against the elderly. The concession was an effort to gain from the Republicancontrolled Senate an extension of the temporaryrelease program for adult prisoners.

One of the works, Benjamin Britten's piano Concerto in D, honors the memory of the composer, who died last year.

Now all but forgotten, she was in her heyday a paragon of pallid beauty and an exemplar of galvanic action in behalf of national freedom.

title: Blackout Politics

Beyond It's natural anxiety over the safety of the people and city, he must surely have felt a nagging worry about a dumb fact which may be politically relevant: He bore no responsibility for the blackout, but nevertheless, he was the mayor when it happened.

Seaver, who also slugged a home run, walked the first two batters in the game and then retired 18 in a row. Willie Montanez hit a oneout double in the seventh inning that ended Seaver's bid for his first career nohitter. His wonlost record is now 10.5.

title: Andrus Plans 4Day Alaska Tour
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, will visit Alaska next week for a fourday tour of proposed national park areas and meetings with several groups, the Department of the Interior announced today. The announcement said Mr. Andrus's visit would include a special briefing on the Alaska oil pipeline situation from Jack Turner, head of Interior Department's Alaska Pipeline Office. The Secretary is due to arrive in Alaska next Tuesday.

title: GHANA SCHEDULES JULY '79 AS DATE FOR CIVILIAN RULE
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 14 (Reuters)Ghana's military rulers said today they would hand over power to an elected government on July 1, 1979.

title: Film: 'Rose Garden' Limns Dark Borders of Reality
description: TO ESCAPEactually, to renaer neutralthe terrors, real and imagined, of this world, Deborah Blake, a pretty, middle-class teen-ager, has created another much more exotic and much more terrifying world that exists just beyond reality. Though she is its ruler, she's also its slave, subject always to the laws and rituals she herself has designed to keep herself in line. At the age of 16, Deborah Blake is a certified schizophrenic.Among the achievements of Anthony Page's screen adaptation of Joanne Greenberg's novel, "I Never Promised You A Rose Garden," is our immediate acceptance of Deborah's fantasy world, a desert landscape inhabited by half-naked pagans whose origins could be comic books perused at some preliterate age. Deborah's demons are both ferocious and absurd and never for a moment do we doubt their existence.Unlike "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," "I Never Promised You A Rose Garden" makes no pitch on behalf of the proposition that the mentaly ill may be more sane and happy than the straights walking around loose outside. Mental illness, it knows, is sad and depressing, full of such breathtaking, manifold possibilities for failure and harm that one always has to be alert. It's exhausting, physically and phychically."I Never Promised You A Rose Garden," which opened yesterday at the Cinema II, is the carefully realized story of Deborah's treatment at a hospital that is probably better than most but still frightening enough, it would seem to us, to drive even someone who's well-balanced over the edge.There's the male nurse who, to assert his own tenuous superiority over the patients, beats them up at will and, when he's feeling at ease, simply teases them. There are fatuous doctors and patronizing nurses. Mostly though, there are the other patients who insist on imposing their own worldly, surreal views on everyone around them, who slide in and out of temper tantrums, feuds and passionate friendships, who effectively befuddle even the simplest logic. To move among them without a collision is to sail without benefit of a centerboard or rudder.How Deborah, with the help of one remarkable doctor, is eventually able to recognize her own pain and thus come to some kind of terms with her demons is the moving substance of this film that leaves one almost as exhausted as its heroine.Mental illness is always a tricky thing to dramatize, not because it's especially difficult but because it's such an acute form of distress that it exists outside all conventional experience. Mr Page and his screenwriters, Gavin Lambert and Lewis John Carlino, never quite succeed in convincing me that Deborah's triumph has much to do with the world at I know It. Most of us can identify in some fashion with astronauts, pearl divers, pirates and presidents, but madness is difficult to comprehendmaybe we are afraid of comprehending it. Whatever the reason, "I Never Promised You A Rose Garden' is something I can say I admired much more than I really liked.The tone of the film is straightforward, terse, even as it shares with us Deborah's melodramatic visions of secret ceremonies and sacrifices, which suggest she's seen more than one movie on the order of "King Kong." Unless you're someone who finds psychotic behavior intrinsically funny, however, you're likely to be ground-down by the ward sequences in which aimlessness and violence are so effectively portrayed you may wish for a weekend pass before the movie's end.Kathleen Quinlan, who had small parts in "American Graffiti" and the California problem-picture, "Life-guard," gives a remarkably fine, contained performance as Deborah. There are no mannerisms, no tricks, only a sense of panic barely contained, of intelligence and feeling struggling to break free. Bibi Andersson is almost equally good as the psychiatrist, nobly free of platitudes and mock-doctor self-importance.Among the inmates you'll recognize Signe Hasso, Susan Tyrrell, Diane Varsi (looking very plump) and Sylvia Sidney. They're all colorful and slightly too-much, as I suppose they should be, though Miss Sidney is achingly pathetic as an old lady who, for a brief time, becomes a legend in the ward after she wins her release.

title: Ford Declares Dividend
description: DETROIT, July 14 (AP)The Ford Motor, Company declared a thirdquarter dividend of 80 cents a share payable Sept. 1 to stockholders of record on Aug. 2, the same effective dividend that has been paid quarterly since the third quarter of 1976. Because of a 5for4 stock split, Ford paid a $1 dividend during the second quarter of this year so that the 80 cent payment would be maintained after the split took effect.

description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 14After 42 years, Herb McCarthy is selling his Bowden Square Restaurant in this resort community, and his patrons, he says, don't like the idea of seeing yet another reminder of Southampton's oppulent past disappear.

description: BURLINGTON, N. C., July 14 (AP) Burlington Industries Inc. announced that it was actively considering a plan to expand its activities in Ireland by constructing an integrated textile processing complex that would include two plants for yarn manufacturing, weaving, dyeing and finishing processes.

title: New York Theaters Bouncing Back Faster Than Its Restaurants After the Blackout
description: New York's theater industry, schooled in adversity and all but immune to sudden crisis, showed signs yesterday of a rapid recovery from the blackout. At the same time, much of the restaurant business remained shuttered.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 5.7%
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 12.7 billion tonmiles, up 5.7 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 368,496 cars, a rise of 5.5 percent from last year. Both years included the Independence Day holiday and the second week of the miners holiday. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 5 percent from a year ago.

title: U.S. Athletes Excel At Games in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, July 14 (AP)The United States continued its medal surge at the Maccabiah Games today, taking three of five swimming races and winning in weightlifting, shooting and gymnastics.

title: Senators Are Expected to Request Further Assurance From Lance

title: Restaurants
description: FOR THE LAST year and a half, much dining attention has been directed skyward to Windows on the World, the glossy, glassy eatery that tops off the North Tower of the World Trade Center. Meanwhile, quietly, painstakingly and ingeniously, a complex of fascinating and stunning restaurants has been developing on the ground floor concourse of the center, adjacent to the Vesey Street entrance. Set on the site of what was once the heart of the Washington Market (there are documents recovered from a time capsule on display to prove it) the four eating facilities here rim what has become Market Square.

description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)Jane Young, the wife of a Texas Representative, was shot to death yesterday in her suburban home. The police said today that the shooting appeared to have been a suicide.

title: Frank B. Ryan, Who Is Well Known
description: When Yale's director of athletics was a professional quarterback completing his work for a Ph.D. in that branch of higher mathematics called Geometric Function Theory, he wrote a dissertation entitled: A Characterization of the Set of Asymptotic Values of a Function Holomorphic in the Unit Disc. His opening sentence began: As is well known ... As is well known, or ought to be, Yale's director of athletics is Frank B. Ryan, of Rice University, the Los Angeles Rams, the Cleveland Browns and the Washington Redskins, who had spent six years feeding the Congress of the United States into a computer when Carmen Cozza decided he wanted to coach Yale football for at least another season. Cozza had succeeded to the athletic director's job when DeLaney Kiphuth retired, but when he chose to continue as coach Yale decided one man shouldn't handle both jobs and hired Ryan.

The proposed merger would be worth $19 million, plus possible additional amounts through 1983, depending on Century's earnings. It would also be subject to a definitive contract and approval by Block directors.

title: Powerless Together
description: One New Yorker achieved the triumph of a lifetime when he seized command of the stalled traffic on a dark and chaotic Broadway. Another suffered the trauma of a lifetime when his Harlem appliance store was sacked beyond repair. Crowds of us sang in a darkened stadium and surged into the streets in curiosity. Mobs of us reveled in the anonymous dark in tantrums of destruction and anger. Those trapped high in an elevator or deep in a subway tunnel responded with cameraderie or fear. Ten million of us suffered a single, sudden deprivation, but all of us responded uniquely. Crisis changes nothing and even a crisis of darkness illuminateswhat we are, what we have, what we are capable of.

title: Deaths
description: ADELMANWilliam. The Board of Trustees, the staff and the patients of Beth Abraham Hospital mourn the untimely passing of our beloved and dedicated Executive Director. For the past 27 years he developed the institution from a Home for the Aged into one of the most outstanding skilled nursing facilities caring for the chronically and subacutely III patients. He was one of those rare Individuals highly respected by his professional colleagues, giving innovative leadership in his field and loved by all who came In contact with him. His foremost concern was always to aloe compassionate care to our patients. His warmth and humanity will be missed by all. To his wife, Doris, and his three sons, Richard, Mark and Robert, his grandchildren, brother and sister, we heartfelt sympathy.

title: Gov. Brown Names Helen Reddy
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 14 (AP)Helen Reddy, the Australianborn singer who helped Gov. Edmund G. Brovin Jr. campaign for President last year, has been appointed by Governor Brown to the California Parks and Recreation Commission. The Australianborn singer backed Mr. Brown's late bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination with contributions and personal appearances.

title: Fiesta at Pamplona: Memories, Aficionados and Plain Idiots
description: PAMPLONA, Spain, July 11Ernest Hemingway, who forged strong fiction from strong Spanish realities, is gone. But one of his great artificesnine days of reeling drunkeness and exalted bullfights known as the Fiesta of SanFerminlives on in this dull industrial city at the entrance to the Pyrenees.

title: The Pop Life
description: ALICE COOPER is on tour again, after a two  year absence from performing, and to hear his publicrelations concern tell it, the tour has been as fraught with adventure as Hannibal's crossing of the Alps. In the openair Calgary Stadium, reads one press release, a crowd of 21,900 fans braved rain and 50 m.p.h. winds, waiting two hours until conditions made it possible for the Cooper show to start. The next press release proclaimed, Police called to calm Alice Cooper crowd in Detroit.

title: Friday
description: The metric system is here already: An eager television weatherman reports the temperature on the Celsius scale, highway signs are popping up with distances in kilometers, and so forth. It you are among the confused majority that doesn't know what any of this rears, you can get some explanations at the Hall of Science in Kushing Meadows, Queens, where a new show called Metrics and You has just opened. The exhibits are designed for practicality. For instance, you can weigh yourself in kilograms, take your temperature in centigrade, ride a stationary bicycle with distance registered on the speedometer in kilometers. There is no admission charge, but contributions are requested. Hours: 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Wednesday through Friday; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Saturday; 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., Sunday, From Manhattan, take the IRT Flushing line No. 7 train to 111th Street. Information: 6999400.

In those seven years, only 15 such applications were rejected (and most of the few rejections were in Connecticut, where the eavesdrop law is particularly tough).

title: Making and Breaking the Lance Pledge

He was not legally required to divest himself of shares in a large Georgia bank, but promised to do so anyway. To sell the stock now would result in a substantial financial loss.

description: DURING LIZ CORRIGAN'S performance at the Ballroom, where she will be appearing for the next four weeks, she lists the elements in her singing style: country, folk, blues, pop, funk, rock, church, white soul opera.

title: Market Place
description: Hours before a systemwide blackout hit the Consolidated Edison Company on Wednesday night, it was a different and most pleasantstory on Wall Street for the huge utility. Before the close of trading that day, Con Ed's shares sold as high as 25their best price since 1973and finished at 25 for a quarterpoint gain on heavy volume.

title: Consent Decrees Bar DieboldChubb Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (Reuters)The Justice Department today filed consent decrees that would prevent a British and an American maker of bank vaults from making agreements to restrict sales.

title: Services Affected
description: The power failure forced the closing yesterday of New York City's banks, securities exchanges, libraries, museums and many retail stores, restaurants, movie theaters and offices. Mail delivery was also suspended, as were alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations.

title: Army Under Secretary Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (Reuters)President Carter has nominated Walter LaBarge, a former NATO official and Assistant Air Force Secretary in the Ford Administration, to be the new Under Secretary of the Army. Dr. LaBerge appeared before the Senate Armed Services Committee in a confirmation hearing today, Pentagon officials said.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: At State Women's Conference, a New Constituency Speaks
description: For many women the feminist move. Went has long seemed a vehicle, for the superstarsthe sleek, bright, successful career women of legend, who asserted their superiority in a world of file clerks and housewives. But there were signs at the recent statewide women's conference in Albany that at a time when the movement appears to have lost some ground with, the defeat of the equal rights amendment in 12 states it is starting to provide a forum for the views of a wider range of women.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: SHADES OF GREENE, the anthology of Graham Greene short stories carried on WNET13 on Fridays at P.M., is one of those uneven affairs stuffed with thoroughly delicious performances. Tonight's representative example is When Greek Meets Greek, in which Paul Scofield plays Nicholas Fennick owner of a correspondence school for servicemen during World War II.

title: Beanie the Campaigner Put in Spotlight As AllNight Guardian of Stricken City
description: Mayor Beanie was campaigning in Coop City when the lights went out, and he in effect continued campaigning for the next eight hours as he sought to mobilize the resources of a stricken city without electricity.

title: Cool Man on a Hot Spot
description: Ten years ago, when he became chief executive officer of Consolidated dison, Charles F, Luce assessed his new job and promised, We will strive to make it the cleanest, mostreliable, bestlooking and mostefficient electric system that can be de Man signed. Mr. Luce promised to make the company first in all waysbutespecially in service to the people of New York He said he realized that supplying vast new quantities of energy at reasonable cost while protecting the city's environment from pollution and unsightly structures, is a kingsize job, but added, I am optimist enough to believe we can do it.

title: Michaela Murphy, Editor, Married to Augusto Odone
description: Michaela Teresa Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Emmett Murphy of Yonkers, was married there yesterday to Augusto Odone, son of the late Gen. Angelo Odone of the Italian army, and the late Mrs. Odone of Rome. The Rev Frederick Hill performed the ceremony at the. Monastery Church of the Sacred Heart.

title: Barney Bernstein, Lawyer, at 76; Practiced With Sherman & Citron
description: Barney Bernstein, a lawyer who was a senior counsel in the firm of Sherman & Citron, died yesterday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 76 years old.

title: U.S.INQUIRY ORDERED
description: President Carter, Governor Carey and Mayor Beame yesterday ordered separate investigations of the Consolidated Edison power failure.

title: Pathos, Heroics, Humor On a Night to Remember
description: When the steamy summer nights descend on the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, the elderly people there pick up their beach chairs and take them out to the boardwalk to sit quietly and breathe in the fresh Atlantic breezes.

title: U.S. COPTER STRAYED ON NORTH KOREA LINE
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  President Carter said today that a United States Army helicopter that was shot down, apparently by North Koreans, had strayed into North Korean airspace by mistake. He said the United States was seeking to prevent the incident from developing into a confrontation.

title: BOARD OF RABBIS NAMES HALT EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR
description: Rabbi Paul L. Hait has been named executive director of the New York Board of Rabbis, an association of Orthodox, Conservative and Reform rabbis in the New York area. He succeeds the late Rabbi Harold H. Gordon, who served as the ranking executive officer of the rabbincalrs ginroofat Orzolyni3ea.a bincal organization for 31 years.

title: Night and Day, Mets Are Blacked Out
description: In the depths of the blackout Wednesday night at Shea Stadium, the crowd of 22,000 was singing White Christmas along with Jane Jarvis at the organ while the Mets held a shadowy infield drill without a baseball, bathed in the headlights of players' cars parked in center field.

title: Sohio Accepts Settlement On Station Leases
description: The Federal Trade Commission said that it had accepted an agreement with the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) on new leasing practices for its Sohio service station dealers.

title: U.N. Talks Canceled Because of Blackout
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14 (AP)Meetings of the United Nations scheduled for today were canceled because of the power failure that darkened New York City overnight. Included in the cancellation was the continu ing sixth session of the Conference on the Law of the Sea and private consultations in the Security Council on when to meet and recommend Vietnam for United Nations membership.

title: Profits Scoreboard (Some of Major Corporations Reporting Yesterday)
description: *Earnings after poolings of interests.

title: Times Published by Shifting Its Printing to Jersey
description: When power failed Wednesday, The New York limes presses at 229 West 43d Street had just started to roll. Eight copies of the planned 850,000 had emerged. To print more, The Times had to move its printing operation to a plant in New Jersey, in the process producing its first daily, newspaper printed entirely by offset, a photographic process.

title: Advertising

description: When friends ask Bruce Wesson where he was when the lights went out, he says, for the umpteenth time, You'll never believe it.
