Now that he is 76 years old and it is 30, Mr. Barnhart occasionally forgets accomplishments past, but what lies ahead is clear in a tome on his office shelf. Future Projects speaks volumes.

title: Weakfish, Blues Abound in Area
description: AREA AWith the water temperature rising to about 73 degrees, fishermen at Margate, N.J., have been enjoying excellent weakfish catches. Using bucktails, they have been catching 3to5pounders a couple of hours before high tide off jetties at the Great Egg Inlet. Offshore in 50 to 60 feet of water, blues in the 10to12pound range have been responding to various forms of squid. Weakfish have also been running well at Island Beach State Park, where an occasional big blue or fluke can also be found. Blues of about 12 or 13 pounds have been plentiful a couple of miles offshore at Seaside Park and at Point Pleasant.

title: New Feeling, Faces Fill Jets' Camp
description: HEMSESTEAD, L.I., July 14It didn't take the Jets' veterans long today to recognizt one another.

title: Broader Rule Proposed by S.E.C. On Investment Adviser Information
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today a new rule that would require all investment advisers now registered with the commission to provide additional information to their prospective clients.

title: Major League Scores
description: EAuerbach. DPAtlanta 2, Cincinnati 1. LOBAtlanta 4, Cincinnati 5. 2BDrlessen, Montanez, Office. HRGFoster 3 (28), Seaver (1). SBMorgan.

title: Oil Burner Triumphs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., July 14 Oil Burner paced the fourthfastest mile in harness racing history tonight as he scored a narrow victory in the $60,000 Joyce Kilmer Pace at the Meadowlands.

title: Savings Association in Mississippi Reopens With Deposit Insurance
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 14The Bankers Trust Savings and Loan Association, whose collapse 14 months ago triggered a statewide moratorium on withdrawals from 34 statechartered thrift institutions reopened today under a new name and with Federal deposit insurance.

title: For New Yorkers in the Darkness, Radio Voices Offered a Comforting Link to the Light
description: Two hours into the blackout Wednesday night, reporters who had gathered in front of Consolidated Edison's energycontrol center, at 65th Street and West End Avenue, were told that the company's chairman would brief them just as soon as the television crews arrived.

title: Kids' Caper in Westchester
description: They must have had the Westchester Touring Children's Theater in mind when they named summer the silly season. The madcap sevenmember group, which tours Westchester parks and playgrounds each summer, will descend on Harrison, Lewisboro and White Plains this weekend and things may never be the same there.

title: Carter and Schmidt To Weigh a Move On Troop Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  President Carter and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany agreed today to consider a new Western initiative to break the stalemate in the EastWest talks on force reductions in Central Europe, particularly if there is no progress in the SovietAmerican negotiations on the limitation of strategic arms.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: assessing the disruption of business caused by the blackout, their suppliers were preparing to help them restore normal services.

title: 100 POLICEMEN HURT
description: As the Consolidated Edison Company struggled to restore power to New York City and Westchester County yesterday, the sweltering city was plagued by the widespread looting and faltering transportation that began when a blackout plunged nine million people into darkness.

title: Midwest Trading Slackens
description: Chicago, July 14The Chicago financial community proved to itself today that it could continue to function without the nation's major money and securities markets and giant banks. York

title: Letters
description: The decision on whether or not to participate in the forthcoming Moscow Book Fair has been a difficult one for American publishersindeed for publishers throughout the world.

title: MARINE MIDLAND EARNINGS WERE UP 29% IN QUARTER
description: Marine Midland Banks Inc. said yesterday that secondquarter earnings before securities gains and losses increased 29 percent to $3.4 million, or 28 cents a share, from $2.7 million, or 22 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Blood Center Issues Appeal for Donors
description: The New York Blood Center issued an urgent appeal for donations yesterday afternoon to help replenish supplies lost as a result of the blackout.

title: Tanner, Richey Upset in Western Tennis
description: CINCINNATI, July 14 (AP)  Unseeded Terry Moore, a 22yearold who is ranked 82d in the world, stunned topseeded Roscoe Tanner tonight, dusting the defending tournament champion, 63, 61, 63, in the 90th Western tennis championships.

title: The Mayor, the Policeand Mrs. Abzug
description: The Beame administration's efforts to write a new labor contract with New York City's police have reached a critical point. An arbitrator has now supported the city's position in favor of oneman patrol cars and against a retroactive pay raise. The city can therefore proceed flexibly to impose more efficient work rules while generously adjusting some of the difficulties these pose for the policemen. If we gauge correctly the present mood of the community, citizens will be impatient with any weakening on the major pointsretroactivity and car manning. While the police union has its own factional fights, its members should remember that City Hall is also involved in a major political battle that can only stiffen its resistance.

title: Still Fun City in Rockaway Peninsula
description: While New York City was without light and power Wednesday night and much of yesterday the roller coaster and gocarts at Rockaways' Playland in Queens sped around as on any normal summer night.

title: EDGAR LIPWORTH, 53, A PHYSICIST, IS DEAD
description: Edgar Lipworth, a nuclear physicist and professor of physics at Brandeis University, died yesterday in Cape Town. He was 53 years old and a resident of Wellesley, Mass.

title: Books: A Bittersweet Journey Through the City of Angels
description: I DID NOT become famous, Eve Babitz writes, but I got near enough to smell the stench of success. It smelt like cloth and rancid gardenias, and I realized the truly awful thing about success is that it's held up all those years as thing that would make everything all right. And the only thing that makes things even slightly bearable is a friend who knows what you're talking about. In these 10 fragments in what amounts to a memoir10 bittersweet set niecesMiss Babitz's homiletic obser vation is amply reflected. In them the authornarrator glides musingly in and out of the lives and haunts of Los Angeles's wealthy and nearwealthy, its entertainment elite and courtiers.

title: About New York
description: The looters scattered, roachlike, in the full morning sunlight, then stopped to watch brazenly when the owner of Joe's candy store showed up and saw his store disemboweled onto the Brownsville sidewalk. He let out a furious howl.

title: LoanAid Telephone For Looting Victims
description: A special city telephone number 2332121  was set up yesterday for businessmen whose shops were looted or damaged.

title: Blackout Arrests Swamp City's CriminalJustice System
description: Massive arrests of looters, robbers and arsonists during the blackout and its aftermath swamped the city's criminal courts and prison system yesterday.

title: Medical Center's Parking Lot Like War Zone Field Hospital
description: It's like wartime and we're at the battlefront, the nurse said. He had just bandaged a young man's slashed hand and wrist in the parking lot of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital and Medical Center, which had moved its surgical and emergency services outside after the blackout and the failure of its own emergency generator.

title: StorePillaging Unchecked In Two Brooklyn Sections
description: Looting and arson continued uncontained in the Williamsburg and Bushwick sections of Brooklyn yesterday in a rampage of vandalism that fire officials called the worst in the city stemming from Wednesday night's power blackout and far exceeding the outbreaks that followed the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968.

title: Services Affected
description: The power failure forced the closing yesterday of New York City's banks, securities exchanges, libraries, museums and many retail stores, restaurants, movie theaters and offices. Mail delivery was also suspended, as were alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations.

title: Angola Reports Plane Shot Down
description: LONDON, July 14 (Reuters)  The Angolan press agency said today that South African forces shot down an Angolan transport plane near the border with SouthWest Africa this week, killing 12 Angolans.

title: Yesterday's Page Summarized
description: Relatively pollutionfree airthe abnormal kind that New Yorkers breathed during the blackout, with fewer vehicles on some streets could be normal, an OpEd article argued in Thursday's editions of The New York Times.

title: Belmont Escapes Blackout and Attracts 20,536
description: Although the track is little more than a short sprint from the New York City line, business at Belmont Park was much brisker than usual yesterday for a Thursday afternoon.

title: DelBello Calls for Replacing Con Edison With Public Utility
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 14  Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, called on Governor Carey and Mayor Beame today to assist Westchester in replacing Con Edison and to join it in setting up a power authority on a regional basis.

title: SENATE FAVORS U.S. ROLE IN OFFSHORE OIL SEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The Senate, opening consideration of a comprehensive bill to tighten devlopment of offshore oil and gas reserves, today adopted a provision that would have the Federal Government, rather than the companies, supervise preliminary exploration.

title: It's Also a Sleepless Cyclist's Isle of Joy
description: For those with a yen to tour Manhattan before dawn, this Sunday will provide an uncommon opportunity to do so safely and intimately, although there may be several hundred People along.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JULY 15, 1977

title: Saturday
description: APPLES IN BIG ORCHARD

title: Swedish Count Slain in Ethiopia, Where He Once Headed Air Force
description: STOCKHOLM, July 14 (AP)Count Carl Gustaf von Rosen, a Swedish nobleman who once commanded the Ethiopian Air Force, was killed in a guerrilla attack in southeastern Ethiopia, the Swedish Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Broadway
description: THE AMERICAN SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL Theater in Stratford, Conn., will not be dark this summer, after all. Something called the Connecticut Star Players will book a series of musicals into that handsome theater. They will open on Tuesdays, close on Sundays, and also play Wednesday and Thursday matinees. The first will be A Little Night Music. It will star Jean Simmons and Hermione Gingold, and it will open Aug. 2. Then comes Li'l Abner, with Lucie Arnaz, Jan Miner and Dirk Benedict. It opens Aug. 9. On Aug. 16, Godspell, with the Hudson Brothers, comes in. Aug. 23, it is Wonderful Town, with Cloris Leachman. Aug. 30, it is Fiddler on the Roof, with Ed Ames, and Sept. 6, it is Anything Goes, with Ann Miller. Tickets rage from $5 to $12, and the box office number is (203) 3754457, or in New York you may call 9663900.

title: F.P.C. to Let Texaco Operate Disputed Refinery
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)The Federal Power Commission relented today and agreed to allow Texaco's massive Port Arthur, Tex., refinery to remain open and to continue receiving natural gas.

title: Last Stalemate in Albany Resolved, Paving Way for Legislative Recess
description: ALBANY, Friday, July 15The last remaining partisan stalemate of the legislative session was broken last night when the Democraticcontrolled Assembly passed the Senate Republicans' version of a bill to phase out the effects of the New York City stock transfer tax.

title: Senator Is Outraged By Proposal to Ease Job Safety Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., chairman of the Senate Committee on Human Resources, informed President Carter today he was outraged by the proposal of three top White House aides to use economic incentives to business rather than enforcement of safety rules to achieve safer workplaces.

title: Ballet: Memorable Act
description: THERE WERE TOO performances to review Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the National Ballet of Canada has opened what promises to be an exciting twoweek engagement.

title: Sally Shelton Gets State Dept. Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)The State Department announced today that Sally Shelton, an aide to Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, had accepted an offer to become Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs. She had initially agreed to become, ambassador to El Salvador and it was not clear why that offer was withdrawn.

title: New Face: Caroline Kava
description: Going from Chicago to study in Cracow, Poland, may not seem the most direct route to win stardom on the stage in New York, but that is part of the route taken by Caroline Kava, who is helping to light up Central Park these nights as Polly Peachum in Threepenny Opera.

title: A Grim Game of Cat and Mouse on Tour of East Harlem
description: They're grabbing anything now, Police Officer John Klink growled as his patrolcar partner, Officer Robert Dalia, gunned their car along the south sidewalk on 106th Street in East Harlem early yesterday morning, scattering scores of looters and onlookers.

title: US INQUIRY ORDERED
description: President Carter, Governor Carey and Mayor Beame yesterday ordered separate investigations of the Consolidated Edison power failure.

title: Coastal States Gas Agrees to Settlement
description: The board of directors of the Coastal States Gas Corporation agreed in principle to a plan caning for an outofcourt settlement of pending law suits relating to its LoVaca Gathering Company subsidiary and a spinoff of LoVaca and certain other Texas utility operations to Castal States stockholders. Major customers and representatives had either approved the plan earlier or agreed to recommend approval, as had the cities of Austin and Corpus Christi, Tex., and the Lower Colorado River Authority.

title: Don't Cry Over Spilled Wax
description: Now that New York's electrical problems are on the wane, some people who waxed lavish with candles rather than curse the darkness are wondering what to do about the drippings.

title: Rockwell Lays Off 4,200
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said that a total of about 4,200 employees had been laid off so far as a result of President Carter's decision on June 30 to end production of the controversial B1 bomber. A spokesman said that the company's B1 division expected to day off about 8,000 of its employees this month.

title: Art People
description: IT'S AN ALARMING TREND, as most museum directors see it, and the latest manifestation of it is sending shock waves through the profession. It's the desire of the Metropolitan Museum to replace its justretired director, Thomas Hoving, with a twoman team, a setup that would have an art historian looking after curatorial matters, subordinate to a paid administrator in charge of the business side.

title: Death in North Korea
description: All the facts about the downing of a stray American construction helicopter and the killing of three of four Army crewmen by North Korean troops are not yet known. Given the nature of the incident and its location within North Korean territory, they may never be surely known.

title: Assembly in Albany Passes Laetrile Bills
description: ALBANY, July 14  The Assembly tonight gave final passage to two bills to legalize the use of the controversial drug laetrile after one Assemblyman rose to tell his colleagues: I have cancercancer of the prostrate. It is only a matter of time.

title: A Souvenir Magazine Till We Meet Again
description: Media people are always trying to do nice things for agency people they know where the money comes from.

title: SCHEDULED CAR OUTPUT UP 8.5% TO 162,836 FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, July 14The American auto industry is scheduled to build 176,606 cars this week, an increase of 8.5 percent from 162,836 cars last week, according to Ward's Automotive Reports. The week's output would be 24.4 percent ahead of the 142,013 cars assembled in the same week a year ago.

title: DOLLAR SHOWS STRENGTH IN WEST EUROPE TRADING
description: LONDON, July 14 (AP)The dollar recouped much of yesterday's losses against West European currencies today amid conjecture that the sinking American currency might stabilize. The price of gold rose in both the London and Zurich bullion markets.

title: Brigham Young Prospect
description: PROVO, Utah, (UPI)Hoping to find another Olympiccaliber basketball center, coach Frank Arnold of Brigham Young University, turned to Europe. Arnold said 7foot Paul Vos of Waalre, the Netherlands, has signed a letterofintent to attend B.Y.U. nest year. The last European center at the school was 611 Kresimir Cosic of Yugoslavia, who led his country to the silver medal in the 1976 Olympic Games.

title: Mechanical Response
description: The realization settled in hard after the 1965 blackout: New York is Electricity City. A massive power outage might handicap Chicago or Los Angeles but it would not have so paralyzing an impact. People outside New York might lose their radio alarms in the morning, but they would not be so dependent on electric pumps to bring them wash water, electric elevators to get them out of their homes, electric trains to take them to work, nor on the electronic nervous systems of such giant industries as securities, banking and communications to give them jobs.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 14Higher automobile insurance premiums for more than three million New Jersey motorists are about to be approved by James J. Sheeran, the State Commissioner of Insurance.

title: COURT UPHOLDS CURB ON STEINGUTS' TRIAL
description: The New York State Court of Appeals, by a 4to3 vote, ruled yesterday that Stanley Steingut, Speaker of the State Assembly, and his son, Robert, a Brooklyn Councilman at Large, could not be tried in Brooklyn on felony charges that they had violated the state election law.

title: Doctor Calls Bellevue Quieter Than in 1965
description: Dr. Robert S. Holzman, a Bellevue physician who worked there during the 1965 blackout, said he was struck by how much quieter the hospital was during the latest blackout.

title: The Crafts Fare Well at Danbury Fairgrounds
description: After a year away, the Itinerant artists and craftsmen who travel the circuit of shows, in the appropriate seasons, from Maine to Florida and hack again, will return this weekend to Danbury, showing their skills by day and campaing at night among the glassfiber pixies and storybook figures that lie about on the rooftops and loom from just about every corner of the sprawling fairgrounds.

title: Europeans Explain Why Blackout Was an American Phenomenon
description: LONDON, July 14 (AP)A New Yorkstyle power blackout is unlikely in Europe, British and other European power authorities said today.

title: Pope Off to Summer Home
description: ROME, July 14Pope Paul VI flew this afternoon by helicopter from the Vatican to the pontifical summer residence at Castelgandolfo, in the hills south of Rome. He is expected to stay there until September.

title: Inquiry Is Slated Into Two Deaths At Bellevue Hospital in Blackout
description: Limited power was restored yesterday afternoon at Bellevue Hospital, the eighthlargest community hospital in the country, whose emergency backup power supply failed, crippling medical services and foking doctors and nurses to squeeze air bags by hand to keep patients with respiratory failure alive.

title: When Poverty's Part of Life, Looting Is Not Condemned
description: A small wiry young man in a dingy white Tshirt and pants walked through the streets of East Harlem yesterday chanting this mournful lament:

title: The Standings
description: Friday, July 15, 1977

title: Books of The Times
description: THE THESIS of James J. Lynch's The Broken Heart: The Medical Consequences of Loneliness is so simple and obvious that one would hardly think it worth an entire book. There are physical consequences to emotional states? The most serious of them is what the loss of a loved one does to the heart? Why, we already knew as much, if only from that famous Life Change Index Scale compiled by Dr. L. T. Holmes and Dr. Richard Rahe, at the top of which was the loss of a spouse or close family member through death, divorce or separation.

title: The Begin Image
description: This is a strictly insidepage style note on the way Menahem Begin's manner, looks, voice and fierce identification with Old Testament Father Abraham, as if 6,000 years ago were yesterday, is bound to shake up assimilated American Jews when he comes over here.

title: Ford Cancels Agreement With U.S. To Test Airbag Safety Systems
description: DETROIT, July 14 (Reuters)The Ford Motor Company said today it was ending an agreement with the Federal Transportation Department to test airbag safety systems in some 1980 and 1981 model cars.

title: Critics Choices: A Sampler of Weekend Specialties
description: All right, so you have been spending your weekend days languorously working on your suntan and now you want to go out in the evening. To help you make your choices, here are the selections of eleven critics of The New York Times who spend their time going out for a living. Their recommendations of shows, exhibitions and programs represent those events they would go to themselves for the fun of it if they had a free weekend. But keeping the blackout in mind, it will be wise to check first to be sure the programs are on as scheduled.

title: WELFARE PLAN LINKS CUTS TO HOUSING AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The Carter Administration is considering whether it should cut back welfare allotments to lowincome families that also receive Federal housing subsidies.

title: State and Atlantic City Joining To Build LowCost Housing There
description: TRENTON, July 14State and Atlantic City officials will announce tomorrow the formation of a corporation to build lowcost housing in the resort city for many of the 14,000 poor and elderly people in danger of being dispossessed by the advent of gambling casinos. The total cost could be as high as $150 million.

title: NATION'S MONEY SUPPLY ROSE SHARPLY FOR WEEK
description: The nation's money supply, reflecting changes in the timing of Treasury distributions of Social Security checks, showed a distinct bulge in the week ended July 6, figures from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed yes terday.

title: Knicks Beseech Court in New York
description: The New Yolk Knicks opened a new legal front late yesterday in their continuing tugofwar with New Jersey and the peripatetic New York Nets franchise

title: Film: 'Outlaw Blues' Are County-Western Type
description: Like many junk foods, "Outlaw Blues," which went on sale at neighborhood theaters yesterday, is pleasantly palatable it not especially nutritious. Despite its aura of contrivance, Peter Fonda and the rest of an energetic cast help transform these "Blues" into a fairly lighthearted adventure set against the background of the country-and-western music scene.Of course, they make the most of a musical genre that has millions of devoted fans. Mr. Fonda makes his movie debut as a vocalist and guitarist, singing the title tune by John Oates, as well as other plaintive rural ditties by such country salwarts as Lee Clayton and Harlan sanders. But, to the credit of B. W. L. Norton's script, the film also strongly indicates the vicious competition and sleaziness that could lurk behind the glamorous facades of some of the medium's recording giants.Essentially, "Outlaw Blues" is a Mack Sennett-like chase with Mr. Fonda, as an ex-convict, in pursuit of James Callahan, playing the ruthless country star who has stolen Mr. Fonda's titular ballad. If our hero is a naive tyro at first, he is soon shown the light by Susan St. James, as a decorative tough cookie wise in the ways of this division of show business. As might be expected, sex and love get into the act.Richard T. Heffron, the director who has focused largely on documentaries, for example "Fillmore," has kept his cast in fairly constant motion in such authentic locales as Huntsville (Ala.) Prison, San Antonio and Austin, Tex., where the chase is centered. As noted, Miss St. James knows a good thing when she sees one, and, using a fracas in which the thieving star is accidentally shot, she proceeds to make a sought-after luminary out of her excon lover.If speeding cars and a speedboat are not particularly original action devices, they are colorful and occasionally funny as our fleeing principals and the police, headed by Buzz Cavanaugh (John Crawford), make their roaring, breakneck rounds through the city and its river.Come to think of it, the athletic cast is broadly oafish or devious in proper tongue-in-cheek style; Peter Fonda manages to be gently appealing and has a pleasant tenor voice, while Miss St. James is convincing as an expert conniver as well as being flip and pretty. "I've got the last laugh on you," Mr. Fonda's "Outlaw" sings, which isn't quite true considering his slight saga. But he and his company make it an amiable, lilting, if lightweight, diversion.Although the young fry are certainly accustomed to the type of violent speeding seen in "Outlaw Blues," some raunchy dialogue probably earned it its PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") rating.

title: Britain Makes LongShot Attempt To Head Off Big Wage Increases
description: LONDON, July 15Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey made a last, longshot attempt today to head off explosive wage increases that could imperil the British economyand doom the Labor Government to defeat by the Tories in the next general election.

title: Strike Snarls Italian Cities
description: ROME, July 15 (UPI)  Italy's main cities today had their worst traffic snarls in seven years with bus, streetcar and waterway workers staging a 24hour nationwide strike. Commuters driving to work were delayed up to two hours in Rome and Milan.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SOLEFUL SIGHTS Why not walk these summery days? It's the best way to explore the Big Apple, especially with an informative guide. There are two free tours every Sunday now, leaving Pier 16 of the South Street Seaport Museum area (Fulton Street and the East River). The landmark area of 19thcentury warehouses, counting houses, sailors' hotels and chandleries is one of the city's more fascinating. These tours last approximately 30 to 40 minutes. For more details, call the museum's education department at 7669062.

title: House Unit Lawyer Quits Korea Inquiry Alter Attack by Chief
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Philip A. Lacovara, special counsel of the House ethics committee's Korean investigation, resigned today after the committee chairman, Representative John J. Flynt Jr., criticized him publicly and ordered an audit of his legal fees.

title: Beame Tours Area of Looting
description: Poking his way through rubble, Mayor Beame briefly toured a riotscarred section of Brooklyn yesterday and immediately found himself beseiged with pleas for help and with some complaints from store owners that the police had shown too much restraint with the looters.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: BERGEN COUNTY 4H FAIR UNDER WAY: Picnickers watching the English horse show, featured at the Overpeck County Park Riding Center in Leonia yesterday. Today there will be an obedience dog show, an archery exhibition and antiques auction. Tomorrow's features will be a pet show, open to all, and a garden show.

title: U.S. BARS PLAINS COTTON FROM TRADING FOR A YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, July 15(AP)The Government today barred the Plains Cotton Cooperative Association, Lubbock, Tex.. from trading on any futures contract market for one year on the ground that the firm allegedly manipulated cotton prices in 1972.

title: ExJapanese Pilot Cites US. Ace
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., July 15 (UPI)The memory of the iirman for whom this base is named was honored today by a Japanese fighter pilot who was involved in the air battle in which Maj. Thomas B. McGuire was killed.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Friday, July 15, 1977

title: H. J. Rich, 89, Former Officer Of Shoe Retailers Association
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Herbert J. Rich, a former vice president of the National Shoe Retailers Association and leader of the business community in this city for many years, died yesterday at the age of 89.

title: Dr. Robert London, Expert in Treatment Of Abused Children
description: Dr. Robert D. London, the director of ambulatory care at Mount Sinai Hospital and a leading expert in pediatrics and the treatment of beaten children, died yesterday in Manhattan after undergoing heart surgery. He was 56 years old and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Deaths
description: KORSHAKOVSKAAnne, on July 14. 1977, after a long Illness. Her friends, colleagues and family mourn her passing. We will always remember her keen mind, her vital, intense personality. her loyalty and devotion to family and friends, and her sensitivity and dedication in helping troubled children and their families with whom she worked most of her life. Visiting Monday evening at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81 St. with services Tuesday 1 P.M.

title: Mets Lose, 71, Then Win, 61; Yanks Bow After Pep Talk
description: First, the fans at Shea Stadium were roasted by last night's 90degree heat. Then the Pirates and the Mets took turns roasting each other in a doubleheader, Pittsburgh winning the first game, 71, and New York the second, 61.

title: For the Aged, Camp Life's Slower, But Much Like That for Young
description: Tommy, Tommy, it's so good to see you, said Rae Abbott, a counselor at Camp Green Acres in Dover Plains, N.Y., giving the diminutive camper a big bear hug. You look so good.

title: 'Last Beau Geste' Is the Funniest:The Cast
description: Marty Feldman, the wild-eyed, cheerfully low-minded English comedian who was indispensable to Mel Brooks's "Young Frankenstein" ("Call me Eye-gore") and Gene Wilder's 'Sherlock Holmes' Smarter Brother," has now spun himself off, so to speak, as the star, director and co-author of his own frontal assault on cinema tradition and sensibility."The Last Remake of Beau Geste," which opened yesterday at the Sutton Theater, sends up just about everything, including a lot of things you may think you'd forgottensuch as the original Percival Christophere Wren novel, William A. Wellman's 1939 film version with Gary Cooper and all Foreign Legion movies. It also takes an extended dim view of gallantry, heroism, true love and honor while dealing in old husband-young wife jokes, jokes about female breasts, as well as a whole range of similar jokes that are funny primarily because they are in absolutely terrible taste.It is Mr. Feldman's marvelous conceit to cast himself and Michael York as identical twins, the adopted sons of aging Sir Hector Geste (Trevor Howard), who was so angry after his wife died in childbirth, leaving him with an infant daughter, that he took into his home (Geste Manor) a pair of ragamuffins from the Wormwood and Gaul Orphanage. Sir Hector raises Beau (Mr. York) to be a leader of men and poor little Digby (Mr. Feldman) to follow as well as to love his adopted sister, "the fair Isabel" (Sinead Cusack), from afar.The arrangement seems to work quite well until the very decrepit Sir Hector returns from a war in the Sudan with a new wife, Flavia, (Ann-Margaret). One night with Flavia and Sir Hector spends the rest of the movie in bed "alive," as the doctor says periodically, "and dying." After the famous Geste "Blue Water diamond" has been stolen, and the scheming Flavia has asserted her will to take control of the family, Beau and Digby, by separate routes, take off to join the French Foreign Legion.I think I may be telling you somewhat more of the plot than is necessary in an effort to keep from myself describing the film's gags, which are really what it's all about. I am trying not to tell you about Digby's brilliant break from jail with the wholehearted cooperation of the prison guards, and about his later meeting, in a desert mirage, with Gary Cooper in a secene from the Wellman film. Like many of the gags in the film, this latter involves some brilliantly clever crosscutting and results in a rather new image for Cooper.The movie's momentum, like that of 'Blazing Saddles," is dependent not at all on any narrative devices and entirely on the individual gags and the performances. Mr. Feldman has surrounded himself with some of the funniest people in the business. They include Mr. Howard; Spike Milligan as Sir Hector's ancient manservant, a fellow who sways like a pendulum when he walks; Peter Ustinov as the sadistic Foreign Legion sergeant, who calls his men "my little fledermouses," and rides a horse that has a pegleg like his own; James Earl Jones as a very Anglicized Arab chieftain, as well as Ann-Margaret and Mr. York, who must play things fairly straight.I'm not sure that Mr. Feldman, as a film's principal comedian, is as much fun as he is when he's part of an antic combination, as he was in both "Young Frankenstein" and "Sherlock Holmes' Smarter Brother." It's the nature of his comic personality that he is funniest when he is a member of a gang, adding a surreal visual touch as well as a presence that's slightly menacing because it's so unpredictable. As the staras well as the directorthere are moments when the desparation is apparent.Yet there are so few comedies of this rakish sort that one can't afford to be too particular. Also, one should not overanalyze it or over-report its comic highlights. Its laughs come as much from the shock of discovery as from what's being said or done."The Last Remake of Beau Geste," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"], contains a lot of explicit sexual and anatomical references that, if they don't go over the heads of youngsters, will probably strike them as the highest form of wit, mostly because they are consistently, often hilariously irreverent.

title: Guidry Victim in 74 Loss
description: KANSAS CITY, July 15Although not all his players took it as seriously as he did, George Steinbrenner today gave an address to his troops for the third time this season, imploring them to quit complaining and start playing harder for dear old Yankee U.

title: Stocks Inch Up in Heavy Volume; Con Ed Falls in Delayed Trading
description: Led by gains in leading computer issues, the stock market staged a modest advance yesterday following Thursday's forced closing because of New York City's power blackout.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: American Export Industries, holding company for the American Export Lines, yesterday filed a petition for arrangement with its creditors under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Coop City Leaders Arrive at Pact With State Aides on Project's Debt
description: Coop City residents would pay an average of 20 percent more in their monthly carrying charges and would increase their equity through additional payments under a tentative agreement reached between New York State officials and tenant leaders at the longtroubled Bronx cooperative.

title: Letters: On Abortion for the Poor
description: Your lead editorial July 5 Will Our Humanity Also Be Aborted? said with precision and eloquence. The decisions against making public funds available for abortions for poor women are outrageous and have large consequences.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended July 15, 1977

title: Mrs. Canter Takes Shot Lead
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, July 15 (AP)JoAnne Carner, using an unusual putting warmup, used only oneputt on 10 greens and posted her best round of the year today, a sixunderpar 66 for the firstround lead in an $80,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: New York Drawing Postponed
description: ALBANY, July 15 (APThe weekly New York State lottery drawing has been postponed from today to Monday because the New York City blackout delayed the processing of returns from ticket sellers.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 11% for Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Department of Commerce reported today that retail store sales last week totaled an estimated $14.17 billion, up 11 percent from the yearearlier $12.73 billion. Department store sales were about $1.26 billion, up 15 percent from last year's $1.09 billion.

title: Putting Is Name of Hatalsky's Game
description: SUTTON, Miss., July 15Morry Hatalsky, a 25yearold golf professional, has not been on the tour long enough to establish a presence or, for that matter, even a preference in first names Morry or Morris, he says, either one is fine.

title: Ravaged Slums Facing a Future Of Uncertainty
description: The feelings of outrage and despair in the neighborhoods that were plundered during the blackout were replaced yesterday by an el, en more overwhelming concerndid this devastation represent the death blow for these already failing areas?

title: Money
description: Friday, July 15, 1977

title: lbsen's The Master Builder Staged Steamily inWestport
description: WESTPORT, Conn.There is no Ibsen play with stronger sexual undertones than The Master Builder. The sexual aspect of the attraction between the builderartist Solness and Hilde, the young woman who becomes his fatal inspiration, is more than an undertone, in fact; it is an outspoken part of the play. But only a part.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JULY 16, 1977

title: McDonalds' Decides To Suspend Glasses
description: OAK BROOK, Ill., July 15 (UPI)McDonald's Corporation today suspended indefinitely its Glasses to Go promotion, citing the inability of Government agencies, to establish a definitive policy on decorated glasses.

title: Darien Cracks Down on Prostitutes Who Solicit Truckers by CB Radio
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 15 A band of alleged prostitutes who reportedly advertised by citizens' band radio and sold their services in the darkened parking lot of the Connecticut Turnpike rest stop here were arrested early this morning

title: Text of Admiral Turner's Letter on C.I.A. Drug Tests
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Following is the text of Admiral Turner's letter on C.I.A. drug experiments, as released by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: INVESTORS GROUP SEEKING DISTRIBUTION COST SHIFT
description: The largest mutual fund complex in the country, the Investors Group fund organization, and Investors Diversified Services, which provides investment advice and administrative services to the group ana is the exclusive distributor of the shares of its 10 funds, yesterday filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission that, if approved, would make the funds' shares more attractive to new investors.

title: Canadian Dancers Projecting New Image Without Nureyev
description: The image the New York public has formed of the National Ballet of Canada has, in the past, been less than accurate. The company's New York forays have always been as support troops to that formidably dashing captain, Rudolf Nureyev. As a result, we have seen Canadians at the Metropolitan Opera House in one classic ballet after anotherand all of them with Mr. Nureyev in the spotlight.

title: Weed the Schools but Save the Buds
description: There remains mu??h waste, inefficiency and corruption in New York City's school system that can be rooted out without harming the education of children. Reporters and other civic watchdogs have repeatedly exposed the diversion of scarce funds to profiteering custodians or to unnecessary adm nistrators. The blame for these conditions lies in the chronic coziness between the Board of Education and the uinions, often preserved with clandestine encouragement from City Hall. Moreover, too many local community school boards disdain financial accountability.

title: Like It Is to Show Report on Tensions In Southern Africa
description: A 90minute special report on the recent United Nations meeting in Mozambique on the volatile southern Africa si tuation will be broadcast tomorrow at 12:30 P.M on Channel 7's Like It Is, the weekly black news and puoljcaffairs pr ogram.

title: Coop City Leaders Arrive at Pact With State Aides on Project's Debt
description: Coop City residents would pay an average of 20 percent more in their monthly carrying charges and would increase their equity through additional payments under a tentative agreement reached between New York State officials and tenant leaders at the longtroubled Bronx cooperative.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: How to Pay for the Mail
description: The Postal Service's board of governors has, unfortunately, endorsed Postmaster General Bailar's confused scheme for raising the revenues from firstclass mail. The Postal Rate Commission still has to pass on this proposal, to charge businesses 16 cents a letter while retaining the 13cent rate for personal letters (among other expected increases). But there is little reason doubt that the commission will go along with a procedure that has con??e to seem like a ritual.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 15In the heat of the summer, the New Jersey state government doesn't close down completely. It just drifts along, with minor problems seemingly taking up everybody's time.

title: Duvall Film Is at the New Yorker
description: We're Not the Jet Set, a documentary feature directed by Robert Duvall, opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, 2409 Broadway, at 89th Street. It was shown at the Film Forum last month; a review by Vincent Canby appeared June 17.

title: Broman, Riding Escapade, Captures SmallPony Title
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., July 15Mr. and Mrs. Chester Broman's Escapade captured three of the four classes today and won the smallpony hunter championship at the opening session of the threeday Century horse show at the Old Field Club.

title: CubanU.S. Art Exchange Is Planned for 1980
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 15 (AP) Negotiations have been held in Havana for a possible exchange of Cuban and American artthe first since President Fidel Castro of Cuba took control the director of the Colorado Spi?? Arts Center announced this week.

title: A Glimpse at Bushwick's Broadway After the Looting
description: My God! My God! said Maria De Jest's, standing in front of a string of stores emptied by Icoters and ravaged by fires along Broadway in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. This is awful. What will we do now?

title: Deaths
description: PYLEAaron M., of Great Neck. N.V. Suddenly on July 15, 1977 Beloved husband of Leona, aevoted father of Joan P. Frankhauser. Dear brother of Katherine J. and the all Recite! A. He Is also survived by five grandcnlldren and two great grandchildren. Friends mar call at the Fliedner Funeral Home Inc., ISO Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, Saturday, the 16th from 7:30 P.M, to 11.30 P.M. Funeral service Sunday, July 1/ at 9:30 A.M. It Is requested that donations to St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn N.Y., would be altered/led. Interment, Mt. Hubron Cemetery. Flushing N.Y.

title: Leading Afrikaans Poet Acquitted Of Stirring Terrorism From Jail
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 15The trial of Breyten Breytenbach, perhaps South Africa's leading Afrikaans poet, reached an abrupt conclusion today when a judge in the supreme court here found him not guilty of promoting antiGovernment terrorism from an isolation cell in the maximum security block of Pretoria Central Prison.

title: Lawyer for Korea Inquiry Resigns Alter Personal Attack by Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Philip A. Lacovara, special counsel of the House ethics committee's Korean investigation, resigned today after the committee chairman, Representative John J. Flynt Jr., criticized him publicly and ordered an audit of his legal fees.

title: Patents
description: Certain organic chemicals, originally liquid and nonconductive, can be changed by ultraviolet light to solid conductors of electricity. Lines of the material, projected onto a paper can be turned into the equivalent of a pattern of wires. Page 31.

title: Labor Strife No Stranger to Indiana Town
description: ELWOOD, Ind., July 15Elwood seems, on first encounter, an unlikely setting for the violenceplagued strike that has been dragging on for more than three months at a small automotive Darts plant on the edge of town.

title: Sotheby's Artful Profits Draw Investors to Stock
description: LONDON, July 15In 1733, a young bookseller named Samuel Baker, with offices near Covent Garden, issued his first catalogue, offering a choice library of books consisting of history, antiquity, divinity, physick, mathematics, law, novels and romances, etc.

title: Help for the Displaced Homemaker
description: ALBANY  They are called displaced homemakers, women suddenly cast adrift in an unfamiliar world, and now the Legislature has passed a bill to help them find a new role.

title: New York's Legislature Recesses After It's Passage Of a Year's Extension of PrisonerRelease Program
description: ALBANY, July 15The 200th session of the New York State Legislature was gaveled into recess today after approving a oneyear extension of the controversial temporaryrelease program for prisoners.

title: Phils Sweep Cubs, 42, 92, and Trail by 2 Games
description: The baseball season has just about reached the halfway mark, and the nobodies from Chicago are still leading the Eastern Division of the National League.

title: Shoulders Abound, as Sundress Blossoms
description: The noontime girl watchers, perched like birds around office buildings, are looking more cheerful these days. They lost their view of legs when the mini became pass, and things got pretty boring. Now they have a lot of delectably tanned shoulders to whistle at.

title: 5 WHO ESCAPED RIKERS RECAPTURED AFTER A TIP
description: Five prisoners who escaped from the Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island Thursday were recaptured by the police after a tip from a sixth escapee who never left the island.

title: Commodiy Price Index Declined To 202.5 From 207.1 in the Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 202.5 from 207.1 last week

title: Italian Communists Back Government On a Key Program
description: ROME, July 15For the first time in 30 years, the Italian Communist Party today expressed support for the Government in Parliament, endorsing a new platform for the 11monthold Cabinet of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti.

title: President Approves Plan to Admit 15,000 More Indochinese Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, July 15President Carter gave approval today to a State Department request to admit 15,000 Indochinese refugees to the United States, including the 7,000 buat people still living on the vessels they used to flee from Vietnam.

title: For the Aged, Camp Life's Slower, But Much Like That for Young
description: Tommy, Tommy, it's so good to see you, said Rae Abbott, a counselor at Camp Green Acres in Dover Plains, N.Y., giving the diminutive camper a big bear hug. You look so good.

title: House Passes Mine Safety Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI)  The House voted today to put metal and nonmetal mines under the sam health and safety regulations as coal mines and to give jurisdiction to the Department of Labor. The measure passed on a 244toSS vote and was sent to the Senate. Coal and noncoal miners have been covered by separate health and safety laws under Interior Department jurisdiction.

title: New York Drawing Postponed
description: ALBANY July 15 (AP)The weekly New York State lottery drawing has been postponed from today to Monday because the New York City blackout delayed the processing of returns from ticket sellers.

title: Looting and Lightning
description: The problem is the politicians. Why did they let the cops surrender the streets to the looters?

title: CON ED DELAY CITED AS A POSSIBLE CAUSE
description: The Consolidated Edison Company may have lost its entire system Wednesday night because, fearful of public hostility and lawsuits, it held out tot) long before cutting out limited parts of the system, according to some of those who investigated the 1965 blackout.

title: Balanchine Day in Saratoga Springs
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 15  Men, women and children lined the sidewalks this afternoon, and traffic stopped on Broadway, where Lillian Russell and Diamond Jim Brady once rode. There were cheers and whistles as a slight, dapper man rode by in an antique surrey, preceded by a marching band and a 1935 fire engine on which smiling dancers perched precariously. It was George Balanchine Day in this ancient capital of summer racing and summer splendor that is now a modern capital of summer ballet.

title: Oil Pipeline Workers Criticized
description: ANCHORAGE, July 15The National Transportation Safety Board late today made public a finding that workers on the TransAlaska oil pipeline failed to follow the operating company's own written procedures in the events leading up to the explosion July 8 that shut down the line, killed one person and injuring five.

title: Wisconsin Phone Service Disrupted for 5 Hours
description: MILWAUKEE, July 15 (AP)A major telephone cable connecting Wisconsin with other states was repaired and service returned to normal today after a fivehour disruption, a spokesmanforWisconsin Telephone Company said.

title: June Industrial Output Up; Inventories Rose in May
description: WASHINGTON. July 15Paced by an especially encouraging strong advance in output of business equipment, industrial production scored a gain of seventenths of 1 percent in June, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Mine Explosion in Colombia
description: MEDELLIN, Colombia, July 15 (UPI)Authorities said today 40 miners were still unaccounted for in a gas explosion that killed at least 100 miners at a coal mine in a remote town about 125 miles southeast of here.

title: Deaths
description: ABELDr. Norman K., on July 13, 1977. Beloved husband of Evelyn C., devoted father of Dr. Edward Abel. Alison and Barbara, dear brother of Dr. Selig Abel, loving fatherIntaw of Jane and brotherInlaw of Anne Abel. Services were held Friday, Westchester Riverside, Mt. Vernon. Shiva at his late residence, Ill Tewkesbury Rd., Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Notes on People
description: Now in the 59th year of his naval career, Adm. Hyman G. Rickover was reappointed yesterday, to no on'es surprise, to a new twoyear term as head of the Navy Nuclear Propulsion Program. Admiral Rickover, who is 77 years old, technically retired from the service in 1964 but has continued to be on active duty on special twoyear extensions. The new extensions will permit the admiral, the chief developer of today's nuclear naval force, to serve until January, 1980.

title: Dollar Gains Against Yen
description: TOKYO, July 15 (AP)The dollar continued to rise against the Japanese yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange matket today, closing at 265.275 yen compared with yesterday's closing 264.70 yen.

title: U.S. to Hold New York Fiscal Data Until After the Primary Election
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission, indicating they were aware that the agency's forthcoming report on New York City's fiscal crisis could affect the mayoral primary and damage Mayor Beame's reelection campaign, do not plan to issue the report until after the Sept. 9 primary. Advance reports have indicated that the draft S.E.C. report issued by the commission's New York City office is severely critical of Mayor Beame and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, as well as one of the major New York City banks. The investigation sought to determine whether fraud was perpetrated or agency regulations violated in the actions leading up the the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Chairman Says House Energy Panel Will Back Increase in Gasoline Tax
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The House ad hoc committee on energy held its first meeting today and, afterward, its chairman predicted committee approval for an increased gasoline tax, relaxation of proposed requirements for insulating buildings, tightening of coal conversion measures and about 20 other changes in the proposed energy package.

title: About New York
description: It was society's turn yesterday, following up en the blackout by attending to some of the hundreds of alleged looters rounded up by the police. James V. Vinci, the head of the Legal Aid Society's criminal defense staff in Manhattan, prepared for the occasion with four stiff bourbons before he went to bed at 2 A.M.

title: Most Cocoa Futures Rise By 6CentsaDay Limit; Dutch Grinding a Factor
description: Most cocoa futures contracts jumped the daily limit of 6 cents a pound yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The September contract closed at $2.21 a pound, up from $2.15 on Wednesday. There was no trading Thursday because of the New York power blackout.

title: Jets, Fillers Get Feel of Powell's Strength
description: HEMPSTEAD, L I., July 15Somehow, Marvin Powell and Larry Pillers survived their first meeting today.

title: People in Sports
description: Bernard King, the New York Nets' No. 1 draft choice, has been arrested for the second time this week. The 22yearold University of Tennessee allAmerican from Brooklyn, who gave up his senior year to apply for the National Basketball Association hardship draft, was picked up by Knoxville police yesterday and charged with prowling, resisting arrest and possession of marijuana. He was released on $600 bond.

title: Congressional Agency Denounces Plan to Sell Radar System to Iran
description: WASHINGTON, July 15A confidential report by the General Accounting Office has strongly criticized the Administration's decision to sell seven highly sophisticated airborne radar systems to Iran.

title: DROUGHT THREATENS CROPS IN 30% OF U.S.
description: We're verging on water bankruptcy, Paul 3. Waite said recently. A good third of the state is virtually out of subsoil moisture.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: 1. New York and Westchester County were hit hard by a power blackout this week. Another serious blackout occurred here some years ago. When did this previous blackout occur?

title: In Wake of Blackout, Agents Find Little Spoiled Food in Markets
description: An allday check of more than 1,000 restaurants, supermarkets, delicatessens and bakeries yesterday by approximately 90 city health inspectors found few violations and virtually no spoiled or tainted foods being served or sold to the public following the city's Wednesday night blackout.

title: Bridge:
description: CHICAGO, July 15As the Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon, with the master team championship initiating 10 days of play, the Grand National knockout team event drew to a close.

title: DISASTER STATUS GIVEN NEW YORK AND WESTCHESTER TO SPEED LOANS; SERVICES RESUME AFTER BLACKOUT
description: The Small Business Administration conferred disaster area status on New York City and Westchester County yesterday as investigations, damage assessments and cleanup operations began in the aftermath of the 25hour blackout that spawned widespread looting and arson.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Earnings Statistics Are Reported by Banks
description: BRestated for 25 percent stock dividend Jan., 1977.

title: DRUG TESTS BY CIA. HELD MORE EXTENSIVE THAN REPORTED IN '75
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Central Intelligence Agency said today that it had found additional information that an unknown number of Americans, including alcoholics, drug addicts and terminal cancer patients, apparently were unwitting subjects of drug experiment programs conducted by the agency in the 1950's and 1960's.

title: ExShoe Executive Is Held as Smuggler Of 6 Lbs. of Cocaine
description: A former president of the I. Miller Shoe Company was arraigned in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of smuggling approximately six pounds of cocaine into the United States from Lima, Peru.

title: Redlining a Topic as Senate Airs Choice of McKinney for S.&L. Job
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Praise for the nominee and allegations of conflict of interest were aired today as the Senate began confirmation hearings on the nomination of Robert H. McKinney for chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: Fumes in Las Vegas Hotel Leave One Dead, 100 Hurt
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 15 (AP)One person died and about 100 were treated after carbon monoxide gas wafted through the 31story Landmark Hotel today officials said.

title: Stores Anxious About Insurance
description: Business in thousands of New York City's department stores, food stores, shopping centers and neighborhood shops returned to a semblance of normality yesterday, after Thursday's virtual shutdown of shopping facilities because of the blackout.

title: Despite Some Looting Westchester Weathered Blackout Well
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 15Westchester County. which was almost completely blacked out by the power failure Wednesday night, did not fare too badly in the crisis, according to Alfred B. DelBello, the County Executive.

title: Lance, Seeking to Hold Bank Stock, Offers Safeguards Against Conflict
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Bert Lance, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, told a Senate committee today that he would take further administrative steps to avoid a conflict of interest if the committee would release him from a pledge to sell 207,000 shares of Georgia bank stock before the end of this year.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JULY 16, 1977

title: Tunisia and Italy Sign Accord For Construction of Gas Line
description: TUNIS, July 15, (Reuters)Tunisia and Italy today signed an agreement for the construction of a gas pipeline beneath the Mediterranean, which separates them, an official announcement here said.

title: Balanchine Day in Saratoga Springs
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 15 Men, women and children lined the sidewalks this afternoon, and traffic stopped on Broadway, where Lillian Russell and Diamond Jim Brady once rode. There were cheers and whistles as a slight, dapper man rode by in an antique surrey, preceeded by a marching band and a 1935 fire engine on which smiling dancers perched precariously. It was George Balanchine Day in this ancient capital of summer racing and summer splendor that is now a modern capital of summer ballet.

title: StarSpangled Slapstick Songs
description: The StarSpangled Washboard Band, which is performing at Tra??p's for the next two weeks, is reminiscent of collision between the Earl Scruggs Review and the Three Sioogres. The group offers equal parts countyrock and slapstick, and if the humor is sometimes funny and someth es simply silly, the music is also a ??ture of fine playing and pure corn.

title: SEALAW CONFERENCE ENDS INCONCLUSIVELY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 15Eight weeks of negotiations for a treaty covering the uses of the oceans and mining of seabed minerals ended inconclusively today with participants from 145 countries deciding to make a further try next year to complete the treaty talks begun in 1973.

title: Policeman Slain by Partner's Gun In Scuffle With a Robbery Suspect
description: A 34yearold city police officer was fatally shot with a service revolver seized from his partner by a robbery suspect yesterday afternoon as the officers tried to handcuff him in the Inwood section of the upper West Side, the police said.

title: Some Parking Rules Remain Suspended
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will remain suspended today, New York City's Traffic Commissioner, Theodore Karagheuzoff, announced yesterday after consulting with Anthony T. Vaccarello, Commissioner of Sanitation.

title: U.S. Aides Meeting With North Korea On Copter Incident
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, July 16American and North Korean negotiators met this morning at the Panmunjom truce site to discuss what North Korea described as the unhappy downing of an American helicopter in its territory.

title: WILLIAM GERHARDIE, AN ENGLISH NOVELIST
description: LONDON, July 15 (AP)The English novelist William Gerhardie, once de, scribed as a genius by George Bernard Shaw and H. Cl. Wells, died today. He was 81 years old.

title: Carter Hints Support For Bill Raising Age Of Retirement to 70
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)President Carter indicated today that he would favor legislation to bar private concerns from imposing mandatory retirement on workers before they reach age 70.

title: How Party Platforms Vary
description: TRENTON, July 15New Jersey Democrats and Republicans have completed their biennial chores of adopting political manifestoes, known as party platforms, and their latest documents establish the state income tax as the major issue in the election campaigns for Governor and State Legislature.

title: Two Blackouts and a World of Difference
description: On Nov. 9, 1965, when the lights went out all over the Northeast, Lawrence Bailey was a high school student living on West 123d Street. He recalls the scene well.

title: Carter Compromise Would Make Election Day Registration Optional
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  Presieont Carter has agreed to accept a major concession to opponents of his proposal for Election Day registration by making the plan optional for states rather than compulsory.

title: Carter Will Name Lowenstein And Mezvinsky to U.N. Posts
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI)President Carter will nominate two former members of CongressAllard K. Lowenstein and Edward M. Mezvinskyto posts on the United States delegation to the United Nations, the White House announced today.

title: Close Calls in Recent Harness Races
description: when he triumphed with Steve's Friend in the $227,500 Hollywood Derby in California. Now, in Fleet Victress, he has what seems to be a consistent moneywinner. She has been in the money in nine of her last 10 outings. Five of those finishes produced victories.

title: Dave Anderson
description: With the whrrrr of his electric wheelchair, Roy Campanella was moving through the corridor of the fourth floor the Rusk Institute yesterday, saying goodbye to the friends he had made there among the patients and nurses and doctors for the last year. ??ddenly a nurse pulled a shiny baseball out of a box for ?? to sign.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Susan L. Guthrie Is Bride Of Alfred Stephen Ceresa
description: Susan Lynne Guthrie, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Robert Jordan Guthrie of Harrison, N.Y., was married last evening to Alfred Stephen Ceresa. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Ceresa of Whitestone, Queens.

title: New York City Fire Union Elects Vizzini
description: Richard J. Vizzini, who four years ago led New York City's firemen in the only strike in Fire Department history, won back the top post of the 8,500member Uniformed Firefighters Association yesterday by defeating the incumbent president, Michael J. Maye.

title: Carter's Political Dichotomy
description: WASHINGTON, July 15After nearly six months, Jimmy Carter remains an enigmatic figure to many people in the capital, particularly to Northern Democrats who have trouble adjusting to the conservative tenor of some of his pronouncements after a cam paign marked by the compassionate rhetoric of reform. And, as one Senate liberal observed today, he shook us again this week with his surprisingly coldeyed comments about social inequality and the limits of government responsibility in social issues as he answered a news conference question about the latest Supreme Court ruling on, abortion.

title: Nurse Verdict Stuns 2 Alternate Jurors
description: DETROIT, July 15 (UPI)Two alternate jurors who sat through the threemonth trial of two Filipino nurses conviced of poisoning hospital patients said today that they had been surprised by the verdict.

title: Senate Panel Backs Carter, Eliminates Restrictions on Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 15A key Senate subcommittee gave strong support to the Carter Administration today and struck from a pending foreign aid bill provisions that would have barred the World Bank from using American funds in loans to Vietnam and six other countries.

title: Bill to Aid Empire Mutual Insurance Voted in Albany
description: ALBANY, July 15The New York Legislature, in its final hour, authorized a $40 million state loan to rescue the beleaguered Empire Mutual Insurance Company and avert the cancellation of 335,000 automobile liabilityinsurance policies.

title: Cosmos Defeated Again on Road, 10
description: ROCHESTER, July 15The Cosmos lost their f fth straight game on the road tonight, bowing to the Rochester Lancers, 10, in a shootout. That is the North American Soccer League's way of deciding games still tied after regulation time and a 15minute overtime.

title: Grandson of Groucho Marx May Be Named His Conservator
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 15Andy Marx, the 27yearold grandson of Groucho Marx, may be named permanent conservator for the ailing comedian.

title: DAVID KRECH, 68, DIES; PSYCHOLOGY PIONEER
description: David Krech, a pioneering experimental psychologist who demonstrated that animals raised in an enriched environment had larger brains and behaved more intelligently than animals from impoverished environments, died Thursday following a heart attack last Saturday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: SYLVESTER W. LABROT 3D
description: Sylvester Welch Labrot 3d, a photographer, painter and printmaker whose work was shown at the Museum of Modern Art and various art galleries, died Thursday of cancer. Mr. Leaot, who exhibited under the name of Syl Labrot, lived at 36 East 10th Street and was 47 years old.

title: Hernandez Is Riding With Luck
description: Ruben Hernandez, a 25yearold jockey from Panama, was watching Angel Cordero and Jorge Velasquez oppose two other jockeys in a Ping Pong game in Belmont Park's jockey room yesterday.

title: JUSTICE UNDER FIRE RESIGNS TEXAS POST
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 15Justice Donald B. Yarbrough of the Texas Supreme Court, faced with removal action by a joint legislative session, as well as indictment and disbarment pzoceedings, resigned today.

title: INVESTIGATIONS OPEN ON BLACKOUT CAUSES
description: Amid many questions about the Con??olidated Edison Company's actions to prevent a systemwide blackout Wednesday night after lightning strokes cut off half of its power supply, and about the ??lowness of the restoration of service, official investigations began yesterday into the blackout's causes, and into ways of nreventing a recurrence.

title: Darien Begins a Crackdown on Prostitutes Who Solicit Truck Drivers by CB Radios
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 15Alleged prostitutes who reportedly advertised by citizens' band radio and sold their services in the darkened parking lot of the Connecticut Turnpike rest stop here were arrested early this morning.

title: Deaths
description: DEUTSCHBarry Robert. In Switzerland, July 3, 1977. Beloved son of Diana Deutsch and the late Jack. Dear brother of Phyllis Sliver and Marlene Salvatore. Service Sunday 11 am Westchester Riverside 21 West Broad St., Fleetwood, Mt. Vernon. Chapel visitation Saturday evening 79 pm.

title: Upgrading of Amtrak's Corridor To Be Cut Back in Economy Move
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Department of Transportation said today that cutbacks had to be ordered in its program of upgrading Amtrak's WashingtonNew YorkBoston rail corridor in order to stay within the $1.75 billion in funds approved by Congress.

title: The DoubleDouble Fault
description: JERUSALEM  Previous United States and Israeli administrations made two fatal mistakes, in 1973 and again in 1976, which greatly complicated the situation both in the world power balance and in the Middle East, according to Gen. Ariel Sharon.

title: Kennedy Center Closes Foyer
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)  The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, plagued by construction problems since it opened six years ago, closed its huge grand foyer entrance lobby last night while engineers studied the safety of its leaky roof. No decision has beep made over how soon the foyer might be; reopened, a spokesman said, but the problem will not effect the center's three, major halls. Scheduled productions continue.

title: New York City Jails Are Crowded With Those Waiting Arraignment
description: With 3,776 persons arrested in the looting and violence that followed the power failure, the city's hot jail cells were jammed yesterday, and two thirds of those behind bars had yet to go before a judge to hear the charges against them, post bail and go home.

title: Service To an Aging Tyrant
description: This column became 15 years old the other day, which is a lot older than it sounds. Newspaper columns, like cats, age much faster than people, so that a 15yearold column is actually about the same age as a 70yearold man and subject to the same problems. This one, for example, doesn't move as fast as it used to, becomes more and more longwinded, and is not so quick any more to wink at a pretty girl.

title: 'Orca,' Whale Film, Flounders
description: If it were medically possible to overdose on claptrap, "Orca," which opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters, would be compelled to carry a warning from the Surgeon General.Awash in pseudo-science, blarney, Indian munbo-jumbo, anthropomorphism, plain old-fashioned superstition, bug-eyed fear and the ill-concealed yearning of its screenwriters to humble "Jaws," this film about whales and men flounders after about 15 minutes.By that time, "Orca" has informed its audience that the killer whales, which are its chief grace, may possess an intelligence superior to man's. Nothing said by the humans for the rest of the movie does anything to raise doubts about that.Speaking in simple idiocies, the characters in "Orca" (Latin for whale)chief among them Richard Harris as a fisherman, Charlotte Rampling as a cetologist, Will Sampson as a font of Indian lore, and Keenan Wynn, Bo Derek and Peter Hooten as various forms of whale fodder  proceed on a doomed course.It begins when Mr. Harris, hoping to pay off the mortgage on his boat by capturing a killer whale, manages instead to mortally maim a pregnant female of the species. Such whales, the audience has been informed, are monogamous. The bereaved male then proceeds to stalk Mr. Harris and to challenge him to a duel.Before the finale amid the ice floes off Labrador, several people have been Killed, one has lost a leg, a few boats have been sunk, a house has been destroyed and a fuel dump has gone up in flames.The finale is chiefly notable for diverting the audience's attention from the action by raising the possibility that Miss Rampling concealed a couturier and a makeup expert aboard Mr. Harris's boat en route to the showdown.The outset of "Orca" is marked by some lyrical and touching scenes involving killer whales. But thereafter this movie offers nothing but total immersion in the ridiculous."Orca's" PG rating ("Parental Guidance Suggested") is probably attributable to a goriness that revolts even its characters, and not to the single rapid scene of the attractive, carefully draped Bo Derek in bed with Peter Hooten nor to some mild expletivs.

At Seabrook, N.H., a massive citizen force of antinuclear protesters went beyond demonstrations and free speech. They forcibly and unlawfully occupied an area of private property slated for construction of a nuclear plant. They were arrested, convicted and fined.

title: Tikal: The First Skyscrapers

Traders brought shells and fish from the Caribbean and the Pacific, jade and obsidian from the mountains. Emissaries journeyed from other Mayan centers like Copn, Honduras; Palenque, Ecuador, and Teotihuacan in Mexico.

title: TV VIEW
description: The litany of arguments against imported programming is familiar and objectively unassailable. Acquisitions from abroad tend to become excuses for avoiding domestic quality productions, which are costly and thus a special problem for public television and its threadbare budgets. As imports increase, protectionists can argue that they deny employment to American writers, directors, technicians and actors. And, on a more abstract level, as purchases generally focus on the better programs available, perceptions in this country of foreign TV systems are undoubtedly distorted. Few essays are more durable, or boring, than the one explaining that British television can be even sillier than its American counterpart, that it is not an unending schedule of such programs as Civilization or Upstairs, Downstairs.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: It is 185 years since Mozart died at age 35 of a still unknown cause and was dumped hurriedly into a common grave along with 16 others (14 beggars and two suicides). Although he was the liveliest and friendliest men in life, his body was accompanied to the pauper's graveyard outside Vienna by a cortege of only five persons, and all of them turned back when a rainstorm came up. As a result, to this day no one knows where the unpainted coffin bearing his remains was planted. There is, in fact, hardly a statement that can be made about Mozart's illness and death that could not be challenged by a partisan of one another of the many theories about his final days. The subject has been a breeding ground for mystery and myth since that December day in 1791.

title: Police Cars Bombed in Brittany
description: SAINTBRIEUC, France, July 16 (AP)Four explosive charges went off simultaneously in a public parking lot in this port city in Brittany early today, damaging three police cars and three police vans. It was not clear who was responsible for the attack, but last February when explosions damaged six other police cars in SaintBrieuc, a group called the Brittany Liberation Front said it had set of those blasts to dramatize its campaign for more local autonomy.
