title: FRANCOIS RABELAIS: A STUDY
description: This is a professor's book, written for specialists in 16thcentury French literature, couched in academic terms and replete with problems of dating, long reviews of the scholarship and extensive summaries of Rabelais great works, Pantagruel and Gargantua. The wonder is that it comes to us under the imprint of a trade publisher; it seems to me it might have been more comfortably housed with a scholarly press.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IN TRADITIONAL menu planning, a main course, more often than not, is served with a starch such as rice or potatoes, plus a green vegetable. Quite obviously, when planning a meal to be cooked in limited time, if you can combine all these elements in one casseroleand in less time than it takes to prepare each separatelyyou are ahead of the game.

title: Violence Not Needed to Bring Socialism to U.S., Newton Says
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 16Huey P. Newton, president and cofounder of the Black Panther Party, says he no longer believes that a violent revolution is necessary to bring socialism to the United States.

title: ReElection of Mine Workers' Head Officially Certified by Union Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)Arnold Miller's reelection as president of the 270,000member United Mine Workers of America has been officially certified by a panel of three union tellers that rejected a challenge by Lee Roy Patterson.

title: Moslems Protest Movie Showing
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 16 (AP) About 500 Turkish Moslems demonstrated today outside a Munich theater to protest the showing of the movie Mohammed, Messenger of God. There were no arrests but policemen were called out to guard the theater. The demonstrators said that the movie, which depicts the life of the founder of Islam, offended the Koran, the Moslem holy book.

title: Of Special Interest
description: Billy Wilder Retrospective

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Contemporary feminism is now fruitfully looking back to its roots, to see what women's sphere was like in the two centuries before its breakthrough. Nancy F. Cott is a historian who has brought together in this well but not oppressively researched and readable book some of what is known of women's experience in New England in the years 17801835. She writes, in summary:

title: North Koreans Return 3 Bodies, Free Crewman
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 16  The bodies of three American helicopter crewmen, shot down Thursday over North Korea, were returned to the United States authorities today. The bodies were borne across the military demarcation line dividing the armistice site of Panmunjom.

title: IBM Reports
description: World population is increasing at more than 200,000 every day. It is expected to double in the next 25 years. Where will the additional food come from? What of the other resources needed to sustain economic growth and provide a better life for the individual on this shrinking planet?

title: Votes in Congress
description: Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area

title: DINING OUT
description: WHEN a recommendation for a Bolognese restaurant in Croton Falls originates in Bologna, Italy, one can hardly resist. Actually, that was simply the last of a string of raves before our recent visit.

title: Scenes From a Campaign
description: FOR the first time in anyone's memory, Nassau County has a primary election campaign in the County Executive race. And then Nassauone of the biggest suburban counties in the nationdoes something, it does it big.

title: Toll Bridge in Search of a Taker
description: WATERVILLE, Me., July 16The TwoPenny Footbridge, spanning the Kennebec River between Waterville and Winslow, is looking for a toll collector again.

title: Bradford Hill Marries Lee Edwards in Virginia
description: Lee Ellen Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Jennelle Edwards of Richmond, was married there yesterday to Bradford Aaron Hill, son of Mr. and Mrs. James I. Hill of Manhasset and Westhampton, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Leslie Tunnell West in the Forest Hill Presbyterian Church.

title: New Paralysis, New Symptoms: Much Uglier
description: Charles F. Luce, the chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company, had an explanation that left little room for mortal secondguessing. He blamed an act of God in the form of three lightning bolts for the power failure that for a full day disrupted the lives of nine million people in New York City and its northern suburbs.

title: Boeing Picked by NASA to Design And Build World's Biggest Windmill
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (Reuters)The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has chosen the Boeing aircraft company to build the world's largest windmilL with rotors 300 feet in diameter.

title: Katonah's Caramoor: A Villa Goes Public
description: Keep Caramoor a home, keep it a living thing. Don't turn it into a museum. Those were the sentiments of the late James Rorimer when he was director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. And they turn out to be the sentiments of the foundation that today operates the 54room Mediterranean villa on a 118acre esate in Katonah, N.Y., some 40 miles north of Manhattan.

title: Marjorie Mehrhot Wed To Mark Alan Salomon
description: Marjorie Lyn Mehrhof, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth C. Mehrhof of Montville, N. J. was married last evening to Mark Alan Salomon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Salomon of Winter Haven, Fla. The Rev. John Miller performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Presbyterian ChurchontheGreen in Morristown. N. J.

title: Old Folks Hop On Travel Bandwagon
description: The bus broke down an hour after leaving the cityan electrical failure the driver couldn't repair. For four hours the 47 of us sat on Interstate 84 near Brewster, N.Y. I was fumingbut not my fellow passengers. They were singing, dancing the hustle by the roadside, shouting answers to a trivia quiz. Of course, they were much older than I.

title: A Fabulous Talent for Invective
description: FEW people stranger than Frederick Rolfe have ever lived. The man who called himself Baron Corvo and signed his books Fr. Rolfe to create the impression that he was a priest, who had be carried out to the street on his bed when he was expelled from a Catholic college in Rome, who was said to have brought amazement, fear, and repulsion to everyone he met, and who ended his life as a gondolier in Venice, floating about the lagoons in a boat with handpainted sails that John Cowper Powys likened to the barge of Cleopatra': this was no mere eccentric, but a literary genius whose works were as singular as their author. Hadrian the Seventh, a novel he published in 1904 about an impoverished British writer who finds himself elected Pope, is one of the most bizarre works of fiction in the language, while his Chronicles the House of Borgia rivals Burckhardt's classic history of the Renaissancein style and passion not in

title: Monmouth
description: FIRST$6,000, cl., 3YO and up, 1??m.

title: Katherine Hogan, Michael Aronstein Plan Fall Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. William T. Hogan of Fair Haven, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Ann Hogan, to Michael Charles Aronstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Burton Aronstein of New York and Monroe, N.Y. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Illinois Man Sentenced to 8 Years In $1.7 Million Digital Watch Fraud
description: CHICAGO, July 16 (UPI)Dennis I. Roberts, the owner of Teltronics Ltd., was sentenced to eight years in prison and fined $50,000 yesterday for defrauding thousands of persons in a scheme in which he advertised nonexistent digital watches at bargain prices.

title: Tax Exemptions for Ministers Of Small Sect Are Fait Accompli
description: KINGSTON, N.Y., July 16An upstate Tax Assessor who has granted exemptions to 213 Universal Life Church ministers filed his final tax roll this week after attempts to constrain him failed.

title: Stadium to Be Aglow With AllStars Tuesday
description: George Steinbrenner, who has spent a fortune trying to bring an allstar team to Yankee Stadium, will finally get his wish Tuesday night when baseball's 48th AllStar Game will be staged in the Bronx home of the New York Yankees.

title: POLITICS
description: CAMPAIGNING during the summer months can often be a hitormiss proposition, as Governor Byrne demonstrated over the Fourth of July weekend, when he took a helicopter ride to Ocean Grove to address a gathering at the auditorium there and then flew north to Jersey City.

title: Economic Man Acquires a Soul
description: Leibel Bestritzky, who operates a kosher grocery at 27 Essex Street on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, is nobody's Economic Manthat profitmaximizing creature who stalks through the pages of economics textbooks and dominates economic theory.

title: Conformity May Be Old Hat, But Beware the Building Inspector
description: People in the suburbs don't worry any more about what the neighbors think of their behavior.

title: You've Heard of the World's Best Golf Courses
description: While watching a telecast of the recent United States Open golf championship from the immaculate Southern Hills Country Club in Tulsa, I was reminded that only a handful of courses meet the stringent requirements for this important event. I have never played any of these courses. However, I have played a few that would definitely not merit consideration by the United States Open advisory committee.

title: EFFORT PRESSED TO ACHIEVE TRUCE IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 16Active discussions are under way involving Lebanon, Syria and the Palestinians tostabilize the situation in Lebanon and achieve a truce in the south.

title: THE 34TH PRECINCT MOURNS COLLEAGUE
description: The flag above the 34th Precinct station house far up on the West Side of Manhattan hung at half staff yesterday, limp and lifeless in the damp heat. Over the arched stone entrance someone had draped a black and purple funeral sash.

title: Demarcations of Local Waters Affected by New Maritime Rules
description: A new set or international ship traffic rules went into effect on Friday.

title: Paula S. Kirschenbaum Is Engaged to Robert B. Stein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kirschenbaum of Springfield, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paula Susan Kirschenbaum, to Robert Bruce Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Stein of East Meadow. L.I.

title: Dance
description: AMERICAN DANCE FESTIVALToday, 5:30: Harry. Thur., 8: Arthur Hall and members of the AfroAmerican Dance Ensemble. Fri.Sat., 8: Pilobolus Dance Theater. Next Sun., 5:30: Danny Williams Grossman and Dance Company. New London, Conn.( 2034429131)

title: New Voices From Africa
description: EVEN before the beginnings of political independence, the established writers of many African nations had been concerned with exploring the damage done to indigenous values by European colonialism. This older generation of writers established a foals that, though not antiEuropean, attempted to deal with the experience of colonialism, much of it bitter, from the African point of view. But now a new generation of writers is appearing, men and women whose vision is turned inward, who seem concerned less with Europeans than with the evolving or conflicting values of their own societies.

title: Gladys L. Busk Married in Greenwich To William H. Thorn Jr., a Yacht Broker
description: Gladys Louise Busk, daughter of Joseph R. Busk Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the Iate Gladys Terbell Busk, was married there yesterday in the Round Hill Community Church to William Henry Thorn Jr., son of Mr. Thorn of Bronaville, N. Y., and the late Patricia Phelps Thorn. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Dr. William Reid, was followed by a reception at the Round Hill Club.

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: Low average and unknowing bowlers they aren't always one and the same often are confused about an aspect of the game that really should be made to work for themthe ball track.

title: Memorial Seruires
description: GLEESONAlice Pearson, 12 July 1964. A low mass of requlem was offered In Latin by a Father of the Society of Jesus.

title: How the New Models Shape Up
description: DETROITHere's the lineup of 10 owreally new1978 models that United States automobile manufacturers plan to introduce in a few weeks:

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: IN an early passage of Samuel Richardson's Clarissa, the heroine laments the fact that there are no more nunneries left where she can seek refuge from an obnoxious suitor. And her complaint offers an important insight into the ultrasecular nature of the literary form that Richardson was pioneering and into the consequences of this secular vision for women.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH there are many things that can cause paint to peel around the outside of a wood house, the most frequent cause by far is moisturethat is, moisture that finds its way into the siding And saturates the wood behind the paint film.

title: Donald V. Gerundo Weds Margarete Mary Silvan
description: Margarete Mary Silvan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Silvan of Scarsdale, N. Y., and Donald V. Gerundo, son of Mrs. Michael Caprara of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and Donald Gerundo of New Rochelle, N. Y., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Roger Williams Johnson in the Scarsdale (N. Y.) Congregational Church.

title: Headliners
description: A South African judge has astounded his countrymen by declaring Breyten Breytenbach, a prominent poet and opponent of apartheid, not guilty of promoting terrorism. Mr. Breytenbach was already serving a nineyear sentence given him in 1975 for violating South Africa's Terrorism Act, when the Government raised new charges against him for allegedly attempting to convert his warden to membership in a white underground group, and enlisting him in an escape plan. But the judge saw the relationship between the two as innocent, a decision widely viewed as a setback for the Government, since Mr. Breytenbach was given little chance to beat the state's elaborate case. In another case, however, nine black members of the banned African National Congress were convicted of acts that endanger the maintenance of law and order in the Republic of South Africa. They will be sentenced later.

title: Tax Reforms in Italy Double Revenues in 3 Years
description: ROME, July 16Italy's chief tax collector is enthusiastic these days because the changes he helped institute in the nation's tax laws have Wan to yield results.

title: Mimi McNamara Bride of James E. Hopgood
description: The Presbyterian Church of Bedford, N. Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mimi McNamara to James Ellis Hopgood. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas A. Hughart.

title: Sallie Ketcham Has Nuptials
description: Sallie Ketcham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Dunham. Ketcham of Boca Grande, Fla., and Greenville, Del., was married yesterday to Winder Laird Stabler 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stabler Jr. of Montchanin, Del. The Rev. John L. O'Hear performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal, Church, Christiana Hundred.

title: CHESS
description: There is a fairly widely held notion among grandmasters that conservative play is the best policy when confronting an unknown opponent.

title: FOOD
description: RASPBERRIES are one of the available delicacies of this season. Precious little saucers of them, a mere cupful, are priced at a dollar or more.

title: After the Elections, a New Period of Political Uncertainty in Japan
description: TOKYOFor all but a few months of the last three decades, Japan's opposition political parties have been out of power and the country has been ruled by a coalition of conservatives under the misnomer party umbrella of Liberal Democrats. After last week's elections for the upper house of Parliament, the five opposition groups are still out of power. But, combined, they are closer than ever to outnumbering the Liberal Democrats and bringing Japan into an uncertain age of multiparty politics Whether the voters will eventually bring about this transition is unclear, but a look at the parties and at why it has taken them so long to come this far provides clue to the answer.

title: SHOP TALK
description: IF Laury Garofano has her way, women will toss out their tennis dresses this summer and slip into clingy silks, crinkly cottons and pale chiffons. Mrs. Garofano says she had a New York kind of head when she opened her shop, Sweet Inspiration, in Briarcliff Manor seven years ago.

title: TORONTO LEGISLATOR FIGHTS FOR PRIVACY
description: OTTAWA, July 16The recent jailing of a Toronto legislator for contempt of court for refusing information has raised complex legal questions, now before an appeals tribunal, concerning a lawmaker's right to keep sources confidential.

title: Director Says Voice of America Will Air Even Bad News About U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)John Reinhardt, director of the United States Information Agency, pledged today to let the Voice of America broadcast straight news about the United States, warts and all.

title: Shakespeare and Suntans
description: ACADEMIC life at Hofstra this summer has not disappearedit's just out enjoying the sun. Despite fierce competition from the beach and the tennis courts, thousands of students have taken to the classroom to study everything from jewelrymaking to Shakespearean tragedy, and get some sun in between.

title: ORT, Striving to Reconcile Curriculums and Revelancy, Attracts More Women Interested in Education
description: 'I was 13, one of eight children, and out in the street. My father was working hard as a street merchant to make enough money for us to live. The majority of the Jews in Morocco were very poor Without ORT I would have had no figure.

title: Deborah J. Wood Wed in Maryland To Rev. E. P. Walk
description: Deborah Jane Wood, daughter of Mrs. Charles Wills Wood of Bethesda, Md., and the late Rev. Charles Wills Wood, was married yesterday in Centreville, Md., to the Rev. Everett Prichard Walk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett G. Walk of Reading, Pa. The Rev. William A. Beal performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Theater
description: ANNA CHRISTIELiv Ullmann in a revival of Eugene O'Neill's waterfront melodrama, directed by Jose Quintero. With John Lithgow, Mary M??Carry and Robert Donley. One and all have come lo look at Liv Ullmann, yet we spend most of our time looking at a luminous Presence in a warm spotlight waiting for a play to get started somewhere. (Kerr) imperial, 299 W. 45th St. (CO 52412)

title: REP. MOSS ASKS CALIFANO TO EXPLAIN VACCINE COST
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)A House subcommittee chairman asked Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, today to explain a major error in the Government's cost estimate of the illfated swine flu immunization program last winter.

title: Brighton Beach Group and the City Near Accord on Plan to Rehabilitate 4 Dwellings Housing 250 Families
description: The Brighton Beach Community Corporation is close to completing arrangements with the New York City Housing Development Administration for the rehabilitation of four multiple dwellings, occupied by 250 families in Brighton Beach, as part of a program aimed at stabilizing the area.

title: In Memoriam
description: CLARKEugene, M.D. July 18, 1972. In memory of my beIoved, Gene and the 42 beautiful years of our marriage.

title: Trudeau Urges Carter To Avoid Strain in Ties With Communist Nations
description: OTTAWA, July 16Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, in an apparent warning to President Carter, declared this week that taking an extreme line with Moscow on human rights could lead to renewal of the cold war and close off a movement of people from Communist countries to the West that began under dtente.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: GIVE A KID A CAMP

title: Moped Sales Go Zipping Along
description: IN A SOCIETY geared to status on wheels, the latest fad is a funky machine called the moped a motorized pedal bike that consumes little gasoline (150 miles a gallon is average).

description: Today  Century, Old Field Club, Stony Brook. Li. Preliminary, junior arid amateurowner jumpers; green, nonthoroughbred and amateurowner working hunters; green conformation hunters. 8:30 A.M.

title: MUSIC
description: FIVE years ago, the famous Borodin Quartet of Moscow played at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville. It was the last concert of their American tour, and three of the players went to New York City for some final sight seeing before their scheduled return to the Soviet Union.

title: The World/Continued
description: Having patched up its quarrel with other oil producers over this year's 10 Percent price increase. Saudi Arabia bras suggested no raise at all next year, citing the continued economic ill health of the oilconsuming countries. Surprisingly, Iran, traditionally hawkish on price increases, agreed.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: A Suggestion For M.T.A.

title: Do Kids and Alcohol Mix?
description: The young man, interviewed just before his 20th birthday, had made up his mind to stop drinking. His reasoning: My father drank for 20, 30 years and he doesn't drink any more. My older brother drinks and he gets into trouble. I drink and I get into trouble. My younger brother and sister don't drink at all and they don't get into trouble at all

title: Several Murders Later, Arizona Finally Moves On Crime
description: PHOENIXThe sun is baking Arizona with its usual ferocious summer glare, but, in many ways, it shines on a different state than it did a year ago.

title: Oneida Indians Win Two Victories In Fight to Regain New York Lands
description: ALBANYThe Oneida Indians have won two victories in their legal fight to regain possession of lands they once occupied in central New York State. But they have lost a bid to have Washington help the tribe in a different claim, to four million to five million acres in the central part of the state.

title: Scandal in New Haven
description: THE CAMPAIGN for the Democratic mayoral nomination in New Haven, which is the only one that matters in that Democratic fastness, is overflowing with candidates who do not have much in common, apart from a clear disdain for one another, and with a concern about where the widening scandal over police wiretaps might lead the campaign.

title: Poverty Is Found Less Persistent But Wider Spread Than Thought
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.A massive study that has monitored the economic ups and downs of 5,000 American families for a decade has concluded that poverty is far less persistent but much more pervasive in American life than most would have thought.

title: It's the Law
description: New York landlords can demand one or two months' security, depending on which rental law applies in their case. The law requires landlords who rent six or more dwelling units to send the tenants  individual annual reports itemizing the size of their security deposits, the amount of interest due, the account number and the name and address of the bank in which the money is placed. The tenant is entitled to the prevailing interest rate, minus a service charge of 1 percent.

title: Gross Helps Cubs Prevail As Phillies Shift Backfires
description: When Lou Boudreau of Cleveland popularized the Ted Williams shift, the Red Sox's lefthandedhitting star disdained the stacked infield between first and second bases and tried to smack the ball through or over the shift. He did it well, too.

title: Valli Fuiks Fiancee Of Paul G. Lukeman
description: Valli Flavin Fuiks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis John Fuiks of Rye, N.Y., and Paul Gardner Lukeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Paul Lukeman of Columbus, Ohio, plan to be married on Sept. 3 at the Wardsboro, Vt., summer home of the bridetobe's parents, who have announced the engagement of the couple.

title: IN BRIEF
description: THE HOUSE COMMERCE COMMTTTEE defeated a proposal to deregulate the price of natural gas by 23 to 20. The vote means that the committee is backing the Carter Administration's plan to increase the price of new natural gas to $1.75 a thousand cubic feet from $1.45.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)  President Carter, in remarks made public today, said his attitude on human rights was fairly moderate compared with those of members of Congress who want to break relations with nations that do not meet American standards.

title: Poverty and Low I.Q.: the Vicious Circle
description: EABLY in this book, discussing the difficulties in making classifications in biology, Paul R. Ehrlich and S. Shirley Feldman indulge in a curiously apt bit of rhetoric. Is this book, they ask, about biology, sociology, anthropology, psychology, or is it just a political tract? To which this reviewer adds a less rhetorical question: Is this a book at all, or is it a bound collection of very fragmentary notes for a series of freshman lectures?

title: MUSIC
description: ONCE upon a ;me there was an unusual music camp in Killingworth, about 20 miles from New Haven. It was called the Creative Arts Center, and its founderdirector, Dr. Elsa Redlich, was deeply committed to helping youngsters discover the joys both of creating music and listening to it. Eventually she saw to the construction of a handsome music shed on the property between Chestnut Hill Road and the Hammonasset River, and there, in the summer of 1970, she inaugurated the Chestnut Hill Concerts.

title: The World
description: Once again, the Soviet Union has demonstrated what the furor over its human rights policies it ail about. It barred Dr. Veniamin G. Levich, a renowned Soviet physical chemist of Jewish origin, from attending a conference in his honor at Oxford University, in effect slamming the door to what Dr. Levich called a graceful way of letting him and his wife emigrate, something they've been trying to do for the last five years.

title: GARDENING
description: WHAT are you going to do about all those gay geraniums that are blooming in your garden? Leave them to be killed by frost, or pot them for late winter and spring flowering in your sunny window garden?

title: Editors' Choice
description: AMEN, by Yehuda Amichai. Translated by the author and Ted Hughes. (Harper & Row. Cloth, $7.95. Paper, $4.95.) Poems by Israel's bestknown living poet, on war, death, sensuality, love; a harshly lovely, exhilarating, saddening book.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Prominently featured in the current exhibition wedding photographs at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue at 99th Street, through Sept. 11, is a fullcolor, halflength, formal portrait of a bride by the Bachrach Studio, circa 1970. It is the quintessential formal portrait of the bride: carefully posed and lighted to.bring out the sitter's youthful beauty and to convey those qualities of demure innocence and radiant expectation that are, in the conservative art of the wedding photographer, still associated with the bride.

title: Judge Orders College to Provide Interpreter for a Deaf Student
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., July 16 (AP)A Federal judge has ordered Converse College in Spartanburg, S.C., to pay for sign language interpreter for a deaf student at the college's summer school.

title: Roth Leads by 8 Pins In Tucson Pro Bowling
description: TUCSON, Ariz., July 16 (AP)Mark Roth of Staten Island, trying for a fourth straight victory, was the leader today after the opening round of the $60,000 Tucson open Professional Bowlers' Association tournament here.

title: Port Authority Executives Sometimes Traveled at Expense of Fore ign Agencies, Trip Records Show
description: Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, whose world tours at the agency's expense are being investigated by New York State, also traveledin some cases with their wivesat the expense of other port authorities and foreign hosts, an examination of trip records bas disclosed.

title: The Way Was Lonely
description: THE 19th century has been pretty thoroughly excavated, with the principal figures all classified and on exhibition, and 90 percent of them are men. Now we are sifting the lesser finds, and it this category that includes most of, the women. We know the reasons. Except in literature, a cottage industry, the gifted woman had few outlets. Muse, hostess, mistress to a celebrated loverthese were her choices. Men determined her place in life.

title: Landlords Must Pay Interest
description: THOUGH LANDLORDS in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut are required by law to make annual interest payments on tenants' security deposits, many of them are just not doing so. The official figures are sketchy, but they indicate that renters in those three states are losing out on considerably more than a quarter million dollars a year in unpaid interest.

title: Feminism May Sink or Swim With the E.R.A.
description: WASHINGTONFor the women's movement, these are neither the best nor the worst of times: there have been some victories in recent months and some, perhaps more, significant defeats. But the most important issue for the movement remains unresolved: The fate of the Equal Rights Amendment is still uncertain. Since Congressional passage in 1972, 35 states have ratified the amendment, but 38 must approve it by 1979 if it is to become part of the Constitution. In three states that had passed it, legislatures have since voted to rescind, though it is questionable whether they have the power to do so. North Carolina and Illinois rejected the amendment this year, while other legislatures have simply tabled it.

title: HOME CLINIC

title: Ousted Congress Party of India Is Floundering in Its Opposition Role
description: NEW DELHI, July 16The Congress Party, which governed India for 30 years until it was defeated in the March parliamentary election, is finding itself helpless and uncomfortable in its role as the opposition in Parliament.

title: MINING THE WEALTH OF THE OCEAN DEEP
description: The flour of the sea is a land no man can ever walk, a spectacular landscape miles beneath the ocean's surface, only recently explored and, as late as 25 years ago, virtually uncharted. Much of the surface of the moon is better known than the surface of the earth beneath the sea. But the floor of the sea has become the subject of one of the bitterest  and, some observers say, most hopeless  disputes in international relations today. On the bottom of the ocean are mineral deposits large enough to supply all mankind for years, even centuries, to come. There is enough copper to last the entire world for 6,000 years, compared with 40 years' reserves on land ; enough nickel to last 150, 000 years, versus 100; aluminium for 20,000 years, versus 100.

title: Beauty
description: What does it take to make an impression in the cosmetic industry that is dominated by the legends, and products. of giants like Este Lauder. Charles Revson, Helena Rubinstein and Elizabeth Arden? The four women below, all with their own ideas, are finding a way.

The company that originated this look traveled the glamorous road from rags to riches, but now it is struggling to avoid the dismal trail back to raes.

title: DINING OUT
description: ONCE you leave Italy, France and China, the Island's ethnic palette (and palate) becomes sharply limited. There is but a scattering of restaurants serving the food of nations other than those culinary big three.

title: BRIDGE
description: Recent experiments in various parts of the world indicate a renewal of interest in the weirdest of all bidding ideas: the strong pass. In first and second position, by partnership agreement, a player with a strong hand passes and expects his partner to keep the auction alive.

title: FATHER AND FOUR CHILDREN DIE IN NEW JERSEY FIRE
description: A father and his four children died apparently of smoke inhalation yesterday when a fire broke out in their home in Hazlet Township, N.J., according to the township police.

title: New Yorkers Hit Beaches as Mercury Hits 98
description: New Yorkers took to the beaches and parks yesterday as the temperature soared to 98 degrees at 2 P.M., equaling the record for the date, set in 1879.

title: Experts Seeking to Ease San Quentin Racial Conflict
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16A team of experts trained in settling prison conflicts began discussions yesterday with inmates at San Quentin prison in an effort to ease racial tensions following clashes between Nazi and Black Muslim inmates last Tuesday that left three convicts dead and four wounded.

title: HONG KONG SCHOOLS DRAWING CRITICISM
description: HONG KONG, July 15  In this booming island colony, textile and electronics factories have long been good investments. So have private schools.

title: DR. AARON BLUESTONE
description: Dr. Aaron Bluestone, a dentist in Brooklyn for more than 50 years and a life member of the American Dental Association, died yesterday at his home at 522 Ocean Avenue. He was 76 years old.

title: Lyndhurst Seeks to Aid Young
description: THE overwhelming success of a small youth recreation center that was opened in Lyndhurst almost five years ago has prompted an intensive community fundraising campaign aimed at collecting $200,000 for the construction of a new facility.

title: THE NEW FACE OF ISRAEL
description: For three weeks lust month, I traveled extensively in Israel. My visit coincided with a tumultuous period in that nation's history. For the first time in 29 years, since the creation of the stale of Israel. the Labor Alignment lost a national election and yielded power to the conservative Likud opposition. Democracy worked, but for most Israelis, that had never been in question. They were absorbed with two other problems: Could Menahem Begin, weakened by a recent heart at tack, govern Israel's volatile society? And could he use his considerable eloquence  and adopt a sufficiently flexible stance  to ease official American doubts about Israel's willingness to strike a compromise deal with the Arabs?

title: Jane Coleman Webster Wed
description: The marriage of Jane Coleman Webster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Coleman Webster of Ambler, Pa., to Peyton Randolph Gray took place yesterday afternoon in Whitemarsh, Pa. Mr. Gray is the youngest son of the late Bowman Gray, former president and chairman of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, and the late Mrs. Gray of WinstonSalem, N.C. Bishop Thomas A. Fraser of the Episcopal Diocese of North Carolina and the Rev. Albert N. Halverstadt Jr. of St. Thomas' Episcopal Church jointly performed the ceremony in St. Thomas'.

title: A Study in Counterfeit
description: SO many of Dr. Watson's manuscripts have been unearthed lately that, even after dismissing the obvious forgeries, we have a great quantity of puzzling scribbling on our hands; while we suspect still further forgery, the purpose of such elaborate machinations is not as yet clear. Certain of our speculations will become evident below.

title: LETTERS
description: Big Brother chauvinism

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. The Emotional Content of Judaism.

title: What Makes Alan Ladd Jr. Hollywood's Hottest Producer?
description: HOLLYWOOD When Alan Ladd Jr. was a boy in Beverly Hills he used to take jobs as an usher so that he could see Errol Flynn pictures five and six times. Out of that experience he developed what he calls his Saturday matinee rule of thumb.

title: Around the Nation
description: NORFOLK, Va., July 16 (AP)Sailors are deserting the Navy in record numbers, according to a Navy report released yesterday. Navy officers say the problem may be due to recruiters trying to meet quotas by enlisting immature and poorly educated personnel.

title: Lisbon Rites for Magda Lupescu
description: LISBON, July 16 (AP)Magda Lupescu, shunned by European royalty in life, joined her husband King Carol of Romania and Portugal's kings and queens in death today when her body was placed in the royal Pantheon.

title: The Crises Before Us
description: SINCE Vietnam, politics and wars have been duly reported by the media, but without the sense of crisis that earlier brought foreign affairs into people's homes. Foreign policy matters have returned to the natural state that diplomats, strategists and policy makers have always wished forthey are dealt with dispassionately in the corridors of power. So it is not widely known, either here or abroad, that a debate on the direction of United States foreign policy has been under way for several years, even as realities are changing. Within the Carter national security establishment the talk is naturally behind closed doors. But, as in the past, there are reflections of the debate in the public discussions of informed outsiders.

title: Mary Bratton Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lester George Bratton of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Farrell Bratton, to John Michael O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. O'Brien of Chappaqua, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Collectors who specialize in foreign coinage will probably be interested in the 1977 prooflike coins recently struck at the Paris Mint in France. Consisting of nine pieces, ranging from the 1centime to the 50franc, the coins include all those currently circulating in France.

title: Butler Names Two Aides
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 16 (AP)Bill Lynch of Indianapolis, who was named the most valuable football player in the Indiana. Collegiate Conference three times, was named an assistant football coach at his alma mater, Butler University. Bill Sylvester, athletic director at Butler, also named Mike Steele, a member of Purdue's 1974 National Invitation Tournament championship team, an assistant basketball coach.

title: ADINSTRATION BARS PUBLIC WORKS FUNDS FOR SMALLER TOWNS
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The Carter Administration, ignoring, a Congressional mandate, has adopted a policy that has resulted in the exclusion of thousands of smaller communities from the $4 billion public works job program.

title: Canine Owners Are Putting On the Dog
description: WHERE have all the Fidos gone? And all the Rovers, the Princes, the Sports and the Brownies? My neighbors all keep dogs, but with astonishing names.

title: A Small Woman Pilots a Big Sailboat
description: CHICAGO, July 16When 234 boats were launched two miles off Monroe Street Harbor today. only one skipper was wearing leather and suede sailing gloves to keep her hands soft and lovely.

title: ART VIEW
description: The name of Patrick Henry Bruce, though it appears now and again in the histories of modern American art, is not yet one that is familiar to the American art public. Few of his paintings can be seen in our museums. Little has been written about his life. The very world in which he moved as an artist in the most crucial years of his developmentParis in the decade preceding World War Iis not one in which American artists are thought to have played much of a part. We do not even have a reliable chronology of the pictures he painted in those years, and we are unlikely to get one. Although not quite the shadowy figure he once was, Bruce's remains an obscure nameoccasionally honored as a pioneer in lists of other painters of the early 20th century, but rarely singled out. As far as I know, no retrospective exhibition of his work has ever been organized here.

title: A Monumental Achievement
description: THE story of the struggle to design and erect the Princeton Battle Monument is almost as complicated as the tangle of fig ices on the giant limestone memorial itkelf. A Broadway actress and a Princeton professor posed for it. The figure of George Washington, sword in hand, was supposed to stand atop a slender column when plans were first drawn for the monument in 1887.

title: Colson Tells Iowans Of Prison Failure
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, July 16 (UPI)Former Sen. Harold E. Hughes of Iowa returned to his home state with Charles W. Colson, the Watergate figure whom Mr. Hughes called his brother in Christ, to tell more than 8,000 persons of the pair's experiences with God.

title: Miss Purdy Engaged To Richard K. Muser
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Ivar Martin of Saddle River, N. J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Martin's daughter, Deborah Elizabeth Purdy, to Richard Knight Muser, who is in his second year at the Washington and Lee Law School.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PACIFIC, Mo., July 16 (AP) Specialist fourth class Joseph Clemmons of Wilmington, N.C., knocked down 99 of a possible 100 targets yesterday and won the United States skeet championship here.

title: State and Federal Officials Looking Into Fuchberg's Note Trading
description: Judge Jacob Fuchsbegg's active trading in $2 million worth of city notes while a member of the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, has become the subject of a series of checks by state and Federal authorities.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Pets Get a Number

title: Quebec Modifies Bill, but Not Enough to Ease Tension
description: MONTREAL, July 16Despite strong objections by Englishspeaking Canadians, the Quebec government has wade few concessions to critics of the language policy designed to, insure the supremacy of French. As a result, there has been a notable increase of tension at the provincial and national levels.

title: BUSINESSMEN ANGRY AS BEAME INSPECTS CITY'S LOOTED AREAS
description: Mayor Beanie and delegations of Congressmen assessing the blackout that crippled New York City and Westchester County last week encountered angry businessmen in sweltering, debrisstrewn streets yesterday as the criminaljustice system struggled to cope with thousands of looting and arson suspects.

title: EGYPT SET TO INTRODUCE STRICT ISLAMIC LAWS
description: CAIRO, July 16 (UPI)Jolted by a resurgence of Moslem religious sentiment, the Government is moving quietly to enforce Islamic law, which provides for death and amputations for thieves, adulterers, drunkards and Moslems who renounce the faith.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Cover art. Among the most influential residents of Publishers Row are the art directors of the major massmarket paperback houses  a dozen men and one woman whose mission in life is to create covers that will impel bookstore browsers to pick their products out of the racks and carry them to the checkout counter. They've just had an unaccustomed experience.

title: Hunt Takes Grand Prix Of Britain
description: SILVERSTONE, England, July 16 (AP)  The world driving champion, James Hunt of Britain, drove his. McLaren to an easy victory in the British Grand Prix today after his closest challengers were forced into the pits.

title: Article 25  No Title
description: right gear up. Eurocommunist Santiago Carrillo criticizes the Soviet Union in terms that usually preceded splits within the left in the past. Henry Kissinger warns that Communists must not come into power in Western Europe. But in Defending America Walter Laqueur argues that perhaps they should be tolerated. Confusing, yes, but just the kind of fundamental confusion that breeds crises and wars.

title: Buy film. Or select a film.
description: 1. We now put the speed rating right in the film name when we launch new ones. Speed is what makes more subjects, situations, and times of day practical for photography.

title: A Boy from Nebraska Sharpens His British For Broadway
description: OOOOAAAHHHHOOOO AAAAAYYYYYOOOOOEEEEEE, Dick Cavett said. That's one of my favorites. The dapper, unflappable host of countless television talkfests with the likes of Marlon Brando, Katharine Hepburn and Laurence Olivier looked a trifle uneasy as he demonstrated one of the vocal exercises he is doing in preparation for his Broadway debut on Thursday. Yes, that's right. Dick Cavett is coming to Broadwaynot as a standup comedian delivering the dryly witty monologues that first brought him acclaim, but as the new star of Otherwise Engaged, Simon Gray's hit play at the Plymouth Theater.

title: Aircraft Termed  No Ozone Threat; Tests Add to Fear on Fluorocarbon
description: New laboratory findings indicate that no existing aircraft presents an imminent threat to the atmosphere's protective ozone layer, according to the head of the Federal Aviation Administration's high altitude pollution staff.

title: U.S. Aides Confident Carter and Begin Will Avoid a Confrontation
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Highranking Administration officials said today that despite their initial misgivings about Prime Minister Menahem Begin they now expected the Israeli leader and President Carter to avoid a confrontation next week and agree on steps toward a Geneva conference on the Middle East.

title: Bucher Says U.S. Failed to Learn From the Pueblo
description: POWAY, Calif.Nine years after North Korean gunboats seized the U.S.S. Pueblo, its retired commander, Lloyd M. Bucher, lives quietly in a secluded ranch house, growing avocados, painting and studying art.

title: Arabs Fear That Carter Will Yield To Israel on StepbyStep Strategy
description: CAIRO, July 15Leading Arab officials are deeply concerned that President Carter might give in to an Israeli proposal that he abandon the search for a comprehensive Middle East settlement and revert to the stepbystep approach advocated ??oy. Henry A. Kissinger when he was Secretary of State. Any such reversal is strongly opposed by virtually all the Arab Governments.

title: OilPrice RiseCritics Pan It but Drama Plays On
description: For the last four years the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has regularly staged its favorite drama Oil Prices Rise Again. In the most recent production, earlier this month, there was an exciting clash between angry hawks, led by Iran, Libya and Iraq, and the doves, headed by Saudi Arabia, the largest exporter. At the denouement all accepted a rise of some 10 percent.

title: Major League TeaAgainstTeam Record Includes games of July 15
Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: MUSSOLINI'S ROMAN EMPIRE, by Dennis Mack Smith. (Penguin, $3.95.) An Oxford historian uses his study of Il Duce's international policy as an opportunity to say much that is interesting, perceptive and ironical about the dictator's personality and about the Fascist regime. In passing he offers fascinating sidelights on how Mussolini's alliance with the Nazis gradually brought about the subordination of his nation.

title: Recovery Is Disappointingly Slow and Spotty, Threatening Political Stability As Well
description: STOCKHOLMThe message from a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Experting Countries last week was that the world may get off without an oil Price increase next year. But the news barely merits a cheer. The oil producers are not talking about a price freeze out of generosity, but because they think the industrial world is too poor to pay a higher oil bill.

title: Disturbance at Rock Concert Halted
description: WOODRIDGE, N Y, July 16State treopers and local policemen quelled a diiturbance involving more than a thousand people who had been turned away frcm a rock concert that was ended by a torrential downpour.

title: Owner of a Looted Store in Bronx Exchanges Words With the Mayor
description: Mayor Beame learned yesterday just how angry a businessman who had lost more than $70,000 worth of merchandise could get.

title: Sadat Tells His Party That the Russians Canceled Military Contracts
description: CAIRO, July 16 (UPI)President Anwar elSadat said today that the Soviet Union had canceled its military contracts and demanded a new political treaty.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Richard Bach
description: Hold on to your pinfeathers. Richard Bach is at it again. His Jonathan Livingston Seagull soared to an extended run in the top spot on the bestseller list and now Mr. Bach's latest inspirational fable, Illusions, The Adventures of a Reluctant Messiah, is climbing, climbing.

title: Deborah Ambrosini Bride
description: Deborah H. Ambrosini and Nicholas C. Habes, son of Mr. and Mrs, Nicholas Habes of Rochester, were married yesterday morning in Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Snyder, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph M. Supple of Brattleboro, Vt., who also concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev, Joseph J. Kohut of Newtown, Conn., and the Rev. James J. Browne. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Armando J. Ambrosini of Snyder and the late Mr. Ambrosini.

title: East End Windmills Are Grist for the Historian
description: AT ONE TIME, as many as 40 windmills dotted the flat Long Island landscape, their sails unfurled to catch enough offshore breezes to power the area's rural economy. But gradually, steam was introduced to grind the wheat and corn for local use, the farms themselves were replaced by splitlevels and the windmills went the way of progress. Today only 11 survive.

title: The Nation
description: President Carter stated the dominant theory of United States military thinking since World War II in clear and classic terms last week: The ownership of atomic weapons and their potential use, he said, is such a horpitying prospecttheir usethat it is a deterrent to a major confrontation between nations who possess atomic weapons.

title: The Director as Star of the Show
description: HUNTINGTON FOR 15 YEARS, the byword in Long Island museum circles has been, When in doubt, ask Eva Eva Ingersoll Gatling, director of the Heckscher Museum here. Now, after a distinguished career as art historian and curator, Miss Gatling is retiring, and to send her off in proper, artworld style, her colleagues have organized a salute to the dean of Long Island museum peoplean exhibition detailing her contributions to her institution and the entire local museum scene.

description: TUCSON, Ariz., July 12On Saturday night the new Last Culture discotheque in the heart of town; its narrowbeamed lights flashing and soul beat thumping, was crowded with some 300 young men and women, most of them homosexuals.

title: He Never Left Home
description: IN 1962, the producer of Call Me Bwana asked Bob Hope's chief gag writer if Hope would star In his African safari picture. The writer, who knew his boss well, got right to the point.

title: Showcase for Chinese Crafts
description: TWO TRADITIONAL Chinese marble lions stand at the entry to a section of Bonwit Teller's seventh floor. Behind them are gleaming vases, some over four feet high, carved from black or dark red solid lacquer and brilliantly decorated with flowers and birds, or subtly painted with red or orange dragons.

title: STEPHANIE DE WAEL MAYER
description: Stephanie de Wael Mayer, who worked for the Office of Strategic Services (O.S.S.) in London from 1943 to 1945 and later headed the United States Information Service in Brussels, Belgium, died Friday at her home at 49 East 73d Street in Manhattan. Miss Mayer was 85 years old.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH there are many things that can cause paint to peel around the outside of a wood house, the most frequent cause by far is moisturethat is, moisture that finds its way into the siding and saturates the wood behind the paint film.

title: Innovative Legislative Session Ending
description: WHAT is perhaps the most innovative Legislature in New Jersey's history is taking a couple of months off. And it is the first summer in the last four that the 80 Assemblymen and 40 Senators have not been under the pressure of trying to pass a state income tax.

title: Anthropology, a Discipline About Man Himself
description: The privilege of the anthropologist is to have lived several worlds. But a price is paid. It is hard to be fully at home in any. And there are no easy answers. Humans pronouncing judgment on their nature are easily beguiled. What seems most plausible is often, with wider knowledge, merely specious.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: IN THE strange language of government, a dedicated funding source is a mighty important thing. And it is the spring that its backers hope will produce a Mississippian flow of dollars. The main thing about it is that it provides a sure means of financing for a particular project.

title: Protests Mark Double Victory for Courageous
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 16Trial races to select the defender of the America's Cup got under way again today on Rhode Island Sound and once more Courageous was in the spotlight. The yacht that defended the Cup in 1974 and now is piloted by Ted Turner, the suspended owner of the Atlanta Braves, twice defeated Enterprise and Lowell North, her skipper, by 26 and 49 seconds on the first day of the Observation Trials.

title: Despite the Deadlock, Hope Flickers in Gaza
description: GAZA, IsraelAt first glance, the Gaza Strip appears to be a hopeless place. A ribbon of land running along the Mediterranean Sea from Rafah in the south to Belt Hanun in the north, it is bursting with 406,000 people in about 100 square miles. More than half of them are Palestinian refugees from Israel, many of whom live in squalid camps whose misery is accented by the constant sunlight, the nearby beaches and the bluegreen surf of the Mediterranean.

title: Looters Offer a PasserBy Booty and a Bill of Goods
description: Carlos and two teenage companions moved about the neighborhoods surrounding 104th Street and Manhattan Avenue yesterday, trying to sell new radios, televisions and furniture looted from nearby stores during Wednesday night's blackout.

title: STAMPS
description: Among the events that helped thwart the grand design of the British to crush the rebellious Americans in the second year of the Revolution was the battle of Cris kany in the summer of 1777.

title: The Politics of Hunger
description: THERE is a special relationship between Americans and the world food question. The United States in the years after World War II took upon itself the unprecedented task of feeding the hungry people of the world. Since then, Americans have sold or given food to billions of farflung customers. The foreign aid policies of the United States Government and the practices of American multinational companies have shaped the agricultural development of much of the world. Americans, meanwhile, continue to look at world hunger with special concern, anger or distress.

description: FIRST$12,000. pace, mile.

title: Dance: Trio by Katherine Liepe
description: Katherine Liepe's The Other Side of This Side was as confusing as its title. Each of the three dances on the program was full of portent but had very little in the way of meaning. it was like a parade of isolated clues that had no real connection and was presented at the Cubiculo Friday evening.

title: U.S. SAYS QUAKES KILLED 2,050 IN FIRST HALF OF 1977
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)Worldwide earthquake deaths in the first half of 1977 were less than onetenth the number in the similar period last year, the United States Geological Survey reported this week.

title: THE NEW FACE OF ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM. For 29 years he had been a fixture in the Knesset, rising from the opposition benches, a slight, clerkly figure, to loose his unavailing shafts against the Government; holding on doggedly against the dislike and derision turned on him by successive Prime Ministers; a friendly man, a family man, an artful politician with a bag of parliamentary skills. who could always be approached for a talk in the Knesset cafeteria; an unabashed fundamentalist in his views on Judea and Samaria, those biblical Jewish lands now part of the West Bank that, to him, were not occupied but liberated in the 1967 warthe maunderings, one was told, of the perennial rightwing oppositionist, not to be given much heed. Until, after the stunning election upset last May, Menahem Begin was saying the same things as the likely Prime Ministera singleminded, 63yearold man proceeding with the creation of a coalition Government, a mission few had ever imagined for him, and one he carried out with brisk dispatch while recovering from a midcampaign heart attack.

title: The Vivian Beaumont Concept Was It an Impossible Dream?
description: When they put up the Vivian Beaumont Theater, a dozen years ago, it Was like erecting the Great Pyramid and advertising for a dynasty of Pharaohs to go inside. It was like building an elephant house to catch an elephant.

title: Red Smith
description: For 15 years, Nick Domingo has been head chef at the Concord in Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., cooking for 3,000 guests three times a day when that Catskills resort is in full cry. In November between the High Holy Days and Hanukkah the crowds taper off and Domingo takes his vacation.

title: White Plains Retail Challenge
description: KAY Larson Shortway, a career fashion merchant, played with clothes as a child in the small resort town of South Haven, Mich. As an adult, she learned the retail business by serving the wellheeled shoppers of the Bullock's stores in Los Angeles. And, last week, as one of the country's most highly placed women retailers, she wandered through the aisles of Bergdorf Goodman's branch store in White Plains and smilingly introduced herself to customers as the store's new vice president and general manager.

title: Behan Leaving As Chief to Take Baltimore Post
description: One of the highestranking commanders in New York City's Police Department, Chief Cornelius J. Behan, said yesterday that he was resigning to become Police Chief of Baltimore County, Md.

title: Patricia Ann Scott, Copywriter, Is Wed
description: Patricia Ann Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott of Crestwood, N.Y., was married yesterday in Bethel, N.Y., to Cleve Swanson Langton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Benedict Langton Jr. of Dix Hills, L.I. The Rev. L. Roper Shamhart, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Fraser Settlement, home of the bride's grandmother. Mrs. Frank J. Quigan.

title: Mystic Morsel
description: IN SPITE OF its reputation for handsome 19thcentury houses, Mystic did not have a historical society until 1973. This summer Mystic's 400member historical society is undertaking its most ambitious project to date in the Captain's House, a designer showcase that will be open to the public until Aug. 15.

title: 10 Marina Opponents Arrested in California
description: SAUSALITO, Calif July 16Ten demonstrators were, arrested yesterday on the waterfront north of here in the second day of confrontations between houseboat dwellers and developers beginning construction of a new marina.

title: Lenin's Apparent Heir
description: AFTER KremlinologyStalinology. This volume of essays on different aspects of Stalin's rule is the product of a conference arranged by Robert Tucker, professor of politics at Princeton, in which 12 other very distinguished scholars participated. Professor Tucker envisaged the discussions as a contribution to the comparative study of Communism, with Stalin's career as a starting point. I doubt that this aim has been achievedif only because Stalinism was marked so distinctively by the personality of the great tyrant that it is difficult to see any basis for comparison with any his imitators. This is, however, of little importance. The conference fully justified itself by producing excellent studies mainly directed toward four themes: the link between Marxism and Stalinism; the extent, if any, to which Stalinism was a heritage of Lenin; aspects of Stalinism as it developed in Russia; and the transplantation of Stalin's model to the countries of Eastern Europe that fell under Soviet rule.

title: Blackout IIan Eerie Slowdown
description: The morning alter, it was almost like a holiday, or a Sunday in Calvin's Geneva. Banks were closed, as were the stock exchanges. In all five boroughs the city's great commercial and manufacturing industries were still, skyscrapers were deserted, restaurants, drug stores, and book shops were dark and hopeful shoppers were turned away by locked doors at the largest retail stores.

title: TV's Influence:
description: THERE has been so much written on the dangerous influence of television on our children. And there is a danger, certainly. But I think it is greatly overrated.

title: Farewell to the Potlatch
description: I HAVE stopped giving dinner parties. A few years ago, they were an important element in my life and in the lives of those around me. Today, I just can't develop the enthusiasm necessary to plan that sort of social gathering.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Variable focal length lenses, popularly known as zoom lenses, are undoubtedly the most versatile of all lenses for the 35mm single lens reflex camera (as well as for many of the larger format cameras).

title: U.S. Is Issuing Loan Forms to Looted Businesses
description: The Federal Government is issuing applications for lowinterest loans to the owers of small businesses who suffered miliions of dollars in damages because of looting and vandalism during last week's blackout.

title: The Puzzling School Systems
description: AN ESSENTIAL ingredient for instilling pride into a community is convincing its residents that theirs is a good school system. Just exactly what is a good school system is no clearer than what is a thorough and efficient education. Both puzzles will continue to puzzle.

title: Miss Gaspar, A.J.S. Shrady Are Married
description: Suzanne Marie Gaspar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Odon Gaspar of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was married yesterday in White Plains to Alexander James Stewart Shrady, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Shrady of Easton, Conn. John Cardinal Wright, Prefect of the Congregation for the Clergy in the Roman Curia, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Our Lady of Good Counsel Chapel on the campus of the Good Counsel Academy, of which the bride is a graduate.

title: A Mom and Pop Business Rings Up $2 Billion
description: DALLASFifty years ago an old ice house operator named John Jefferson Green handed over $1,000 to a young executive of the Southland Ice Company. The money was the company's share of the earnings that Uncle Johnny had made selling milk, eggs and cigarettes in one of its ice houses.

title: DR. HERMANN N. MORSE, ECUMENIST, DIES AT 89
description: The Rev. Dr. Hermann N. Morse, one of the chief architects of the National Council of Churches, a former moderator of the United Presbyterian Church and a pioneer in the ecumenical movement, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 89 years old.

title: Hazel Chapman Bride Of C. M. Niemczewski
description: Hazel Perry Chapman and Christopher Martin Niemczewski were married yesterday at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Inlet, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Leonard Unger.

title: WILLIAM EMMETT BROOKS
description: BREWTON, Ala., July 16 (AP)William Emmett Brooks, a former head of both the Alabama Broadcasters Association and the Alabama Press Association, died at his home yesterday after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: $57 Million Owed To U.S. by Convicts  In Assessed Fines
description: WASHINGTON, July 16.(AP)The Justice Department is trying to collect nearly $57 million in fines from thousands of ??onvicted criminals, including G. Gordon Liddy, the Watergate conspirator, and moonshiners from the Pronibition era.

title: Lynne Robin Burns Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Burns of New Rochelle, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynne Robin Burns, to Andrew. Mel Edelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Edelman of Mount Vernon, N. Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: Police Clash With Demonstrators In Religious Disturbance in Israel
description: BNEI BRAQ, Israel, July 16 (UPI)Hundreds of policemen clashed with thousands of rockthrowing demonstrators in Bnei Braq today, the third weekend of violence between observant and nonobservant Jews over the closing of a major intersection on the Jewish Sabbath.

title: COURT ALLOWS NEW YORK PARKINGBAN EXTENSION
description: New York City was granted more time to submit specific plans for carrying out a parkingcontrol program to alleviate air pollution in Manhattan.

title: Care Project Scored
description: ALTHOUGH New Jersey has one of the most elaborate computerized programs for keeping track of Medicaid families, a Washingtonbased organization has isued a report that is sharply critical of the state's administration of a Federal healthcare project for poor children.

title: Carey Often Seems Otherwise Engaged
description: ALBANYThis was the year Hugh L. Carey had to come back down to earth.

title: Letters: Pet TravelIt's for the Birds, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: SYLVIA LINK BOEHM
description: Sylvia Link Boehm, vice president of the Sterling Publishing Company and the wife of David A. Boehm, the company's president, died yesterday at her home after a long illness. She was 59 years old and lived at 39 East 79th Street.

title: Philadelphia Gets Sludge Warning
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP)The Federal Government is holding Philadelphia to a schedule for improving its three sewage treatment plants and ending ocean sludge dumping by 1981. The order arrived here yesterday from the Environmental Protection Agency, which said that by agreeing to meet the deadline the city would remain eligible for Federal funds to modernize its sewage plants.

title: Marcella Graves Wed To Robert S. Fortuna
description: Marcella Frances Graves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Perry Graves of Jacksonville, Fla., was married there yesterday to Robert S. Fortuna, son of Mr. and Mrs. James O. Fortuna of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Stanley Bullock performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Good Shepherd.

title: Tom Snyder Has Gone West But Still Hankers For the Big Apple
description: LOS ANGELES It was a couple of hours before the 8:95 P.M. taping of the Tomorrow show, and Tom Snyder was sitting in his new office in the sprawling NBC studio complex in Burbank, Calif., marveling over an eightounce can of cold soda. They don't have these in New York, he said, brandishing the short and squat can that he.had drawn from his refrigerator. I think they're test marketing them here or something. It's greatthose big cans are too much to drink anyway.

title: Northern Suburbs Suffer Power Loss As Storm Strikes
description: A severe electrical storm temporarily cut off electricity yesterday to thousands of residents in areas of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut north of New York City.

title: Margaret Nuttle Is Wed to P. F. Melcher
description: The marriage of Margaret Barksdale Nuttle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Everngam Nuttle of Easton, Mr., and Hobe Sound, Fla., to Pierson Fort Melcher of Philadelphia took place yesterday at the Nuttles' home in Easton. The Rev. Charles O'F. Mastin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Surging Royals Put Torrez to Rout
description: KANSAS CITY, July 16The Yankees, recipients of George Steinbrenner's words yesterday and his money today, are learning that neither the owner's oratory nor his benevolence can help them win games.

title: Photography
description: HARRIET CASDINSILVERThreedimensional light imagery. Museum of Holography, 11 Mercer St. Through July 26. Weds.Suns., 126.

title: Contest Is On Over Rents and Repairs at MitchellLama Project in Williamsburg
description: In the middle of Williamsburg, we have been forgotten, said Gerald Seiderman, a resident of Lindsay Park, a MitchellLama cooperative development in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Except for the behavior of the stock market's blue chips, which are continuing to exhibit lack of conviction that better days are, ahead for the American economy, there is little evidence of fear so far that inflation is worsening or that business is pointed toward a serious slowdown in the second half of the year comparable to the pause that developed in the final six months of 1976.

title: The Peseta Is Devalued
description: Americans planning a summer spree on the beaches of the Costa del Sol, along the boulevards of Barcelona, or in the palaces and museums of Madrid will find their fling considerably cheaper than they had anticipated. Last week Spain devalued the peseta by a whopping 24.9 percent, allowing the currency to float downward to a new level of 87.50 to the dollar, compared with the range of 69.89 to 70.09 when the market closed the previous week.

title: Miss Universe Crown Is Won by First Black
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sunday, July 17 (AP)A jubilant Miss TrinidadTobago, Janelle Commissiong, became the first black to be crowned Miss Universe last night.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: LONDON It is not really curious this power that Shakespeare so clearly exerts upon choreographers. One of the prime difficulties of ballet is simply that of narrative structure or basic storytelling and, for the most part, the fullevening work does need some kind of story for its base. What better than Shakespeare? The actual stories are usually well knownit is difficult to envisage a ballet audience that will be unacquainted with Hamletand the characters themselves have acquired that peculiarly emblematic quality through familiarity and custom, which makes them uncommonly suitable for choreographic translation.

title: Another Consequence of the MiddleClass Migration to the Suburbs
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J.To a casual visitor, and even to many residents, Morris County, with its closeclipped lawns, wellcaredfor houses, and general picture of abundance, seems to be the model sociologists have in mind when they talk about affluent America.

title: A Homecoming for Valentine
description: AT THE AGE of 20, he was the Player of the Year in the TripleA Pacific Coast Leaguea fleet, powerhitting shortstop with Spokane who had led the league with a .340 batting average, hit 19 home runs, knocked in 80 runs, stole 29 bases and was the league leader in double plays by a shortstop.

title: Gilbert Deitch Fiance Of Susan Paula Chase
description: Susan Paula Chase of Atlanta, specialevents director for Rich's, the department store chain in the Southeast, and Gilbert H. Deitch, a partner in the Atlanta law firm of Shulman, Bauer, Deitch, Raines & Hester, will be married in September in Atlanta.

title: BRIDGE
description: ONE of New England's most talented young bridge players, Ross Grabel of Rocky Hill, Conn., was within measurable distance of a major success during the last three days. He was teamed with five experts from the Boston area in the national quarterfinal stage of the prestigious Grand National Team Championship.

title: MEDICAL SPECIMENS SPOILED IN BLACKOUT
description: Several research projects involving frozen specimens collected from humans and animals with cancer, genetic disorders and other diseases were seriously hamperedpossibly ruinedbecause of the power failure in New York City last week.

title: Police Union Rejects an Offer For Settling Its Contract Dispute
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association formally rejected an arbitrator's proposal for settling its contract dispute New York City and served notice that it would file an appeal in 10 days with the city's Board of Collective Bargaining.

title: The Case of the Camouflaged Chickweed
description: HAS Agatha Christie developed a secret desire in your breast to solve the perfect crime? Does television's Cannon give you ambitions to solve the crime of the century every week?

title: Party for African Students
description: Cocktails and auction bids will be inorder at the party Thursday for the African Student's Aid Fund at the fund's offices at 10 East 87th Street. Artifacts from Ethiopia, Ghana, Cameroon, Mali, the Ivory Coast and Nigeria will be on the block. Admission is $5 at the door.

title: China Paid a Price
description: TWO thirds of the way through this peculiarly ambivalent book Alain Peyrefitte says, It hard both to temper one's admiration for the regime with restraint and to temper one's criticism with understanding. The challenge does not seem to have been too hard for Peyrefitte, for overall he comes down solidly on the side of admiration, above all for Mao Tsetung and the legacy he left China when he died.

title: IN AMERICA
description: SACRAMENTO. For six glorious weeks last year, the daring young man crisscrossed the country, rousing audiences with a medley of themes that almost made them forget the Dixie lullabies of Jimmy Carter. There was the stern Era of Limits, the stirring Space Ship Earth and the visionary Planetary Realism. Between performances on the stump, Jerry Brown showed the critics that he could discourse on the subject of why government doesn't work with more originality, wit and, yes, even depth than any reasonable person could expect to find in a candidate. Whether he could also govern was another question, which tended to get lost in discussions of whether anyone could. A year later, Brown is still discoursing, still performing, but if you listen closely, he seems to be singing another tune.

title: A Prophecy Fulfilled
description: For all its other fascinating aspects, the 1977 blackout of New York City will be remembered primarily for the looting and burning that erupted as soon as the lights went out and which ultimately resulted in the arrest of more than 3,700 persons, as well as untold property damage and heartbreaking losses for innocent merchants.

title: Detroit's Trim New Gas Sippers
description: DETROITAn extraordinary year for American automobiles is about to begin.

title: On the Curious Fruit of the Potato Plant
description: Excited home gardeners believe they have discovered a new vegetable when they report finding a potato plant bearing tomatoes. They dream of achieving fame and fortune by introducing a new vegetable that will produce two cropsa bountiful harvest of tomato fruit in the summer and a multitude of potato tubers in the fall. Almost invariably, everyone independently selects the same name for this proposed new vegetable: the pomato.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Lenny Randle of the Mets, at bat at Shea Stadium when the blackout struck Wednesday night: I thought for sure He was calling me. I thought it was my last atbat.

title: Tiger Cub Strolls on Soviet Beach
description: MOSCOW, July 16 (AP)A 220pound tiger cub escaped from its circus cage and took a stroll down a crowded beach at the Black Sea resort of Sochi recently, before being persuaded by its trainer to come home, the Sunday newspaper Nedelya reported today. The tiger cub was goodnatured throughout.

title: The Region
description: For most of what lab been the longest regular legislative session in Albany since 1911, lawmakers seemed to do little but dodge or postpone issues. The lethargy seemed understandable, at least to the legislators. It followed two dramatic years during which they worked hard with Governor Carey to keep New York City and state agencies from bankruptcy. As Manfred Ohrenstein, the Senate's minority leader, explained, It's hard to get psyched up for lesser issues.

title: A Former Prisoner Helps Others Go Straight
description: There came a point in Fred Marra's life when he decided he couldn't go to prison again. He was 36 years old and had spent 16 of those years, off and on, behind bars.

title: Crime Pays A Prison Boom
description: Rising crime rates and public demands for stricter law enforcement have created a growth industry out of prison construction.

title: Article 21  No Title
description: to be built. And by one of those fortunate strokes of destiny, Palladio was there to build them.

title: FISHING
description: PATCHES of bluefish in varying concentrations are providing some good, although at times frustratingly inconsistent, action for Long Island fishermen. A new school of large bluefish has arrived at Shark's Ledge southeast of Block Island, and the Cholera Banks off the South Shore and the Steppingstones in western Long Island Sound also are producing big choppers up to 15 pounds.

title: ART
description: ROSLYN THE WORD is that the art world slows down in the summer. The pulsebeats of the dealers, the museum people and the artists are supposed to work at a more moderate rate. But we really know that things are moving much faster than we might care to believe, as shows are organized and hung for the summer, and guidelines are laid down for the coming season.

title: LorieAnn Schwartz Fiancee Of Dr. Alexander S. Bernath
description: Dr. and Mrs. Murray N. Schwartz of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, LoriAnn Schwartz, to Dr. Alexander Sandor Bernath, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Bernath of Mount Vernon, N. Y.

title: Susan Stein, Stuart Moshell, Law Graduates, Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Stein of North Bellmore, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Stein, to Stuart Ronald Moshell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Moshell of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The Positive Side At Stony Brook

title: Priorities on the Aged
description: AGING is beginning to come of age in Connecticut. Strong budget support by Governor Grasso, new legislative programs passed by the 1977 General Assembly and expanding public involvement all are evidence of a growing Connecticut commitment to services for and with the aging.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Women's Conference: A Sight to Behold

title: When Profits Go Down, Down, Down...
description: Once again, despite the nation's economic recovery, a corporate giant, reeling from a cash squeeze and the demands of its banks, found itself resorting last week to the protection of the Federal Bankruptcy Act and successfully obtained court permission to reorganize its affairs while keeping its creditors at bay.

title: GARDENING
description: AMERICA is a land dedicated to change in the name of progress. Each day, old landmarks fall as sturdy buildings, some only 40 or 50 years old, are demolished to make way for new construction or parking lots.

title: The Payoff
description: Federal crime insurance, like conventional commercial coverage, usually does not pay the full value of stolen property. Deductibles aside, payment is generally made on a depreciated basis. A TV set, for example, might be arbitrarily assigned a life of seven years. If the set is two years old, the householder can expect to recover only fivesevenths of its cosi.

title: BEGIN IS PLANNING A VISIT TO CROWN HEIGHTS TODAY
description: Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel spent his second day in New York quietly yesterday, remaining at his hotel and observing the Sabbath. He met there with friends.

title: If You Go...
description: ... to Tikal, Aerolineas de Guatemala Aviateca will fly you there from Guatemala City for $100 round trip. Arrangements must be made in Guatemala: at the airport in Guatemala City or through a travel agent. The oniy direct flights (four and a half hours) from Kennedy Airport in New York are on Pan American World Airways. A regular roundtrip fare in coach costs $504, but 10to30day excursion fares are available most of the year for $375 midweek and $415 on weekends. American tourists must obtain a tourist card, which can be picked up at the Pan American desk at Kennedy, the Guatemalan Consulate, 1270 Avenue of the Americas, New York 10026 (tel.: 2122465877), or through a travel agent.
