The card costs $1. In addition, a $1 charge is made for establishing proof of citizenship: a passport or birth certificate will suffice. There is a $5 departure tax when you leave Guatemala. Guatemala no longer requires a smallpox vaccination certificate.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: YOU may know what's going on in your own backyard, but you might be surprised at what's going on in your neighbors'. Spoke to a stunned couple from Queens the other day who had just visited an uncle's house in Saddle Rock over the weekend for a barbecue.

title: 2 Again Assail Flynt Over Korea Inquiry; Prosecutor Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The chairman of the Republican. National Committee, Bill Brock, and a leader among House Democrats, Peter H. Kostmayer of Pennsylvania, excoriated the chairman of the House ethics committee, John J. Flynt Jr., Democrat of Georgia, and renewed today their demand that a special prosecutor take over the investigation of the South Korean scandal here.

title: Some Major Democratic Incumbents Face Tough Primary Fightq
description: While most of me attention has been focused on the mayoral primaries in both the Democratic and Republican Parties, the filing of designating petitions last week showed that some of the cites major Democratic office Milers also face stiff challenges in the Democratic primhelminary, which in this overwhelmingly Democratic city is invariably tantamout to the election.

title: Washington Tourney Features McEnroe
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)The accent will be on youth in the $125,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament this week, with the two topranked players in the worldBjorn Borg and Jimmy Connorsmissing.

title: What Role for Neutron Bomb?
description: WASHINGTONTo its opponents, the neutron bomb is a frightening, especially ugly weapon that must have been developed by a mad gnome at the Pentagon or Dr. Strangelove. It's in the realm of the unconscionable, said Senator Mark O. Hatfield, the Oregon Republican, who led the losing fight in the Senate last week to bar funds for the bomb. It raises the greatest probability and potential of introducing nuclear weaponry into conventional warfare.

title: Miss Wetherill Will Be Bride Of Peter Gerry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Elkins Wetherill of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., and Waldoboro, Me., of the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Wetherill, to Peter Goelet Gerry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elbridge Thomas Gerry of Old Westbury, L.I., and Delhi, N.Y.

title: The Voter Gets a Voice
description: MANY influential members of the General Assembly opposed passage of a Presidential primary bill in 1977. No one really in the know around the State Capitol thought the bill had any chance as short a time as two and half weeks before the legislature adjourned. Yet, by a 128to17 vote in the House and with the unanimous consent of the Senate, the General Assembly recently mandated a Presidential primary for both parties in 1980the first such state law in Connecticut's history.

title: Susan Ruggiero Engaged To Clifford P. Simonetti
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Ruggiero of Valhalla, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ruggiero, to Clifford P. Simonetti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander J. Simonetti of Thornwood, N. Y.

title: Lorraine Wilowski Wed to Grant Gibson
description: In the chapel of Manhattanville College in Purchase, N. Y., yesterday morning, Lorraine Marie Wilowski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey E. Wilowski of Bayside, Queens, and Aquebogue, L. I., became the bride of Grant Henry Gibson, son of Billie Gibson of Seattle and the late Capt. Grant Hanley Gibson, Merchant Marine.

title: HITERVIEW
description: MATT BONORA has some ideas about the individual known as the 44caliber killer or Son of Sam. Mr.Bonora believes the killer is outwardly a very straight person without a criminal background. He is an individual who has been spurned by a woman, and every time he attacks a woman he is, in effect, shooting the woman who rejected him.

title: GARDENING
description: GETTING there is half the fun, say some of the travel ads. But for many commuters the daily ride into and out of Grand Central Station is just the same old routine. Diversions. That's what's needed. There are a few established ones. Newspapers. Maps. Bridge games. Chess. Catchup work.

title: Brooklyn College Has Versatile Toolin Accelerator
description: After more than two years of installation problems and labor disputes, the city's only Dynamitron accelerator, a machine designed for sophisticated nuclear and atomic research, has gone into operation at Brooklyn College.

title: BYRD SAYS THE BLACKOUT MAY SPARK ENERGY ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, said today that New York City's power failure should give impetus to President Carter's energy program. He added that the Senate would remain in session this fall until it completed action on the program.

title: Salvation Army Aide Named
description: Maj. David A. Baxendale has been appointed principal of the school for officers' training of the Salvation Arley in. Suffern, N.Y. Major Baxendale, who was on the school's faculty from 1962 to 1966, served for the put two years as the organization's divisional commander for southwestern Ohio and northwestern Kentucky, with headquarters in Cincinnati.

title: Finding Fault With NoFault
description: NOFAULT auto insurance, an issue that has been embroiled in political and legislative maneuvering in Albany for three months, is now having a summer rerun in the struggle for the Republican nomination for Nassau County Executive.

title: COUPLES IN FEDERAL JOBS EARN SIXFIGURE INCOMES
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)Led by Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker and his wife, former Ambassador Carol C. Laise, five married couples who work for the executive branch have joint salaries of $100,000 or more, the National Journal has reported.

title: Deaths
description: ALBERTOLionel B. On July 15, 1977. Beloved husband of Salving H. Devoted father of Sally Farrar, Yvonne Vagle, 3 loving grandchildren, 1 great granddaughter. Reposing Fred Herbst Sons Funeral Home, 5th Avenue at 75 Street, Brooklyn, Sunday, 25, 79:30 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial. Monday 11:45 St. Ephrems R.C. Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Cerisa Eugenie Bogert Plans August Wedding To William Throop 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Calvin Bogert of Newtown Square, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cerisa Eugenie Bogert, to William MacIntosh Throop 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Throop of New Canaan, Conn.

title: What Jackie Robinson Meant to an Old Friend
description: It was October, maybe November, in 1945 and I was on a Navy transport ship coming back from overseas, from Guam. I'd played shortstop for the Brooklyn Dodgers for three seasons, then into the Navy for the duration, as they used to say during the war. Now I was finally coming home, and somebody on board told me that the Dodgers had signed a black ballplayer. And that was the first time I can remember being aware of Jackie Robinson's arrival on the baseball scene.

title: Princeton's Animal Kingdom:
description: THE average community animal shelter may put to death up to 85 percent of the stray pets it takes in every year; only the lucky few get adopted. At the Princeton Small Animal Rescue League shelter, the odds are reversed. The great majority of pets are adopted; few are destroyed.

title: Auto Racing
description: BRITISH GRAND PRIX

title: Wine Talk
description: HEY, get'cha cold beer was once as familiar to most New Yorkers as God Save the Queen is to most Londoners. Beer and baseball are theon of American myths. Like Gallagher and Sheean, bacon and eggs, and Sonny and Cher.

title: Rescuing the Sewer District
description: PAULINE in all her perils hardly went through all the twists and turns of fate that have buffeted Suffolk County's monstrousand monstrously expensiveSouthwest Sewer District Project. And as with the heroine of the silent movies, fate has turned out to be a lot kinder to the sewer project than the taxpaying audience believed possible during the early years of the East Coast's largest public construction project.

title: Oh Hits 738th Homer
description: TOKYO, July 16 (AP)The Hiroshima Carp beat the Yomiuri Giants, 42, today as Sadaharu Oh hit his 23d home run of the season and 738th of his career. Jim Lyttle, a former New York Yankee, also homered for the winners.

title: Italian Diver Scores Victory Over Boggs
description: BOLZANO, Italy, July 16 (UPI)Giorgio Cagnotto of Italy won the men's springboard event of an international diving meet today, defeating Volk Hoffmann of East Germany and the world champion, Phil Boggs of the United States.

title: Publishing Thrives in Westchester
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Philip Cohen, founder and president of Oceana Publications, moved his Manhattanbased company to Dobbs Ferry. Bradbury Press, publisher of children's books, left New Jersey in 1971 for Scarsdale so that employees could drive to work and wear jeans, according to Richard Jackson, the company's editor and vice president.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Bolmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: Park Slope Group Withdraws $865,000 From a Bank It Says Redlines
description: Last week more than 300 Park Slope residents withdrew about $865,000 in savings from local banks they accuse of redliningsystematically refusing to grant mortgages in specific, usually depressed neighborhoods. They called their action'bank withdrawal week.

title: Ballet: Ala Recherche du Rambert
description: LONDON, July 12The Ballet Barnhart Is Britain's oldest dance company. It celebrated its half century last year, and its founder, 89yearold Dame Marie Rambert, is still happily clucking over its future. The director nowadays is John Chesworth, and what began as an adventurous classic ballet companyit started the careers of both 7 Freerick Ashton and Antony Tudoris now still an adventurous moderndance troupe.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: After flagrant Russian breaching of new United States fishing regulations, culminating in the Coast Guard's seizure of a trawler that bad overfished for herring off Boston, the State Department warned the Soviet Union last April 11 that further violations could lead to a worsening of our bilateral relations.

title: The importance of timely harvesting to fine wines.
description: In order to make the best possible wine, we want to crush our grapes only at the very peak of their maturity. Our experience. of course, tells us approximately when each varietal grape will reach that point, but it is important that we know precisely when the grapes will reach that critical point of maturity.

title: Race, Discrimination and Standards in Medical School Admissions
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Stuck in New York this summer? Go to the CooperHewitt Museum (2 East 91st Street) for a little vicarious and wonderful resort hopping. An exhibition of resort and vacation architecture called Palaces for the People offers instant delight and refreshment through Sept. 11. The photographs, drawings, models, postcards and artifacts (actual table settings, menus and matchbooks from a galaxy of celebrated and obscure hotels and motels) packed into the small downstairs gallery cover 100 years of America seriously at play.

title: Endangered: The Museums of the Soul
description: THE fancy title now is Multimedia Center, but to me it is still just plain library. It always has been, and always will be, a place where books are available for everyone. Library is still a beautiful word.

title: Group Trips for the Mature
description: If you are at least 55 years old, you may be eligible for the discounts that are increasingly being offered at hotels, restaurants, resorts and sightseeing attractions, especially if you are prepared to travel midweek or offseason and are a member of a group of 40 or more. Many resorts have found that with guaranteed reservations from a sizable groupand a substantial depositthey can trim their rates and add a few inexpensive frillsa song fest, a guided stroll through the grounds, a hayride.

title: Critic in Assembly Wins $40,000 In Aid for Canarsie Health Unit
description: Why would a Brooklyn legislator who called the Canarsie Health Station a good, oldfashioned piece of pork barrel solicit only words of praise from the facility's administrators? Because the same man, Assembly Majority Leader Stanley J. Fink, had just secured a $40,000 appropriation from the State Legislature that will enable the health station to remain open through fiscal 1978.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: Weimar Gets Denver Post
description: DENVER, July 16 (AP)Bill Weimar, an assistant coach to Al Harden last season, was named the head basketball coach at the University of Denver today. Harden resigned in May.

title: Nancy L. Munder Wed To Joel Kirk Pondelik
description: Nancy Lynn Munder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Munder of Fort Salonga, L. I., was married there yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church to Joel Kirk Pondelik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pondelik of Riverside. III. The Rev. Robert Jewett performed the ceremony.

title: Boit Wins 800 Meters In Slow Time of 1:48.2
description: MOMBASA, Kenya, July 16 (Reuters) Mike Boit of Kenya today won the 800meter run in the slow time of 1 minute 48.2 seconds here at a trial track meet for the first World Athletics Cup in Duesseldorf, West Germany, next September.

title: High Court Shows Consistency
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)The Supreme Court wrote opinions on 176 cases in the recent term, the same number as in the previous two terms. Statistics compiled by the court clerk showed that 4,730 cases were put on the court's docket in the work session that ended July 6, as against 4,761 in 1975 and 4,668 in 1974.

title: W.P.A. Legacy
description: The heritage of the Federal Arts Projects of the Works Progress Administration of the 1930's can still be seen in schools, post offices and libraries in 16 Westchester communities. The projects were established not only to give unemployed artists work and relief but, as one of the directors said, to feed the hunger of millions for music, books, plays and pictures. The prevalent medium locally was the mural and the subjects usually historic or social, as the titles will indicate:

title: New York State Gathers Windfall in Tax Revenue For 3 Months of Its Year
description: ALBANY, July 16New York State finished the first three months of its fiscal year with $200 million more cash on hand than It had expected, state officials reported this week.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the jolt of the trade, Tom Seaver was a stranger in paradise. During his decade with the New York Mets, he had won 189 games despite a torturous amount of runs from teammates he understood. Suddenly he was with the Cincinnati Reds, who produce a joyous amount of runs for a pitcher, but he did not know his teammates except by reputation. After a month in his redtrimmed uniform, Tom Seaver has adjusted. I feel, he was saying, like a Red now. It's no one thing, just being with this club day after day, understanding new people. And their understanding him.

title: Gas That Killed 1 in Vegas Hotel Is Linked to Auxiliary Generator
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 16 (UPI)The gas that spread though the towering Landmark Hotel and Casino yesterday, killing one person and hospitalizing 138, was carbon monoxide from the exhaust of an auxiliary power, generator, investigators for the fire department said today.

title: DIVISIONS AMONG WOMEN HELD POLITICAL HINDRANCE
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 16 (UPI)Women have beer. losing seats in Congress because of division in their ranks stemming from efforts to pass the equal rights amendment, according to Carmela Lacayo, Democratic Vice Chairman.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JULY 17, 1977

title: The Faith of a Flower Child
description: LAUREL LEE, just past 30, mother of two small children, is pregnant with her third child when she discovers that she has Hodgkin's disease. First, this former flower child now into Jesus, fights for the safety of her unborn daughter, refusing, abortion and postponing radiation therapy until the infant is safely delivered. She then begins walking through the fire of operations and radiation. She keeps a record of events. She draws illustrations of flowers and birds and parts of machines. She writes down lines from the Bible. She embroiders and teaches one of her doctors how to do a herringbone stitch. She misses her children, but when home from the hospitals, finds she's too sick to take care of them. She hemorrhages on the floor and grows weak.

title: Where Are All Those ExGiants Now?
description: Craig Morton is listed as the No.?? quarterback, behind Craig Penrose and Norris Weese, on the Deaver Broncos.

title: Stephanie Appleby Severance Engaged to Robert McCarter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm D. Severance of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mr. Severance's daughter, Stephanie Appleby Severance, to Robert Young McCarter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. P. McCarter, also of Rumson. The wedding is planned for September.

title: If a Conversation Travels Through the Air, Chances Are Growing that It's Not Secret
description: WASHINGTONIn the mid1960's Soviet intelligence agents began appearing at a wide range of business and professional meetings on computer technology in the United States, Western Europe and Japan. The. Soviet Union was woefully behind the West in the use of computers, and it was clear from the reports that they had made data on computers a to spying assignment.

title: New Mission for Missionary
description: AFTER 30 years of service in foreign lands, the Rev. Cyprian M. Sullivan is back in his native state, his missionary spirit unquenched. The genial 63yearold priest, who was born in Newark, celebrated the 40th anniversary of his ordination on May 22.

title: Francesco Cardinal Roberti Dies; Was a Member of Vatican Curia
description: ROME, July 16 (AP)Francesco Cardinal Roberti, an expert in canonical law and a member of the Vatican Curia for many years, died at a Rome hospital today, the Vatican announced. He was 87 years old and had been suffering from progressive paralysis for several years.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Among the freshestlooking table linens around are those CacheCache makes up from its own fabrics. There are two cotton floralsboth the essence of spring. English Garden offers nosegays of bright flowers on a white ground. Sharon has scatterings of rather Chineselooking orange and yellow flowers on grass green. Or you can get the linens made up white piqu. Some of the designs, like placemats and napkins, are scalloped in contrasting binding. You can also order the linens in solid colors with any binding. Placemats (fabric or laminated) are $5, napkins are $5, cocktail napkins are $2.50. There are also trays from $18 to $25, straw French bread baskets with fabric liners, $20, and laminated coasters, $7.50 for six. Or you can have a round cloth made to order. In white piqu, with a color border, a cloth covering a 3footdiameter table to the ground is $55; the same size cloth in a floral is $75. CacheCache is at 758 Madison Avenue (between 65th and 66th Streets).

title: For Maurice Abravanel, All Roads Led to Utah
description: Last November, Maurice Abravanel, the venerable conductor and music director of the Utah Symphony Orchestra, was walking on a Paris street when he,felt a searing pain in his shoulder, In New York a few days later the same thing happened. One visit to a doctor and Abravanel was rushed back to his adopted home of Salt Lake City and checked into a hospital to undergo openheart surgery.

title: U.S AID RESTRICTIONS CALLED INCOMPLETE.
description: A recently completed and detailed analysis of American foreign aid to eight developing countries indicates that the United States is still providing significant support to regimes that allegedly violate human rights, and is stepping up aid to one of themIndonesia.

title: Behind Todd of Jets, Three's a Crowd
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 16It is an honest, old profession, recalling names like Mike Taliaferro, Bob Davis, Al Woodall and, yes, even Richard Todd.

title: EnglishSpeaking Whites, Frearing the Onset of a Racial Flareup, Flee From South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 16A few weeks ago, a wealthy Durban socialite flew 320 miles to Johannesburg to keep a longstanding appointment with a medical specialist, only to find his office abandoned. Inquiring among other doctors in the building, she learned that he had left South Africa for the United Stateson a oneway ticket and without a word to his patients.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now: Samuel DeMillia, president of the Patrolman's Benevolent Association.

title: Kathy A. Kornreich Planning Wedding to Samuel Weinberg
description: Mr. and Mrs, Matthew R. Kornreich of Harrison, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathy Ann Kornreich, to Samuel G. Weinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Weinberg of New York.

title: Farming Without Soil
description: WHENEVER P. A. Schippers drove along the rambling country roads that cut across acres of farmland in the Riverhead area, he couldn't help noticing that several greenhouses were not being used. This, of course, was not an unusual observation. A lot of people who traverse the back roads leading into town could see the same thing.

title: THEATER
description: A TANNERY next door to an insane, asylum one hour out of New York City in the Connecticut countryside may not strike you as the ideal setting for a summer theater, but it did strike the Theater Guild almost halt a century ago as just what they wanted.

title: PETER EDSON, EXCOLUMNIST DISCLOSED 1952 NIXON FUND
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)Peter Edson, retired national columnist for the Newspaper Enterprise Association, died here Thursday after suffering a stroke. He was 81 years old.

title: Florida Swamp Fires Contained
description: MADISON, Fla., July 16 (AP)Fire officials said today they had contained several stubborn swamp fires smoldering in a threecounty area of droughtstricken northern Florida.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: Miscellany
description: BIG APPLE CIRCUSBattery Park. Weds., 10:15 and 1:15; Thurs., 1: Fris., 7:30; Sats. 1 and 7:30; Suns., 1 and 4. (For information, call 5863581)

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: UNTIL a couple of weeks ago, I was, I suppose, a felon of sorts. It was nothing to worry the children about, of course, but nevertheless the fact is that I had evaded the law for several months.

title: In Paperback
description: In the July 3 issue the review of Dangers by Heather McHugh failed to mention that a paperback edition at $4.50 was available from Houghton Mifflin's New Poetry Series.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: No Luck at Bryant Pond
description: DORCHESTER. N.H.The fat brook trout of Bryant Pond now have eluded me for more than a decade.

title: Rise in Deaths Linked to Alcohol Is Reported by Doctors in Denmark
description: COPENHAGEN, July 16 (Reuters)Two doctors studying Danish drinking habits have reported a steep rise in the number of Danes dying from cirrhosis of the liver.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: For Sale 3702.

title: A Girl's Dream House, With No Mortgage and No Taxes
description: EVER hear of painting a window frame with a Qtip, wallpapering six rooms in one day or putting in a grain of wheat light bulb? That is, did you ever build a dollhouse?

title: Melissa W. Milam, Harry E. Ekblorm Jr. To Marry Aug. 13
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Henry Killay of Washington have announced the engagement of Mrs. K hay's daughter, Melissa Wilson Milam of New York, to Harry Edward Ekblom Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ekblom of Ridgewood, N. J. The wedding is planned for Aug. 13 at St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: If You Go ...
description: ... to Caramoor from New York, take the Hutchinson River Parkway north until it becomes Interstate 684. Take Exit 6 at State Route 35 for Katonah, then turn right on Route 22, which continues onto State Route 137. Caramoor is about half a mile from the juncture of the two roads, on the right. Look sharp for the sign.

title: If You Go ...
description: ... on U.S. 89 through Montana, carry cash or traveler's checks, especially at the Glacier National Park end of the route, because credit cards may not be accepted for food or lodging. Write or call ahead for accommodations; a good midpoint stop is the Heritage Inn (doubles $26$32, tel: 4067611900) in Great Falls. For dinner, try the Black Angus Steak House ($2.95$7.95), one of the reliable Montana chain of 4B's restaurants.

title: Rachel Mizrahi Fiancee Of Bruce Siegel, Lawyer
description: The engagement of Rachel R. Mizrahi to Bruce A. Siegel, a lawyer with the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been announced by the future scle's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Mizrahi of New York. Mr. Siegel is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Siegel of Pomona. N.Y.

title: Spain Orders Extra Security
description: MADRID, July 16 (Reuters)The Spanish Interior Ministry has ordered extra security around government buildings, power stations and other strategic sites next Monday, the 41st anniversary of the nationalist uprising that led to the Civil War and the dictatorship of General Franco.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE'S an ugly commercial sprawl lining Route 7 between Danbury and New Milford, a manmade blight of gas stations, fastfood restaurants, movie houses, package stores, diners and shopping centers. Amid this confusion, between an autoequipment shop and a realestate agency stand two substantial brick gateposts, the sort that usually mark the forbidden entrance to a vast, private domain.

title: THE MOST INFLUENTIAL ARCHITECT IN HISTORY
description: If architecture is the inescapable art. then Andrea Palladio is the inescapable architect. For more than 400 years, his work has dominated the style and substance of the Western world. It is no exaggeration to call Palladio the most influential architect in history.

title: Food
description: We don't often write about nutrition because we believe that any wellplanned meal, by its very nature, will he well balanced in the nutritional sense. Salads are part and parcel of good nutrition and, with rare exceptions, should have a place in almost every major meal year in and year out (someone is bound to ask what the exceptions are and one answer is: following a platter of sauerkraut). Good nutrition aside, salads can be delectable, particularly during the summer months. Here is an assortment of salads for the season: a fine, elegant, luxurystyle European salade gourmand with lettuce, asparagus, green beans, avocado, foie gras and truffles. Much more earthy and robust but irresistible is a salad of tomato with sliced onion and gorgonzola cheese. A bit more prosaic are the hearts of palm bean dishes.

title: Article 16  No Title
description: For Sale 3702

title: Peter Birnbaum Fiance Of Christine M. Sullivan
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Sullivan of Westwood, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Mary Sullivan, to Peter Birnbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Birnbaum of New York and Hillsdale. N. Y.

title: Miss Bushkin Wins In Equitation Class
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., July 16Tippy Bushkin of San Diego. Calif., who arrived in the metropolitan area less than a week ago, won the United States Equestrian Team equitation class, today at the second session of the threeday Century horse show.

title: Article 22  No Title
description: Your vacation lives up to your dreams at the Aruba Caribbean Hotel!

title: 3 TeenAgers Killed in Crash
description: CONNEAUT LAKE, Pa., July 16 (AP)Three Crawford County teenagers died early today in a threecar accident on Pennsylvania 285 near here. The state police identified the victims as Michael Lasch, 18 years old, and William Bossard, 16, both of Conneaut Lake, and Sandra Lou Jones, 19, of Linesville.

title: F.H.A. Policing of Loans Criticized as Inadequate
description: The policing mechanisms set up in 1975 by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development to curb widespread abuses in Federal Housing Administration loan programs have proven to be totally inadequate, according to a. report by the Housing Research Group, which is funded by Ralph Nader.

title: Topics
description: Aiding Mozanibique

title: Roosevelt
description: (OTB payoris subject to 5% Municipal surtax.)

title: F. M. Bush Is Fiance Of Catherine Murphy
description: The engagement of Catherine Marie Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester V. Murphy Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, LI., and Christiansted, St. Croix, V.I., to Frederick Morris Bush, son of the late Col. Morris Bush, U.S.A., and the late Mrs. Bush of Littleton, Colo., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Commuters' Lot in the Parking Game
description: PARKING space in Fairfield County is a frequently absent commodity. The commuter belt from Greenwich to Westport has 346,000 residents, and each of these residents has 1.6 cars. So at the commuter parking lots or in the shopping districts of the towns, the name of the game is space. It is probable that drivers here have vented more spleen on this subject than on any other single topic, aside from than taxes.

title: ... But Laws May Bar Rise Of More Hotels
description: THE advent of casino gambling is bringing a battle of the second front to Atlantic City. Although many visitors think of this coastal resort of 40,000 people only as a long strip of beach, boardwalk, amusement piers, hotels, motels and restaurants, it also is a city of varied residential sections. It is a city that is half black and has many Hispanic people. And it is a city on an island that is twothirds grassy wetlands, unpopulated lowland areas regulated by the state to preserve marine ecology. These sections are barred to new residential or industrial development.

title: Article 26  No Title
description: Alan Reinsold

title: Making Friends Through Soccer
description: NORTH BABYLON SOCCER, one of the fastestgrowing team sports in the nation, seems to add a new wrinkle each day, and the latest is the tournament  a kind of oldfashioned revival meeting where people come from miles around to hear and see the gospel according to the Laws of Association Football played out on a series of fields 100 yards wide by 130 yards deep.

title: Dolisa Lund Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Dolisa Oteka Lund to Loring Pickering 4th, son of Mrs. Harold L. Yoh of Philadelphia and Palm Beach, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Col. Sigurd A. Lund, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Lund of Beach Mountain, N. C. Miss Lund is a graduate of the University of South Florida, where her fianc is in his senior year.

title: Case of the Angry Chairman And Even Angrier Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTONIt all started earlier this month with a confidential memo from Philip A. Lacovara, special counsel to the House ethics committee for its inquiry into the Korean candal on Capitol Hill. And it ended last week in a manner that left the investigation in tatters.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: BOOK ENDS
description: ANITA BRYANT to the contrary, books by, for, about homosexuals continue to pour out. Two recent ones symbolize the conflicting images of homosexuals abroad in the culture. One, The David Kopay Story, by the former pro football player falls into the currently popular coming out upbeat confessional genre. Heavily promoted by Mr. Kopay on television, it was on the Best Seller List for seven weeks. The other, The Sexual Outlaw by John Rechy, whose City of Night was a shocker and best seller in 1963, is called by its'author a documentary novel and employs essays and a parade of explicit sex scenes to protest antihomosexual laws. The Sexual Outlaw is not a best seller and both Grove Press president Barney Rosset and Mr. Rechy's editor there, Kent Caroll, feel that a ban on radio and TV advertising in the New York area has hurt sales. The stations' objections were not to the ads themselves but to the content of Mr. Rechy's book, which was considered too graphic.

title: U.S. Labor Aide Says Women's Goal On Apprenticeships Is Impossible
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., July 14  A Federal Labor Department official dismissed today as absolutely impossible demands of feminist organizations that women receive places in Federally registered apprenticeship programs in proportion to the number of women in the labor force.

title: Absentee Leadership
description: FAIRFIELDERS can no longer sit back, complacently assuming that our Representative Town Meeting is providing the kind of balance that a legislative body is intended to exert upon the executive branch. At the session on the annual budget a few weeks ago, a $35.8 million budget was approved unanimously with barely any discussion by 33 members. Twentyone members were absent. (There is one vacancy.)

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: ART

title: Time Is No Longer Running Out; It's Gone
description: When the lights went out, a teenaged Harlem youngster is saying outside a Lenox Avenue food shop, I did my natural thing. I hit the streets, looking to get over.

title: BLACKOUT A PROBLEM FOR FRESH AIR CROUP
description: Here's the problem: You've got 850 children due to return to the city tomor. row and 1,000 more to send to the country tomorrow, when the lights go out. Public transportation stops dead in its tracks. What do you do?

title: AMIN SAID TO SHARE POWER WITH A MILITARY GROUP
description: TORONTO. July 16 (AP)A Canadian journalist has quoted a top aide to President Idi Amin of Uganda as having said that the President was not the sole ruler of Uganda but got help from a military council.

title: Janet Morris Bishop Married To Ronald Smith, Engineer
description: Janet Morris Bishop of Portland, Ore., and Ronald Bromley Smith, a widower of Old Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday afternoon at the bridegroom's home. The Rev. Vincent O'Connor, pastor of St, Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn., and the Rev. Donald Stauffer, the rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, officiated.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Julius Baker, Hate. Fri., 8. Trout Quintet Schubert (Quintet for piano and strings). Rossini (Sonata Jar cello and bass), Mozart (Quartet in Gminor. K.478). N.Y. Chamber Soloists; Julies Levine, bass; Harriet Maureen, piano. Sat. 8: Four Seasons. AllVivaldi. N.Y.Chamber Soloists. Next Sun., 8. Mozart (Concerto is D. K.211; Concerto in A. K.239), Bach (Concerto in Dminor). N.Y.Chamber Soloists; Helen Kwatwasser, Eugene Drucker, violins Burtington, Vt.

title: The Pleasures and Pains of Finding a Job at the Age of 40
description: Dolores Moyano Martin, an expert in Hispanic affairs, put her feelings bluntly: Right after I had the second child, when I saw how much work it was to take care of two little boys in diapers, I was appalled, my prime objective was to get away from the children, to clear my head and breathe; so I decided to go back to work, but I still felt terribly guilty.

title: Helen Childs Is Wed To Robert G. Burns
description: Helen Akin Childs and Robert Garfield Burns were married yesterday in Trinity Episcopal Church in York Harbor, Me. The Rev. Samuel S. Odom, assisted by the Rev. David Holroyd performed the ceremony.

title: Down the Road to 1985Tiny Cars
description: DETROITBeyond 1978, according to present plans, the shrinkage of United States cars will proceed in overlapping stages toward 1985the year when the V8 engine should be all but extinct, the biggest car will weigh about as much as today's compacts and Detroitmade autos as a group are to average 27.5 miles per gallon.

title: DR. RALPH D. CASEY, 87, COMMUNICATIONS SCHOLAR
description: Dr. Ralph D. Casey, a pioneer in American journalism education and a nationally known scholar of public opinion and propaganda, died yesterday in Seattle, a spokesman for the University of Minnesota said.

title: The Swans of Mamaroneck: Breadwinning Beachcombers
description: NO ONE knows where they come from. No one knows where they go. But for as long as anyoneeven Stephen E. Johnstoncan remember, there have been swans on the beach at Mamaroneck.

title: Wife Joins Husband as Fight Judge
description: Carol Castellano's father enjoyed listening to the fights on the radio, and when Carol was growing up in Massachusetts she used to like to sit and listen with him. So when she moved to New York and married Tony Castellano, fulltime sales executive, parttime boxing judge and allround sports fan, Carol knew what she was in for. I knew Tony would go to all the fights whether he was judging or not, she say's, and I made up my mind I wasn't going to stay at home alone.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in the early editions of last Sunday's Times incorrectly stated, Irving Maidman, who owns a building housing an East Side massage parlor. Mr. Maidman does not own any massage parlors or any buildings containing a massage parlor. Mr. Maidman says that he owns no East Side property: The story accurately reported that the Maidman Realty Company, which is controlled by Irving Maidman, is the lessee of 670 Eighth Avenue, which is occupied by a pornography shop.

title: Desai Cancels Statue Honoring Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, July 16 (AP)Prime Minister Morarji Desai of India has intervened to halt the spending of $15,000 in precious foreign exchange to cast a sevenfoot bronze statue of his defeated predecessor, Indira Gandhi.

title: The Role of the Junior Olympics: A.A.U. Insists They Are Vital
description: I disagree strongly with the article by Garry Hill, managing editor of Track and Field News (Invest in Today's Sports, not Tomorrow's, June 5). Hill writes that the Sears Roebuck and Company sponsorship of the Amateur Athletic Union's Junior Olympics program is a case of money going to the wrong place (well, if not wrong then at least less right).

title: Nathalie Sarraute Talks About Her Newest Novel
description: CONTRADICTIONS. But she's always held that nothing is what it seems, that each of us creates an internal world of fantasy. Paradoxesbut after all, she's French. Yes, and Parisiennelook at her, age 74, she should be flattered by jet lag, yet she's flitting through New York, a tiny brown sparrow of a girl with straight white bangs, pert dark eyes alert with interest, hopping from one public reading to another, to the theater, to interviews, lunches and dinners and meetings with her publisher, sailing down Park Avenuebeautiful as everand up the Avenue of the Americasfantastique! J'adore New York.

title: A Blind Night
description: Distance and perspective on the New York blackout leave ugly pictures in the mind. Smoke hovering over Brooklyn; shards of glass and leftover litter covering Pitkin Avenue. The anguished face of a merchant whose life's work and savings have just disappeared through a broken storefront. There are lithe, dark, young bodies darting past, laden with booty. There is a bearded black man, standing on a street of his own youth, surveying the scene and pronouncing the looters rotten scum.

title: Scientists Urge Funds For Jupiter Mission
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 16 (UPI)A group of scientists has urged members of Congress to support funding for the proposed Jupiter Orbiter space mission that they say would enhance understanding of the earth's atmosphere.

title: Roosevelt Trot Mark Broken by Kash Minbar
description: WESTBURY L.J. July 16  Earl Cruise was fotced tonight to drive Kash Minbar, a hardtohandle 5yearold whom Hereye Filion refused to drive.

title: Cox Broadcasting Corp. Authorized To Acquire Atlanta Cable Television
description: ATLANTA, July 16The Federal Communications Commission has authorized the Cox Broadcasting Corporation of Atlanta to acquire full ownership of a cable television company and has granted Cox a twoyear waiver of its crossownership rule involving a local cable franchise.

title: Yanks Get Gifts, Then a 51 Setback,. Henderson Stars Again as Mets Win
description: Jerry Koosman crossed the Met' locker room after their game yesterday afternoon at Shea Stadium and placed a beer in Steve Henderson's locker. To Koosman and the other Mets, that meant the rookie left fielder had starred again.

title: Two Dissenting Views on Food Coops
description: THE idyllic picture Janet DeJulio painted in the July 3 Westchester Weekly section of an early morning expedition to Hunt's Point to buy produce for a suburban family food coop momentarily aroused a happy rush of memories for me.

title: What's Doing in ROME
description: VIGILANCEThe headlines are of violence but, for the most part, tourists need not worry. While handful of journalists, factory officials, university professors and students have been injured in these days of political unrest, tourists are not targets. Visitors do have to fret about the purse snatchers who whip along the narrow streets on motorbikes and grab handbags. Women should carry their bags away from curbs, and watch fat motorbikes coming from behind. Do not put off a visit because of the reports of riots and demonstrations. Millions of tourists are still flowing into this Eternal (and still relatively safe) City and finding it the delight it has always been, if somewhat more expensive.

title: Floyd, at 67202, Leads Nicklaus and Curl by 3
description: SUTTON, Mass., July 16Ray Floyd broke out of a threeway tie on the back nine this afternoon to take sole possession of the lead in the third round of the Pleasant Valley Classic golf tournament. He shot 67, four under par for the Pleasant Valley Country Club, for an aggregate of 202, or 11 under par for 54 holes.

title: County Aids Crime Victims
description: ANDREW PINKA,a Larchmont pharmacist who was robbed at gunpoint two years ago, is one of a select group of Americans for whom testifying in court has not meant hurry up and wait. Westchester Couty became one of eight areas in the nation to gain a VictimWitness Assistance Unit after Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Administration provided a $1 million grant for pilot programs. The Federal agency responded to studies showing that many Americans had lost confidence in the criminal justice system and did not even bother to report crimes.

title: Spinning Around the World On Recorded Folk Tales
description: Folk tales have apparently existed ever since there were people to tell them to each othertales or stories, as the dictionary puts it, handed down by word of mouth, by the'common people. All literature has its roots in these oral origins, and it is surprising in how many guises and in different cultures the same basic situations turn up. Talking tortoises and frogs abound on every continent; Cinderella surfaces in Africa as Umusha Mwaice; the heron and crab who run their race along a Melanesian shore are surely distant relatives of Aesop's hare and tortoise. The foolish folk in the South American story who believe that the moon has drowned in local lake and must be fished out have their counterparts in Ireland's Hudden and Dudden, who leap into Brown Lake to retrieve the reflections of their lost sheep and cattle. The stock of plots is limited.

title: INTERVIEW
description: THERE is good newsor maybe it's bad newsfor New Jersey duplicatebridge players: S. Bolton Schwartz of Normandy Beach is taking up the game again. After a 50year hiatus, during which he became New Jersey's most widely known newsman, Mr. Schwartz now has the time and inclination to resume a game in which he once had few peers. He has retired from the newspaper business.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH there are many things that can cause paint to peel around the outside of a wood house, the most frequent cause by far is moisturethat is, moisture that finds its way into the siding and saturates the wood behind the paint film.

title: Home Beat
description: Come As You Are

title: Let the Community Rebuild the Stores
description: The magnitude of the disaster that struck merchants in the looted sections of darkened New York is now apparent. Few lives were lost and injuries were for the most part borne, with rough justice, by those who tried to clamber through broken shop windows. The loss of property, however, was immense, especially if measured against the assets of small proprietors. Equally important is the loss of morale by the devastated shopkeepers, by New Yorkers generally, and by residents of the despoiled areas. These losses must be redressed.

title: BandAids and Berettas
description: GREENWICH WITH THE ADVENT of the supermarket, the discount chain and the fastfood franchise, the Great American Drugstore has kept up with the competition by becoming the purveyor of a vast array of goods and services. Grannick's Pharmacy at 277 Greenwich Avenue is no exception. Since opening in 1943 it has relocated three times. Each move has been to larger quarters, providing more space for more merchandise. These days, Grannick's sells all the expected items, pharmaceuticals, surgical appliances, notions, cosmetics, and that is unexpectedguns.

title: Files on C.I.A. DrugTesting Work Said to List Prominent Doctors
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Records of a secret Central Intelligence Agency drug testing program contain the names of several prominent physicians and medical institutions that conducted some of the experiments, senior intelligence officials said today.

title: THE REV. EDMUND VASVARY, HISTORIAN AND AUTHOR
description: The Rev. Edmund Vasvary, research historian and an authority on Hungarian immigration to the United States, died Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 89 years old.

title: Economical Fare: Elegant, Tasty
description: Shepherd's Pie

title: A WellKept Secret: Federal Theft Insurance
description: THE BURGLARS who ripped off Judy and Richard Forrest's apartment a couple of years ago were professional and highly selective. They bypassed the silver and other bulky items in favor of such easily concealed valuables as the jewelry, a collection of gold coins, and a small portable TV set that was probably spirited out to the street in the folds of a trench coat that Richard Forrest had bought only a few days before.

title: HOWARD C. SWEET
description: Howard C. Sweet, a member of the Rhode Island House of Representatives from 1963 to 1969, died yesterday at Westerly Hospital, Westerly, R.I. A former resident of New Rochelle, N.Y., he had lived in Westerly since 1962. He was 78 years old.

title: Drs. Susan Forster and Richard Gusberg Wed
description: Dr. Susan Hall Forster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hall Forster of New York and Mason's Island in Mystic, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Richard Jefferson Gusberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. Saul B. Gusberg of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

title: Today's Blank Art Explores the Space Behind the Obvious
description: The Ramones blast out rock song after rock song, each offering no more than two or three chords and the same short phrase repeated over and over, all at a constant dynamic level. Michael Snow makes experimental films in which a single image fills the screen for 10, 20 or 30 minutes, changing glacially. Robert Wilson paints the stage with tableaux vivants as moribund as Snow's. La Monte Young composes music that consists of a 60cycle hum prolonged eternally. Trisha Brown offers accumulation dances that consist of short, simple gestures strung together in a chain. The Whitney Museum's annual retrospectives of new painting and sculpture are full of rudimentary artifacts that cause conservative critics to wax indignant, and all our major museums are hung with canvases by minimalists like Barnett Newman, Jules Olitski and Kenneth Noland that doubters dismiss as nonart. K. C. and the Sunshine Band, the disco group, make hit records with a repetitive rhythmic backdrop punctuated by catchphrases and a periodic uhhuh, and Richard Hell writes an underground rock anthem about the blank generation.

title: Born to Be a Chief Exec
description: VANCOUVER, British ColumbiaCanadian board meetings are by tradition stuffy. Directors adhere strictly to Robert's Rules of Order and Anglican decorum prevails, perhaps reflecting the country's ties to Britain.

title: The Gristede's Link in Southland's Chain
description: DALLASWhile the Southland Corporation has spread its 7Eleven convenience stores through the United States and into several foreign countries, there is one place in this country where the stores' logo is unfamiliar. New York City.

title: LEGAL AID LAWYERS IN COURT SLOWDOWN
description: A slowdown yesterday by Legal Aid Society lawyers doubled and tripled the time taken to arraign defendants accused of looting and vandalism in New York City's blackout last week, further slowing an alreadyclogged processing operation.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: LONDON I love the way the British ask and answer questions. Directeven bluntin the asking. Briefor should I say terse?in the answering. This extends even to the questions and answers that appear on the factsheets provided by publicists when some new event is at hand or some new building to be opened. The new British National Theater is now completely opened, with all three of its theaters functioning regularly, and of course a brochure was put in my hand to explain the choice of its site along the curving Thames (the view is magnificent, and that is my word, not the publicist's), to inform us just who the designer was (Denys Lasdun, and inspired), and to explain how the complex operation was and is financed. Normally I do what you probably do with such brochures: throw them away, preferring to see for myself what is there to be seen. In this case, I stayed my hand, having caught sight of a particular question:

title: INTERVIEW
description: IT ISN'T often th.t a 24yearold minor government functionary gets a chance to say no to a President of the United States. But that is what happened seven years ago, when Richard Blumenthal, then the White House choice for director of the Volunteers in Service to America (VISTA) rejected the appointment because of sharp disagreetnent with President Richard M.Nixon's Indochina and domestic policies.

title: Congress May Raise the Shelf Five Years
description: WASHINGTONHank Aaron, baseball's alltime homerun king, retired last October at 42, a relatively ancient age for a professional athlete. But John Wayne is still a movie tough guy at 70. GeorgeMeany, who will be 83 next month,. continues to rule the American labor movement with an iron hand. And Artur Rubinstein gave a television piano concert on his 90th birthday.

title: Garlits Is Old Man of Drag Racing
description: Certain drivers are immediately associated with certain races or areas of racing. Mention the Indy 500 and the first name that conies to mind is A. J. Foyt. Talk about Grand Prix racing and names like the late Jimmy Clark, Jackie Stewart, or recently Mario States, are associated. Motor Mention drag racing and Sports one of the first names to come to mind has to be Don (Big Daddy) Garlits, who is easing into a role as the sports grand old man.

title: More Than a Bolus of Idiosyncrasies
description: AMERICAN writing needs a resourceful critic. The American poet's characteristic act has been to invent a new kind of poem, as absolute as the bicycle, and then devise a Collected Works as an openended set of examples that may as well have an expansible title. Thus Leaves of Grass is all the poems Whitman wrote; The Cantos is all Pound's work after 1920; Stevens thought of calling his life's collection The Whole of Harmonium. Books that challenge our whole notion of what writing may be demand acts of critical collaboration.

title: The Places to Apply For an S.B.A. Loan
description: Applications tot emergency loans to owners of small businesses will be accepted by the Federal Small Business Administration today at 201 Varick Street in Manhattan.

title: Design
description: HENRY SMITHMILLER AND MICHAEL RUBIN are two architects in the vanguard of the trend to anonymous storefronts. With their design for Tidy's, a beauty salon on Park Avenue, they renovated what had been a liquor store into a supermodern salon. From the street, the bronzetinted window looks into the reception area, toward a glass block wall that screens off the activity in the salon behind it (see bottom photo). The only identification is the name neatly lettered onto the window. The owner, Maurice Tidy, wanted the front to be very discreet and not be an imposition on the avenue. He didn't want to incur the wrath of the Park Avenue Association, says 33yearold Michael Rubin, who worked for architect Louis Kahn before joining Carson, Lundin and Thorson as an associate three years ago. There really is no storefront as such, says his partner, 35yearold Henry SmithMiller. The exFulbright scholar, who spent three years in Italy as a sculptor, now is an associate with Richard Meier Associates. The facade is actually the glass block wall which is backlit and changes color and pattern according to the movement and activity in the salon behind it, he adds.

title: Medicaid Kickbacks Found Widespread By a Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 16There is Significant and convincing evidence that kickbacks are widespread in the Medicaid program, the Senate Committee on Aging said in a report made public today.

title: Dengue Fever Outbreak Reported In Jamaica; 2 U.S. Cases Suspect
description: ATLANTA, July 16 (AP)An outbreak of dengue fever, a fluelike ailment, has been reported in Jamaica for the first time in two generations, the national Center for Disease Control said yesterday. The center said it also was investigating two possible cases in the United States.

title: Gaters, Loves Defeated By Apples In One Night
description: The New York Apples, thanks to last Wednesday's blackout, became the first team in World Team Tennis history to win two matches in a single night. They did it last night by finishing off Golden Gate, 2918, in the match suspended by the citywide power failure and by trouncing the Indiana Loves, 2414, in the regularly scheduled match before 3,170 at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum

title: Art
description: Galleries Uptown

title: TEXAS IN THE LEAD IN U.S. BRIDGE PLAY
description: CHICAGO, July 16Contract bridge teams representing Washington, D.C., and Texas clashed in the final of the Grand National team championship here today. The winner of the event, which began eight months ago with an entry of some 7,000 teams, will qualify to represent the United States in the world openteam championship next summer in New Orleans.

title: Girls Playing Headsup Ball
description: THE fielder stood, hand on hip, one knee bent, coolly surveying the situation. Suddenly, the batter, who had swung at two pitches, hit a fly deep into left. The fielder ran back a few feet, held out both arms, stumbledand came up with the ball. The crowd in the bleachers went wild.

title: Fashion
description: One comes from New Zealand one from Cuba and one from New Jersey. All three are designers who, right now, are generating their own brand of fashion excitement in New York. Gordon Clarke makes glamorous yet practical evening dresses. Marta Salvadori makes gauzy cotton clothes sophisticated. Ted Muehling is an alchemist of a jewelry designer, treating base metals as if they were pure gold.

title: Investigations Begun Into Horse Racing
description: ACOUPLE of investigations into New Jersey horse racing, one of them somewhat mysterious, are under way. And, according to State Senator Alene S. Ammond, Democrat of Cherry Hill, who has been demanding a cleanup of racing in the state for almost 18 months, it is about time.

title: Cosmos Hope to Rebound at Home
description: The Cosmos or the Portland Timbers will win a North American Soccer League game at Giants Stadium tonight, and the Cosmos are getting hungry for a victory.

title: New York on $5 A Datefor The Fun of It
description: OH YES, we know money can't buy happiness, but on Friday or Saturday night in New York, it sure can help. Send most any couple out on the town with enough cashbuy them tickets for the Met, or an evening of dancing at the Rainbow Room, or dinner at Lutceand unless he rips her Halston, unless she throws the tarte  l'orange in his face, they are apt to have a fairly good time.

title: Ironically, the Human Rights Drive May Be Too Successful
description: PARISAmong the authors of the 1975 Helsinki declaration, the Western Europeans, not the Americans, were the main proponents of human rights provisions. The pledges, they hoped, would extend their contacts eastward, ease the reunion of friends and families and quicken the pace of liberalization in their Eastern neighbors. Yet today, some Western European officials are voicing concern that the United States is pursuing the human rights issue too zealously, blowing the dispute out of proportion and undermining detente.

title: Music
description: Opera

title: Nicklaus, While Reluctant To Play, Draws Crowds
description: SUTTON, Mass., July 16  Jack Nicklaus, almost alone, has been responsible for the huge galleries at the Pleasant Valley Classic golf tournament. The crowds are the largest since Arnold Palmer last played here in 1968. Yesterday's turnout was announced at 29,500 and today's was well over 30.000.

title: Slew's Owners Buy Colt For Twice His Price
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 16 (AP)The people who gambled $17,500 and came up with Seattle Slew, this year's Triple Crown champion, put up twice that much today for a colt at the FasigTipton Kentuckian Selected Yearling Sale. Mickey Taylor and Dr. Jim Hill, dealing Wooden Horse Investments, who bought Seattle Slew at this sale in 1975, purchased a son of Cornish Prince out of Rough Mood who was consigned by Spendthrift Farm, with Lee Eaton acting as agent.

title: The Good Life Has Found a Limit
description: When the lights go out as they did in New York last week, people suddenly realize how dependent they are on electricity for the amenities and necessities of modern life. And they must wonder if the blackout, temporary though it was, does not represent yet another warning of the potentially dire consequences when it seems that, as Emerson once wrote, Things are in the saddle and ride mankind.

title: Yachting
description: AT PORT WASHINGTON, L. I.

title: HONOR STILL MOTIVE FOR CRIME IN GREECE
description: ATHENS, July 12After Pagona Argyriou and Nicos Iliopowlos became engaged, they started sharing the same bed. When young Nicos, a bus driver here, broke off the engagement before the wedding, Pagona's mother marched into his apartment and stabbed him to death.

title: Menotti's Adventures In the Dance World
description: If one were asked to name an important international summer festival in which dance has continually played a pivotal role, the answer might well be the Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds, founded 20 years ago by Gian Carlo Menotti. Indeed, this year the festival not only celebrated its 20th anniversary in the ancient hill town of Spoleto, Italy (where it closed its threeweek run last Sunday), but it also successfully launched the first Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S. C., making a reality of Menotti's longcherished dream of one day uniting his Two Worlds not merely in spirit but geographically.

title: LaSelva Will Bring Free Opera to New York No Matter What
description: T here's always more than one way to do anything, said Vincent LaSelva, coaching his lissome but slightly confused Violetta in the party scene of Verdi's Traviata, which was the first of four summer productions his New York Grand Opera Company is currently offering in the parks (this Thursday the opera in Central Park will be La Boh&me). Mr. LaSelva was showing the soprano how to use her fan in the fashion of a great courtesan, who, having exhausted mere infatuation, how needs to find a great love to sustain her against pain, despair and her fourthact death. Using the skills he has acquired without perhaps even wanting to, he acted, mimed, dashed madly, sang, conducted the pianist, supplied the chorus part and vocalized, when necessary, the orchestral diggadigga do's.

title: LETTERS
description: Trippe's Pan Am

title: Lelee Brandt to Wed Aug. 27
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Brandt of Southern Pines and Blowing Rock, N. C., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Brandt's daughter. Lelee Schenck Brandt, to Bennett Emil Smullyan, son of Clinton Ives Smullyan and Barbara Mosbacher Smullyan, both of New York.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The time has come when, from even the best of all possible jobs, it's necessary to take off, to cut out, to go away, to hide. It's not only because that after a certain amount of time spent in other people's dreams, always as a stranger, you can become as disconnected from reality as someone who's been deprived of sleep. That's obvious. But each year there are other, more subtle, more specific pressures from which one needs a respite. There is also equipment that requires repair. After a certain number of weeks engaged in looking ahead in glancing back, one has to reestablish a present tense, to reaffirm the value of the now, even though the now can't last. The following are the 10 best reasons I can think of for my going on vacation at this very minute:

title: Winston Hill Traded
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 16 (AP)The New York Jets have traded Winston Hill, their 14year veteran offensive tackle, to the Miami Dolphins for conditional future considerations, the National Football League team announced today.

title: Mary Carillo Bows To Miss Tomanova
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, July 16 (Reuters)Renata Tomanova of Czechoslovakia, a strong favorite, beat Mary Carillo of New York, 63, 61, in the semifinals of the $75,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

title: Ideas. &Trends
description: Still more tests have confirmed what scientific studies have been demonstrating for 20 years. Laetrile is bunk as a cancer cure. Nevertheless, demands continue to legalize the substance, or at the least, to test further in hopes of settling the issue. But the effort seems futile. As Dr. Vincent DeVita of the National Cancer Institute said recently: There's no way that a negative answer will turn this off because it is not based on reason. The push behind laetrile is not scientific. It is financial and political

title: Atlantic City: It's Heading Down Road To Revival
description: THE talk in Atlantic City is of a Caesars Palace rising out of the memory of Traymore Hotel; of another MGM Grand Hotel, Las Vegasstyle, and gambling at the Resorts International Hotel the way it's done on Paradise Island in the Bahamas. And it is the talk of dreams, of a glittering resurgent boardwalk, of an Atlantic City once again a resort spectacular of sand, sea and sun by day and of sophisticated cafe society at night.

title: DINING OUT
description: TRATTORIA RENATO is one of those little tuckedaway places that a reviewer might never hear cf were it not for enthusiastic readers. A longtime fan of Renato's praised highly, and so it seemed worth investigating. In fact, the restaurant has a lot going for it. It is smallthe capacity is only about 30 people. The service is friendly and enthusiastic. And the cook, a vivacious woman who obviously enjoys her own handiwork, cares enough to come to the table and discuss the meal.

title: Smoke Alarms Detect Fires In Their Earliest Stages
description: Fire officials estimate that out of the thousands of people who are killed in residential fires each year, anywhere from 50 to 80 percent could have been saved if every home in which fire broke out (there are over 2.5 million residential fires each year) had been equipped with an early warning smoke and fire detection device.

title: Wife Unaware of Husband's Life as Double Agent
description: WASHINGTON July 16 (UPI)Nicholas and Blanka Shadrin had an unusual marriage.

title: THE REV. EDMUND V ASVARY, HISTORIAN AND AUTHOR
description: The Rev. Edmund Vasvary, research historian and an authority on Hungarian immigration to the United States, died Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 89 years old.

title: Is RateStructure Reform the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 Colts and Filly Qualify In Swift GoldRush Trials
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 17Five twominute miles were paced today at Monticello Raceway, three in the elimination trials for 'ext Sunday' $300,000 Gold Rush final. Phil Tully did doubletakes at the Visuamatic timer panel on the infield board.

title: Bethpage Triumphs at Polo
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., July 17  Harvey Rhein scored four goals and led the Bethpage polo team to a 95 victory over Brookville today at Bethpage State Park.

title: For a U.S. Role in Somalia
description: All around Brava, except to the east, the red sands swirl. Sparse scrub bush and the thorny acacia tree somehow survive in the parched earth. This is the land Ahmed Mohamed knew for forty years as he herded camels and goats across the semidesert of Somaliland in an endless quest for water.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Practial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Dispute Over New British College Reflects Nation's Ideologic al Split
description: BUCKINGHAM, EnglandThe University College at Buckingham, Britain's newest and most controversial experiment in higher education, is awaiting the arrival of 11 exchange students from Bucknell University. The small number would go unnoticed in most British universities. Here, however, every bit of recognition counts.

title: Argentine Lawyers Finding Peril in Leftist Causes
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 17One evening in May, armed men identifying themselves as members of the Argentine security forces removed Jorge Rebori, a lawyer, and his wife, Celia, from their apartment at gunpoint.

title: Courageous Repeats 2 Trial Victories
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 17Nis baseball team, the Atlanta Braves, may be going nowhere this summer but Ted Turner is flying and he has the yacht Courageous flying, too, at the America's Cup trials.

title: VietnamLaos Pact Marks Special Relationship
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 17 (UPIVietnam and Laos signed a pact today at the end of a three.day visit by Vietnamese leaders that revived a special relationship between the two countries, official reports said.

title: Panel Says Lockheed Billed Navy For Twice the Steel It Needed
description: WASHINGTON, July. 17 (AP)The Federal agency responsible for overseeing defense contracts says that Lockheed Shipbuilding and Construction Company billed the Navy for 117.4 million more pounds of steel Than it needed to fulfill a contract, more than twice as much as it used.

title: Americans Excel in Maccabiah Games
description: TEL AVIV, July 17 (AP)Americans took the first medals in track and field competition and continued to collect victories in swimming today at the Maccabiah Games for Jewish athletes.

title: Mount Etna Is Starting to Erupt; No Danger to Inhabited Areas Seen
description: CATANIA, Sicily, July 17 (UPI)The Mount Etna volcano began erupting with clouds of dense, acrid smoke and thick lava flows today in what scientists said was its most violent activity in 18 months.

title: G.O.P. Benefits as Small Papers Publish Press Releases as News
description: WASHINGTON. Jul 17House Republican campaigners have found a new weapon to use against Democratic incumbentsthe willingness of many small newspapers to print thinly described political propaganda as news.

title: Phils, Carlton Put Heat on Cubs and Win, 42
description: For the second day in a row the temperature on the Astroturf field at Veterans Stadium, in Philadelphia was more than 120 degrees. About the only player not complaining about the heat, as the Phillies defeated the Cubs yesterday, 42, was Steve Carlton, the Philadelphia pitcher.

title: Retirement a Harsh Reward for Many Americans
description: WASHINGTON. July I7What we have, says Max Serchuck, is more than 800 million years of experience walking around. Surely, 800 million years of experience can still make a contribution to American life.

title: Davis Wins Fourth Straight Bout By a Knockout in Eighth Round
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 17 (UPI)Howard Davis, the Olympic lightweight boxing gold medalist, punished Dom Monaco for nearly eight rounds today before stopping him for his fourth straight professional victory.

title: Commodities: Big Corn Crop's Impact
description: CHICAGO, July 17Less than a week after the Agriculture Department issued its prediction of the biggest corn crop in history6.3 billion bushels, 2 percent bigger than last year's record harvestexpert. observers are casting skeptical eyes on the dimension of that forecast.

title: FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN U.S. IS STILL HIGH
description: Foreign industrial investment in the United States is continuing at the high levels of a year ago, but with a trend now to more joint ventures, or partnerships with domestic companies, according to a conference Board survey.

title: Residents Selling Homes Complain About Some RealEstate Brokers
description: PATERSON, July. 17Many homeowners in North Jersey who are selling their houses are complaining about unethical practices by realestate companies linked with multiplelisting services.

title: Curbs Worry East German Writer
description: EAST BERLIN, July 15It is not as if Jurek Becker had not known trouble before. When he was 3 years old, the Nazis seized his parents and him and confined the family to the Jewish ghetto of Lodz.

title: Inmont Sues Esmark on Bid
description: The Inmont Corporationwhich only a week ago dropped its fight against a takeover by Esmark Inc. long enough to discuss the chances of a friendly merger between the two companiessaid over the weekend that the talks had so far failed to produce agreement and that Inmont had sued Esmark in on the dam, has been blacklisted by Manhattan Federal Court.

title: HOSPITAL PROPOSAL STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: A state application by the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn to convert a new $11 million nursing home into an acutecare hospital wing has created a controversy within Governor Carey's Administration.

title: Alaskan Oil Is Expected To Flow Again This Week.
description: ANCHORAGE, July 17 (AP)Investigators for the Department of the Interior say they know of no major problems that would prevent them from approving resumption of oil movement through the PransAlaska Pipeline.

title: Gail Ross Is Bride of Robert Schwartz Jr.
description: The marriage of Gail Sharon Ross to Robert Jay Schwartz Jr. took place yesterday in Clifton, N.J., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Ross, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is the son of Beatrice S. Schwartz of Great Neck, LI., and Dr. Schwartz of New York and East Hampton, ??. Rabbi Natharr Fish performed the ceremony.

title: HOUSE PANEL TO RESTUDY GAS PRICE DEREGULATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)The House Select Energy Committee will take another look at the controversy over deregulation of natural gas prices and may add a 3to4cent gasoline tax to President Carter's energy package, Representative Thomas L. Ashley said today.

title: Want to See Tut? Take a Number
description: CHICAGOWaiting for Tut isn't so bad after all. In fact, it's like waiting in line at a bakery or waiting to board a flight at the airport.

title: NoTitle
description: FRESH AIR FUND. PLEASE GIVE.

title: A Church Synod Assails Violence And Sex on TV
description: The General Synod of the United Church of Christ has directed the church's office of communications to act to eliminate the misuse of violence and sexual imagery in television programming.

title: ExPresidential Yacht Becomes Tourist Attraction
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 17Thomas Aquinas Malloy sat shirtless on the deck of his new boat this muggy afternoon, enjoying the sun and shouting, Hiya, brother, to the curious occupants of lesser craft, passing tugboats and visitors who stepped aboard.

title: Royals Top Yanks And Sweep Series
description: KANSAS CITY, July. 17If nothing else can be said for the AllStar Game break, the Yankees can at least look forward to living three days of their lives without suffering a loss or encountering a fight.

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: Two men were stabbed to death in the hallway of 1842 Seventh Avenue at 146th Street in Manhattan, reportedly b,Gilford Best, 23 years old. of 2121 Eighth Avenue, whose sister allegedly was stabbed a month ago by one of themJames Hutchins, 27, of 2124 Eighth Avenue. The other victim was Joseph Doughty, 24, of 20 Clarke Place, the Bronx . . . A 38yearold man, tentatively identified as Ernest Zimmerman of 425 West End Avenue, was found dead, either from a stab or a bullet wound, with his hands tied behind his back and his pockets turned inside out in the schoolyard of Public School 125 at 425 West 123d Street in Morningside Heights. His clothing also had been set afire . . . Charles Harris, 57, of 208 Hopkinson Avenue, Brooklyn, was sent to Kings County Hospital for psychiatric observation after he was arrested for fatally stabbing a man and slightly cutting another in front of Nathan's Famous restaurant at 438 Utica Avenue in the Crown Heights section, where he was a former security guard. The dead man was Emanuel Joseph, 36, of 741 Cleve land Street.

title: 3 Die Battling Forest Fire in Utah As Blazes Scorch the Arid West
description: A winddriven, 20foot wall of flame shot over burnedout sagebrust and killed three .men fighting a major Maze In Utah's Ashley National Forest, officials reported yesterday.

title: China Says Economy is on Rise in Turmoil's Wake
description: HONG KONG, July 15China's economy has begun to recover from serious dislocations caused by last year's political turmoil. Industrial production in the first six months of 1977 showed an increase over the same period of 1976, according to figures relesed recently by the Chinese press agency, Hsinhua.

title: END CURRENCY CONTROLS, FRIEDMAN TELLS ISRAEL
description: MONTPELIER. Vt.,July 17 (AP)Nobel Prizewinning economist Milton Friedman has recommended to the Likud party that Israel halt currency controls and let a free market determine monetary exchange rates.

title: BEAME ASKS LABOR, BUSINESS AND BANKS FOR BLACKOUT HELP
description: Mayor Beanie asked labor, business and banking leaders yesterday to join the city in a multimilliondollar rescue fund to provide immediate cash grants to small businesses that were devastated by looting, vandalism and arson in the blackout that hit New York City and Westchester County last week.

title: Gathering Is Smaller and Older for Captive Nations Week Rally
description: A march up Fifth Avenue and a colorful rally in Central Park by 250 demonstrators, mainly middleaged and elderly Americans of Eastern European descent, marked the opening yesterday of Captive Nations Week.

title: Panthers Working Within System in Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 17Huey P. Newton, cofounder and chairman of the Black Panther Party, sits in an Oakland jail today waiting for a hearing Tuesday that could eliminate his $100,000 bail requirement for murder and assault charges and get him released on his own recognizance.

title: CRASH KILLS DESIGNER OF AIR ESCAPE SYSTEM
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 17 (AP) A man who designed aircraft escape systems that were credited with saving the lives of many United States pilots in Vietnam died in the crash of a private plane yesterday.

title: No Title Article
description: Robin G. Ross Married To Lawrence W. Shaw

title: L.I. Agency Cuts Medicaid Fraud With Innovative Use of Computer
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 17A local concern that specializes in taking indigent and infirm patients to clinics and hospitals was doing a good businesstoo goodSuffolk County's Medicaid computer found out last year.

title: Police Win Understanding With Program That Takes Concerned Citizens on Patrol
description: A police department, the president of a Brooklyn car dealership has discovered, is not run as a business.

title: Threat of Brown Lung Prompts Women To Fight the Cotton Dust of Textile Mills
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.Sharon Langston stood in the sun outside a turnofthe century red brick cotton mill. kicking at the fire ants in the sand.

title: Konstantin A . Fedin, Soviet Author, Head Of Writers Union
description: MOSCOW, July 17 (AP)Konstantin A. Fedin, a leading Soviet writer who headed the board of the Union of Writers, has died at the age of 85, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Mr. Begin Comes to Washington
description: No encounter at Jimmy Carter's White House has attracted more attention than the meeting this week between the President and Israel's new Prime Minister, Menahem Begin. Watching their vigorous transoceanic sparring in recent weeks, some commentators and officials have been led to predict a tense confrontation, perhaps even worse.

title: Tennis
description: FinalDean Colson, Miami, defeated Asher Kahn, New Rochelle, N.Y.. 64, 63.

title: Day for Shade and Watching Polar Bears
description: It was a day for waterborne polar bears and young carrousel riders as temperatures rose here yesterday to a scorchingthough not a record breaking97 degrees. The record was 100 degrees set in 1953. The beaches were crowded and the city's waterfront parks and grass strips were jammed with sunbathers, tennis players and a diehard jogger or two.

title: MINIMAL JITTERS MET RISE IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: Moneysupply watchers, an edgy group of late, ordinarily might have been expected to push all sorts of panic buttons last Thursday when the Federal Reserve reported a $3.2 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply for the latest week and a striking $5.6 billion jump in the more broadly defined money supply.

title: Questioning Assumptions About Drug Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Ln Puerta del. Vino; Fetes, Debussy; Concerto, Vivaldi; Sonatina for Plano and Violin, Schubert; Overture to Peleus and Thetis, Boyce.

title: Amateur Radio Operators Help Coast Guard Rescue 11 Fishermen
description: MIAMI, July. 17 (UPI)The Coast Guard, aided by amateur radio operators in the United States, directed today the rescue of 11 men from a 92foot fishing vessel sinking in the Caribbean Sea about 220 miles south of Jamaica.

title: Cut in AllNight Radio Talk Show Has Insomniacs Muttering in the Dark
description: SALT LAKE CITYAll across middle America, insomniacs will go to bed angry again tonight.

title: Albany Pace: Slow Motion
description: ALBANY, July 17The Legislature's bicentennial session, which finally straggled to a close Friday, provided a mirror for the mood of an electorate troubled by crime and a lagging economy, marked ly less concerned than in past years about the environment, and finally accepting such social changes as the widespread use of marijuana and the mass entry of women into the labor force.
