title: Events Today
description: LE GRANDE BOURGEOISE, In Italian with English subtitles, directed by Mauro Bologninl, Earring Catherine Deneuve and Giancarlo Glanninly at the Beckman Theater.

title: 1,039Pound Mako Shark Breaks Scale at Montauk
description: MONTAUK, L.I., July. 17A scalebreaking mako shark was weighed at the Montauk Marine Basin today, The 1,039pound mako, 21 pounds short of the International Game Fishing Association record, was hooked by Jimmy George of Paterson, N.J., fishing aboard Craps Two Sixes out of West Lake Marina.

title: Red Smith
description: New York and her nine million were in darkness. Looters ravaged the lifeless city, hauling away vanloads of furniture, television sets, refrigerators, smashing showroom windows to drive off in new automobiles. Surgeons performed operations outdoors in the glare of Fire Department Spotlights. As the police casualty list climbed toward 100, prisoners sat manacled on the floors of precinct stations because the jails were already overflowing. Plunder, fire and vandalism together with indirect losses to the industrial, commercial and financial communities added up to 81 billion. There was pressure on Mayor Beame to declare martial law and call in the National Guard. In Boston the next day, The HeraldAmerican put it all in perspective. The banner headline across the top of page one read: Massive power failure hits New York and disrupts TV. Losses of a billionschmillion. No Kojak. No Mary Hartman.

title: Albany Pace: Slow Motion
description: ALBANY, July. 17The Legislature's bicentennial session, which finally straggled to a close Friday, provided a mirror for the mood of an electorate troubled by crime and a lagging economy, markedly less concerned than in past years about the environment, and finally accept ing, such social changes as the widespread use of marijuana and the mass entry of women ints the labor force.

title: PALESTINIAN GROUPS IN LEBANESE BATTLE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17  Rival Palestinian guerrilla factions battled with heavy weapons today at the main refugee camp on the southern outskirts of Beirut.

title: Bridge
description: CHICAGO, July 17The final of the Grand National team championship here last night could not possibly have been closer. A Texas quintet won by I international match point after 64 deals. ending a contest that beean eight

title: ELLEN STRAUS NOW HEADS STRAUS COMMUNICATIONS
description: Ellen Sulzberger Straus today becomes president of Straus Communications, which operates radio station WMCA. Mrs. Straus replaces her husband, R. Peter Straus, who has been named by President Carter to be director of the Voice of America.

title: Ongais and Marcis Win Twin 200 Races
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 17 (AP)Danny Ongais sped away from the field on the final lap and won the Indianapoliscar part of the Norton Twin 200's today.

title: Cauthen Wins Stakes on His Delaware Day
description: STANTON, Del., July 17 (AP)Steve Cauthen,'the nation' leading rider, drove True Colors to an easy victory in the $30,250 Leonard Richards Stakes today at Delaware Park, where it was Steve Cauthen Day.

title: COMPROMISE NEARS ON WHEAT SUBSIDIES FOR NEW FARM BILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The nexttolast round in the adoption of a new farm, bill will begin this week in the House, of Representatives, with a new compro, mise on the levels of wheat subsidies ex. pected.

title: L.I.R.R.Is Planning Rebates for Blackout
description: The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that rebates would be given to holders of weekly and monthly commutation tickets who were unable to use the trains during last week's Con Edison power blackout.

title: Begin Plans to Reveal Peace Ideas Soon
description: Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel ?old visitors in New York yesterday. according to a prominent American rabbi. that he planned to make public the substance of his Middle East peace plan at a news conference immediately after preseating it privately to President Carter this week, if the President agreed.

title: Books of The Times
description: CLOSE QUARTERS. By Larry Heinemann. 336 pages. Farrar, S??aus & Giroux. $10.

title: No Title  Article
description: ABRAHAM J. GUREVICH

title: Stone Defeats Dietz in Rowing Trial
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 17 (AP)Greg Stone of Harvard upset the favorite in the finals of the world rowing trials on Lake Carnegie today. Stone defeated Jim Dietz of the New York A.C., who said he was suffering from a virus. It was the first time in eight years that Dietz was beaten for international competition in the United States.

title: City Fanfare Is Mixed for AllStar Game
description: What AllStar Game? exclaimed a Times Square policeman and his partner as they refueled their cruiser. When is it? We've been too busy with the blackout to think about baseball.

title: Henderson Cracks Grand Slam as Mets Turn Back Pirates, 93, After 31 Loss
description: The Mets split a doubleheader with the Pittsburgh Pirates in the steambath that was Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon, and the New Yorkers' secondgame victory was another chapter in what the team calls The Steve Henderson Show.

title: Poll Shows New Jerseyans Rate Public Schools Only Fairly Good How New Jerseyans View Their Schools; (Asked of 1,005 adult residents)
description: NEW BRUNSWICK July 17Althougn suburban schools generally have a reputation for excellence and New Jersey among the country's most suburban states, its residents rate their schools only fairly good, according to the latest in a series of polls on New jersey Images by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: Korchnoi Wins and Takes 51 Lead In Chess Match With Polugayevsky
description: EVIAN, France, July 17 (Reuters)Viktor Korchnoi. a Soviet defector, took a 51 lead over Lev Polugayevsky of the Soviet Union today, winning the sixth game of their world chess championship semifinal challengers match here after 60 moves.

title: Iran Announces Suit Against French Firm

title: Don't Discount Unemployment

title: After the Blackout, justice Goes by the Book
description: Even in the best of times, New York City's criminaljustice system does not operate smoothly. In the worst of times, it verges on collapse. Since the mass arrests for lcoling and arson stemming from last week's blackout, the criminaljustice system has sputtered, stalled and even stopped, although the partners in the systemthe police, prosecutors, defense lawyers, judges and prison officials  may have been doing just what is expected of them.

title: DATA ON SOVIET NAVY IS DISPUTED BY ASPIN

title: A Trial by Heat in New York Jails

There was no fan, and their bodies elistened with sweat. The cell was littered with empty coffee containers, each of which was labeled: It is Our Pleasure to Serve You. Two rats suddenly darted out of a corner, leaped over a cup, then slipped back into a hole in the wall.

William Lockwood, director of programing at Lincoln Center and hence responsible for the festival, acknowledged that he was crossing his fingers and knocking on wood, but he didn't sound the least bit worried. title: Car Kills Husband; Wife Held

They said that the couple had argued over Mr. Webb's disciplining of one of their children. When he blocked Mrs. Webb's way as she got in her car to leave and said, You're not going anywhere, she allegedly ran over him, the police said. She had gone to pick up their three children who had stayed with their father over the weekend.

description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 19The head stay let go aboard Courageous today in the middle of her race against Enterprise, forcing Courageous to quit immediately before her mast came down during the America's Cup Observation Trials.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: One may love or hate airconditioning but the fact remains that it's with curse or blessing. So what's the solution when outside it's hct and muggy and one can't think of anything but a sleeveless dress, and inside it's cool enough to shiver? The shawl is one answer and the good old jacket is another. The jacket of the moment is not, however, old. It's inspired by (you know what that means) Yves Saint Laurent. and it's braidtrimmed, even at the shoulder seams, shortish and made of quilted cotton, silk or a mixture of yarns. The price is Fa98, which may sound, zici indeed is, a lot of money except when one thinks of what the originals cost. Lillie Rubin.at 22 West 57th Street has them, and if you plan ahead, look at the gold and silver quilted brocade version, which cost about $50 more hi't could be a longterm standby in any wardrobe.

title: Books: Settling a New Continent
description: When historical events are analyzed in terms of the productive forces and relations that precipitated them, much becomes clear that is otherwise shrouded in mystery. This is the point of view adopted by Prof. David B. Quinn of the University of Liverpool, in describing the European exploration, settlement and ultimate penetration of North America and in depicting the native American (or Indian) response to this incursion.

title: A Fountain Complex Is Donated to Grace City Hall Park
description: A $200,000 granite and limestone fountain complex, a gift to the city from George T. Delacorte, the publisher, to emphasize the simplicity, elegance and the historic nature of the site, will be constructed at the southern tin of City Hall Park.

title: Appeals Court Upsets. Conviction In Port Chester Fire Fatal to 24
description: An appellate court fit Brooklyn yesterday reversed the conviction of a 25yearold Connecticut man who had been charged with felony murder for setting fire that killed 24 persons in a singles bar on the New YorkConnecticut line in 1974.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. July 20 (AP)The Carter Administration and Palestinian guerrilla leaders are involved in secret highlevel contacts, the Beirut newspaper Al Anwar reported today.

title: CANADA'S LOWER HOUSE BACKS GUN CONTROL LAW
description: OTTAWA, July 19After several years of sometimes heated debate, the House of Commons approved a gun control law last night that will require purchasers of firearms to obtain a form of permit for the weapons.

title: The Picnic: For Romantics And Revelers; Steak Tartar; Steamed Mumsls; Mussel and. Potato Mayonnaise; Shrimp with Dill and Cognac Sauce; Boiled Shrimp; Eggs in Tapennae; Escabeche of Chicken San Juan.; Seviche; Mock Head Cheese; Thought should be given to incidentals.; Rillettes de Parc
description: AND we meet with champagne and a chicken, at last. Those words were written by Lady Mary Wortley Montagu in England in 1749. Now, I have never read the works Lady Mary Wortley Montagu. But I like that line and I have my own visions of the lady and her ;over sitting in some antfree, leafy, sundappled glade, munching on that cold roast bird between sips of bottle of wellchilled brut.

title: The Coop City Deal
description: After more than two years of muddled conflict over rents, the tenant leaders of Coop City in the Bronx and New York State housing officials have reached a tentative settlement. Its main virtue is that no one likes it.

title: Yugoslav Jumper Triumphs
description: CELJE, Yugoslavia, July 19 (AP)Nenad Stekic of Yugoslavia defeated United States Olympic gold medalist, Arnie Robinson, in the long jump event today at an international track and field meet. Stekic's winning distance was 26 feet 6 inches. Robinson was second with a leap of 2511 and Hans Baumgartner of West Germany was third at 246.

title: A. H. Raskin
description: WASHINGTONThe fever charts that tell the country whether its two most persistent economic maladies, inflation and unemployment. are getting better or worse are themselves about to undergo . extensive surgery. Both the Consumer Price Index and the monthly report on how many Americans have jobs and how many do not changes in comprehensive ness and character. The end results of the overhaul will affect the lives of tens of millions of Americans only dimly aware of the importance these barometers of national economic health have acquired in the determination of White House and Congressional policy and in the distribution of billions of dollars in pliblic and private funds.

title: REO Speedwagon
description: REO SPEEDWAGON, a rock band that originated in Champagne, Ill., has been playing to large crowds in the Midwest for seven years. Like Z.Z. Top, which makes its living playing massive stadium shows in the Southwest and South, REO Speedwagon is the kind of group the rock press tends to overlook or ignore.

title: Topics
description: SACCO AND VANZEITI  The 50th anniversary of the execution of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti next month will be a somewhat less melancholy occasion thanks to Governor Dukakis of Massachusetts. For a half century the fate of the two Italianborn anarchists has nagged at the nation's conscience. Whether either or both of them were in fact guilty of robbing a payroll and of killing a paymaster and a security guard remains in dispute, hilt the character of their trial was indisputably unfair. In issuing a proclamation that acknowledges the prejudice that prevailed against the defendants, the Governor has helped to remove a stigma not only from the memories of Sacco and Vanzetti but also from the judicial system of his state.

title: Housewares Show: Some Early Winners
description: THERE were dozens of practical and fascinating objects among the thousands of kitchen gadgets, electrical appliances and cooking and table implements on dispiay last week at the trade show of the National Housewares Manufacturers Association in Chicago. description: ESSINGTON, Pa. July 19Leaders of the American Farm Bureau Federation from eight Eastern states met here today to map strategy for dealing with what the big farm organization called a real threat of unionization of farm workers.

description: Reported net income for many indepeddent oil and gas producers would be significantly reduced Sunder new accounting rules proposed yesterday.

title: Black Leaders Reject Plan
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 19 (Reuters)The two black leaders with whom Prime Minister Smith hopes to settle the future of Rhodesia without bowing to demands for a universal franchise today scorned his appeal for an election mandate. Bishop Abel Muzorewa and the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole said they would accept nothing less than one man, one vote.

description: WHITE PLAINS, July 19A joyous Joseph F. Leonard said today that he was gardening outside his home in Byram, Conn., when a neighbor brought word of today's court decision.

title: NewYorkers, etc.
description: IT IS THE season for house guests, those peripatetic freeloaders who come down on houses on the beach or in the country on summer weekends, and who sometimes leave their hosts and hostesses permanently scarred. is not easy to be a host or hostess, and often is not easy to be a house guest, either. The delicacy of the situation requires tact and restraint, and when the etiquette is breached on either side :it almost always means there will be a disaster. The consensus among hostesses is that the worst house guests they can have are husbands and wives who spend the weekend fighting with one another, while many house guests believe that the ultimate horror is to have a hostess who will schedule their weekend so rigidly that they have no time to sit by the pool. Other bad things can happen, too.

title: MICHAEL A. MORTON
description: Michael A. Morton, a textile executive, died Monday at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: No Impropriety by Senators Found By Inquiry Into Korean Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Senators Adlai E. Stevenson 3d and Harrison Schmitt, the chairman and vice chairman of the Senate ethics committee, reported to the panel today that a threemonth inquiry into Korean lobbying had as yet disclosed no impropriety by present or former senators.

title: Charles H. Blitman; Son of Poor Family Became a Developer
description: Charles H. Blitman, the son of a poor upstate farming family who rose to become one of New York City's most prominent building developers, died Monday at his home, 650 Park Avenue. He was 83 years old and had remained active until recently as chairman of the board for the Blitman Construction Corporation, which he founded in 1922.

They are Ani Kavafian, violinist: Heidi Lehwalder, harpist, and Ursula Oppens and Paul Schenley pianists.

title: British Steel Shows a Deficit
description: LONDON, July 19 (Reuters)The stateowned British Steel Corporation today announced a loss last year of the equivalent of $163 million and forecast another huge deficit for the current year. The corporation's chairman, Sir Charles Villiers, said the loss for this year could be comparable with the $438 million deficit recorded in 1975. He warned that would be much worse than this if there was a wage or price explosion.

title: Carter Is Reported Ready to Seek Gasoline Tax Rise of Up to 5 Cents
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  President Carter agreed today to seek an increase in Federal gasoline taxes of up to 5 cents to finance transportation or other Government programs, according to Administration officials.

title: AllStar Ovation for Tom Seaver
description: In the dazzle of the afternoon sun, the official temperature in Central Park was as high as 102 degrees. By evening, as the AllStar teams assembled at Yankee Stadium, it was still in the 90's. Yankee Steambath, it should have been called last night. But the weather merely reflected the warmth of the applause for Tom Seaver in his first appearance in New York since being traded by the Mets to the Cincinnati Reds nearly five weeks ago. Tom Seaver was among the National AllStars who trotted out to the thirdbase line after the starting team had been introduced. And when the words, Tom Seaver, pitcher, blared over the publicaddress system, the ovation began as Torn Seaver stepped forward and doffed his red cap. And the ovation continued . . . and now Tom Seaver turned toward the outfield and waved his red cap again, then waved his arms. Eventually the ovation stopped, after about a minute, and the introductions continued.

title: A Check From Dixie ... to Help Y All Out

title: 60 Minute Gourmet
description: AFEW weeks ago in this column a recipe for veal zurichoise or veal Zurichstyle appeared and, as prepared in my skillet at home, it was made to tally with veal. A short while later an acquaintance from Switzerland, a professional chef, passed through town and advised me that white the dish, made only with veal, was acceptableand is often prepared that way even in Swiss kitchensthe real, the true, the original veal zurichoise is made with three principal ingredients, namely veal, pork and fresh mushrooms. It is certainly a fine combination of flavors and textures and I would never dispute a Swiss native.

title: Carey to Make $500,000 Available To Assist BlackoutLooted Stores
description: ALBANY, July 19Governor Carey said today that he would make available $500,000 to assi't the city's shopkeepers in any way that we can in recovering from the damage caused in New York during last week's blackout.

title: Stiffer Rules Set on Cattle Imports
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) ,The Agriculture Department has stiffened rules covering cattle imported from Canada to protect American herds from the costly disease brucellosis. Dr. Francis Mulhern, head of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said the new regulations included stronger herdhealth certification requirements, new vaccination standards, tighter shipping rules and uniform herd and individual brucellosis test rules for imported Canadian cattle.

title: Yachting
description: AT LARCH MONT Y.C. 79th LARCHMONT RACE WEEK Fourth day (Second Junior Dar)

title: Demonstrators Outside Tombs Protest for Looting Suspects
description: About 250 people in two groups demonstrated on the sidewalk across the street from the Tombs yesterday afternoon, protesting arrests and prison conditions in behalf of those still held since being arrested in last week's looting outbreaks.

title: West Germans Advance In Canoe Championships
description: KLAGENFURT, Austria, July 19 (AP) West Germany continued its domina tion of the world whitewater canoeing and kayak championships on the Lieser River near Spittal An Der Drau today, as its women won the wildwater team event in the kayak competition.

title: Worst July Since Dust Bowl
description: The nation is broiling in what weathermen say may be the hottest July since Dust Bowl days.

title: Heat Wave Just Starting for Giants
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 19The heat doesn't rise at the Giants training camp. It just sits, covering the Pace University practice field, and on days like today it can even be seen, shimmering over players in full uniforx while they battle tackle dummies.

title: FLORENCE L. ROTHENBERG
description: Florence Lorenz Rothenberg, administrating supervisor of adult and health services for the Monmouth County Board of Social Services, died Sunday at a hospital in Cambridge, Mass. She was in her late 60's and lived in Keyport, N. Y.

title: DelTufo Called Leading Candidate For the Office of Federal Attorney
description: TRENTON, July 19Robert J. Del Tufo, 43yearold director of the State Division of Criminal Justice and the first assistant state attorney general, was described by national law enforcement officials today as the leading contender to succeed Jonathan L. Goldstein as United States Attorney for New Jersey.

title: :Judge Reduces Bail for Newton But Denies a Motion for Release
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 19Huey P. Newton, president and cofounder of the Black Panther Party, pleaded not guilty in Municipal Court here today to charges of murdering a young woman and assaulting a middleaged man in separate incidents here in 1974.

title: Port Authority Seeks to Build Rail Projects
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced unexpectedly late yesterday that it would immediately ask its bondholders for permission to build rail masstransit projects in both states.

title: Careers
description: Equipped with a Bachelor of Science degree from Rutgers University this spring and unusual professional training, Michele Denicola, 23 years old, had little trouble finding a job in a new and growing fieldthat of physician's assistant.

title: Six Killed in Peru As Strike Protests Austerity Program
description: LIMA, Peru, July 19 (UPI)Peruvian policemen and marines opened fire today on rioting demonstrators supporting strike prohibited by the Government. At least six persons were killed and dozens of others were injured, authorities and news reperts said.

title: Egyptians Turn Over 19 Coffins to Israel
description: TEL AVIV, July 19At a desert rendezvous in the United Nationscontrolled buffer zone between the ceasefire lines in Sinai today, Egypt transferred to Israel 19 coffins said to contain the bodies of soldiers killed during the war of October 1973.

title: CUTOFF DEVICE FAILED TO PREVENT BLACKOUT
description: Protective devices to cut off electricity automatically for 50 percent of New York City and Westchester County should have saved the Consolidated Edison system from its massive electrical blabkout July 13, the heads of the utility and the State Public Service Commission testified yesterday.

title: Secretariat Filly Brings $300,000 at Keeneland
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 19 (AP)A filly by Secretariat was one of four yearlings to reach the $300,000 mark tonight at the Keenland summer sale. The daughter of the Triple Crown winner, out of Libro d Oro, was sold for $300,000, the same price reached by a daughter of GraustarkNatural Sound.

title: Bicycle Lead Is Retained By Thevenet
description: L'ALPE D'HUEZ, France, July 19Bernard Thevenet retainod his overall lead in the Tour de France cycling race today, finishing a strong second to Hennie Kuiper on the most demanding Stage of the 24day endurance test.

title: Grand Jury Studies Forger's Charges of Tax Frauds
description: Charges by a convicted forger, who has vanished, that certain commodity traders faked deals involving some $5 billion of crude petroleum futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to evade taxes are being investigated by a New York grand jury, it was learned yesterday.

title: Beanie Meets With H.U.D. Aides And Wins Delay on Rises in Rent
description: In a policy reversal, the Federal Government agreed yesterday to hold in abeyance its plans for big rent increases at Lincoln Towers and other housing projects in New York City that it had previously determined would need the increases to remain economically stable.

title: Governing Party Sweeps To an Apparent Victory In Elections in Bahamas
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, July 19 (UP1)Prime Minister Lynden 0. Pindling's Progressive Labor Party rolled to comfortable victory tonight in the Bahamas elections, the first since the nation of 700 islands won independence from Britain four years ago.

title: Technology
description: Classical European departments of electrical engineering often were divided into two courses of studystrong current for the students planning career in electric power and weak current for those interested in communications

title: Housing Starts Fell 6% in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (LTDHousing starts fell 6 percent in June from the previous month, but stil maintained an annual construction rate of 1.83 million units, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Black Tennis Champion Seeks a Breakthrough
description: Every once in a while the question is asked, Where are the black tennis players? One of the best is here for the summer, playing in local tournaments. He is Terry Jackson from Houston, and all he asks is to be free to devote two years exclusively to improving his game. That's when I'll know if I can make the big breakthrough, he says.

title: Arraignments Still Clogging Courts
description: About 600 people arrested in the Bronx and Brooklyn over the last several days were still awaiting arraignment yesterday evening, but estimates of how many cases were blackout related varied wildly.

title: Around the Nation
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 19 (UPI)Gov.. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania repaid the Federal Treasury today $299,066.21 in Presidential campaign funds that the Federal Election Commission ruled he had received illegally.

title: McCulloch to Form Development Concern
description: LOS ANGELES, July 19 (AP)The McCulloch Oil Corporation said today that it was forming a new company to take over ils multimilliondollar landdevelopment operations.

title: American and Soviet Institutes Agree on Joint Energy Research
description: An agreement has been signed between a private American research institute and a Soviet institute to explore collaborative testing of a fusionbased power system that also breeds fuel for fission reactors such as those now in wide use.

title: U.S. Brothers Finish 1, 3 in Decathlon in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, July 19 (AP)Two American brothers, Ken and Buddy ICring, won the gold and bronze medals in the decathlon at the Maccabiah Games today.

title: Events/Sports
description: R:309:30 P.M., WNYCAM: Na, tional Town Meeting. Working Couples.

title: Home Wares Offered
description: One could practically furnish a home, or at least the dining room cupboard, with all the copies of glassware, china and silver that museums have been reproducing and offering for sale.

title: SEARCH STEPPED UP FOR KOREA COUNSEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Under strong pressure for action from younger members of the House, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. pressed today a search for new special counsel for the Korean influencebuying investigation.

title: Common Sense the Best Rx For Staying Cool in the Heat
description: Although the city's heat wave is expected to last at least through Friday, one can stay relatively comfortable by following the advice of medical and weather experts.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A second casinotraining school agreed to stop enrolling students and refund tuition until the school obtained a state license.

title: Sequoia FaresPoorly As Floating Museum
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 19 (UPI)Saying that intense,heat had kept tourists away, the owner of the former Presidential yacht Sequoia decided today to pull up anchor and leave India Point Park a week early.

title: Senate Panel Hears Doctor Lost Hospital Rights By Using Laetrile on 80YearOld Cancer Patient
description: HACKENSACK, July 19A State Senate committee holding hearings on the alleged anticancer agent laetrile were told today that a physician on the staff of Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch had had his privileges to admit new patients suspended because he allegedly treated a terminally ill cancer patient with the controversial substance.

title: Wilmington Desegregation Fight Appears Heading for a Showdown
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 19Twentythree years after Brown v. Board of Education, the landmark Supreme Court school desegregation decision in which this state's blacks were among the successful plaintiffs, Delaware is still arguing bitterly over how to end public school discrimination in this city, where the classroom population is 85 percent black.

title: Telephone Tyranny Puts Status on Hold
description: ALL objects of convenience sooner or later become objects of power. The telephonethat ubiquitous convenience and nuisanceis no exception, though has taken some time to understand its subtle hierarchical implications.

title: Cool Buses Putting on Airs
description: If you can't stand the heat, get out of the buses. Many of New York City's 2,813 airconditioned buses aren't, according to a spot check in midtown.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)The State Department said today that Cuba had increased its troop commitment to Angola, but then issued a retraction few hours later.

title: Of 2 South African Trials (Facades)
description: Two of the more important trials in Africa's history ended last week in Pretoria, South Africa; one was a trial of Africa's past, the other of its future.

title: Mr. Smith Elects the Impossible
description: Inside the beleaguered fortress of Rhodesia, Ian Smith plays for time, hoping that somehow he can pull off the impossible: create a political system in which coopted blacks will eventually seem to have a preponderant role; preserve the essential elements of white privilege, and get the rest of the world off his back. His dissolution of Rhodesia's parliament and his call for a general election on Aug. 31 can only have this meaning.

title: Incentives for Capital Investment In Carter's Tax Plan Are Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that the Administration's tax proposals probably would include a combination of incentives for capital investment.

title: Deaths
description: ABBESylvia, beloved wife of Harry, mother of Steven, motherInlaw of Marilyn and grandmother of Brian and David. Passed on after a long Illness Tuesday morning July 19th.

title: CUTOFF DEVICE FAILED TO PREVENT BLACKOUT
description: Protective cievices to cut on electricity automatically for 50 percent of New York City and Westchester County should have saved the Consolidated Edison system from its massive electrical blackout July 13, the heads of the utility and the State Public Service Commission testified yesterday.

title: Con Edison President Says System Designed to Avert Blackout Actually Was a Factor in Bringing It On
description: In the moments before last week's prolonged power blackout in New York City and Westchester County, an important failsafe system operated in a way that actually contributed to the blackout, according to Arthur Hauspurg, president of the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Funky Chico Hamilton Offers Humor
description: CHICO HAMILTON'S QUINTET, which is appearing at Hopper's through next weekend, should be required listening for every overamplified jazzrock band, every purveyor of contemporary funk clichs, and every solemn, humorless musical filibusterer. The group includes an electric guitarist and electric bassist, yet two saxophonistsone of whom doubles on flutewho play without microphones and are heard. The music is funkytight rhythm riffs, stuttering conversations between instruments, a danceable backbeatbut it avoids almost every clich that has become associated with the genre. There is humor to the music, and each tune goes on just long enough to make its point.

title: Germans Condemn 4 in Slayings
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, July 20 (AP)A West German court sentenced three men and a woman to life in prison today for their roles in the 1975 seiz??e of the West German Embassy in Stockholm during which two diplomats were killed. Those sentenced, Lutz Manfred Taufer, KarlHeinz DelIwo, Bernard Rossner and Hanna Elise Krabbe, had taken part in a raid on the embassy to demand the release of 26 terrorists from West German jails.

title: Klein Is Named Top Junior at Race Week
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20Bruce Klein of Sea Cliff Yacht Club, the 1976 Midget sailing champion of Long Island Sound now in the Junior (15 to 17 year) category, was named the outstanding skipper of the Junior series of Larchmont Yacht Club's 79th annual Race Week tonight and received The Commodore's Trophy.

title: GARDENING
description: IF WILLIAM PENN'S statue above Philadelphia's City Hall could turn its head to look over its left shouder, it would see a remarkable garden in the heart of City Center. The elements of design are so carefully developed in this private yard that the impression is overwhelmingly serene.

title: A Laser Pinpoints Mt. McKinley
description: ANCHORAGE, July 20Young mountaineers are descending this week from Mount McKinley, the highest mountain in North America, after helping a scientific expedition to chart its position precisely.

title: About Newyork And Now, the Game of Par Que?
description: Life has been plaintive and inexorable for the last week, with darkness giving way to heat and with New Yorkers showing, one another looks of crankiness and wonderment.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: For the second time this month, the Kennecott Copper Corporation has cut 3 cents a pound from its copper price. The new price, effective today, will be 65 cents a pound for fullplate electrolytic copper cathodes.

title: Solomon Beats McEnroe In Close Match, 76, 75
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)Harold Solomon, who won the Western championship last week. had a difficult time in beating young John McEnroe of New York, 76, 75, in a firstround match at the $125,000 Washington Star tennis tournament today.

description: OKLAHOMA CITYSean O'Grady, Okla home City, knocked out Richardo Flores, Mexico City, 2 rounds, bant??weights.

title: Making Furniture Shine
description: TO SOME New York furniture craftsmen, the everyday care of tables, chairs and other pieces of fine wood furniture is somewhat like maintaining a car. You can't rub too often, too vigorously or too longthe more polishing, the better.

title: Home Beat
description: The continentalizing of New York continues with another outlet for Italian products. Around the First of the year we'll have a new furniture store, tentativey named Techinteriors, but don't memorize the name. It will be changed as soon as the deal is consummated to link the store loosely to a renowned Italian home furnishings magazine.

title: Jeter Versus Powell: A Standoff in the Trenches
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 20There have been more cosmic meetings throughout history. But whenever the Giants and Jets top draft choices happen to face each other, more than a scrimmage is involved.

title: DR. EDWIN F. GILDEA, PROFESSOR, 79, DIES
description: Dr. Edwin F. Gildea, a retired professor of psychiatry at Washington University in St. Louis, died Tuesday at his home in Woods, Hole, Mass. He was 79 years old.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Two Insurers Upheld On Crane's Collapse
description: TRENTON, July 20 (UPI)No insurance claim may be filed if equipment covered by an exclusionary clause is misused by the operator, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today in a nineyearold insurance dispute

title: KnicksNets Dispute Is Sent to Court Here
description: The trial in the territorial dispute between the Knicks and the Nets is scheduled to start tomorrow in Federal District Court in Manhattan under Judge Robert L. Carter. The issue is whether the Nets can move from the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, LI., to New Jersey.

title: CARTER TALK TODAY TO FOCUS ON SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter is preparing to use a trip into the South tomorrow to deliver an address on SovietAmerican relations, with the aim of creating a more positive atmosphere for dealing with Moscow.

description: LIMA, Peru, July 20Peru's military rulers, concerned over yesterday's general strike, met until dawn today to consider economic measures to relieve public unrest.

title: Flights of Concorde To U.S. Increasing
description: LONDON, July 20 (AP)British Airways said today that its four supersonic Concorde flights to Washington each week were so full that there would be six flights a week beginning Aug. 21. The airline also announced that it had taken delivery of a fifth Concorde.

title: While Town He Visited in March Is Troubled
description: CLINTON, Mass.Four months ago, President Carter came to a town meeting here in an exercise that gave many people the impression that Clinton was a typical New England town.

description: Some oil and gas issues that ranked as recent prominent stock market gainers were hit by selling yesterday, while prices on the New York Stock Exchange generally held about even.

title: I.R.S. and U.S. Attorney Study a $50,000 Payment Made by Allied Chemical
description: WASHINGTON,July 20The Internal Revenue Service and a United States attorney are investigating a $50,000 payment made by the Allied Chemical Company in 1976, the company disclosed today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The four upper New Yorkbound lanes of the George Washington Bridge will be closed weekdays from 8 P.M. to 6 A.M. and during daytime offhours starting Monday and continuing to the end of the year, while the upperlevel deck is replaced, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced.

title: Court Upholds Nebraska On Malpractice Solution
description: LINCOLN, Neb.,July 20The Nebraska Legislature's 1976 attempt to end the alleged medical malpractice insurance premium crisis was upheld today by a divided state Supreme Court.

title: Paine Webber Quarter Profits Up 12.3% to $2.3 Million From 76
description: Paine Webber Inc., parent company of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., the nation's fifthlargest investment banking house, announced yesterday that profits for the June quarter rose 12.3 percent to $2.3 million from $2 million a year earlier. Revenues rose 24 percent to $67.2 million from $54.4 million.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT IS 1825. Schlumberger  William Schlumberger, hunchback Alsatian chessgeniussits at his customary table in Paris's Caf de la , Rgence, his mood foul from hangover, his image reflected infinitely by surrounding mirrors as he meditates an endgame of Philidor's. Before him stands Maelzel  Johann Nepomuk Maelzel, court mechanician of the Austrian Empire, or so he claims challenging Schlumberger to play his supreme invention, a chessplaying automaton, a thing of gears and magnets and a pantograph, called simply enough The Turk. Schlumberger sneers.

title: Backgammon:
description: After taking first prize at the Clermont Club Spring Tournament, Stephen Raphael won the Crockford's Summer Backgammon Tournament in London this month. These unprecedented back  to back triumphs were particularly gratifying for Raphael. Despite his standing as one of England's foremost players, first place in international competition had eluded him since before World War II. At Crockford's, Raphael's victory over Lou Kollakis in the 25point match finals was hard fought. The lead changed hands often until Raphael finally nosed ahead, 23 to 22.

title: CARTER SAID TO SEEK AMNESTY FOR ALIENS IN COUNTRY 7 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter will propose to Congress next week legislation granting,full amnesty to aliens who have been working illegally in this country for seven years or longer, Administration officials disclosed today.

description: The blackout of New York City and the looting that occurred during it are rapidly becoming issues in the Democratic mayoral primary as, a week later, candidates continue to hold news conferences and issue almost daily press releases on the subject. In addition, they are commissioning polls to gauge the reaction of the electorate to the blackout and looting.

title: A.C.L.U FINDS CARTER LAGGING ON LIBERTIES
description: WASHINGTON,July 20The American Civil Liberties Union accused the Carter Administration today of compiling a poor civil liberties record in its first six months in office.

title: DEATH WARNING IS URGED ON CIGARETTE PACKAGES
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)Cigarette packages should flatly warn that smoking may kill one rather than saying that it is merely dangerous to one's health, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: CLARK C. SORENSEN
description: Clark C. Sorensen, a retired management consultant, died Monday at the Lakewood, Ohio, Hospital. He was 62 years old and a resident of Lakewood.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON,July 20 Rocco D. Ricci took the oath of office today as the new State Commissioner of Environmental Protection and pledged that he would work for an effective and realisic program for preventing toxic and carcinogenic substances in the environment.

title: Senate Approves Compromise Bill Setting Stiff StripMining Rules
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)The Senate adopted today a compromise version of a strip mining bill that would set tough new provisions for reclaiming land ravaged by the extraction of coal and require the consent of surface owners before it could be mined. The vote was 85 to 8.

title: Armed Citizens Patrol Bushwick, Saying the Police Do Not Do Job
description: Late every evening, when the sun has disappeared behind the decaying tenements in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, William Johnson brings out his shotgun, coaxes his two German shepherd dogs out of their kennels and starts patrolling his block.

title: Cauthen Boots Home 3 Belmont Winners
description: Steve Cauthen replaced the weather as the main conversation piece at sticky Belmont Park yesterday. The 17yearold jockey rode three winners with a slight assist from the stewards before 14,665 customers baking in 90degree temperatures.

title: Judge's Distaste Worth $141,000 To Coffee Man
description: A jury awarded $141,000 yesterday to a food vendor who had been brought in handcuffs to the chambers of a Suffolk County judge who disliked his coffee.

title: The Garbage Picker: Treasures Made of Other People's Trash
description: JASON MARTINELLI'S idea of a night on the town is to jump into his mungopicking outfit, jump in o n commodious refuse bin, and just root around in there collecting fantast c. free. found material with which to decorate his apartment.

title: Criminal Justice Costs Rise
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The cost of the nation's criminal justice systems rose from $11 billion in the fiscal year 1971 to $17 billion in the fiscal year 1975, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration said today. It said that the new figure represented an increase to $71 from $45 for each man, woman and child in the country.

title: Dixon Catches Giants Eyes in Jets Scrimmage
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 20The goalpost at one end of the Pace University practice field was judged too close to the fence to try for extra points without sending someone into the woods looking for the ball, so the final score of the scrimmage between the Jets and Giants rookies and free agents today must be listed as 1818.

title: Battered Spouses Are Helped in Bill Approved by Carey
description: ALBANY, July 20Predicting more effective relief to the battered spouse,  Governor Carey announced today that he had approved a bill giving the victim of family violence the choice of seeking reconciliation in the Family Courts or punishment for the assailant in the Criminal Courts.

title: Let Them Eat Workfare
description: What is it in American political morality that makes the giving of food to the hungry so grudging? For years, the only Federal food assistance was the distribution of surplus commodities, such as powdered milk and soybeans. These were finally superseded by food stamps, much more useful and generous, but even they involve a stigma and, in any event, users are required to put up considerable cash in order to receive the federally subsidized discount. Now Congress is on the verge of eliminating this requirement. The Senate has already voted to do so and the House is likely to act this week. But the House appears willing to institute a new obstacle in its place.

description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Central Intelligence Agency conducted a 14year program to find ways to control human behavior through the use of chemical, biological and radiological material, according to agency documents made public today by John Marks, a freelance journalist.

He leaves his loving wile Sylvia, his devoted sons and daughterinlaw, Richard, Howard and Osier. His beloved mother Mary Abrams and sisters Charlotte Starr, Evelyn Epstein and Rita Solon. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, Thursday, July 21st, 11:30 A.M.

title: Teachers Union Is Fined $50,000 for Illegal New York City Public School Strike in 1975
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday fined the United Federation of Teachers $50,000 and the Council of Supervisors and Administrators $7,500 for the illegal strike that virtually closed New York City's schools for five days in September 1975.

title: Califano Revising Welfare Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, education and Welfare, said today that the Carter Administration's welfare plan had been adjusted to make it fairer to states like New York that give relatively high benefits to the poor.

title: Mars Dust Storm Hinders Viking
description: PASADENA, Calif.,July 20(Reuters)The planet Mars is engulfed in a massive dust storm which is interfering with the yearold scientific mission of the Viking spacecraft on the planet's surface, a Jet Propulsion Laboratory spokesman said here today. The spokesman, Alan Wood, said the Viking I lander, which touched down on the planet a year ago to send back the first ground level pictures, was transmitting murky, indistinct photographs. The storm is a big one, Mr. Wood said, adding it was not expected to clear for several more weeks.

title: U.S. Proposes Porpoise Deaths Be Reduced to 31,140 in 1980
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)The National Marine Fisheries Service proposed today regulations to reduce the number of porpoises killed annually by American tuna fishermen, from 59,050 this year to 31,140 in 1980.

title: Readmitted West Point Cadets Complete First Makeup Course
description: WEST POINT, N.Y. July 20 (UPI)The first group of cadets to be readmitted to the United States Military Academy since last year's cheating scandal has successfully completed a makeup course in electrical engineering, a spokesman for the Academy said today.

title: Kenya Somalia Agree on Plan To Maintain Peace Along Border
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 20Kenya and Somalia have pledged to maintain peace along the:r border and agreed to set up a border commission to normalize and restore tranquility in the region, it was announced today.

title: Trust Company Welcomes Effort By Port Authority on Rail Projects
description: The United States Trust Company, the largest single holder of bonds of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, welcomed yesterday an authority campaign to win bondholders agreement for financing new rail transit projects in both states.

title: BANKRUPTCY CHANGE SOUGHT FOR U.M. & M
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday asked a Federal court to shift the bankruptcy status of United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc. to a Federal receivership in order to protect debenture holders and stockholders.

title: Sound
description: SOUND IS WHERE you find it, and since the advent of batterypowered, portable cassette recorders of reasonable quality, vacation travelers have come to look upon such machines much as they regard their camerasas devices to hold fast impressions gathered on their journeys. Often the sonic snapshot evokes the atmosphere of a place or the memory of an event more vividly than a photograph. One wellfinanced and chronically footloose friend has gone on farflung tape safaris, bagging aural trophies at hootenannieS, carnivals and country fairs, at the initiation rites of the Navahos, at snakecharming contests in Katmandu and at evensong in Westminster Abbey.

title: While the Present Troubles Clinton, Mass.
description: CLINTON, Mass.Four months ago, President Carter came to a town meeting here in an exercise that gave many people the impression that Clinton was a typical New England town.

title: Jaworski Named To Take Charge Of Korea Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The House ethics committee today chose Leon A. Jaworski, the former Watergate special prosecutor, to take charge of its investigations of Korean influencebuying and help revive public confidence in the inquiry.

title: Kodak Net Off 3.7% in Latest Drop While Rival Polaroid's Rises 10.8%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday for the second quarter a second straight decline in net earnings, while its archrival, the Polaroid Corporation, piled up another quarterly earnings record.

title: Poll Shows More Optimism About Economic Future
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 20New Jerseyans are more optimistic about their economic futures than they were last year, according to the latest in a series of polls on New Jersey Images released today by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: The Steady Onslaught Against the Dollar
description: LONDON, July 20 (AP)The dollar sank to new lows against Europe's two major currencies, the West German mark and the Swiss franc, in what dealers described as hectic trading today.

title: As for the 02 KosherFood Rioters . . .
description: The blackout and the accompanying social disorders among many very poor black and Hispanic New Yorkers soon will become part of contemporary urban folklore. Judging by much that has been written and spoken in the last week, it is possible that too many New Yorkers may remember little more than what some have misleadingly, and unpardonably, described as the night of the animals. Others, as reported in the press, characterized the disorderly as vultures, a jackal pack, buffalo, and predatory animals.

title: Cubs Sutter Out 10 Days
description: CHICAGO, July 20 (UPI)The Chicago Cubs star relief pitcher, Bruce Sutter, is suffering from a hemorrhaging back muscle and will be out of the lineup for about 10 days, the club said today. Sutter was examined by the team's physician, and advised to refrain from throwing until at least next Monday. Sutter is currently the major leagues leading reliever with 24 saves and a 51 wonlost record.

title: Private Companies Rally to Aid Thoie Who Lost to Looters
description: About $1.25 million has been pledged or given by New York City banks, businesses, unions and individuals to a special fund for the relief of victims of looting, vandalism and arson that occurred during last week's power blackout.

title: Low Calorie Rules issued
description: WASHINGTON,July 20 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration today proposed strict rules on what foods can be called low in calories and how that fact can be advertised.

title: Looting Cases Persist as a Problem
description: Courts, prosecutors and prisons in three boroughs still have a sizable task ahead in processing people arrested last week for crimes associated with the power blackout, despite the arraignment yesterday morning of the last of the nearly 4,000 suspects.

title: Esmark, Halting Its Takeover Bid, To Offer Option on Inmont Shares
description: The Inmont Corporation, the nation's largest ink makers, appeared yesterday to have defusedat least temporarilya $200 million, unfriendly takeover bid by Esmark Inc., the food and chemical company once known as Swift & Company.

title: A Cold Front, Creeping East, Is Expected to Bring Relief by Tomorrow
description: After being stalied for days west of the Great Lakes, a cold front is creeping eastward and is expected to bring relief from the heat along the East Coast by tomorrow.

title: ECONOMY EXPECTED TO CONTINUE GROWTH THROUGH END OF 78
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Congressional Budget Office forecast today that the American economy would continue to expand throughout 1978 and that inflation was a deeply embedded force that would abate only slowly.

title: Church of Scientology To Get Documents Back
description: LOS ANGELES,July 20 (AP)A Federal prosecutor has agreed to return thousands of documents seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a raid on the Hollywood offices of the Church of Scientology.

title: CORPORATE BONDS EASE MODERATELY
description: Corporate bond prices fell moderately yesterday, but Government and taxexempt obligations showed little change in the credit markets. Trading remained subdued.

title: TODD SECURES APPROVAL TO REDUCE SHARE VALUES
description: Stockholders of the Todd Shipyards Corporation yesterday gave their permission for a reduction of the par value of the common and preferred stocks to $1 from $10 a share and an increase in the authorized preferred to 5 million from 1 million shares.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COOL CIDER Although the label of Big Apple has become the popular label for New York City only during the last decade or so, the words could easily have been substituted as the title for Wonderful Town. The Broadway musical hit of 1954, derived from My Sister Eileen, had a score by Leonard Bernstein, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, a Joseph FieldsJerome Chodorov book and it emphatically starred Rosalind Russell, in a return from Hollywood. Reviewing the show for The New York Times, Brooks Atkinson stated that Miss Russell should run for President.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Wednesday, July 20. 1977

title: West German Car Output Off
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 20 (UPI)West Germany's auto industry produced 358,700 cars in June, the Association of German Auto Industry said today. This compares with 357,429 units produced in May. The total includes passenger cars, station wagons and commercial vehicles. The June output was up 9 percent against the 1976 month. In the first six months, a total of 2.19 million cars were produced, up 8.2 percent against a year ago.

title: JUDGE OVERRULES JURY AND FREES EXLEGISLATOR
description: WATERBURY, Conn., July 20A Superior Court judge overturned a jury verdict today and acquitted former State Representative Bernard L. Avcollie of murdering his wife.

title: Business Records
description: BUSINESS RECORDS

title: The Tour de Force Of Redecorating Boscobel
description: GARRISON, N.Y. THE clients of the interior decorating project in question have been dead for 150 years. Nevertheless, the urgency to accurately analyze their personalities,  interpret their way of life and complete the revamping of their residence in less than nine months was even more press ing than when the elegant country seat of States Morris Dyckman was being finished 175 years ago.

title: FuelCost Assistance Is Offered to Poor
description: ALBANY, July 20 (AP)Poor families that are having trouble meeting their fuel bills will be eligible for as much as $250 in Federal aid, Governor Carey announced today.

title: Smallest O.E.C.D. Countries Suffer Payment Ills
description: PARIS, July 20  They are known informally as The Tiny Twelve  or sometimes The Feeble Fifteen, depending how you countand they are rapidly emerging as a major economic headache

title: Rohatyn Accuses Carter Of Ignoring Cities Plight On Financing of Welfare
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, charged yesterday that President Carter was ignoring the plight of the cities by refusing to move quickly on a Federal takeover of local welfare costs.

title: U.S. Quintet Captures Gold At Maccabiahs
description: TEL AVIV, July 20 (AP)The United States basketball team, with only a week's practice before the start of the Maccabiah Games, beat Israel by 9291 today and won the last gold medal of the Jewish Olympics.

title: ARGENTINES PROHIBIT MASS BY CONTROVERSIAL PRELATE
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 20 (AP)Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the traditionalist who has been feuding with Pope Paul VI over modernization of the Roman Catholic Church, arrived here today but apparently was barred from saying Mass.

title: U.S. Blackout Aid Put at $5 Million
description: At least $5 million and probably more in Federal grants will be made available for New York City to recover from the arson and the looting that accompanied the July 13 electric power blackout, various sources in the city and Washington said yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: S.E.C. Halts Trading In 2 Stocks Till Monday
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading yesterday in the stock of Frigitronics Inc. and the Vernitron Corporation until 10 A.M. Monday.

title: U.S. Deaf Athletes Excel
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 20 (AP) American men sprinters swept the 100meter dash, overwhelming their Soviet rivals, and United States swimmers grabbed six more gold medals at the World Games for the Deaf today.

title: Showers Depress Soybeans, Corn; Other Grains Slip
description: CHICAGO, July 20 (AP)Scattered thundershowers over portions of the Midwest depressed soybean and corn futures prices and pulled down other grains on the Chicago Board of Trade today.

title: NEW &USEFUL
description: Handpainted fabric for the home is getting to be quite the thing. And canvas is the fabric of the momentat least for summer. All of which makes Alan West, painter and graphic designer, a man who doing the right thing at the right time: He is painting on artist's canvas and offering his oeuvres as coverings for tabletops, pillows, upholstered furniture, floors, walls and screens. Macy's, too, thought it was an idea whose time had come. The store has set up a large platform in the middle of its ninthfloor furniture department as a showcase for Mr. West's designs. The fabrics here are painted in bold arcs or diagonals of color; others are what is known, when the work is done on wood, as fantasy finishes. That is, he paints fabrics to resemble lapis or malachite or wood burl. He even paints fabrics to resemble suede or cotton sateen. Why bother? The depth, Mr. West insists. You get effects of shadow and depth you can't get otherwise. The platform setting includes modular seating covered with Mr. West's strokes of the brush, as well as a round table cover, a screen, director's chairs and pillows. Unless you buy something off the platform, everything is customordered through Macy's decorating department. The fabrics are $25 a yard; the modular seating units are $300 for an ottoman, $375 for an armless seat, and $450 for a corner seat. Paneled screens, 16 inches wide and 84 inches high, are about $300 a panel. Throw pillows from $45 to $60.

title: Floods Hit Johnstown Area;25 Are Feared Dead
description: RICHLAND TOWNSHIP, Pa., July 20A nightlong seveninch rainfall caused severe flooding and killed at least la persons in Johnstown and surrounding Communities, leaving Johnstown an island today, reachable only by helicopter from this suburb five miles away.

title: Policing Human Rights
description: The United States is gradually but finally getting out of the business of providing weapons and knowhow to the police agencies of authoritarian governments. Withdrawal from these oncethriving programs has reached a point where it is crimping the sales of American manufacturers of small arms and other police paraphernalia, but their interests should not override the nation's on the course now set by Congress and the Executive.

title: Notes on People
description: IN A wartsandall critique of her children, Lillian Carter said of her son, President Carter: I don't think when Jimmy says, I've never told a lie, that he means white lies, because everybody has to. tell those. But I think he's truthful and admire his family life. Of her daughter Ruth Carter Stapleton, the evangelist, Mrs. Carter, in an interview in the August issue of Ladies Home Journal, said, about all I admire about Ruth is her persistence in her work. She never gives up, said Mrs. Carter. She's not a very good mother, but her family just adores her, so I reckon she's all right. Mrs. Carter said of her yongest son: Billy drinks a little too much beer. I have never mentioned to him, and I like Billy just like he is. If he ever, tried to change, he'd be the biggest mess that ever was. The interview was conducted by Gloria Carter Spann, of whom her mother said: You pay no attention to me, and that suits me fine.

title: Addict Gets Maximum Sentence For Fatal Stabbing in Queens
description: At the recommendation of District Attorney John Santucci of Queens, a 25yearold drug addict received a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison yesterday for a fatal stabbing, The Associated Press reported.

title: Mostly Mozart, Partly Stravinsky
description: THERE WERE three Mozart trios in the Mostly Mozart Festival program in Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night, and they were played to a faretheewell by the members of the group known as Tashi. But the big hit of the evening was a short interlude devoted to Stravinsky's Three Pieces for Clarinet Solo. Responsible for this success were not only the composer's ingenious, logical and entertaining ideas but also the performance by the ensemble's Richard Stoltzman.

title: Junkyard Operator and 3 Workers Indicted in Auto Insurance Fraud
description: A junkyard operator and three men who worked for him were indicted in Manhattan yesterday for allegedly conducting an insurancefraud scheme to dispose of automobiles that were falsely reported to have been stolen.

title: Home Vandalism Laid To 3 Children, 5 to 12
description: HANOVER PARK, ???., July 20(AP)Three children caused $13,000 damage in vandalizing a neighbor's home while the family was on vacation, the police said today.

title: Albus and 7 Others Advance in L.I. Golf
Sears Warns on Exercise Cycles
description: CHICAGO, July 20 (UPI)Sears, Roebuck and Company said today that a potential hazard existed in two of its exercise cycles and the owners should not use them until they were repaired. The company said that, after extensive use, a metal post underneath the seat might push through the plastic seat material, exposing the rider to, the risk of injury. Some 17,000 of the cycles have been sold by Sears. The model numbers, which can be found on an identification label on the frame, are 166.28260, or 592.28260 and 166.29680.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Horses listed In order of nest positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Jesuits Remain in Salvador as Death Deadline Nears
description: SAN SALVADOR, July 20 (AP)With the approach of the deadline tomorrow when rightwing terrorists said they would kill 50 Jesuit priests if they remained in El Salvador, the priests went calmly about their tasks today, guarded by armed police and unarmed parishioners.

title: Alaskan Oil Flowing Again
description: DEADHORSE, Alaska, July 20 (AP)Oil is moving again in the troubleplagued Alaska pipeline after the third shutdown in 16 days. As in the other stoppages, officials blamed human error for the latest incident, which had halted the flow yesterday.

title: Safety Dispute Delays a Market
description: Approval of a plan to build a market beneath the Queensboro Bridge is being delayed by a dispute over whether concrete slabs are likely to fall from the bridge and strike people below.

title: Prison Uprisings Spread in Spain To Back Call for. General Amnesty
description: MADRID, July 20(AP)The, Spanish Government struggled today to quell rebellion , by prison inmates that has spread to jails across the country since it began here Monday to back demands for a general amnesty.

title: The Great Kitchen Hangup
description: WHEN IT COMES to kitchen storage, there are two schools of thought. The Good Housekeeper approach is to hide everything behind closed doors. Nothing is allowed out except perhaps a toasterand if there's a way to build that in, the architects who have encouraged this look will find it. In these kitchens the cabinets are paramount. At their bestand costliestthey can be made to accommodate the most ungainly items.

title: Croatian Couple Get Life Terms For Air Piracy
description: Two of the Croatian nationalists who hijacked a Trans World Airline jet last Sept. 10 were sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday to mandatory terms of life imprisonment for air piracy resulting in a death.

title: Election Panel Approves the Audit Of Church Presidential Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)  The Federal Election Commission approved today the final audit of the 1976 Presidential campaign of Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, after his campaign committee made several minor corrections to comply with the law.

title: The PorkBarrel Challenge
description: The public works appropriations bill emerged from conference yesterday with the traditional string of politicalgrease projects as the result of a compromise under which President Carter was forced. to surrender both. his principles and the clearcut public interest.

title: Little Theater of Deaf Begins Story Hours
description: Looking for something for the children? The Little Theater of the Deaf begins its fourth annual story hour Monday at the Hans Christian Andersen statue near the pond at 76th Street in Central Park.
