description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: People in Sports
description: Its legal battle against Bob Arum settled in its favor by a United States District Court judge, Madison Square Garden formally announced yesterday the world heavyweight title fight between Muhammad All and Earnie Shavers.

title: A Host of Unfulfilled Promises ComeHome to Haunt Sadat
description: CAIROPresident Anwar elSadat is on the spot, more so perhaps than at any time since he came to power, the victim es home and in foreign policy of unfulfilled promises.

title: Hypnotic ViolinistWriter
description: MICHAEL GALASSO is a violinist and composer from Louisiana who is best known around Lower Manhattan for his faultless performances of other composers music and for his musical accompaiments to some of Robert Wilson's plays. He has been Performing his own music at the Franklin Street Arts Center, 112 Franklin Street, this weekthe final performance is tonight at 8and bringing a distinctive personality to bear on an increasingly standardized brand of music.

title: New York City Spending Millions on Empty Space, Comptroller's Audit Says
description: In an audit that was highly critical of the New York City Real Estate Department, Harrison J. Goldin, the City Comptroller, charged yesterday that the city was spending $5.4 million a year for office and storage space it did not need.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Hospital Reinstates the Privileges Of a Physician Who Used Laetrile
description: LONG BRANCH, July 20Officials of the Monmouth Medical Center voted today to reinstate the staff physician whose privileges to admit new patients to the facility were suspended last Friday because he administered laetrile to a terminally ill cancer patient, after the physician, Dr. Harold Gabel, agreed not to continue the injections.

title: Soccer
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Judge's Distaste Worth $141,000 To Coffee Man
description: A jury awarded $141,000 yesterday to a food vendor who had been brought in handcuffs to the chambers of a Suffolk County judge who disliked his coffee.

title: Croatian Couple Get Life Terms For Air Piracy
description: Two of the Croatian nationalists who hijacked a Trans World Airline jet last Sept. 10 were sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday to mandatory terms of life imprisonment for air piracy resulting in a death.

title: In Carter Compromise, Conferees Drop Funds for Breeder Reactor but Approve Nine Water Projects
description: WASHINGTON,July 20House and Senate conferees accepted President Carter's offer of a compromise today, agreeing to drop funds for the Clinch River breeder reactor but approving nine of 18 water projects the President had opposed as wasteful.

title: Bank Reports
description: For periods ended June 30. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecenter.

title: Opening Olmsted's Mail
description: AS A young sailor on a ship bound for China in 1843, Frederick Law Olmsted wrote his letters home on both sides of very thin paper. Trying to transcribe one of these can boggle the mind, said Charles Capen McLaughlin, who is editing 60,000 pages of letters and manuscripts of the pioneer landscape architect who codesigned Central Park in 1856.

title: Family Money: The Dream House Market
description: DOLLAR for dollar, one of the best investments around these days is not a new high technology stock, but the plain old onefamily house. Over the last five years. the median value of the singlefamily home has increased at the rate of 14 percent a year. That figure does not take into account the advantages of income tax sayings generated by mortgage Interest or realestate tax payments.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONI give praise to my lord and Savior for giving me the health and strength to be here, said the small, bluehaired lady in the pink dress, as she began to speak before the bright television lights in the ornate Senate caucus room last Tuesday.

title: Disks: Colin Davis Enlivens Sibelius
description: Though perhaps his most popular, Sibelius's first two symphonies are transitional works, weakened by stretches of repetition and melodrama. Even so, they are full of good things, and a canny conductor can subdue the occasional banality of the style by stressing affinities to the starkness and concision of the composer's mature works.

title: Arab World Assails Begin View; `Not a Peace Plan but a War Plan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20Arabs, militant and moderate, joined today in denouncing the peace proposals of Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel but did so on the basis of reports about them that have circulated in the Middle East in recent days.

title: Melinda Ann Lewis Is Bride Of Thomas Edward Hassen
description: Melinda Ann Lewis was married last evening in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest to Thomas Edward Hassen, a vice president of the investment concern of Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc. The Rev. Alan Houghton performed the ceremony.

title: CARTER IS OPTIMISTIC ON GENEVA MEETING AFTER HEARING BEGIN
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter said today he believed, as a result of discussions with Arab, leaders, that the views expressed to him by Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel in the last two days would produce a Geneva peace conference on the Middle East as early as October.

title: For Elderly, Coping With Heat Proves a Traumatic Experience
description: On a bench in Sheridan Square in Greenwich Village, 79yearold Connie Gugliandolo dipped into a pint of chocolate ice cream with a slotted cookingspoon.

title: Cuomo Meets With Sinatra in Little Italy
description: Mario M. Cuomo, a Democratic mayoral candidate, went to Little Italy yesterday to visit Frank Sinatra on a film set in a restaurant on Mulberry Street.

title: Personal Beauty
description: BABY, it's hot outside. One feels sticky and limp, nerves fraying. Head for water, the most soothing of the elements. It not only gets you clean, it helps you to recharge. You may not have a mountain stream at your door but you do have a bathroom. with a title thought, you can turn it into a blissful retreat.

title: HANOI ENTRY BACKED IN SECURITY COUNCIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20The Security Council approved Vietnam's admission to United Nations membership today and the Vietnamese used the occasion to push their demands for United States assistance in healing the wounds of war.

title: Army Clerk's Dismissal Upheld
description: FORT RUCKER, Ala., July 20 (AP)Col. George F. Powers, commander of the First Aviation Brigade, today approved the recommendation of a military board that Marie Sode, a 22yearold Army clerk, be expelled from the service for homosexual tendencies based on her marriage to a transsexual man. Colonel Powers agreed that Specialist 4 Sode and her husband, a former WAC, 29, who goes by the name Kristian von Hoffburg, lived together as biological females.

title: Slogans in Peking Report Party Meeting
description: PEKING, Thursday, July 21 (Agence FrancePresse)The third plenary session of the Central Committee of the Communist Party has just been held in Peking, according to slogans seen this morning in the streets of the capital.

title: FOREIGN FUNDS VIOLATION LODGED AGAINST LAW FIRM
description: WASHINGTON. July 20The Justice Department today sought a civil injunction against a New York law firm, saying that it had violated the Foreign Agents Registration Act by hiding the true source of funds it spent to entertain and lobby Congressmen. The complaint. which was filed in United States District Court here. charged the law firm of Casey, Lane and Mittendorf, and others, with willfully concealing the source of payments for lobbying of members of the House Agriculture Committee, so as to hide a possi ble conflict of interest situation.

title: With Fewer Little Luxembourgers, Grand Duchy Worries
description: LUXEMBOURG  This tiny grand duchy, nestling in the heart of Western Europe where Belgium, France and West Germany meet, is running out of people. Its own people, that is. Foreigners, by contrast, are too plentiful.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Dr. Sidney P. Schwartz, at 81; Was a Cardiologist and Teacher
description: Dr. Sidney P. Schwartz, a cardiologist, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 8 East 96th Street.

title: PRODUCTION OF CRUDE OIL IS REVISED DOWNWARD
description: In its latest weekly supply statistics. the American Petroleum Institute announced a downward revision in its estimated United States crude oil production for the month of July, a change attributable to recent 10days shutdown of the transAlaskan pipeline.

title: Design Notebook
description: IN NEW YORK you can dine in a basement, in a garden or on top of a skysolaper, but until recently you could not eat at what, given the city's geography. should be the most natural place of allthe water's edge. But in recent weeks a place in Brooklyn at 1 Water Street has begun to remedy this omission. Called the River Cafe (5225200), it serves meals on a barge and, from the standpoint of design, it is one of the most pleasing places to eat that New York has seen in some years.

title: Warnings Ordered On Use of Progestin And Estrogen Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)  The Food and Drug Administration moved today to require that warning brochures be issued with estrogen and progestin drugs, taken by more than three million American women.

title: World Team Tennnis
description: TUESDAY NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Nola Locke Arndt, 88, Inspired Her HusbandtoBe to Write Nola
description: Nola Locke Arndt, whose courtship with the late Felix Arndt inspired him to write the song Nola, died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 88 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Bridge:
description: CHICAGO, July 20The New York partnership of Peter Weichsel and Alan Sontag added another title to its large collection here last night by winning the lifemasterpair championship, thus strengthening their claim to be regarded as America's strongest pair.

title: Excerpts From the Statement by Begin
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Following are excerpts from opening remarks by Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel at his news conference today:

title: C.I.A. Data Show 14Year Project On Controlling Human Behavior
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Central Intelligence Agency conducted a 14year program to find ways to control human behavior through the use of chemical, biological and radiological material, according to agency documents made public today by John Marks, a freelance journalist.

title: Festive Washington Square Music Festival
description: WHEN THE directors of the Washington Square Music Festival realized that its 20th anniversary was coming up, they decided to do something special to celebrate the occasion. Because the five weeks of summer concerts have always been outdoor events in the Square, they planned an indoor event to be given at the nearby Church of the Ascension at Fifth Avenue and 10th Street.

title: 2 MAYORS WILL PUSH FOR MORE STATE AID
description: JERSEY CITY, July 20The Mayors ofthe state's two largest cities, Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark and Thomas F. X. Smith of Jersey City, talked today about how we can get our grantsmanship act together as they viewed the upcoming governorship election in terms of which candidate would do more to help them solve their problems. Both are Democrats.

title: Carter Praises Wilkins
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)President Carter today expressed gratitude on behalf of the American people to Roy Wilkins, the retiring executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: F.B.I. Arrests Two on Information Alleging Cruise Missile Spy Scheme
description: MIAMI,July 20Federal agents today arrested an American and a West German on the basis of information that they had been supplying Communist governments with an assortment of sophisticated electronics and computer data.

title: Chicago Protest March Set
description: CHICAGO, July 20 (UPI)Members of the Martin Luther King Jr. Movement Coalition announced today that they would march Saturday to Marquette Park, the scene of violent clashes last year between blacks and whites. The Rev. Edgar Jackson, leader of the group, said that the march would be held to protest recent alleged beatings of blacks in the park.

title: $56 Million in Federal Aid Allotted to Shoe Producers Hit by Imports
description: WASHINGTON,July 20The White House announced today an experimental, threeyear, $56 million effort to help American shoe manufacturers who have been hurt by imports.

title: Grant, in Quieter Fashion, Joins Applause for Seaver
description: New Yorks baseball fans showed Tom Seaver how they feel about him before and during Tuesday night's AllStar Game. Yesterday, M. Donald Grant, Seaver's former employer, disclosed how he feels sometimes.

title: Kicks Down Swedish Team
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn, July 20 (AP) Stan Cummins scored on a pass from Peter Short to give the Minnesota Kicks a 21 victory over Hammarby, a Swedish First Division team, last night in an International Challenge match. Both teams scored once in the first half on penaltykick conversions.

title: Thoreau: More Than a Big Fish in Walden Pond
description: IN THE WORLD ABOUT HIM, Henry David Thoreau studied the grandeur of nature's design, but what he got from people was studied neglect.

title: Duffey Expected to Head Humanities Endowment
description: WASHINGTON, July 20President Carter has offered the chairmanship of the National Endowment for the Humanities to Joseph D. Duffey, who has been serving as Assistant Secretary of State for Cultural Affairs since January.

title: ARCHIBALD L. BEYEA
description: Archibald L. Beyea, a retired advertisI ing executive, died Monday at Norwalk (Conn.) Community Hospital. He was 72 years old and a resident of Westport,i Conn.

title: CARTER TALK TODAY TO FOCUS ON SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter is preparing to use a trip into the South tomorrow to deliver an address on SovietAmerican relations, with the aim of creating a more positive atmosphere for dealing with Moscow.

title: Sassy Declared Winner
description: SARNIA, Ontario, July 20 (AP)Sassy, the first yacht across the finish line in the ChicagoSarnia race, was declared the winner today as other competitors struggled to overcome flat winds and fog.

description: BASEBALL

title: ExInmate Says Fatal Prison Fire Was Set as Part of Escape Plan
description: MORGANTON, N.C., July 20 (UPI)A former inmate at the McDowell County prison unit, where a fire killed nine prisoners last year, said yesterday that inmates had set the blaze to lure guards into the cellblock as part of a mass escape plan.

title: General Telephone Reports 25.8% Rise In Quarter's Profit
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, which operates the nation's largest independent telephone system, posted substantial sales and earnings increases for the quarter and six months ended June 30, according to the report yesterday of Theodore F. Brophy, chairman.

title: AGENCY TO MOVE FASTER IN DISCRIMINATION CASES
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission announced today a major reorganization designed to clear up a huge backlog of job discrimination complaints and speed processing of new cases.

title: N.A.S.L. Sets Record With 2.5 Million Fans
description: The North American Soccer League has set a season attendance record, passing the 2.5 million mark with three weeks of play remaining.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Letters From Home
description: ONE of my goals for this summer is to catch up on my sleep. This has been one of my goals for so long that I estimate that I am now behind on my sleep by six years. When I was a teenager I slept later in the morning than my parents thought was either neccessary or befiting the Protestant ethic. They assured me that the body requires less sleep as it gets older and that I world outgrow the need. Next month my father will be Sowhich must ?? that I am getting olderand I'm still waiting.

title: Advertising
description: Consumers love centsoff coupons.

title: In Case Of Blackout Light Up,
description: LIKE most other big stores, Hammacher Schlemmer (147 East 57th Street) was closed to customers the day following the big blackout. But for buyers and executives, it was business almost as usual. Nothing could be done about the heat, but considerable illumination was provided by the array of nonelectric lighting devices that are one of the store's specialities.

title: Kentucky Jury Convicts 3 in Deep Throat Trial
description: COVINGTON, Ky., July 20 (UPI)A Federal court jury found three men guilty today of interstate transportation of obscene material and conspiracy in connection with showing the movie Deep Throat at a neighboring Newport, Ky., theater more than four years ago.

title: Letters
description: To THE HOME SECTION:

title: JUDGE STAYS STATE ORDER TO CLOSE CLAM BEDS OFF L.I.
description: A temporary stay was issued yesterday against moves by the State Department of Environmental Conservation to close 2,600 acres of Suffolk County clam beds lying in polluted water.

title: Yachting
description: 79th LARCHMONT RACE WEEK Fifth Day (Third and Final Junior Day) Fireball Class, Division 1 (sail numbers anding in digits 1, 2, 7 and 8) (2B started)1, Pede Dickey, Indian Harbor (116)3 points; 2 Jeff Doughty, Port Washington (327)14; 3, Jim Johannessen, Norwalk Shore and C. C. (862)16.

title: HOWARD FRENCH
description: MIAMI, July 20, (UPI)Howard French, listed as the world's oldest commercial pilot and the holder of a flight certificate signed by Orville Wright, died yesterday at a nursing home here. He was 92 years old.

title: House Unit Votes 4Cent Rise in Federal Gasoline Tax
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The House Ad Hoc Energy Committee approved tonight a 4centpergallon gasoline tax to take effect in two stages beginning in January. The vote, 22 to 18, sends the proposal to the full House of Representatives, where its fate is uncertain

title: Proposals Would Permit Doctors To Advertise Services in Press
description: ALBANY, July 20 (UPI)Doctors and other professionals would he permitted to advertise in newspapers or other outlets under proposed regulations released today by the state Board of Regents.

title: City Announces Strict NoParking PlanThen a Modified Version
description: New York City detailed yesterday how it would ban most onstreet parking in Manhattan below 59th Street by Sept. 14 in strict compliance with a courtordered traffic control plan

title: Bruhn Swan Lake Shows Its 10 Years
description: THE PROLIFERATION of Swan Lake is a comparatively recent phenomenon. It is still less than 30 years ago that North America first saw a fullevening Swan Lake, little more than 40, for that matter, since it was first staged outside the Soviet Union. Even the ballet itself in the version we knowis not so old as the vast majority of operas in the current repertory. Yet, like the other two Tchaikovsky classics, The Nutcracker and The Sleeping Beauty, its hold upon the repertory is as viselike as ever.

title: CARTER IS OPTIMISTIC ON GENEVA MEETING AFTER HEARING BEGIN
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter said today he believed, as a result of discussions with Arab leaders, that the views expressed to him by Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel in the last two days would produce a Geneva peace conference on the Middle East as early as October.

title: Millie Joins TipA Capital Event!
description: WASHINGTON TIP AND MILLIE are together again, full time. The odd couple has broken up. The Tuesday to Thursday Club has lost a prominent member. And a lot of Washington marriages have been saved. This is not a compilation of the latest gossip in the capital but simply a status report on a marriage of long standing and the repercussions caused its latest phase.

title: ALCAN ALUMINIUM RAISES EARNINGS IN JUNE QUARTER
description: Alcan Aluminum Ltd., the world's secondlargest aluminum producer, reported yesterday a rebound from its strikeriddled earnings of a year ago.

title: CURBING OF CONGRESSMEN ON BOOKS URGED ON HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)The director of the Library of Congress has proposed new rules to dispose of surplus books as a result of disclosures that Representative Charles J. Carney, Democrat of Ohio, allegedly took almost 82,000 books over the last six years.

title: John W. Finger, a Retired Dealer In Real Estate, Dies at 72 in Queens
description: John W. Finger, a retired realestate financing executive, died yesterday at Astoria (Queens) General Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 960 Park Avenue.

title: Tax Delays Detailed For Blackout Victims
description: ALBANY, July 20 (UPI)State Tax Commissioner James Tully Jr. provided details today of a taxrelief program announced by Governor Carey for merchants victimized by looting and vandalism in last week's power blackout in New York City.

title: Taxes Going Up in Smoke
description: The vandalizing of four tobacco warehouses during the recent blackout suggests that someone had longterm looting in mind. Whoever broke into the establishments made off with the entire cigarette inventory. More important, the burglars also took the machine that each distributor uses under Government license to imprint New York City and State tax stamps on the packages.

title: Britain's Yarrow Yard Gets Order To Build 4 More Ships for Iran
description: LONDON, July 20 (UPI)The Clyde Yard of Yarrow has received a contract to build four more support ships for the Imperial Iranian Navy, a spokesman for Yarrow said today. The contract is estimated to be worth about $93.5 million.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Front Page 2  No Title

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Piano Trio in B Hat, Haydn; Cantata, Herr, nun lasset du deinen Diener, Bux?ehude; Gorund in A, Gibbons; Entrance of the Gods into Valhalla from Das Rheingold, Wagner; Premier Concert from Pieces de Glavecinen Concert, Rameau.

title: Hester Pushes Plansfor New U.S. Open Site
description: Armed with modified drafts and renderings for the new tennis complex in Flushing Meadow Park, Slew Hester expressed confidence yesterday that the United States Open. would be moved there from Forest Hills in time for next year's championships.

title: New York Researcher Asserts Nuclear Magnetic Technique Can Detect Cancer, but Doubts Are Raised
description: A New York City medical researcher announced yesterday at a news conference that he had developed a new technique for the nonsurgical detection of cancer anywhere in the human body. However, in an interview later in the day, he retracted a contention that he had already used the technique on a cancer patient.

title: A National Canine Program Set for Business Security
description: Pilot projects involved with dogs have long been a specialty with Dick Maller of Island Park, L.I. The trainer now is embarking on a national canine security setup geared to every type of business now using a security man.

title: Reds Call Up 2 Pitchers From Indianapolis Farm
description: CINCINNATI, July 20 (AP)The Cincinnati Reds, hoping to shore up their sagging pitching staff, reached into the ranks of their top farm club at Indianapolis today for two 21yearold righthanders.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: Time2:00 .

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: O.E.C.D. Sees Slow Gains For West in Coming Year
description: PARIS, July 20The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that unemployment would rise and economic growth would slow over the next year in most of the 24 nations that belong to the organization.

title: Charismatic Christians To Meet in Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.,July 20 (AP)Praying, singing, Biblecarrying Americans of many denominations, Protestants and Roman Catholics, will gather here tomorrow for what is described as the biggest ecumenical gathering of charismatic Christians in modern history.

title: Amsterdam News Links Lootings To Vacuum in Black Leadership
description: The New York Amsterdam News, the country's largest black weekly, declares in a page 1 editorial in the issue of July 23, out today, that the recent blackout exposed a massive vacuum in black leadership.

title: Kuwait and Iraq Pull Back Troops
description: KUWAIT, July 20 (Reuters)Iraqi and Kuwaiti troops along the disputed border between the two countries today began withdrawing to prearranged positions under an agreement reached by a joint border commission yesterday, Kuwait Interior Ministry officials said here.

title: Calendar of Events for the Home
description: Some events of interest for enthusiasts of the house and home.

title: Hers
description: MY MOTHER was not a good housekeeper, but fortunately she came to marriage with a dowry of inherited antiques that either hid the dirt or fooled you into thinking that a Huguenot had put it there. When she thought about it at all, she operated on the theory that what is good is clean enough, or could certainly be gotten Lark into shape if she ever had to sell it, and more than once she has dug up petunia patch with a rattail serving spoon and not thought a thing about it.

title: Jackson Denies Knocking Down a Fan
description: Reggie Jackson, the beleaguered Yankee millionaire, denied yesterday that he had knocked down a 13yearold boy he chased outside Yankee Stadium after Tuesday night's AllStar Game

title: Judge's Distaste Worth $141,000 To Coffee Man
description: A jury awarded $141,000 yesterday to a food vendor who had been brought in handcuffs to the chambers of a Suffolk County judge who disliked his coffee.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Jaworski Named To Take Charge Of Korea Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The House ethics committee today chose Leon A. Jaworski, the former Watergate special prosecutor, to take charge of its investigations of Korean influencebuying and help revive public confidence in the inquiry.

title: Federal Drug Agents Arrest Six in Roundup
description: BOSTON, July 20(AP)Starting at a takeout restaurant allegedly offering fish and chips and cocaine, Federal agents struck today at a ring that they said combined the sale of cocaine with traffic in prostitution.

title: TV: Another Magazine Page
description: THE ELECTRONIC  MAGAZINE sweepstakes gets another entry tonight at 10 on ABCTV. This one is called ABC News Closeup: On Camera. William Peters is the senior producer. Peter Jennings and Sandy Hill are the hosts and chief correspondents. And the content is exceedingly dull.

title: Four Agencies Vying For Kentucky Fried
description: Kentucky Fried Chicken, whose advertising account has replaced Datsun's as a focus of Madison Avenue interest, has selected the four finalist agencis Ted Bates & Company: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn: Cunningham & Walsh and Young & Rubicam.

title: People and Business
description: Christian de Guigne 3d will step down as chairman of the Stauffer Chemical Company of Westport, Conn., on reaching the mandatory retirement age of 65 next month, it was announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by H. Barclay Morley, the company's president and chief executive officer.

title: It's Captive Nations Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (Reuters)President Carter today proclaimed this week as Captive Nations Week and asked Americans to demonstrate their support for peoples seeking national independence, liberty and human rights. His action was based on a resolution adopted by Congress in 1959 asking the President to designate the third week in July as Captive Nations Week to emphasize disapproval of the Soviet Union's takeover of the Baltic states and the emergence of Communist governments in Eastern Europe, China, Cuba, North Korea and North Vietnam.

title: Courageous Beaten Twice in Trials
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 20Waiting for Enterprise to do something spectacular at the America's Cup trials ended today when the most expensive yacht in the 107year history of this competition twice trounced Courageous and evened some sore scores.

title: Conferees Back Veto Over Bomb
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)House and Senate conferees agreed today to give Congress a veto over any Presidential decision to proceed with development of the neutron bomb. The conferees accepted a provision adopted by the Senate under which President Carter could not spend funds on the bomb if both the House and Senate voted to overrule his decision within 45 days. President Carter has not made a final decision on the bomb, but has asked Congress to provide the funds.

title: Alabama Will Get U.S. Aid
description: WASHINGTON,July 20 (AP)President Carter declared a drought emergency today for Alabama, making the hardest hit sections of the state eligible for Federal assistance. The aid will be distributed in 26 counties by the Agriculture Department to help livestock producers maintain foundation herds. The prolonged dry spell has dried out pastures. Gov. George C. Wallace had sought the aid for his state.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JULY 21, 1977

title: Jury Begins Deliberating in Trial Of 12 Hanafi Moslems in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 20A jury of 10 women and two men begin deliberations late today in the trial of 12 Hanafi Moslems accused in the takeover of three buildings here in March.

title: CONGRESSIONAL UNIT SEEKS S.E.C. FISCAL DATA ON CITY
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The completed Securities and Exchange Commission draft report on New York City's fiscal crisis has been requested by a Congressional subcommittee.

title: Yazoo City, Which Carter Will Visit, Looks to Past and Future
description: YAZOO CITY, Miss., July 20Confederate monuments are as inevitable as magnolias or mosquitoes in Missisippi Delta towns.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter said he believed that, as a result of his earlier discussion with Arab leaders, the views of Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel would produce a Middle East peace conference in Geneva as early as October. A few hours later Mr. Begin made public his plan for the Geneva talks, excluding the Palestine Liberation Organization. Since all Arab countries insist on P.L.O. participation, this raised questions about the likelihood of an early conference. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: U.S. Blackout Aid Put at $5 Million
description: At least $5 million and probably more in Federal grants will be made available for New York City to recover from the arson and the looting that accompanied the July 13 electric power blackout, various sources in the city and Washington said yesterday.

title: Two Share Lead at 145 In Men's State Amateur
description: VOORHEESVILLE, N.Y., July 20 (AP) Greg Harden of McConnellsville and Rich Serian of Troy were tied for the lead with 145 scores after 36 holes in the state men's amateur golf tournament today.

title: Carter's Broken Lance
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Jimmy Carter is trying to sell the Senate a dubious bill of goods about his longtime friend, Office of Management and Budget Director Bert Lance.

title: C.I.A. Data Show 14Year Project On Controlling Human Behavior
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Central Intelligence Agency conducted a 14year program to find ways to control human behavior through the use of chemical, biological and radiological material, according to agency documents made public today by John Marks, a freelance journalist.

title: Dave Anderson
description: For one moment, one swing, it was a game, but Ron Fairly got around too quickly on Torn Seaver's slider and his drive down the rightfield line at Yankee Stadium curved foul. Had it been a home run, the American League would have had a 65 lead as well as its honor restored. But then Torn Seaver struck out Ron Fairly on a fast ball that ran away from the Toronto Blue Jays venerable dh, as the Cincinnati Reds noble righthander would explain later.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, July 20Veniamin G. Le vich, a Jewish scientist who has beer barred from emigrating was questioned today for eight hours by the K.G.B., the security police, about his relations with Anatoly Shcharansky, a Jewish activist expected to stand trial for treason.

title: U.S. Envoy Calls Proposed Regulations on Ocean Mining Unacceptable
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20Elliot L. Richardson, the chief American negotiator at the Law of the Sea Conference, charged today that a handful people had devised proposals for regulating deep seabed mining that were fundamentally unacceptable to the United States.

title: In This Theater
description: MINNEAPOLIS

title: U.S. Allows Italian Communist Paper to Open Bureau
description: ROME, July 20The United States Government has decided to allow L'Unita, the official newspaper of the Italian Communist Party, to open d. news bureau in the United States for the first time.

title: COLUMBIA AND U.S. SUE CITY OVER ATOM REACTOR
description: Columbia University and the Federal Government sued New York City yesterday, seeking to overcome the city's refusal to permit the operation of a small nuclear reactor on Columbia's Morningside Heights campus.

title: Fire Aboard Destroyer Injures 6
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 21 (AP)Six crewmen suffered minor injuries in a fire aboard the U.S.S. Direct, a minesweeper on her way to Boston, the Navy announced today. A spokesman said a fire that began about 10 A.M. yesterday was extinguished about 12:15 P.M., but reignited in the afternoon, slightly injuring four crewmen from the Direct and two crewmen from the U.S.S. Neuman Perry, a destroyer that had come to the Direct's aid.

title: Antiques
description: NOBODY KNOWS how many antiques shops and galleries there are in Manhattan. But the acreage is astounding, and new ones appear weekly. In recent months, at least four of some distinction have opened on the Upper East Side. And, as is usually the case, each has a stock shaped by its owner's tastes.

title: In Memoriam
description: RANNIEGeorge. Sadly missed by his family. Passed away 10 years today.

title: CARTER BIDS SOVIET LIMIT BIG MISSILES IN RESPONSE TO U.S.
description: CHARLESTON S. C., July 21President Carter told the Soviet Union today that the United States was prepared to limit its strategic weapons programs, such as the development of the cruise missile, if Moscow would agree to controls on its heavy intercontinental missiles.

title: Europeans, Wary About Future, Step Up Pace of Investing in U.S.
description: Fears in Western Europe of possible economic deterioration and radical change apparently have given new impetus to the flow of investments into the United States.

title: Market Place
description: While Wall Street has focused on the siliconchip microcomputer and its manufacturers, relatively little attention has been directed toward the makers of a different chip, that harnesses the microcomputer to nonnumerical measuring devices.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: 50,000 L. I. Bathers Driven From Shore By Sewage Debris
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 21The presence of sewage near the shore today forced 50,000 bathers seeking relief from the hottest day of the year to leave the cooling waters at Nassau County and Town of Hempstead beaches.

title: Photography: American Classic
description: NATURE was once a wordand an ideathat artists in every esthetic field invoked with terrific loyalty, pride and passion. To be inspired by nature seemed almost a guarantee of honesty and virtue. For nature served such artists (or so it seemed, anyway) as both a model and a guidea subject matter to which they could always return and a spiritual ideal that would never fail to nourish them. Above all. it was taken as a defense against the artificial, protecting art from mere contrivance and artiness. Such, at least, was once the strongly held belief.

title: Europeans See Currency Shifts In Dollar's Fall
description: PARIS, July 21Many European bankers and monetary officials are now saying that the dollar's sharp fall in value on foreign exchange markets may signal the opening of a new period of currency unrest, after the relative tranquillity of recent months.

title: DR. WILLIAM CHOMSKY, 81, HEBREW GRAMMARIAN, DIES
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP)Dr. William Chomsky, one of the world's foremost Hebrew grammarians, died Tuesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 81 years old.

title: People and Business
description: Takashi Ishihara, president of the Nissan Motors Company, Japan's second largest auto maker (after. Toyota), said yesterday at a news conference in Nagoya that his company had sounded out the possibility of establishing an assembly plant in the United States.

title: Fire at Camp Kills Man, 90
description: WELD, Mc., July 21 (AP)  One person has died and three were injured in a fire yesterday at Kamp Kawanhee. a summer camp for boys. A camp official identified the dead man as 90yearold George R. Frank of Columbus, Ohio, who was one of the original owners of Kamp Kawanhee.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Tickets for the National Ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, are $6 to $15 at the box office or through Center Charge: 8746770. Information: 7994420.

title: BEAME PRAISES RAID ON A LOOTING CACHE
description: Mayor Beanie and Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd went to an Upper West Side precinct station yesterday to congratulate four detectives for their part in a raid Wednesday night on an alleged fencing operation that netted what the Mayor said was the largest police recovery so far of stolen property apparently looted in last week's blackout.

title: Three New Types of Memberships Approved by Brokers on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that member brokers voted, by 715 to 454, to create three new types of memberships to widen access to the exchange. For a $25.000 annual fee, brokers gain admittance to the trading floor and set up facilities. Electronic access now will be available to brokers for $13,500 a year.

title: PRESSURES ARE EASED ON U.S. MONEY SUPPLY
description: Moneymarket temperatures moderated late yesterday afternoon when the Federal Reserve reported a decline of $1.7 billion in the nation's money supply in the week ended July 13.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Thursday, July 21, 1977

title: High on Big Board Short Interest Is at 32.3 Million Shares in Month
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the short interest rose 2,735,081 shares to 32,290,212 shares in the month ended July 15, setting a new high. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 24,225,588 shares.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post Positions

title: R. W. Stock, Times Travel Editor, Moving to BusinessFinance News
description: Robert W. Stock, editor of the Sunday Travel section of The New York Times, will become an assistant business and financial editor responsible for the Sunday Business and Finance section, it was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Concert Royal No. 4, Couperin; Grande Duo Coneertant e on Robert le Diable, Chopin; Mencut Antique, Ravel; Dance Music of the High Baroque. Various.

title: Ray P. Whitman, Aviation Pioneer And a Founder of Bell Aircraft
description: BUFFALO, July 21 (AP)Ray P. Whitman, an aviation pioneer and the last surviving founder of the Bell Aircraft Corporation, now the Bell Aerospace Company, died Thursday at the age of 83 in his suburban Williamsville home. He was a native of Washington, D.C., and was associated with American military aviation almost from its start, before World War I.

title: Soybeans Futures Prices Advance
description: CHICAGO, July 22 (AP)Limited advances in nearby soybean oil deliveries bolstered prices, enabling soybeans to close firmly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade today..

title: Atkinson's Case Goes to the Jury
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 21George Atkinson's libel suit against Chuck Noll and the Pittsburgh Steelers will go to She sixperson jury tomorrow morning, as attorneys for both sides completed their final arguments today.

title: Guide to Additives Published
description: Because of the demand by consumers for information on chemical additives in food, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs has published a blooklet, The Consumer Guide to Food Additives.

title: Music: Urbane Jazz Trio ,TaylorMade
description: Billy Taylor, who is appearing at Storyville through Sunday with his trio, seems wholly unaffected by the violent change that overtook jazz in the 1960's. He is still the urbane, essentially conservative, Bud Powellrooted pianist who led similar trios around New York 20 years ago.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: 10 Major New York Banks (Selected balance sheet items in millions of dollars: Wednesday figures)

title: JAWORSKI PROMISES FIRM KOREA INQUIRY
description: HOUSTON, July 21Asserting that he despised crooks of any political stripe, Leon A. Jaworski vowed today to investigate allegations of wrongdoing by Democratic Congressmen as vigorously as he pursued White House Republicans in the Watergate affair.

title: Carter's Record Assailed by Head Of Urban League
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Vernon Jordan, executive director of the National Urban League, who is one of the black leaders closest to President Carter, says that the Carter Administration has fallen short on policies, programs and people.

title: June's Consumer Prices Up 0.6% In U.S. and 0.9% in New York Area
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  Consumer prices rose in June by sixtenths of 1 percent with food, services and sundry, other retail items continuing to climb, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The rise in the Consumer Price Index was just equal to May's less than the full 1 percent surge that occurred in February and considerably more than the Monthly advances of threetenths of 1 percent in the second half of 1976.

title: Deaths
description: ARNDTNola. We record with deep sorrow the death of our beloved Member and Colleague Nola Arndt in New York City on July 19, 1977.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Spirits Owner Sues Nets
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 21 (UPI) Ozzie Silna, who was a coowner of the Spirits of St. Louis of the American Basketball Association, charged today that the New York Nets. who are trying to move to New Jersey, had given the Spirits a first option on a National Basketball Association franchise there. Silna filed suit in State Supreme Court in Mineola to enjoin the Nets, now of the N.B.A., from moving to New Jersey without first offering the Spirits an opportunity for a New Jersey franchise.

title: Begin Says That Everything Is Open for Discussion
description: Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel said of his controversial Middle East peace proposals yesterday that everything is open for discussion.

title: 104 in New York Ties for 2d Hottest
description: New York City suffered through a blistering 104 degrees yesterday  the secondhighest temperature ever recorded here  with wilting discomfort but no disaster.

title: Trevino's 67 Shows Way By Shot in Canadian Open
description: OAKVILLE, Ontario, July 21Jack Nicklaus has had four secondplace finishes in the Canadian open, one third and two fifths, but he has never won. And his little joke is that he would have to create his own golf course to make it possible to win the Canadian.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Troubles Multiply for Nazi Leader in Chicago Suburb
description: CHICAGO, July 21Frank Collin, the fuehrer of the National Socialist Party of America, is troubled these days.

title: Charismatic Christians Seek to Infuse the Faith With Their Joyous Spirit
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 21Shouts of Hallelujah! and Praise the Lord! resound through cavernous convention halls as thousands of jubilant Christians cast arms and eyes upward. Many wear fixed, faraway stares and others gently sway as they sing such hymns as Come Holy Ghost.

title: Restaurants
description: W???? SO MUCH ATTENTION being paid nowadays to the Mandarin, Shanghai, Szechw?n and Hunan kitchens of northern China, the food of the southern province o. anton is all too often accorded short shrift. Yet the wide variety of that cuisine, along with itssubtly enticing and soulsoothing flavor and textural counterpoints, makes it one of China's most popular and satisfying, even among the Chinese themselves.

title: Notes on People
description: Mavis Eletha Finch, widow of the actor, Peter Finch, has been appointed administrator of his estate by a Los Angeles court. She will have the power to gather the estate's assets, estimated at $115,000, and pay creditors. Meanwhile, her attorney Eugene Goodwin, told the court that Mr. Finch's London attorney had refused to turn over the actor's will, made in 1965, which left the estate to Mr. Finch's mother and three children by a previous marriage. Mr. Goodwin, in trying to upset the will, maintains that an 1837 English law holds that a man's marriage invalidates previous wills. If the will is invalidated, Mr. Goodwin would then try to establish that Mr. Finch, a Beverly Hills resident when he died last January, left no legal will ad, under California law, his widow would be entitled to half the estate.

title: City Does Much Business With Just a Few Appraisers
description: Three realestate appraisers who share office space have received more than $1 million in fees in the last three years by acting as expert witnesses for the city in tax assessment cases, according to a study prepared by Assemblyman Charles Schumer, chairman of the Assembly Subcommittee on City Management.

title: Weekly Retail Store Sales Up 12%
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Department of Commerce reported today that total weekly retail stores sales in the latest week was an estimated $14.05 billion, up 12 percent from the yearearlier $12.59 billion. Department stores sales were about $1.32 billion, up 13 percent from last year's $1.18 billion.

title: 3 CROATS ARE GIVEN 30YEAR SENTENCES
description: Three of five Croatian nationalists who hijacked a Trans World Airlines passenger jet last Sept. 10 were sentenced in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to 30year terms for air piracy and conspiracy.

title: Don't Forget Summer Stock Right in Our Own Backyard
description: Take a bigcity neighborhood an hour or so from Broadway and a community college with an idle auditorium and a strong commitment to the arts. Stir in a couple of persuasive directors. In Bayside, Queens, this adds up to the QCC (for Queensborough Community College) Theater Company, which is billing itself as the only Equity stock company in the city this summer.

title: At the Movies
description: Now that Tatum O'Neal is 13 years old, she's been giving marriage some serious thought and has decided to take the plungebut only in her next movie, and then not until the final fadeout. This cinematic thunderbolt will be the climax of International Velvet, MGM's absurdly tardy sequel to the 1944 classic National Velvet, in which a glowing teenager named Elizabeth Taylor galloped to triumph in the Grand National. Bryan Forbes, the director and author of International Velvet, is betting that he can coax Miss Taylor into playing the middleaged Velvet, a kindly soul who takes her orphaned niece from Arizona under her wing and out to the stable. The odds are not in Mr. Forbes's favor, however, because the newly married actress balks at the idea of abandoning home and hearth in time for the September filming in England. Anthony Hopkins, on the other hand, is already in the saddle as the spirited trainer who spurs timid Tatumpresumably on to victoryfirst as a member of the British Equestrian Team and then as a formidable competitor in the Olympics.

title: Along the StrawHat Trail
description: THE OLD DOORDIE, idealistic school of summertheater apprenticeshipovernight discovery on the legendary strawhat circuitis as faded as that old Judy Garland movie, Summer Stock. These days, if a star breaks a leg, another star is quickly hired to take her placeor the entire tour is canceled. Summer theater is now big business. Shows are prepackaged in New York, marked commercially digestible and shipped on a road tour of maior summer theaters.

title: Youmans Revival
description: HIT THE DECK, music by Vincent Youmans; book by Herbert Fields; lyrics by Leo Robin, Clifford Grey, Irving Caesar, Oscar Hammerstein 2d; assistant con. ductor and orchestrator. Russell Warner; setting by Herbert Fields; lyrics by Leo Robin, Clifford Grey, John Lee Beatty; costumes by David Toser; lighting by Peter M. Ehrhardt; special consultant, Alfred Simon; production stage manager, Peggy Peterson; technical director, Jim Crossley; musical direction by Lynn Crigiers directed and choreographed by Dan Siretta. Presented by the Goodspeed Opera House. Michael P. price, producer. At ???? Hadoam, conn.

title: TimeLife Buys Susskind TV Company
description: David Susskind's successful 25yearold television producing company, Talent Associates Ltd., has been purchased by TimeLife Films for Time Inc. stock reportedly valued at about $3 million.

title: Carey Approves Coop City Pact
description: Governor Carey gave final approval yesterday to an agreement that requires Coop City residents to pay an average of 20 percent more in their monthly maintenance charges and increase their equity though additional payments to the huge Bronx development.

title: OldFashioned White House Picnic
description: WASHINGTON, July 21As members of Congress cheered him on, a shirtsleeved President Carter did a bit of fancy squaredancing on the White House lawn at dusk last night.

title: The Standings
description: Friday, July 22, 1977

title: U.S. Foilsmen Eliminated
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 21 (Reuters)Italy beat the United States, 92, today to qualify for the semifinals of the men's team foil event at the world fencing championships. The Soviet Union, Poland and West Germany also qualified.

title: Screen: A Chaplin From Germany
description: THE MORNING IS SOUR and dark. Ferdinand Rieche, a security policeman demoted for overzealousness, is having breakfast. With a mournaful countenance, a prominent nose and a face that resembles both mousetrap and mouse, he devours raisin cake. The radio announces a tropical storm approaching Wiesbaden.

title: F.B.I. Candidate Oversaw Disputed 75 Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 21An official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who is being considered for head of the bureau oversaw an internal investigation of possible corruption in the bureau in 1975 that was rejected as incomplete by Edward H. Levi, then Attorney General, and was characterized privately as a whitewash by several Justice Department officials.

title: Rock: Musical Misogyny
description: Darryl Rhoades and the HaHavishnu Orchestra, a troupe of rock parodists from. Atlanta, have settled into the Other End for a 10night run. Although they have yet to record, their reputation has preceded them, and with songs like Leprosy Queen, Shaft on Welfare, and You're So Impotent in their repertory, they live up to heir advance billing as a band that is trying to offend almost everyone.

title: One Who Broke Down the Barriers Formed by Poverty and Isolation
description: Everything's going smoothly. Soon he'll be off to Princeton on a scholarship, after some stunning years at Collegiateeditor of the paper, member of student government, pitcher on the baseball team, remarkable student. You get the picture.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: Amid concern that consumer spending, which has powered the economy forward for the last 28 months, may soon slow down, the upturn is getting new impetus from a littlenoticed source: invigorated government spending at all levels. The emergence of this new thrust has received scant attention because the economy is still moving spiritedly ahead due to the large consumer outlays for autos, housing and other goods and services. Another factor has been the problem of projecting. Federal expenditures during baffling budget underruns and predicting the spending of many state and local governments until recently in a severe financial bind.

title: New Jersey Judge Gives Donor of Sperm the Right Of Visits to Woman's Son
description: BRIDGETON, N.J., July 21Despite strenuous objections by the unmarried mother, the donor of the sperm she used to conceive a son was granted the right today to visit the child.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK;
description: ART (GR 37014) Fri. Sat. Merchant of Four Seasons 1.4:25, 7:50,11:20; Every Man For Himself &God Against All 2:35, 6, 9:25. Sun. Merchant 3:05,6:30,10: Man 1.15,4:40, 8:05

title: Jaworski Post: Image Problem Alleviated
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Putting Leon A. Jaworski in charge of the House ethics committee investigation of Korean influence buying appears to solve the committee's immediate problem of public skepticism, at least for the time being.

title: First of Oil Reserve Stored in Cavern
description: WEST HACKBERRY, La., July 21The first of what will eventually be a billionbarrel reserve of oil flowed into an enormous cavern here today.

title: CAMBODIANS BATTLE THAIS ALONG BORDER
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 21Heavily armed Thai and Cambodian troops fought a battle across their border today, the first since the Communists assumed power in Cambodia more than two years ago.

title: Advertisements by Professionals Expected to Be Allowed by Regents
description: ALBANY, July 21Physicians and other professionals would be permitted to advertise in newspapers and magazinesin some cases, to list the prices of their servicesunder regulations expected to be adopted by the New York State Board of Regents next week.

title: Independence Comes Close But Courageous Wins 2
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 21Newport, a hospitable town, put on the dog today for the Swedish contingent of 60 who have come here hoping to capture the America's Cup in September. Their handsome 12Meter yacht, Sverige, was paraded through the harbor with her color signal flags flying from her mast and then the crew, smartly dressed in blue blazers and white pants, marched six blocks from Long Wharf uptown into Washington Square for a ceremony of welcome at the 200yearold Old Colony House, an impressive brick edifice.

title: TheftDamage Cost in Blackout Put at $135 Million Out of Total Business Loss in  Hundreds of Millions
description: New York City officials estimate that the July 1314 blackout cost businesses $135 million to $150 million in theft and other property damage out of a total bill in the hundreds of millions of dollars, including a generally lost work day.

title: Ghosts of TV Screen (And Radio) Find a Home
description: Return with us now to those thrilling days of yesteryear: The Lone Rangrides again.

title: 3 TeenAgers Killed in Crash
description: NEW TRIPOLI, Pa., July 21 (AP)Three Lehigh County teenagers were killed and two others were critically injured last night when their car missed a turn and rammed a mountain bridge west of here, the police said. The victims were identified as Roger R. Evans Jr., Clifford C. Hankee, and Daniel Yenser, the driver of the car. All were 16 years old and from Slattington, the police said.

title: Circus Performer Hurt in Fall
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21 (AP)Daniel Acosta, 30 years old, a highwire performer, fell 40 feet and landed on an usher at a circus performance last night as many of the 13,000 in the audience screamed. Mr. Acosta, who suffered an elbow fracture , rib cracks and a spleen rupture, was in serious condition today. The usher's back was injured.

title: Dazzling Dane Among Canadians
description: Ballet's latest heartthrob is Peter Schaufuss, a Danish dancer with a sensational technique and a special romantic fervor, who will appear as guest star in Giselle tomorrow at 2 P.M. with the National Ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Judge in Bridgeton Gives Donor of Sperm the Right of Visits to Woman's Son
description: BRIDGETON, July 21Despite strenuous objections by the unmarried mother the donor of the sperm she used to conceive a son was granted the right today to visit the child.

title: Books of The Times
description: ANNE EDWARDS, author of six novels, and now at work on the sequel to Gone With The Wind, added a touch of class to the overcrowded field of Judy Garland biographers a couple of years ago. Now she has taken on another tragic lady of the theater, Vivien Leigh, whose life was perhaps tormented by more demons than Miss Garland's and whose sufferings were more beyond her control. The gum taste and intelligence that prevailed in her Judy Garland book are at work here; with even more satisfying effect.

title: Egypt and Jordan Likely to Seek Geneva Talk Despite Begin Stand
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon,July 21Amid Aran denunciations of the peacetalk proposals of Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel, indications have also appeared that moderates led by Egypt and Jordan want to continue pressing for the reconvening of the Geneva conference on the Middle East.

title: Pill Use Rivaled By Sterilization, Survey Indicates
description: Sterilization now rivals the birth control pill as the leading contraceptive method used by married couples, according to the finding of a newly reported national survey.

title: How to Get There
description: By car, take the Saw Mill River Parkway to the Katonah exit on Route 35. Turn left and proceed west on 35 to the intersection of Route 100. Turn right and take Route 100 four miles north to the Elephant Hotel and the center of Somers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Ballet: Schaufuss Is Exciting in Giselle
description: THERE ARE at least two Peter Schaufusses; they might be dubbed ego and alterego. The Peter Schaufuss New York knows best is the selfeffacing principal dancer of New York City Ballet, the impeccable exponent of such Balanchine roles as the leads in Raymonda Variations or Scotch Symphony. Yet the Danish star does have a quite different persona, best known in Europe, as a classic ballet prince, the hero of Giselle, La Sylphide or Swan Lake.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Thursday, July 21, 1977

title: Con Ed Gives $250,000 In Help for Businesses
description: The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday contributed $250,000 to the fund to help small businesses damaged by looting and arson during last week's blackout.

title: CAMBODIANS BATTLE THAIS ALONG BORDER
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 21Heavily armed Thai and Cambodian troops fought a battle across their border today, the first since the Communists assumed power in Cambodia more than two years ago.

title: House Votes a $2.90 Wheat Subsidy
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Despite objections of the Carter Administration that it would add millions to the cost of farm supports, the House set the 1977 wheat subsidy at $2.90 a bushel today.

title: What's Playing on the Circuit
description: A guide to what's doing on the strawhat circuit in neighboring regions:

title: American Motors Announces a Profit
description: DETROIT, July 21The American Motors Corporation, continuing to show signs of emerging from its financial crisis, today reported a profit for its third fiscal quarter, ended June 30, of $1.6 million, or 6 cents a share, on sales of $580 million. That was in contrast to a yearearlier loss of $3.9 million, on sales of $602 million.

title: LANCE PUTS AN AIDE IN CHARGE OF BANKING
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The National Bank of Georgia established a correspondent banking relationship with the First National Bank of Chicago shortly before the Chicago bank granted Bert Lance, then the Georgia bank's chief executive officer and now President Carter's budget director, a $3.4 million personal loan, a spokesman for Mr. Lance confirmed tonight.

title: Car Insurers Ask NoFault Limit, With $50,000 on Medical Claims
description: TRENTON, July 21Spokesmen for the insurance industry called today for changes in the state's nofault automobile insurance law that would place a $50,000 limit on medical payments for accident victims and eliminate the ability of a person to sue for pain and suffering.

title: About Real Estate
description: Predictably, the issue of Federal preemption of local rent controls has been injected into the New York mayoral campaign. Not to be outshone by Bella S. Abzug, a mayoral challenger, Mayor Beame used his time in Washington the other day to approach officials of the Department of Housing and Urban Development on behalf of the residents of Lincoln Towers in Manhattan, one of the candidates for preemption. Mrs. Abzug had been there first.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Mary, Mary will be performed tonight at 8, tomorrow at 7 and 10 P.M. and Sunday at 4 and 8. Tickets are $4, $5, $6, tonight and tomorrow; $3, $4, $5 on Sunday. Jacques Brel begins Wednesday and runs through Aug. 7. Plaza Suite runs Aug. 10 through Aug. 21. There are no performances Mondays. Box office: 6316311. information: 6316295.

title: Events and Openings
description: Music

title: CARTER LINKS LOOTING TO LONGTIME NEGLECT
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  President Carter described last week's looting in the New York City blackout as an additional indication of the need to channel Federal programs for housing, health, education and jobs opportunities to rundown urban areas neglected too long.

title: ATTACK BY LIBYANS BLOCKED AT BORDER, EGYPTIANS REPORT
description: CAIRO, July 21Egypt reported a major border clash today with Libya, saying that the Libyans had carried out an armored and aerial attack across the border but that they had been beaten back with the loss of 40 tanks and two planes.

title: Dance: Joan Miller
description: Going against the strong historical pattern in which modern dancers form companies around themselves as leading performers, Joan Miller has decided to reform hers around the role of artistic director. The resultant programpart of the Clark Center Dance Festival at the City University Graduate Center Mall on Thursday eveningwas a transitional one reflecting a mixture of dance, music and dramatic recitation. It had flashes here and there, but lacked a feeling of unified identity.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: They are being called the invulnerable children because, despite the most stressful lives, they don't break down. In fact, they thrive, even thoughtheir parents may be deranged, even though they may live in poverty or have suffered profound bereavement and pain. They do well in school, take on roles of leadership, succeed where they would have been expected to fail.

title: T.W.A. Net Off; 2.3% Drop Tied To Labor Costs
description: Trans World Airlines Inc., blaming higher labor costs, reported yesterday that its secondquarter net income had slipped by 2.3 percent.

title: Legion, Meeting In Pittsburgh, Recalls the Past
description: PITTSBURGH, July 21A fourman honor guard halfstepped through the dimly lit ballroom of the Pittsburgh Hilton last night, stacked four rifles on the stage and draped an American Legion cap over the weapons muzzles.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY,JULY 22, 1977

title: Murphy Gives His All to Make Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 21When you're 24 years old and your unemployment insurance has run out and the only place left to go is back to East New York in Brooklyn, you don't permit heat prostration to get in the way of a trial with the New York Jets.

title: Reverts to Human Rights Theme
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 21President Carter reverted to the human rights theme as he defended his position in addressing a crowd on his arrival here from Charleston, S.C.

title: Art: Crispo Shows an American Album
description: GOING TO A house miscellany in a goodsize dealers gallery is like leafing through the family album of an old but fallible friend. Whatever can he have seen in her? we say as we turn a certain page. How well assorted they look! we say of a couple long since divorced. And when a future Nobel Prize winner turns up in a group of sunburned vacationers we remember how few of us foresaw his potential. Hindsight gives poignancy to ancient images.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday. July 21, 1077

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: (Some of Major Corporations Reporting Yesterday)

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon July 21 (AP)Palestinian guerrillas have agreed to an unconditional ceasefire in their conflict with Israelibacked Lebanese Christians in southern Lebanon, the Palestinians announced today.

title: Publishing: Joys of Rewriting
description: NEW YORK may not know it, but it has a quiet booster in Joyce Carol Oates. The prizewinning novelist and shortstory writer is giving a course this summer in creative writing at New York University. And what is a writer who can surely pick and choose doing, in our town in the summer, when even the most loyal inhabitant will grant that the city is not at its best. The answer is that Miss Oates and her husband, Raymond Smith, love the place.

title: 4 HELD FOR ALTERING: NAMES ON WATCHES
description: An attempt by a peddler to sell fake Omega and Seiko watches to an investigator with the Manhattan District Attorney's office two weeks ago led to the arrest of four men yesterday.

title: 9Day Heat Wave Compounds Water Problem in Glen Cove, L.I.
description: GLEN COVE, LI., July 21At the lowincome housing development, people were walking around with wet towels around their necks or foreheads. Homeowners in the estate area feared property damage because of a ban on lawn sprinkling. One family was fretting because the city had refused it a permit for a swimming pool. At the local car wash, water used to wash one car was being recycled through a filter system for use on the next car.

title: Yanks Lose, 54, in 10th After 70 Victory
description: After laughing their way to a 70 victory behind Catfish Hunter in the first game of a doubleheader with the Milwaukee Brewers, yesterday, the Yankees saw the second contest turn into anything but a laugh as they lost, 54, in 10 innings.

title: Excerpts From the Address by President Carter on Relations With Soviet Union
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., July 21Following are excerpts from the text of President Carter's address here today to the Southern Legislative Conference:

title: TV WEEKEND
description: ACIRCUS may not be the alternate summer diversion. Merely watching all that energy can be enervating. But CBS has two hours of The World Famous Moscow Circus on tape and will be offering the first half tonight at 8 o'clock with William Conrad as the host. (The second hour, overseen by Shirley Jones, goes on next Friday.) At least, unlike NBC, which won the bidding to carry the 1980 Moscow Olympics, CBS cannot be easily accused of ulterior motives for carrying a production of the Soviet Union's state committee for radio and television. Perhaps for ideological dilution, the program was made in association with Teleglob A.G. and the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Texaco and Indiana Standard Have 2dPeriod Gains
description: Increased profits were posted by two leading oil producers, the first in the industry to announce midyear results. Texaco Inc., the nation's second largest, after the Exxon Corporation, realized an 18.4 percent rise in the second quarter and 13.1 percent in the halfyear. The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) had profit increases of 7.2 percent for the quarter and 10.7 percent for the six months.

title: Free Market on the Stock Market
description: When the members of the New York Stock Exchange first met under the buttonwood tree in 1792, they agreed in gentlemanly fashion to fix a standard commission on the sales of stocks. Those fixed rates are now gone, by Government fiat, bringing sweeping changes to Wall Street. And the further restructuring of the securities industry decreed by Congress and the Securities and Exchange Commission will be virtually completed within a few months. Next January, if the S.E.C. schedule holds, members of the New York Stock Exchange will be able to buy and sell Big Board stocks anywhere, without taking the orders to the exchange floor. These changes follow the legal mandate to create a national and freely competitive market, in place of the quasimonopoly that lasted for nearly two centuries.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: WESTON WINDFALL

title: Beyond the Begin Visit
description: Perhaps the best to be expected from the three days of talks in Washington between President Carter and Israel's new Prime Minister, Menahem Begin, was that they would get on well together. Personal relationships count for much in the delicate diplomacy of the Middle East, particularly in IsraeliAmerican relations. That the two heads of government laid a foundation for mutual confidence was no small achievement.

title: Britain's New Envoy Flies to U.S.
description: LONDON, July 21Peter Jay, Prime Minister James Callagniin's soninlaw. flew to Washington today to take up his appointment as ambassador to the United States, but not without setting off yet another controversy.

title: Xerox Net Up 10.2% For 3 Months
description: Despite increasing competition, the Xerox Corporation yesterday reported a 10.2 percent gain in secondquarter net income and an 11 percent gain for the first half.

title: June's Consumer Prices Up 0.6% In U.S. and 0.9% in New York Area
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  Consumer prices rose in June by sixtenths of 1 percent with food, services and sundry other retail items continuing to climb, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The rise in the Consumer Price Index was just equal to May's, less than the full 1 percent surge that occurred in February and considerably more than the monthly advances of threetenths of 1 percent in the second half of 1976.

title: Rockland U.F.T. Members Scored By Shanker on SchoolPay Stand
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., July 21Some New York City school teachers who live and pay taxes in Rockland County are taking public stands against contract demands of teachers in their local school districts.

title: Mets Are Reunited With Kingman And Then Beaten by Padres in 10th
description: SAN DIEGO July 21For the first time since he and Tom Seaver were traded during the midnight massacre five weeks ago. Dave Kingman was reunited with the New York Metsat 39.000 feet above the Grand Canyon.

title: BANDARANAIKE PARTY BEATEN IN SRI LANKA
description: COLOMBIO, Sri Lanka, Friday, July 22Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike headed for a stunning defeat today in Sri Lanka's national parliamentary elections.

title: Giants Tucker Relishing More Spice in the Offense
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. July 21Bob Tucker looked back in anger today, and it wasn't because Al Dixon was gaining on him.

title: Ludlam's a Success In a Ridiculous Way
description: The busiest actor in New York this weekend is Charles Ludlam, founder, director and artistic inspiration of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company.

title: Congress Sends Carter a Coal StripMining Bill Designed to Assure the Reclamation of Damaged Land
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)Congress today sent to President Carter for his expected quick approval a stripmining bill that is designed to assure reclamation of land damaged by the removal of coal.

title: Broadway
description: JACK LEMMON will be here late next spring in Tribute, a new play by Bernard Slade, who also wrote Same Time, Next Year. Tribute will be directed by Arthur Storch and produced by Morton Gottlieb, and it is about a father and his son, age 20, who get together after a long separation. The setting is the chic part of Manhattan, and Mr. Slade is supposed to have been thinking about Mr. Lemmon when he wrote the part of the father. Certainly it does sound like a part for Mr. Lemmon, even if he is not precisely sure why he will do it.

title: Florida Man's Arrest in Secrets Case Stirs Disbelief
description: MIAMI, July 21If Carl had been politically involved, that's one thing, but he doesn't even vote, said Dorothy Heiser, mother of the 33yearold Floridian held by Federal investigators investigating the possibility that her son was a spy.

title: The Pop Life
description: CBGB's unveiled a new sound and media setup this week that could have a telling effect on the Underground rock groups appearing in the club. A brand new sound system is involved, but there are also facilities for live recording, radio broadcasting and making soundtracks for television or film. According to Charlie Martin, stage manager of the Bowery club, CBGB's is negotiating distribution for its own series of recordings, but the facalities will also be available to record companies.

title: Firemen Can't Walk Out
description: GARRISON, N.Y.  It appears that the mayoral candidates are affected by the gooseandthegander mythology, as evidenced by their arguments in the recent righttostrike controversy. All sides are saying that firefighters and policemen are alike, at least in regard to this issue, and that together they should either have or not have the right to strike.

title: Dow Scores Its Fifth Straight Gain
description: Against a market backdrop filled with crosscurrents, the Dow Jones industrial average forged ahead slightly yesterday to post its fifth consecutive gain.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An appeal by New York City's Fire Department to hire 600 more members was granted yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan. In making the appeal, the department cited increases in fires, in casualties of both civilians and firemen, and in costly overtime payments.

title: Who's That? Who's That?
description: Liv Ullmann? Faye Dunaway? Guess again. It's Louise Lasser, formerly Fernwood's own Mary Hartman, trying to leave Kenneth's beauty salon without being observed. Miss Lasser has been making weeklysometimes dailyvisits to her hair stylist in an effort to find just the right look with which to come out from under her Mary Hartman wig. Her hair style changes from day to day, said the salon's owner Kenneth Battelle. She played that role for so long the public still thinks of her that way. Now she's trying to find a look that suits her.

title: Fed Discount Window Stayed Open Later
description: Chalk up another milestone in New York banking history. Thanks to last week's massive power failure, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York kept its discount window open until 8:30 P.M. last Friday to aid banks uncertain of their reserve position as their computers, as well as their lightbulbs, only slowly started working again.

title: Art People
description: WITH NOTHING MORE than a loaded paintbrush, Wayne Thiebaud sets out a luscious buffet of foodstuffs so real you could eat them off the canvas: cold turkey, fish, ham, hors d'oeuvres, sandwiches, salads, cakes, pies, ice cream and allday suckers. And his sharp, dramatically lighted paintings of edibles, people, landscapes, now served up at the Neuberger Museum (part of the State University of New York) in Purchase, reveal him as one of California's liveliest contributions to the current scene.

title: Fire Damages One Floor in Tower In Detroit's Renaissance Center
description: DETROIT, July 21 (AP)Four firemen were overcome by smoke battling a threealarm fire today in an uncompleted 39story office tower in the new $337 million Renaissance Center.

title: Jaworski to the Rescue
description: Once more, Leon Jaworski has been called on to ride up from Texas to rescue a faltering quest for justice. Last time, those summoning himto be the Watergate special prosecutorwere Richard Nixon and Alexander Haig, which made some people skeptical about him. This time, his sponsorship is different. The Democratic leadership of the House wants him to save the floundering investigation of Korean influencepeddling on Capitol Hill. It's not the sponsorship that worries people so much this time round as it is Mr. Jaworski's failure to indict and prosecute Richard Nixon and the suspicion that he had something to do with the pardon.

title: Casino Fire Routs 1,000
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 21 (UPI)Smoke from burning drapes poured into the Lunes Hotel casino yesterday, shutting down gambling, forcing the evacuation of 1,000 persons and interupting work on the Bionic Woman television series. Three persons were hospitalized for smoke inhalation. Others were treated with oxygen at the scene. A Bionic Woman film crew using the casino as a location had to leave. The series star, Lindsay Wagner, was in her room on an upper floor and was not affected.

title: Fishermen Report Water Pollution Along the Coast
description: BRIELLE, July 21Fishermen along the New Jersey shore today reported polluted water running in a ban( along the coast from Sanc:y Hook to Cape May. Their reports were not confirmed by the State or Federal Environmental Protection Agencies.

title: Private Phone Line Resale Cleared; A.T.&T. Ending Telpak Discounts
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit today ended a temporary stay of a Federal Communications Commission order opening the way for unrestricted resale and sharing of privateline leased telephone and telegraph circuits in the United States.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: LONG BEFORE most Americans ever heard of the Big Top, Hachaliah Bailey, an ambitious farmer of the early 1800's, devised a plan to import an elephant to work his land in Somers, N.Y., local legends go. But the elephantnamed Elizabeth, or Old Bet for shortwas slow and clumsy and soon proved to be illsuited for farming. So Bailey hit upon the idea of a traveling menagerie with Old Bet as the star, and Somers thus became the birthplace of the modern circus.

title: West 14th St. Turns Into 3Day Fiesta Espanol
description: There will be flamenco dancers in colorful costumes on 14th Street this weekend, and you can watch them from a sidewalk cafe while sampling tortillas and sangria or join in yourself and dance to the strains of a Latin band.

title: OSANO, ON TRIAL, DENIES INVOLVEMENT IN LOCKHEED
description: TOKYO, July 22Kenji Osano, Japanese hotel executive, pleaded innocent of perjury, denying his involvement in the Lockheed payments scandal at the first hearing of his trial at the Tokyo District Court today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: New Face: Kathleen Quinlan
description: When Kathleen Quinlan was 18 years old, her college diving coach got angry at her. You keep going to rehearsals for Fiddler on the Roof, and you've got a diving meet tomorrow, he said. Which is it going to be, acting or athletics?

title: Memorial for Nabokov Has Its Laughter, Along With Solemnity
description: A memorial service was conducted here yesterday for Vladimir Nabokov, and there were times when the solemn gathering broke upwith laughter.

title: Advertising
description: There was a spate of jokes a while back that required that the question be given in response to the answer.

title: For Children
description: Pere David Deer
