title: Bill to End Mandatory Retirement Of Public Workers Vetoed in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Maine, July 21 (AP)Gov. James B. Longiey has vetoed a bill that would have ended the practice of forcing public employees to retire at a certain age.

title: Bach Mass in Bronxville
description: The Bach mass in B minor, with soloists, chorus and orchestra, will be presented tonight at 8 in. Reisinger Concert Hall at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N.Y. Harold Aks, of the music faculty, will conduct, and students and members of the community will participate. Tickets are $2 at the door. The concert hall is in the Performing Arts Center at the corner of Kimball Avenue and Glen Washington Road.

title: Party Said to Expel Mao's Widow
description: PEKING, July. 21 (Reuters)The socalled Gang of FourMao Tsetung's widow, Chiang Ching, and three other disgraced Chinese leadershave been expelled from the Communist Party, wall posters here announced today.

title: ADMIRAL SAYS CALLS IN U.S.ARE OVERHEARD
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Vice Adm. Bobby R. Inman, head of the National Security Agency, said today that his agency had made what he called Madvertant pickups of the telephone conversations of United States citizens.

title: MADRID PRISON RISING ENDED BY RIOT POLICE
description: MADRID, July 21 (AP)Riot policemen laid a fivehour barrage of smoke grenades and rubber bullets on 500 rebel convicts here today, then burst into Carabanchel Prison and suppressed a fourday mutiny.

title: Mobile Is On Rise  Not That It Was Down
description: MOBILE. Ala.Life has never been quite the same in Mobile since Admiral Farragut damned the torpedoes and forced his Yankee gunboat into the long bay that stretches from here to the Gulf.

title: Galletta and Delich Gain L.I. Golf Final
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., July 21Mal Galletta of Glen Cove, the Long Island open champion, defeated 37yearold Jim Albus of Staten Island, 4 and 3, today in the semifinals in the 42d annual Long Island Professional Golfers Association match play championship at the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club.

title: CARTER LINKS LOOTING TO LONGTIME NEGLECT
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  President Carter described last week's looting in the New York City blackout as an additional indication of the need to channel Federal programs for housing, health, education and jobs opportunities to rundown urban areas neglected too long.

title: DUSAN PETROVIC
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia,July 21 (Reuters)Dusan Petrovic, president of the Yugoslav Socialist Alliance, a Communistled mass political organization, died here today, the Belgrade radio reported. He was 63.

title: Stage: A Buoyant Hit the Deck
description: EAST HADDAM, CONN.

title: JAMES C. MARSHALL, 79, RETIRED ARMY GENERAL
description: Brig. Gen. James C. Marshall, U.S.A., retired, died in Syracuse Tuesday at the age of 79. He was a resident of Skaneateles, N.Y.

title: Jesuits in Salvador Under Guard
description: SAN SALVADOR, July 21 (UPI)El Salvador's 47 Jesuit priests moved into heavily guarded church schools today, rejecting a demand by rightist terrorists that they leave the country by midnight or be killed.

title: Pill Use Rivaled By Sterilization, Survey Indicates
description: Sterilization now rivals the birth control pill ra the leading contraceptive method used by married couples, according to the finding of a newly reported national survey.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Thursday, July 21, 1977

title: Katherine White, ExFiction Editor Of The New Yorker, Is Dead at 84
description: Katherine S. White, who as the first fiction editor of The New Yorker exerted a profoundly rceative influence on contemporary American literature, died Wednesday at Blue Hill Memorial Hospital near her home in North Brooklin, Me. She was 84 years old.

title: Big Apple Circus Pitches for Permanence
description: A large green tent has sprouted near the Battery, signaling perhaps a new institution in New York. It's the Big Apple Circusand its promoters say this circus has come to town to stay.

title: Haughton Sets Sights On a Jackpot Triple
description: Even by Billy Haughton's bigmoney standards, the weekend odyssey he begins tomorrow invites comparison to Jason's search for the Golden Fleece.

title: Around the Nation
description: BALTIMORE, July 21 (AP)Gov. Marvin Mandel, making his first public comment about the racketeering and mail fraud charges he faces, testified today that he did not know his friends secretly owned a race track when a bill favorable to the facility was being considered.

title: Refugee But Not Rootless
description: Several hundred New Yorkers braved the savage heat of midtown Manhattan yesterday morning to attend a memorial service in the auditorium of the McGrawHill Company for the great novelist, Vladimir Nabokov, who died early this month in Switzerland.

title: A Bill of Workers Rights
description: The labor legislation sent to Congress this week under the joint sponsorship of President Carter and organized labor is not the outrage that business contends. It is designed to assure that workers attempting to organize a company, or unions trying to negotiate a first contract, will not be tied up in endless litigation.

title: Highlights for This Weekend
description: Following are some of the highlights of the weekend's summer stock, within reach of the metropolitan area:

title: 104 in New York Ties for 2d Hottest
description: New York City suffered through a blistering 104 degrees yesterday  the secondhighest temperature ever recorded here  with wilting discomfort but no disaster.

title: A Tuneful Twosome At Holmdel Arts Center
description: Anthony Newley, lyricist and composer, and Marvin Hamlisch, a composer who received the Tony Award in 1976 for his music in A Chorus Line, will offer an evening of songs at the Garden State Arts Center tonight and tomorrow at 8:30.

title: News summary
description: FRIDAY, JULY 22, 1977

title: Europeans, Wary About Future, Step Up Pace of Investing in U.S.
description: Fears in Western Europe of possible economic deterioration and radical change apparently have given new impetus to the flow of investments into the United States.

title: CARTER BIDS SOVIET LIMIT BIG MISSILES IN RESPONSE TO U. S.
description: CHARLESTON S. C., July 21President Carter told the Soviet Union today that the United States was prepared to limit its strategic weapons programs, such as the development of the cruise missile, if Moscow would agree to controls on its heavy intercontinental missiles.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Bluefish Plentiful in Places, As Are Weakfish and Bass
description: AREA AThe big news this week on the New Jersey coast has been the influx of vast schools of bluefish, most between one and three miles from shore but a few caught on the surf around Seaside Park. Bananas have been used to haul in an abundance of blues, which range from seven to 15 pounds, depending on the area. Captain Andy's Marina at Margate will hold its annual bluefish contest tomorrow, with a prize of $1,500 to the fisherman catching the eight heaviest blues. A few weakfish of tour to 10 pounds have also been caught on the surf at Seaside Park with bait or plugs. Fluking is reported good in Barnegat Bay. There is excellent tuna fishing in 40 fathoms just inshore from the Canyon, where 50 and 60pounders have been caught on rigged mullet or rigged squid. Bottom fishermen around Barnegat have been making good catches of sea bass near wrecks.

title: ALFRED LIPPMANN, 72, LED E. T. HOWARD, AD AGENCY
description: Alfred Lippmann of New York, chairman of the board of the E. T. Howard Company, one of the country's oldest advertising agencies, died Tuesday in New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 72 years old.

title: FOREIGN AID MEASURES ARE APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)The House passed and sent to the Senate today two foreign assistance bills that contain restrictions on military aid to Ethiopia, Argentina and Turkey.

title: Telpak Service Ending
description: A court decision has cleared the way for unrestricted resale and sharing of leased private telephone and telegraph circuits. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company immediately announced that it would end its Telpak service, which offers discounts on bulk leases of such lines. Among the major users of Telpak are United Press International and The Associated Press, which employ A. T. & T. circuits to transmit news reports nationwide. Page D9.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Schultze Scores Price Move
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Charles L. Schultze, President Carter's chief economic adviser,today denounced price increases announced by United States Steel, the nation's largest steel manufacturer. Calling the steel price increases inconsistent with the Administration's effort to control and reduce the nation's inflation rate, Mr. Schultze said he had discussed the steel price increase with President Carter, and that the President specifically expressed sharp disappointment with the price increases.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Reluctantly, the copper industry fell in line yesterday with the Kennecott Copper Corporation and cut copper prices by 3 cents to 65 cents a pound. This was the second 3centapound price reduction this month for most of the industry. Asarco Inc. had cut its price of electrolytic copper cathodes, by 3 cents to 68 cents a pound on June 1. The industry had resisted that cut, but when Kennecott made an identical price cut after settling a wage dispute with copper workers, the 68cent price prevailed.

title: Emily D. Meyer, 71, Wife of Head Of ScrippsHoward Foundation
description: Emily D. Meyer, the wife of Matt Meyer, who was former president of both The New York WorldTelegram and The Sun and The World Journal Tribune, died Wednesday at her home at 69 Chase Road in Scarsdale, N. Y., after a long illness. She was 71 years old.

title: Excursions in New York's Changing Neighborhoods
description: What are brand new, 45story apartment towers doing rising out of the tawdry seediness surrounding Times Square?

title: Carter's Record Assailed by Head Of Urban League
description: WASHINGTON. July 21Vernon Jordan, executive director of the National Urban League, who is one of the black leaders closest to President Carter, says that the Carter Administration has fallen short on policies, programs and people.

title: Bridge:
description: CHICAGO, July 21The Spingold knockout team championship, the prestige event of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, continued here this afternoon with 64 teams surviving out of a recordbreakins entry of 160 teams.

title: Price Index Rises 0.9%, Paced by Cost of Power And Clothing for Women
description: Paced by large increases in the cost of women's clothing and electricity, the Consumer Price Index for the New York metropolitan area advanced by ninetenths of a percent in June, threetenths of a point greater than the national average. Food prices in the region also continued their upward spiral, although at a somewhat reduced rate of sixtenths of a percent for the month, compared with eighttenths of a percent in May and 2 percent in April.

title: A No Sale For Iran
description: WASHINGTONMy illustrious fellow Missourian Mark Twain once wrote a novel called A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court, detailing the adventures of a 19thcentury New England machinist who was magically transported back in time to the days of the Round Table.

title: Rate of Economic Growth Put at 6.4% in 2d Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Commerce Department reported today that the national economy grew at an annual rate of 6.4 percent in the second quarter, an expansion that was somewhat slower than had earlier been indicated but was said to be better balanced.

title: Books: Horror on Coast
description: When Emily and David Blake, a young uppermiddleclass couple, move into the old Victorian house in San Francisco's Pacific Heights, their lives are as comfortably serene as their status indicates. Except for a slight quarrel over Emily's apparent inability to have children, they appear to have an ideal relationship. An aura of foreboding is quickly introduced, however,. when Emily begins to hear strange knocking noises in the pluming. Probably an element, says Mrs. Prentice, a tottering crone who lives a few houses away. If you don't encourage them, they go away. Well, apparently somone does encourage them, or. it, for the cryptic portents continue. And, after the Blokes marital tranquility is upset by David's infidelity, it becomes clear that Emily is in the grip of demonic presence manifest in the frail body of an 11yearold Mexican. boy, Lupe. Then, when David's mistress is brutally murdered, Emily is indicted for the crime even hough she has a solid alibi  the ambitious prosecutor, Rufus Simonds, intends to prove her guilty of murder by witchcraft.

title: Red Sox Reign by Day But It's Indians by Night
description: Butch Hobson slammed a threerun homer, his second hit during a ninerun seventh inning. and Rick Miller went 4 for 4 at the plate as the Boston Red Sox battered the Cleveland Indians, 114, at Fenway Park yesterday.

title: JOHN R. POWERS DIES; LED MODELING AGENCY
description: John Robert Powers, creator of what is believed to be the world's first modeling agency, which led to an aura of glamour and affluence that drew thousands of women, men and eventually competitors to what is now a billiondollar industry, died Tuesday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Glendale, Calif. He was 84 years old and had been ill for many months.

title: Commodity Price Index Advances 0.8 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 203.3 from 202.5 last week.

title: Italy Weighs Amnesty To Ease Jail Crowding
description: ROME, July 19Amid a wave of crime and violence, Italian officials are discussing plans for an amnesty to ease overcrowding in prisons.

title: Gambino Deportation Plea Is Rejected as Judge Gives Him 10 Year Term Instead
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected the voluntary appeal of Joseph Gmbino to be deported to Italy and sentenced him to 10 years in prison.

title: ATTACK BY LIBYANS BLOCKED AT BORDER, EGYPTIANS REPORT
description: CAIRO, July 21Egypt reported a major border clash today with Libya, saying that the Libyans had carried out an armored and aerial attack across the border but that they had been beaten back with the loss of 40 tanks and two planes.

title: Monument to George Morton Levy
description: George Morton Levy had planned a gala at his home in Old Westbury. L.I., for last night to entertain horsemen, press and others involved in Roosevelt Raceway's 19th International Trot, but the party had to be canceled when the host. was called away unexpectedly. He will not be back, but the $200,00 race will go on tomorrow night with a field of eight horses from seven countries, and perhaps a few $2 players will pause on their way to the mutuel window to say a small prayer for the man whose vision, persistence, energy and gutsy willingness to gamble brought harness racing out of the sticks and onto the metropolitan sports stage. There will be more here later about George Levy. For now, let us consider the race that has become the showpiece of his track, a race that stands as a monument to his memory.

title: Herbert G. Fales, 81 Was Pioneer In Aviation and Metal Concern Aide
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 21 (AP)Herbert G. Fales, an aviation pioneer and retired metal company executive, died yesterday. He was 81 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An executive of a South Kearny truckloading company has been sentenced to 18 months in jail for his part a conspiracy to pass $4.3 million in counterfeit bills in the metropolitan area

title: Road to Geneva: Israeli Picks Risky Route
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Prime Minister Menahem Begin's visit to Washington opened on a note of suspense three days ago and ended today on one of mystery. The question of whether the Israeli Prime Minister would end up in a confrontation with President Carter was decisively answered in the negative; not only was a clash avoided but a striking measure of cordiality was restored to IsraeliAmerican relations. But there was uncertainty on the vital question of whether the twoday meeting between the two leaders contributed to the goal of a new Geneva conference on the Middle East and a just and durable peace.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: The Ridiculous Theatrical Company in Repertory is at the Truck and Warehouse Theater, 79 East Fourth Street. Stage Blood will be performed tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets: $6.50 tonight, $7.50 tomorrow.

title: Joyce Bryant, After the Age of Silver
description: In 1955, Joyce Bryant was riding the crest of a singing career that had been building since, 1942, when she was 14 years old and sang On Top of Old Smoky in a nightclub audienceparticipation performance and was offered a twoweek contract at $125 a week. She had become the epitome of the sexy nightclub singerwith silverdyed hair, wearing a backless, spangled silver gown and silver nail polish, belting out Love for Sale and Drunk With Love (both hit records although they were banned from the air).

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions

title: Ethiopia and ProSomali Rebels Claim Success in Border Conflict
description: NAIROBI. Kenya. July 21Ethiopian troops are battling Somalibacked insurgents in southeastern Ethiopia, with both sides claiming substantial gains.

title: A Variety of Companies List Reports of Their Sales and Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended June 30 unless otherwise, indicated. (N) indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange end (O) overthecounter.

title: Amex Bars Connecticut Move
description: The American Stock Exchange, which has been studying proposals to relocate in New York, New Jersey or Connecticut, said yesterday that it had eliminated Connecticut as too far away and too costly to move to and was still considering the other two. Paul Kolton, chairman, said New Jersey offered lower costs while New York offered convenience, operating efficiencies and important intangible benefits.

title: $500 Million Deposit Is Withdrawn by Iran
description: PARIS, July 21Iran has withdrawn $500 million it had deposited earlier with the French central bank, French officials reported today.

title: Salad Day, Big One, for Albany
description: ALBANY, July 21The 90degree heat in Albany today failed to deter the state and a local supermarket from building the world's largest salad in the middle of the Empire State Plaza.

title: Mondale Campaigns for Byrne, Fulfilling Administration Pledge
description: CLIFFSIDE PARK, N. J., July 21Vice President Mondale visited New Jersey today for the first time since his election to fulfill a pledge of the Carter Administration that it would stump for Governor Byrne's reelection.

title: An Invitation to Dance At Old Bethpage Village
description: Visitors to Old Bethpage Village Restoration can join in dancing oldtime quadrilles, reels and waltzes tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. when a fiddler play in the Noon Inn barn. Icecream making will be demonstrated in the crossroads area at 6:30 P.M. tonight and tomorrow.

title: ISRAELIS HEARTENED BY OUTCOME OF VISIT
description: JERUSALEM, July 21Prime Minister Menahem Begin's first meetings with President Carter earned praise today for the Israeli leader from politicians and editorial writers who, at the same time, pointed out that substantive policy differences remained between Israel and the United States regarding the search for peace in the Middle East.

title: 5YearOld Mare Sets Pacing Record
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 21Meadow Blue Chip set a world mile record of 1:54  for a pacing mare tonght as she won the $75,000 Bergen County Pace at the Meadowlands.

title: Greek Anger at Schaufele Remark May Block Assignment as Envoy
description: WASHINGTON.July 21The assignment of one of this country's highestranking career diplomats as United States Ambassador to Greece apparently has been jeopardized by the use of the word unusual to describe the proximity of Greek islands to the coast of Turkey.

title: Goldin Scores Youth Job Program
description: New York Citys $35 million, federally financed job program is a shambles, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday, and he persuaded the Board of Estimate to delay approval of supplemental contracts with 139 sponsors who are supposed to employ 70,000 youths.

title: U.S. STEEL PLANNING INCREASES IN PRICES TO EASE LABOR COSTS
description: The United States Steel Corporation caught the steel industry by surprise yesterday and announced that it planned to raise prices on structural shapes by about. 6 percent and tin mill products by about 7 percent on Sept. 4. These products account for approximately 15 percent of the company's total steel shipments.

title: Management
description: A cooperative computer at the Strategic Planning Institute in Cambridge, Mass., provides 150 companies with invaluable information from facts collected on an anonymous basis.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Vandals in Central Park Forcing Weather Service to Seek New Site
description: Besides taking New York City's temperature and trying to predict when it will go up or down. National Weather Service forecasters are searching for a new place in Central Park to keep the sensitive instruments they use to prepare their hourly reports.

title: Johnstown Flood Toll Reaches 45 As the Task of Digging Out Begins
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 21As this city struggled to begin the job of digging out from the devastating floods of Tuesday night the death toll here and in surrounding communities rose to 45 today, with hundreds of persons still missing, and an estimated 50,000 displaced.

title: Carter States Panama Canal Objectives and Reviews His First 6 Months at a TownMeeting
description: YAZOO CITY, Miss., July 21President Carter said tonight the United States wanted a new treaty that would let this country help operate the Panama Canal for the rest of this century and allow American warships to protect it after the year 2000.

title: Jacobson Sworn In as First Head of Energy Dept. Expects No Need for Emergency Power Steps Now
description: TRENTON. July 21Electricity reserves in New Jersey were almost nonexistant today, but because of an expected break in the 10daylong heat wave, there should be no need for emergency measures, Joel R. Jacobson said after being sworn in at noon as the first Commissioner of the new Department of Energy.

title: It Was a Busy Day for Beauties
description: For thousands of sweltering New Yorkers, it was a day to dream of getting away from it all. But for eight young visitors who descended on the melting city, yesterday was just another episode in the sometimes onerous life of a beauty queen.

title: Fed Votes to Maintain 5 3/8% Weekly Rate
description: The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, the 12member group that meets each month to set monetary policy for the weeks just ahead, voted no change in midJune in its weekly Federal funds rate objective. of 5 3/8 percent.

title: Israelis Upset by Violence in Conflict on Sabbath Driving
description: BNEI BRAQ. IsraelFor several weeks violence has marred the Sabbath in this mostly Orthodox town near Tel Aviv as ultraOrthodox Jews have sought to keep a road closed.

title: COOLING CAMDIAN AIR ENDS LONG HOT SPELL
description: Cooling breezes from a Canadian cold front moved into New York yesterday to break the nineday heat wave that had sent temperatures into the 90's and the 100's.

title: ALFRED A. NEUSCHAEFER SR.
description: TRENTON, July 22 (AP)Alfred A. Neuschaefer Sr., an awardwinning swimming coach at Trenton High School for 28 years and a member of the International Swimming Hall of Fame, died yesterday at Mercer Medical Center. He was 79 years old.

title: EXXON PROFIT FELL 3,4% IN 2D QUARTER; REVENUES AT A PEAK
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's leading petroleum enterprise, yesterday reported a 3.4 percent drop in earnings in the second quarter.

title: U.S. Missionary Leaves Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 22 (Reuters)An American Mennonite missionary, Thomas Capuano, who said recently that he had been tortured by the Brazilian police, left the country last night after being refused a permanent visa. Last month he described to Rosalynn Carter the beatings he said he and other prisoners had suffered at police hands in Recife.

title: Indictment Says Schwenk Stole $245,284 From Suffolk G.O.P.
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 22Edwin M. Schwenk, a former chairman of the Suffolk County Republican Party, was indicted here today on charges of embezzling nearly a quartermillion dollars in party funds.

title: Belmont Racing;
description: Horses listed In order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Tory M.P. Facing Ouster From the Commons Quits Over Contempt Charges
description: LONDON, July 22A Conservative Member of Parliament, facing possible explusion for having acted secretly as paid lobbyist, rose in the Commons today to announce his resignation so that the good name of the House should not suffer.

title: League Leaders;
description: Based on 200 at Bats;

title: Fire Levels 7 More South Bronx Houses
description: A threealarm fire in an alreadydevastated section of the South Bronx spread to 15 buildings, some separated by a street, before it was brought under control yesterday afternoon.

title: Jockey Banned 25 Days
description: CORNWELLS HEIGHTS, Pa., July 22  Keystone Race Track stewards today suspended William Phelps for 25 days  the longest ban ever imposed on a jockey here.

title: Better Ties With Egypt Sought
description: MOSCOW, July 22In a plea for better relations with Egypt, the Soviet Government asserted today that only through cooperation and coordination with Moscow could Arab nations attain lasting peace and independence.

title: Quake Rocks Anchorage Area
description: PALMER, Alaska, July 22 (UPI)A small earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.0 on the Richter scale occurred 15 miles south of Anchorage yesterday, the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center reported. The earthquake was not strong enough to generate a tsunami wave. It was felt in Anchorage and Palmer. There were no reports of damage.

title: Begin Bids Waldheim Help Get Jews Out of Syria
description: Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel urged Secretary General Kurt Waldheim yesterday to try to arrange the departure of the 800 Jewish families still living in Syria.

title: A Delivery Boy Wins $1 Million in Lottery
description: Michael. Johnson, 19 years old, a $3anhour Manhattan liquorstore delivery boy, won $1,000 a week for the rest of his life yesterday in New York's million dollar lottery.

title: Hot Spell Helped Movie Houses, But Left Some Restaurants Cold
description: The nineday hot spell received mixed reviews from theater, restaurant and museum people here, with business reported going up, down and sideways.

title: U.N. Unit Admits P.L.O.
description: GENEVA, July 22Over American objections, the Palestine Liberation Organization today became the first nonstate to rise to full membership in a United Nations body.

title: Mt. Vernon Moves to Stop Arsons
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 22This city appointed a fulltime arson investigator today, one day after its 82d suspicious fire of the year.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Agrieulture U.S.A. 6:24(5)News 6:30(2)Summer Semester (4)A Better Way (5) Patterns for Living (7)News

title: Jets Drop Five Players
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 22The Jets, who play a game in eight days, made their first cuts today by dropping their finalround draft choice and four free agents.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Democratic Party's finances that appeared in The Times on July 14 contained some errors. A corrective article appears on Page 17.

title: JUDGE BACKS CONTROL BY HUGHES RELATIVE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 22The authority of William R. Lummis over Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation was upheld in an opinion filed today by the Delaware judge who appointed Mr. Lummis 15 months ago to act temporarily as owner in the place of Mr. Hughes.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO.AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 747.0500; SUFFOLK CO. (518) 669.1800; CONNECTICUT (203) 348.7767.

title: Yankees, 63
description: Before last night's game between the Yankees and Milwaukee Brewers at Yankee Stadium, Paul Blair of New York was asked how his team could undo the sick feeling that came from blowing Thursday night's second contest in the ninth and 10th innings.

title: Steel Move Seen Reminding U.S. It Lacks Price Power
description: WASHINGTON. July 22The Carter Administration's first effort to turn back an industrial price increase by a public expression of disapproval appeared to have failed today barely 24 hours after it occurred.

title: CONGRESSMAN QUESTIONS JAWORSKI CONNECTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 22A Michigan Republican said today that Leon A. Jaworski was serving as a director of Houston company that had admitted bribing foreign officials. He said the fact raised questions about Mr. Jaworski's fitness to investigate alleged Korean influence buying here.

title: Personal Investing
description: A twotier market appears to be developing in new  issue preferred stocks. Institutional investors, after a long while on the sidelines, have become buyers mainly of highquality preferreds.

title: SENATORS BID LANCE EXPLAIN BANK'S LOAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee decided today to summon Bert Lance, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, to explain the circumstances involved in a $3.4 million loan he obtained in January from the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: Dow, Buoyed by Reserve's Report On Money Supply, Advances 1.64
description: The Dow Jones industrial average Moved ahead modestly yesterday for the sixth consecutive session as stocks generally ground out small but steady gains.

title: Taking the Measure
description: PARISWinding up a European tour largely devoted to acquainting himself with the United Nations subsidiary organizations in Geneva and Paris, Ambassador Andrew Young passed through here Thursday and unloaded some very sensible and farsighted observations about this complex and highly charged world and the role therein of the United Nations and the United States. His longrange views included the following:

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Friday, July 22, 1977

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed In order of Post positions Letter ciezienates OTB 1st silne

title: BETHLEHEM FOLLOWS U.S STEEL IN MOVE TO INCREASE PRICES
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced yesterday price increases on some steel products similar to the rises planned by the United States Steel Corporation.

title: New York Legislature Acted to Aid Economy
description: The business and financial community came away from the latest session of the New York Legislature with a number of major gains, inriming elimination of the New York City stock transfer tax, a reduction in personal income taxes and the likelihood of $750 million in state bond money to finance economic development projects over the next three years.

title: Schaufele Won't Take Up Post In Greece for the Time Being
description: WASHINGTON, July 22(Reuters)William Schaufele, a target of criticism by Greek politicians and the Greek press, will not take up his post as United States ambassador there for the time being, the State Department said today.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, July 22 (AP)A Federal judge ruled today that a Chicago Park District requirement that American Nazis buy $350,000 worth of insurance before holding a public rally was unconstitutional

title: Fans Say Hello! to Touring Dolly!
description: INDIANAPOLISCarol Channing brought her revival of Hello, Dolly! here for a week of standingroomonly business, then headed for Kansas City, the fourth stop of a national tour that will bring Dolly! back where she belongson Broadwaynext February.

title: Cars, Houses, Trees and Debris Lie in Mud in Johnstown Suburb
description: WINDBER, Pa., July 22James DeBiase looked up at the clear blue sky, bright with sunshine and ornamented with occasional fleecy ciciuds, and said, Things look so pleasant, you can't believe it.', But the view at closer range was reality, and reality in Windber, where two persons died in Tuesday night's flood, was not pleasant at all.

title: PRESIDENT THWARTED ON AUTHORITY TO SET NATURAL GAS PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Denying the Administration the power it sought to set natural gas prices, a SenateHouse conference committee agreed, today on details of legislation to create a new, 20,000employee Department of Energy.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Democratic Party's finances that appeared in The Times on July 14 contained some errors. A corrective article appears,on Page 17.

title: Horse Show
description: SUNNYFIELD FARM

title: Shocked Neighbors Recall Victims in Connecticut
description: PROSPECT, Conn., July 22On a sundappled hillside in this town of modest homes, six miles from Waterbury, the state police, arson specialists and medical examiners went about their grisly task of trying to identify nine bodies scattered through the interior of a small burnedout, red shingled house.

title: Brown Off on Visit to South Korea
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (Reuters)The Secretary of Defense, Harold Brown, left today for Seoul to discuss plans for withdrawing American ground troops from South Korea over the next five years. He will also present proposals to President Park Chung Hee for modernizing the armed forces.

title: The Standings
description: Saturday, July 23, 1977

title: G.M. HALTS PRODUCTION AT ITS VEGAASTRE PLANT
description: LORDSTOWN, Ohio, July 22 (AP)The world's fastest auto production center, slowed by lack of demand for the Chevrolet Vega and Pontiac Astre subcompacts it produced, rolled to a halt today as the General Motors Corporation prepared to restyle and rename the economy cars.

title: Notes on People
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, for the last 15 years New York state's chief Mediator between unions and management, said yesterday that he had submitted his resignation as chairman of the State Mediation Board. Mr. McDonnell, who joined the board in June 1962 as its executive secretary, had indicated some time ago that he planned to resign. He declined to elaborate on the reasons for his resignation. He was a registered Democrat when he was appointed chairman of the mediation board, but in recent years has not listed himself as a member of any political party. The 60yearold mediator has served under both Republican and Democratic governors.

title: Mandel Denies Gifts Were Payoffs
description: BALTIMORE, July 22 (AP)Gov. Marvin Mandel insisted today that an estimated $357,000 in business interests, goods and vacations he received from his five codefendants represented legal fees and friendly giftgiving, not political payoffs. The Maryland Governor testified at his trial in Federal District Court on charges that he improperly used his influence in behalf of a racetrack.

title: MARTIN DIAMOND, 57, A POLITICAL SCIENTIST
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Martin Diamond, a political scientist and professor at Georgetown University, collapsed today moments after he testified before a Senate subcommittee and died of a heart attack two hours later, despite the efforts of two Senators to revive him.

title: Ashley, Energy Unit's Head, Faces Hometown Pressure
description: TOLEDO, OhioWhen he stands at the picture window of his office here and looks out across the broad Maumee River, Representative Thomas Ludlow Ashley can see on the far horizon a tall redringed smokestack rising like a great barber's pole above the Sun Oil Company's refinery.

title: Major League Scores
description: EGrimsley DeCinces. DPBaltimore 2. LOBTexas 8, Baltimore 4. 2BDe Cinces, Washington, Henderson, Har. grove. SCampaneris 2.

title: Port Aide Defends World Junkets As Honest and Beneficial to Area
description: Guy F. Tozzoli, the director of world trade for the Port. Authority of New York and New Jersey, said Thursday that the world trips he and other officials and their wives had taken at the authority's expense were entirely proper and had developed millions of dollars of business forthe port area.

title: Politicians in Clash to Take Credit For Lincoln Towers Rent Decision
description: Top officials of President Carter's Administration became embroiled in the volatile politics of New York City rent control yesterday as several New York politicians clashed over who should take credit for a Federal action favorable to some New York City tenants.

title: 4 Are Indicted In Fire Fatal to 6 At Chicle Plant
description: A Queens grand jury has voted to indict the WarnerLambert Company and four employees for reckless manslaughter in connection with the explosion and fire in its chewinggum factory in Long Island City last Nov. 21 that killed six workers and burned dozens more.

title: Matlack Stifles Padres With a SevenHitter, 50
description: SAN DIEGO, July 22The mystery man of the New York Mets this year, Jon Matlack, shed some more light on the mystery tonight when he pitched the Mets to a 50 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: In Memoriam
description: BRACKETTS. Cora. July 23, 1969.

title: Yankees Box Score; MILWAUKEE (A.)
description: DPYankees I. LOBMilwaukee 7, Yankoos 4. 28Quirk, Booth), Jackson 2, HRJoshua (4), Nettles (22). SSakata, Romero, Quirk.

title: Salvador Jesuits Say Land Reform Is the Main Issue
description: SAN SALVADOR. July 22  Jesuit sources said today that the campaign of threats and intimidation against progressive Roman Catholic priests in El Salvador reflects conservative anger at the church's support for a muchneeded land reform program here.

title: New Orders Dip
description: New orders for durable goods dipped 1.1 percent in June, but shipments rose 1.5 percent, reversing a pattern that began last fall. The main reason for the decline was a 10 percent drop in the primary metals sector: Steel orders fell sharply in the month that prices went up. Page 27.

title: Indictment Says Schwenk Stole $245,284 From Suffolk G.O.P.
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 22Edwin M. Schwenk, a former chairman of the Suffolk County Republican Party, was indicted here today on charges of embezzling nearly a quartermillion dollars in party funds.

title: Support Waning, Women's Movement Knuckles Under in japan
description: TOKYO, July 22Japan's women's liberation movement has folded. After enduring five years of frustrating struggle and ridicule, which can be immensely powerful in groupconscious Japan, the only major women's liberation group and its affiliates have shuttered their offices and admitted defeat at the hands of an overpowering male chauvinism and a wide generation gap among women seeking to change their social status.

title: Carter Canal Talk Stirs Concern
description: WASHINGTON, July 22State Department officials expressed concern today that an offthecuff response yesterday by President Carter in Yazoo, Miss., to a question about the Panama Canal would seriously complicate the delicate negotiations for a new canal treaty.

title: S.E.C. Proposes Rule Requiring Added Investment Adviser Data
description: WASHINGTON. July 22The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed a longawaited rule, which, if enacted, would require investment advisers now registered with the agency to provide additional information to their prospective clients and to the commission.

title: Mother, 7 Children and a Niece Found Slain in Connecticut Fire
description: PROSPECT, Conn., July 22A mother, her seven children and her niece, some of the children bound and gagged, were found dead in the early morning hours todaypresumably murderedin the burnedout interior of their home.

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to priceearnings ratio, tte number times the company's latest 12month earnings can to divided into the stock's closing price. All prices are In dollars. The letter ustands for new annual high and dIndicates new low.

title: State's Main Source of Natural Gas Reports Ample Supply for Winter
description: NEWARK, July 22Joel R. Jacobson, the new Commissioner of Energy, was assured today by the state's largest supplier of natural gas that there would be ample gas supplies for both industrial and residential use next winterprovided were not so severe as last winter. In that case, he said, industrial users might be affected.

title: RICHARD KAMUCA, JAZZ SAXOPHONIST
description: Richard (Richie) Kamuca, a jazz saxophonist with a relaxed, individual style, died of cancer in Los Angeles yesterday. He was 46 years old.

title: Illness Tied to Dengue Fever
description: ATLANTA, July 22 (UPI)Four states and the District of Columbia have notified the Center of Disease Control of acute illnesses, apparently dengue, or breakbone, fever, in persons returning to this country from Jamaica. The virus disease is spread by mosquitoes and is marked by high fever lasting nearly a week, intense headache, muscle and joint pain and .a rash. The four reporting states are Florida, Louisiana, Maryland and New York.

title: Thais to Protest Strongly Over Cambodian Incursion
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 22Thailand's Foreign Minister said today that his country would strongly protest the movement of Cambodian troops . into Thailand that led to the border clashes of the past two days between forces of the two countries.

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: CLOSE HARMONY There's an easy way tonight to do some musichopping in SoHo in quest of cool sounds on a warm evening. Three major showcases in the downtown area are close together, within two short blocks of one another, all with airconditioned comfort and with entertainment policies commended in The New York Times.

title: Mother, 7 Children and a Niece  Found Slain in Connecticut Fire
description: PROSPECT, Conn., July 22A mother, her seven children and a visiting child, some of them bound and gagged, were found dead in the early morning hours todaypresumably murderedin the burnedout interior of their home.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 22Governor Byrne and Representative James J. Florio, Democrat of Camden in the First Congressional District, met today in Washington and will meet again Sunday night at Morven, the Executive Manion in Princeton, to try to settle a potentially serious political dispute.

title: Jacob BenAmi, Actor, Dies at 86; A Founder of Jewish Art Theater
description: Jacob BenAmi, a founder of the Jewish Art Theater who achieved critical acclaim on both the Yiddish and Englishspeaking stages, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. He was 86 years old and lived alone at 50 West 97th Street.

title: NASA Awards Telescope Contract To Lockheed and PerkinElmer
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced that it had awarded $131 million in work for the orbiting space telescope that will be launched in 1983 to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the PerkinElmer Corporation.

title: Uruguay Holds Journalist as Spy
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 22 (Reu,ters),A Brazilian foreign correspondent; Flavio Tavares Freitas, is being held on espionage charges, the Government announced last night. The Buenos Aires correspondent of the Mexico City paper Excelsior, he disappeared last week on a journey from Montevideo to the Argentine capital.

description: Music

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street. the Bronx. 2 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 2 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 1:55 P.M.)

title: U.S. Pair Takes Kayak Title
description: DRAU, Austria, July 22(AP)Jack Lyda and Muriel Gilman of the United States, the defending champions, captured the title again in the canoe and kayak world championships today, winning the mixed kayak competition. They were clocked in 483.443 seconds. Two other Americans, Linda Aponte and Kim Kennedy, finished second.

title: U.S. Women Sink Canada Five
description: MEXICO CITY,July 22 (AP) The undefeated American team downed Canada, 8453, for its third straight victory in the women's PanAmerican basketball championships last night.

title: Bridge:
description: CHICAGO, July 22One of the weirdest systems ever played anywhere scored a dramatic success in the Spingold knockout team championships here last night, assisting four Canadians to clobber a group of national champions.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: 'My Grandfather and the Looters
description: A number of readers, some of whose letters appear below, take us to task for identifying poverty and race as explanations for the looting during last week's blackout. They suggest that blacks and Hispanics are slow to take the route of hard work but quick to take the route of welfare, crimeand now looting. These readers ask, as did many during the urban riots of the 60's, what might be called the my grandfather question: My grandfather pushed a pushcart all over the Lower East Side to earn enough to feed and raise his family. He worked to make it. Why can't they?

title: Carey Asks for Disaster Status For New York City Over Blackout
description: Governor Carey yesterday formally appealed to the Federal Government to have New York City declared a major disaster area as a result of the recent blackout, a status that would entitle it to Federal reimbursement for financial loss suffered by the city government.

title: Atkinson Loses Suit Against Noll
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 22George Atkinson failed to convince a Federal Court jury that Coach Chuck Noll and the Pittsburgh Steelers had slandered him last September by referring to him as a criminaVelement in the National Football League, and the Oakland Raider defensive back's twoweek trial ended here today with a decision in favor of the defendants.

title: Books of The Times
description: A HISTORY OF MODERN POETRY. By David Perkins. 623 pages. Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: NEW FUSION EFFORT REPORTED BY SOVIET
description: Soviet scientists, according to a report from Moscow, have started to build an experimental fusion reactor that, by using superconducting magnets, will be able to sustain a plasma at a temperature of 50 million degrees for more than one second.

title: Quimby Melton, Former Publisher Of Griffin, Ga., Daily News;Was 86
description: GRIFFIN, Ga., July 22 (AP)One of Georgia's bestknown newspaper publishers, Quimby Melton Sr., died here last night. He was 86 years old.

title: One Way to Come In Out of the Sun
description: Oldfashioned, feminine, romanticperhaps so. But the women carrying parasols these daysand there are an increasing number of themare doing so for quite different reasons.

title: Van Pelt Stays Away From Camp
description: PLEASANTVELLE, N.Y., July 22Brad Van Pelt was not here today. He probably won't be here tomorrow.

title: Take 5,000 Cookies...
description: William Accorsi has been tickling smiles out of people for years with his zany wood cutout sculptures. A short time ago he decided he wanted to try his hand at designing, and he liked the idea of kitchenware.

title: Moscow Assays Role of Jews in U. S.
description: MOSCOW, July 22 (Reuters)Moscow gave unusual publicity today to a study by Soviet specialists about the power they said was wielded by Jews in the United States.

title: Letters: On the blackout
description: To the Editor:

title: House Amends Farm Bill to Revive System of Sugar Price Supports
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The House of Representatives amended the new farm bill today to require the Agriculture Secretary to establish a new system of domestic sugar price supports at 14 cents a pound, a move that opponents said could cost consumers and industrial sugar users an additional $1 billion a year.

description: P?7 A.M.; WNYCFM. Sancta et Immaculata Virsinitas; O Magnum Mysterium, Gabrieli; Es wollt ein Maidlein Wasser hol'n; Asperges me. Senfl; Terpsichore Musarum, Caroubel.

title: Ballet: Schaufuss With Canadians in Swan Lake
description: Two things have emerged from the twoweek visit of the National Ballet of Canada to the Metropolitan Opera House, which ends tonight. The first has been the ability of the Canadians to hold the opera house, virtually on their own, without the boxoffice assistance of its customary guest superstar, Rudolf Nureyev. Nor has this been an easy time for the companyits second night was blacked out by the power failure, and the whole season has taken place in a heat wave for the record books.

title: Ted Hood Has His Day AslndependenceWins2
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 22Everyone has been having his day at the America's Cup trials lately and this one belonged to Ted Hood, the beleaguered skipper of the new yacht, Independence. Twice today she beat the other new 12Meter, Enterprise, the second time with considerable help from the latter.

title: 8 Wounded in Montreal Strike
description: MONTREAL, July 22 (Reuters)Three private security guards were arrested today after eight men were hit with shotgun pellets during a riot outside a strikebound flour mill, the police said here. About 500 workers struck last February after the federal AntiInflation Board rolled back wage settlements.

title: About New york
description: Right at delivery, the doctor recognized Down's Syndrome, and he told Virginia Wrynn that her new infant daughter was retarded. The Wrynns named her Dolores, after the Mother of Sorrows, and they decided it would be best for themselves, their five older children and Dolores to find a decent institution for the infant.

title: Deaths
description: ACZELDr. Bono, of BronxvIlle, N.Y., on July 21, 1977. Mourned by his wife Dr. Lill Gonda Aczel, his son Peter, his sister Elsa, his grandsons Eric and Thomas, his daughterInlaw Bodll, his brotherlnlaw Frank Nagy. Services Sunday July 24, 2 P.M. at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home In Bronxville. Interment Monday afternoon July 25 at the Bronxvlie Cemetery.

title: Competing for, and in, the Olympics
description: July 31 is the last day on which New York City may file a formal request to be designated by the United States Olympic Committee as host city for the 1984 Summer Games. In the few days left, Mayor Beanie, surely in consultation with Governor Carey, must decide whether to let the date go by without action or to try for the designation.

title: Then, Why Ramps?
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.  Institutions of higher education are missing or ignoring the major thrust of the new guidelines for handicapped students. To date, the principal response to Federal regulations has been outrage at the potential cost of structural compliance.

title: Red Smith
description: The Kirby boys of Salem County, N.J., are in Cheyenne, Wyo., this weekend, discovering all over again what life is like on the American frontier. Cheyenne's annual rodeo, which the city fathers call Frontier Days and advertises as The Daddy of Them All, begins its 81st stand today, meaning that right on through next week the town will swarm with frontiersmen and frontierswomen out of colleges and high schools and homes and houses from Church Buttes to Spotted Horse. The days will be all dust and noise and sweat and violence and there will be sounds of revelry by night. As the week wears on, pedestrians will watch their step to avoid tripping over sunburned frontiersmen and frontierswomen sleeping the sleep of the pure heart among broken bottles. A nest of squirming maggots, was one cowboy's coalmentary on the scene. It is happening that has become old hat to the Kirby boys, who will be going for the money in the arena and, probably, kinging off between performances to work rodeos going on simultaneously in Salt Lake City and Ogden.

title: People in Sports
description: I intend to call your bluff, was what AI Hrabosky was told by August A. Busch, septuagenarian owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, on Thursday night. Busch gave the lefthanded relief pitcher a present on his 28th birthday by relaxing Manager Vern Rapp's ban on facial hair for the rest of the season. 'You said in the newspaper that you can only get batters out by being psyched up with your mustache and beard. Then go ahead and grow it. But boy, are you going to look like a fool if you don't get batters out, Busch said.

title: P.L.O ATTACKS VISIT BY BEGIN AS WARLIKE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22The chief spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization today attacked the current American visit of Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel, saying it inevitably leads to war.

title: Delich Defeats Galletta In Long Island Golf Final
description: OLD WESTBURY, LI.,July 22Ten years ago while a quarterback at the University of Wisconsin, Jim Delich became enamored with golf. Yesterday, the 33yearold native of Milwaukee who developed into an outstanding golfer in Florida, won the 42d Long Island Professional Golfers Association match play championship at Old Westbury Golf and Country Club.

title: JERSEY UTILITY AIDE DEFENDS CON EDISON
description: An official of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey says he wouldn't be critical of decisions by the Consolidated Edison Company in recent years to delay expansions of powertransfer links across the Hudson that some people say could have helped avert last week's blackout.

description: Brewers Beat Slumping

title: Mrs. Begin, in New York, Tells of a Generation of Survivors
description: Aliza Begin, wife of the Prime Minister of Israel, has to admit she is impressed.

title: SENATORS BID LANCE EXPLAIN BANK'S LOAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee decided today to summon Bert Lance, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, to explain the circumstances involved in a $3.4 million loan he obtained in January from the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: Telpak Service Continued
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced it would continue to offer its discount packages of private telephone and telegraph lines for now after the Justice Department won a ruling from a Washington court ordering existing service continued. Page 31.

title: Coffee Futures Prices Drop Again
description: Coffee futures contract prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange confined theft long decline yesterday. Most contracts were down the daily limit of 6 cents a pound, and the currentdelivery month of July, in which limits do not apply. lost 8.50 cents a pound.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: One of two gunmen who attempted to rob an Upper East Side bank yesterday was critically wounded by the police after he tried to flee, first by car, then aboard a city bus, the police said.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Cranford Township has been cited by the American Automobile Association for superior achievement in the prevention of pedestrian traffic fatalities.

title: 4 Are Indicted In Fire Fatal to 6 At Chicle Plant
description: A Queens grand jury has voted to indict the WarnerLambert Company and four employees for reckless manslaughter in connection with the explosion and fire in its chewinggum factory in Long Island City last Nov. 21 that killed six workers and burned dozens more.

title: 2,350 Con Ed Clients Suffer Power Failure
description: About 2,300 residents of City Island and New Rochelle were briefly without power again yesterday because of a short circuit at the Consolidated Edison Company's New Rochelle substation, a company spokesman reported. In New Rochelle, 1,600 customers who live along. Long Island Sound lost power at 3:15 A.M.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 22(AP)  Two Carter Administration spokesmen today defended plans to sell the secret airdefense system to Iran and said they did not share fears that it would fall victim to Soviet spies.

title: Four Firemen Die In a Blazing Forest Near Atlantic City
description: BASS RIVER TOWNSHIP, N.J., July,22(AP)Four volunteer firemen were burned to death tonight while fighting a forest fire here that engulfed more than, 1,000 acres in the Pinelands 15 miles north of Atlantic City and raged out of control for several hours, the state police said.

title: New DurableGoods Orders Dip, Mainly Because of Steel Pricing
description: WASHINGTON. July 22 (UPI}New orders for durable goods dipped 1.1 percent in June, but shipments increased 1.5 percent, reversing a pattern that began last fall, the Commerce Department said today.

title: She Struggles to 73 for a 143 in Open;
description: CHASKA, Minn., July 22Hollis Stacy, a sparkling profsesional golfer, was not expected to lead any round of the 32d annual United States Women's Open championship. She might have been picked to finish well down the list behind the more familiar troopers on the women's tour if anyone really thought of her as a threat at all.

title: A.T.&T. CONTINUES ITS TELPAK SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said bulkrate discount service to largescale communications users, such as networks or wire services, would continue, but conflicting appellate court decisions have left the situation in doubt.

description: Boston 24, New York 21. Cleveland vs. The Soviets, at Louisville. Phoenix at San Diego. Sea.Port at Indiana.

title: Stoltzman Excels on Clarinet
description: Richard Stoltzman is a wonder. If he were an opera singer or pianist he would be the subject of television specials, an international celebrity with tax problems and Swiss bank accounts to worry about. Mr. Stoltzman, however, is a clarinetist, and though he is a prodigious one his audience would seem fated to remain limited to the comparatively small number of people who dote on chamber music and appreciate its nuances.

title: James Greene Dies at Age 62; Vice President of Liberia Since 72
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 22 (Reuters) The Vice President of Liberia, James Greene, has died at age 62, the Government announced.

title: PAUL ANDERSON PEASLEY
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 22Paul Anderson Peasley, senior vice president of the Union Trust Company, died yesterday lit Stamford Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 167 Fairview Avenue.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON  Absorbent goods such as towels could be made to soak up more than 30 times their own weight in liquid by a process that was patented this week. Designed to give fabrics, nonwovens, paper and cellophane spongelike qualities, the process was invented by Vivian T Stannett and Joel L. Williams. staff members at North Carolina State University, Raleigh, who received Patent 4,036,588.

title: Straw Vote Shows Public's Sentiment On Blackout Issues
description: Five out of six New Yorkers managed to find candles during last week's citywide blackout and three out of four found some matches. But only about half got their hands on a working flashlight. Virtually no one found a kerosene lamp.

description: WASHINGTON, July 22  Governor Byrne testified before a Senate antitrust subcommittee today in favor of legislation to allow states to sue to recover triple damages in behalf of. citizens who have been victims of illegal pricefixing.

title: GLOBAL EFFORT TO ATTACK PIRATING OF TV SHOWS
description: MOSCOW, July 22Actors associations . from 38 Western and Communist countries resolved at a. conference concluded here today, to increase legal efforts to eliminate internationally pirated television programs that deprive actors of royalties.

title: RESTORATION OF TENG AROUSES JUBILATION
description: PEKING, July 22 (Reuters)China officially announced tonight that the purged leader Teng Hsiaoping had been returned to power and that his ultraradical opponents, the socalled Gang of Four, had been expelled from the Communist Party.

title: Northville Crude Shipping Backed
description: The Northville Industries Corporation announced that the Government of Panama had authorized it to commence immediately petroleum transshipments off Bahia Parita, Panama. The transshipment will involve the transfer of Alaskan crude oil from supertankers to smaller tankers that will pass through the Panama Canal and carry the oil to ports on the east and Gulf coasts of the United States.

description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)A Federal grand jury today indicted four corporations and two individuals on charges they conspired to fix prices for paint resins.

title: Israelis Allowed To Use U.S. Aid To Develop Tank
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Carter Administration, in an apparent gesture to Prime Minister Menahem Begin, announced today that it had agreed to permit Israel to use $107 million in American military aid to produce Israel's newly developed heavy tank, the Chariot.

title: Con EdLilco Link Might Have Eased Blackout Impact
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 22The Consolidated Edison Company and the Long Island Lighting Company have been laying a cable to link the two utilities that, completed, might have given Con Edison greater flexibility in dealing with last' week's blackout, according to officials of both utilities.

title: ABRAHAM FELDMAN, JEWISH LEADER, DIES
description: Dr. Abraham J. Feldman, a nationally known Jewish leader and ecumenist, died Thursday at his home in West Hartford, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

title: GAF Will Drop Its Consumer Photographic Lines
description: Plagued by years of low earnings in its photographic business, the GAF Corporation announced yesterday that it would drop its consumer lines of cameras, films and color print papers,leaving the Eastman Kodak Company with little domestic manufacturing competition in amateur photography except in instant pictures.

title: Glen Cove Youths to Face a Jury Of Peers for BikeLaw Violations
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., July 22Youths in this North Shore community accused of violating bicycle regulations will be judged and sentenced by a jury of their peers under a program that begins tomorrow.

description: A sixperson Federal Court jury in San Francisco rejected George Atkinson's $2 million slander suit against the Pittsburgh Steelers and their head coach, Chuck Noll. Details Page 15.

description: WASHINGTON,July 22The Carter Administration, in an apparent gesture to Prime Minister Menahem Begin, announced today that it had agreed to permit Israel to use $107 million in American military aid to produce Israel's newly developed heavy tank, the Chariot.

title: Vance Sets August Mideast Tour
description: WASHINGTON. July 22 (Reuters)Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will visit Israel and five other Middle Eastern countries beginning Aug. 1, State Department officials said today.

title: HOUSE PANEL EASES A CURB ON UTILITIES
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Under intense pressure from utility industry lobbyists, the special House energy committee today liberalized tough restrictions on interlocking utility directorates that had been approved by another House committee.

title: Czechoslovakia Raising Some Consumer Prices But Is Lowering Others
description: PRAGUE, July 22 (AP)New prices take effect tomorrow and Czechoslovaks are going to pay 50 percent more for coffee, 33 percent more for chocolates and 34 percent more for some cotton and wool products.

title: Venetian Gondola Joins Baltimore's Permanent Fleet
description: BALTIMORE, July 22A 34foot authentic black Venetian gondola named Gina was added to Baltimore's motley fleet of dockbound vessels today.

title: NetsKnicks Trial Opens With Testimony Conflicts
description: Conflicting testimony marked the opening yesterday of a trial to determine whether the Nets should be permitted to move their basketball franchise from Long Island to New Jersey.

title: He Paces Nicklaus, Kite by 3 in Canada
description: OAKVILLE, Ontario, July 22It has been two years since Lee Trevino, the most celebrated member of the golf tour's walking wounded, has been nine under par, and Super Mex attributes that happy status ton hot putting streak and a tremendous amount of luck.

title: Strong Winds Hinder Firefighters in Maine
description: MILLINOCKET, Maine, July 22 (AP) Strong winds impeded firefighters today in their efforts to control a sixdayold fire that has charred more than 2,000 acres of timberland in Baxter State Park.

title: Excerpts From Chinese Party's Communique on Teng's Rehabilitation
description: PEKING, July 22 (Reuters)Following, as provided in English by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, are excerpts from the communiqu ending a meeting of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party at which Teng Hsiaoping was formally rehabilitated:

title: Power Company Kit Called Propaganda For Nuclear Plants
description: A leading conservation group has accused the electric industry of unfairly promoting atomic power and ridiculing critics of the industry in a purported educational game being placed in thousands of classrooms around the country. The industry says it is not so.

title: SADAT'S JETS POUND AN AIR BASE IN LIBYA; HE ASSAILS QADDAFI
description: CAIRO, July 22  Egyptian planes bombed and strafed a Libyan air base today, the second day of major military clashes between the two countries, a military spokesman here announced.

title: Cubs Are Prospering On Reuschel's Pitching
description: Remember the famous pitching formula of the old Boston Braves? Spahn and Sain and pray for rain. The surprising Chicago Cubs have their own sloganReuschei and Sutter and stay out of the clutter.

title: Business Records
description: Friday, July 22, 1977

title: $2.8 MILLION WAS RAISED BY DEMOCRATS IN 6 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Democratic Finance Council' the party's new fundraising ann, collected more than $1.5 million in the first six months of 1977, raising total Democratic income for the year to $2.8 million.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JULY 23, 1977

title: JULIAN C. STANLEY
description: Julian C. Stanley, a stockbroker, died Monday at his home in Oyster Bay, L. I., at the age of 81. He had been a partner since 1942 in the brokerage, firm of Mitchell, Hutchins & Company.

title: Theatrics Overwhelm Show by Alice Cooper
description: The show Alice Cooper brought to Nassau Coliseum on Thursday night, his first touring show in more than two years, was a case of the tail wagging the dog. The theatrical elements that Mr. Cooper introduced into arena rockand theatrical means the full panoply of Hollywood and Las Vegas show business, from lights to choreography to elaborate costuminghave swallowed up his music.

title: Police Vehicles On Fire Island Called Perilous
description: SALTAIRE, L.I., July 22After two recent incidents in which police vehicles ran over sunbathers, the Mayor of this Fire Island community has asked the Suffolk police to stay off its beaches.

title: PRESIDENT THWARTED ON AUTHORITY TO SET NATURAL GAS PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Denying the Administration the power it sought to set natural gas prices, a SenateHouse conference committee agreed today on details of legislation to create a new, 20,000employee Department of Energy.

title: Apples Beaten By the Lobsters
description: Virginia Wade, the queen of Wimbledon's women singles, was very, very perturbed at the Felt Forum last night. The usually reserved English star, who won the women's crown at Wimbledon this. year in her 16th attempt since, 1962, lost her temper and her match to Martina Navratilova, 61, as the Boston ton Lobsters downed Miss Wade's New York Apples, 2421, before a crowd of, 3,148.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: MY reasons for moving to Locust Valley after 17 expatriate year., 4. Paris had nothing to do with (1)finding a cure for lockjaw (2) a passion for golf pros (3) the Junior League. But esthetics does play an important role in the life of a writer. And Locust Valley, like Paris, is a mighty pretty town, snug and untouched by malls or neon. There is a substantial quality here. I like it immensely.

title: 1976 Summer Olympics Are Still Haunting Montreal
description: MONTREAL, July 23On the first anniversary this week of the opening of the Olympic Games, Montrealers did more than reminisce about them. The games have become an inextricable part of the economic and political life of the city and of Quebec Province and threaten to remain so for a lone time to come.

title: Annual Interest Debt of $373,000 Revives Conflict Issue for Lance
description: WASHINGTON, July 23In the seven months since he became budget director, Bert Lance has seen his income and assets decline to the point where the Congressional oversight committees that once voiced concern over possible conflicts of interest because of his assets have begun to ask whether such conflicts could grow out of his debts.

title: New Zealand Premier Attacked
description: DUNEDIN, New Zealand, July 23 (Reuters)Prime Minister Robert Muldoon was hit by a flour bomb and his car attacked by angry demonstrators protesting Government austerity measures here last night. Mr. Muldoon described the incidents as probably the most disgraceful demonstration we have had. in New Zealand politicS.

title: Medical Diagnosis
description: WE have here what amounts to a mournful communiqu from the high command this nation's $140billionayear medical enterprise. The main message, accompanied by a few contrary opinions, is, sorry, folks, you're deluded if you think modern medicine can.do you much good; it can pull off a few tricks, but, for the most part, your health is in your own hands. And, finally, the message continues, though the system is administratively daft, overpriced, and largely irrelevant to your needs, it is also politically immune to reforms that would enable it to serve you better.

title: Topics
description: If you are a woman and you thumb a ride and are picked up by a male driver and raped, you were asking for it. That, believe us, was the reasoning applied by a California Court of Appeals in overturning the conviction of an accused rapist the other day. Judge Lynn Compton wrote, for a unanimous court: The lone female hitchhiker in the absence of an emergency situation, as a practical matter, advises all who pass by that she is willing to enter the vehicle with anyone who stops and in so doing advertises she has less concern for the consequences than the average female. Under such circumstances it would not be unreasonable for a man in the position of the defendant here to believe that the remate would consent to sexual relation.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Miniseries mania. This time last year many bestselling novelists and their publishers were enjoying severe cases of Great Expectations. Bright in their memories was the experience of one of their number, Irwin Shaw, whose 1970 novel, Rich Man, Poor Man, rather routinely made into an ABC miniseries, had turned out to be one of the preceding TV season's biggest successesand had sold 4,750,000 copies in Dell's paperback edition. Even brighter were the prospects for the approaching 197677 season. NBC had scheduled a whole string of Best Seller miniseries and it seemed likely that their competitors would put on similar specials.

In the east the sky was already turning cobalt, and all around me I heard the basso profundo of frogs.

After 30 years he is still its musical director, and he has made a few appearances here during that period. One of them was on Friday night as conductor of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: What's Doing in ATLANTA
description: THE CITY  Atlanta, like London and San Francisco, is one of those rare cities that almost everyone likes. It is a thoroughly Southern place, the geographic crossroads of southeastern Dixie. Its 1.5 million residents are ever polite, footballcrazed and hooked on grits and greens. And yet Atlanta has enough Yankee hustle and brass to qualify as an allAmerican city. Within the past year, it has been headquarters for one of the most successful Presidential campaigns in United States political history. Before that, it was headquarters for the civil rights crusade led by a native son, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Threefourths of the country's top 500 companies maintain offices in Atlanta's skyscrapers. The city's airport, Hartsfield International, is the second busiest in the world, trailing only Chicago's O'Hare. As a convention center, Atlanta competes with New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. So chances are, if you go to conventions or head below, the MasonDixon Line on business or vacation, you'll eventually .pass through Atlanta. Peachtree Street, the city's main thoroughfare, con. siders itself the main street of the entire South

title: The Price Of Success
description: WHILE the spotlight has been focused on the struggles for the Nassau County Executive nomination within the Democratic and Republican Parties, the tiny Conservative Party in the county has its own squabble going over the County Executive designation, struggle that has carried down to virtually every Conservative nomination for public office on the county and town level.

title: Southern Rock Is Spreading Across the Country
description: Confederate flags waved in Central Park last summer when the Marshall Tucker Band performed, and longhaired fans in overalls square danced. The Atlanta Rhythm Section, opening shows for Alice Cooper on his current tour, has been,greeted by rebel yells in the most unlikely places. Clearly, Southern rock has a mystique all its own, one which transcends regional differences. In part, this is because white Southerners still seem exotic, and therefore fascinating, to many Americansa Southern friend was recently asked in New York whether his people had really wanted to secedeand because our Southern president has popularized Southern chic. But the Southern rock band predated and perhaps helped create the climate for Jimmy Carter, and exotic or not, the music is distinctive enough to have created a nationwide audience strictly on its own merits.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to watch the Perseids, peak meteor activity will occur Aug. 12. Conditions for watching the shower are particularly good this year, since the moon will set an hour or two before the sun and will rise an hour or two before sunrise, so that the sky will be dark for the greater part of the night. The nearmaximum shower rate, productive of 60 or more meteors per hour, will endure for about two days before the peak and one day after, although a week on either side will still yield a respectable showing of 15 or 20 meteors an hour. The Perseids are only one of a dozen or more annual meteor showers, but they are the favorite of amateur observers because they put on a better display than the rest and occur at just the right time of year for comfortable viewing. You can watch the Perseids wherever you are, and group viewing

title: M. Donald Grant: Taking the Heat
description: The spotlight he never sought flashed on Michael Donald Grant again Tuesday night during baseball's AllStar Game, when Tom Seaver, on his return to New York, was greeted with a oneminute standing ovation.

title: Blair's Homer Supports Guidry As Yankees Defeat Brewers, 31
description: The Yankees put their star wars behind them yesterday and beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 31, with just plain old baseball. A sixhitter by Ron Guidry, normally a spot starter, and a tworun homer in the second inning by Paul Blair, a substitute outfielder, sparked the victory and provided the team with a split of the fourgame series at Yankee Stadium.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, July 23The Chicago police broke up an attempted march today in the predominantly white Marquette Park section by black members of the Martin Luther King Jr. Movement, but 19 injuries and at least 27 arrests followed when a crowd of whites began attacking other blacks passing through the area.

title: The World
description: An ancient Chinese proverb says: When wanted, then go; When set aside, then hide. In the last 30 years, Teng Hsiaoping has had spectacular comings and goings as pragmatists and ideologues have alternated in directing China's course. Denounced as demon and freak during the Cultural Revolution, restored to power in 1973 by then Prime Minister Chou Enlai only to be discarded three years later after Mr. Chou's death, Mr. Teng has been rehabilitated again by the suces; sors of Mao Tsetung.

title: Pamela Joan Frye Married To Mark Chuhinko in Jersey

description: IN ADDITION to some of the ambitious chambermusic festivals I've been mentioning in these pages recentlyprimarily those at Norfolk, Chestnut Hill and Music Mountain ,there are some fascinating summer programs in Connecticut operating on more modest scale.

title: Libraries Pushing Reading for Children
description: ORANGE SUSAN FRUCHTMAN, the children's librarian at the Orange Public Library, recently took a group of youngsters who had read at least three books this summer to a Mets game. In Phillipsburg, for every 10 books they read, children receive free paperback. Matawan youngsters who read at least 15 books may attend gala party at summer's end.

title: Blanche Sweet: Flashback to 1911
description: NARRATION: Of all the filmmakers who created silent motion pictures on location in and around Fort Lee, there were none like D.W. Griffith. Although he made most of his journeys to New Jersey from New York's Biograph Studio nearly 70 years ago, his memory and his work live on within people and places.

description: Finish planting late vegetables for fall harvest. . . . Last call to feed evergreens. . . . Water when rainfall is rare. . . . Keep faded flowers picked from annuals to promote continuous bloom.
