Gross of Lawrence, L.I. Dr. Algernon D. Black, leader emeritus of the New York Society for Ethical Cultbre, performed the ceremony.

title: Headliners
description: It is almost 50 years since the execution of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti for the murder of two men a Massachusetts payroll robbery, but protests by those who felt the two Italianborn anarchists were not fairly proved guilty have never died. Last week Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts acknowledged as much. In a proclamation creating a Sacco and Vanzetti Memorial Day, he declared that any stigma and disgrace should he forever removed from the names of the two men, their families and the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Governor Dukakis said a study of the case by his legal office had found many abuses by the prosecution, including ...appealing to the jury's prejudice and biases. On the advice of his staff, the governor did not pardon the two men, chiefly because the word pardon connotes guilt. In fact, the guilt or innocence of Sacco and Vanzetti is still in dispute.

title: DR. ALEXANDER R. M'LEAN
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., July 23 (AP)Dr. Alexander R. MacLean, a pioneer in the epidemiology of multiple sclerosis, died last night at St. Mary's Hospital here. He was 68 years old..

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH concrete patios and terraces do not need paint or other coating to protect them against the elements, homeowners often find it advisable to paint them for cosmetic reasons; for example , when patches must be made or cracks are filled and the patch comes out a different color than the original concrete. Also, people often paint the patios to keep the dust down, or simply because they want a brighter looking surface that will also be easier to keep clean.

title: String Players on Record From Heifetz To Perlman and Zuckerman
description: String players may not occupy quite the same charismatic position in musical circles as pianists, but recent record releases by a number of artists indicate that the kind of magnetism Paganini generated to spellbind 19thcentury audiences has been passed down to a select few of his successors. Take Jascha Heifetz, for example, a name that has become virtually synonymous with the violin. His fame is such that two years ago RCA, in one sweeping gesture, restored to circulation very nearly every recording this virtuoso made for the label between 1917 and 1955.

description: CANTON, Ohio, July 23 (APIBart. Starr and Forrest. Gregg, cornerstones in Green Bay's first two Super Bowl champions, will join professional football immortality Saturday.

Equally unusual, considering the committee's recent history, was general approval the move received.

title: Italy's Delfo, $2 2 ,Wins International
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 23The Italians finally made it to the winner's circle of the $200,000 International Trot. After 16 failures for Italy in the 19yearold event, Delfo, a 6yearold stallion, scored a wiretowire victory tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The favored United States representatives, Keystone Pioneer and Kash Minbar, finished out of the money in the 1l4mile event.

title: Reporter's Notebook: A Change Of Heart Bolsters Charismatics
description: KANSAS CITY, July 23A young woman wearing a white cotton dress and holding a plain wooden cross in her hand knelt to pray on the concrete floor of a noisy exhibit hall, her eyes closed, whispering Thank you, Jesus again and again. Moments later, she arose smiling and said to a stranger,

title: One Year Later, Mystery Persists, but Enigma Is Gone
description: When Paul Detsch, a 53yearold carbon plant worker in northwestern Pennsylvania, began to feel weak and dizzy last March, he thought he had the flu. But within days, Mr. Detsch's fever climbed to 105 degrees as he developed a pneumonia that did not respond to an antibiotic. Mr. Detsch became disoriented, barely cognizant of his transfer to a medical center 100 miles away. There, after doctors prescribed two different antibiotics, Mr. Detsch's fever broke quickly and his pneumonia cleared. He slowly regained his health over the next two months.

title: Pay Telephone Calls In Florida Increased From 10 to 25 Cents
description: MIAMI, July 23  Beginning next month, Floridians are to pay 25 cents for a pay telephone call, the highest figure in the nation for any Bell Telephone System.

title: TV VIEW;
description: Once again, the promise and reality of public television are about to be subjected to the scrutiny of a major study. With the blessing of the White House, a commission has been established by the Carnegie Corporation of New York to determine a future course for noncommercial television and radio, particularly as it might develop in the new satellite system of programming distribution expected to get under way in 1979. There is renewed talk of technology and economics and internal power struggles and personality conflicts. There has been a great deal of publicityjockeying and egostroking in the press. Not surprisingly, there is a tendency in the midst of this fuss to forget that the ultimate point isor at least should beprogramming content, the product that finally, appears on the home screen for the enlightenment or.stultification of the audience. And the appalling fact is that the state of the current programming process in public television is disintegrating rapidly.

title: Beating Inflation Actively or Passively
description: The second question competent investment counselors ask a new client is usually, Why are you investing? The first question, obviously, is, How much do you have to invest?

title: Consumer Guide on Doctors Issued
description: SCARSDALE

title: Bucks and Bangs
description: THE unregulated buying and selling of arms currently one of the world's biggest gogo industriesa bigger buck for the bang, so to sveak. Much of Anthony Sampson's brilliant new book, The Arms Bazaar, summarizes the history of armaments in terms of the men who pioneered their sale, showing how selling arms has been a source of worldwide profit and selfjustification since the end of the first industrial revolution.

title: How to Succeed in Tennis And Become a Social Lion
description: All tennis lovers know that the game is an admirable end in itself. At its best it can be an unconfined joy, an ecstasy second only to one.

title: NIGERIA'S DISSIDENT SUPERSTAR
description: Up until five months ago, he was only the best musician in Nigeria  a raucous, insolent, flamboyant superstar, the inventor of the new music called Afrobeat. His morals were the scandal of his countrymen. He lived behind barbed wire in a Westernstyle commune, smoked pot religiously, called himself the chief priest and was idolized by thousands of young Nigerians as a sort of African Bob Dylan. His records, churned out at the rate of six and seven albums a year, were banned on Government radio because of a dispute over copyright payments, but they boomed out of shantytown shops on every other street in the congested capital of Lagos with a subliminal, perhaps even subversive, message, and they sold coast to coast across the continent.

title: DINING OUT
description: FOR 50 years, Ye Olde Cedar Inn has had an enviable reputation as a dependable dispenser wellcooked, wellserved food. It is our pleasure to report that, in our view, this sprawling, countrified eating place on the way south merits its reputation. In all ways, it is an honest restaurant.

title: Great Contractor Beats Forego by 11?
description: Forego, the people's choice in a crowd of 31,167 at Belmont Park yesterday, disappointed his followers for the second straight time.

title: TIMELESS SUMMERS IN OLDTIME MAINE
description: The bonnets and ruffles have given way to Tshirts and bikinis, but otherwise summer in Maine looks much the same today as it did almost 80 years ago when a middleaged widow named Chansonetta Stanley Emmons began to focus her camera on the people, places and pastimes she had known most of her life. Born in Kingfield, Me., in 1858, Mrs. Emmons spent almost every summer there until she died in 1937. Over the decades, she recorded on hundreds of glass plates the serene and timeless scenes of summer  children fishing and wading, outdoor picnics and indoor chores, vistas sea, mountains and woods, and everywhere the classic, nonon sense look of the local farm and town folk. Though Mrs. Emmons exhibited her work and occasionally sold prints (priced from $2.50 to $13), she was little known beyond the circles of a few New England camera clubs; when she died, her photographs virtually disappeared with her. But in 1975, another native of Maine, Marius B. Peladeau, tracked down Mrs. Emmons nephew and acquired his collection of more than 1,100 prints and almost 100 glass negatives. A selection of these will appear in Mr. Peladeaus book, Chanso netta, to be published in September by Maine Antique Digest, and will be put on exhibition at the Neikrug Gallery in New York until late fall. (Text and pictures continued on Page 21)

title: Examining Colleagues, Quite Uncomfortably
description: WASHINGTONThe House ethics committee different from other committees. For one thing, few members of Congress want to sit on it. Representatives from farm states vie to be on Agriculture, and members from coastal states seek seats on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, where they can do their constituents some good. Almost everyone wants to be on powerful Appropriations or Rules or prestigious Armed Services or International Relations. But the ethics committee, in the words of a member, is wretched assignment. It has no constituency and no votes to be gained by competent service. Even worse, it puts Congressmen in the position of assessing the conduct of the people with whom they work every day. No one, says Millicent Fenwick, Republican of New Jersey, likes to sit in judgment of his peers.

title: Smoking Ban Gains
description: TRENTON LAST YEAR, two million New Jerseyans smoked 18 billion cigarettes. And many of them were puffed in public places, much to the annoyance of nonsmokers, an increasingly belligerent majority group.

title: Solar Music In New Canaan
description: ONE LIGHT at the end of the energycrisis tunnel is the sun. Every day scientists are working on the pretlenis of harnessing the free power that it radiates. Architects are designing new ways to put such technology to work. And almost daily, consumers are collecting these ideas and innovations for their own use.

title: Four Novels
description: FOUR new novels, four distinctly individual voices: comparisons are not inevitable, but possibly helpful. The most ostensibly conven

title: Allison R. Hallingby Bride of J. A. Dodge
description: Allison Roberts Hallingby, daughter of Paul Hallingby Jr. of New York and Essex, COnn., and the late Allison Lazo Hallingby, was marired yesterday in Washington to John Arrington Dodge, son of Mrs. John Doane Dodge of Washington and the late Mr. Dodge. The Rev. E. Pinkney Wroth Jr. performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Pop: Judy Collins in Her Own Niche
description: Summer in New York would not be complete, it seems, without Judy Collins singing Who Knows Where The Time Goes in Central Park. Her concert on Friday evening did not break much new ground, but it had the advantages of a new band, one that lent considerable musical interest to some otherwise shopworn numbers, and aultless weather, with sunlight dapbling the ground and a cool breeze blowing.

title: Turning Ice Skates Into Dance Shoes
description: Last season, local journals spread the exciting news that a champion skater, John Curry, was working with ballet and moderndance choreographer, Twyla Tharp.

title: This 11YearOld Becomes A Woman in Gymnastics
description: Jackie Cassello is a little girl with big responsibilities. As a member of the national junior elite gymnastics team, the 4foot5inch; 64pound pixie from South Hempstead, L.I., is one of only 10 girls under age 14 in the country who have been selected to be trained especially for international couipetition aimed at the United States making a stronger showing at the 1980 Olympic Games. And tonight, Jackie will head an American Squad that will compete against the Swiss national team at the Nassau Coliseum in a women's meet sanctioned by the United States Gymnastics Federation.

title: Al Goldstein Denied Trial Delay
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., July 23 (AP)A Federal district judge has refused to grant Al Goldstein a sixth delay of his trial on pornography charges, despite the suggestion of a courtappointed physician that a postponement would be reasonable. Judge Frank G. Theis decided at a hearing yesterday that Mr. Goldstein, publisher of Screw magazine, was capable of standing trial, and he scheduled jury selection for Monday. Mr. Goldstein has what doctors have described as sleep apnea syndrome, a disorder that makes difficult for him to breathe.

title: When the Bees Swarm, the Parks Department Calls (in Honeyed Tones) for Help From Brooklyn Apiarist;
description: When a colony of 5,000 bees living in the Washington Square Park area ???? grew its hive and resettled in a swarm on a local firebox, residents of the area Panicked and called the Parks Department for help. The Parks Department in turn called 22yearold Henry Mulzac, a Brooklyn beekeeper who has been help g the city cope with its bees since he was 14.

title: Urban Poor Worse Off Than Ever
description: WASHINGTONA decade ago, when the nation's inner cities one by one, were erupting in riots, the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders questioned many of the participants to find out why they had destroyed their neighborhoods. One finding was that. for many, the violence was a means calling attention to the urban condition, and an ex, tension of the civil rights movement despite its departure from the nonviolent tradition that had prevailed until then.

title: The Message to Moscow
description: Mounting concern that the Carter Administration's Soviet policies were endangering detente and reviving the cold war required a Presidential response, and Mr. Carter has now delivered it. Its specifics are far less important than its tone. In contrast to some past offthe.cuff remarks that have stirred difficulties, the tone of the carefully drafted speech he gave in Charleston, S.C., was Presidential. It should give, as intended, more positive thrust to SovietAmerican negotiations, as well as to the atmosphere of the relationship. These have run downhill as a result of Mr. Carter's human rights campaign, his strategic arms proposals and the Soviet reaction to both.

title: Notes: Summer Fairs Across the Northeast
description: Throughout the Northeast, committees are meeting to draw up final plans for that annual downhome ritual: the summer fair.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LAST February, when tempera= trees roared temporarily and nongardenon frolicked and re. jolted, New Jersey gardeners feared that their trees and shrubs might respond to the sudden heat by relaxing the tight scales that protect the flower buds.

title: Economists Temporize as Dollar Slides, but Oh the Consumer!
description: Distressing though the dollar's recent slide may be to Americans traveling abroad or buying West German or Japanese cars, economic analysts, who were thrown into travail by currency turmoil a few years ago, are remaininn calm this time around.

title: Enterprise Is Winner Twice Over Courageous
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 23A lot of the early steam generated by Ted Turner, the maverick owner of the Atlanta baseball team who is described by some as the Mouth of the South. went out of Courageous touav as Enterprise beat the Turner yacht twice in light winds the America's Cup trials.

description: The programs of the Manhattan Council, Boy Scouts of America, will benefit from a theater party at the Aug. 18 performance of Annie at the Alvin Theater. Tiacets at $25 each are available from the beneficiary at 345 Hudson Street.

title: Food;
description: Cooking on skewers is conceivably the oldest form of cookery on earth. It most assuredly preceded a grill of any sort. And it is easy to surmise that our earliest ancestors, no matter how primordial, had better sense than to get their fingers too close to those newly discovered flames.

title: Princeton Applauds Its Street Theater
description: PRINCETON HEATER is a highly adaptable and mobile art .form with numerous practitioners. It has been presented at one time or another in possible place, from

title: Gets Water Bill
description: Although Mayor Logue said on Thursday that the city of New Haven would make payments to the towns in lieu of lost property taxes, the city would not be legally liable for the gross receipts tax, sales tax, municipal property taxes, state business tax and Federal income taxes paid now by the New Haven Water Company. The taxes came to $5.8 million last year.

title: A Basketball Player Who Didn't Make It
description: Playing professional basketball is a dream of millions of young men throughout the United States. But a basketball player is constantly under pressure to prove his worth to coaches and peers, and when he has based his entire existence on his performance in a sport, a poor showing can lead to severe anxiety.

title: SWEDEN IS AROUSED BY ETHNICPROBLEMS
description: STOCKHOLM, July 23 (AP)Sweden has become enmeshed in ethnic problems after long seeming to be invulnerable to them.

title: Resilience In Energy Strategy
description: BRIDGTON, Me.We have developed a society in which the basic functions of life depend on a continuous supply of electricity. In New York, traveling, going upstairs, opening doors, even waking, eating, seeing and breathing may depend on the electrical supply.

title: CHESS
description: Under the pressure of a mating attack, there are two general stratagems available to the defense: one is to limit the scope of the attacking pieces by a pawn advance; the other is to meet the attacking pieces tactical threats with tactical defenses using the defending pieces.

title: New Way to Aid College Students

Indeed, there is a drive by most institutionsand by the majority of students and facultyto increase Federal, state and local support for such education as a key to national prosperity and survival.

description: Jamie Bennett Tilghman and David Hepburn Deming, who are with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, plan to be married in September.

description: AT 5:30 A.M., some Ridgewood residents might rub their eyes at the sight of a small Japanese woman running silently . along the street. To earlyrising commuters, however, Toshiko d'Elia's running is as routine as their own sprints for the 7:43. But what they may not know is that the woman is a championand that her husband, Manfred, is, too.

title: Is Baseball Too Slow? Or Is It Supposed to Be That Way
description: In an article on this page (Baseball: Too Slow a Game in a Jet Age) two weeks ago, Edward R. Walsh called baseball boring and a slothfooted sport. He said there was too much dead time and too long a season. He suggested such changes as seven innings to a game, three strike and out even if the third strike is a foul, and a rule requiring a pitcher to throw within 10 seconds after getting the ball. Here are responses to that article.

title: Connecting Flight Woes And How to Avoid Them
description: The shortest distance between two airports is a nonstop flight. But there is no nonstop service between, say, Las Vegas, Nev., and Decatur, Ill.; some 70 percent of all domestic air trips involve one or more stops. The traveler is thus often left at the mercy of the connecting flight, a prospect that has moved strong men to tears.

description: EAGLESWOOD TOWNSHIP, N.J., July. 23(AP)The 50th anniversary of the Volunteer Fire Department here was to have been celebrated today, but instead, members mourned the death of their chief and three firemen, who were killed yesterday in a Pinelands forest fire.

title: $21.5 Million Lab Is Being Designed For Oceanic Studies

title: Family Fun Day at Church
description: It's a gettogether day for families and friends at St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Stroudsburg, Pa. next Sunday (rain date Aug. 7). The Rev. Francis Barrett is the man behind the Family Fun Day, as the annual summer festival is called. Games for children and adults, a flea market, a wheelbarrow of cheer, and homecooked food are the order of the day. The church is at North Ninth and Main Streets, where the fair starts at noon.

He won 10 of the 22 NASCAR events in which he had started. That's one more victory than even the Grand National champion, Cale YarSports borough, was able to record. Pearson also won almost $300,000.

title: GLOBAL EFFORT TO ATTACK PIRATING OF TV SHOWS

title: Notes on Being ScaredProperlyat the Movies
description: Gloved fingers sliding up a banister; a person who's not reflected in a mirroror who casts no shadow, or whose shadow falls in the wrong direction; silence; the onrushing train, which may decapitate a hero or speed a villain toward a lethat errand; the killer's hands fondline the scarf that will strangle the next woman; silence; the engulfing waveany of these breathstoppers can be preposterous if the filmmaker falters: classics can so easily become clichs. Styles in fear do change; what was devastating in earlier decades can seem hilarious now, and those who gibber at the memory of Hangover Square (1945) or The Night of the Hunter (1955) may find that the thrill is nil today. Admittedly, some of Disney is still harrowing, especially when the whale chases Pinocchio, or during the forest fire in Bambi; exchildren who spent time beneath their seats may have the same instinct at 30. And last fall, one adult reported that she would not stand next to Margaret Hamiltononce the wicked witch in The Wizard of Ozin a movie lobby.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: What was it E.M. Forster said about India? Something to the effect that to understand one has either to stay only two weeks or one has to live there 10 years. I probably have got the timing wrong, but the sentiments are definitely Forster's. It is amazing what a little journalistic guessing will do by way of endowing someone with authoritygive a good journalist one week in a strange town and he will take on all the authority of a scholar and prophet. A little background reading and a few careful, sporadic, reportorial observations and your good correspondent will have something made, or at least constructed. title: Nobody (in TV) Loves You When You're Old and Gray
description: Lydia Braggar is the trim, feisty, 70ish chairwoman of Media Watch, a nationwide volunteer force created by the Gray Panthers to keep an eye on how television treats senfor citizens. The Manhattanbased Mrs. Braggar has a speech she delivers around the country on what the watchers have discovered so far; its key passage is that old people as depicted on television are ugly, toothless, sexless, incontinent, senile, confused and helpless. . . . Old age has been so negatively stereotyped that it has become something to dread and feel threatened by.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH concrete patios and terraces do not need paint or other coating to protect them against the elements, homeowners often find it advisable to paint them for cosmetic reasons; for example, when patches must be made or cracks are filled and the patch comes out a different color than the original concrete. Also, people often paint the patios to keep the dust down, or simply because they want a brighter looking surface that will also be easier to keep clean.

title: Smithy Finally May Be Abandoning His Illusions
description: SALISBURY, RhodesiaWhen Prime Minister Ian Smith went on television last week to appeal for white Rhodesians support in a general election, he cut a dramatically different figure than he did When he assumed office on April 13, 1964. His face, taut since the plastic surgery that followed a fighter crash in World War II, loolcecI tnin and pale, and his wavy hair seemed suddenly quite gray. Ironically, the symptoms of exhaustion evoked sympathy even among those whites who have felt that his 12year rebellion against Britain has been a catastrophe for Rhodesia all along.

title: A Confrontation Drama Deals with Dictatorship
description: Sometimes they leave an apple or a banana for the teacher. Occasionally they write notes on the blackboardI love you. Miss Margarida or, more likely, You're a bitch, Miss Margarida or Miss Margarida has crabs. Miss Margarida is a schoolteacher, an authority figure, and the sole speaking character in Miss Margarida's Way, written and directed by Roberto Athayde, a 27yearold Brazilian playwright. The play, now offering public performances at Joseph Papp's Public Newman Theater and starring Estelle Parsons, has had 55 other productionsin countries from Argentina to Japan. In 1973, it was banned, then censored, in Brazil. Annie Girardot played it for yearandahalf in Paris. Michael Cacoyannis chose to direct it on his return to Greece after the overthrow of the military regime. Wherever it has been performed, the play had been controversial; Miss Margarida is a tyrant, dictator and, by the playwright's description, a terrible monster. Depending on one's point of view, she can be seen as a dominating mother, powerful politician, Richard Nixon or even Adolf Hitler.

title: But Franklin Mints Little Gold

title: Bushwick: Nothing To Lose
description: In the mid1960's, the Bushwick section of Brooklyn was refused model city status because, based on 1960 census data, Federal officials considered it predominantly white and nonpoor. Community leaders argued that the statistics were outdated and later took their own census to prove their point in order to qualify for antipoverty programs. Ten nights ago, looters in Bushwick poured into the darkness and put their neighborhood in the news as one of the worst slums in the country.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: David Wallechinsky
description: You could put David Wallerbinsky on a lot of lists. He's a Vegetarian Who Changed His Name Upon Reaching Adulthood and one of an infinitesimal number of Bearded Authors of Books on Laughing Gas. He is a Writing Son of Literary Parents and Wrote his First Poem (about tucking a piece of candy in your cheek and sucking on it all day at kindergarten) Before Reaching the Age of Five. And The Book of Lists, which Wallechinsky compiled with Irving Wallace, his father, Amy Wallace, his 22yearold sister, and a little anonymous maternal assistance, may lead the category of Books CoAuthored by Four Members of the Same Family.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Ten years ago everybody was asking, What's television doing to children's reading? No one knows the answer even now, but the signs are not encouraging. Children read less than their counterparts of 20 years ago; they prefer short snatches that fit the 60second rhythm they have learned from TV, and they go for such nonbooks as The Guinness Book of World Records. Recently, the peak period of youthful reading interest dropped from teenage to preteen. For the first time, the Teen Age Book Club readership is smaller than that of the Arrow Book Club for middle graders.

title: ART VIEW
description: By way of a comprehensive summer attraction, the Whitney Museum has mounted a show called TurnoftheCentury America. It ranges from mural painting to early comic books, and from the documentation of immigrants newly arrived at Ellis Island to likenesses of people who in later life never went short of a square meal : J. Pierpont Morgan, for one, and Henry Clay Frick, for another. Though it has well over 200 items, the show never looks crowded ; the very good catalogue by Patricia Hills is in effect as much a history society as a history of art, and it will cost you $10.

title: But the Russians Still May Not Like What He Has to Say

There has been a lack of coordination on Soviet policy within the Administration, and Mr. Carter has seemed at times to plunge into human rights and arms control initiatives without taking the probable Soviet reaction into account. In the past few weeks, however, the President seems to have taken the criticism to heart.

description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI)Hearings will be held this week on a bill to improve Conrail's commuter rail program and to force continuation of services once provided by bankrupt Northeastern railroads. Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, who introduced the measure, said that it would require Conrail to honor the Erie Lackawanna and Penn Central commitments to the state and local authorities to run commuter trains in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut.

title: SADAT ORDERS HALT TO ATTACKS IN LIBYA, HEEDING ARAB PLEAS
description: CAIRO, July 24President Anwar elSadat tonight ordered Egyptian forces fighting against Libya to observe an im mediate ceasefire.

title: U.S. and Soviet Forces Alarmed Barbadians
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, July 24 (Reuters)The Barbados Government has reported that Soviet Navy vessels and United States planes touched off an alert Friday night that led the island to put Its troops and coast guard into action.

title: Deaths
description: ASHSol, on July 23, 1977, beloved husband of Mary (nee Powell), a devoted, uncle and friend. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Sol and Lillian Ash Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Banks in the West Set Pace With Earnings Power
description: There are banks, and there are banks, as the recent reports of secondquarter earnings show.

title: BRITISH EDITOR ARRESTED AFTER RETURN FROM BERLIN
description: LONDON, July 24 (Reuters)The editor of a British coalminers journal was arrested here today on his return from East Berlin after abandoning a request for political asylum in East Germany.

title: SADAT ORDERS HALT TO ATTACKS IN LIBYA, HEEDING ARAB PLEAS
description: CAIRO, July 24President Anwar elSadat tonight ordered Egyptian forces fighting against Libya to observe an im mediate ceasefire.

title: 6 Americans Triumph In French Track Meet
description: NEURS, France, July 24 (Reuters)American athletes scored six victories at the French track and field championships this weekend.

title: IRMA SELZ ENGELHARDT, 69, THEATRICAL CARICATURIST
description: Irma Selz Engelhardt, a wellknown political and theatrical caricaturist who was professionally known by her maiden name, died Friday at New York Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived at 36 Sutton Place South.

title: Campaign Is Started to Attract More Autosto Betsy Ross Bridge
description: CAMDEN, July 24A campaign has begun to bring more business to the $115 million Betsy Ross Bridge, which has been operating at a deficit since the Delaware River Port Authority opened it 15 months ago.

title: U.S. Study Calls EarlyWarning System in Iceland Obsolescent
description: According to a Congressional Study, the United States earlywarning system and interceptor aircraft in Iceland are obsolescent and have only a limited combat capability against any surprise attack by modern Soviet aircraft

title: Brief Power Failure in Queens
description: About 2,900 Consolidated Edison Company customers were without power briefly yesterday when problems with feeder cables caused blackouts in two sections of Queens, officials said. A Con Edison spokesman said that 1,100 customers lost service between 4:10 P.M. and 5:25 P.M. in Queens Village because of a problem with a feeder cable. Later, in the borough's Little Neck section, 1,800 customers lost electric power between 6:32 P.M. and 7:06 P.M. for similar reasons, the spokesman said.

title: U.S. Five Captures Gold At World Games for Deaf
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 24 (AP) The United States defeated Sweden, 9659, to win a gold medal in basketball, and America's Leo Bond won the 400meter dash in worldclass time at the World Games for the Deaf today.

title: New York F.T.C. Director Resigns
description: Richard A. Givens has resigned, effective Sept. 1, as New York regional director of the Federal Trade Commission. He plans to enter private law practice.

title: 50 Dairy Queen Operators Secede in a Butterfat Dispute
description: TENAFLY, N. J.The curl on top of the big plastic and neon ice cream cone has been cut off. The sign that for 17 years proclaimed Dairy Queen on top of the ice cream stand in the middle of town here has been partially painted over leaving only the word Dairy.

title: JOHN CAMPBELL, 48, OFFICER OF PHILADELPHIA PAPERS
description: John Campbell, 48 years old, an adver tising and marketing executive at Philadelphia Newspapers Inc. (PNI) and a former retail advertising manager of The New York Times, died last night in a Philadelphia hospital. He suffered a cerebral hemorrhage at home last month, after which he never regained consciousness.

title: Soccer
description: YESTERDAY'S MATCHES San Jose 1, Chicago 0. Vancouver 2, Las Vegas 1. Connecticut 2, Rochester 0 (n.). St. Louis 4, Minnesota 0 (n.).

title: Carter Gains in Confidence and Gets a Few Lessons in the Limits of Presidential Power
description: WASHINGTON, July 24One bright morning last May, the President of the United States strode briskly from the Oval Office into the White House Rose Garden and seated himself at a little table where, surrounded by smiling members of Congress, he signed into law a. bill authorizing millions of dollars in emergency funds for farmers caught in the dust at an extended drought.

title: To Repair Detente
description: BOSTONWhether intentionally or inadvertently, United StatesSoviet relations have been deteriorating. In large part, this appears more a result of uncontrolled rhetoric and a shortage of substantive agreements than the product of policy design. It may also be the result of a change in diplomatic styles.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: Buyer Is Reported Found for Lance's Bank Stock
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The sale of the 200,000 shares of National Bank of Georgia stock owned by Bert Lance, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, has been tentatively arranged, the trustee responsible for Mr. Lance's holdings said today.

title: A Sense of Serenity
description: A sense of serenity now possesses the land. The green world is fully green. The early rush for a place in the sun is over. Grapes fatten on the vine. Earliest apples begin to ripen. The hayfield mowed in June is lush and green again. Wild blackberries ripen.

title: Playgoers New Tastes Give Life to NonHits
description: A subtle change has taken place in the questions people ask as they think about going to the theater nowadays. People are always asking for advice, of course, and not necessarily from reviewers. But the advice sought used to be very narrowly, most specifically channeled. Do you think I can get into Plaza Suite'? an outoftowner might ask, or perhaps How long would I have to wait for tickets to Sleuth?

title: Fourth Largest Bank In Wisconsin Sold
description: MILWAUKEE, July 24 (AP)The Midland National Bank of Milwaukee, Wisconsin's fourth largest bank, has been sold to a member bank of the First Bank System Inc. of MinneapolisSt. Paul, company officials announced today.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of post positions

title: Libya Calls Up Reserves
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24  Libya called up its military reserves today as its war with Egypt intensified before President Sadat ordered a ceasefire.

title: In Southeast Asia Neglect Can Be Benign
description: The entry of unified, Communist Vietnam into the United Nations last week and the formal demise last month of the long moribund Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) start a new era in which the United States is a bystander in a region of previous deep involvement.

title: Briton Says He's Less Hopeful Than Carter on the Middle East
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (Reuters)Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain said today that he was not so optimistic as President Carter about the prospects for a Middle East peace settlement this year.

title: BOOK ON A SUICIDE STIRS SUIT IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, July 24A book in the form of a novel allegedly detailing the real reason behind the mysterious 1972 suicide of Yastmari Kawabata, the Nobel Prizewinning author, has prompted legal action here in an effort to halt its sale.

title: Miss Higuchi Wins in Japan
description: OSAKA, Japan, July 24 (AP)Chako Higuchi, the defending champion, shot a threeunderpar 71 today and retained the Japan women's professional golf title. Miss Higuchi, winning the 41st event of her career, had a 54hole total of 218, four under par for the 6,254yard course at PL Country Club.

title: Alaska Oil Stirs Hope For US. Tanker Fleet
description: During the first week of August, barring major catastrophe, an ocean tanker dubbed the Arco Juneau will depart the oil terminal at Valdez, Alaska, carrying the first 120,000 tons of crude oil to flow from the Alaska pipeline.

title: Weather Is Star As Gad Leads Music at River
description: The Summer of Music on the Hudson festival is in Tarrytown, N.Y., on the grounds of Lyndhurst, the impressive Gothic mansion from which Jay Gould once commuted to work by yacht. Even so, it has been aptly described as a poor man's Caramoor. The informal outdoor concerts attract family groups with picnics, blankets and lawn chairs, and the music, performed by the County Symphony, is mostly conservative and familiar.

title: Dierker on Disabled List
description: ST. LOUIS, July 24 (AP)The St. Louis Cardinals said today that, for the second time this season, they had placed Larry Dierker, a righthanded pitcher, on the 21day disabled list. Dierker, who missed the first six weeks of the season while recovering from an ankle fracture, has suffered from recurrences of a shoulder injury in recent weeks.

title: Brown Tells G.I.'s in South Korea To Maintain CombatReadiness
description: CAMP PELHAM, South Korea, July 24 Secretary of Defense Harold Brown peered through field binoculars across the North Korean border today, visited South Korean units and told American soldiers to remain fully combat ready during the gradual withdrawal of United States ground forces from South Korea.

title: MRS. ABZUG PLANNING A BIG PHONE CAMPAIGN
description: In a major shift from her campaign strategy in the United States Senate primary race last year, Bella S. Abzug is spending some $225,000about a third of her campaign budget for a massive telephone campaign to identify and get to the polls her supporters in the Sept. 8 mayoral primary.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Frank DiMango, an elderly bootblack who had been a familiar sight to riders on the Staten Island ferry for more than three decades, drowned Saturday when he fell off a pier into 30 feet of water.

title: Rhodesian Whites Squabble As Their Confidence Wanes
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 24A dozen years after they broke loose from Britain, white Rhodesians are enduring all the travails of rebels in a losing cause.

title: SALVADOR CONFUSED BY AMERICAN MOVES
description: SAN SALVADOR, July 24The Carter Administration's apparent difficulty in translating its. general humanrights campaign into specific policy toward every small nation has caused disarray in relations between the United States and El Salvador.

title: St. Louis Rediscovers Its Past as a New Spirit Rises
description: ST. LOUISThe house at 2635 Locust Street, where the young T. S. Eliot lived and formed impressions that would later help shape his desolate vision of The Waste Land, is now a parking lot.

title: Crowds Flock to Seattle Opera Ring
description: SEATTLE, July 24The Pacific Northwest Festival is based on Wagner's Ring of the Nibelungen. So are other festivals one could name. Bayreuth, or course. Munich last year. But here in Seattle there are two significant differences. The four Ring operas are given in German within a week, to he followed immediately by the cycle in English, also within a week. And the stagings of the Seattle Opera are in conception and execution so old that they seem new.

title: Brooklyn Boy,13, Killed by Bullet Through Window
description: A 13yearold Brooklyn boy standing at the kitchen sink of his family's 13thfloor apartment was shot in the head and fatally wounded yesterday afternoon, the victim of a bullet apparently fired through a window.

title: China Says That Relics Back Claim
description: HONG KONG, July 24 (UPI)Relics dating back more than 2,700 years are being cited by China as evidence supporting its claim to disputed territory along the ChineseSoviet border.

title: Rhodesian Whites Squabble As Their Confidence Wanes
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 24A dozen years after they broke loose from Britain, white Rhodesians are enduring all the travails of rebels in a losing cause.

title: CHARISMATICS LAUD ECUMENICAL ADVANCE
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 24The largest ecumenical conference of charismatic Christians in the nation's history ended today with the movement's leaders proclaiming. the event a major advance to ward Christian unity but cautioning followers against creating divisions in their churches.

title: Nearby Yachting Results
description: AT LARCHMONT Y.C.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of post posit ons.

title: 57th St. to Yesterday on Nostalgia Subway
description: Why would 250 people voluntarily spend an entire afternoon on a New York City subway train?

title: JORDAN URGES CARTER TO VISIT LOOTED AREAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 24Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the executive director of the National Urban League, urged President Carter today to signal his concern for the cities and the poor by visiting and talking to the people in the looted sections of New York City.

title: Nun May Face Reprisal for Backing Abortion Aid
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., July 24  A controversy over the use of Medicald payments for abortions in Vermont, which had raised questions of whether Catholics could be penalized by the church for taking part in decisions by the state, appear to be settled.

title: MAJ. GEN. ROBERT B.DAWSON
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 24 (Reuters)Maj. Gen. Robert Boyd Dawson, a former New Zealand Chief of General Staff, who was decorated for services in World War II, died in Welling?on today. He was 61 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: CaryeBelle Henle, 78, Radiologist For City of Newark for 20 Years
description: Dr. CaryeBelle Henle, radiologist for the City of Newark from 1942 to 1962 and professor of radiology at the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry until 1968, when she was named professor emeritus, died July 14 at her home in Kinnelon, N.J. She was 78 years old.

title: Scientists Fear Heavy Use of Coal May Bring Adverse Shift in Climate
description: Highly adverse consequences may follow if the world, as now seems likely, depends increasingly on coal for energy over the next two centuries, according to a blueribbon panel of scientists.

title: PLANNERS EMPHASIZE TRANSIT EXPANSION
description: A strong recommendation that New York's subway and commuter lines be improved and that adequate power be provided to run them was issued yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

title: The Lazy Days of Summer Settle In at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24  The Austrians call this season SaureGudkenZeit, meaning pickle time, because the small cucumbers are ripening or are being readied for the preserve jar. The origins of the term seem to be in dispute, but the Austrians say it describes the eventless, lazy days of midsummer.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: Front Page 3  No Title

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: HIGH VOLTAGE Few of the ancient Greek tragedies have been successfully transposed from stage to screen in strictly film terms. An exception is Michael Cacoyannis's version of Euripides's Electra (1962), which drew rave reviews for the director and the star, Irene Papas, and almost immediately dropped into oblivion. The import opened here on the eve of a long newspaper strike, with few printed reminders to alert the public to the movie's worth. Bosley Crowther of The New York Times called it a brilliant utilization of the cinematic device to transmute the gold of verbal poetry from one to another art form.

title: Jazz: John Hicks
description: John Hicks, who has served for several years as acccompanist to the vocalist Betty Carter, gave a concert with his trio at the New York Jazz Museum on Saturday. When he is backing Miss Carter, Mr. Hicks is a discreet pianist, one who spins out delicate lacework embroideries and has a knack for coming up with just the right chord voicings but never intrudes on the singer's territory. At the helm of his own group, he is a much more intense and extroverted player. Standards and originals alike become raw material for fulltilt improvisations lasting up to 30 minutes at a stretch.

title: City Help for Stores Damaged in Blackout
description: To facilitate the reopening of businesses damaged during the blackout, the New York City Office of Economic Development is setting up special neighborhood business assistance teams. These units will operate out of the following centers starting today, Mondays through Fridays, between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M.

title: Buyer Is Reported Found for Lance's Bank Stock
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The sale of the 200,000 shares of National Bank of Georgia stock owned by Bert Lance, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, has been tentatively arranged, the trustee responsible for Mr. Lance's holdings said today.

title: Radio
description: 78 AM, WNCN. Overture to L'Olimpiad, Pergolesi; Dance for Harpsichord, Delius; Overture to A Night in Venice, Strauss; Mazurka in A minor, Chopin; The Storm, Tchaikovsky; Divertixento in G minor for 2 Oboes, 2 Horns and Strings, (from K.15), Mozart.

title: New but Flawed Don Giovanni Is Mounted at Glyndebourne Fete
description: LONDONGoing to Glyndebourne is a stately ritual long enjoyed by natives and foreigners alike. You can drive down to the Sussex countryside from London, of course, and you can even stay in nearby Lewes or other country towns. But the most customary way of going is by train, with carfuls of formally dressed operagoers carrying their neatly prepared picnic baskets. They are then bused in from Glynde to the Christie estate of Glyndebourne, and deploy their dinners on the manicured lawns amid rolling hills and curious cows during the 90minute interval.

title: Dance: Unique Pilobolus Troupe
description: NEW LONDON, Conn.,July 24One of the most fascinating aspects of modem dance has been the emergence of the Pilobolus Dance Theater. What fascinates particularly about this company is not its quality, which is high or its popularity, which is already large and clearly increasing, but simple its existence. For this is a company that is sui generis; so far as one can tell it has no predecessor, no choreographic progenitor. It is as new ac anything ever can be in an old world.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: AsBeame Seeks Reelection, City Hall Has Political Tinge
description: The official schedule that is churned out daily at City Hall for Mayor Beame contains the same lists of public appearances as always, but with a crucial difference. In parentheses, the Mayor's office now puts in the word campaign to indicate those itemsthe dropins, remarks and walking toursthat are purely \political.

title: Big Towner, $3.60, Wins OTB Classic
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 24 Another episode in the getrichquick story of Big Towner was recorded today when the favored son of Gene Abbe spurted through the stretch to win the $291,700 MonticelloOTB Classic.

title: U.S. Considers More Assistance To New York for Blackout Losses
description: The Carter Administration disclosed yesterday that it was, exploring sources of additional aid for New York City to help it recover from looting and vandalism during the July 1314 blackout.

title: The Standings
description: Monday, July 25, 1977

title: Jarier, Merzario Victors
description: LE CASTELLET, France, July 24 (AP) JeanPierre Jarier of France and Arturo Merzario of Italy, driving an Alfa Romeo 33SC12, were easy winners of a 311mile race today.

title: Bloom of Dallas Wins 2 More Food Brands
description: Bloom Advertising, Dallas, which got some new product assignments from Anderson Clayton Foods of Dallas late in 1975, has just been rewarded: with two going brands with about $4 million a year in billings. They are Chiffon margarine and Seven Seas salad dressing.

title: Bad'N Big Winner on Coast After J. O. Tobin Is Scratched
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (UPI)Bad N Big held off the stretch challenge of Iron Constitution today and captured the 31st running of the $163,700 Cinema Handicap for 3yearolds at Hollywood Park. Three hours before post time, J.O. Tobin, conquerer of Seattle Slew in the Swaps Stakes earlier this month, was removed from the Cinema by his owners because of a fever.

title: Where to Apply for BlackoutLoss Loans
description: Applications for emergency loans to owners of small businesses damaged by looting and vandalism during the blackout are being accepted by the Federal Small Business Administration at the following locations between 8 A.M. and 7 P.M. on weekdays and 8 A.M. and 5 P.M. on weekends. Starting today, New York City officials will also accept applications at these locations for immediate financial grants.

title: In Memoriam
description: COHEHWIlliam I. July 25, 1976. In loving memory of our dear Bill. Shirley, Stefit & Allan; Cathy & Stanley & the grandchildren

title: JESSE W. BEAMS, 78, A TOP PHYSICIST, DIES
description: Jesse W. Beams, retired chairman of the physics department at the University of Virginia, whose decades of research using centrifuges won him the National Medal of Science in 1967, died of cancer Saturday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 78 years old.

title: BUSY DAY IN NEW YORK FOR ISRAELI PREMIER
description: Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel was as active as a New York mayoral candidate yesterday as he made his way around town meeting reporters, shaking hands with admirers, receiving celebrated visitors and keeping American and Israeli security agents nervously alert for quick changes of plans.

title: The Russians Are Listening
description: At the first hint that the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation or the National Security Agency has been poking into the lives of private citizens by tapping their phones, we can expect frontpage stories, investigations by Congress, action by the Executive. That is as it should be in an open society. But for at least two years, high Washington officials have known that the Soviet Union has been eavesdropping on countless telephone conversations in this country, and nobody outside those official circles was informed.

title: June Tool Orders, 5.1% Below May's, Topped 76 Level
description: June orders for new machine tools fell 5.1 percent below the May level, but were 46.5 percent higher than in June 1976, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend. As a result firsthalf orders were 57.6 percent higher than in the first 6 months of 1976.

title: 20 Dead as Sri Lanka Acts to End Violence
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, July 24 (Reuters) The new Government of Sri Lanka called for peace today and closed taverns and liquor stores after an outburst of political violence in which 20 people died.

title: Mary Roche, 69, Magazine Editor
description: Mary McDermott Roche, the managing editor of House and Garden magazine from 1958 until her retirement in 1971, died Saturday at New York Hospital. She was 69 years old and a longtime resident of Manhattan.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: EBi?ttner DPChicago I. LOBHouston 5, Chicago 6 2BJCruz, Biittner, Murcer, Cardenal. HRCabell (9), Howe (6), Cedeno (4), Biittner (7). SBJCruz, Cabell, SFTrillo.

title: Pop Music: Diana Ross Has It and Charisma Too
description: Diana Ross, who performed at the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium on Saturday night, has It What is it? The answer is not simple. Back in the early days of the silver screen, Clara Bow was said to have itthey called her the it girland the term was widely understood as a euphemism for sex appeal. But to say that Miss Ross has sex appeal, which she does, is not to say that she has it, or has it.

title: Antiboycott Law  Puzzles Energy Industry in Texas
description: HOUSTON, July 24Executives of the energy industry, still puzzling over provisions of a new Federal law limiting the participation of American corporations in the Arab boycott of Israel, are glancing expectantly toward the Commerce Departmept in hope that regulations now being written there will clarify their obligations under the law.

title: Chess:
description: Do you deliberately sacrifice the exchange for a pawn and positional compensation against a man who has made a great part of his very successful career out of exploiting material advantage? That is what the Soviet grandmaster Lev Polugaevsky ventured in the first game of his semifinal candidates match with the Russian defector Viktor Korchnoi in Geneva.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly stated in The Times yesterday that Dr. Charles M. Skeete had died Thursday, in Riverhead, L.I. It was his father, Dr. Curtis Skeete, a retired physician, who died.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly stated in The Times yesterday that Dr. Charles M. Skeete had died Thursday in Riverhead; L.I. It was his father, Dr. Curtis Skeete, a retired physician, who died.

title: Mets Bow, 53, After an Error On Last Out
description: LOS ANGELES, July 24The New York Mets drove a couple of nails into the Cincinnati Reds coffin today when they gave Dave Lopes of the Los Angeles Dodgers another chance with two outs in the bottom of the ninth inning. And Lopes responded by hitting a threerun homer that overpowered the Mets, 53.

title: Mitchell Stays on Falcons
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.. July 24 (AP)Jim Mitchell, the Atlanta Falcon receiver, has decided to stay with the National Football League team, the general manager, Eddie LeBaron, said today. Mitchell, seeking a larger role in the offense, had asked to be traded.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Yachting
description: AT SEACLIFF Y.C.

title: At Least 12 Killed in South Korea As Two Passenger Trains Collide
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 24 (Reuters) At least 12 persons were killed and 53 injured in a crash of two passenger trains in South Korea today a railroad spokesman said here.

title: The People Behind the Campaign to Shoot Down the B1 Bomber Project
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The death of the BI bomber was made imminent late last month in the bright lights and airconditioning of a White House news conference. But the fatal blow to the huge plane may really have been struck in a cramped. stifling thirdfloor office on Capitol Hill, amid a litter of paper and a tangle of telephone wires.

title: Michael Berger Weds Miriam Janet Haines
description: Miriam Janet Haines, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Haines of Great Neck, L. I., was married yesterday morning to Michael Gary Berger, son of Jacob Berger of Union, N. J., and Edith Rosefsky of Binghamton, N.Y., and Bay Harbor Islands Fla.

title: Town Acts to Curb Home Cost
description: DAVIS, Calif., July 24 (UPI)The City Council of this university community of 34,000 population has adopted an emergency ordinance designed to curb inflation of housing prices caused by speculation.

title: BURGLARS ROB L.I. HOMES OF SOCIALITES AT PARTY
description: After breaking into the homes of two socially prominent women while they were attending a fundraising affair, burglars in Southampton, L.I. escaped with $200,000 worth of jewelry early yesterday, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Auto Racing
description: AT ELKHART LAKE, WIS.

title: Marty Robbins Back on Track
description: NASHVILLE, July 24 (UPI)Marty Robbins, the countrywestern singer who retired as a parttime race car driver two years ago, says he has changed his mind and will enter the Talladega 500 on Aug. 7.

title: HEATH SAYS CARTER STAND MAY CLASH WITH DETENTE
description: LONDON, July 24 (Reuters)Former Prime Minister Edward Heath of Britain said today that President Carter's stand on behalf of human rights might well conflict with the overall aims of promoting dtente at the European security review conference now under way in Belgrade.

title: It's All Quiet Close to the Western Desert Front
description: MERSA MATRUH, Egypt, July 24A group of Bedouin women walked down the sandy street into town with their troop of sheep and goats, while a family in a brightly painted donkey cart careened around the corner and a small group of townspeople gathered at the railroad station to wait for the daily train.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JULY 25, 1977

title: Vilas and Gottfried Advance To Net Final in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)Guillermo Vilas and Brian Gottfried, the topseeded players, had to struggle early in their matches today but overcame their problems and advanced to the final of the $125,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament.

title: Finishes 2 Shots Ahead of Nancy Lopez on 292
description: CHASKA, Minn., July 24Hollis Stacy, who failed to crack under pressure today, contrary to what many had expected, played a strong and steady game to become the youngest professional to win the United States Women's Open golf championship.

title: Surprising Orioles Top Brewers Twice and Leap Past Red Sox Into First
description: The Baltimore Orioles, with little of the glamour and the power of the Yankees or the Boston Red Sox, continue to confound the baseball experts and bedevil their closest rivals in the American League East.

title: Legal Aid Society May Turn Out To Be Unlikely Victim of Blackout
description: An unlikely victim of the July 1314 blackout may turn out to be the Legal Aid Society, which, in the course of defending needy clients, is now often identified with looters.

title: Hendrik de Leeuw, An Author of Books About Traveling, 86
description: Hendrik de Leeuw, the author of many travel books, died Saturday in New York Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: Mormon Turnout Overwhelms Women's Conference in Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITYWhen representatives of the International Women's Year organization here began planning their statewide convention several months ago, they invited a number of Utah women's groups to participate in hopes of showing, as the coordinating committee put it, that diversity does n't have to divide people.

title: Market Place
description: Eli Broad, chief executive officer of Kaufman & Broad Inc., the nation's largest builder of singlefamily homes, thinks Wall Street is wrong about his company today  just as he thought in April 1972.

description: AT RIVERSIDE Y.C.

title: Strikers Win 7th Straight, Near Title
description: Another victory, their seventh in a row, by the Fort Lauderdale Strikers has bought them closer to winning the Eastern Division off the North American Soccer League.

title: Advertising
description: Last week, which began with the switch of Borden's Wyler Foods to Ted Bates & Company, ended with the move of two other healthysized advertising accounts. The JackintheBox fast food chain was assigned to Wells, Rich, Greene. And the Marriott Corporation moved all of its advertising business to Ogilvy & Mather and its subsidiary, Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: Be It Known: Cities Are Not Harmful to Your Health
description: TORONTOThings may be looking up for the United States cities. Just a few years ago, everyone from Gerald R. Ford to Johnny Carson was getting a lot of mileage out of jokes about our great urban centers, especially New York, our largest and greatest.

title: U. S. TO OPEN HEARINGS ON RAILTRANSIT BILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 24A Senate transportation subcommittee opens hearings tomotrow on a bill sponsored by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, to clear the way for improved and expanded rail commuter service by Conrail.

title: Cesar Chavez Visiting Manila
description: MANILA, July 24 (Reuters)Cesar Chavez, the California labor leader, arrived here today as a guest of the Philippine Government to receive an award from President Ferdinand E. Marcos in recognition of his trade union work. About 50,000 Filipinos living in the United States are members of the United Farm Workers Union, led by Mr. Chavez.

title: Commodity Investing
description: some managers of investment portfolios, finding it hard to protect their clients capital from inflation, are thinking of trading in commodity futures. This would be done in a diversified manner and would involve a relatively small percentage of total assets. The rest would remain in stocks and bonds. Page 35.

title: Before and After Billy's Phone Rang
description: For 24 hours, the whispers had been circulating that Billy Martin was about to be discharged and now, shortly before noon yesterday, the manager of the New York Yankees was sitting barefoot at the desk in his office deep in the Yankee Stadium catacombs. I feel like those guys on death row, Billy Martin said, forcing a smile. I need a reprieve from the Governor. Wearing a white sportshirt and pink slacks, the manager was smoking a cigar and sipping coffee from a plastic cup. But if they were going to make a change today, I think I would have heard before this, Billy Martin said. You usually get a phone call in the morning so you don't come to the ball park. And then the phone rang. Billy Martin. answered it, listened a moment, said, I'll be up and put the phone down.

title: Highly Rated HealthCare System In Jersey Is Believed in Jeopardy
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J., July 24  The healthcare system in this rural section of western New Jersey, regarded as a model for the test of the country, is in danger of coming apart.

title: Courageous Gains a Split With Hood's Independence
description: NEWPORT, RI., July 24The action was exciting but inconclusive at the America's Cup trials today as Courageous and Independence split two races. Ted Hood, the skipper of Independence, twice sailed into the spectator fleet before a start and Ted Turner took Courageous right in after him. There were no collisions but close calls and the fleet scattered quickly, like chickens with two foxes in the hen house.

description: WASHINGTON, July. 24 (UPI)  The Senate Democratic leader, Robert C. Byrd Jr., said today that he would take as many votes as necessary to shut off a Republican filibuster by the end of, the week and pass legislation to provide public financing for Senate elections.

Baum, national vice president of Bnai Zion, the American fraternal Zionist organization, died Thursday at Jewish Memorial Hospitalafter being struck by an automobile at Broadway and 207th Street. He was 73 years old and lived at 3299 Cambridge Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

description: PARIS, July 24 (AP)Francois Jauffret won in singles today to clinch a victory for France over Rumania, moving the French into the European zone semifinals of the Davis Cup.

title: Patricia Ann Larkin, 46, Principal At Public School 129 in Queens
description: Patricia Ann Larkin, principal of Public School 129 in the College Point section of Queens, died Friday in St. Agnes Hospital, Point Pleasant, N.Y. She was 46 years old and lived at 1523 Central Park Avenue in Yonkers.

title: Pakistan Seeks New Financing To Fight Deficit
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Pakistan has begun a search for new sources of international financing to help it battle a growing budget deficitthe legacy of months of political chaos and natural disasters. The disorders, rioting and accompanying general strikes, coupled with widespread floods, have cost the nation an estimated $1 billion or more and brought the economy close to paralysis.

title: Voles Reduce Upstate Apple Crop
description: HIGHLAND, N.Y.The pine vole,a small underground rodent that is about as big as a thumb, is devastating the apple orchards of Ulster County.

description: ST, LOUISThe house at 2635 Locust Street, where the young T. S. Eliot lived and formed impressions that would later help shape his desolate vision of The Waste Land, is now a parking lot.

description: Harry E. Resseguie, the chief of the Washington bureau of Fairchild Publications from 1941 until his retirement in 1956, died Saturday at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Pine Plains, N.Y.

description: PARIS, July 24Bernard Thevenet won the Tour de France bicycle endurance race here today, finishing the threeweek grind in a steady rain and taking no chances of losing the comfortable lead he had built in the last week.

description: WASHINGTON, July 24The Carter Administration will Make every effort this week to demonstrate its full backing for Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy and his minority Christian Democratic Government, which depends for survival on Communist support in Parliament.

description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 24 (AP) Peter Gethin of Britain won his first CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup race in seven years today.

description: WASHINGTON, July 24A review of the role of women in the armed forces has concluded that present laws and policies deny women their rights and that women should be able to fill at least twice and perhaps three times as many jobs as the Defense Department envisions.

title: 'First Nudie,' New Film, Sets Sex to Music
description: At the conclusion of "The First Nudie Musical," Stephen Nathan and Cindy Williams, a clean-scrubbed couple with matching pug noses, decide to get married, he proposing shyly and she all aglow. This show of naivet, however touching, comes as something of a surprise, since the pair have just shuffled their way through a musical number about oral sex.Mr. Nathan is playing the son of the head of a failing movie studio, and it seems his only means of salvaging the family business involves producing, and even performing in, the world's first pornographic musical (hence the title). Surely there must have been a better way.Since sex, at least under optimum conditions, is no laughing matter, and since comedy isn't often erotic, Mr. Nathan's brainstorm turns out to be a losing propositioneven though, according to Bruce Kimmel's screenplay, the movie-within-a-movie knocks 'em dead and saves the day.Mr. Kimmel is something of a quadruple threat, since he has also composed a tuneless score (sample lyric: "Gotta sing, gotta dance/While I'm taking off my pants"), co-directed with Mark Haggard (on a $200,000 budget during two weeks' time, though the finished product looks considerably more fly-by-night than the figures would indicate), and cast himself in the third lead, as a fledgling director whose bashfulness borders on idiocy.At the other end of the acting spectrum is Miss Williams. Her performance, despite some gamy dialogue, isn't much of a departure from her television work, but her pure sit-com mugging makes her the most mercifully subdued player in the bunch.

title: Volunteers Dig for Fun and College Credit in Israel
description: TEL APHEK, IsraelA fierce midmorning sun. The sound of spades and trowels scratching at the earth. Suddenly, from a hole in the ground, a young woman's voice, the inflections definitely those of a New Yorker, singing a song from Annie Get Your Gun.

title: Newman Is Third
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 24 (AP)Paul Newman, the actor, finished third in a TR6 after starting last in the D Producion race today in a benefit for the Deborah Heart and Lung Center. The race was won by Tom Robertson of Gales Ferry, Conn., driving a Lotus.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Call it sentiment, or the approach of Senility, but I find both pleasure and oldfashioned comfort in whiling away an occasional afternoon in my own reflection of things past. Just recently, browsing through a handwritten service manual from a Swiss hotel school, was amused at the following admonitions for wouldbe hotel keepers or members of a hotel staff.

title: Poll Finds Most Residents Believe That State Government Is Corrupt
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 24In a state once tainted by corrupt politicians, more than 75 percent of New Jersey residents believe their state and Federal Governments are corrupt, and their skepticism about honesty in government has grown since Watergate, according to the findings in the latest New Jersey Images Poll taken by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: Youth Jobs: Puzzles and Progress
description: President Carter's initial reaction to the blackout and looting in New York City was doubly puzzling. The first puzzle was that he limited his earliest expressions interest to the need for a national power grid and the availability of the National Guard in case of future power failures in New York. It took a week before he got around fto addressing the national problem that the blackout exposed. Finally, in a radio interview on the National Black Network, he said; as we wish he had said more promptly: The number one contributing factor to crime of all kinds is high unemployment among young people, particularly those who are black or Spanishspeaking or in a minority age or group where they have such a difficult time getting jobs in times of economic problems.

title: 15 East Europeans, on Vacation In Greece, Ask Political Asylum.
description: ATHENS, July 24 (AP)Fifteen vacationing East Europeans have sought political asylum in Greece over the last week, a police spokesman said today.

title: Nancy Prince, N.Y.U. Alumna, Married to Jonathan B. Albin
description: Nancy M. Prince and Jonathan B. Albin were married yesterday afternoon at the Quidnessett Country Club in North Kingston, R.I., by Chief Justice Edward P. Gallogly of the Rhode Island Family Court.

title: Kuwait Opens Iraq Border
description: KUWAIT, July 24 (Reuters)The Kuwait Government announced today that it was reopening its border with Iraq, which has been closed to Kuwait citizens since 1972.

title: ARSON CHARGE ADDED TO 9 MURDER COUNTS
description: PROSPECT, Conn., July 24A former convict who was charged yesterday with murdering nine members of his foster brother's family was also charged today with arson.

title: Danny Grossman Is Growing With His Own Dance Troupe
description: NEW LONDON. Conn., july 25Danny Williams Grossman, who in the still comparatively recent days when he was dancing with Paul Taylor was known as plain Danny Williams, is more or less a new comer to the odd business of his own dance company. His performance at the 1977 American Dance Festival here at Connecticut College last night marked him as a newcomer of distinct promise.

title: Space ShuttleOrbiter Flight Today
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., July 25 (UPI)The Space ShuttleOrbiter was pronounced ready today for takeoff tomorrow morning for the last of its captive flights, bolted to the back of a jumbo jet, in a dress rehearsal of its first free flight next month.

title: Of Time, Tashi and Peter Serkin
description: Peter Serkin, once a symbol of rebellious youth, turned 30 this week. What better moment to catch up on the pilgrim's progress of the slim pianist whose refusal to follow the staid conventions of concert life made him something of a youthcult hero in the 1960's? ft is no problem to discover where he is (living in a spartanly furnished apartment on upper West End Avenue), but, in the, ading jargon of another time, you wonder where he's at, in 1977.

title: Cheerful Begin Returns to Israel, Says He Repaired Ties With U.S.
description: TEL AVIV, July 25Prime Minister Menahem Begin returned triumphantly from his mission to the United States today and told a roomful of Government officials, politicians and journalists he had undone the damage to relations with the Carter Administration that he said had been caused by the policies of Yitzhak Rabin and the former Government.

title: Boy's Fatal Shooting In Brooklyn Called A Freak Accident
description: The police said yesterday that the fatal shooting of a 13yearold boy in the Fort Greene Houses in Brooklyn was the result of a freak accident, rather than the work of a sniper.

title: Brazil's Primary Begins, With 10 Apparently in Line for Top Post
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 25  A few weeks ago, only a handful of Brazilians knew anything about the life, hobbies, thinking or habits of a withdrawn but influential army general named Joao Baptista Figueiredo.

title: HEBERT GRUNFELD
description: Herbert Grunfeld, chairman of Metal lurg, producers of ferroalloys here and in Europe, died Sunday at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 69 years old. Surviving are his wife, the former Erika Bos, and a brother, Ernst.

description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 25 (AP)A Honduran Air Force plane carrying religious pilgrims crashed today shortly after takeoff from Yoro, 70 miles northeast of this capital, killing 23 persons and injuring 11.

description: CAIRO, July 25A precarious ceasefire appeared to be taking hold in the LibyanEgyptian border region today as the Government of Col. Muammar elQaddaft studied a set of Egyptian conditions Put to it through Algerian and Palestinian mediators.

description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Congress today ratified a compromise proposed by President Carter and approved a conference report on the $10.4 billion public works bill after conferees emphasired that the Clinch River Breeder Reactor was very much alive.

description: A special research program of the Internal Revenue Service has shown a substantial decline in the willingness of small businesses to pay their taxes, costing the Government billions of dollars. Page 39.

title: Surgical Teamwork Gives Disease Victims a New Life
description: At the age of 17, !Cathy was an honor student in her Georgia high school and a talented musician, but her grotesque appearance so frightened people that she shied away from all but a few close friends. Her jaws didn't meet, so never she took her food in front of anyone, because she was too embarrassed to fish out the food that stuck in her mouth.

The series will open on Oct. 28 with the Milwaukee Symnhonv. under the direction of Kenneth'Schermerhorri, and close next spring with a sixconcert Beethoven cycle. description: With summer, television viewing levels decline, and the news documentary inevitably gets trotted out for publicservice commendations. Part of this week's collection includes The Retirement Revolution. on CBS tonight at 8, and Africa's Defiant White Tribe, on NBC tomorrow at 10.

title: Curbing the Wiretappers
description: Presidents since Franklin D. Roosevelt have claimed inherent power to tap telephones for national security purposes. Abuses such as the F.B.I.'s monitoring of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and Nixonera taps on journalists and Administration officials grew out of that claimed power, which, happily, is explicitly denied in the foreign intelligence wiretap bill now being considered by the Senate Judiciary Committee. The bill would be even better, however, if it were cured of one major defect.

title: Korean Businessman Linked to $200,000 in Gifts to U.S. Officials in 7576
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Kim Han Cho, a relatively unknown South Korean who is alleged to have been an agent of his country's Central Intelligence Agency, distributed $200,000 in cash gifts and favors to American officials and members of Congress up until a year ago, according to a former director of the agency. Kim Hyung Wook, the former intelligence head, said in an interview that the money was spent from mid1975 to mid1976. In previous testimony before House subcommittee he identified Kim Han Cho as the source of some Korean largesse.

title: BANKERS AND UNIONS PLEDGE $2.5 BIWON FOR CITY AND M.A.C.
description: New York City's major banks and municipal employee pension funds have agreed to the refinancing of $2.5 billion in debt issued by the city and the Municipal Assistance Corporation. This will clear the way for the city to sell its own securities to the public, possibly as soon as September.

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Decline
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

title: Hong Kong Seizes Forged Banknotes
description: HONG KONG, July 25 (Reuters)Hong Kong authorities yesterday seized forged banknotes with a face value of more than $700,000 and also printing plates for counterfeiting Thai, Indonesian and Hong Kong currency, the police said.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: In the perspective of history, I'm not sure tht the move to negotiated commission rates on Mayday in 1975 will have really served a public purpose, said Paul Kolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, in a recent interview following the announcement that he would soon be leaving the top administrative job in the nation's second largest securities market.

title: LUCY MORGENTHAU HEINEMAN
description: Lucy Morgenthau Heineman, who was active in civic and college affairs, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.

title: The Lion of Swaziland. at 78, Pragmatist of Statecraft
description: MBABANE, Swaziland, July 22In Africa, a continent with its share of improbable leaders, there have been few more unusual than King Sobhuza II, septuagenarian who counts his wives by the score and rules autocratically through a cabinet composed mostly of his sons, sonsinlaw and cousins.

title: Firemen in a New Image
description: To the Editor There was a picture in yesterday's Times showing a New York City fireman turning off a hydrant and telling a group of young children to go to the nearest police precinct to pick up a sprinkler.

description: PHILADELPHIA. July 25 (AP)The Soviets defeated the Cleveland Nets for the second time in four days, 2119, in World Team Tennis. The Russians Pulled out the victory when Olga Morozova and Marino Kroshina scored 63 triumph over Peggy Michel and Marianna Simionescu.

description: A woman tentatively won the right yesterday to join the Basking Ridge Fire Department, even though firemen had contended that women were physically inferior to men when it came to fighting fires.

This year the concerts are featuring an exceptional variety of Performing artists. The programs themselves also include more interesting and less familiar music, and fewer standard selections.
