title: SENATORS BACK LANCE AND ABANDON INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, July 25A Senate commite accepted today Budget Director Bert Lance's content:sc that there was nothing improper in his personal or business finances and decided not to investigate them further.

title: Letters
description: In his OpEd article of July 6, Maj. Gen. George J. Keegan Jr. (former chief of Air Force intelligence, now retired) criticizes President Carter's decision to cancel production of the B1 and to rely instead on nucleararmed longrange cruise missiles launched from B52's or later from some other aircraft. In this he sees the Administration as opting for the ignoble military unpreparedness of the 1930's. Further, he raises the alarm that the Russians with their highenergybeans research, hope to neutralize the Intercontinental ballistic missile before the end of the next decade and he criticizes the production of the Trident submarine.

title: Rebuilding
description: New York City and its people have responded quickly to our editorial suggestions that victims of looting need outright grants as well as longterm loans to recover from their disaster. Following the Mayor's appeal for help, $1.7 million in voluntary gifts and pledges were made to the Citizens Committee for New York, 630 Fifth Avenue, which was established to receive and disburse money to those victimized by the looters. The grants will be made by the Emergency Aid Commission, seven unpaid citizens selected by the city. John Procope, pubusher of The Amsterdam News, is chairman. The first checks should be issued by the middle of the week.

title: Series of Southampton Burglaries Nets Thief $250,000 in Jewelry
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 25 One of the country's wealthiest enclaves, a cluster of mansions on beautiful grounds here close to the shore, has been hit in the last month by five burglaries that have yielded the thief about $250,000 in jewelrY.

title: GOLF OIL NET UP 3.8% AND REVENUE 11.6% IN SECOND QUARTER
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday a 3.8 percent gain in secondquarter net income on a revenue improvement of 11.6 percent. Firsthalf net income, however, slipped by 5.9 percent even though revenues ran 12.8 percent higher than a year ago.

title: UALEARNINGS SURGED 69.6% IN 2D QUARTER
description: UAL Inc., owner of the nation's largest airline, reported yesterday that its sec ondquarter earnings soared 69.6 percent! above the 1976 level. Pan American World Airways Inc., meanwhile, announced a riofirit of 82.4 percent for the three months ended June 30:

title: $155,000 WAS A LOAN, MANDEL TELLS COURT
description: BALTIMORE, July 25Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland surprised the prosecution today at his currupticn trial in Federal District Court here by producing a handwritten, threeyearold I.O.U. in which he promised to repay one of his codefendants S155,000 that The Government has charged was a bribe.

title: Mineola Jeweler Held Up
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 25 (AP)  A jeweler was robbed of $25,000 in cash and jewelry tonight when a man broke into his shop here, the Nassau County police said.

title: A Postelection Curfew Is Eased by Sri Lanka As Violence Dies Down
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, July 25 (Reuters) A curfew imposed in eight districts of Sri Lanka after postelection violence which 34 people died was relaxed today as life returned to normal.

title: Assignments Benefit Retired State Justices
description: Former justices of New York State Supreme Court received court appointments in the months following their retirement, according to The New York Times study of court records.

title: Government Sector Gains as Fed Injects Reserves
description: The Federal Reserve injected sonic overnight reserves into the banking systern yesterday that, in turn, spurred some modest upside activity in the Government market.

title: Tendonitis Puts Fidrych Of Tigers Out 21 Days
description: DETROIT, July 25 (AP)  The faltering Detroit Tigers disclosed today that their ailing star pitcher, Mark (The Bird) Fidrych, had tendonitis and would be out at least two weeks. He was placed on the 21day disabled list retroactive to July 20, because of the ailment in his right arm.

title: DOLLAR HITS LOWS AGAINST THE MARK
description: The dollar fell to record lows in two European money markets yesterday and also closed down in most other exchanges, The Associated Press reported.

title: Waldheim Cancels Visit to Peking Because of Accident to Relatives
description: VIENNA, July 25 (Reuters)Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations has canceled a visit to Peking because his daughter and motherinlaw were involved in a headon automobile collision in Austria, United Nations offidais said today.

title: Restoration in Galveston Success Raising Problems
description: GALVESTON, Tex.The apartment in a converted printing shop that Emily Whiteside moved into in 1975 was the first example of an old industrial building being converted into residential use in this city, and for a while.

title: 2 INDICTED IN FRAUD IN L.I. CATERING DEAL
description: A prominent Long Island contractor and the former chief executive officer of three locals of the International Union of Operating Engineers were indicted yesterday on charges of mail fraud and racketeering in connection with the acquisition of Colonie Hill, Long Island's largest catering concern.

title: Shoemaker Victor In Big Coast Race
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 25 (AP) Bill Shoemaker rode Today n Tomorrow to a startling upset today in the S171,700 Sunset Handicap as Hollywood Park closed its 36th racing season.

title: Rich Lands Plan I.M.F. Aid to Poor
description: PARIS, July 25Finance ministers from the United States and other rich countries, including the major oil exporting nations, are to meet here Aug. 6 to discuss a new program for sustaining the world's economic recovery by helping financially pressed nations pay for their imports.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York State Insurance Department has granted automobile insurance rate increases to seven ens,panies that provide coverage for nearly 700,000 motorists in New York State.

title: Heads of U.S.T.A., West Side Club Volley Charges on Open Shift
description: A heated confrontation took place yesterday between the president of the United States Tennis Association and the president of the West Side Tennis Club over the plan to move the Open championships from Forest Hills to Flushing Meadow Park next year.

title: OTTAWA PERPLEXED AS DISSENSION RISES
description: MONTREAL, July 25The federal Government in Ottawa, often attacked for wielding too much power, has had to sit by powerlessly while the provinces engage in practices that further contribute to the crisis in Canada's national unity.

title: MidJuly Sales At G.M. Off 0.8% As Contests End
description: DETROIT, July 25 (AP)A postcontest lull at the General Motors Corporation sent newcar sales in midJuly down percent from yearearlier levels, the domestic industry reported today.

title: Japanese Says That Sea Creature Could Be Related to Shark Species
description: TOKYO, July 23 (AP)A marine biologist says a :10foot, twoton sea creaturs netted by a Japanese trawler off New Zealand in April showed a biochemical makeup similar to that of a kind of shark.

title: Administration Bars Delay Asked by Byrd In RadarPlane Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (Reuters)The Carter Administration told a Senate panel today that it would not delay the proposed sale of seven radar planes to Iran, despite a request by the Senate Democratic leader to defer it until next year.

title: Manufacturer Says a Study Shows XRay Scanner Can Reduce Costs
description: The leading manufacturer of computerized tomography Xray scanners yesterday issued results of a study that it said showed the devices could save rather than increase health care costs if the scan were substituted for the nowstandard diagnostic tests.

title: Lebanon and P.L.O. Act to Ease Tension
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25Lebanon and the Palestine Liberation Organization today reached agreement on measures intended to ease the tense situation near the border with Israel and to reduce the level of armament at 14 Palestinian camps in this country. The agreement under the supervision of Syria, which has 30,000 troops here serving under the Arab League flag.

title: Letters: On Mandatory Retirement
description: Your July 8 editorial Retirement on Short Notice criticizes as precipitate the New York State Assembly's decision to prohibit agebased mandatory retirement.

title: Swan Halts Dodgers, 10, On 3Hitter
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25If you were wondering what the New York Mel would do for an encore after their lastgasp defeat on Sunday, the word tonight was that they came up with winning new act: Craig Swan pitched a nifty? threehitter that stopped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 10.

title: PRESIDENT REJECTS JORDAN'S CRITICISM
description: WASHINGTON. July 25  President Carter charged today that criticism of his Administration's record on blacks and the poor damaged the hopes and aspirations of those poor people.

title: Earnings at The Times Rose 12.4% In 2d Quarter to a Record Level
description: The New York Times Company yesterday reported secondquarter earnings of $6.9 million, or 60 cents a snare, up 12.4 percent from the $6.2 million, or 54 cents a share, it reported during the comparable period of 1976.

title: 3 Plead Guilty in 76 Chowchilla Kidnapping of 26 Children and Driver
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 25In an unexpected action barn today in Alameda County Court, the three young men charged in the 1976 kidnapping of 26 Chowchilla schoolchildren and their bus driver pleaded guilty.

title: EDWARD FLYNN, DIES AT 63
description: Edward Francis Flynn of Pelham Manor, N. Y., executive vice president and creative services director at the Humbert & Jones Advertising agency, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: This Teacher Calries the Bag for Golfers on 2 Pro Tours
description: Most regular caddies on the men's and women's professional tours are young single men who never saw a hickory shaft on a golf club. Many of them are low handicap golfers and most of them arc single, which permits them to travel constantly. Some are college, graduates and at least one of the women's regulars is a recent law school graduate. But Kathy Whitworth, who has won more money than any woman in golf history, has a summer caddie who has seen the game grow for the last 45 years since he began toting allleather bags full of hickory sticks in the 1930's. Miss Whitworth took off for a week's rest after tying for 10th place in the United States Women's Open Sunday, so her caddie, Jim Dever, headed back to his New Jersey home for a couple of days of rest.

title: Brooklyn Welfare Family Linked To $40,000 ArsonforProfit Plot
description: A Brooklyn family has engaged in arson for profit for more than seven years and received more than $40,000 in special welfare benefits for relocation and replacement costs, according to a report by the State Office of Welfare Inspector General.

title: East Orange Mayor, in Shift, Restores U.S. Funds to Tenants' Group
description: EAST ORANGE, July 25Mayor William S. Hart reversed himself today and restored Federal financing to this Essex County communitys only tenant group, ending a dispute that began last spring.

title: Doctors Reconnect Severed Arm
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 25Doctors at White Plains Hospital Medical Center performed an apparently successful operation yesterday to reconnect the severed arm of a 38yearold man who had fallen from the roof of a sixstory apartment building.

title: Observations on the Art Of Rebuilding a Child's Face
description: The pictures that were taped to the operatingroom wall were of a pretty 6yearold girl named Deirdre, not her real name. A doctor said her brain might have been slightly injured by the accident, but in the photos, sheI'm a flyer in uniform, and she's proud to be seen with me. But later, when I take her home, and start to kiss her good night at the moment my appeared friendly and cheerful.

title: Letting the Buyer Be Aware
description: The patient shopping for a doctor, the homeowner shopping for an architect, the smallbusiness man shopping for an accountant, all find themselves in much the same situation. The charges for professional services cover a wide rangebut there is no easy way to find out exactly what they are. An internist in the New York City area, for example, may charge $15 for a visitor $50. But an assortment of professional codes and legal prohibitions have long made the advertising of prices unethical or illegal. This confusing situation may be clarified somewhat on Thursday, when the New York State Board of Regents votes on a package of proposed revisions to the rules of conduct for the 29 professions that it regulates.

title: Green Giant Units Sold
description: The Green Giant Company, which reported a loss on processed meat operations for fiscal 1977, said yesterday that Illini Beef Packers inc had completed the acquisition of Green Giant's processed meat subsidiaries, the Schweigert Meat Company )f Minneapolis and the Copeland Sausage Company of Alachua, Fla. The terms involved an unspecified amount of cash and notes, Green Giant said.

title: About NewYork
description: The two men from North Carolina walked down the track toward the empty, silent train parked in the IND yard at Kew Gardens, Queens. It was not yet 6 AM. and the grudgingly emerging daylight was lightening to dirty, gray Monday morning. No, would not be the best of days, but the two men eyed the eight long, new R46 cars with cool professional eyes and knew what they would have to do. They would take over the train.

title: Buehler Walking the Sands in OpenBeach Campaign
description: BARNEGAT LIGHT, July 25It was a poor beach day and an even worse one to be looking for an audience, but State Senator Herbert J. Buehler, Democrat of West Allenhurst, pulled on his leans, a sweatshirt, raincoat and floppy hat today and headed for the oceanfront. This wass the third day of his weeklong 100mile trek from Sandy Hook to Cape May designed to call attention to a pending bill that would guarantee greater access to public beaches and impose some state oversight of municipal beach operations.

title: HEBERT GRUNFELD
description: Herbert Grunfeld, chairman of Metallurg, producers of ferroalloys here and in Europe, died Sunday at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Knicks and Nets Discussing Solution at Judge's Urging
description: A Federal judge urged the Knicks and the Nets yesterday to try to resolve their dispute. The parties immediately heeded the judge's suggestion and met into the night and the early morning with Larry O'Brien. the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, and their respective lawyers.

title: Orioles Top Brewers on Criscione s Clout in 11th
description: The Baltimore Orioles seem to enjoy being in first place in the American League East and evidently plan to stay there for a while.

title: Director of Godfather Pictures Stakes Future on Vietnam Film
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25In the rolling wine country north of San Francisco, Francis Ford Coppola is filming scenes this week of a time that most Americans would like to regard as long ago and far awaythe period of the war in Vietnam.

title: 2 Nominees for Nuclear Regulatory Unit. Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Three public affairs lobbying groups today opposed two of the three men President Carter has nominated to serve on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: State Firefighters Block Spread Of Last of 3 Pine Barrens Fires
description: weary firemen were satisfied yesterday that they had blocked the spread of the last of three weekend forest fires in the parched Pine Barrens of Central New Jersey that killed four volunteer firemen and destroyed 4,533 acres of woodland.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 25Governor Byrne, citing the success of New Jersey's mandatory test for autoemission pollution, urged support today for the strong new cleanair legislation pending in Congress.

title: Steinbrenner Backs Martin, But Lists Tight Set of Rules
description: Rain postponed the YankeesKansas City Royals baseball game at Yankee Stadium last night, and George Steinbrenner, the Yankees principal owner, seized the opportunity to clear the air on the rumors concerning Manager Billy Martin.

title: BANKERS AND UNIONS PLEDGE $2,5 BILLION FOR CITY AND MAC.
description: New York City's major banks and municipal employee pension funds have agreed to the refinancing of $2.5 billion in debt issued by the city and the Municipal Assistance Corporation. This will clear the way for the city to sell its own securities to the public, possibly as soon as September.

title: Yorick Blumenfeld Is the author of Future Tense. about doomsday.
description: Yorick Blumenfeld Is the author of Future Tense. about doomsday.

title: Reed Chooses an Aide
description: Willis Reed has completed his coaching staff. The new Knick head coach will name Nat Frazier, the Morgan State University basketball coach, his second aide, joining Dick McGuire. The new assistant is not related Walt Frazier, the Knick guard.

title: JazzDisco: By Norman Connors
description: Crossing over from jazz to pop is nothing new, but Norman Connors, who performed in a packed A.very Fisher Hall on Sunday, has crossed further than most of his fellow fusion musicians. A few years ago, Mr. Connors was the drummer for Pharaoh Sanders, Sam Rivers and other avantgarde jazzmen. Now he is an artistrecord producer who has launched the pop careers of Michael Henderson, Jean Carn and Phyllis Hyman, all of whom sang hits on Mr. Connors's albums before making albums of their own.

title: On the S.E.C. Report on City Finances
description: Three months is not a great deal or time to come to know an agency of some 2,000 people. Nevertheless, In the three months that I have been chairman of the Securities and Exrinnm,A Commission I have developed a great respect for the integrity, ability and dedication of my fellow commissioners, and of the members of the commission's staff. It is not hard to see why the commission has consistently been identified as the best of the independent regulatory agencies.

title: CARTER ENERGY PLAN CALLED OVERSTATED IN A REPORT BY G.A.O.
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The General Accounting Office charged today that the Carter energy program had significantly overstated its probable achievements to the extent that oil imports could rise instead of fall between now and 1985.

title: The Standings
description: Kansas City at New York (n. ppd, rain).

title: The Moral Superiority of the Neutron Bomb
description: Today I was killed by one of NATO's neutron nukes. Yes, painfully, dizzily, I'm still capable of writing this, my last letter. But the radiation dose I received was so intense that I know I can only live for a few hours beforeI lose consciousness forever.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: A special research program of the Internal Revenue Service has disclosed that the willingness of small businesses and corporations to pay their taxes has slipped to dismally low levels. According to the I.R.S., the smallest companies pay barely more than half theirtax bill without prodding. This recalcitrance Is costing the Government billions of dollars, the I.R.S. asserts. The problem has prompted Representative Sam M. Gibbons, the Florida Democrat who is chairman of the House ways and means subcommittee on oversight, to hold hearings on the issue. The hearings, which started in May and are continuing today, are designed to elicit recommendations about how to improve tax compliance by small business.

title: SENATORS BACK LANCE AND ABANDON INQUIRY,
description: WASHINGTON, July 25A Senate committee accepted today Budget Director Bert Lance's contention that there was nothing improper in his personal or business finances and decided not to investigate them furtllcr.

title: Peabody Sale Lifts Kennecott Net
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday a 4 percent improvement in firstquarter net income on sales gain of 9 percent. Net income for the first half climbed by 94.4 percent over the 1976 period as sales rose by 14.3 percent.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Trout Quest
description: CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward IslandIn July, silverbright sea trout surge up the West River and other streams on Prince Edward Island.

title: Stage: In Last Analysis, Leibman Is OneMan Show
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., July 24The Original production of. Saul Bellow's The Last Analysis, a failure on Broadway in 1964, was overdirected and miscast. Mr. Bellow's hero, the comedian Bummidge, seemed far better suited to the outrageous clowning of Zero Mostel or Sid Caesar than to the More gentle humor of Sam Levene, who created the role.

title: Albanians AreReported too Demand That Chinese Withdraw Advisers
description: BELGRADE. Yugoslavia. July 25Diplomatic sources said today that Albania had asked China to pull out its technical experts in a move that could lead to break in the 16yearold allince.

title: New York G.O.P. Club Is Alive and Hopeful
description: It looked at first as if the political organization that first helped John V. Lindsay to prominencethe New York Republican Clubhad faded into oblivion: There was the club listed in a recent Citibank advertisement among those whose accounts had become so inactive that the money was to be turned over to the state.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in yesterday's Times incorrectly reported the secondquarter operating earnings of J. P. Morgan & Company and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. Mnrgan's operating earnings increased 1 percent from the first quarter and Manufacturers Hanover's declined 9 percent. Because of a typographical error second quarter earnings of the Chase Manhattan Corporation were reported incorrectly. Its operating earnings decreased 5 percent in that quarter over the yearearlier period.

title: Three Casino Commission Members Are Confirmed
description: TRENTON, July 25The State Senate tonight confirmed the first three members of the State Casino Control Commission and the new chairman, Joseph P. Lordi of Newark, said the first casino in Atlantic City could be open by next spring.

title: Paris Couture Sets A Lively Pace
description: PARIS, July 25The glory days have not exactly returned to the couture, but it's not the dog days either. The demise of the couture is heralded as regularly as the death of the theater or the novel, but none is yet ready to lie down.

title: Dr. Margaret D. Craighill, at 78, Former Dean of Medical College
description: Dr. Margaret D. Craighill. a former medical college dean and the first woman to be commissioned directly in the Army Medical Corps, died Wednesday at her home in Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn. She was 78 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Hadiyah Joan Nadir would be a much more suitable name, for her than Joan Little, said the North Carolina convict who was acquitted two years ago of murdering a jailer, and she's asked court in Wake County to grant her a name change. The new name is of Arabic origin, and Miss Little told the court, The reason for which your petitioner desires to change her name is that she prefers to use a name that better describes her ancestry. Miss Little, who is black, also said: One reason is for religious purposes. Another reason is that it is a new start. The 23yearold Miss Little, who is eligible for parole in September, is serving a sentence for breaking and entering.

title: Britain Grants Leyland $170 Million New Loan
description: The British Government announced a new $170 million loan to the stateowned British Leyland Motors, makers of cars and trucks.

title: Vilas Beats Gottfried in Final, 64, 75
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)Guillermo Vilas continued his claycourt dominance over BrianGottfried tonight with a 64, 75 victory In the raindelayed final of the $125,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament. The match was held up 1 hour 45 minutes.

title: High Winds Put Off Sail Cup Trials
description: NEWPORT, RI, July 25Strong southerly winds gusting up to 40 miles an hour caused the New York Yacht gub to cancel racing today at the America's Cup trials. The match beOffeen Enterprise and Independence, the new American 12Meter yachts, ws postponed until tomorrow.

title: Kent State Building Ban Is Lifted
description: KENT, Ohio, July 25Judge Joseph Kainrad today lifted a temporary restraining order against construction of a $6 million gymnasium annex at Kent State University.

title: Saudi Flying to Texas for Surgery
description: LONDON, July 25 (Reuters)Prince Abdullah, nephew of King Khalid of Saudi Arabia, left here for Houston today for urgent heart treatment. The prince arrived in London at the weekend from Riyadh to be examined first by doctors at Hillingdon Hospital.

title: FUTURES PRICES RISE FOR GOLD AND SILVER;
description: Prices of gold and silver bullion futures continued to advance yesterday as the value of the dollar weakened further in currency exchange markets.

title: The Courts of First Resort
description: A lawsuit against Yale University alleges that women students have been sexually harassed by the Yale faculty. The court is asked to make the university make the faculty behave itself, as indeed the faculty should, if in fact it has been misbehaving, which Yale officially denies.

title: World News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 26 (UPI)The Angolan radio said today that the country was under attack by guerrillas from three directions and charged that Zaire and South Africa were involved in the fighting.

title: Califano, Citing Imminent Hazard, Orders Drug for Diabetes Taken Off the Market
description: WASHINGTON, July 25A drug used by 385,000 diabetics in this country was ordered off the market today as an imminent hazard to public health by the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Joseph A. Callfano Jr.

title: Iran Loan to Britain Canceled
description: LONDON, July 25 (AP)  A planned $400 million loan frcm Iran to Britain has been cmceled by mutual agreement of both governments, a British treasury spokesman said today. The loan was 11 have been the third drawing un a 51.2 billion credit facility arranged in July 1974. However, the treasury said, a rise in British monetary reserves to record levels and the prospects for a current external account surplus this year made the loan no longer appropriate.

title: 3ERTHA R. FARMER, 87; ENTERED COLLEGE AT 83
description: Bertha Rosenthal Farmer, who at the age of 83 enrolled as a nondegree student at Baruch College, died Saturday in the American Nursing Home, at 60 East Fifth Street, where she had lived since suffering a stroke eight months ago. She was 87 years old.

title: Phone Union Backs Strike
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)Telephone workers gave union leaders overwhelming approval today to call a nationwide strike against the Bell System next month if contract talks fail to produce an acceptable agreement. A formal strike date was left to union leaders. We want a settlement, not a strike, said Glenn E. Watts, president of the Communications Workers of America. But the situation is very serious and it's getting verylate.

title: Radio
description: 78 AM. WNCN. Danse Slave, Chabrier; Adelaide, Beethoven; Variations on a Theme by Mozart, Glinka; Sonata in A for Violin. Viola, Obbligato Harpsichord and Cello, J. C. F. Bach; Norwegian.

title: N.Y. Delegation to Women's Conference Is Decidedly Feminist
description: New York State will be sending strongly feminist delegation to the First National Women's Conference to be held in Houston in November.

title: Rain Helps Fight 5,000Acre Fire in Maine
description: Rain brought relief yesterday to grimy firefighters in Maine, helping their chances to control a fire that has blackened 5,000 acres at the foot of Mount Katandin. But in California and New Jea. sey new fires have charred an estimated 5,000 acres.

title: LUCY MORGENTHAU HEINEMAN.
description: Lucy Morgenthau Heineman, who was active in civic and college affairs, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25 (UPI)The adoptions of 20 Cambodian orphans from the 1975 Operation Babylift by American families of the Evangelical Protestant !faith was upheld today by a judge despite ihis pfevious ruling that placement of the orphans was unconstitutional.

title: F E A.to Study Whether Refiners Overcharged Oil Users by Billions
description: WASHINGTON, JUly 25A special task force formed by the Federal Energy Administration reported today that the nation's oil companies might have overcharged consumers by billions of dollars. The agency said that it agreed with the finding and announced that it would begin an intensive audit of the 15 largest refiners.

title: BODY IN CAR IDENTIFIED AS BROOKLYN WOMAN, 19
description: The body of a slain young woman found Sunday in an abandoned Lincoln Continental in Brooklyn was identified yesterday as that of 19yearold Cherie Golden, who had been missing since last Wednesdayevening, when her friend, John W. Quinn, was also murdered.

title: S.E.C. ADOPTS NEW RULES AFFECTING TENDER OFFERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The Securities and Exchange Commission today adopted rules that will require companies and individuals making tender offers to disclose more meaningful information about their operations and previous contacts with the company whose securities are being sought.

title: Different Drummer Wins Around Long Island Sail
description: SEA CLIFF, L.L. July 25  Different Drummer, a 31foot sloop sailed by Ted Naughton, a building contractor who divides his time between homes in Head of the Harbor, L.I. and Boca Raton, Fla., was the winner of the Newsday Cup. the major prize of the Around Long Island Regatta.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in yesterday's Times incorrectly reported the secondquarter operating earnings of J. P. Morgan & Company and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. Morgan's operating earnInes increased 1 percent from the first quarter and Manufacturers Hanover's declined 9 percent. Because of a typographical error second quarter earnings of the Chase Manhattan Corporation were reported incorrectly. Its operating earnings decreased 5 percent in that quarter over the yearearlier period.

title: Carter, in Letter to Park, Pledges U.S. Commitment to South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 25President Carter today assured President Park Chung Hee that the United States security commitment to South Korea remained firm and undiminished despite the planned withdrawal of American ground troops.

title: Gulf and Western Tax Practices Coming Under Wide Examination
description: To passersby, it must have been a strange scenea group of welldressed businessmen lugging boxes of corporate records on a hot summer night out of a midtown Manhattan office building into a car.

title: Beame Given Key Endorsements By Two Leading Labor Groups
description: Mayor Beame yesterday received two significant endorsements from organized labor in his bid for reelection, adding to the impressive amount of union backing he had already garnered.

title: Falsehoods Charged By Official of C.&W.
description: Gulf and Western Industries Inc. said yesterday that a series of articles in The New York Times covering the corporate and financial activities of the company and its chairman. Charles G. Bluhdorn. contain falsehoods.

title: Germany Trade Surplus Narrows
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, July 25 (UPI)West Germany recorded a $1.2 billion trade surplus in June, the Federal Statistical Office said today. This compares with a $1.6 billion trade surplus in the previous month and a surplus of S888.8 million in June 1976. In the first six months, West Germany had an 58.1 billion trade surplus against S7.2 billion in the same period last year.

title: Advertising
description: The youthful psychologist and market researcher, who brought you Sports Insight in 1974 and Media Insight in 1975, is now preparing to go into the field with Consumer Profiles, a study intended to measure the information influences that lead to consumer buying decisions for a variety of products.

title: Love and Death in India
description: Andrew Youne was right: The British did invent racism. And it is something other than a doctrine or a policy, something more than an attitude. is a psychopathology, a form of cultural sadomasochism, with its own etiquette, dreams, demons, denials, myths, tormented exceptions, and builtin death wish. The proof is in Paul Scott's marvelous Raj Quartet. The four novels in the quartet simply could not have been written about the French, Spanish or Portuguese colonial ventures, vicious and genocidal as those ventures might at various stages have appeared to be. It took the British to introduce the idea of unspeakable sex, the dark dialectic of oppressor and oppressed.

title: Freedom, at Last, From the Burden of Taxation
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  New Hampshire was first to have a lottery, perhaps because it enjoys a unique opportunity to induce visitors to support its government.

title: HISATSUNE SAKOMIZU, 74; WROTE HIROHITO MESSAGE
description: TOKYO, July 25 (AP)Hisatsune Sakomizu, a conservative politician who drafted Emperor Hirohito's World War II surrender message, died of a heart attack today. He was 74 years old.

title: San Francisco's International Hotel: No Fleabag
description: Your July 2 editorial The Flophouse as Landmark uses San Francisco's International Hotel as the jumpingoff point to talk about the problem of fleabag hotels and firetraps which house derelicts, people with multiple social problems, etc. While I am not competent to discuss those issues, which abound In New York and other big Eastern cities, I am able to speak knowledgeably about the International Hotel.

title: 9.18 DECLINE IN DOW TO 91424 PUTS END TO 6SESSION RALLY
description: A sixsession rally came to a halt on Wall Strett yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 9.18 points to 914.24 in moderate trading. The bluechip Dow had advanced more than 21 Points since July 15.

title: BUDGETARY INCREASE IS APPROVED BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, July 25Governor Carey announced today that he had approved additional budget appropriations of S97 million for this fiscal, year, after vetoing an item that would have limited the amount the Metropolitan Transportation AuthoriSpecial to The New York Times ty could assess localities for station maintenance.

title: Buttle Hates Any Player Who Lines Up on Offense
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 25It's nothing personal, but Greg Buttle detests anyone who plays offense.

title: Steve Cady
description: Earnie Shavers they were saying yesterday at Madison Square Garden, can take you out with either hand. A vicious hitter. Explosive. Devastating. All the adjectives that spill so easily from a fight promoter's mimeograph machine. But that isn't all. As one witness put it in a hushed voice: Earnie Shavers takes no prisoners. The reference was to the shavenheaded Ohio heavyweight's record of 52 knockouts in the 54 fights he has won, 20 of them in the first round. Why, then, the question had to he asked, is 35yearold Muhammad All defending his world title against Earnie Shavers on Sept. 29 at the Garden? Why Shavers? Has Ali, nearing the end of the line in his 18th years as a professional boxer, decided to go out with a bang? Will he stand up there like a doomed man in front of a firing squad? Let it end swiftly and cleanly with one lethal punch thrown by the fearsome Shavers?

title: Tamaicans Are Divided Over Nation's Leftward Course
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica  Dorothy Dobson, a mother of four, is a crashie, worker in Jamaica's crash, or Special Employment Program, which is similar to the Works Progress Administration of the Great Depression era in the United States.

title: Luba Greene, Art The rapist, is Married to Brian Marsh
description: Luba Greene, an art therapist with the Belchertown (Mass.) State School, was married last night to Brian Marsh, a. faculty member and dramatic director at Mount Wachussetts Community College in Garden, Mass. The Rev. Arthur W. Shaw performed the nondenominational ceremony in the bridegroom's home in Shutesbury Center, Mass.

title: Republicans in House Offer an Energy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)House Republicans, miffed at being ignored in committee, offered their own energy program today while criticizing the Democrats version.

title: L.S.U. Star Drowns
description: MANDEVILLE, La., July 25,A former Louisiana State University football standout, Carl Otis Trimble, drowned yesterday while on an outing with friends. Trimble played his sophomore season at quarterbackthe only black man ever to call signals for L.S.U. He was moved to wingback for his final two seasons. He was graduated last summer and planned to enter law school this fall. He was 22 years old.

title: Tennis
description: Fkst RoundSam Scorn defeated Jiatis Mends, 63, 46, 62; Bill Tully defeated Tom Kovailk, 6.0, 6I; Bob Kehn elated George Kfourv, 6.4, 60; Harm Karmiller defeated B111 Petrusky, Al, 63; Marloyn Marcus defeated Cheri!. Crawford, 5.7, 64, 64: Buddy Kaye, detailed Marshall Upton, 16, 64, 75; Dick Mallory defeated Charlie Friedman, 61, 61; Dan, Leonard defeated Gene Gilmartin, 6.2,64.

title: People in Sports
description: Terry Metcalf. the St. Louis Cardinals running back, has signed a new contract that could allow him to leave the Cardinals this coming season.

title: STEEL OUTPUT OFF IN WEEK 3.8% TO 2.3 MILLION TONS
description: For the eighth consecutive week, domestic steel production has fallen, dropping 3.8 percent to 2.3 million tons in the week ended July 23, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This meant that the industry was utilizing only 75.5 percent of its total available capability against the 78.4 percent utilization factor a week ago when 2.4 million tons were poured.

title: Factory Explosion Hampers Cleanup in Johnstown
description: JOHNSTOIVN, Pa., July 25 (AP)An explosion in a glass factory hampered the rescue crews wading through the debris from last week's flood today, and more heavy rain prompted residents in lowlying areas to seek higher ground.

title: PRESIDENT REJECTS JORDAN'S CRITICISM
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  President Carter charged today that criticism of, his Administration's record on blacks and the poor damaged the hopes and aspiralions of those poor people.

title: BUDGETARY INCREASE IS APPROVED BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, July 25Governor Carey announced today that he had approved additional budget appropriations of $97 million for this fiscal year, after vetoing an item that would have limited the amount the Metropolitan Transportation Author, ty could assess localities for station maintenance.

title: Curb on Ocean Dumping of Sludge Is Backed by Court;
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25A legal effort to upset the Environmental Protection Agency's progressive ban on ocean dumping of sewage sludge has been rebuffed in Federal court.

title: EGYPT SENDS LIBYA LIST OF CONDITIONS
description: CAIRO, July 25A precarious ceasefire appeared to be taking hold in the LibyanEgyptian border region today as the Government of Col. Muammar elQaddafi studied a set of Egyptian conditions put to it through Algerian and Palestinian mediators.

title: An Impossible Dream
description: To the Editor A month or two ago, a story appeared in the press quoting the M.T.A. as saying that 80 percent of our city buses are now airconditioned. That would seem to be a fair figure. But that doesn't mean that the airconditioning is functioning.

title: EDWARD FLYNN, DIES AT 63; HUMBERT & JONES OFFICER
description: Edward Francis Flynn of Pelham Manor, N. Y., executive vice president and creative services director at the Humbert & Jones Advertising agency, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of Scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: New Yorkers Need to Know
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission must show cause in Manhattan Federal District Court this morning why it should not release a report on how New York City officials, including Mayor Beame and Comptroller Goldin, sold the city's bonds and notes in the months before buyers turned their backs on them. Although the report has been in preparation for many months, its failure appear has aroused an understandable suspicion, fed the Mayor's political rivals, that its final release was being delayed until after the city's primary elections September. In our Letters column this morning, however, the commission's chairman explains that the report cannot be released because it is not finished and that political considerations have had no influence upon the timing of the investigation.

title: Deaths
description: BRAHAMSIda. Beloved wife or the tato Isadore. Devoted mother of Jerold and Samuel. Sister of Jonah Dorman and Gertrude Swersky. Loving grand mother, Services today, 1:30 P.M. Schwartz Bothers Chapel, 76Hs Rd. and Queens Blvd. Forest Hills.

title: No No Yankee, $12, Wins Rich Pace
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 25When Charlie Keller, the former New York Yankees slugger, retired from baseball almost three decades ago and announced he was going into the horsebreeding business, his plans provided the material for many a joke around major league diamonds.

title: Senate Debates Campaign Subsidy
description: WASHINGTON. July 25Amid Reoublican threats of a filibuster, the Senate opened debate today on legislation that would give campaign subsidies to candidates for the Senate. President Carter has endorsed the legislation.

title: Haigaz Mekhalian, Director Of Armenian Benevolent Union
description: Haigaz Mekhalian, executive director of Armenian General Benevolent Union of America, a branch of the main philanthropic organization of the worldwide Armenian community, died of a heart attack Friday at his desk there. He was 60 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: F,E,A.to Study Whether Refiners Overcharged Oil Users by Billions.
description: WASHINGTON, July 25A special task force formed by the Federal Energy Administration reported today that the nation's oil companies might have overcharged consumers by billions of dollars. The agency said that it agreed with the finding and announced that it would begin an intensive audit of the 15 largest refiners.

title: Relatives of 9 New York Justices Received $526,353 in Court Fees
description: By HOWARD BLUM Close relatives of nine State Supreme Court justices in the Bronx and Manhattan have received 460 appointments during the last nine years to serve as guardians. receivers or referees, and they have so far earned $526,353 in legal fees for the assignments, according to court records.

title: Business Records DISTRICTMonday JuIy,25 1977
description: JOHN F. BURLINGHAM, P.O. Box 4f. West Hurley, N.Y. Liabilities. 576.577; asset,. 363,304 odine real Moo. erty of $48,0001.

title: Bridge: Only 2 New York Players Left In Spingold Semifinal Play
description: CHICAGO, July 25  The semifinal stage of the Spingold knockout team championship began here this afternoon, with players from the Midwest and South predominating.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, duty 751 QUEEN ELIZABETH Z (Cunard). Lett Southampton July 22; dud 6 A.M. at W. SSM Street.

title: Liberal South Carolina Democrat Seeks Thurmond's Senate Seat
description: CHARLESTON. S.C., July 25Charles D. Ravenel, 38 years old, a Harvardeducated investment banker who is considered a political liberal in South Carolina, announced today his Democratic candidacy for the Senate seat held by Strom Thurmond, 74, for more than three decades one of the South's leading conservative voices.

title: Four Indicted by Jury in Brooklyn In First of BlackoutLooting Cases
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn is asking the State Supreme Court to set up a special part for handling blackoutrelated criminal cases as speedily as possible, a spokesman for him said yesterday.

title: 'Big Four Inflation

title: SUSPECT ARRAIGNED IN FIREMURDER CASE
description: WATERBURY, Conn., July 25  Lorne J. Acquin was arraigned in Superior Court here this morning on charges of having murdered his foster brother's wife, their seven children and a niece, and setting fire to their home early Friday morning.

title: City Ballet Switches To Two More Waltzes

title: To the Editor:
description: As there are not enough employment opportunities for all persons able and willing to work, I would like to pose the following question in connection with the current discussion of the demerits of mandatory retirement at 65. If employees stay on after 65, will there not be even fewer openings for the young who are about to enter the labor market and for the middleaged who are being forced to retire when laid off? Obviously, more jobs are needed to save the Social Security Administration from bankruptcy.; GITTA WILLEMSON New York, July 18, 1977.

title: U.S.Rhodesia Trade Detailed by U.N. Units
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25 (Reuters)The United States imported 45,854 tons of minerals and other embargoed items from Rhodesia between last October and December 31, the Security Council's Sanctions Committee reported tonight.

description: MONTREAL, July 25Charles de Gaulle, who died in 1970, came to the help of the Quebec independence movement last night as he did 10 years ago with his shout of Long live fr a Quebec!

description: DURING the past six or eight months, several new shops have opened around town, each offering an assortment of prepared foods to be carried out and eaten at home. Whether one resorts to such an alternative fora big party or a solitary dinner for one, such shops afford the pleasures of decorative and appetizing meals in the comfort and privacy of home without any of the before and after work involved in their preparation.

Opera in English is a permanent feature of the Seattle Opera. During the regular season, operas are given in the original language and followed by an equal number of performances in translation.

title: Eventual Parole for Chowchilla 3 Rests With Judge
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26Attorneys for both sides in the Chowchilla kidnapping case began preparing today for trial before a state judge to determine whether three young defendants. who pleaded guilty yesterday will ever be released from jail. the three stooges because of the ineptitude of the kidnapping plan, said it was important that the case now go to judge. With small children involved, jury might not be very sympathetic to our clients  he said.

title: King Tut Sits for TV Portrait Tonight
description: ON A RECENT TRIP to Chicago, a magazine editor arrived at the Field Museum of Natural History at 8 in the morning and stood on a ridiculously long line for several hours, only to be told that the exhibition was already completely filled for the day. On display, of course, was Treasures of Tutonlaiiman, currently on a tour of the United States (it will reacn New York's Metropolitan Museum in the spring of 1979) and setting all kinds of new attendance records to the delight of headcounting esthetes.

description: A surprising finding that a widely prescribed antibiotic called gentamicin can persist in the body for hundreds of hours after the last dose Is injected has been reported in a medical journal by a team of researchers in Buffalo and Philadelphia.

description: Engineers have not given up on tapping shale for oil and gas, despite the gloom that has descended over much of the industry lately, Engineers' attention is focusing on two promising processes. Page D7.

description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)Suzi Park Thomson, a South Korean native who worked on Capitol Hill, said today that I have no knowledge of any bribes or payoffs in Congress.

description: Victor Hugo's NotreDame de Paris, more popularly known as The Hunchback of Notre Dame, is being adapted as a musical for the coming Broadway season. Entitled Quasimodo, the play is being written by Anthony Scully. The music and lyrics are by Larry Grossman and Hal Hackady, respectively. Lorin E. Price is the nroducer.

title: A State Lottery Millionaire Loses His Job, And Now He Collects $90 More a Week
description: POTSDAM, N. Y., July 26 (UPI)Gary LaShomb, who won the $1,000aweekforlife jackpot in the March state lottery drawing, is collecting $90 a week in unemployment insurance. also from the state.

title: JOSHUA P. SKINNER
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 26 (AP) Joshua P. Skinner, former managing editor of The Atlanta Constitution and assistant managing editor of The Miami News, died today. He was 69 years old. A native of Augusta, Ga., Mr. Skinner, after graduating from Harvard in 1929, Kited for The Augusta Chronicle and Augusta Herald before joining the Atlanta bureau of The Associated Press in 1935. He joined The Constitution in 1943 and wais.managing editor from 1944 to 1948. In 1949, he became assistant managing editor of The Miami News and later joined Hank Meyer Associates, a Miami public relations firm. He retired four years ago.

title: Suspect in Sales to Communists Is Linked to 75 Case
description: WEST BERLIN, July 26Carl Lutz Wiesohenberg, a. West German who was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Florida last week along with Carl John Heiser, an American, on charges of having supplied electronics and computer data to Communist governments, was involved in Germany two and a half years ago in a case involving allegedly illegal transactions with the Russians.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The J. C. Penney Company, which entered the supermarket field in 1970, said yesterday that it had decided to discontinue that business starting in the next few. months.

title: Quebec EnglishSpeaking Parents Defy French Policy
description: MONTREAL, July 26The split between the Frenchspeaking majority and the Englishspeaking minority in Quebec has widened with the start of a campaign of defiance of language legislation that would restrict English schooling as one way of insuring the domination of the French language.

title: Shell Earnings Rise 4.2% as Virtually All Oil Companies Show Increases
description: With the demand for gasoline strong and prices up, profits of virtually every oil company have improved over last year's second quarter, but the range of increases has varied widely.

title: News Summary
description: Most of the American combat troops now in Korea will remain there until the final year of the planned withdrawal, in response to a plea by the South Korean Government, according to a joint statement in Seoul. The headquarters of the Second Infantry Division and two of its brigades will stay until the final phase of the pullout of four to five years. Defense Secretary Harold Brown gave this word to President Park Chung Hee, who was said to be pleased. [Page A1, Column 6.]

description: WASHINGTON, July 26Taking issue with recent pronouncements from the Treasury, Arthur F. Burns, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, said today that the United States should be protecting the dollar's international value in the exchange markets.

title: Batter Up!
description: It was good news yesterday for the Bad News Bears, above, as the young cast of that movie defeated the children from the Broadway cast of Annie, in a softball game in Central Park. Their 62 victory came in spite of the best efforts of Andrea McArdle, upper right, who plays the title role in Annie. At right : In Flushing, Mary Calorel, 15 years old, assisted her 4yearold sister, Ann, in baseball practice. Although both girls are legally blind, they play with a baseball that emits beeps and can be detected by its sound.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: You may be someone who cari take or leave ribbons but when they're woven into multicolored handbags, they're really quite a lot of fun to take. The bags, made in California, come in both clutch and shoulderstrap styles, in black mated with brilliant shades, or a combination of pastels. The envelopeclutch is for tailored types, and the shoulder bag is meant for the adventurous. The prices are $65 and $80 (a luxurious ribbon fringe on the shoulder style may account for the differential). There are too, if one wishes, belts to match. Off Broadway at 139 West 72d Street has them all.

title: The Effort to UnPAC Congress
description: Ever since candidates discovered television ads and the cost of campaigning began to soar, students of government have wondered how to contain it. They have feared that, without some limit, the only candidates who could win would be those who are rich or who will accept, to an unhealthy extent, money from special interests. Congress tried to allay these concerns in 1974 by establishing campaign spending limits. But they were struck down as unconstitutional by the Supreme Court. Such limits, the Court said, would be acceptable only within the framework of campaigns that are publicly financed. And that is exactly the proposal now being filibustered in the Senate.

title: Private Lives
description: HE IS BIG. He always has been, over six feet, with that slump of the shoulders and tuck in the neck big men in this country often affect, as if to apologize for being above the democratic norm in size. (In high school and at college he played varsity basketball. In high school he was senior class president.) And he looks healthy enough, blueeyed behind his beard, like trapper or a mountain man, acquainted with silences. He also erins a lot.

title: Angels Reap Few Dividends So Far
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 26  The most expensive flop or modem times, or heroes of one of the great stretch drives of baseball history? As one or the other, the 1977 California Angels will be remembered, and the threegame series they opened here tonight had symbolic overtones.

title: The Outcasts of Cooperstown
description: This year's Alistar baseball game was dedicated to the memory of Jackie Robinson because somebody discovered that 30 summers had passed since Robinson broke in with the Brooklyn Dodgers and thus opened the major leagues to Willie Mays, Ernie Banks, Bob Gibson, Roy Campanella, Roberto Clemente, Hank. Aaron and all the other great black players who have lent excitement to the game that had ostracized their race for threequarters of a century. In addition, individual clubs are offering tributes to Robinson and each salute gives baseball a new opportunity to take bows as a leader in the struggle against bigotry. Hardly anybody will mention that when Branch Rickey The Times hired Robinson he did so over the opposition of his 15 fellow owners some outspoken and some surreptitious; that some, membersof the Dodgers considered it beneath them to play with a black man; that the St. Louis Cardinals planned to pull a protest strike on their first visit to Ebbets Field and might have done so if Rud Rennie and Stanley Woodward hadn't exposed their intentions in The New York Herald Tribune.

title: Mr. Carter and Mr. Jordan
description: Anyone seriously interested in the state of civil rights in America just now would do well to study carefully this week's exchange between Vernon Jordan, executive director of the National Urban League, and President Carter at the league's annual convention in Washington. Mr. Jordan spoke from a mood of disappointment in the Administration which, as far as we can tell, is broadly held in the black community these days. Mr. Carter, could be expected, defended the record of his Adminis[ration and pronounced his good intentions. Then took Mr. Jordan behind closed doors and expressed real pique.

title: To Avoid Disaster On China
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.As Secretary of State Cyrus Vance prepares to visit Peking in August, let us note how China policy misconceptions have twice led us into warfare and disaster. China remains so incomprehensible we fall back on the high school debaters axiom: When you don't krtow the facts, assert the principles. Principled ignorance led us to fight. China in Korea and to fight Chinese puppets, as we assumed them to be, in Vietnam.

title: A Return to the Past Helps to Spark Hopes for the Future in Newburgh
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y.For years the plight of this oncebeautiful Hudson River community has been one of the Image molding the reality. Besieged by racial divisions, scarred by riots and the scourges of age and urban decay, The city has, in horror, watched its decline portrayed in countless newspaper accounts and at least two major television documentaries over the last few years.

title: Senator Kennedy Introduces Bill On Coal and Uranium Ownership
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Senator Ed1 ward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, chairman of the Senate Antitrust subcommittee, introduced today a bill that would prohibit ownership of coal and uranium resources by 16 large oil companies and six large natural gas producers. The bill would prohibit the companies from acquiring coal and uranium properties and would require the sale of any such holdings within three years of enactment. Hearings were scheduled to start next Tuesday. The prohibitions would apply to producers of 150,000 barrels a day, of oil or 100 billion cubic feet of gas a year.

title: Associated Press
description: JOHNSTOWN CLEANS UP: Youngsters shoveling mud In front of a restaurant in Johnstown, Pa., yesterday as residents of the floodravaged town began to clean up. Losses to merchants have been heavy.

title: SmallBusiness Bill Approved
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The House today passed a bill to authotize $2.96 billion for smallbusiness programs in the two years beginning Oct. 1, A voice sent the measure, a compromise between House and Senate versions; to the Senate for final legislative action. The actual funds will be determined by appropriations legislation. The bill also would authorize nearly S7 billion in guarantees of private loans by the Small Business Administration.

title: Advertising
description: The Lesney Products Corporation, the British makers of the Matchbox line of tiny autos, planes and ships, is moving this fall into model road racing, expecting that the good image of Matchbox will help no end.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: KING RICHARD A summernight salute in melody to one of the most durable and hurnmable talents in Atherican show business occurs tonight starting at 8, as Ainslee Cox conducts the 54piece Goldman Band in a tribute to Richard Rodgers. The admissionfree concert will include highlights from the illustrious Broadway, Hollywood and television career of the 75yearold composer. He is expected to attend the concert. The place is Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center.

title: MANY SET TO TESTIFY TO AID JUSTICE TYLER
description: Scores of prominent politicians, judges and professionals from the Harlem community who helped elect Andrew R. Tyler to the bench are preparing to lend their support to the State Supreme Court justice as he goes on trial in Manhattan on charges of Deriurv.

title: Big Floods Linked to Strip Mining
description: WASHINGTON, July 26A House subcommittee heard conflicting testimony today about the effect of strip mining in large areas of the Appalachian coal fields on floods that have taken scores of lives and caused millions of dollars in property damage.

title: Somalia at a Glance
description: GEOGRAPHYThe Somali Democratic Republic, situated on the Horn of Africa on the east coast of the continent, is bordered by Kenya, Ethiopia and Djibouti. It is a promontory of a country, jutting into the Indian Ocean, with the Gulf of Aden its northern border. About the size of Spain and Portugal combined, its 270,000 square miles comprise the territory of the former British and Italian Somaliland.

title: Kent State Votes to Construct Gym
description: KENT, Ohio, July 26Trustees of Kent State University voted today to begin construction of a $6 million gymnasium annex near the site of the killing of four students by the Ohio National Guard during an antiwar protest on May 4, 1970.

title: Concert: East and West in Harmony
description: KIPLING TO THE CONTRARY, the twain can meet, and did so Monday night at the mostly Mozart Festival when the Tokyo Strong Quartet and the Cleveland String Quartet pooled their forces for a performance of Mendelssohn's Octet. It was a strenuous, highpressure reading that generated all the visceral excitement one could expect from this famous piece for double quartet, composed by a 16yearold boy who rarely in later years produced anything as original and astonishing.

title: A Healthy Stretch for New York City's Debt
description: New York City's financial situation has been improved if that is the word for a narrow escape from disasterby cutting expenditures and postponing debt. But the future is mortgaged and more of the future must be mortgaged if the city is to hold its balance at the edge of the abyss. So we suggest a kind reception for some further debt shuffling by the everresourceful Municipal Assistance Corporation which proposes, at some expense, to transform some nearby days of reckoning into what might be called some distant months of pinching.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Noting that there are thousands of special permits allowing parking on city streets, environmentalists yesterday atJacked a citysupported plan to reduce onstreet parking because, they said,  failed to cone with specialpermit abuses.

title: Peru's Harried Military Regime Struggles With Economic Disarray
description: LIMA, Peru, July 26Peru's financial disorder, inflation and social unrest have reached the advanced state that has set the stage in many Latin American countries for the armed forces to seize power. But in Peru, the armed forces are already in power.

title: Senate Panel Studies Proposal to Raise Employers Social Security Tax
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Senate Finance Committee made public today a plan for Social Security financing that next January would remove the ceiling on wages on which employers must pay taxes. That would cost employers an additional $48 billion in taxes in the period 197882.

title: Fulton Sheen Doing Well AfterOpenHeartSurgery, But His Doctor Is Cautious
description: Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen was reported to be doing well yesterday after having undergone open heart surgery 12 days ago. But his physician, Dr. Michael S. Bruno, who confirmed reports that the operation took place July 15 at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City, cautioned that the 82yearold patient was not yet out of danger.

title: Sadat Reports Conflict Is Over; Warns Libya on  Playing With Fire
description: CAIRO, July 26President Anwar elSadat announced tonight that Egypt's conflict with Libya was over but he did not give any details of a settlement.

title: FLORENCE FOWLER RIDGEWAY
description: Florence Fowler Ridgeway, who was prominent in Putnam County civic and charitable affairs, died Monday at St. Luke's Hospital in NeWburgh, N.Y. She was 75 years old and a resident of Garrison, N.Y.

title: House Defeats Attempt to Remove Tobacco From Food for Peace Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The House of Representatives in a reversal of a vote last May, defeated an attempt today to eliminate tobacco from the Food for Peace program. The debate pitted those who expressed concern for the economy and the nation's 600,000 tobacco farm families against those who denounced the harmful effects of smoking.

title: PORK BELLIES FALL IN FUTURES TRADING
description: All but the most distant pork. bellies futures contract dropped the daily permissible limit of 2 cents a pound yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Hayes, Eastern Clay King, Going on a Tougher Circuit
description: For hardserving John Hayes, winning the Eastern claycourt championship was the biggest victory of his career. The lean, 6foot3inch Princeton graduate from Cos Cob, Conn., is now off on the satellite prizemoney American Express Challengers circuit. He wants to give himself a year to see what he can do in pro tennis, but by knows it's going to be tough because many good young players are comity up.

title: Foreman Pact Extended For 2 Years by Vikings
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 26 (AP)  Minnesota's star running back, Chuck Foreman, tonight agreed to a twoyear extension of his contract with the Vikings.

title: U.S. Soccer Coaches to Tune Up in Brazil
description: Twelve of the top American amateur soccer coaches, including the coach of the United States national team, will travel to Brazil for an intensive twoweek training session starting Monday.

title: F.T.C. STUDYING METHODS OF DRY BATTERY MAKERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had begun an investigation into possible monopolization and unfair methods of competition by manufacturers of dry cell batteries, such as flashlight batteries.

title: Andreotti, in U. S. For Talks, Is Given A Warm Welcome
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  President Carter gave an unusually effusive welcome to Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti today in a demonstration of United States backing for a minority Government in Italy that must depend for survival on Communist supportin Parliament.

title: The. Summers of Youth, Frozen in Memory
description: These days ice is ice. It is something that comes 100 cubes to the package and pick some up at the deli on the way home, please. It is something that in big cakes is useful to cool soda, beer and canned tea at block parties.

title: NewYorkers, etc.
description: THE SIXTH Earl of Carnarvon, who is also Lord Porchester, and is known therefore mostly as Porchey, has been in town promoting the Treasures of Tutankhamun. This is the collection that the fifth Earl of Carnarvon, Porchey's father, helped to find in 1922, and which is now being taken from museum to museum across the country. Tonight there will be a onehour television special about it, Tut: The Boy King, on NBC. This means it is getting a good deal of attention, and so, of course, is Porchey. He is 79 years old, and the great passions of his life have been horses, women and the family estate and its Highclere Castle. For years, however, he have been coming to New York, staying at the St. Regis, dining at 21 and La Caravelle, and hanging about The Racquet & Tennis Club. All this has made him a man of strong opinions, some of which we shall hear now.

title: RailroadBased Concerns Post Earnings Records
description: Record revenues and earnings for the quarter ended June 30 were announced yesterday by a number of the nation's leading railroadbased companies. This resulted in sharply higher totals for those companies in the first six months of this year.

title: Voters Confused Over A's and B's in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26With only a week to go before a special election that could decide political fortunes and the control of the city government, coalitions on all sides of the issues have committed their final funds to mass advertising and their volunteer workers to get out the vote drives.

title: CARTER URGES CHANGE IN CLEANAIR STATUTE
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  President Carter urged CongresF today to change the Clean Air Act before going on vacation next month to avoid a possible shutdown of auto asserabi,. lines and consequent damage to the economy.

title: Letters
description: To THE LIVING SECTION As a novice canner, I was delighted to see your long article [July 6, A Time of Plenty: Home Canning Heyday] on the art of preserving the produce that seems so abundant at this time of year (and often so sad in February). However, I was disappointed to note that no mention was made of the book which I think is the most comprehensive and intelligent source of information currently available, especially to the beginner. Putting Food By, published by the Stephen Greene Press, is fun to read even if one intends to dine exclusively in restaurants, but doubt that anyone who is the least bit susceptible will be able to resist their peach chutney, for instance.

title: State Health Official Cited on Moonlighting
description: TRENTON, July 26 (UPI)The state's Ethical Standard Commission is investigating a complaint that the moonlighting job of a recently demoted assistant state health commissioner may represent a conflict of interest.

title: 2 Germans Acquitted of Murder
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, July 26 (Reuters)A court here today acquitted two leftwing extremists, KarlHeinz Roth and Roland Otto, of a charge of murdering a policeman in a gunfight. The prosecution had asked for life terms for both men, although it produced no evidence that either had fired a shot at police officers who stopped their car in a routine check here in May 1975. Witnesses in the sixmonth trial said the gunfight had begun when a third occupant of the car, subsequently killed by policemen in an exchange of fire, drew a gun.

title: $8 MILLION FOR ARTS TO AID 48 INSTITUTIONS IN NEW YORK IN 1978
description: Eighteen cultural institutions in New York City will get nearly $8 million from the National Endowment for the Arts in the first round of a new challenge grant program whose funds must be matched, $3 for each $1 granted.

title: St. Joe's Earnings Down
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation reported yesterday secondquarter net income of $14.3 million, or 63 cents a share, down 23.9 percent from yearearlier results. Sales were also off, by 4.4 percent to 5195.6 million.

title: ALLIE M. STEVENS
description: Allie M. Stevens, a former specialist in remedial skills for the New York City Board of Education, died Monday at her home, 1073 Warburton Avenue, Yonkers. She was 73 years old. She was the wife of Hope R. Stevens, a lawyer and president of the Harlem area Chamber of Commerce, who survives her.

title: Chicago Fans Dream of Pennants for Cubs and White Sox
description: CHICAGO, July 26For the first time in a long while, Chicago's victorystarved baseball fans, who are as numerous as they are longsuffering, can buy outside the White Sox's Comiskey Park or the Cubs Wrigley Field bona fide souvenir pennants that declare, however ephemerally, We're No. 1.

title: A. H. Raskin
description: After a decade of strikes every time new contracts are negotiated, the United Steelworkers of America hopes it can persuade the nation's copper producers that it is time to move toward cooperative relations of the kind that have made the onceturbulent steel industry a model of labormanagement peace. The obstacles to such a turnaround in copper are obvious enough in the current round *of socalled divideandconquer settlements, in which one company after another reluctantly falls into line with the basic wage pattern that originated in steel last spring.

title: Selling Pressure for Second Day Pushes Dow Down 6.06 to 908.18
description: Selling pressure touched off by disappointing profits for two huge corporationsUnited States Steel and Exxonsent the stock market sharply lower yesterday for the second consecutive session.

title: Nets Will Move To New Jersey; Cost: $4 Million
description: The Nets basketball team will move to New Jersey under an agreement reached yesterday with the New York Knicks.

title: Home Values Up 57% in Five Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) A report released today by the Census Bureau and the Department of Housing and Urban Development shows that from 1970 to 1975 the median value of owneroccupied homes rose 57 percent, from $21,700 to $34,100. It shows also that between 1970 and 1975 the median income cf homeowners increase 45 percent, from $11,900 to $17,300.

title: British Joblessness at Postwar Peak
description: LONDON, July 26The Government reported today that unemployment in Britain surged to postwar records in midJuly prompting angry comment in the House of Commons and putting further political pressure on Prime Minister lames Callaghan.

title: The Cuisine Of Northern Italy A Cook's Tour
description: WHERE FOOD is concerned, the old port city Genoa is celebrated for two things. First and foremost is the local basil, which is, of course, the base for pesto genovese coveted by epicures the world over. Second is one of the finest French pastries in the worldthat delicate, spongelike, eggenriched pastry known as genoise. If gastronomic justice prevailed, Genoa would be equally celebrated for a third thing, the marble statue of Caterina Compodonico, a lady who might be called the patroness saint of pastryshopkeepers. Caterina Compodonico was born in 1880 and died 82 years later. She owned a bake shop in the heart of Genoa and is said to have been a miserly sort who catered to all the town's wealthy folk. Born poor she was determined to sleep through eternity alongside the rich. For more than half her life she accumulated lire for a monument and to purchase a plot in the Genoa cemetery where the rich ones were cuddled at Abraham's bosom. There she stands. Not tall, a bit stout; two rings of bread it ??? hand and around her waist, a rosary of hazelnuts. And there she lies. Who says you can't take it with you?

description: IHAVE BEEN READING Vita Sackville West on gardening, and it has not really helped. Vita SackvileWest is probably best known right now for being the mother of Nigel Nicolson and the star of his book, Portrait of a Marriage, which he wrote a couple of years ago about her unusual marriage to his father, Harold Nicholson. But she is also known to have beenquite a gardener.

title: Nizer Courts His Guests With Caricatures
description: Be it paper, cardboard, canvas, wood, velvet, petit point, scrim or table linen if it's blank, Louis Nizer has to fill it up. He has been doing so, with words and pictures, for most of his long, illustrious life. Four Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States and hundreds of his luncheon and dinner euests are immortalized on napkins.

title: Oskar Morgenstern Is Dead at 75; Economic Game Theory Pioneer
description: Oskar Morgenstern, one of the giants of modem economics and a pioneer in the development of mathematical economies and game theory, died yesterday of cancer at his home In Princeton, N.J. He was 75 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, July 26 The arrangement for an Atlanta business man, David N. Smith, to buy Bert Lance's entire block of 200,767 shares of National Bank of Georgia stock was put together by an Arkansas financier who was an early and generous supporter of his Naval Academy classmate, President Carter.

title: Careers
description: A growing business field usually provides growing opportunities for jobhunters. The commodities business fits the fastgrowth category, partly because population growth spurs more demand partly because of the effects of inflation and partly because of more general sophistication about conurinities trading.

description: A Federal judge was told yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had not yet completed a report on its investigation of New York City's fiscal crisis.

description: FROM THE tip of the toe to the top of the boot, Italy offers compelling and highly diversified kind of cookery. Here are an assortment of dishes sampled recently in the restaurants of Genoa, Torino. Milan, Recco and Portofino.

Others in his organization handle the property.

title: Underground Fires in Marshlands Pose Problems for Town Leaders
description: LYNDHURST, July 26A stubborn and tricky underground fire burned for a third day today beneath an abandoned garbage dump and marshland here. It marked reoccurrence of a perennial dryseason fire problem that has taken on a new dimension because of millions of dollars of new commercial development in recent years in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: About Education
description: One of the developments that highereducation officials seldom discuss openly is the demise of selectivity at many of the nation's small private, liberal arts colleges.
