description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 26 (AP) Eddie Dibbs, flirting with the disaster that befell him last year, recovered from a firstset loss to defeat Ramiro Benavides of Colombia, 26, 60, 62, in firstround play at the $125,000 ??? tennis tournament today.

title: U.S. May Sell Cairo Military Craft
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Carter Administration, in a shoW of support for President Anwar, elSadat, privately informed key members of Congress today that it would like to sell Egypt more than $200 million in military reconnaissance and transpbrt planes.

title: Zoologist Scotches Plesiosaur Rumors
description: LONDON, July 26 (Reuters)A Scottish zoologist said today that the creature picked up by a Japanese trawler in deep waters off New Zealand last April was a decomposed sea lion.

title: Crahay Turns Paris Into a Celebration
description: PARIS, July 26The first bravos of the fall couture showings resounded today in the Ceztle Interallie on the Faubourg St. Homed where JulesFrancois Crahay presented his collection for Lanvin. It was done in a brilliant haute peasant style, ranging all over history and the globe and the names of the dresses give some indication of the scope: Petrograd, Katmandu Marrakech. Salome.

title: Eastern Will Divert 3.5% of Wages
description: Eastern Air Lines, reporting yesterday sharp drop in net income, to $3.2 million from $19.3 million, also disclosed an unusual pact with union employees whereby 3.5 percent of their wages are to be deducted and put in a fund to insure the carrier a 2 percent annual profit on gross revenues.

title: Rites Held for Slain Connecticut Girl
description: WATERBURY, Conn., July 26  It was 6yearold Jennifer Santoro's brief life that they talked about at her funeral today, not the manner of her death. The priest who offered the mass called her a really beautiful flower in God's garden, a very nice little girl.

title: Beame, Backed by Carey, to Make A Formal Bid Friday for Olympics
description: With the enthusiastic backing of Governor Carey, Mayor Beanie announced yesterday that he would formally ask the United States Olympic Committee on Friday to select New York as the host city for the 1984 Summer Olympics.

title: Notes on People
description: THE DESTITUTE widow of Pvt. Eddie Slovik, the only American soldier shot for desertion since the Civil War, said yesterday she had been told by White House officials she'll have to wait at least two more weeks to learn whether she will receive her husband's military pay benefits. Antoinette Slovik, who has waged a 23year battle to have her husband's World War II records changed so that she may receive about $70,000 in military insurance and interest, said she was told at first that she would finally get a ruling early this week. Now, she said, the decision will have to be made personally by Clifford L. Alexander Jr., Secretary of the Army, and he won't be back from Europe until Aug. 8.

title: Revamping of New York G.O.P. Is Sought by New State Chairman
description: ALBANY, July 26The new chairman of the New York Republican State ComMittee said today that he would seek approval to restructure the party, primarily by expanding its executive committee and appointing special vice chairmen for party affairs.

description: Pan American World Airways Inc. has reported an 82.4 percent drop in earnings for the second quarter of 1977, despite a substantial increase in revenues and the first blackink airline operations for the period since 1969.

title: 55.085 See Alouettes Win
description: MONTREAL, July 26 (AP)  A staunch Montreal defense and 10 points by Don Sweet, a placekicker led the Alouettes to their third straight victory, a 176 Canadian Football League triumph over Calgary tonight. A crowd of 55,085, the largest in the league this season, saw Sweet kick field goals of 48, 33 and 15 yards, plus an extra point.

title: Bridge

title: Bat Battalino, Won Featherweight Title And Fought Until '40
description: Christopher (Bat) Battalino, a tough body puncher who was the world featherweight champion from 1929 to 1932, died Monday in West Hartford. He was 69 years old.

title: Enterprise Wing Twice, Takes Command in Trial
description: NEWPORT, RI., July 26When the history of this summer's campaign for the defense of the America's Cup is written, July 26 will be the important date because on this day the yacht Enterprise took command of the competition. She twice defeated Independence, the other new 12Meter, doing it so decisivelyby 1 minute 3 seconds and 1:59as to dispel much of the fog that had surrounded these trials among the three yachts aspiring for the role of defender.

title: Reconnection of Severed Arm Fails After Infection Sets In
description: An attempt to reconnect the severed arm of a 38yearold man ended in failure last night when infection set in and the arm had to be amputated.

title: U.S. STEEL'S PROFITS OFF 36% IN QUARTER; LAG IN DEMAND CITED
description: The United States Steel Corporation's secondquarter net income fell 36.2 percent although sales ran S.3 percent higher, the company reported yesterday. Its firsthalf profit dropped 52.3 percent as sales ran only 6.7 percent ahead of the yearago level.

Now that yesterday's crisis is rising to the level of a longrange problem, it looks as if the moped may be about to attain similar degree of acceptance. Virginia and West Virginia.

Besieged by racial divisions, scarred by riots and the scourges of age and urban decay, the city has, in horror, watched, its decline portrayed in countless newspaper accounts and at least two major television documentaries over the last few years.

title: Rock: Fluid Harvey Mandel
description: HARVEY MANDEL, who brought a rock group into the Bottom Line on Monday, has been a Rolling Stones session guitarist, a member of Canned Heat and a participant in a number of distinctive rock and blues collaborations. If any single word describes his guitar style, it is fluidity. Mr. Mandel's lines seem to ooze out of hisinstrument, forming globules like a viscous fluid; they are the perfect aural counterpart to the lightshow blobs one used to see at rock concerts in the 1960's.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: Dodgers Turn Back Phils, 51, Then Lose by 51
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers have been anything but efficient in the last two weeks, but the Cincinnati Reds have been even worse, having lost eight straight games.

title: Chester Roth, Dies at 75; Founded Hosiery Concern That Became KayserRoth
description: Chester H. Roth, chairman and chief executive officer of the KayserRoth Corporation, died yesterday at his Manhattan home. He was 75 years old and lived at the Hotel Pierre.

title: Playing Dangerous Games
description: PARISThe logical conclusion to be deduced from Moscow's new African policy is a Kremlin decision to try to crush or overthrow the Egyptian Government of President Anwar elSadat. During the past 18 months or so the following events have contributed to this idea:

title: The Now York Times/Teresa Meta
description: ITALIAN LEADER ARRIVES IN U.S.: Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti Italy thanking President Carter after the President's welcoming speech White House lawn. At center is Vice President Mondale. Page A8.

title: Around the Nation
description: Special to The New York Tures

title: FBI RAIDSON CHURCH ARE RULEDIMPROPER
description: WASHINGTON. July 27 A Federal Judge ruled today that a raid by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Church of Scientology office here July 8 hid been conducted with an improper search warrant and ordered the bureau. to surrender hundreds of documents it had seized.

title: orporation Affairs
description: The Maritime Administration announced in Washington yesterday the award of a $310 million contract to the General Dynamics Corporation's Quincy, Mass., shipbuilding division for construction of two tankers to carry liquefied natural gas from Algeria to Lake Charles, La. The Maritime Administration said it would fund $39.9 million of the cost.

title: Robinson Lifts Pirates Over Astros
description: Bill Robinson hit his 12th home run of the season in the ninth inning and tied the game, then scored the winning run in the 11th on a single by Rennie Stennett as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Houston Astros, 32, at Three Rivers Stadium last night. The victory was Pittsburgh's seventh straight.

title: Stock Tables Explained.
description: P/E refers to priceearnings rialo, the number of limes the company's latest 12month earnings can be divided into the stock's closing price. All prices are In dollars. The letter ustands tor new annual high', and dIndicates new low.

title: Big Board Issues Its Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies.

title: Blousons, Bustles At Saint Laurent
description: PARIS, July 27Yves Saint Laurent startled the fashion world a year ago with a collection that was singleminded and direct. Incredibly luxurious and lavish, it launched the haute peasant look that is still being recreated in couture salons and readytowear workrooms around the world.

title: Denny to Rejoin Cardinals
description: ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP)John Denny, St. Louis Cardinals righthander, will rejoin the club Friday and make his first start in six weeks on Saturday night, Manager Vern Rapp said today. Denny suffered a pulled hamstring muscle June 21 while pitching against the Los Angeles Dodgers and has been on the 21day disabled list.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL: James Earl Ray, convicted assassin of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., is led into courtroom in Wartburg, Tenn., by Stonney Lane, warden of the Brushy Mountain State Prison. Ray was arraigned with six others on charges of breaking out of the orison on June 10.

title: Alexander Is Upset by Bunis
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 27 (AP)Henry Bunis of Cincinnati, who played for Columbia University, stunned ninthseeded John Alexander of Australia, 64, 6.2, today in the first round of the $125,000 Louisville international tennis tournament.

title: New York City Will Hire Youths In a Drive to Thwart Arsonists
description: Several hundred youths will soon be hired by New York City to board up abandoned buildings in slum areas to combat the rising incidence of arson.

title: F.T.C. Tightens Proposed Rules On Advance Notice of Mergers
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The Federal Trade Commission made public today a revised and more complicated set of proposed regulations concerning the application of 1976 antitrust legislation requiring advance notice to the Government of some corporate merger, acquisition and takeover plans.

title: Tenants Reject Apartment Sale To Saudi Prince
description: An application by Prince Saud alFaisal, Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, to buy an 18room apartment at 640 Park Avenue has been rejected by the building's residents, realestate informants reported yesterday.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Some events of interest for enthusiasts of the house and home.

title: Chairman of Commodity Commission Asks Ban on Options Sales in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)William T. Bagley, chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, recommended that the sale of commodity options be banned in the United States.

title: Jon Gibson Plays Solo
description: JON GIBSON, who plays reed instruments and flutes with the Philip Glass ensemble and other Sohobased groups, is presenting solo recitals of his own music this week at the Franklin Street Art Center, 112 Franklin Street. The final performance is tonight at 8. Interestingly enough, the new works Mr. Gibson is performing are not in the hypnotic, steadystate vein he has often favored.

title: Bridget St. John Performs
description: KENNY'S CASTAWAYS, at 157 Bleecker Street, has an appealing if not entirely satisfying triple bill through Sunday. Actually, twoandahalf bill is more like it. First there's Bridget St. John, a veteran British folkie now based here. Miss St. John is accompanied on guitar and vocals by Jesse Walden, who then does three songs (15 minutes) on his own. The headliners are the Lunsfords, a family countryfolk group from Tennessee.

title: Beanie Rejects Rent Decontrol For Apartments of $300 and Up
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that his administration was rejecting an application by realestate interests to remove from rent control all controlled apartments in New York City renting for $300 a month or more.

title: Mother and 7 Children Are Buried
description: PROSPECT, CONN., July 27  A young mother and her seven children, victims of murder and arson in this suburb of Waterbury early last Friday, were buried side by side in a single grave here today following a restrained funeral service that drew nearly a thousand mourners to the St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church:

title: Alydar Takes Tremont With Speed and Style
description: For now. Alydar appears to be the heir to Seattle Slew as this year's top 2yearold thoroughbred.

title: Begin Rejects U.S. Charge That West Bank Settlements Violate Law
description: JERUSALEM, July 27prime Minister Menahem Begin today rejected the American contention that Israeli settlement in occupied Arab areas violated international law.

title: PRICES MOVE LOWER IN U.S. BOND MARKET
description: Prices moved lower in the Government bond market yesterday as participants sensed a possible upward adjustment in rates by the Federal Reserve.

title: Church That F.B.I. Raided Is an Amalgam of Unorthodoxy That Thrives on Contention
description: Scientology, the religion at the center of the controversy over raids by Federal agents, is an amalgam of elements from Hinduism, Buddhism, Hellenism, Taoism and Christianity, selected, assembled and imaginatively modified by the man whose title is founder and whose works are subject to official veneration.

title: Deaths
description: ATLAS  Dr. Samuel. Hebrew Union College  Jewish institute of Religion deeply mourns the death of Professor Samuel Atlas, for 35 years a distinguished member of Its faculty. As a philosopher he taught the tradition of philosophical idealism upholding its purity against skepticism and relativism; as a teacher of Talmud, he found clarity of reason In classic rabbinic thought. To him, the polyhistor, there was only one truth and pursuing It he considered his sacred task. Generations of students have been influenced by this rare man whose passion was ter the sublime verities of life. Faculty and students and the Board of Governors express their heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife.

title: U.S. ASKS HALT TO TRANSFER OF OVERSEAS INSURANCE
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reuters)The Carter Administration today asked Congress for authority to abandon efforts aimed at transferring to private companies government insurance against expropriation and other risks to United States businesses abroad.

title: Trade Deficit Up In June to a High Of $2.82 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 27A record $2.82 billion deficit in American trade in June was reported today by the Commerce Department, foreshadowing further weakness in the dollar and adding to gloom on Wall Street.

title: BLACK LEADER HINTS MORE JABS AT CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Vernon E. Jordan Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, said today at the close of his organizations convention that he was leaving town as he had arrived, dissatisfied and discontented with the Administraion's progress on social issues.

title: Scarlett O'Hara's Younger Sister
description: HOLLYWOOD  SCARLETT O'HARA'S Younger Sister is a strange sort of autobiography agg to have wait ten  a sexual odyssey up and down the decades, in which Evelyn Keyes pauses only occasionally to mention movie she has just started or just finished.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 27New jobs in New Jersey increased by 47,000 in May, and the;:number of people working in June was, near a record high the State Department of Labor and Industry Department said today.

title: Broker and Head of Gerber Spar On Offer by Anderson, Clayton
description: FREMONT, Mich., July 27An exchange between the chairman of the Gerber Products Company, John C. Suerth, and a Wall Street stockbroker who challenged the company's opposition to a proposed takeover enlivened Gerber's annual shareholder meeting today.

title: Swan Lake To PinUps
description: LEE, MASS. THE LATE Ted Shawn, performer, choreographer, cultural zealot and general father figure of modern dance, refused to turn his back on any form of dance. The Jacob's Pillow Festival, which remains as testimony to his allinclusive embrace, still features those programs of ballet, modern and ethnic presentations that were so dear to his heart.

title: crimes Against Elderly Bring Aged and Youths Into Court as Monitors
description: Inside the yellowpainted storefront on Olmstead Avenue in the East Bronx the old people were talking with the young people.

title: Home Beat
description: LL F YOU'RE going to give me an expensive gift, said Leonard Pollikof, the Los Angeles interior designer, give, me painting. He prefers a Johns or a Rauschenberg. It was his interest in contemporary art that led to the creation of Dropcloth, his first line of. handpainted fabrics. It is being sold to, the trade locally through Groundworks, Pat Ross's wallpaper and fabric showroom at 231 East 58th Street.

title: New York to Increase School Desegregation Funds
description: ALBANY, July 27The State Education Department intends to increase substantially its spending for school desegregation and for private education of the blind and handicapped, according to a preliminary budget request for 197879 released today.

title: House Bank Unit Ends Demand That Fed Project its Rate Goals
description: WASHINGTON. July 27, (Reuters).The House Banking Committee today bowd to criticism from Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve, and dropped a proposal that would have re= ouired him to make public forecasts of the. Government's interest rate goals..

title: Monetary Good Intentions: Side Effects, 1927 and 1977
description: Amid great attempts at secrecy, one of the pivotal meetings in modern economic history took place in New York 50 years ago this month. At that time. business was bustling in the United States, and the Wall Street boom was gathering force. But Britain was depressed by the rigidEconomic ities of the gold standard; Analysis France was struggling to stabilize its economy and Germany was still recovering from the shock of hyperinflation. On Friday, July 1, 1927, The. New York Times reported in its financial pages the impending arrival of the Mauretania, carrying Sir Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, and Hjalmar Schacht, president of the German Reichsbank. The two central bankers had attempted to travel incognito but had been discovered. In New York, they were joined by Charles Rist, deputy governor of the Bank of France.

title: Radio
description: 78, WNCN. March in D (K. 215), Mozart; Vidi Speciosam. Victoria; Second Rhapsody from Namouna, La lo; Gigue, Telemann; Andantino Valle for Piano Four Hands, Schubert; M'appari from Martha, Flotow; EtudeTableau No. 9, Rachamaninoff.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONThe enforcement of the Federal antitrust laws seems at a crossroads. New faces abound in influential Washington postions, promising revised priorities and new pet interests. And as the guard changes, there is considerable questioning whether antitrust enforcement has accomplisaed anythine.

title: Sweden Jails Soviet Hijacker
description: STOCKHOLM, July 27 (UPI)  Vasily Sosnovsky, a 37yearold Soviet citizen who commandeered a domestic Aeroflot airliner to Stockholm on May 26 and asked for political asylum in Sweden, was convicted today and sentenced to four years imprisonment. Despite Soviet appeals for the man's return, the Government decided that he would be tried in Sweden. According to the 1970 Hague Convention, to which both the Soviet Union and Sweden are signatories, hijackers may be expelled or tried in the country in which they are caught.

title: Bethlehem Halves Dividend to 25c; SecondQuarter Profit Off by 36%
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday cut its quarterly dividend in half, to 25 cents a share, and announced that its secondquarter earnings feii by 36 percentalmost an identical decline to that reported on Tuesday by the United States Steel Corporation.

title: Led Zeppelin Abandons Tour After Death of Son
description: KIDDERMINSTER, England, July 27 (Reuters)The rock group Led Zeppelin today abandoned an American tour after the death of lead singer Robert Plant's 5yearold son Karac from a mysterious infection. Mr. Plant rushed home to be with his wife, Maureen after he had learned of their son's illness.

title: ALLIE M. STEVENS
description: Allie M. Stevens, a former specialist in remedial skills for the New York City Board of Education, died Monday at her home, 1073 Warburton Avenue, Yonkers. She was 73 years old..She was the wife of Hope R. Stevens, a lawyer and president of the Harlem area Chamber of Commerce, who survives her.

title: FAULTY WELDS DELAY OIL ARRIVAL IN VALDEZ
description: VALDEZ, Alaska, July 27Faulty welding, a problem that has plagued the TransAlaska Pipeline system for two years, spoiled plans to bring the first oil into the pipeline terminal here today in preparation for loading the first tanker this weekend.

title: Redskin Back Hurt in Drill
description: CARLISLE, Pa., July 27 (UPI)Mike Thomas, Washington Redskins running back who reported to camp last night after a twoday holdout, strained a hamstring muscle at this morning's practice. Thomas, who is obligated to the Redskins in the option year of his contract, is seeking a new pact. It has been reported that he wants $100,000 nearly four times his salary in each of his first two seasons.

title: News Summary
description: Sudan has been told that the United States is ready to contribute to its legitimate defense needs. This follows the decision to sell military supplies to Somalia and the request to Congress to approve sales to Egypt. A State Department official said similar requests from Chad woula get sympathetic consideration. The Carter Administration, an official explained, has decided to challenge Soviet inroads in a strategically important ares and also to demonstrate strong support for President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, who along with Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Fand has repeatedly urged such involvement. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: A PROCESSION OF PALLBEARERS, carrying the white coffins containing the bodies of murder, arson victims Cheryl Beaudoinand her seven children, enters cemetery In Prospecf, Conn. Page
description: The New Tot Times ????

title: Bridge:
description: CHICAGO, July 27Three Texans had won their second major team title in a period of 11 days when the Spingold knockout team championship ended here in the early hours of this morning.

title: Validity of Drake Relic Is Disputed
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 27Nuclear chemists at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory today released evidence that a brass plate thought to have been left by Sir Francis Drake when he landed on the northern California coast in 1579 is not authentic.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: A PROCESSION OF PALLBEARERS) carrying the white coffins containing the bodies of murder arson victims Cheryl Beaudoin and her seven children, enters cemetery in Prospect, Conn. Page.

title: Grocer Is Held as Revenge Killer After Slaying of His Wife in Holdup
description: A Brooklyn grocer whose wife was shot to death by robbers Monday night was arrested on a murder charge yesterday afternoon, accused of having killed one of his wife's assailants.

title: Books: Poet of the Ballet
description: THE DEVELOPMENT of British ballet, wrote a critic for London's The Tatler, will owe so much to this young man. The remark, made in 1933, was prophetic. The young man was the great English ballet choreographer Frederick Ashton, molder of the lucid, elegant British performance style, but then a neophyte who earned a pound a minute for his first ballets and took on the most frivolous of musical comedy assignments in those arduous but very happy days that began both his career and the English ballet.

title: Talented hands can create a mural, a wine cellar or a window box. See Page
description: Talented hands can create a mural, a wine cellar or a window box. See Page Illustration by Hal Just

title: In Memoriam
description: COHENRose, 3 years today, beloved wife of the late David, devoted mother of the late Sylvia Mintzer and Mildred Malin, dear grandmother of Lewis and. Stephen Malin and Freya Mintzer. You are always and forever in our hearts.

title: Israel's Unsettling Settlements
description: In giving, official sanction to three previously unauthorized settlements on the occupied West Bank the Jordan River, Prime Minister Begin's new Israeli Government has surely complicated the search for Middle East peace settlement. By making the move only hours after his return from a generally amicable meeting with President Carter, Mr. Begin has also complicated further his relations with the United States.

title: Insulin Supply Called Sufficient
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 27 (UPI)The United States has enough insulin to meet the needs of all diabetics, Eli Lilly & Company officials said today. Lilly issued the statement in response to a request by the Food and Drug Administration for insulin makers to review whether supplies are ample to meet the needs of certain patients now treated with an oral drug called phenformin, which was declared an imminent hazard to.public health Monday by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: PRODUCTIVITY GAINS CITED FOR MOST U.S. INDUSTRIES
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  Most American manufacturing, trade and service industries showed significant productivity improvement in 1976 with the only major declines in mining industries, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Tannan Zee Playhouse To Reopen Tuesday
description: The Tappan Zee Playhouse in Tappan, N. Y., closed for the last two years after a fire that partly destroyed its backstage, will reopen next Tuesday for a fiveweek summer season with the premiere of Columbus Circle, musical with book and lyrics by Isaiah Chaffer and music by Bobby Paul. The show, a retelling of the story of Chris topher Columbus from a slightly whacky political and theatrical perspective, features Geanie Faulkner, James Barbosa and Maurice Edwards. It will play through Aug. 7.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street. the Bronx, 2 P.M. (RadloWMCA, 1:55 P.M.)

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: WHEAT

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)The Vatican has granted permission for Roman Catholics in this country to receive communion in the hand if they choose, rather than on the tongue.

title: Pennsylvania Site Yields Clues to Life Of Stone Abe Man
description: AVELLA, Pa.  Chill autumn winds howled across a massive rock overhang sheltering the ledge where a little band of Stone Age hunters huddled around a campfire.

title: DR. MORRIS GLEICH
description: Dr. Morris Gleich, a retired pediatrician, died yesterday at his San Diego, Calif., home. He was 88 years old.

title: Soviet Sensitive About Its Debt to the West
description: MOSCOW, July 27The Soviet Union's sensitivity about its trade deficit with the West was underscored today as the, press rebutted suggestions that Moscow might have overextended itself in seeking Western credits.

title: F.B.I. PAYMENT LINKED TO WIRETAPPING SITE
description: NEW HAVEN, July 27 A document made public tonight by an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said that the agency had rented an apartment for the New Haven Police Department to do legal police work in. The bureau was unaware, according to records, that the apartment was being used for an alleged illegal wiretap operation by the local police.

title: Tony Kornheiser
description: Down deep in the belly of the Nassau Coliseum the air conditioning was working overtime, giving the hall a winter's chili. Some maintenance men were just beginning to set up the floor seats for a rock concert, and the gray concrete walls provided the workers with all the comfort and grace of a fallout shelter. On the day of Roy L.M. (Let's Move) Boe's victory party at the Meadowlands, a Coliseum carpenter named Bill Weitzman was trying to put Boe's moving of the Nets into perspective.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a United Press International dispatch in The Times on July 6, John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, was incorrectly quoted as saying that the disclosure of improper corporate payments could destroy a company's business and ruin the persons involved. In fact, Mr. Connor said that such payments could themselves be destructive and ruinous, not merely their disclosure.

title: Jazz Tree in Flower
description: THE FIRST of Harry Chapin's two performances at the Dr. Pepper Festival in Central Park was rained out on Monday, but on Tuesday at 5 P.M. the show began under faultless blue skies, opening with the Jazz Tree led by Mr. Chapin's father, Jan. This Chapin nevotism is becoming something of a fixture in Central Park. Last year's show also opened with Jim Chapin's jazz group and proceeded to an energetic song recital by Harry Chapin, with his brother Steve featured on piano.

title: MSGR. MICHAEL A. BUCKLEY
description: Msgr. Michael A. Buckley, in charge of the Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue since 1970, died at the home on Tuesday. He was 71 years old. Monsignor Buckley, who was ordained in 1932, had been a teacher at Cardinal Hayes High School, a principal of Dubois High School, and had been the founder and first pastor of St. John Vianney Parish in the Bronx. He was named a papal chamberlain in 1950 and a domestic prelate in 1956.

title: BHT, A Food Preservative, Called Dangerous to the Public's Health
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  A preservative used for nearly 30 years in potato chips, cake mixes and other foods should be banned immediately because of safety questions, a public interest group told the Government yesterday.

title: U. S. EXPLAINS PLAN ON KOREA TO JAPAN
description: TOKYO, July 27The Japanese Government, worried about the planned withdrawal of United States ground forces from South Korea, was assured today by Secretary of Defense Harold Brown that the Carter Administration intended to maintain strong military forces in Asia and play an active roie there.

title: The Friction Between Carter and His Constituency
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The sparks flying from Vernon E. Jordan Jr.'s recent criticism of President Carter may suggest o developing pattern of friction between the White House and the various pressure points of its constituency. Mr. Jordan, executive Director or the National Urban League, accused News Mr. Carter earlier this week Analysis of neglecting the interests of black Americans after ardently courting them as candidate. In response, the President said that he had no apologies for his approach to the problems of poor minorities and bluntly told Mr. Jordan that his complaints hurt rather than helped the situation.

title: GARDENING
description: WHAT better way to dispel the moisture of the mind brought on by the clinging heat and humidity than to think dryor dried. To be more specific, consider drying flowers now from summer's bountiful stand of color to cheer the fall and winter days ahead.

title: Mets Beat Giants, 74; Matlack Is Hurt Again
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 27Nobody threw any beanballs for a change, but the New York Mets still suffered casualty today while defeating the San Francisco Giants, 74. Their No. 1 pitcher, Jon Matlack, left the game after five innings with a stiff shoulder.

title: Cosmos Rout Diplomats, 82, As Chinaglia Scores 3 Goals
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 27With Franz Beckenbauer playing brilliantly in midfield and Giorgio Chinaglia in high spirits on attack, the Cosmos trounced the Washington Diplomats. 82. at Giants Stadium tonight.

title: Legalesey Does It
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Why do lawyers write the way they do? Why must wills give, devise and bequeath, or leases caution without let or hindrance, or contracts convey right, title and interestand all the rest, residue and remainder of legal archaisms?

title: Naturalist Dies of Bee Sting
description: MOUNT WASHINGTON, Mass., July 27 (AP)George Handler, 31 years old, naturalist at Taconic State Park, New York, died yesterday of a bce sting received while hiking with his wife on his day off, the police said. Mr. Handler, of Savoy, lost consciousness almost immediately after being stung in a rugged area of Mount Washington State Forest. He was pronounced dead on arrival at Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington.

title: People in Sports
description: The National Football League has ordered George Atkinson to leave the Oakland Raiders training camp until he pays $2,000 in fines. Atkinson, the defensive back who just lost a $2 million slander snit against the Pittsburgh Steelers, was fined $1,500 for alleged dirty play last year when he sidelined Lynn Swann with a concussion and another, $500 for another incident against the New England Patriots in the playoffs.

title: Wilderness Plan Rouses Minnesota Lake Country And Poses Hard Questions About Land Use Policy
description: ELY, Minn.With a small grunt of disgust, Dan Engstrom bent to pick up the CocaCola can lying in the mossy bog and placed it carefully in the center of the trail.

title: Rambling Willie Is Favored
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., July 27A field of eight will start tomorrow night at the Meadowlands in the final of the $186,000 Governor Alfred E. Driscoll pacing series. Rambling Willie, the top moneywinner In the first three legs, has drawn post No. 2 and been named the 52 morningline favorite.

title: Personal Beauty
description: IT HAD TO HAPPEN: a beauty book for men. With books that promise to make women more attractive coming out faster than cookbooks, it was inevitable that men would have their turn. Of ccurse, Looking Good (Hawthorn, $14.75) is not billed as a beauty book. Grooming is the word most often used. Charles Hix, the author, isn't happy with groominghe says that's what one does to a horsebut is resigned to it until somebody comes up with a better word.

title: A Peculiar Valkyrie in Seattle
description: SEATTLE THERE WAS one peculiar thing about the staging of Wagner's The Valkyrie by the Seattle Opera Tuesday night. It was all the more peculiar in that the cycle is presented in a completely traditional manner. How long has it been since you last saw a Brllnnhilde in full battle dress complete with spear, breastplate and winged helmet? But for some reason the end of Act II saw Wotan destroying Siegmund's sword not with his but by lightning bolt.

title: Turin Cardinal Resigns
description: ROME. July 27 (Reuters)Pbpe Paul VI has accepted the resignation of 74yearold Michele Cardinal Pellegrino of Turin, one of Italy's most progressive churchmen, for reasons of health, spokesman announced today.

title: Anglican Report in Canada Leans Toward Euthanasia
description: OTTAWA, July 27  The Anglican Synod of Canada has been asked to consider endorsing the termination of life at birth for severely retarded infants, as well as the withdrawal of life support for the terminally ill.

title: About New York
description: Midsummer in New York is a time for stocktaking, which in this midsummer is synonymous with votegetting. The action is in the form of questions, momentous questions that are either rhetorical or unanswerable. Why did the lights go out? Where will we get the money? Why won't the Feds send more help? Is New York going down the drain? In this league of heavy imponderables it may strike some as frivolous to find a city agency fielding a question such as. Tennis, anyone?

title: Africa's Horn: New Alliances
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 27The Carter Administration's decision in principle to supply military assistance to Somaliaa nation that surpasses the rest of Africa in its dependence upon Soviet armsis stunning evidence of how quickly the crazyquilt pattern of major power alliantes is changing in the volatile Horn of Africa.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Moynihan Bill Asks Envoys Expulsion In Phone Intercepts
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Citing reports that Soviet agents are eavesdropping on the telephone calls of hundreds of thousands of Americans, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan introduced today a bill requiring the President to, expel diplomats who engage in electronic surveillance in the United States.

title: OPEC Members Borrow $4 Billion In First Seven Months of 1977
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries borrowed $4 billion in international markets during the first seven months of 1977, compared to $4.1 billion during all of 1976, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reported.

title: Washington & Business
description: With new figures coming into important positions in antitrust enforcement, there is considerable questioning whether such enforcement has accomplished anything. Page D3.

title: Injured Jets Staying Home
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 27  The Jets, restricted to taking 65 players an their traveling squad to Canton, Ohio, for Saturday's N.F.L. preseason opener against the Chicago Bears, have decided to leave home their injured and those players just returning to practice from injuries.

title: WELFARE FRAUD LAID TO 79 IN GOVERNMENT
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn announced yesterday the arrest Of 79 government employees on charges of defrauding the New York City Department of Social Services of nearly $500,000.

title: Italy Rescinds Its Ban on Entry Of Foreign Students Into Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  The Italian Government has rescinded a ban on new foreign students entering Italian universities during the coming scadeinic year. Prime MinisterGiulio Andreotti said here today.

title: Jersey Panel to Own Nets If Team Fails Financially
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 27The New Jersey Sports Authority could become the owner of the Nets basketball team.

title: Services for Slain Doctor and Wife
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 27  Memorial services for Dr. Warren A. Mann, a Connecticut psychiatrist, and his wife, RoseMarie, discovered fatally shot Sunday morning in their New Canaan home in what police said was a murder and suicide, will be conducted at 11 A.M. Saturday at the First Presbyterian Church here. According to the New Canaan police and medical examiner's reports, Mrs. Mann, in ill health for two years, is believed to have used a shotgun to kill her sleeping husband and then to have taken her own life with the same weapon.

title: Beame Vexed on U.S. Welfare Help
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Mayor Beame found his bands tied tonight in his latehour campaign to win more Federal aid for welfare costs after the Carter Administration said it had an aid package, but declined to disclose its specifics.

title: Curb on Diplomatic Immunity To Parking Fine Passes House
description: If a bill now making its way through Congress does become law, diplomatic license plates will no longer be a license to park illegally in New York City.

title: SMALLBUSINESS AID BILL SENT TO CARTER BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)A bill to authorize $2.96 billion for smallbusiness programs in the two years beginning Oct. 1 was sent to President Carter today.

title: United Press International
description: KENT STATE PROTEST continues through night despite erection of chainlink fence around construction site of new gymnasium. They are opposing new structure because it will be built on site where four students were killed by National Guardsmen in 1970. The group's leaders yesterday. pleaded innocent to charges stemming from the protest.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW JULY 30

title: U.S. STEPS UP OFFERS OF ARMS TO AFRICANS; READY TO AID SUDAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 The Carter Administration, in another major policy decision on supplying military equipment to African nations, said today that it had informed the Sudan that the United States was prepared to contribute to its legitimate defense needs.

title: PERUVIAN MILITARY WARNED BY CHURCH
description: LIMA, Peru, July 27The Roman Catholic leadership has warned Peru's military regime against trying to solve this country's severe economic crisis by using repressive methods against labor protest.

title: F.B.I. Candidate Withdraws
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)Judge Harlington Wood Jr. of United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit withdrew today as a candidate for director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation because of personal reasons and family considerations, the Justice Department announced. Judge Wood of Chicago was one of five selections a search committee recommended to President Carter for successor to Clarence M. Kelley, who has announced that be would retire Jan. 1.

title: 'Spy Who Loved' A Bit Long on Bond
description: DURING THE COURSE OF "The Spy Who Loved Me," James Bond vanquishes an amphibious building that looks like a giant spider, a 7 foot 2 inch villain with metal fangs, hundreds of hapless extras and one very beautiful broad, but he hardly ever comes to grips with his most insidious adversary, the James Bond formula.The same conventions that have provided 10 Bond movies with their patent pizazz also serve as a straitjacket, and these days a Bond film is interesting only insofar as it quietly subverts the series' old tricks. Happily, "The Spy Who Loved Me" has its share of self-mockerynot enough for a full-scale send-up, but enough to give shopworn old 007 a shot in the arm.The motivating sentiment behind the Bond movies has always been envy: the viewer, poor slob, is expected to covet Bond's women, admire his elaborate playthings and marvel at his ability to chase through the desert in evening clothes without getting dusty. Fifteen years ago, at the time of "Dr. No," this sort of thing was a great deal more effective than it is today, because the notion was new and the gadgets could be genuinely dazzling. But by now Bond fans have seen so many fast cars and floozies come and go that they may be almost as jaded as James himself.Almost, but not quite: Roger Moore is so enjoyably unflappable that you sometimes have to look closely to make sure he's still breathing. Presented with a fabulous new white Lotus, he drives off impatiently without even examining the car's special accessories (as it turns out, the Lotus can swim). Seduced by a conniving cutie, he looks desperately bored.Mr. Moore has the anonymous aplomb of a male modelappropriate, because the film is littered with trademark-bearing merchandise  and he seems incapable of bringing much individualized zest to the role. But his exaggerated composure amounts to a kind of backhanded liveliness. Though Mr. Moore doesn't compromise the character, he makes it amusingly clear that hedonism isn't all it's cracked up to be.The plot this time, which bears no resemblance to that of Ian Fleming's novel, features Curt Jurgens as a shipping magnate determined to destroy the world and Barbara Bach as a Rusian agent who grudgingly joins forces with Bond to pole-ax this scheme. Miss Bach is spectacular but a little dim, even by Bond standards; certainly she makes no sense as a master spy who is almost (but not quite) as ingenious as 007 himself.In all fairness, Miss Bach's is an impossible role: Beauty and brains needn't be incompatible, but maintaining the requisite level of pulchritude of a Bond heroine is such a full-time job that it precludes any other work more strenuous than, say, watching Bond sip his very dry martini (shaken, not stirred).The film moves along at a serviceable clip, but it seems half an hour too long, thanks to the obligatory shoot-'em-up conclusion, filmed on the largest sound-stage in the world, but nevertheless the dullest sequence here. Bond's final blowout, however lavishly produced, has long since gotten to be old hat, and besides, it's the attention to smaller details that has helped the series maintain its high gloss.The theme song, sung by Carly Simon, ranks with Paul McCartney's theme from "Live and Let Die" as one of the most delightful surprises the series has had to offereven if it is accompanied by footage of a naked woman, in silhouette, doing silly calisthenics on the barrel of an enormous gun."The Spy Who Loved Me" has a PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") rating even though Bond indulges in his favorite means of exercise a little more listlessly than usual. A number of extras are gunned down almost bloodlessly, and arch-villain Curt Jurgens feeds his secretary to a shark.

title: 4 IN CATHOLIC SLUMS DIE IN BELFAST HOSTILITIES
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 27 (Reuters)Gun and knife battles flared between rival groups in the Catholic slums of western Belfast tonight and the toll rose to four dead and 40 wounded.

title: Britain Ends Rein on Pound Rate To Cut Danger From Tie to Dollar
description: LONDON, July 27In a move to minimize danger to Britain from the skidding dollar, the Government today abandoned a monthslong policy of holding the pound at about $1.72 and let it rise nearly 13A cents to the highest level since last September.

title: Linowitz Calls U.S. Much Closer To New Treaty on Panama Canal
description: Mr. Linowitz, a former delegate to the Organization of American States who is negotiating the treaty with Ellsworth Bunker, called it conceivable but not likely that a treaty could be agreed to by the end of next month.

title: Andreotti Ends Washington Visit
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy today ended an official visit to Washington marked by extreme caution on the part of President Carter and Administration leaders on the problem posed by Italy's powerful Communist Party.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Half of the 4,000 teachers in the Newark public schools will be forced to show the proper state credentials in order to keep their jobs, it was disclosed yesterday.

description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 27More than 185 homes, each worth upward of $100,000, were destroyed by an explosive brush fire last night that devastated large parts of one of the nation's most scenic residential communities.

Civiletti said today in an unusual public discussion of the case before junior members of the House.

description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: EXAMINER BACKS CON ED IN BID FOR GAS RATE RISE
description: ALBANY, July 27 (AP)  The Consolidated Edison Company should be allowed to raise its rates for its 1.1 million gas customers an average 8.5 percent, a hearing officer for the Public Service Commission recommended today.

title: Judge Dismisses 18 of 24 Counts In U.S. Tax Case Against Lawyer
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., July 27A Federal judge in Palo Alto has thrown out 18 of the 24 counts of a tax fraud indictment against Harry Margolis, a Bay Area lawyer. The ruling came as a blow to Government prosecutors, who had called the case perhaps the biggest breakthrough we've ever had in the whole area of fraud and the widspread use of offshore tax havens

title: Senators Vote to Bar Tax Money to Fund Primaries for Senate
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)The Senate voted today against using tax funds to help to pay for the primary campaigns of candidates for the Senate.

title: Stocks Drop 19.75; G.M. Net 1.1 Billion
description: A selling wave engulfed the stock market yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 19.75 points in its biggest oneday drop in more than two years. Only 262 issued showed a gain while 1,327 stocks declined.

description: DENVILLE, N.J., July 27Martin Vybihal of Clinton, N.J., who has just returned from playing in the world junior golf championships in California, today led the way into the semifinal round of the 60th Metropolitan Golf Association junior tournament at the Rockaway River Country Club.

description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 27 (AP)With lawyers and a judge gathered around his hospital bed, Groucho Marx, the 86yearold comedian, today accepted the appointment of his grandson as his conservator.

Despite a hot News summer night, about 100 people turned out to hear of the versatile environmental Dogs and wildlife radio commentator.

title: L.I. Mailman Kills Himself In Road as Police Plead: Don't Do It, Don't Do It
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., July 27Two policemen spent 45 minutes today trying to convince a despondent man not to kill himself. They pleaded with him, listened to him, tried to soothe him with patience. But 29yearold Thomas A. Duffy, who sat on the Meadowbrook Parkway clutching a shotgun, took his life anyway.

title: 2 Networks to Carry Carter News Parley
description: President Carter's news conference at 10:30 o'clock this morning will be broadcast live by two networks, CBS and ABC, and their local stations, Channels 2 and 7. NBC will carry the proceedings only on its radio network. WNET/Channel 13 has scheduled live coverage as well as a rebroadcast at 7 o'clock tonight. The following radio stations will broadcast the news conference live: WCBSAM, WINS, WMCA, WNBC and WNYCAM.

title: Letter From Home
description: NEW HAVEN IONCE HEARD S.J. Perelman say that, after Arabic, Yiddish is the world's richest language for cursing and that one of the strongest epithets during his boyhood was: May a trolley car grow in your stomach. Even in English this sounds painful, and the only consolation is that it sotiqds unlikely. I also know as a born New Yorker and a baseball fan that the Brooklyn Dodgers were so named because the residents of that borough learned by necessity to be trolley dodiers. The team should have left its nickname behind when it moved to Los Angeles, a city consecrated to the automobile. In any race, the two linguistic curios recall an era when trolleys were so profuse that they were a menace as well as an amenity in American life, and I think of them whenever I pass the signs pointing to TROLLEY MUSEUM (SEASONAL) in nearby East Haven.

title: Design Notebook
description: SOMETHING LOOKS different at Bonwit Teller, Lord & Taylor, and Macy's these days. It is not so much new merchandise as new housing for merchandise, an extensive redesign that has altered the physical appearance of these three venerable institutions and their spirit as well.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE WAY IT IS Details of book production, book trends and other aspects of the publishing world will be discussed today at 12:30 P.M. in the regular, admissionfree Hour With the Author session at the Mercantile Library Association. The guest speaker, Carol Houck Smith, a trade editor of W. W. Norton Publishers, will also examine the relationship between editors and writers.

title: News Summary
description: Sudan has been told that the United States is ready to contribute to its legitimate defense needs. This follows the decision to sell military supplies to Somalia and the request to Congress to approve sales to Egypt. A State Department official said similar requests from Chad would get sympathetic consideration. The Carter Administration, an official explained, has decided to challenge Soviet inroads in a strategically important area and also to demonstrate strong support for President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, who along with Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Fated has repeatedly urged such involvement. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Courageous Victor Over Enterprise
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 27Cutler Godfrey, a member of the small group of natty yachtsmen who go out each day in large vessels to watch the America's Cup boats race, returned to Newport early today. He figured there was no more to see because Enterprise, the going boat, had a comfortable lead of a couple of lengths on Courageous and the race locked un.

title: Philharmonic to Start Park Season Tuesday
description: The first of this summer's free park concerts by the New York Philharmonic will be given next Tuesday at 8:30 P:M. in the Sheep Meadow of Central Park. Andre Kostelanetz will conduct Tchaikovsky's Coronation March and Symphony No. 6, Ravel's Daphnis and Chloe Suite No. 2 and Offenbach's Gaite Parisienne. As is customary, fireworks will accompany the final measures of the concert.

title: Sound
description: EACH JUNE, at Chicago's Consumers Electronics Show, the audio industry unveils its latest productsif that's the proper expression for something other than monumentsand this year's show was the biggest of ail. With more than 50,000 audio dealers and distributors from some 40 countries milling around 700 exhibits, the event overflowed the vast spaces of McCormick Place, Chicago's lakefront exhibition center, spilling over into dozens of hotel suites along Michigan Avenue and up the Gold Coast.

description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N. Y.Jo (Vollers) Tolhurst travelled the farthest, from Kailua, Hawaii. Janet (Shearon) Armstrong brought the most famous husband: the first man to walk on the moon. He didn't say much. George ("Duke") Hust, a Minneapolis broker, had aged less visibly than any man present except maybe Billy Jenks (we who knew him in the sixth grade never think of him as Bill), a marketing manager in Toledo.

title: Delfo Draws No. 1 Post
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 27Delfo of Italy, winner of the International Trot, drew the coveted rail slot for Saturday's $50,000 Challenge Cup rematch of the International contestants at Roosevelt Raceway. The oddsmaker established Delfo as the morning line 31 favorite for the 1mile trot.

title: Drug Dealer Slain in U.S. Prison; Was Linked to Big Heroin Theft
description: Vincent C. Papa, a major narcotics dealer who was linked to the theft of $70 million worth of drugs from the Police Departmetat property clerk's office in 1972, was stabbed to death late Tuesday in.the Federal penitentiary in Atlanta, Federal officials disclosed yesterday.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Away with formal tablecloths; bring on the placements Placemats today have come a long way from the basic choice of wipeclean vinyl, woven straw or solidcolor linen. At Ground works, for example, you can get placemats you won't find anywhere else. That's because this fabrics establishment will take any of its 100 or so handsilkscreened prints and turn them into informal table linens. The handsome, heavyweight cotton placemats are $9; generous napkins are $7.50. While you're there, take a look at Groundworks's napkin rings. They are designed by Jerry Kott, a softsculpture craftsman, who has taken two thick cords of fabric and intricately knotted them into a ring. The napkin rings come in natural raw silk or black satin, or can be ordered in a range colors in satin; $12 each. Groundworks is at 231 East 58th Street.

title: Secret Service Reports Less Intelligence Data
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  H. S. Knight, the Secret Service director, said today that the Government's domestic intelligencegathering capabilities were so reduced that it had become more difficult to protect the President. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, attributed the reduction to the Freedom of Information and Privacy Acts.

title: ABC Is Altering NewsAnchor Role
description: WITH ROONE ARLEDGE, ABC's chief of sports programming, now taking over the news department as well, tinkering has finally started on the format of the network's evening news. And, quite understandably, nervousness reisrns.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 16yearold saleswoman was raped in a Queens novelty store last night by a man who forced her to open the store's safe and then fled, the police reported.

title: Giants Ramsey Earns More Than a Passing Glance
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 27Despite two sore ankles and an overabundance of stomach, Steve Ramsey showed the Giants for the first time today that he was not just a throwin to the Craig Morton deal.

title: Jacob Marschak, A Key Developer Of Economics Theory, Dies at 79
description: Jacob Marschak, an important developer of economics information theory and a contributor to the early study of econometrics at the University of Chicago, died yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 79 years old.

title: Heavy Rains Damage Utah Park
description: BRYCE CANYON, Utah, July 27 (AP)Heavy rains have washed out trails and damaged several natural rock formations at Bryce Canyon National Park, officials at the southern Utah park say. Storms earlier this week dumped more than two inches of rain on the park, known for its colorful shapes of eroded rock. The officials said that the rain had caused a partial collapse of a series of formations called the Camel and the Wise Men. The head of the camel collapsed onto the floor of the Bryce Amphitheater, they added.

title: U.S. STEPS UP OFFERS OF ARMS TO AFRICANS; READY TO AID SUDAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The Carter Administration, in another major policy decision on supplying military equipment $o African nations, said today that it had informed the Sudan that the United States was prepared to contribute to its legitimate defense needs.

Agency gave no indication of the time place of the test. Placards at center. read, Welcome with cheers the inauguration of Hua Kuofeng as leader of the party and liberation army.

title: The Ground Is Broken For First Casino Hotel
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 27Ground was broken today for the first gambling casino hotel, to be operated by Resorts International.

title: ENTRIES
description: Horses listed In order of post Positions Letter designates 01B listing.

title: Letters
description: As a writer on things African and otherwise, I say brave to your comments in your Home Best I column of July 7. Besides being a superhypa the manufacturer has made a classic error regarding wildlife in Africa: There are no tigers. As the gentleman showed a tigertype carpet to the Zulu, I'm not surprised he was met with surprise. As far as getting the mark of authenticity, therefore, it's of somewhat dubious value. The Zulu's chances of knowing such an animal so well are about as likely as a desert nomad's.

title: Books of The Times
description: ANTHONY SAMPSON continues to bring us the bad news. The author of the exemplary Anatomy of Britain has in recent years addressed himself to huggermugger among the multinational corporations. such as International Telephone & Telegraph in The Sovereign State: The Secret History of ITT and the oil cartel in The Seven Sisters. Now he turns his baleful eye and supple prose on the merchants of death, the armsmakers and exporters, their eagerbeaver salesmen, bagmen, undercover agents and bought politicians, all of whom help to make the Middle East and other hot spots such interesting places to.try to live.

title: Senators Seek Additional Time To. Weigh Disputed Sale to Iran
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee asked President Carter toddy for a month's delay to consider more fully the proposed $1.5 billion sale of a highly secret air defense system to Iran.

title: OntheJob Safety
description: WASHINGTONNot long ago, President Carter's brother, Billy, had few wellchosen words for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Using somewhat more colorful language, he told officials of the agency to jump in a lake when they required him to install a couch in his ladies washroom.

title: Hers
description: CERTAIN BOOKS are so wonderful that I can't bring myself to finish them. They stimulate me as James Thurber once commented about a brilliant friendto a point beyond which I think I cannot go.

title: Discord Besets the New Rochelle Inquiry on Killings,
description: The threejudge panel appointed to examine charges that the New Rochelle Police Department had failed to investigate a 1975 murder threat by the sniper, Nazi sympathizer, who fatally shot five persons there last February has threatened to resign because of alleged political interference with its work.

title: Garden State Decision Delayed
description: TRENTON, July 27 (AP)A spokesman for the Garden State Racing Association said today the association would decide by Aug. 20 whether to rebuild the Cherry Hill track that was destroyed by fire or sell it.

title: Disks: Grieg's Peer Gynt Is Crafted With Care
description: There was a time not long ago when Grieg's incidental music for Peer Gynt was an inescapable fixture of lightclassical programs. It seems less popular now, along with so much pictorial sentimental music of the turn of the century, and in this case at least that's a great pity. For this is lovely music, crafted with exact care and invariably capable of making a fresh effect. The new Andrew DavisNew Philharrnonia disk is about as fine as any of its competitors. Partly that's due to Mr. Davis (a promising younger British conductor and no relation to Colin Davis) and the excellence of the playing and recording. But it's also due to Elisabeth Soderstrom the superb Swedish soprano who sings here in Grieg's native Norwegian. Miss Stiderstrom, an artist of refined quality, with a demurely sensual soprano, has never made a big American reputation, and at this stage of her career some of the major operatic parts would tax her. Here she sounds technically comfortable, and her phrasing and sensitivity are really quite wonderful. The five songs added after the Peer Gynt music (two of them orchestrated by Mr. Davis) only make the disk more desirable.

title: MS QUARTERLY NET TOPS $1 BILLION MARK FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: DETROIT, July 27The General Motors Corporation, the nations biggest automobile maker, today reported a profit of $1.1 billion for the second quarter ended June 30an increase of 20.6 percent. Until now, only the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had earned more than $1 billion in a quarter.

title: Energetic Reading
description: WHEN WE MOVED into our house on Long Island, one of the first things we did was to remove all the cornices from the living room a'nd library windows. Heavy draperies are oldfashioned and definitely not our style, we said, so we dressed our windows in living curtains of plants, with a few shutters and blinds where necessary for privacy.

title: Big Companies Quarterly Profits Showing Modest to Strong Gains
description: Despite disappointing earnings reports from such leading companies as Exxon, United States Steel and Bethlehem Steel, secondquarter corporate profits appeared to be registering moderate to relatively strong gains.

title: Reserve Mining Granted Permit
description: ROSEVILLE, Minn., July 27 (AP)A permit allowing the Reserve Mining Company to construct a waste disposal facility near its Silver Bay plant in northeastern Minnesota has been approved by the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency board.

title: State Health Chief in New Dispute_ With Aide She Demoted Last. May
description: TRENTON, July 27Dr. Joanne E. Finley, State Commissioner of Health, and Dr. Martin Goldfield, whom she demoted from assistant commissioner to director of research earlier this year, were embroile4,in another dispute today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a United Press International dispatch in The Times on July 6;John Ti Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, was incorrectly quoted as saying that the disclosure of improper corporatepayments could destroy a company's business and ruin the persons involved. In fact, Mr. Connor said that such payments could, themselves be destructive and ruinous, not merely their disclosure.

title: Union Official, Once Tied To Mafia Figures, Indicted On Racketeering Charges
description: A union official, once linked by the Senate Labor Rackets Commitee with such Mafia figures as John DioGuardi and Anthony Tony Ducks Corrallo, was indicted yesterday along with five other persons and three companies on charges of extortion and labor racketeering.

title: Advertising
description: We fully expect this advertising will bring us some grief and it could have a reverse marketing effect. But we have ultimate faith that the good will overshadow that.

title: Backgammon:
description: Philip Morris's European Backgammon Championship, the year's largest international competition, was held in Monte Carlo July 510, under the auspices of the Societe des Bains de Mer. Hundreds of playera converged at the opulent Monte Carlo casino, lured by the challenge, the prestige and the unequaled prize moneymore than $270.000. The purse attracted players from some three dozen countries. They included the world's finest strategists and lesserknown competitors hoping for a timely streak of luck. There were also those players simply enjoying the high season at Monte Carlotennis, sun, gambling and blacktie galas.

title: Topics
description: Frances Knight, director of the United States Passport Office since 1955, who leaves office on Sunday, was almost retired eleven years ago. It was in 1966 that she beat back efforts to ease political restrictions on the issuance of passports and brought about the resignation of her putative superior, Abbe Schwartz, then head of the State Department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs. That was also the year she was shown to have played a part in trying to have United States embassies spy on H. Stuart Hughes, a Harvard professor and prominent opponent of the war in Vietnam, as he travelled abroad.

title: British M.P.'s Spurn Big Raise
description: LONDON, July 27 (Reuters)British Members of Parliament today rejected $70 a week pay rise for themselves and agreed to accept only $7 in line with the Government's pay restraint policy. They rejected the higher raise after Michael Foot leader of the House of Commons, said the people would view a large increase as in defiance of the spirit of the pay policy.

title: Poverty Group Leader's Petitions For Rossetti's Post Are Invalidated
description: In a classic clash between the Democratic organization and politically active antipoverty groups, the New York City Board of Elections yesterday invalidated the designating petitions of a poverticlan who was challenging the East Harlem district leadership of Frank G. Rossetti, the Manhattan Democratic leader.

title: FUTURES PRICES FALL DAILY LIMIT IN COCOA
description: Cocoa futures prices closed down the daily limit of 6 cents a pound yesterday, with the spot September contract finishing at $2.02. Aside from some technical factors, the drop in cocoa reflected two statements by the Hershey Foods Corporation.

title: Decorating By Committee
description: THE FOUR families on the secand floor of our mediumsized, unpretentious West Side building redecorated their hall. One day it was the same muddy pink and green as the rest of the building's public spaces; the next day a lovely black and white scenic paper appeared opposite the elevator, and tasteful gold letters and numbers identified the apartments. The doors had been painted black and the rest of the walls were a beautiful shining white.
