description: Special to The New York Times

title: Major League Box Scores
description: FIRST GAME

title: Move Bolsters the Dollar
description: The dollar held firm yesterday in foreignexchange trading in Europe and later, in New York, the Associated Press reported.

title: Suit Contends 350 Ailing Children Are Confined Out of State Illegally
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union charged in a lawsuit that the city and state were illegally confining 350 New York City youngsters in institutions out of state.

title: The Geography of Civility
description: The lights are on and the heat is gone, but the anger still burns in New York, and even far from New York. Our desks are piled high with letters that not only condemn the looting during the blackout but also compete in expressions of hate for the looters. Those of us who perceived a social overload alongside the electrical one are accused of sponsoring permissiveness. We are reprimanded for seeking economic, sociological and pathological explanations. We are rebuked for undermining the discipline of the poor. The looters have merged in many minds with the muggers and the addicts and even with blacks and Hispanics hrgeneraL Fear has fused with rage.

title: Byrne Attends Funeral of4 Volunteers Killed in Forest Fire
description: WEST CREEK, N.J., July 27 governor Byrne and 1,000 firemen from around New Jersey and neighboring states visited this small, sleepy coastal hamlet today to pay homage to four volunteer firemen who were killed last Friday in a forest fire near Bass River State Forest.

title: Tenants Reject Apartment Sale To Saudi Prince
description: An application by Prince Saud alFaisal, Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, to buy an 18room apartment at 640 Park Avenue has been rejected by the building's residents, realestate informants reported yesterday.

title: Con Ed, an Hour After the Blackout Started, Tried a Wide Restoration of Power in Vain
description: System controllers of the Consolidated Edison Company made an abortive attempt about an hour after the start of the blackout of July 13 to restore widespread. service, according to a detailed timetable released this week by Con Edison.

title: CRUDE OIL IMPORTS SLIDE FROM WEEKAGO LEVEL
description: Imports of crude oil for the week ending July 22 were down sharply to 6.4 million barrels a day from 7.1 million barrels in the previous week, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute. An industry spokesman attributed the decline to irregurarities in arrivals of shins.

title: Two Records Broken At Paraoleeic Games
description: STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 27 (AP)Britain headed the medal list with 14 golds today, One ahead of the United States, on the fourth day of the Olympic competition fo, physically handicapped persons. In third place was West Germany with eight golds.

title: New Rhodesian Party May Tie Smith's Bargaining Hand
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 27Jack Saunders, a modestly prosperous farmer who came to Rhodesia from Britain in 1906. has voted in the last four elections for Prime Minister Ian D. Smith. But next month, his vote will go to the newly formed Rhodesian Action Party, which has repudiated Mr. Smith's tentative commitment to majority rule.

title: MISTRIAL INTERRUPTS TYLER PERJURY CASE
description: The perjury trial of Justice Andrew R. Tyler of State Supreme Court ended in a mistrial yesterday, after Presiding Justiee Leon B. Polsky decided itwould be prejudicial for the prosecutors on the case to have td. testify, as it appeared they might have to db:

title: House Specialties:
description: HEN it comes to home improvements, the usual combinations of carpenters, plumbers and painters click automatically into our minds. But consider some of the more unusual altarnatives.

title: Evenings of Wine and Daffodils
description: JOHNNY MERCER was such a versatile and productive songwriter that any evening spent dipping into his song bag is, inevitably, both rewarding and disappointing. Rewarding because even the most casual skimming of Mr. Mercer's songs would include a variety of top landmarks of the last 40 years from Lazybones, And the Angels Sing and Jeepers Creepers to Laura, That Old Black Magic, Autumn Leaves and Days of. Wine and Roses. Disappointing because so many memorable favorites are left out, so few of Mr. Mercer's less familiar songs can be included.

title: Maddox Gets Key Hit as Orioles Inflict a 64 Setback on Yankees
description: The Yankees paused in their daily soap operatics last night to play an oldfashioned baseball game (one played with actions, not words), but by the time it had ended, they were reminded of another controversy out of their past.

title: Dow Plummets 19.75 in Biggest Decline For a Single Day in More Than Two Years
description: A selling wave that engulfed the stog market pushed the Dow Jones industria two years. The bluechip barometer, da dining from the opening bell, closed 888.43, its lowest reading since Januar; 1976.

title: Ukrainian Advises Carter to Tell Brezhnev to His Face, Stop Lying
description: PARIS, July 27A Ukrainian writer and film director who renounced his Soviet citizenship as a protest against the regime has written to President Carter urging him to tell Leonid I. Brezhnev to his face, Stop lying.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: The New York Times
description: ENDORSED: Robert H. McKinney was endorsed yesterday by the Senate Banking Committee for chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Story on page D3.

title: The New York Times/Edward Mesmer
description: TIRELESS COMPETITOR: Despite heavy raincoat and boots, a young participant in Playground Day in Rutherford made a spirited run through tire obstacle course. Outing was sponsored by Bergen Passaic Hudson Recretion and Parks. Association, and youngsters from 20 towns participated.

title: House Backs Carter's Plan for Free Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The House of Representatives voted today to eliminate from the $5.6.billionayear food stamp program the requirement that recipients pay for a portion of their coupons.

title: Between the
description: CHICAGO The allwhite room with its Mickey Mouse telephone and its dozens of Najudged figurines would hardly be, judged an ideal working setting by most authors, Outrageous? Far from it, I call it serene, insisted Richard Himmel, the interior designer who is also the author of The TwentyThird Web, a highly successful whodunit published by Random House last April. Tell me, why do writers have to work in seedy rooms?

title: The New York Times/Paul Hosefros
description: ON A CLEAR DAY: This youngster had a difficult time choosing between the Lower Manhattan skyline or scanning the contours of the Statue of Liberty during ferry ride to Staten Island.

title: Coal, Carbon Dioxide and Climate
description: The National Academy of Sciences flashed a warning light this week at plans to rely on coal as a major energy source in coming centuries. Not that oil or natural gas, for which coal is being substituted, are much better for the environment. But those fuels are becoming scarcer and more expensive, and the Carter Administration is encouraging the conversion of major industries to coal. If the industrialized nations continue to burn significant amounts of any fossil fuel for the next 200 years, the consequences could be catastrophic.

title: Two Seized in Capitol Protest
description: WASHINGTON July 27 (UPI)Two young men interrupted debate in the House chamber today when they shouted from the visitors gallery $3 minimum wage. The police immediately removed the two and took them to a holding cell in the basement of the Capitol. The police had no immediate comment on their identities or what action would be taken. One source said the men were members of 1 a group called Youth in Action.

title: Beame Rejects Rent Decontrol For Apartments of $300 and Up
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that his administration was rejecting an application by realestate interests to remove from rent control all controlled apartments in New York City renting for $300 a month or more.

title: IRMGARD VON CUBE
description: Irmgard von Cube, a motionpicture script writer, died Monday at her Hollywood, Calif., home. She was 77 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: THE former chairman of the House Ways and Mears Committee, Wilbur D. Mills, will return to Washington in the fall as a tax counsel for the New York law firm of Shea, Gould, Climenko and Casey. Mr. Mills, an Arkansas Democrat, was a powerful figure in Congress before troubles with alcohol and an Argentine stripper ended his legislative career William A. Shea, senior partner in the law firm said yesterday that he was not worried about Mr. Mills possibly resuming drinking when he returned to Washington. He's done such a terrific job on those things, said Mr. Shea. It takes a great man to talk about himself that way. He's given several lectures to Alcoholics Anonymous. When I talk to him I'm afraid to take a drinkbut I do.

title: Shaw Superman Takes Super Stamina
description: NIAGARA ON THE LAKE, Ontario IT CAN BE hard work and on stage it can be the hardest work of all. The Shaw Festival's version of Man and Superman, which not only is uncut but includes the entire Don Juan in Hell sequence of Act III as well, is often memorable and ultimately exhausting.

title: EARNINGS OF MOBIL RISE 14% AS LOCAL LIFTS ITS NET 34,5%
description: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's third largest oil producer, which also operates Marcor (Montgomery Ward and the Container Corporation, reported yesterday a 14 percent increase in secondquarter earnings and 8 percent in the half year.

title: Byrne Attends Funeral of4Volunteers Killed in Forest Fire
description: WEST CREEK, July 27Governor Byrne and 1,000 firemen from around New Jersey and neighboring states visited this small, sleepy coastal hamlet today to pay homage to four volunteer firemen who were killed last Friday in a forest Fire near Bass River State Forest.

title: Africa's Horn: New Alliances
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 27The Carter Administration's decision in principle to supply military assistance to Somaliaa nation that surpasses the rest of Africa in its dependence upon Soviet armsis isstunning evidence of how quickly the crazyquilt pattern of mg or power alliances is changing in the volatile Horn of Africa.

title: Market Place
description: Wall Street analysts, watching the Dow Jones industrial average experience its worst oneday drop in more than two years and reach its lowest point since January 1976, offered explanations yesterday playing down the negative implications of the slide.

title: Most in Poll Feel State and Local Taxes Are Too High
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 27Eight of 10 New Jerseyans believe they pay too much in state and local taxes for the services they receive, and a majority think government pays too little attention to them when making decisions, according to the latest poll on New Jersey Images, released today by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: Albania, IdeologyBound, May Lose Its Ally
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27A traditional distrust of foreign countries, coupled with an official ideology other Communists view as verging on fanaticism, seems to be weaning Albania away from its sole friendChina.

title: Italy Plans to Make Repayment To I.M.F. of $825 Million Loan
description: ROME, July 27 (Reuters)Italy said today it was repaying $825 million to the International Monetary Fund only three months after the I.M.F. had agreed on loan of $530 million. The repayment, made possible by a sharp rise in Italy's currency reserves, is being made on schedule under a threeyear standby loan agreement, the Italian Treasury said.

title: Composer Takes Bow for Mozart Work
description: IT'S NOT OFTEN that the composer takes a bow after the performance of a piece by someone born 221 years ago. But that's what happened at Tuesday's Mostly Mozart Concert in Avery Fisher Hall (the concert was repeated there last night).

title: Trade Deficit Up In June to a High Of $2.82 Billion
description: The excess of imports over exportsmore than twice the May figure and the 13th consecutive monthly deficitwas larger than most experts expected and brokers said it contributed to a drop of 19.75 points in the stock market today.

title: Knievel Evel, One Dares Say
description: THE FIRST WE SEE of Evel Knievel he is visiting an orphanage, handing out toys to children t and fudge to the nuns. Then he stops by a stadium to sign some autographs and chat with his fans. Later. he returns to the stadium to make a little speech about why America's youth shouldn't get mixed up with drugs and almost incidentally, to jump his motorcycle over a cage full of lions and tigers.

title: Senate Unit Endorses McKinney To Head Home Loan Bank Board
description: WASHINGTON. July 27The Senate Banking Committee voted 12 to 3 today in favor of confirming Robert H. McKinney as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which oversees the nation's savings and loan associations. In winning the endorsement, Mr. McKinney surmounted the major obstacle to full Senate confirmation expected later this week.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Invitation to the Dance will be shown at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street today and tomorrow at 12:45, 4:25 and 8:05 P.M. An American in Paris at 2:25, 6:05 and 9:45 P.M. Tickets are $3 each; children under 12, $1.50, and until 5 o'clock today, the elderly will be admitted for $1. Further information: 7243700.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Commodity Price Index Increases To 203.5 From 203.3 Last Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose slightly to 203.5 from 203.3 last week.

title: Card of Thanks
description: CHARLES BEER and Family Wish to express their gratitude to air their friends and associates for the kind expressions of sympathy upon the Passing of their beloved wife and mother. MOLLY BEER

title: Article 5  No Title
description: NEW LAKE ON THE BLOCK: Small boys stopping at site of water main break on Roemer Avenue in New Milford. A 30inch main broke, causing local flooding and road damage, but no injuries:

title: Samuel Atlas, 77, Taught At Hebrew Union College As Philosophy Professor
description: Samuel Atlas, professor emeritus of philosophy and Talmud at Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion, died Wednesday while vacationing at Liberty, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived at 645 West End Avenue.

title: Saxton Beats White, 4 and 3, For. Met. Junior Golf Title
description: DENVILLE, N.J., July 28Jon Saxton, a towheaded,16yearold golfer from Greenwich, Conn., said, If I continue to improve I'd like to go South and play with a good college golf team. If I don't improve too much, I want to go to Dartmouth.

title: Roosevelt
description: FIRST57,500, pace, ci., mile.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: MINNESOTA (A.)

title: Israeli Settlers Hope West Bank Camp Is Only the Start
description: ELON MOREH, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, July 28 For 18 months bright red Israeli postal vans serving towns and villages in occupied Jordan whisked past a large highway signpost proclaiming in large Hebrew letters the location of Elon Moreh.

title: News Summary
description: A conciliatory view was taken by President Carter toward Prime Minister Menahem Begin's decision to legalize three existing Jewish settlements in the West Bank occupied by Israel. He said the decision was an obstacle but not an unsurmountable barrier to a Middle East peace. He seemed to wish, however, that the settlements would not be established while the United States was actively seeking a new Geneva conference on the Middle East. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Proposal to Develop Liberty Park As a World's Fair Is Under Study
description: JERSEY CITY, July 21State officials seemed uncertain today about whether one of the metropolitan area's leading restaurateurs and amusementpark entrepreneurs could win legal approval of his plan to develop a $600 million entertainment center and park within Liberty State Park, in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty on the Jersey City waterfront.

title: Carter Delays Iran Plane Sale After House Panel Opposes Deal
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  President Carter bowed today to a tide of Congressional opposition and agreed to put off until September his controversial offer to sell a modern airborne radar warning system to Iran.

title: $5 Billion U.S. Money Supply Rise Pushes Government Issues Lower
description: A sharp $5 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply, coupled with further evidence that the Federal Reserve was tightening its policy reins, sent Government securities lower again yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT SUGGESTS DEMAGOGIC REMARKS ARE HARMFUL TOPOOE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  President Carter portrayed himself and Congress today as the last hope of America's poor and charged that critics damaged the optimism of the underprivileged by suggesting that national leaders did not care about their welfare.

title: At the Movies
description: GETWHITEY MOVIES are old hat, said Michael Schultz, a black director whose Greased Lightning starring Richard pryor as a sterling stockcar racer who zooms to victory with the help of his noble redneck buddy Beau Bridgesopens here next Wednesday. I'm much more troubled by The Deep, which one of the most racist movies I've ever seen. It's O.K. for all the villains to be black, but when one of their prime motives is to terrorize a poor helpless the makers of the movie are stimulating hatred and fear in the white audience. And black audiences are being duped when they don't see the inherent racism in Rocky, a movie whichfor all its meritstapped the racist feelings of America by pitting the poor white guy against a black guy who was a total caricature of Muhammad Ali. It made it so easy to root for the white guy.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: THE VILLAGE GREEN is a blur of activity. It is an hour before the main event. Picnickers dot the lawn, others grab a hamburger at the grill, but the nucleus of the crowd is over at the gazebo listening to an early band concert.

title: Helpand Hopefor the Poor
description: President Carter yesterday reiterated his concern for the poor, suggesting that they need help and hope. Most Americans are willing to believe in his sincerity. At the same time, it must be observed that the poor have grounds for being skeptical.

title: Carter Calls Oil Key to Reducing Deficit in Trade
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  President Carter said today that oil conservation was the key to reducing the nation's yawning trade deficit, which is expected to reach an unprecedented $23 billion this year.

title: Dance: Shimazaki
description: SATORU SHIMAZAKI'S dances float along in a selfcontained, preoccupied manner that doesn't give the slightest nod to theatrical tension. They hardly even have any dynamic relationship to the music that accompanies them, except to bathe in the changing aural background. None of this would be detrimental if the movement itself were highly inventive, but It tends to be quite repetitious, for the most part. Mr. Shimazaki's company presented program of four works Wednesday evening, as part of Clark Center's festival at the City University's Graduate Center Mall.

title: Senate Confirms 3 Envoys
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)The Senate today confirmed David B. Bolen, a career Foreign Service Officer, as Ambassador to East Germany. Also confirmed without objection were the nominations of another Foreign Service Officer, Raymond L. Garthoff, to be Ambassador to Bulgaria and Mauricio Solaun of Illinois to be Ambassador to Nicaraeua..

title: CARTER ASSERTS STEP ON ISRAELI SETTLERS IS OBSTACLE TO PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28President Carter said today that Prime Minister Menalem Begin's decision to legalize three existing Jewish settlements on the Israeli)ccupied West Bank of the Jordan River was an obstacle but not an insurmountable barrier to a Middle East peace.

title: Drug Center Workers Charged
description: NEWARK, July 28 (AP)Two employees and an outpatient at Patrick House, a Jersey City drug rehabilitation center, have been charged with conspiring to set up a laboratory to manufacture amphetamines. Bail for the men, Jacob Peakes, 34 years old, a Patrick House counselor, and John Healy, 25, social worker at the rehabilitation center, and Stephen Janes, 23, an outpatient, was set at $1,500 each in Federal Court. Authorities said that about four pounds of amphetamines worth about $360,000. were found in Mr. Peakes apartment in Orange, N.J.

title: Rules Panel Clears Carter Energy Plan For Action in House
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  The House Rules Committee cleared President Carter's energy program legislation tonight for House floor action.

title: U.S. Exports to Soviet Union Off 22.6% for 5Month Period
description: MOSCOW, July 28 (UPI)Overall exports of American products to the Soviet Union fell 22.6 percent for the first five months of 1977, led by a sharp drop in farm products, the United States Trade Office in Moscow reported today.

title: Carter Delays Iran Plane Sale After House Panel Opposes Deal
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  President Carter bowed today to a tide of Congressional opposition and agreed to put off until September his controversial offer to sell a modern airborne radar warning system to Iran.

title: NewMusic Partisan Does Mostly Mozart
description: Dennis Russell Davies will make his debut tonight at the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall, and what's surprising about that is there are still a few orchestras in New York that the 33yearold conductor has not yet led.

title: Big Bluefish Are Plentiful Along Coast
description: One has the impression that if it were not for the seemingly unending stream of bluefish cruising the shores from southern New Jersey to Cape lighttackle trine sport fishing in the Northeast would fall into a disastrous decline.

title: Ballet: At Saratoga
description: IT MAY SEEM only yesterday, but it is not. It was 1966 that New York City Ballet first found its handsome summer quarters at the then brandnew Saratoga Performing Arts Center, amid the prancing ponies and bubbling spa water of Saratoga. Now coming slowly to the end of its 12th and longest season, the company can look back to a continuous growth of popularity. Once ballet used to be a poor relation in Saratoga, now it has become a rich cousin, and the most admired staple on Saratoga's artistic bill of fare.

title: Nostalgia Is Given Free Rein Astride the City's Carousels
description: Roller coasters make you swallow your heart and ferris wheels free you from gravity, but only a carousel lets you travel backward in time to memories of childhood. It is more than the brightly painted horses and the happy squeals of young riders. It is the music that sets the mood  Rosie O'Grady, School Days, Sidewalks of New York  lilting ballads of a happier era before New York City was the public relations conglomerate known as the Big Apple.

title: Bobick Rebounds With a Knockout
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 28 (AP) Duane Bobick, in his first fight since his 58second knockout by. Ken Norton, bounced back tonight with a knockout of Scott LeDoux in the eighth round of a scheduled 10round fight.

title: Dollar and Pound Continue Gains
description: The dollar showed strong improvement in foreignexchange trading yesterday for the second consecutive day, posting gains against most foreign currencies in New York and abroad, The Associated Press reported.

title: Free Now. (Sigh)
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J.They came to visit Valeri, but Valeri wasn't home.

title: Jazz: Giuffre Opens Up
description: FOR SEVERAL years, Jimmy Giuffre has been leading a trio in which his various instruments (flutes, saxophones and clarinet) have been joined by bass and percussion in lowkeyed, impressionistic sketchesfrequently of animals, birds and insectsall his own compositions. Although many of them were charming cameos, they had a dry, miniaturistic quality that became repetitive and eventually, restricting over a program of any length.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Browning, a firearms importer and distributor once known as the BrownFig Arms Company, said yesterday that its directors had voted to approve a $20 million takeover bid from a Belgian arms company.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The United States Attorney General, Griffin Bell, said yesterday that he planned to replace Jonathan L. Goldstein as United States Attorney for New Jersey, probably with Robert Del Tufo, New Jersey's first Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Criminal Justice Division.

title: American Tourists Are Spending Weaker Dollars With Little Pain
description: LONDON, July 28Edward Carpenter, a marine insurance underwriter who lives in Queens, peered through the Buckingham Palace fence this gray afternoon feeling a bit smug. No matter what happens to the slumping dollar, he explained, his trip through England and Scotland will not be cut short, for he had remembered the situation four years ago, when hotels, restaurants and even professional money changers across Europe would not accept dollars for several days and he had decided to take precautions.

title: Preliminary Federal Backing Given On LongDilayed Battery Park City
description: The Carter Administration has given preliminary approval to a request that the Federal Government provide millions of dollars in mortgage insurance to permit construction of the first 1,600 apartments at Battery Park City, the longdelayed new town envisioned for milelong landfill site on the Hudson River in lower Manhattan.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: WODEHOUSE PLAYHOUSE, being carried these summer weekends on Channel 13, turns this Sunday at 10 P.M. to Mr. Potter Takes a Rest Cure. Mr. Potter is an American publisher spending a weekend at the English country estate of Lady Wickham, who is anxious to have some of her passion novels put into print. Her daughter Roberta is being pushed into an engagement with a promising politician named Clifford Gandle but she much prefers the company of Algy Crutts, who spends most of his waking hours carrying a tennis racket. The irrepressible Roberta, or Bobbie, as she is known to intimates, stirs up all sorts of naughtiness and of course, with knowing wink, finally gets her way.

title: A Brand New Agency Will Keep Old City Records
description: Mayor Beame signed into law yesterday a bill creating a new city department to handle records of the city's business dating back to the. 17th century.

title: Santa Ana Winds Pose Trouble for Californians
description: LOS ANGELES, July 28A furnacehot, desertdry wind blows fiendishly, sometimes steadily for minutes or hours, sometimes in intermittent but endless gusts, as if some invisible giant were trying to drive you crazy.

title: Protesters Reoccupy Kent State Construction Site
description: KENT, Ohio, Friday, July 29About 50 demonstrators defied a court order early this morning and reoccupied a construction site at Kent State University near the point where four students died in a hail: of National Gunfire in 1970.

title: Nicaraguan Chief Flown to Miami For Treatment of Heart Condition
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 25 (AP)President Anastasio Somoza Debayle wag flown to the Miami Heart Institute in a United States Air Force ambulance plane today for treatment of a heart condition, a presidential spokesman announced.

title: Saudi, Citing Problems Faced by Prince, Calls New York Unfit for U.N.
description: Citing a Saudi Arabian Prince's apartmenthunting problem here, the chief of the country's United Nations delegation asserted yesterday that New York was unfit to be the site of the U.N. headquarters.

title: Nationwide Poll Finds 6% Think New York Is a Good Place to Live
description: A national poll conducted after the blackout in New York City on July 1314 has found that 6 percent of those polled think New York is a good place to live and 34 percent think it is a good place to visit.

title: British and Guatemalans Looking to U.S. for Help In the Dispute Over Belize
description: GUATEMALA CITY, July 28  British and Guatemalan officials are looking to the United States to help them settle the potentially explosive dispute over the tiny British colony of Belize, which is claimed by Guatemala.

title: An Auction House's Many Mansions.
description: Thinking of moving? How about restored manor in the Blue Ridge Mountains? It's a steal at $2 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In Richard Eder's review yesterday. of Man and Superman, at the Shaw Festival in Ontario, the opening sentence should have read: Wit can be hard work and on stage it can be'the hardest work of all.

title: Nomination by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  President Carter announced today that he would nominate Marshall D. Shulman, the State Department's top Sovjet expert,, for the rank of ambassador. Mr. Shulman; who has been a parttime consultant to Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, will now be working on a fulltime basis. Mr. Shulman will take a leave of absence from Columbia University where he has been director of the Russian Institute and professorof government.

title: CARTER TAKES A ROLE IN INQUIRY ON KOREAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 President Carter is personally involved in diplomatic efforts to persuade the South Korean Government to get Park Tong Sun to return to the United States to testify in the investigation citalleged Korean influence buying. Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Steel and other industries must wonder what measures the Carter Administration might take if the latest price increase in steel holds and touches off rippling effects in the economy. Page D3.

title: Bahrain Tries to Revive Pearling
description: MANAMA, BahrainThe Government here is trying to encourage a revival of Bahrain's oldest industry, pearl diving. But to a Persian Gulf sea captain who worked at it for 10 years, the Government is wasting its time.

title: Ford's Profit in Second Quarter Rose 20% as Chrysler's Fell 33%
description: DETROIT, July 28The Ford Motor Company reported today a 20 percent gain in secondquarter earnings and the Chrysler Corporation reported a 33.1 percent drop in earnings.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: LTV Net Drops 83%
description: The LTV Corporation, the Dallasbased conglomerate, reported yesterday an 83 percent plunge in secondquarter earnings and a loss for the half year because of the continuing poor results of its steel and food subsidiaries.

title: A Park for the Bard, After All
description: There will be free Shakespeare in the park this summer after all.

title: Parents/Children: When the Youngster Says I Hate You
description: When they say they love us, these darting children, we kiss their hair, stroke their cheeks and love them beck. We believe them.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions DAILY AVERAGES

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MAMMA'S LUCKY BABY: Scardy Cat licking her threeweek old baby before she took her first walk at Great Adventure. Newborn giraffe was named Lucky Lady because she was born on July 7, 1977 and weighed 77 pounds at birth.

title: Classic Revisited
description: COUNSELLOR AT LAW, by Elmer Rice; direded by Will Ueberson; setting and costumes by Christina Glannlpi; lighting by Bill McComb:sound by George Jacobs. Presented by Quaigh Theater Inc. At the Hotel Diplomat, 108 West 43d Street.

title: Carter Panel Picks Chief of Humanities
description: Joseph D. Duffey, an assistant secretary of state for Educational and Cultural Affairs, will be named on Tuesday by President Carter to head the National Endowment for the Humanities, according to cultural sources in Washington. The endowment allocated nearly $111 million in 2,045 grants in education and research in the 50 states in its last fiscal year.

title: JOHN W. HARDER
description: John W. Harder, an American who held a permanent commission as a Royal Air Force fighter pilot in World War II, died Monday at Swedish Hospital in Seattle. He was 53 years old.

title: Restaurants
description: MANDEB, a handsome, little, publike, Bohemianlooking restaurant on East 72d Street between First and Second Avenues, has exactly the sort of food and menu certain to perk up appetites jaded by heat waves. The front room, with its brick walls, dark wood and candlelight tables is more atmospheric than the less intimate back room, and if the management would turn off the background music, all would be even more restful and congenial. One or two tables could use a little more light, but in general the darkness is a pleasant relief from the heat outside.

title: OIL IS MOVING AGAIN IN ALASKA PIPELINE
description: VALDEZ, Alaska, July 28With its welding problems resolved by replacement of a threeroot piece of new pipe, the transAlaska pipeline system began moving oil again today toward Valdez and a tanker fleet.

title: Management
description: An esoteric organization relatively unknown to many corporate managements may have an important impact on company policy. The organization, the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws, begins an eightday annual meeting in Vail. Colo., today.

title: Publishing: Chinese Puzzles
description: HE IS BIG and hulking, whitehaired and pale. She is tiny, a wisp, 90 pounds. He acts as though nothing would faze him, an unflappable Englishman who has lived ong and learned a great deal. She smiles readily, a perky Chinese woman who makes light of her learning.

title: The Pleasures of Plazas
description: Although visitors may be surprised to hear it, New York is a city of seasonal delights. Some of these pleasures even surprise New Yorkers, to whom summer refreshment.has traditionally meant the inside of a cool, dark bar. There are more options now, including informal concerts on the new officebuilding plazas and peoplewatching in the open spaces that, by zoning decree, have cut swathes of green through ranks of tall buildings. For pure, outrageous summer theater, this city's pedestrians are unmatched.

title: Increasing U.S.Japan Trade Tension Seen
description: TOKYO, July 28  Evidence is mounting that the United States and Japan, the two largest economic powers of the nonCommunist world, are entering new period of increasing trade tension, full of potentially serious misunderstandings.

title: Bridge:
description: For the first time, and perhaps the last, Long Island enthusiasts have mid summer opportunity to compete in a major tournament in their own backyard. The NassauSuffolk Regional Championships, replacing a tournament usually played in Manhattan, begins today at the NassauSuffolk Coliseum.

title: Books: Queen for a Century
description: Eleanor of Acquitaine, whose life spanned most of the turbulent 12th century, has exerted a powerful fascination on modern biographers. Including Marion Meade's book, five biographies have been devoted to her in English in the last quarter of a century, three of them by women. Save for Amy Kelly's pathfinding study in 1950, none has produced significant new material for the simple reason that Eleanor left virtually no personal records, and contemporary chroniclers were maddeningly spare in their accounts. This situation opens the door to conjecture, obliging biographers to create their own Eleanor.

title: About Real Estate
description: Fluctuation in the housing market has not deterred Robert Little. Steadily since 1970 he has been gutting townhouses and renovating them in Manhattan, first on the West Side and then on the East Side, one at a time. He creates six or seven duplex or triplex apartments per building.

title: Antiques
description: AS A BOY, James Thomas Hooper was tireless in his quest of the art and artifacts of primitive peoples. He began his collection when he was 12 with an African spear, a gift from his father. Then, in pursuit of other weapons and crafts, he traveled by bus and bicycle from one junk shop to another throughout London.

title: Soviet Sent 89 Subs Into Atlantic
description: BRUSSELS, July 28 (Reuters)  Nearly 100 Soviet submarines moved into the Atlantic Ocean recently in a show of naval strength that stretched NATO's surveillance forces to their limits, alliance intelligence sources disclosed today.

title: Klein Confirmed by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)The Securities and Exchange Commission today confirmed the appointment of Andrew Klein to direct its division of market regulation. For the last three years, Mr. Klein has been associate director in charge of the commission's office of market structure and trading practices, which has been working closely with selfregulators in development of a central securities market.

title: Peru's Military Regime Pledges Civilian Rule in 1980
description: LIMA, Peru, July 28Peru's military regune, in power for nine years, announced through President Francisco Morales Bermudez today that a constitutional assembly will be elected next year to Prepare for a return to elected, civil government in 1980

title: Crenshaw's. Longest Season
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 28Everyone on the pro golf tour knows that Ben Crenshaw has been in a slump, but how serious is it?

title: Ombudsman Proposed in India
description: NEW DELHI, July 28 (Reuters)The Indian Government today introduced bill for creating an ombudsman to investigate complaints of misconduct by people in public life, including members of Parliament and government ministers. Home Minister Charan Singh said the bill aimed at making the ombudsman an effective instrument to combat the problem posed by corruption at higher political levels.

title: Federal Judge Again Bids H.E.W Continue Medicaid for Abortions
description: A Federal district judge in Brooklyn told the Department of Health, Education and Welfare yesterday to continue making Medicaid funds available to states that wanted to use them for elective abortions.

title: Homeless in Santa Barbara Differ On Rebuilding in FireProne Area
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 28The house at 469 Barker Pass Road is gone. So are its 30 avocado trees and dozens of apple and apricot trees. Also gone Lorenzo Dall'Armi's brand new tuxedo, the first he had ever owned.

title: Chilean Upsets Fibak in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 28 (AP)Hans Gildemeistei of Chile unleashed a flurry of passing shots today and posted a 62, 76 upset victory over fourthseeded Wojtek Fibak of Poland in a secondround match in the $125,000 Louisville international tennis classic.

title: Protest Costs Enterprise a Victory
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 28Enterprise today had to give back one of her victories over Independence at the America's Cup trials, which concluded the second of three series here yesterday.

title: ALFRED BERNSTEIN
description: Alfred Bernstein, a retired textile converter, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Text of State Rules for Professions
description: ALBANY, July 28The following is the text of the new general provisions of professional conduct that apply to all 29 professionsby the New regulated York State Board of:Regents, including broadened regulations on professional advertising.

title: 2 Women Work Their Magic With Fabric
description: PARIS, July 28Two women dominated the last day of the fall couture collections hereHanae Moir; the Japanese designer who stormed Paris last January and is the newest member of the couture, and Alix Gres, who began designing in 1931 as Alix Barton after a career as a sculptor. She has been known as Mme. Gres since her marriage in 1937. Widely revered as a living symbol of the haute couture, she was chosen president of the Chambre Syndicate, its trade association, in 1972.

title: Antipornography Bill Is Signed by Beanie
description: Mayor Beame signed into law yesterday an antipornography bill that provides for strict civil penalties and court injunctions. In conjunction with criminal penalties, the Mayor said the bill would serve as a strong deterrent to the nuisance of pornography and prostitution.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: falrollowing 4 a transcript of President Carter's news conference in Washington yesterday morning, as recorded by rhe New York Times through the for:gibes of ABC News:

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 28State fire wardens and park rangers today began searching cars inside stateowned land for possible arsonists.

title: Carter Backing Off on Postal Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Carter Administration, wary of the financial pitfalls involved in taking over the United States Postal Service, is turning away from legislative proposali that would put the huge agency back under political control.

title: Getting a Call From This Man Means Money in the Bank
description: If you get a letter from Louis Travers this month, you may be in for some money.

title: Federal Judge Again Bids H.E.W. Continue Medicaid for Abortions
description: A Federal district judge in Brooklyn told the Department of Health, Education and Welfare yesterday to continue making Medicaid funds available to states that wanted to use them for elective abortions.

title: Time Bomb Wrecks Beersheba Market; 29 Persons Injured
description: TEL AVIV. July 29Twentynine persons were injured today in the vegetable market of Beersheba, the desert town, when a time bomb exploded under a stall, was the third terrorist bombing in two days.

title: Justice in Sentencing
description: WASHINGTONCriminal sentencing today is a national scandal. Every day different judges mete out vastly different sentences to similar defendants convicted of similar crimes. One offender may receive probation while anotherconvicted of the very same crimeis sentenced to a lengthy term of imprisonment. This glaring disparity can be traced directly to the unfettered discretion we confer on our judges. They act without any statutory guidelines or review procedures.

title: AIRBORNE AMBULANCES: Coast Guard helicopters landing at Wall Street heliport carrying newborn twins with lung defects. The babies were born
description: The New York Times prematurely in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.,and were flown to New York in incubators where they were taken by ambulance to New York Hospital for treatment.

title: THOMAS J. DONOHER
description: Comdr. Thomas J. Donoher, an Annapolis graduate who served as a regular officer and as a Navy chaplain, died of cancer last Friday at the Bethesda, Md., Naval Hospital. He was 51 years old.

title: Letter: On Mexican Farm Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Regents Vote to Allow Doctors and Dentists to Advertise
description: ALBANY, July 28The New York State Board of Regents, considerably broadening its earlier position, voted unanimously today to permit physicians, dentists and other professionals to advertise not only their services but also their prices in newspapers and magazines.

title: Cruyff Undergoes Surgery
description: BARCELONA, Spain, July 28 (UPI)Barcelona's Dutch soccer star, Johan Cruyff, underwent surgery today for leg injury suffered in a game two days ago. Doctors said the operation will idle the forward for two months. Cruyff was the star of the Dutch team that made it to the World Cup final before he accepted a lucrative offer in Spain.

title: Warning Issued on Triumph Cars
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)There may be safety defects in up to 53,000 Britishmade Triumphs sold in this country since 1975, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today. One defect involves a strong likelihood of either a partial or complete failure of throttle cables in 1975 through 1977 TR7 cars. A limited failure can cause the accelerator to stick in an open position, reducing the driver's control over speed, the agency said. A complete failure, added, will result in a loss of engine power.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS WELFARE FUND RISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Despite opposition by the Carter Administration, the Senate Finance Committee today approved Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's plan for a oneyear increase of $1 billion in Federal spending on welfare. The first half billion would become available Oct. 1, and New York State's share would be $85.2 million in addition to the Federal welfare aid it normally receives. New Jersey would receive $21.5 Million more, and Connecticut, $7 million.

title: Weakness in secondary Plagues the Jets Again
description: HEMPSTEAD. IA, July 28Pass. To the Jets', defense last year, it was the worst fourletter word.

title: Union Calls Met's Cancellation Plan'a7.LIOTkOTit
description: Max L Arons, president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said yesterday that it now appears that the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera will be locked out on Sept. 9, because of failure to reach agreement on a new contract.

title: Events and Openings
description: MOSTLY MOZART: FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 8.

title: SCORES OF FIRES RAVAGE 500,000 ACRES IN ALASKA
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 28 (AP)Megtk?? titan half a million acres of Alaska land were burning today as hot, dry conditions continued to hamper efforts to bring the flames under control, the Bureau of Land Management reported.

title: Meadowlands Challenges Monticello
description: ONTICELLO, N.Y., July 28The four leading drivers from the Meadowlands will challenge the top four drivers from Monticello Raceway here on Sunday. The special competition, which will be scored on a point system, will feature the drivers handlinghorses they do not usually drive and will be part of the regular 10race program.

title: Nets Show Rise At Delta, KLM, British Airways
description: Delta Air Lines Inc., the nation's fifthlargest carrier and one of the most successful reported yesterday in an unaudited statement for the fiscal year ended June 30 net earnings of $92.4 million, equal to $4.65 a share. This sets new airline industry record and represents a 32 percent rise from $70.2 million, or $3.53 a share, earned in fiscal 1976.

title: ATO Formally Charged by S.E.C. With $11 Million in Payoffs Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Securities and Exchange Commission has formally charged ATO Inc., an Ohiobased automatic bottleprocessing company, with making more than $1 million in secret bribes and kickbacks to agents in Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Central America.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PRISONERS OF WAR: Picture released yesterday in Tripoli, Libya, is said slum Egyptians taken prisoner by Libyans during recent clashes. DespiteAssocited Prass some harsh exchanges of words between the two countries, the ceasefire along 650mile border held for fourth straight day without reported incident.

title: Latest Price Confrontation For Steel and Government
description: Some followers of business developments have dismissed the latest confrontation between the American steel industry and the Administration over a new price increase as another of their periodic wrangles that, in the end, would amount to little more

title: Lance Batik Stock Deal Is Weeks Away, Buyer Says
description: ATLANTA, July 28The sale of Bert Lance's stock in the National Bank of Georgia to David N. Smith, an Atlanta entrepreneur, is at least weeks away but is still a solid possiblity, Mr. Smith said today in a private Interview.

title: A President Under Strain
description: WASHINGTON, July 28More than at any other time since entering the White House, Jimmy Carter gave the public impression today of a President being crowded by tough, intractable issues.

McCloskey, a California Republican, suggest that President Carter was influenced by a political campaign commitment to maritime unions and the industryi ssupporting controversial legislation that means inincreased revenues for the American maritime industry.

description: What is President Carter trying to tell Vernon Jordan and the black community? It sounds suspiciously like Be quietI know what's best for you. Or maybe Don't call me, I'll call you.

title: UrbanRural Coalition Successful On Farm and Food Stamp Measure
description: WASHINGTON. July 28  A new urbanrural coalition in the House of Representatives succeeded today in winning passage of a fouryear farm bill estimated to cost $10.5 billion to $11.5 billion annually, including $5.6 billion for a revised food stamp program.

title: State's First U.S. Public Defender Is Stepping Down
description: NEWARK, July 28Roger Lowenstein is returning to private law practice after four years as New Jersey's first Federal public defender and the eighth in the country's 92 Federal Court districts. He has mixed emotions about leaving his post.

title: Market Place
description: Superficially, at least, it would appear that the Continental Corporation has treated minority shareholders of its subsidiary, Diners Club, uncharitably.

title: Movies Revisited: Invitation to Dance
description: You can never go to see an old play or rather, you can never go to see an old production of an old play. Even a ballet changes its castand often its nuanceswith the revolving seasons. Symphonies can be virtually recycled with the right, retreading sort of conductor, while almost the only innovator in opera today is the opera director. But films are stucklike a needle in a phonograph groove. Old films are waiting fnr us all over town, resembling, if we have seen them, the immaculately preserved yet largely forgotten pages of an old diary.

title: Hammer Falls and Century Is Sold to a Spanish Bank
description: If you wanted to buy a seemingly solid New York City bank, the place to be yesterday was the American City Squire Inn. That's when, for $8.2 million, and where, the Century National Bank and Trust Company went under the auctioneer's hammer.

title: Home of Peter Beard Photographer, Burns
description: A salvaged windmill known as the easternmost house on Long Island burned to the ground in Montauk on Wednesday night in a spectacular fire that flashed through the frame/ cliffside dwelling.

title: NUCLEAR FOES HOLD PROTEST IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, July 28Opponents of nuclear energy as a source of power demon. strated today, with pickets, speeches and songs, at Military Park across the street from the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the state's largest energy supplier.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Robert Klein appears at 6:30 o'clock tonight it the Dr. Pepper Central Park Music Festival. Wollman Rink, 59th Street and Fifth Avenue. The rain date for the performance is Sunday at 2 P.M.; tickets in the orchestra are $4, in the balcony $2. For ticket or weather information, call 2498870.

title: New Face: Hye Young Choi
description: After Hye Young Choi made her Carnegie Recital Hall debut last February, a reviewer wrote In The New York Times that the sweet ardor of the Song to the Moon from Dvorak's Rusalka seemed a perfect vehicle for Miss Choi's artistry. So it seemed perfectly natural to her when she auditioned for a part in the Broadway production of The King and I that she sing that same song.

title: Carter Staff Prepares Memo on Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, July 28After an open display of disagreement with President Carter's opposition to Federal funding for elective abortions, highlevel women in the administration have muted their dissent and are quietly preparing a memorandum to the President taking issue with his Position.

title: 204 on Plane Escape Explosion and Fire
description: BOSTON, July 28 (AP)A DC10 jetliner headed for Los Angeles with 292 passengers and a crew of 12 aborted its takeoff today when an explosion and fire erupted in its tail engine es it gathered speed on the runway at Logan International Airport.

title: Carter Will Stump. U.S.. to Aid Demotratic Candidates: in 78
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 hign command of lire Democratic Party met at the White House with President Carter today and won a pledge from him that he would campaign actively around the country in the 1978 offyear elections.

title: Look Who's Out There in Front
description: Between baseball seasons, Reggie Jackson, Bobby Grich, Wayne Garland and Royle Stillman walked out of Baltimore to seek their fortune in the greener pastures of New York, Anaheim, Calif., Cleveland and Chicago, and in spring training Earl Weaver tried to look on the bright side. The Orioles doughty manager kept saying that sometimes blessings came heavily disguised. Nobody would be expecting a lot of the club this year, he said, the pressure would be off and maybe the guys might surprise a few people. Yesterday the Orioles shaped up in Yankee Stadium to play their 100th game of the season and lose it, and Sports they were booming along at the top of the American League East with the Red Sox The Times second and the best team money can buy another game back in third place. What were they doing up there?. Earl Weaver had the grace brush the canary feathers off his smile before speaking. They forgot we had some pretty good ballplayers left, he said. They were all talking about the guys who were gone.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CUNARD PRINCESS (Cunard). Left Bermuda.16:1Y 28; due a A.M. at IN. 55th Street.

title: INDICTMENT CHARGES POVERTY FUND THEFT
description: A former director of a poverty program was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on a charge of having diverted more than $50,000 of the program's funds for his own use, including $13,500 for a MercedesBenz car.

title: Kirkland and Hamilton Merge
description: The board of trustees of Kirkland College, an innovative school for women in Clinton, N.Y., voted Wednesday night to accept consolidation with Hamilton College.

title: Police in South Africa Use Tear Gas to Disperse Hundreds of Black Youths
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 28 (UPI)  South African police fired tear gas today into the ranks of hundreds of black students massed in Meadowlands, a residential area reserved for blacks outside Johannesburg, witnesses said.

title: The New York Times/Fred R. Conrad
description: WET PAINT signs weren't needed as Walter Cella, a bridge painter, found perfect day to go about his job atop George Washington Bridge yesterday.
