title: Kidnapping of Man Over Moped Thefts Tied to 3 in Brooklyn
description: Three men were arrested yesterday and charged with kidnapping a man they said had stolen eight mopeds from Brooklyn store, the police said.

title: Where to Go
description: Carousel hours are subject to weather and daylight, particularly at Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, which has no surrounding enclosure. Operators, in addition, are free spirits, who may just decide to close up if business doesn't seem brisk. So the following guide is subject to change:

title: Mrs. Carner Is Favored In New L.P.G.A. Tourney
description: POCONO MANOR, Pa., July 28 (AP) JoAnne Carner has a good chance to improve her top ranking on the Ladies Professional Golf Association's earnings list in the Pocono Northeast Classic, which starts tomorrow. Mrs. Carner, of Lake Worth, Fla., heads a field of 74 pros and six amateurs in the tournament, being held for the first time.

title: F.B.I. Scans Report of Payments To Nixon Aides to Restrict Hoffa
description: WASHINGTON, July. 28The Federal Bureau of Investigation is pursuingallegations that organized crime figures and teamsters union officials might have paid large sums to Nixon Administration officials to insure that James R. Hoffa could not regain control of the union after his release from prison, a source familiar with the investigation said today.

title: Playing or Clowning, They Work Together
description: The Art Ensemble of Chicago, the fiveman band that performs at Storyville, 41 East 58th, this weekend, employs an assortment of instruments large and varied enough to supply an orchestra. The two saxophonists, Roscoe Mitchell and Joseph Jarman, play more than 15 horns between themsopranino, soprano, alto, tenor, baritone and bass saxophones, various flutes and clarinets, oboe and bassoon. Lester Bowie, the trumpeter and Malachi Favors, the bassist, command an assortment of secondary instruments that range from bass drum to harmonica, from banjo to steer's horn. The drummer, Don Moye, performs in the middle of an array that includes gongs and congas as well as his standard drum kit.

title: Broadway
description: C AN THE FORMER PRESIDENT of American Ballet Theater find happiness on Broadway? Can two investment counselors and marketing experts consummate a musical with Stephen Schwartz? The old balletomane is Sherwin M. Goldman, who also produced last year's Porgy and Bess. Everyone laughed when he said he wanted to do Porgy; they said it wouldn't work. Now he wants to do a musical set in Egypt in 1300 B.C. The two investment counselors and marketing experts are Stephen R. Friedman and Irwin Meyer. The first show they were ever involved in was Annie.

title: People in Sports
description: Lenny Randle of the Mets pleaded no contest yesterday to a charge of battery for punching Frank Lucchesi, former manager of the Texas Rangers on March 28 and was fined $1,0,50 by Circuit Court Judge Maurice Paul in Orlando, Fla.

title: BANK UNIT BILL PROPOSES FED APPOINTMENT CHANGES;
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)The House Banking Committee today approved a bill designed to bring the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board into a somewhat closer relationship with the President and Congress.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE SHOW that Hall and Oates 1otherwise knownas Daryl Hall and John Oateswill offer at the Wolkaan Rink in Central Park tomorrow evening will be something of a climax. It's the culmination of two and a half years of development, said Mr. Oates by telephone the other day from Los. Angeles, where the two are finishing their latest album, due in September and called A Beauty on a Back Street. I'm proud of this show. he added.

title: A Variety of Corporations Report Operating Results Disclosing Their Sales and Earnings Figures
Strained Left Shoulder Forced. Exit of Matlack
description: Jon Matlack, the Mets lefthander who took himself out of Wednesday night's game against San Francisco in the sixth inning suffered a strained left shoulder, the team physician said yesterday.

title: A. T. C. BONE, EXPERT ON BURMESE SHRINES
description: A. T. C. Bone, one of the last of the great breed of British eccentrics who remained behind in what was once the Empire, died in an auto accident in Burma on June 18, according to word received here yesterday. He was 56 years old.

title: Morales, Obersteia in Final
description: BAYSHORE. L.L, July 28  Miguel Morales of New York, seeded sixth, upset the topseeded player, Oscar Olea, tonight and gained the final of the New York State indoor summer festival championship at the Point Set Tennis Club. Morales a 64, 76, 62 winner, will face David Oberstein, of Brightwaters, L.I., the second seeded player, in the final.

title: Pan Am. London RoundTrip Fare Set at $256, or $20 Above Laker's
description: Pan American World Airways will farmally put before the Civil Aeronautics Board today its keepthefrills answer to Laker Airways nofrills $135 New YorktoLondon travel bargain.

title: Senate Panel Backs Amendments To Bill Setting Curbs on Busing
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)The Senate Judiciary jcommittee adopted today two amendments to a bill designed to restrict courtordered busing for school desegregation.

title: Fire Forces Evacuation
description: LIBERTY, Tex., July 28 (AP)Firemen today extinguished a blaze that had roared through an nil storage facility and forced the evacuation of about 200 persons from their homes in this southeast Texas town. The authorities sdid the fire was controlled before it could reach several large tanks filled with gasoline located near the Gulf Oil Company facility. Three firemen suffered minor injuries.

title: Study Links Some Cancer Drugs to Risk of Leukemia
description: A National Cancer Institute study has found that a small percentage of women with ovarian cancer who were treated with drugs called alkylating agents later developed leukemia. This second cancer, the study said, apparently developed as a result of taking the drugs.

title: World News Briefs
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan. July 28 (Reuters)  Pakistan's new military rulers today freed former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was detained when an army coup toppled his government July 5.

title: Bandits in Paris Escape With $3.5 Million in Coins
description: PARIS, July 28 (AP)  Four bandits believed acting on inside information seized a truck carrying $3.54 million in newly minted coins today in one of the world's biggest robberies.

title: Smith Challenges Eviction in Rhodesia Of Colored Family
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 28 (AP)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith has challenged an eviction order against a family of mixed race that has owned a house in a white Salisbury suburb for two years. Mr. Smith said he has asked for a report with full facts on the order by the city council.

title: Affluent Households And What They Read
description: The affluence of the readers of some publications is an important part of the sales pitch of their advertising departments. Ten such publications signed up with Monroe Mendelsohn Research for a syndicated Survey of Adults and Markets of Affluence. It looks into the reading habits and purchasing patterns of households with $40,000andover annual incomes.

title: Art: Thiebaud's Food for Thought
description: WAYNE THIEBAUD is Californian painter who for much of the last 25 years has addressed himself to the subject of food. He is also an intelligent man who has looked at the work cf a great many good painters and taken.:hit he needs from each of them. If we add to that an appropr:ate succulence in the handling of paint and an element of drive and brio which relates to his earlier theatrical experience it can be guessed that his retrospective.7t the Neuberger Museum on the SUN? canpus at Purchase, N.Y.. is a very enjoyable experience. It is there through Aug 28. and although its han;ing lesves much to be desired, is very well paired with the vast and tenebrous hail of black sculptures by Louise Nevelson through which we v.aik to get to it.

title: $23 Million Plan to Restore Seaport Museum Area
description: A $23 million project will restore bit of Little Old New York to a 19thcentury seaport along the East River just south of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: In Aemoriam
description: BECKENSTEINFannie. July 29, 1971, In cherished memory of our beloved mother. Her family.

title: CONTRACT LOWS HIT IN CORN AND WHEAT
description: Corn and wheat futures prices plunged to contract lows again yesterday in Chicago as improving weather kept many commercial buyers on the sidelines.

title: For Children
description: TEATOWN LAKE RESERVATION, owned and operated by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, is a 305acre wild life and conservation preserve that Includes forest, meadows, hemlock and laurel groves, a 33.acre lake and 10 miles of marked trails (trails open at all times). Yearround outdoor exhibits. Preserve Is one mile west of Taconic Parkway on Spring Valley Road, Ossining, N.Y. Free. Building oven 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Friday end Saturday, and from 1 to 4 P.M. on Sunday. (914) 7622912.

title: At People
description: THE PROGRAM to provide.johs for unemployed artists, announced in May by the Beame administration, is now being shaped by the Department of Cultural Affairs and its private, notforprofit helpmeet, the Cultural Council Foundation. The jobs will be.financed with money the city is receiving ($320 million over an 18month period, beginning July 1, 1977) under the Federal Comprehensive Employment Training Act, or C.E.T.A., designed to provide work for the disadvantaged and the longterm unemployed. Many artists qualify on both counts.

title: Albany Opens a Tax Inquiry Into Port Authority Trips
description: New York State tax agents have started an investigation into possible tax cheating and avoidance by up to 300 officials and employees of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Tax Commissioner James H. Tully Jr. announced yesterday.

title: Woooooooooooo, It's Robert Klein
description: Have you heard the one about the traveling comic who grew up in the Bronx, pulled down gigs as a substitute teacher to pull down cash, played the small clubs where you practically have to pay them to take the stage, and finally made it to the night spots, the records, the television shows, and the sitcorn offers? You have?

title: CARTER ASSERTS STEP ON ISRAELI SETTLERS IS OBSTACLE TO PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28President. Carter said today that Prime Minister Menat hem Begin's decision to legalize three existing Jewish settlements on the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan River was an obstacle but not an insurmountable barrier to a Middle East peace.

title: Survey Based on 1,447 Interviews
description: The New York TimesCBS News survey is based on telephone interviews conducted from July 19 to July 25 with 1,447 adult men and women around the United Sates.

title: Around the Nation
description: MADISON, Wis., July 28 (UPI)Judge Archie E. Simonson, the judge who touched off a controversy by suggesting rape was a normal reaction in a permissive society, became today the first Wisconsin official to face recall.

title: Fuchsberg Says His Note Holdings Made Him Refuse a Court Role
description: Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg of the New York State Court of Appeals said yesterday that he and his wife had such substantial investments in New York City notes that he had to disqualify himself from hearing a crucial case on the city's finances or divest himself and face a loss of more than $500,000 on their Investment.

title: Manslaughter Ruling in Gun Death
description: MOUNT HOLLY, NJ., July 28 (AP)A Marlton, NJ., man has been found guilty by a jury in Burlington Court of involuntary manslaughter in the shooting death of a neighbor. The man, Herbert Yurkow, was convicted of killing Charles E. Ainis in June 1975 by handling a revolver with gross negligence. Mr. Ainis died two days after being shot in the face by Mr. Yurkow, who had been showing off his gun collection. Mr. Yurkow faces a sentence of up to 10 years.

title: ALCAN PIPE ROUTE BACKED BY ENVIRONMENTAL STUDY
description: OTTAWA, July 28A proposed gas pipeline from Northern Alaska into Canada, known as the Alcan Route, cleared a Government environmental hurdle today with recommendations for only minor changes.

title: Braills
description: ABERLINIsador, beloved husband of Jane Stein Aberlin beloved father of Robert Edward Aberlin and Jean Aberlin Kaufman, devoted fatherinlaw of Mary Beth Aberlin and Richard Kaufman, dear brother of Edward Aberlin. Services at Jewish Community Center, 175 Victory Blvd., Staten Island, Friday, at 2:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers contributions to Jewish Community Center of S. I. would be appreciated.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises 4.5%
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.8 billion tonmiles, up 4.5 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 456,360 cars, up 1.7 percent from last year. The American Trucking Association Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 4.8 percent from a year ago.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The nineyearold Staten Island Civic Theater is proud of its record. While it doesn't have professional status, it delights in calling itself the next best thing: amateurs who have been together for quite a while. Tonight, the company opens its final production of the summer season, Elie Wiesel's Zalmen, or the Madness of God The play, set in a small Jewish community in the Soviet Union,, concerns the repercussions of a rabbi's outcry, shortly after Stalin's death, against religious persecution in his country. Performances tonight and tomorrow at 8. P.M. and Sunday at 7 P.M. (The production continues next weekend, tooThursday through Sunday.) At Christ Church Parish House, 76 Franklin Avenue. Tickets are $3.50 ($2.50 for students and the elderly).

title: Books of The TimEs
description: IN One More July; George Plimpton has returned to the world of professional football, and one's first inclination is to protest that we had enough of it in Paper Tiger and more than enough in Mad Ducks and Bears. But what has drawn Mr. Plimpton back this time is not another inglorious opportunity to get himself pasted to the turf at the quarterback position. It is the beguiling intelligence.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Horses listed In order of post ooslions Lefer designates OTB listing.

title: STRONG DOLLAR CALLED VITAL BY BLUMENTHAL
description: LOUISVILLE, July 28 (Reuters)Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said tcday that a strong dollar was vital to the world economy and the United States would not be indifferent to a continuing large trade deficit.

title: Yankees Crush Orioles, 142, With 3Homer, 15Hit Attack
description: Getaway day became runaway day at Yankee Stadium yesterday as the Yankees walloped the firstplace Baltimore Orioles, 142. The onesided victory captured the series for New York, two games to one, and moved the Yankees two games behind the Orioles as they headed for nine games on the West Coast.

title: Tokyo Stocks Plunge Under Heavy Selling
description: TOKYO, July 28Stock prices registered their heaviest plunge in fgur months today amid a wave of selling. The setback was triggered by the growing concern over export posnects and the continued pause in domestic economic recovery.

title: U. S. Asks Oil Data in Antitrust Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Justice Department said today that it was demanding documents and oral testimony from a number of international oil companies as part of an antitrust investigation.

title: Excerpts From Reply by Dr. Ronan
description: The draft report is both unfair and inaccurate in many respects. These inaccuracies and misrepresentations stem from both omissions of essential information as well as misstatements of fact and misleading inferences from data examined.

title: Art Pepper Toots His Own Saxophone
description: Art Pepper is convinced  absolutely convinced  that be is the best jazz musician in the world. And the alto saxophonist views his engagement at the Village Vanguard this weekend through Sunday evening as one of the first in a series of steps that will give people outside California an opportunity, virtually denied them for the last 20 years, to hear him and to appreciate his talent.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A trucker sleeping in his tractortrailer at Fulton and Water Streets outside a lower Manhattan fish market was kidnapped before dawn by two gunmen who stole his truck with $50,000 worth of fish from Maine. They bound and blindfolded him, put him in a car and drove him around the city, for five hours before releasing him unharmade.

title: Music: Newport
description: NEWPORT in summer is a resort of many attractions. Sailing regattas and tennis matches are lures for sportsmen, a beguiling mix of 18th19thand 20thcentury dwellings and public buildings set amid magnificent trees, appeals to architecture and history buffs, and the extravagant Bellevue Avenue residences of past and present rich are a source of wonder and amazement for all.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Fair to partly cloudy skies will cover the Northeast today. Showers and thundershowers will be scattered through most of the rest of the Eastern Board the lake region, Ohio Valley and lower Mississippi Valley; scattered showers and thundershowers may also develop in Illinois, southeastern Missouri and the eastern sections of Oklahoma and Texas. Scattered or widely scattered showers will dot the Rockies and Arizona, while elsewhere, it will be mostly sunny. Except for some cooler weather in western Montana and the northern plateau region, only minor temperature changes will occur elsewhere.

title: 12 Amusement Parks: An Explorer's Guide
description: THE SIGNS begin to tell the story: This Ride Not Recommended for Guests With Heart Conditions, High Blood Pressure or Expectant Mothers. Cyclone. Big Fury. Warning, Baboons May Tear Vinyl Roofs. Keep Right for Baboon Bypass Road.

title: TV SETS FROM JAPAN ESCAPE SPECIAL TAX
description: WASHINGTON, July 28In what was described by the Carter Administration as a major legal victory, the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today overturned a lower Customs Court ruling that would have required the Treasury to impose special duties on imports of Japanese television sets.

title: Public Likes Carter, Survey Finds, More for His Style Than Programs
description: Six months into his term of office, President Carter still enjoys strong general approval from the American people, but there has been a marked decline in public confidence that he can achieve such targets as significantly reducing unemployment or balancing the Federal budget.

title: Moscow's Perennial Scapegoat
description: Once upon a time Soviet Communists took pride their official effort to wean the Russian peoples away from their deepseated antiSemitism. Until a decade ago, even Stalin's crudest campaigns against Jews were dismissed as the aberrations of a mad dictator. But the official inhibitions have evidently been wearing thin.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In Richard Eder's review yesteiditi; of Man and Superman, at the Shay; Festival in Ontario, the opening sentence should have read: Wit can'be hard work and on stage it can be th4, hardest work of all

title: Nancy Ann Block Is Bride Of Les Howard Perlson
description: Nancy Ann Block, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cy Block of Lake Success, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Les Howard Perlson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Perlson of Brooklyn.

title: Moynihan's Message
description: Such is the grace of Daniel Patrick Moynihan's style, and so refreshing his many insights, that even my brother Bill, who devoted three columns to the Senator's recent position paper on the problems of New York, was beguiled into acquiescing in Mr. Moynihan's central thrust, to wit: I have reached the conclusion that our decline has come about as the  direct and palpable consequence of the policies of the Federal Government.

title: Gunmen Slay Six and Wound Two After Ransacking House in Miami
description: MIAMI, July 28 (UPI)The police sought today a band of gunmen who ransacked a home, lined up the eight occupants and shot them execution style, apparently in an attempt to erase all witnesses to their crime. Two of the victims survived.

title: Albany Opens a Tax Inquiry Into Port Authority Trips
description: New York State tax agents have started an investigation into possible tax cheating and avoidance by up to 300 officials and employees of the Port Authority of New York and New. Jersey, Tax Commissioner James H. Tully Jr. announced yesterday.

title: Rich Pace To Willie In Jersey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 28Rambling Willie, the aged son of Rambling Fury, who spent his first and second years competing on the Indiana Fairground circuit, demonstrated again tonight why he is now a bigtime campaigner.

title: First Woman on Civil Air Panel
description: When Elizabeth Ellery Bailey of Rumson, N. J., takes office next month as the first woman to serve on the Civil Aeronautics Board in its 38year history, she will be much more concerned with the pricing policies that set air than with personal milestones. Mrs. Bailey, whose nomination was confirmed by the United States Senate yesterday, describes herself as a strong advocate of pending legislation that would give major airlines more leeway to adjust ticket prices. She sees such legislation as the beginning of a consumeroriented change that would allow the prices of some tickets to be reduced by as much as onethird.

title: OCTOBER TALKS SET ON A FM TEST BAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The United States, the Soviet Union and Britain announced today, after two weeks of preliminary talks in Geneva, that the way had been cleared for formal negotiations in October on a treaty banning all underground nuclear explosions.

title: Carter Panel Picks Chief of Humanities
description: Joseph D. Duffey, an assistant secretary of state for Educational and Cultural Affairs, will be named on Tuesday by President Carter to head the National Endowment for the Humanities, according to cultural sources in Washington. The endowment allocated nearly $111 million in 2,045 grants in education and research in the 50 states in its last fiscal year.

title: News Summary
description: A conciliatory view was taken by President Carter toward Prime Minister Menahem Begin's decision to legalize three existing Jewish settlements in the West Bank occupied by Israel. He said the decision was an obstacle but not an unsurmountable barrier to a Middle Fast peace. He seemed to wish, however, that the settlements would not be established while the United States was actively seeking a new Geneva conference on the Middle East. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Committee to Aid Looters Victims Is Now Within $800,000 of Its Goal
description: Two weeks after the blackout, the Citizens Committee for New York City is within $800,000 of its goal of raising $3.5 million to give to smallbusiness men whose stores were damaged or destroyed.

title: TV SETS FROM JAPAN ESCAPE SPECIAL TAX
description: WASHINGTON, July 28In what was described by the Carter Administration as a major legal victory, the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today overturned a lower Customs Court ruling that would have required the Treasury to impose special duties on imports of Japanese television sets.

title: Stage: Counsellor Sets Precedents
description: A LAWYER'S OFFICE is like hospital, a police station or grand hotel: people come and people goand the plots never change. George Simon, the hero of Winer Rice's CounselloratLawn is an archetype in his genrelegal melodrama.

title: Meadowlands
description: Hnrses listed In order of post positions

title: Wilkins Surrenders the Helm of the N.A.A.C.P.
description: Roy Wilkins turned over the leadership of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to Benjamin L Hooks yesterday as 200 supporters, wellwishers, friends and people who have benefitted from the organization's civilrights battles watched tearyeyed_ and solemnly.

title: FON ETHIOPIAN CRAFT DOWNED, SOMALIS SAY
description: ROME, July 28 (Reuters)  The Somali Republic said today that it had shot down three Ethiopian Jets and a planeload of paratroops over its territory in the widening war on the Horn of Africa.

title: Stocks Mixed as Dow Rises 1.56 And Declines Outpace Advances
description: The stock market failed to put together even a halfhearted rally yesterday as prices ended mixed following Wednesday's jolting drop of 19.75 points in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Notes on People
description: Vice President Mondale announced Yesterday the start of a campaign to raise 522 million to establish a Hubert IL Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Minnesota. Mr. Mondale, said that the institute bearing the name of his longtime mentor, Mr. Humphrey, would be patterned after the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairsat the University of Texas. The campaign to raise the money got off to an impressive start at a lunch in Washington yesterday, when guest after guest got up to pledge contributhins that totaled $2.3 million. Mr. Mondale said the institute would be an especially fitting recognition of this extraordinary and gifted public servant who has dominated in a humane and gifted way the public life of this nation for well over a generadon.

title: Nassau Political Leaders to Fight A Move for CrossCounty Busing
description: Nassau County political leaders have vowed to fight an integration suit asking that black students from Andrew Jackson High School in Queens be mixed with white suburban students from across the county line.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)Money rates fnr Thursday.

title: Cubs Win, 1615, in 11Homer Game
description: In a recent letter to The Times, the writer complalnai of baseball's inaction and overall dullness.

title: PRESIDENT SUGGESTS DEMAGOGIC REMARKS ARE HARMFUL TO POOR
description: WASHINGTON, July 28President Carter portrayed himself and Congress today as the last hope of America's poor and charged that critics damaged the optimism of the underprivileged by suggesting that national leaders did not care about their welfare.

title: Nassau Asks $50 Million In Net Move
description: Nassau County began action yesterday to try to collect $50 million in damages that it says it will lose as a result of the Nets move from the Nassau Coliseum to New Jersey. The Coliseum is countyowned and countyoperated.

title: Kerry Elizabeth O'Sullivan Wed to Sydney Stokes Jr.
description: In the Garden of the Southern Vermont Art Center in Manchester, yesterday evening, Kerry Elizabeth O'Sullivan, daughter of Mrs. Gerald Patrick O'Sullivan of Sydney, Australia, and the late Mr. O'Sullivan, became the bride of Sydney Nelson Stokes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stokes of Arlington, Vt., formerly of Plainfield, N.3.

title: VANCE WILL PRESENT SPECIFIC PROPOSALS DURING MIDEAST TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that he would present specific American proPosals to Israeli and Arab leaders during his forthcoming Middle East trip in an effort to overcome the obstacles to a new Geneva peace conference.

title: $50,000 Bail Set for Student Held In Murder of Woman in Scarsdale
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 29  Bail of $50,000 was set yesterday for a 23yearold graduate student charged with bludgeoning to death his former girlfriend in Scarsdale.

title: Participants in Alaska Gas Plan Back Al can's CrossCanada Line
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Participants in the Arctic Gas consortium seeking to build a crossCanada pipeline to carry Alaskan natural gas announced today that they were abandoning their project and would support instead a crossCanada plan advanced by the Alcan Pipeline Company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Devernon LeGrand, the selfstyled head of a Brooklyn church, sentenced to 25 years to life in prison for the murder in.,May 1970 of Ernestine Tin. mons, his divorced wife. Mr. LeGrand, who is 52 years old, is already serving sentence of 25 years to life for the murder of two teenage sisters, Gladys Rivera Steward and Yvonne Rivera, in October 1975. He is scheduled to go on trial next month on charges of having murdered his commonlaw wife, Ann Sorise, in September 1,973.

title: Roosevelt
description: Fiarses listed in order of pest Positions Lehr, designates On listing.

title: PRESIDENT EXHORTS CHIEF NEGOTIATORS ON A PANAMA TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, July 29President Carter intervened personally in the Panama Canal treaty talks for the first time today by calling the chief negotiators for both sides to a morning session at the White House.

title: With Richmond's Old Guard Watching, Blacks Take On Aging City's Problems
description: RICHMONDSix months after blacks took political control of this old Confederate capital, the statues honoring Rebel heroes still stand along Monument Avenue.

title: Dewey Thruway Toll Receipts Off
description: ALBANY, July 29 (AP)  Passenger car tolls droped off for the first six months of 1977, officials of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway reported today, as New Yorkers cut down their driving somewhat.

title: 50,000 Coal Miners on Strike
description: More than 50,000 Kentucky and West Virginia coal miners were idle today as a wildcat strike protesting cutbacks in medical benefits gained momentum. A spokesman for the West Virginia Coal Association said that 46,000 miners were idle with virtually all mines shut down in Charlestonbased District 17 and Beckleybased District 29. Mines in the northern part of the state were reported still operating. In eastern Kentucky, 10,000 miners were estimated on strike, cutting coal production in that state by 80,000 tons daily.

title: Third World Debt: Reasons and Remedy
description: Ever since the Arab oil embargo, the international nancial system has lent itself to a doomsday scenario, which goes something like this: Lessdeveloped countries pile up debts to pay for oil. Commercial banksmainly Americanlend them the money, but the oilshort nations cannot repay on time. One or two countries default. The lending capacity of the banks is impaired. A ??? fail. The American economy lurches. And, finally, the delicately balanced structure of international finance begins to come apart.

title: CHATTANOOGA SYNAGOGUE DESTROYED IN EXPLOSION
description: CHATTANOOGA, Ten., July 29 (AP)An explosion that rained debris over square block area destroyed a synagogue tonight about an hour after evening services had ended, the police said.

title: MILT BUCKNER DIES; MUSICIAN, COMPOSER
description: CHICAGO, July 29 (AP)Jazzman Milt Buckner, B2 years old, long the pianist and organist of the Lionel Hampton band, died Wednesday night after collapsing while setting up instruments for an appearance at a Chicago night spot.

title: Where Tiny Tots Can Frolic: Their Own Roof Playground
description: In back of the parlor floor of a handsome old house at 6 East 93d Street; a playground was set up on a fencedin roof overhung with tall sycamores and locusts from neighboring yards.

title: A Midsummer's Measure Of the 23d E.D.'s Political Pulse
description: If it were still the Gashouse District, politics would permeate the local gossip and everyone would understand why the professionals were focusing on Chris McGrath's and Vince Albano's election instead of Abe Beam's.

title: Topics
description: It's difficult to fit Prince Saud elFaisal of Saudi Arabia into the role of victim, but this seems to have been accomplished by the board of directors of 640 Park Avenue, a cooperative apartment house. The Prince, the nepheW of the present King of Saudi Arabia, was not permitted to buy an apartment because the board didn't want him in the building.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONResearchers at the RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J., have succeeded in keeping solar cells automatically pointed directly at the sun for maximum production of power.

title: Steel Rally Helps Sluggish Dow Post Token Gain in Slow Session
description: A late rally in sharply depressed steel shares enabled the Dow Jones industrial average to post a token gain yesterday after a price slump in the morning. The Dow, down nearly 8 points at 11 A.M., finished 0.08 higher at 890.07.

title: Rhodesians Say a Border Post Was Attacked From Mozambique
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 29 (UPI)Rhodesia and Mozambique traded fire across their border today and the military command in Salisbury said seven biz ck nationalist guerrillas had been killed in the last 24 hours.

title: Schneider and Friends Delight
description: The artist's calling is reputedly a lonely one, but judging by the number of friends who turn up with performers in concerts these days, it is anything but lonely. On Thursday night it was the turn of Alexander Schneider and Friends to present the Mostly Mozart Festival program at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Some Medical Students Eager to Serve the Aged
description: David Allen, a 23yearold secondyear medical student from. Roxbury, Mass., membered how telpless he felt when his greatgrandmother was sent to a nursing home. He believes now, as he. did then, that she could have received adequate care at home if medical attention bad been available.

title: Senator Is First Brazil Civilian To Bid for President Geisel's Job
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil (AP)A popular Brazilian senator has become the first civilian to announce his candidacy to succeed Gen. Ernesto Geisel as president. If elected by the Congress in the October 1973 election, the Senator, Jose de Magahlaes Pinto, would become the first civilian president since Joao Goulart was overthrown in a military coup in 1964.

title: Meadowlands Drivers
description: Meadowlands Drivers

title: Alaska Oil Flow Reaches Valdez After Delays and Pipeline Mishaps
description: VALDEZ, Alaska, July 29Despite sabotage, explosion, fire, bad welds and clumsy accidents, oil from the Alaska Arctic was pouring into the terminal storage tanks here today.

title: EDWARD W. BOURNE
description: Edward W. Bourne, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Alexander & Green and a life member of the board of governors for New York Hospital, died Wednesday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in West Cornwall.

title: Paris Presses Search in Coin Theft
description: PARIS. July 29Hundreds of policemen fanned out across Paris and its suburbs today in search of three or four men and the truck they hijacked last night containing $3.65 million in 10franc coins.

title: Meadowlands
description: Meadowlands ENTRIES Horses listed in order of post positions

title: Where Did the Winter Go? Torrid Rio Wants to Know
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 29Where did winter go. The question is a frequent one these days.

title: Soviet is Raking In Profits At Shops for Foreigners
description: MOSCOW, July 24The Russian shopper looked with anticipation at the Christian Dior cosmetics tidily arrayed behind the counter, but before she could inquire the saleswoman cut her short. This is not our store, said the clerk, emphasizing the possessive. This is only for foreigners.

title: Golf
description: PHILADELPHIA CLASSIC The Leading Scores.

title: Cauthen Riding High Despite Loss of Bug
description: About a month has passed since Steve Cauthen, the 17yearold riding sensation from Kentucky, lost his apprentice allowance of five pounds. The taciturn teenager,. however, seems to have lost little of, his appeal among trainers.

title: News Summary
description: Israeli and Arab leaders will be given specific American proposals by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance during his forthcoming Middle East trip in an attempt to help them overcome obstacles to a new Geneva peace conference. Mr. Vance was very cautious at a news conference in Washingtoncontrasting sharply with President Carter's optimismand he did not hide the possibility that his mission might not be successful. The major difficulty is settling the question of whether the Palestine Liberation Organization should be represented in Geneva. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Beame Dons a Yarmulke and Campaigns in Catskills
description: ELLENVILLE, N.Y., July 29Mayor Beame, seeking votes among New York City's Jewish residents vacationing in the Catskill Mountains, was, for the most patt, greeted warmly here today, but he encountered an undertone of dissastisfaction and worry over his handling of the looting and arson during the, July 1314 blackout.

title: COURT UPHOLDS I.C.C. ON ALASKA OIL PRICE
description: ANCHORAGE, July 29 (AP)A Federal appeals court in New Orleans upheld today an effort by the Interstate Commerce Commission to reduce the price that oil companies will receive for shipping oil through their transAlaska pipeline.

title: Drive for Federal Welfare Aid Set
description: Mayor Beame and two dozen business, labor and community representatives met yesterday to plan a signature campaign that will get under way next week urging President Carter to have the Federal Government assume part of local welfare costs.

title: Chrysler President Optimistic
description: DETROIT, July 29 (AP)John J. Riccardo, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that he was, convinced Congress would settle on new pollution standards in time to avert a threatened shutdown of automobile plants in two weeks.

title: Judge Halts Excavation for Gym At Kent State After 70 Are Held
description: KENT, Ohio, July 29Protesters fightIn construction of a gymnasium near the site where four students were slain by National Guardsmen on the Kent State University campus in 1970 won a temporary stay today that will halt work until their case can be heard in Federal District Court.

title: CAMPAIGN TO OUST YOUNG BEGUN BY CONSERVATIVES
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)  The Conservative Caucus and its Citizens Cabinet have opened a campaign to oust Andrew Young as United States delegate to the United Nations. They say response so far has been very heavy.

title: 3 Dates Are Proposed by Canada For Ending WagePrice Controls
description: OTTAWA, July 29The Canadian Government proposed three dates today for ending wage and price controls, with leaders of industry and labor to make the choice provided that they accept certain conditions.

title: Illness Resembling Dengue Fever Being Investigated in Nine States
description: ATLANTA, July 29 (AP)Illnesses resembling dengue fever, which has not appeared in epidemic proportions in the United States since the 1940's, are being investigated in nine states and the District of Columbia, the national Center for Disease Control said today. All cases involve persons returning from Jamaica.

title: 3 Share L.P.G.A. Lead On70'satMountPocono
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., July 29Amy Alcott has a touch of the pixie and a bright sparkle in her brown eyes. A 21yearold professional golfer from California, she was having difficulty being serious today trying to describe the West Course at Pocono Manor.

title: PETER A. LEVINE
description: Peter A. Levine of White Plains, commercial credit executive, died suddenly Wednesday while playing tennis near his home. He was 44 years old.

title: Tennis
description: Guillermo Vitas, Argentina, defeated Brian Fairlie, Australia, 6.4, 6.2; Hans Gilde. meister, Chile, defeated Dick Crealy, Australia, 6.1, 6.3; Dick Stockton, CaroIlton, Tex., defeated Tim Wilkison, Shelby, N.C., 6.3, 75; Phil Dent, Australia, defeated Hans Kary, Austria, 6.3, 1.6, 6.4; Ion Tiriac, Rumania, defeated Andrew Pattison, South Africa, 75, 6.4; Victor Pecci, Paraguay, defeated Patricio Corneio, Chile, 6.4, 6.4; Eddie Dibbs, Miami, defeated Jean Cauiolley, France, 6.4, 6.4; Bernie Mitton, South Africa, defeated Harold Solomon, Silver Spring, Md., 64, 6.3.

title: Apples Pin 2216 Loss On Racquets
description: UNIONDALE, July 29In a strange World Team Tennis match tq. night at Nassau Coliseum, the New York Apples took advantage of tvo injuries to the Phoenix Racquets but still needed a game in overtime in posting a 2216 triumph. A crow of 7,284 attended.

title: Police Check Drug Link of Revenge Victim
description: The victim or a revenge killing Brooklyn Tuesday who had been described as a holdup man may have been involved in the drug trade in his neighborhood, the police said yesterday.

title: Joseph F. Scrozati
description: RARE SIGHTING: A juvenile White Ibis photographed as he perched on branch in the Great Swamp. The bird's normal habitat ranges southward from South Carolina. The National Audubon Society has issued a rare bird alert after several sightings here and in Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge.

title: AETNA LIFE EARNINGS SOAR RECORD 993%
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company reported yeaterday its highest earnings for any quarter Or halfyear period in its 124year history.

title: Monzon to Defend Title In Farewell to Boxing
description: MONTE CARLO, July 29Tbree weeks late and what seem like three million words later, Carlos Monzon will defend his world middleweight boxing championship here tomorrow night against Rodrigo Valdes in what Monzon insists will be his farewell fight.

title: JUNE BUILDING CONTRACTS 41% AHEAD OF 1976 MONTH
description: With all categories of construction showing substantial gains, building contract awards in June totaling $15.4 billion were 41 percent ahead of the $10.9 billion awarded in June of 1976, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company said yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: Beginners are taught that if both members of a partnership have an opening bid a game should be bid, and that conversely if neither player has full opening a part score should be sufficient.

title: Black Caucus Criticizes Carter and Backs Jordan In Dispute Over Remarks
description: WASHINGTON. July 29 (UPI)The Congressional Black Caucus today unanimously endorsed Vernon E. Jordan's Jr.'s criticisms of President Carter and warned Mr. Carter that he was starting to lose black support.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)Senator Barry Goldwater said today that President Carter's overeager foreign posture has led some nations to move without fear of American anger.

title: 32,000 Smoke Alarms. Recalled Over Sensitiveness of Warning
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)  The Master Lock Company is recalling 32,000 Master smoke alarms, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today. Officials said the Milwaukee concern was recalling No. 2551 batteryoperated alarms and No. 2553 dualpowered alarms made in 1975 and part of 1976.

title: Susan Ginsberg Is Bride Of Michael Enzer, Ad Man
description: At the Central Synagogue yesterday, Susan P. Ginsberg, daughter of Mr. and Murray P. Ginsberg of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married to Michael J. Enzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton M. Enzer of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi R. Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: Barre Accepts Carter Invitation
description: PARIS, July 29 (UPI)  Prime Minister Raymond Barre has accepted an invitation from President Carter to visit Washington on Sept. 15 and 16, his office said today.

title: Key Indicators Index Dips Again; June 0.6% Decrease Is Discounted
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The Commerce Department reported today that its index of leading economic indicators, which is designed to show which way the economy is headed, declined in June for the second consecutive month.

title: Dividends
description: Stk. of pay.

title: Stray Bullet Kills Nurse in Exchange On W W. 108th Street
description: A 44yearold nursing supervisor at St. Luke's Hospital was fatally wounded yesterday when she was caught in an exchange of shots on the upper West Side a few brocks from the hospital, the police reported.

title: SENATE REJECTS MOVE MGT OFF FILIBUSTER
description: WASHINGTON. July 29The Senate refused decisively today to cut off debate on a proposal backed by President Carter to provide Federal campaign subsidies for Congressional candidates and limit the amount they can spend in a political race.

title: New York contends That Conrail Diverts Freight Traffic Front City
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Conrail, the Northeast rail giant, is diverting freight traffic from New York City and urging rail shippers to move out of the city and telocate in New Jersey and elsewhere, a spokesman for the city charged at Senate transportation hearing today.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: FIRST GAME ST. LOUIS (N.) ??? (N.)

title: Soviet Test Indicated
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (Reuters)Seismic signals presumed to be from Soviet underground nuclear% explosion were picked up by the American atomic energy detection system, the United States Energy Research and Development reported today: It said the signals were recorded Tuesday and originated from central Siberia, north of the Arctic Circle, where the Russians have an underground testing area.

title: PaperPrice Conspiracy. Is Charged
description: HARTFORD, July 29 (AP)Connecticut has accused 13 major paper companies of conspiring to limit competition, rig bids and divide up territory, Attorney General Carl Mello said today.

title: English Coal Town, a Lot Less Grimy, Is Still Under a Cloud
description: WIGAN, EnglandThe northerners never hesitate to say that they are the only realists in England. They are warmer, earthier, blunter and more honest than the southerners, they say, but above all they are more realistic.

title: US Freedom, to German Director
description: WEST BERLIN  Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the outstanding figure among the young directors of Germany's new dnema, says that he is about to leave Germany and settle in the United States, where he expects to lind more freedom for future projects. From his base in Munich, be told a telephone caller, III am leaving next week to go to New York, The first thing I plan to do is look for a house in the Village to settle down there.

title: The Haute Couture: Expensive, Influential and Enduring
description: PARIS, July 29 The Paris couture is not for you and me. To begin with, the clothes are too expensive. Typically, they'll run around $3,000 or $4,000 for a relatively simple style. More elaborate ones can go into five figures. Then, the collections are divided between hopelessly conservative and incredibly fantastic styles.

title: Court Voids Order To Allow Clamming
description: The Appellate Division in Brooklyn has vacated a judge's order that would have allowed a resumption of clamming in mere than 2,000 acres of the Great South Bay. The restraining order had been issued nine days ago by Justice Vito J. Titone of the Appellate Division of State Supreme court at the request of the Town of Babylon, ending an appeal made on Aug. 23 by four Suffolk County towns with large clamming industries.

title: Attack in Argentina Fails
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 29 (AP)  Six persons believed to be leftist guerrillas tried to seize a suburban radio station at dawn today but were repelled by security forces guarding it the police said. They said one policeman had been seriously wounded. There were no reports of casualties among the attackers, who were reported to have escaped.

title: New AfricanConflicts Threaten To Further Weaken Soviet in Area
description: MOSCOW, July 29,Soviet foreign policy in the Middle East, already battered in recent years by Moscow's estrangement from Cairo and the civil war in Lebanon, appears to be suffering further setback as a result of the latest hostilities in northeastern Africa.

title: Banks Use New Device To Detect Check Fraud
description: Because the checkfor $2,700was drawn on another branch, the man trying to cash it was directed to a bank officer for her approval. She asked for identification, which he had in abundance. Because she did not know him, she also asked him to put an inkless fingerprint on the back of his check. The man balked, then hurriedly headed for the door.

title: Con Ed Begins the Autopsy
description: Was the blackout of July 13 an act of God, as Consolidated Edison chairman Charles Luce suggests, or case of gross negligence by the utility, as Mayor Beame asserts? That question may ultimately be answered through separate investigations by the Federal Power Commission, the State Public Service Commission, Mayor Beame's blueribbon panel and Con Edison's own inquiry. This week, Con Edison issued the first results of that inquirya chronicle of the events by which power was disrupted and then restored. This report deliberately avoids any analysis of what caused the blackoutthat will be dealt with later. But its recital of events raises troubling questions about both the collapse of the system and the effort to revive it.

title: A Better Deal for the Bettor
description: It was probably inevitable. Thanks to the politicians. parimutuel racing has become such an obvious consumer swindle that management must now bribe horseplayers to come out to the track. The newspaper ads for today's Priceless Day II at Belmont Park tell the story: a picture of three winners from Priceless Day I holding up their giveaway checks for $5,000, $3,000 and $1,000. July 2nd Was Their Lucky Day, the headline reads. July 30th Could Be Yours. Radio soots have been talking about the day you might win $5,000 just by watching the Sports thoroughbreds run. That's one way to send a few horseplayers home happy: free adof mission to the grandstand, free musical enThe Times tertainment, free rides for the kids, and free shot at $10,000 worth of cash prizes a people's sweepstakes. A better way to get the horseplayers back to the track would be to cut the takeout enough so they could feel more like customers than suckers.

title: Let There Be Some Kind of Light
description: PARIS  Nothing demonstrates how fragile modern society has become more than the gloomy drumbeat of statistical evidence accompanied by counterpoint of occasional disasters like this month's blackout of New York. Twice in a dozen years the power on which United States urban existence now depends was cut off around the country's largest metropolitan area.

title: Fed Approves Bid to Take Over Banco Economias of Puerto Rico
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)The Federal Reserve Board approved today the application of Banco Central, the second largest bank in Spain, to take over control of Banco Economias of San German, Puerto Rico.

title: Art Auction Season Breaks Records
description: The most turbulent art auction season in 200 years will end next week, and preliminary reports issued in London yesterday show that both Sotheby's and Christie's will have surnassed all previous totals. Since the beginning of the season last September, they will also have eclipsed more records, if less spectacular ones, than in any season in memory.

title: House Democratic Leaders Agiee On 5caGallon Gasoline Tax Rise
description: WASHINGTON, July 29With enthusiastic backing from the Carter Administration, the House Democratic leadership has worked out a compromise in its energy package, calling for a 5centagallon gasoline tax increase instead of the 4cent plan proposed by a special House committee.

description: ARLINGTON, Tex.,, July 29 (AP)The Texas Rangers put Ken Henderson, an outfielder, who has been suffering from rib injuries, on the 15day disabled list and activated Tom Grieve, another outfielder.

description: ARCHBISHOP BURIED: Archbishop Edward A. McCarthy performing the final act of commendation over the coffin of Archbishop Coleman F. Carroll, the man he succeeded as head of Miami archdiocese, in services yesterday.

description: PARIS  An immens blue big top in the plaza of the Centre Georges Pompidou welcomes full houses twice daily, but the real circus is in the museum.

description: CLEVELAND, July 29A declaration of war against all forms of pornography, and all persons who peddle it was made here at a national conference that ended today.

title: O'DONNELL IS JOINING THE STAFF OF DURYEA
description: ALBANY, July 29  Harry J. O'Donnell, who resigned last month as Governor Carey's director of communications to reshape my life and find new areas of professional satisfaction and personal fulfillment, today joined the staff of Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly minority leader and a likely opponent for Mr. Carey in the race for Governor next year.

title: Udall Asks Inquiry on Atom Material Loss
description: WASHINGTON,, July 29Representative Morris K. Udall, chairman of the House Interior Committee, said today he had asked President Carter to determine whether the Federal Government had covered up the theft of a large amount of nuclear material that could have been converted to atomic bombs.

title: Carter Announces 2 Nominees For Federal Power Commission
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)  Presi dent Carter announced today his nominees for two positions on the Federal Power Commission.

title: 25 Suits Filed in Kentucky Fire
description: COVINGTON, Ky., July 29 (UPI)The amount of legal damages sought by relatives of victims of the Beverly Hills Supper Club fire has risen to $784 million. The total soared when a $200 million classaction suit was filed yesterday in Federal District Court on behalf of Karen Coburn of Ironton, Ohio, whose father, Orville Coulter, died in the May 28 blaze that killed 164 persons. Yesterday's was the second Federal classaction suit asking $200 million in damages among 25 lawsuits filed to date.

title: Greek Sentenced in Playboy Case
description: ATHENS, July 29 (AP) Greece's major foreign magazine distributor was sentenced to five months in prison today for distributing last August's issue of Playboy magazine. An Athens court found Christos Samouhos, 38 years old, guilty of offending public morals on the ground that the issue was pornographic. He was allowed to pay a fine instead of serving the prison term.

title: Terry Diehl Learns Power of Positive Thinking
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 29  The proportion is a matter of opinion8020, 7525, 6040but golf professionals unanimously agree that compaition golf is more a mental enterprise than physical.

title: T W A. to Submit Plan On N.Y.London Fares
description: Trans World Airline said yesterday it would formally submit to the Civil Aeronautics Board on Monday its proposals in the New YorkLondon fare competition started by Laker Airways nofrills $135 bargain.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CUNARD PRINCESS (Cunard). Left Bermuda July 28; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Strongest Magnetic Field
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 29 (AP)  A fivefoottall barrelshaped magnet at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has produced the strongest continuous magnetic field ever generated by man, a spokesman said yesterday. The magnet produced a field of 301,000 gaussmore than 30 times the power of large industrial electromagnets. The field broke record of 254,000 gauss set by another magnet at M.I.T.'s Francis Bitter National Magnet Laboratory in February.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson said yesterday that his city was dropping Blue CrossBlue Shield health coverage for 1,400 city employees and would save half a million dollars over two years as a result.

title: DOLLAR IS STRONGER IN EUROPEAN TRADING
description: LONDON July 29 (AP)The dollar gained against all major West European currencies today, soaring against the French franc and the West German mark in what some dealers called a confused and illogical market.

title: Limited Progress in Flood Aid
description: The latest flood at Johnstown, Pa., points up both good news and bad news in national efforts to mitigate such periodic disasters. The good news is that the calamity is not one of those occasional developments that disclose a complete lack of public and governmental preparedness. A comprehensive Federal program to minimize flood damage and provide financial help to the victims is in operation.

title: Mackinac College Sold to Investors
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 29 (AP) Mackinac College, the island property where the television evangelist Rex Humbard once hoped to establish a Christian university like that of Oral Roberts, has been sold.

title: University Autonomy And the Bakke Case
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.One important argument of those who believe that Allan Bakke should lose his United States Supreme Court case against the Regents of the University of California is that universities and professional schools must retain the autonomy to select their students as they see fit, within of course certain limits.

title: State's High Court Rules Governorship Candidates Cannot Accept Individual Gifts Exceeding $600
description: This means that Governor Bryne and his Republican opponent in the November election, State Senator Raymond IL Bateman of Somerville, will have to find a lot of small contributions instead of a few big ones to pay off their campaign debts from the June primary.

title: Micko Tilly of Sweden Takes Trot at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 29Sweden's Micko Tilly, a disappointing seventh in the International Trot last week, scored a 5length triumph tonight in a $20,000 class A2 trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Guidry Stymies ks With Lyle's Help
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 29Ron Guidry, a quiet Southerner who has remained aloof from the controversy that has engulfed the Yankees all season, continued to make noise with his pitching tonight.

description: Television

description: How can the antitrust laws be enforced?

title: Wealth, Fame and the Liniment Set
description: As every American knows, success Is the greatest thing in life and a terrible thing to happen to the young and the beautiful. Why? Because it destroys them, erodes their talent, spoils their beauty, diverts them to vice, disrupts the liver function and leads to heartbreak, alcohol, corruption, pills, squalor and an early grave. How delightfully dreadful How we enjoy it How angry we become when these favorites of the gods refuse to wither in suffering and despair.

title: Bhutto, Released From Detention, Assails Martial Law in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 29 (AP)Former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, making his first public appearance since being freed from military detention, said today that martial law was not the answer to Pakistan's prob. lems.

title: New York Ordered To Continue Funds To Poverty Agency
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday ordered New York City to continue subsidy payments to a Harlem antipoverty agency that city officials sought to cut off because of the criminal record of its recently reinstated executive director.

title: George Batson, 61, Playwright, Specialized in Comedies, Farcei
description: George D. Batson, a playwright specializing in comedies and farces, died Monday at the age of 61. He lived at 245 East 21st Street.

title: Carey's HealthCareCost Aide Quits After Just Two Months
description: Joseph M. Giglio, who was appointed last May by Governor Carey to head new cabinetlevel Office of Health Systems Management, has resigned to take a higherpaying job in private industry.

title: Niekro Brothers Baffle Cubs, Pirates
description: During major league baseball's century of competition, many brother acts have got their share of attentionparticularly among pitchers.

title: Farmers Prices Off 2% in Month; Overall Drop Is 7% Since July 76
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)Prices farmers receive for raw products as they enter the consumer pipeline dropped 2 percent between June 15 and July 15, the second consecutive monthly decline, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: LESSRAPID GROWTH IN ECONOMY IS SEEN IN 2D HALF BY BURNS
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Arthur F. Burns, said today that the economy would grow somewhat less rapidly in the second half of this year, but that activity would still be strong enough to produce some further reductions in unemployment.

title: Cooperative's Rejectionof Prince Being Investigated by Lefkowitz
description: At the request of former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller, the New York State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, is looking into the rejection of an application by a Saudi Arabian prince to hnv an anartment on Park Avenue.

title: F.B.I. HOLDS MAN SOUGHT FOR 72 GANGLAND SLAYING
description: A man charged with the 1972 murder of Carlo A. Lombardi, a reputed mobster, was arrested yesterday in Atlantic City by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the bureau announced.

title: Fisherman Killed by Hornets
description: ELKTON, Md., July 29 (UPI) A fisherman who was digging for earthworms accidentally disturbed an underground nest of hornets and was stung to death, the state police reported today. Eugene W. Ewing, 64 years old, went into a ???oma yesterday shortly after he was attacked by the yellow jackets and died of shock when the venom forced his blood pressure to drop drastically, a Cecil County deputy medical examiner said.

title: JDA COHEN ROOSE
description: Ida Cohen Roose, a retired principal at Public School 5 in Manhattan, died Thursday at the Jewish. Home and Hospital for the aged. She was 94 years old and livd. in Pomona, N.Y.

title: UNION LEADER IS INDICTED ON TWO FEDERAL COUNTS
description: A twocount Federal indictment was filed in Manhattan yesterday against Peter Ottley, the president of Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital, Nursing Home and Allied Health Service Union.

title: US. AGENCY APPROVES DESIGN OF WESTWAY
description: ALBANY, July 29  The Federal Highway Administration has approved the design of the Westway, the controversial $1.16 billion replacement for the West Side Highway, the State Transportation Department announced today.

title: Jersey High Court Puts a $600 Limit On Campaign Gifts
description: TRENTON, July 29The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled 6 to 0 today that candidates for Governor might not accept more than $600 from an individual in the general election this year.

title: TASS ASSAILS CARTER OVER ISRAEL AND TRADE
description: MOSCOW, July 29 (AP)The Sovietpress agency Tass said today that United States policy on the Middle East was hypocritical and that President Carter reflected this in his Washington news conference yesterday.

title: News Summary
description: Israeli and Arab leaders will be given specific American proposals by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance during his forthcoming Middle East trip in an attempt to help them overcome obstacles to a new Geneva peace conference. Mr. Vance was very cautious at a news conference in Washingtoncontrasting sharply with President Carter's optimismand he did not hide the possibility that his mission might not be successful. The major difficulty is settling the question of whether the Pal. estine Liberation Organization should be represented in Geneva. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: People in Sports
description: Dave Bing has been given permission by the Washington Bullets general manager, Bob Ferry, to make a deal for himself if he can with another National Basketball Association team. The 6foot3inch 185pound Bing, an 11 year pro, played in 64 games and averaged only 10.6 points per game last year. His career scoring average in the N.B.A. is 21 points per game.

title: WKCR Will Be the First Station To Transmit From Trade Center
description: The first radio or television station to broadcast from a transmitter atop the World Trade Center will be WKCR, the Columbia Universityowned FM radio outlet.

title: Disappearance of Young Woman Alarms Her Family and Friends
description: Two weeks ago, Ellen Jane Hover disappeared. And to her friends and family, who find nothing missing from the small, walkup apartment where she lived alone at 686 Third Avenue, her absence is extraordinary and alarming.

title: F.P.C. Officials Say Con Edison Lacked Preparedness for Blackout
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Officials of the Federal Power Commission said today that the Consolidated Edison Company had not been properly prepared to avert the July 1314 blackout of New York City and Westchester County. But they also had praise for the utility's efforts to restore service.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N. J., July 29 (UPI)Volkswagen of America today became the sixth foreign auto company in the last two weeks to raise auto prices to offset the decline in the value of the dollar against the West German mark and Japanese yen:

title: Car Holding Bones Found in Lake; 15Year Mystery May Be Solved
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 29  A sunken car that contained two human skulls and numerous bones was pulled out of  an Orange County, lake yesterday by the New York state police  and with it emerged the possibility that a 15yearold mystery had been solved.

title: Koosman Winner Boos for Kingman
description: Dave Kingman led the pathetic San Diego Padres into Shea Stadium last night to play the equally pathetic Mets. The big slugger, who was traded by New York June 15 when he refused the Mets contract offer and the Mets refused his terms, was probably the leading interest in a meaningless game. but it certainly helped the younger guys by giving them confidence. When you've got an experienced man talking hitting to you all day, it can't hurt.

title: The New York Times/Gary Settle
description: KENT STATE PROTESTERS stand idly outside fence after 61 demonstrators were arrested there. A judge later issued a stay, halting construction gymnasium on site where four students were killed in 1970. Article, page.

title: Drought Spurs Drive to Save Wild Horses
description: WINNEMUCCA, Nev., July 29Hot in the day and cold at night, the Owyhee Desert northeast of here is stingy with the things that support life even in the best years. Though it often seems empty, the 600,000acre desert can suddenly explode with herds of wild horses, deer, antelopes, groups of rabbits, snakes, ravens, sage hens, and field mice and individual badgers, coyotes and mountain lions.

title: GOIUNG OUT Guider
description: HARVEST TIME A Salute to Tv vie Musicals seems an apt program for Joe Franklin, host of a special eitent tomorrow and Monday nights ate the downtown Ballroom in Soho. Mr. Franklin, as many television watchers know, is the star of a popular nocturnal talk session that often has a fascinating array of guests and just as often is the salvation of the homescreen when the Late Late Shows are impossible.

title: Drought Spurs Drive to Save Wild Horses
description: WINNEMUCCA, Nev., July 29Hot in the day and cold at night, the Owyhee Desert northeast of here is stingy with the things that support life even in the best years. Though it often seems empty, the 600,000acre desert can suddenly explode with herds of wild horses, deer, antelopes, groups of rabbits, snakes, ravens, sage hens, and field mice and individual badgers, coyotes and mountain lions.
