title: About NewYork
description: With the speed of stagehands switching sets in a manyscened Nev: York changes its profile. Sometimes the urban caterpillar is metamorphosed into a municipal butterfly, sometimes the beautiful form gives 7.7.y to drab profitable function. But the rapidity of change influences our sense of time, and in this quickmoving city the good old days of only a halfdozen years ago can evoke nostalgia that small towns reserve for events of decades back.

title: A Federal Manual Is Called a Guide to Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON, July 29A California Congressman said today that a report prepared for the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy appeared to be a howtodoit manual on noncourtordered wiretapping.

title: United Press International
description: THOUSANDS OF DEAD FISH were washed up on shore of ship channel in Corpus Christi, Tex., Thursday. More 40,000 fish died from what authorities believe was an oxygen depletion in the water.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Recently, New York State Attorney General Lefkowitz wrote in opposition to a legislative proposal of mine which would grant explicit authority to the United States Attorney General to initiate law suits to protect the consitutional rights of institutionalized persons, including the elderly, mentally handicapped, children and prisoners who are housed in state and local facilities.

title: New York Says Conrail Is Diverting Freight From
description: Attacking Conrail's monopoly position as the successor to the Penn Central and other bankrupt carriers, the city spokesurged legislation, if necessary, to allow the Delaware and Hudson Railway to serve the port of New York directly.

title: The Standings
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Seahawks Tackle Sidelined
description: CHENEY, Wash., July 29 (AP)The Seattle Seahawks secondyear tackle, Steve Niehaus, will undergo surgery on his right shoulder and will be out from 10 to 12 weeks, Coach Jack Patera said yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: President Carter yesterday recorded a special message of good will for possible unknown civilizations in the galaxies, to be placed in the Voyager spacecraft to be launched Aug. 20. The message, recorded in electronic impulses that could be converted into printed words, said: This is a present froM a small distant world, a token of our sounds, our science, our images, our music, our thoughts and our feelings. We are attempting to survive our time so we may live into yours. We hope someday, having solved the problems we face, to join a community of galactic civilizations. This record represents our hope and our determination, our good will in the vast and universe.

title: A Terrible, Terrible, Confession
description: I have a confession to make, and it has to do with physics. No, I haven't been spinning my Higgs bosons or charming my mesons on the sly. I don't do physics, I write about it. That means, of course, that I spend quite bit of time reading about physics, talking to physicists, even thinking about physics. But, there is a skeleton in my professional closet whose bones rattle tellingly whenever I start flinging around words like resonance and parity. The ugly truth, howevei well I may hide it behind curtains of transplendent prose, is that I just don't understand physics.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, July 29 (AP)Legal abortions: in the United Stales increased 12 per cent in 1975 over the 1974 total, and onethird of the patients where teenagers, the national Center for Disease Control. reported today.

title: Madagascar Cabinet Said to Quit
description: ANTANANARIVO, Madagascar, July 291 (Agence FrancePresse)  Madagascar's Government has resigned, the national radio station reported today. President Didier Ratsiraka accepted the Government's resignation from Prime Minister Justin Rakotoniaina, the radio said.

title: Widow Wins $30,000 In Guess on Oil Flow
description: ANCHORAGE, July 29 (UFI)An unemployed Anchorage widow who waila with the aid of crutches won $30,000 today by submitting the closest guess as to how long it would take the first oil to flow from Prudhoe Bay to Valdez.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: VANCE WILL PRESENT. SPECIFIC PROPOSALS DURING MIDEAST TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that he would present specific American proposals to Israeli and Arab leaders during his forthcoming Middle East trip in an effort to overcome the obstacles to a new Geneva peace conference.

title: Bomb Explodes at Milan Office
description: MILAN, Italy, July 29 (AP)A sevenpound dynamite bomb exploded early today at the entrance to the Swiss airline office in this northern Italian city, the police reported. They said that a leftist extremist group had telephoned police headquarters and claimed responsibility for the attack, which it said was to protest the long detention of an alleged West German anarchist, Petra Krause, in Swiss jails.

title: Cooperative's Rejectionof Prince Being Investigated by Lefkowitz
description: At the request of former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller, the New York State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, is looking into the rejection of an application by a Saudi Arabian prince to buy an aoartment on Park Avenue.

title: Urban and Rural Lawmakers Join To Support Each Bloc's Interests
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Urban and rural members of Congress, who used to oppose each other with regularity on issues involving their parochial interests, have begun to change their voting patterns and Increasingly to band together.

title: END LAKE POLLUTION, MILWAUKEE IS TOLD
description: CHICAGO, July 29Federal District Judge John F. Grady issued an injunction today against the City of Milwaukee, ordenng it to stop polluting Lake Michigan.

title: Soccer
description: LAST NILI4T'S MATCH Seattle at Rochester. pod., rain.

title: Books of The Times
description: For the longest time during last year's Presidential campaign, many reporters reacted to Jimmy Carter's unabashed espousal of born again Christianity with about as much befuddlement as if Mr. Carter had said he had ridden in a flying saucer.. But finally the press and the public came to grips with this biographical fact and in the process discovered a lot about the evangelical movement that has loomed so large in the nation's past and has again emerged as a major religious force.

title: PRESIDENT EXHORTS CHIEF NEGOTIATORS ON A PANAMA TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, July 29President Carter intervened personally in the Panama Canal treaty talks for the first time today by calling the chief negotiators for both sides to a morning session at the White House.

title: Spain Acts to Aid Jobless
description: MADRID, July 29 (Reuter)The Cabinet announced a $340 million program tonight to reduce unemployment. The money will be spent for the most part on publicworks projects and lowcost housing in the provinces of Andalusia in the south and Extremadura in the west, where the number of jobless workers is higher than the national average of percent.

title: New Way of Moving Household Goods
description: The last time Paul and Cathy Winters moved, some of their things got broken. Some disappeared. As the crew, some of whom had been drinking, closed the door of the van, the Winterses wondered if they would ever see their possessions again.

title: 14 Die as Thai Buses Collide
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 29 (Reuters) Fourteen persons were killed and seven hurt yesterday when two buses collided in the southern province of Prachuab Khiri Khan, the police said today.

title: Lifers Invite Police to a Prison Barbecue
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., July 29The police came to Rahway State Prison today for an outdoor barbecue put on by prisoners serving life sentences.

title: South Africa Arrests Mrs. Mandela On Charge of Violating Politics Ban
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 29 (Reuters)Winnie Mandela, a black militant, was arrested yesterday and charged with having violated a Government order barring her fromp olitics and banishing her to the remote settlement of Brandfort. She is the wife of Nelson Mandela, black nationalist leader serving a life sentence in Robben Island Prison.

title: Belgrade Talks Remain Deadlocked
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29After six weeks of efforts to reach agreement on an agenda, the Belgrade Conference on Security and Cooperation fn Europe remained deadlocked today, with mounting pressure for adjournment in the next few days.

title: Con erees Remain Split on New Car Pollution Rules
description: WASHINGTON, July 29After marathon negotiations, House and Senate conferees moved today toward agreement on controversial amendments to the Clean Air Act.

title: H. U.D. Chief Surveys Johnstown Damage
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 29 (UPI)Patricia Roberts Harris, United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, flew here today to survey flood damage and  recovery efforts under the threat of more showers and a flash flood watch issued by the National Weather Service.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: HOLIDAY VICTORY: Ted Turner, skipper of the Courageous, after he won race in Newport harbor in a 9foot dingy. The race was for the captains and crews of the America's Cup 12Meter yachts.

title: Jndians and Maine Support Plan For a Lawsuit Over Land Claims
description: AUGUSTA, Me., July 29 (AP)Maine Indians say they would welcome the opportunity to sue the state to attempt to win the return of publicly owned land while negotiating an outofcourt settlement with the Federal Government on claims to privately held land.

title: Events Today
description: MOSTLY MOZART: FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 8.GUGGENHEIM CONCERT: GOLDMAN BAND, Seaside Park, Brooktyn, 8.

title: Personal Investing
description: A study released recently gives credence to a theory that money management is a loser's game won by cautious concentration on avoiding mistakes rather than by swinging from the heels for some hot growth company whose stock is bound to go from 3 to 30 overnight. Page 27.

title: Fire Perils More California Homes
description: CORONA, Calif., July 29 (UPI)A brush fire that turned the sky a mass of reddish brown swept into this rural town 40 miles southeast of Los Angeles today but was driven off at the doorsteps of a fashionable, 100home development on the town's outskirts.

title: ARTHUR M, WOLFSON, EMANI1EL CANTOR, 65
description: Arthur M. Wolfson the cantor of Congregation EmanuEl, who introduced many innovations in its liturgical music and who assisted in commissioning several musical compositions by contemporary composers, died Tuesday while vacationing in New Zealand. He was 65 years old and lived in Queens.

title: Former Speaker of Missouri House Convicted of Accepting Kickbacks
description: ST. LOUIS, July 29 (An)A Federal District. Court jury has convicted Richard J. Rabbitt, former Speaker of the Missouri House, on all 15 counts of an indictment charging that he accepted kickbacks and peddled his influence from 1967 to 1976.

title: Second Bomb at Coors Center
description: CORIELIA, Calif., July 29 (UPI)A second pipe bomb, possibly planted by the New World Liberation Front, was found near an air compressor at a Coors beer distribution center yesterday and was disarmed by Army specialists. The first bomb was found Wednesday near 1,000gallon butane tank after news media were telephoned by persons saying the bomb had been planted by the liberation group in sympathy with striking Coors emnlovees at Golden. Colo.

title: UNION OIL WITHDRAWS FROM LOOP PROJECT
description: The Union Oil Company of California announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from participation in the proposed Louisiana offshore oil port known as LOOP.

title: SOVIET SUB DEPLOYMENT CALLED ANNUAL EXERCISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)A Soviet deployment of submarines in the Atlantic three months ago was part of an annual exercise dating back several years, the Pentagon said today.

title: Aide Denies Carter Is Abnormally Tired
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)President Carter is no more tired or under greater strain than normal, his spokesman said today. Questioned about New York Times article saying that he looked tired at his news conference yesterday, his deputy press secretary, Rex Granum, quipped, I asked the President about that, and he kind of dozed off.

title: Harlem Dancers Begin TwoWeek Series
description: There had to be a way to get Arthur Mitchell's company on stage in its hometown. After the spring season was canceled because of a serious fiscal problem, things appeared bleak, but on Thursday Dance Theater of Harlem began a twoweek series of performances at Wollman Auditorium on the Columbia University campus.

title: Teller, the Mother of 4, Is Slain As Gunmen Flee With $16,000 on L.I.
description: GREENVALE, LL, July 28A 42yearold bank teller, the mother of four children, was shot to death here this morning during a bank holdup.

title: Dance: City Ballet in Form at Home in Saratoga
description: SARATOGA, N.Y., July 29  It is interesting how many of the world's leading ballet companies have summer homesand equally interesting how different they are. For Britain's Royal Ballet it is an elaborate tent in Londoit's Battersea Park, which is called the Big Top and has the basic facilities of Covent Garden. For the Paris Opera it is an enormous stage constructed in the courtyard of the Louvre, and for New York City Ballet, most sumptuously housed of all, it is the Performing Arts Center here in Saratoga.

title: Iranian Women Return to Veil In a Resurgence of Spirituality
description: TEHERAN, IranMore and more women are seen on the streets of this Middle Eastern capital wearing the chaddour, a long enveloping veil, in what looks like a women's backlash.

title: Sutton Says Looting Was Criminal, Not Racial
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan charged yesterday that the looting and disorders of the July 1314 blackout in New York City had been generally misperceived as racial rather than criminal.

title: INTEGRATION PLANS DENIED IN COLUMBUS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 29A Federal District judge today rejected plans submitted by the city and state boards of education for desegregation of Columbus schools.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two New Jersey communities and three counties are scheduled to receive Federal urban renewal grants totaling $8.44 million. Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, said yesterday that the largest grant would go to Monmouth County, which is to get $3.71 million for rehabilitation of housing and public facilities.

title: Personal Investing
description: Is money management a loser's game that is won by cautiously concentrating first on avoiding mistakes rather than by swinging from the heels for some hot growth company whose stock is bound to go from 3 to 30 overnight?

title: Antigone,
description: MUNICHFor most American musiclovers, Carl Orff is known as the composer of Carmina Burana, that jolly neoMedieval suite that has appeared on the programs of symphony orchestras and opera and ballet companies.

title: Stub, at $17.40, Captures Sorority
description: OCEANPORT. N.J., July 30One dance doesn't decide the belle of the ball, but a filly with the ungraceful name of Stub took a step in the right direction today at Monmouth Park.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Before me reposes the third edition (1977) of the ASCAP Symphonic Catalogwell over 500 large pages, with some 26,000 listings of symphonic, chamber (10 instruments or more) and choral works, the product of over 900 publishers. It is fascinating document, at once a monument to enterprise and alsn, in an unfortunate way, to futility. So much music is being composed. So little of it has a chance of being performed.

title: Intendedly Inauthentic
description: THE Austrian, Peter Handke, who writes poetry, novels, plays and memoirs, is concerned with a familiar subject  the loss of authenticity or innocence. For Handke, this loss characterizes modern life. He thinks we no longer

title: LETTERS
description: It would be hard to beat Joseph Lelyveld (In America column on The New Sexual Revolution, July 3) for a simplistic analysis of teenage pregnancy, but blaming mother for social problems does have a long history in American journalism. If mother were not working or playing tennis, presumably, the young people could not have sexual intercourse. One might also blame car manufacturers for putting back seats in their vehicles, or parks departments for planting bushes. A more likely set of targets, however, would be those who have sexualized the selling of everything from toothpaste to dog food and no mention at all by Lelyveld  the young males whose need to score is apparently con

title: THE AMERICAN MONOMYTH.
description: This study of our popular entertainment produces a claim for an American monomytha pervasive theme which involves an Edenlike society helpless in the face of evil but rescued by an outsider, a superhero, who then disappears again.

title: Davies Leads Mostly Mozart
description: By juxtaposing Johann Christian Bach's Sinfonia in G minor (Op. 6, No. 6) and Mozart's C minor Piano Concerto (K. 491), the opening half of the Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall Friday night struck a decidedly somber note. There were sound musicololgical reasons for this pairing, though, and the conductor of the evening, Dennis Russell Davies, made the most of them.

title: Apples Defeat Strings, 2918
description: UNIONDALE, LI., July 30Sandy Mayer led the New York Apples to a 2918 World Team Tennis victory over the Los Angeles Strings tonight with a commanding performance after intermission. He defeated Me Nastase, 62, and then teamed with Ray Ruffels to beat Nastase and Charles Pasarell by the same score in the closing doubles event

description: Interruption of service on New York City subways and commuter rail lines during the blackout cost the Metropolitan Transportation Authority 59,308,000, Harold L. Fisher, the authority chairman, has announced.

The premiere at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, earlier this month of his fourthand, he says, lastopera, The Ice Break, aroused enormous interest here.

description: Penelope Hunter Orr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hunter Orr of Lewes, Del., was married there yesterday in St. Peter's Episcopal Church to Robert Harold Hawkes, son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter H. R. Hawkes of Southington, Conn. The Rev. Frank Moon performed the ceremony.

title: Giving Up
description: After Panamanian agitation since 1914 and direct United StatesPanamanian negotiations for the last 13 years, a new treaty covering the status of the Panama Canal now is in sightso much so that President Carter intervened last week to cheer on the negotiations.

description: Alice M. Hormel and Herman Hormel Jr., both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Lawrence Hormel, to Dr. Hamilton Moses 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Jr of Winnetka, Ill.

title: Despite the Criticism, Carter Has Done a Lot for New York
description: That the New York City power failure would open up a new phase of local political debate became clear even before the lights were turned back on. But in the last two weeks, the blackout has also reopened another political debate: the battle between New York City and Washington over Federal aid to urban areas.

description: 205 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $7.95.

title: Dollar Wise, Oil Foolish
description: The astronomical June trade deficit announced last week is a worrisome preview of the financial problems that lie ahead for the nation as it consumes increasing amounts of imported oil. Some of the record $2.8 billion trade gap can be blamed on the failure of West Germany and Japan to spur their economies and thus absorb more of our exports. But the major reason for the whopping deficit is our whopping appetite for imported pil.

title: Realty News
description: The Sogen Swiss International Corporation has subleased the entire 10th floor, comprising about 32,000 square feet of office space, at 245 Park Avenue from the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company.

title: EDWARD J. BROWN
description: Edward J. Brown, a former executive vice president of Gimbel Brothers Inc., died Friday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 70 years old.

title: STUDY OF TAKEOVER OF CON ED IS URGED
description: Charging that the Consolidated Edison Company was essentially unaccountable to the public, Bella S. Abzug yesterday called for a New York Cityfinanced study of the costs and benefits of nublic takeover of the utility.

title: Freezer Pleasers
description: There can be nothing  in a gustatory sense  that gives as much solace and cheer to the palate and soul as a frozen dessert. And there's nothing in that category to equal the things that can come from a home icecream maker. Two celebrated categories of frozen desserts are ice creams and granites. Ice creams as the name implies. are made with cream (with milk they're known as iced milk). Granites. which are to some palates the ultimate frozen dessert. are made with pure fruits or fruit juices plus water and sugar. Unlike sherbets they do not contain egg white or meringue.

title: Scrutiny by Government and Corporate Boards May Be the Answer
description: Niculae Asciu

title: The Poets Explain
description: SOME hundred American poets found a questionnaire in the mailwould they pick a current poem and tell how it happened? Fifty came through; the ones who declined might have reflected that Milton, testy Milton, filled out a kind of questionnaire in 1674. Browsers were having trou

title: Onethird of Nassau Pregnancies End in Abortion
description: MINEOLA LI., July 30One of every three pregnancies in Nassau County was terminated in elective: abortionin 1975, the County Planning.Commission said in 2, population report released this week.

title: Italy's Communists Practicing Power
description: Although the recent Soviet denunciation of errant Western Communists was nominally aimed at the Communist Party of Spain, the polemics may have had more immediate political importance for the Communists of Italy and France. Where the Spanish party, newly legalized, won less than 10 percent of the vote, in Spain's parliamentary elections in June, the Italian Communists already have an important role in government policy and the French Communists in alliance with the Socialists, are given a good chance of winning national elections next spring. Jean Kanapa, the French party's chief theoretician, and Giacario Pajetta. head of the Italian party's commission on foreign affairs, discussed Communist theory, internal politics. European unity and EastWest relations in interviews with correspondents of The New York Times last week. Paul Lewis interviewed Mr. Kanapa and Ina Lee Selden talked with Mr. Pajetta.

title: TV VIEW
description: The HolocaustHitler's, not Stalin's or any of the other mass atrocities that dot 20thcentury history is being given still another television examination this week in the form of four hourlong programs called The World at War: The Final Solution. Written and produced by Michael Darlow for Britain's Thames Television, the programs will be carried on WORChannel 9 at 11 P.M. beginning tomorrow evening and running through Thursday. Why should we, one again, be forced to confront the horror? Indeed, the Holocaust is experiencing a pronounced revival of interest in book publishing. is also slated to be the subject of an American television miniseries this fall. Perhaps the sheer enormity of the barbarism will always be mesmerizing. Or, perhaps, with the passing time, the Holocaust has become just another historical event, on a level with the sacking of Rome or the Crusades. Distancing objectivity can be brought to bear on man's inhumanity man.

description: Theater

title: Karen Leahy Bride Of George Rathman
description: St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Karen Leahy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Edward Leahy of Darien, to George Henry Rathman, son of Mrs. Theodore S. Rathman of Los Angeles and the late Dr. Rathman.

title: Jets Open Preseason With a Loss
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 30The New York Jets finally made it to a Hall of Fame Game today, and discovered that they were not quite ready for election.

description: When the builder of the 150unit UPACA Terrace. apartments at 118th Street and Lexington Avenue visited them recently, lie was the focus of a Hi, Charlie: chorus from residents, staff and neighbors.

Kip Rosenthal to Teach, At Ox Ridge Hunt Club

description: Little and Big

title: Editors
description: AMEN, by Yehuda Anlichai. Translated by the author and Ted Hughes. (Harper & Row. Cloth, $7.95. Paper, $4.95.) Poems by Israel's bestknown living poet on war, death, sensuality, love; a harshly lovely, exhilarating, saddening book.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Many amateur photographers are so conditioned to shooting in color that they almost completely ignore the potentials of serious blackandwhite photography. While is true that the photographer must work harder to translate some subjects in blackandwhite because color seems more realistic (we don't see in monochrome), blackandwhite still offers number of unique benefits for selfexpression and experimentation. In fact, several of today's great photographers are known only for their blackandwhite imagesAnsel Adams and W. Eugene Smith, for example.

title: Redman's Promising Year Now One of Recuperation
description: This was the year Brian Redman was going to go straight to the top in United States motor racing. He already was there in Europe, where he had been regarded as one of sports car racing's premiere endurance drivers since the late 1960's.

title: Engineer to Marry Susan J. Surette
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Federhen Surette of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jeaninne Surette, to Robert Le Roy Honstein, son of Mr. and .Mrs. Le Roy Henry Honstein of Espanola, N.M.

title: N.Y. Juniors in Soviet Series
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 30 (UPI)The New York Riverside Hawks will represent the United States in a sixgame junior basketball series with the Soviet Union, starting Tuesday, the Amateur Athletic Union said. All six games will be played in the Soviet Union through Aug. 14.

title: MANDEL UNDERGOES INTENSE QUESTIONING
description: BALTIMORE, July 29Gov. Marvin Mandel has completed six days of testimony in his own defense on Federal corruption charges, days marked by denial after denial of wrongdoing.

title: CONSTRUCTION FOREMAN SLAIN NEAR 7TH AVE. SITE
description: The foreman of a construction crew was shot to death yesterday in front of a building project on Seventh Avenue near 14th Street by a man who the police believe had been dismissed as an employee earlier in the day.

title: Saien Nazi Supporters Arrested Near Chicago Demonstration Site
description: CHICAGO, July 30 (AP)Seven Nazi party members and sympathizers were arrested today after authorities found rocks and bottles on the roof of their twostory headquarters near the scene of anantiblack demonstration.

title: Daniel Maloney Offers Imaginative Dances
description: Daniel Maloney's freely roaming imagination constructs dances that have the vigor of real situations and the look of dreams. He is not constrained to explain why exactly two men costumed like witch doctors occupy one portion of the stage while nurse in operatingroom green assists a doctor in preparing for an operation at another. Mr. Maloney dumps the fact of his dances into the laps of his viewers and lets things take their own course. He presented his program Friday evening at the American Theater Laboratory.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GATESHEAD, England, July 30 (AP)Clancy Edwards, an American sprinter, completed another double in the international track and field meet at Gateshead today, winning the 200 meters in 20.9 seconds and the 100 meters in 10.4 seconds. He achieved a similar double at the British Amateur Athletic Association championships at Crystal Palace in London last weekend.

title: James R. Jones, a Producer Of Radio Programs for Blind
description: James R. Jones, who went blind eight years ago and then began producing radio programs for blind people, died yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 39 years old.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Bow SeaRun Trout
description: ST. PETERS HARBOR, Prince Edward IslandA few miles south of St. Peters Harbor, where the surf of the Gulf of beach Lawrence pounds on miles of empty and where sea birds wheel and cry overhead, there are broad meadows along the course of the Morell River, and wild strawberries mat the ground under the tall grass.

title: GERMAN BANKER KILLED; ANARCHISTS SUSPECTED
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 30 (AP)Jiirgen Ponto, head of West Germany's second largest bank, was fatally wounded Saturday by two women and a man who entered his suburban villa, the police said.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Ox Ridge, Ox Ridge Hunt Club, Middlesex Road, Darien, Conn. Local and junior working hunters, pleasure horses, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

description: In Summary

title: Joyce Sharon Strauss Fiancee of Robert Jonap
description: Joyce Sharon Strauss, a media buyer with Gaynor & Ducas Advertising, Inc., and Robert Paul Jonap, product manager at Savarin Coffee Company in Palisades Park, N. J., will be married next October.

title: Home and Apartment Dweller's Guide to Locks
description: Although there may be some Utopian community where people can still feel secure without locking doors, in most areas residents recognize the need for equipping entrance and exit doors with at least one good quality lock. Even the best locks and other security arrangements will not be enough to stop a truly determined professional burglar, but a good door lock will go a long way toward preventing a breakin in the vast majority of cases.

title: Rise in Tuition Charges Angers Philippine Students
description: MANILA, July 30  The protesting youths started as a small cluster on the front campus of the University of Santo Tomas in downtown Manila. As they marched, shouting to other students to join in if they had the courage the cluster swelled into a taunting, doorbanging crowd.

title: THE GOAT, THE WOLF, AND THE CRAB
description: Equally hard to sympathize with, though for different reasons, is Gillian Martin's The Goat, the Wolf, and the Crab, in which is middleaged English housewife chooses to die of cancer rather than submit to surgery. The problem here is not the style, which seems blessedly understated after William Lavender's, but the plot.

title: NO RELIEF
description: 128 pp. Ann Arbor, Mich.: Street Fiction Press. Paper, $4.95.

title: Mr. Cuomo, to End the Tribalism
description: The worst thing about the primary campaign for Mayor so far is that it so well reflects the state of New York City: a broken and fragmented society. Separate ethnic, economic and ideological constituencies are vying for the City Hall throne like so many feudal baronies. The present Mayor runs for his own party's nomination the candidate of the clubhouses, of labor and real estate barons. He is challenged by a candidate from the black community and a candidate from the Puerto Rican community, by the businessman's candidate and the white ethnic candidate, by an oldleft, feminist candidate (Manhattan West) and by an oldline liberal candidate (Manhattan East).

title: Christine A. Rising Is Married
description: Christine Anne Rising, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Rising Jr. of Glen Head, L.I., was married yesterday morning to Preston John Turner, son of Ethel Persons Turner of Williston, Vt., and the late John M. Turner. The Rev. Thomas J. Phillipp, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Risings summer home in Brightwaters, L.I.

title: Tips Raise Bar Dancer's Income
description: Most of the dancers who appear in the topless and bottomless bars in the New York metropolitan area are hired and supplied by talent agencies that recruit through newspaper advertisements or through referrals.

title: Earnings Climb While Stocks SagG.M. Joins $1 Billion Club
description: Paradoxically, as the stock market has tumbled this year, corporate profits have climbed, in an inverse relationship that has market analysts tearing their hair. The perverse trend was highlighted last week when the Dow Jones industrial average took a nosedive just as most companies were reporting income gains that would warm the heart of any stockholder.

title: Anne R. Jarvis Becomes Bride
description: Anne Reid Jarvis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Arthur Jarvis of Lancaster, Pa., was married there yesterday afternoon to John Christopher Gerbner, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Gerbner of Ardmore, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Donald C. Wilson performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Monzon Outpoints Valdes in 15
description: MONTE CARLO, July 30Going out champion, Carlos Monzon of Argentina retained his world middleweight boxing title here tonight by scoring unanimous decision over Rodrigo Valdes in 15 rounds.

title: Amy Hutchinson Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Hutchinson of Syosset, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Tabnage Hutchinson, to David Ken Noji, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas T. Noji of Melville, L. I.

title: CHALLENGING MEDIA MONOPOLIES
description: By 1975, the Steinman family had gained a dominant hold over the news media in Lancaster, Pa. Through the years, their holdings had grown to include the morning, evening and Sunday newspapers  the only three in Lancaster television station WGAL, radio stations WGALAM and FM and 60 percent of the city's cable television network. The Steinmans, clearly, had gained extensive power over the Lancaster community's understanding of itself and the outside world, but for many years, nobody seemed to care.

title: Stars in Caribbean Track
description: MEXICO CITY, July 30 (UPI)The top athletes from Central America and the Caribbean, including some Olympic gold medalists, will participate in the sixth Central America and Caribbean track and field championships next Friday through Sunday in Jalapa. Veracruz. The athletes include Alberto Juantorena and Silvio Leonard of Cuba. Don Quarrie of Jamaica and Daniel Bautista of Mexico.

title: New York Is Denied DisasterStatus Aid
description: The Carter Administralion confirmed last night that a final determination had been made to withhold disasterarea status from New York City for losses suffered from looting during the blackout of July 1314.

title: Meg and Hannah and Elaine
description: MODERN marriage is a strange beast, if you judge it by these three books. The wives endure, gritting their teeth; the husbands either bury their bitterness In work or throw shattering tantrums; and the children, if there tare any, are shunted to one side, where They tend to lurk in various doorways.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: THIS journal note of mine, dated Black Mountain College, August 1952, records what is said to be America's first Happening, that medley of randomness and sheer chutzpa which became a password of the 1960's. 1 turn back to it out of a need to pay tribute to Black Mountain, one of the most visionary communities of the century, and also out of impatience with those writers presently celebrating the 1960's legacy of rebellion and innovation as if it had no historic roots in previous epochs.

title: Through Cancer and Pregnancy She Kept Faithand a Journal
description: PORTLAND, Ore.Laurel Lee has Just been through what her Bible calls the Fire and Brimstone. She has faced cancer, death, birth, poverty, hospitals, abandonment and divorce in less than a year. She went to the fourth and final stage of Hodgkin's disease, but then she didn't die as she was supposes to. All along the way everyone expected her to falter, but she never did. What she did do was respond with patience, cheer and a homey philosophy of love and faith in Jesus.

title: Subvert and Conserve
description: WE need people like Edward Abbey, who is a combination of Thoreau and Marion the Swamp Fox. He is not merely spokesman for nature lovers, he is a guerrilla fighter in what may be the last great American conflict. the one over land use. I shout Right On! to much

title: James Baldwin Back Home
description: JAMES BALDWIN will turn 53 on Aug. 2. He was born and grew up in Harlem.,He left this country when he was 24 for France, where he has, mostly, lived ever since. This summer he returned to New York City, but not on yet another brief visitthe expatriate cEpping into the forsaken land for draught of outrage I disgust. He is coming home to live, and glad to be back. But if one presses him a bit on the virtues of this country, he is quick to spell out his particular point of view: I left America because I bad to. It was a personal decision. I wanted to write; and it was the 1940's, and it was no big picnic for blacks. I grew up on the streets of Harlem, and I remember President Roosevelt, the liberal, having a lot of trouble with an antilynching bill he wanted to get through the Congressnever mind the vote, never mind restaurants, never mind schools, never mind a fair employment policy. I had to leave; I needed to be in a place where I could breathe and not feel someone's hand on my throat A lot of young Americans, white or black, rich or poor, have wanted to get away, as a means of getting closer to themselves. For me France was the beginning of a writing life; I wrote Go Tell It on the Mountain there. It was there I began the struggle

title: Deaths
description: COOPERRalph D., on July 29, 1977. Be!dyed brother of Leo M., Lucy F. Cooper and George V. Services Private.

title: IslamJewishChristian  Magazine on Mideast Falters
description: BOSTON, JULY 30A cooperative endeavor of Moslem Arab, Jewish and Christian students at Boston University to publish a magazine focusing on the Middle East conflict has provoked COrAtroversy and resignations.

title: Elizabeth H. Keyser Wed to John Evans
description: Elizabeth Hambleton Keyser, daughter of Mrs. William Adamson Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and the late R. Brent Keyser of Garrison, Md., was married last evening to John Custis Evans, son of Lucius W. Evans of Lincoln and Marion, Mass., and the late Virginia Everett Evans.

title: Roy Wilkins Retires
description: The passage of Roy Wilkins from active participation in the political life of this nation is more than the end of one man's career. His handing of the reins of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored Peopleto Benjamin Hooksmarks the end of an era. Mr. Wilkins is the last of a generation of civil rights leaders whose work began when American society was still rigidly segregated by law and lynching was a regular occurrence in our national life.

title: Though It Is Inherently Full of Evil, Goodness Can Be Added For a Price
description: WASHINGTONLike an alchemist's potion, a lump of coal can be cooked, coked, boiled, and broiled, slaked and baked and transmuted into thousands of astonishmentsfrom aspirin to TNT, plastics to pesticides, wood alcohol to oil of wintergreen. Out of desperate necessity, Nazi Germany figured out how to run its air force on highoctane gasoline that German scientists pioneered in coaxing from coal. The Republic of South Africa is doing that again, now, with better results. Ersatz champagne from coal may not be unthinkable. Coal is already in perfume.

title: Jan, Pat O'Malley Put In Plug for Women's Sailing
description: Jan and Pat O'Malley are sistersinlaw. Pat, 39 years old, is a social worker. Jan, 31, is the mother of two children. They're also a teamthe best women sailors in the world after topping a 25boat fleet from 19 countries

title: Article 2  No Title
description: See a great show, have a great dinner

title: THE BATTLE OVER THE MIGHTY COLORADO
description: That's how Maj. John Wesley Powell, who in 1869 was the first white man to explore the unknown Colorado River, described it only a century ago. Today, he would hardly recognize it. Last winter, a fraction of the normal snow fell on the Rocky Mountains, and by June many of the million cascade brooks were already dry. But even had the usual snow fallen, the mighty Colorado has not been a mad turbid stream for many years.

title: Jackson H.S. Integration Case Is Just One Example of a National Issue
description: In Cambria Heights, Queens, the streets around Andrew Jackson High School run in straight, wellordered grids. They bear numbers, not names. The school and these streets are in the city. Just a mile to the east, on the other side of the Cross Island Parkway, the streets wind gracefully. They have leafy names like Fairmount and Spring Garden and Birchwood, and become, not just streets and avenues, but Terraces, Places, Drives and Courts. They are in the suburbs.

title: THE MARKETS
description: It seemed the worst of all worlds last week for the stock market. Bethlehem Steel cut its dividend in half. The Federal Reserve apparently tightened its monetary policy. The nation showed a record trade deficit for June. Giant corporations reported disappointing profits.

title: Small Goods in Small Packages
description: BLOOD RELATIONS

title: G.I.'s LEAVING GERMANY RINGING UP PHONE DEBTS
description: BONN, July 30 (AP)American soldiers transferred from West Germany last year left behind S1.1 million in unpaid telephone bills, the national post office reports.

title: Atlantic Travel: New Rules, Low Fares
description: A new bilateral agreement between the United States and Britain, establishing new rules of the road for scheduled airline service between the two nations, was initialed by British and American authorities in Bermuda last weekend.

title: HANGING ON
description: Hila Colman is a prolific writer of children's books. Her husband Louis  Limey to everyone  was a medical writer until a stroke forced him into retirement Then,

title: How the New Theatrical Directors Are Upstaging the Playwright
description: Shortly before his recent resignation, Joseph Papp announced plans for a thoroughgoing renovation of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center. The Beaumont would be remodeled, Papp said, with a view to making it a directors showcase, while the Public Theater, Papp's other fief, would remain primarily a place for writers. This is a curious separation, but behind it is a large cultural ideaPapp's wish to create a bridge between the avantgarde theater and the conventional one. At the center of this ambition, not unknown in modern theatrical history, was his intention of presenting perennial works in ways that would shatter conventionclassics treated by modern minds.

title: Beanie Riding Publicity Wave Since Blackout
description: Momentum is usually as importirit in political campaigns as it is in sports, and, at the moment, Mayor Beame clearly has captured the momentum in the race for the Democratic nomination. But whether that momentum is trans

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: FOR those who believe that the performance the various financial markets conveys an insight into what actually is going on in the real world of business activity, monetary developments, political affairs and international relations, there appeared to be considerable cause for concern last week. The markets seemed to be saying that too many things were going wrong at the moment and that too much uncertainty has clouded the outlook.

title: Stephanie Hamilton Fiancee of Robert Moore
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Watrous Hamilton Jr. of Hadlyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Anne Hamilton, to Robert Scott Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Moore Jr. of Riverside, Conn.

title: The Battle Of the Blenders
description: BAGNOLET, FranceJean Mantelet, the 77yearold founder and president of Moulinex, the big French company that makes food preparation equipment, views women's liberation with an indulgent eye. I've been liberating them since 1932, he says proudly. That was the year he introduced his company's first product: a handoperated vegetable mill, or moulin, which gave the company its name.

title: Family Says the F.B.I. To Hunt for Daughter
description: The mother and stepfather of Ellen Hover, the 23yearold woman missing since June 15now suspected of being kidnappedfrom her Third Avenue apartment said yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had agreed to assist in locating their daughter.

title: TV Producers Are Nibbling at the Big Apple
description: When did New York City cease to be the center of the universe? When California passed New York State in population? When the St. Lawrence Seaway opened, enabling ships to bypass the Port of New York?

title: JOHN BAKER ROSEBROOK
description: John Baker Rosebrook, a former vice president and manager of the copy department at Young & Rubicam International Inc., the advertising agency, died yesterday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 79 years old.

title: Still in Its Shadow
description: SURREALISM was a manifestation in literature, art and cultural events of the unachieved revolution of the 20th century. Most likely, it was the most comprehensive statement of that revolution, for it sought not only the economic and political transformation of society but with equal, if not greater emphasis, the inner transformation of individual human beings.

title: Madagascar Shaken As Meteorite Strikes
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, July 30 (ReuterstA meteorite plunged earth in Madagascar today, causing a crater 240 yards across, Madagascar Radio reported. The impact was fe:t over a 250mile radius of the capital.

title: Soviet in Stern Attack On U.S. Neutron Bomb
description: MOSCOW, July 30 (Reuters)The Soviet Union issued its sternest warning yet to President Carter today about the projected development of the neutron bomb, condemning Washington's arguments in favor of the weapon as inconsistent and dangerous.

title: SAMUEL SPITZBART,69, FORMER BANK EXECUTIVE
description: Samuel Spitzbart, former senior vice president in charge of the mortgage department of the Security National Bank of Long Island, died early yesterday of a heart attack in Greenport, L.L, white on a business trip. He was. 69 years old and lived at 1042 East 23d Street, Brooklyn.

title: Patience of Dobson May Be the Key To Turner's Success at Cup Trials
description: NEWPORT, R. L, July 30Gary Jobson, a 27yearold teacher of sailing from Toms River, N.J.. has the stickiest job of all among the 77 sailors competing for the America's Cup here this summer. Jobson's title ts tactician aboard Courageous, but there is more to it than that. He also serves as guru, as shrink, as confidant and nursemaid for Ted Turner, the volatile skipper of Courageous whose moods range from infectious enthusiasm to infectious gloom.

title: Insect Ravages Called Worst in 2 Decades
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 30 (AP)The forests of the Northern United States are suffering their worst infestation of leafchewing caterpillars in more than 20 years, scientists say.

description: LONDON, July 30The gilded dome of a new mosque gleams over the familiar Nash buildings in Regents Park. Set back a few yards from the busy Outer Road of the Park, it has already become a landmark in one of London's most favored residential areas.

title: A's Lose as White, Tackson Connect
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 30The Yankees, who have spent the entire season clearing the air, saw some more smog creep into their lives today even as they watched themselves maintain one of their more positive playing periods of the season.

title: Lance Probe Closed Quickly and Gently, but it Raised New Issues
description: WASHINGTONThe controversy over Bert Lance's finances subsided, at least for the moment, when the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee concluded last week that he hadn't compromised his trust as Budget Director, and apologized for any inconvenience or embarrassment it had caused him, It had been the first challenge to the integrity of an official of the Carter Administration, and the committee not only decided that it didn't warrant a serious investigation but also that, as Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, put it, Mr. Lance had been smeared by the Press.

title: Extension at Columbia, A Case for Building Down
description: A newcomer's confusion with a sprawling campus is usually eased as he grows accustomed to guidepostsmainly other buildings. If that's Fayerweather Hall, this must be Avery, he learns. But should he meander through the new extension to the Graduate School of Architecture and Planning at Columbia University after it opens this fall, he may find himself repeatedly asking the question, Where am I now?

title: Crews Encircling California Fire
description: CORONA, Calif., July 30 (UPI)A force of 1,500 firefighters had almost halfcAntained a 3,000acre brush blaze in the Cleveland National Forest today. They were optimistic of Completely ringing the fire by tomorrow morning, sparing this town from a third onslaught.

title: Somalia Reports Gains By Rebels in Ethiopia
description: MOGADISHU. Somalia, July 30 (Reuters)Three rebelheld towns in southwestern Ethiopia have resumed normal life under the control of the guerrillas of the Western Somali Liberation Front, Somalia's press agency reported today.

description: This first novel by it writer in her mid30's has already enjoyed a considerable success in France. It looks back from the present to the France of World War II, seeks out and reinvents the life and times of Albert B., a successful chemical engineer who at the age of 30.

description: Frances Jo Hudgins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hudgins of Richmond, was married there yesterday to William John Pender, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Pender of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. David M. Canada performed the ceremony in the Highland  Springs United Methodist Church.

title: Oil Companies Filing Tariff Reductions
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)Oil companies followed the lead of the Atlantic Richfield Company and began filing reduced tariffs with the Interstate Commerce Commisson today in preparation for transporting the first shiploads of oil pumped through the Alaska pipeline.

title: Women and Their Future in Sports: More Muscles, More Contact Games

title: Vladimir Nabokov, 18991977
description: NABOKOV would be flabbergasted by the information that he was loved as a person. Whatever sins could he have committed to deserve such unjust affection? A declaration of feeling should. one be rude enoughwould cause those deep Russian rumblings of laughter to gather in all his caverns and to come rolling out with desperate chortlings and running tears and final dabs with handkerchief. Love, love, love, you say? Poshlost: Such avowals belonged for him in the realm of poshlost, a word he defined for me as covering the spectrum of feeling from the airline ad in which a young couple eye ecstatically the cucumber canape (he admiring wistfully the hostess) to Death in Venice. You see the range, he added.

title: Steel Industry Shows Its Weaknesses

title: Managers Remember

title: CARTER CHIDES PUBLIC FOR WASTING ENERGY; HINTS STERNER STEPS
description: WASHINGTON. July 30  President Carter says the American public is not paying attention to energy problems and has not heeded his calls for voluntary conservation.

title: People of the Word
description: THE YEMENITE GIRL is a book of small virtues: grace, proportion, light irony. All, paradoxically, encased in the passionate story of an obsessed, middleaged, secondrate litterateur; a kind of J. Alfred Prufrock of the Jewish/Hebrew literary world.

title: Chilean Gains Semifinals With Vilas, Dibbs and Dent
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. July 30 (AP)Hans Gildemeister, the unseeded sensation from Chile, joined today the first Ulm seeded players, Guillermo Vilas, and Eddie Dibbs, and the seventhseeded player, Phil Dent, in the semifinals of the $125,000 Louisville international tennis tournament.

title: But the Impact of a National Grain Reserve on Farmers as Well as Consumers Is Far From Certain
description: WASHINGTONDuring the recent farm bill debate in the House of Representatives, the proposal for a national grain reserve was hailed by its proponents as a timely new idea, and they were partly right. The idea of the Government, in some manner, storing wheat and corn in years of plenty and releasing them in years of scarcity is certainly not new. Some members of Congress have been trying for ten years to get a reserve bill through Congress.

title: Vanivard of Hong Kong Leads in Channel Race
description: COWES, England, July 30 (UPI)The Hong Kong boat Vanguard. skippered by David Lieu, was leading the Admiral's Cup Channel Race fleet on corrected times after rounding the Brighton Fairway buoy today and heading on the final leg to the finish at Port Gilkicker, near Portsmouth.

title: J. S. Ridley Jr., Bettina Hyland Are Married

The Rev. Rollin J. Fairbanks performed the ceremony.

title: F.B.I. Seizes 5 in Piracy Of 8Track Recording

title: DANCE VIEW
description: National tastes are nothing newthe French, with one of those sniffs generally termed barely perceptible, perhaps because they are anything but, used to refer disparagingly to le gout Anglais, and probably even the Greeks had a word for it when they were referring to the Trojans. But in dance, in recent years, there seems to have developed new continental tastes, with Europe arrayed on one side, and the United States, from its vantage point across the Atlantic, drawn up on the other.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Anne Edwards
description: There aren't many writers who can say they've been to bed with Rhett Butler, Judy Garland and Vivien Leigh. And Anne Edwards is planning an extended affair with Countess Tolstoy next. But it's all in the cause of literature, for Miss Edwards is the latest in a line of authors who, like Edith Wharton, prefer to write under the counterpane. It's very eine. +n you, that way.

title: IN AMERICA
description: MOOREFI ELD, W.Va. Obert Byrd has never faced a serious opponent in four races for the Senate and probably never will. When his present term ends in five and a half years, he'll presumably have been majority leader through three sessions of Congress: an established national figure, unassailable by any reckoning. So why, when he could be spending a short recess at home, is he on his second trip to his state in two days, orating and playing his fiddle before small assemblages that could easily have been placated with polite regrets? Why, specifically, on this muggy afternoon is he sitting on the back of small Fiat convertible, on a pillow covered in imitation leopard skin, as this obscure hamlet marks its bicentennial with a parade?

title: Rucker League Thrives After Return to Outside
description: After four years of playing indoors at City College and Brandeis high School. the Harlem Professionals Inc. (Rucker Pro) Summer Basketball League moved the tournament back outside onto the concrete. That means you won't find as many of the National Basketball Association pros playing this year. The risk of injury is too great and the price of a pro career has climbed too high into six figures to chance it.

If he'd come along a bit later, he might be among the prosperous fantasy artists whose work fascinates millions of young people today.

description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)Commerce Secretary Juanita M. Kreps favors deferring mandatory retirement to age 68 and withholding full Social Security benefits until Americans reach that age, her chief spokesman said today.

description: The scientific bias of new music emanating from the SoHo avantgardea bias that was already beginning to reveal itself during the early 1960'shas been becoming more and more overt in the works of younger composers. The music of Philip Glass, Steve Reich and other composers of their generation is scientific in a sense, since it is more concerned with the orderly elaboration of rhythmic and structural relationships than with spontaneity or the direct expression of emotion.

title: Nationalism Flavors French Communism
description: PARISThe French Communist Party headquarters, set in Paris's suitably proletarian 10th Arrondissement, looks as if it is expecting a nuclear attack. The newish office building is screened off from the street by a high wooden fence, plastered with party posters. The only entrance is through a guarded back gate, down narrow concrete steps into a bare underground chamber that resembles an airraid shelter. But this oppressive atmosphere vanishes on the building's upper floors, where the party leaders work in sunny, if austerely furnished, offices. And a talk with Jean Kanapa, the party's leading theoretician, is a similarly relaxed experience. For the French Communist Party, long thought of as the most rigidly orthodox and proSoviet in Western Europe, is now anxious to show itself as a moderate, democratic, libertyloving adherent of Eurocommunism.

title: Norway Accused of Recruiting Finns to Spy on Soviet in 1950's
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 30 (Reuters)According to the director of Finland's intelligence service, Norway recruited Finns to spy across their country's sensitive border with the Soviet Union in the early 1950's. Arvo Pentti, the security chief, disclosed last night that three Finnish citizens had been convicted for their roles, two as recently as 1970.

title: Technology
description: LIVERMORE, Calif.Several times yearly, a curious request leaves a Federal office complex in Germantown, Md. There are only two copies of the request: One arrives at this town in Northern California, the other in Los Alamos, N.M. And with their arrival, an unusual technological footrace beginsa race to develop nuclear weapons.

description: There are two major league baseball clubs in Chicago. The one on the North Side, the Cubs, has been getting most of the attention, probably because it started the season composed mostly of nobodies and it has been leading the National League East most of the campaign.

description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 30 (UPI)Miners at a closed meeting in Beckley have voted to ask for the resignation of the United Mine Workers president, Arnold R. Miller, and other top union leaders.

description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Francis Kelly of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Marie Frances Kelly, to Gordon MacKay Burns, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Lincoln Burns, also of Rye. An October wedding is planned.

description: On a mellow autumn afternoon in October 1917, he faced John McGraw's National League champions, the New York Giants, with their World Series lineup intact. For 10 innings he showed them smoke, striking out 20 Giants. No one got a hit.

description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30A Croatian Communist official disclosed today that there are 201 persons serving; prison terms for political offenses in Croatia.

title: Who Makes Nuclear Weapons, and Where
description: America's nuclear weapons design and production organization consists of more than 30,000 people working in nine states. It is part of the Energy Research and Development Administration, which absorbed the old Atomic Energy Commission in 1974.

title: Genetics
description: One of the tragedies of modern science was the destruction of Soviet genetics during the 1930's and 1940's, in effect by government decree. It was decided by the leaders of the Communist Party that Trofim D. Lysenko was right and that classical Russian geneticists were reactionary and disloyal. Nikolai I. Vavilov, widely recognized as one of the world's leading plant geneticists, and many others were exiled. Vavilov apparently died in the labor camp at Magadan on the Sea of Okhotsk. Lysenko's ideas were applied to agriculture, resulting in near disaster.

description: Thousands of City University students owe the university $11.5 million in unpaid tuition for the 197677 academic year, and the university does not know how much of this money it will eventuallv collect.

title: The Annual Bill Is Only a Matter of $40 Billion
description: PARISThe weakening United States dollar Is both the symbol and the symptom of a fundamental economic malaise facing the Western world today and which it does not yet know how to remedy. The difficulty is to decide which countries should find the roughly $40 billion in surplus income that the richest members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are collecting each year. At present, a disproportionate amount of this bill, which economists call the World Oil Deficit, is being shouldered by the United States and a group of economically weaker countries.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: AFTER her book Pilgrim at Tinker Creek brought her renown and a Pulitzer Prize in 1975, Annie Dillard could have done a lot of things newly famous authors do, such as take to the lecture circuit or do readings or write Son of Pilgrim at Tinker Creek. instead, she wanted mountains, with a college nearby to teach at, so she got out atlases and made triangulations and came up with the island she now lives on near Puget Sound and Western Washington State College.

title: Consulate in Turkey Is Bombed
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 30 (AP)A bomb exploded in the backyard of the American consulate in the southeastern Turkish city of Adana last night, shattering windows but causing no injuries, officials said. They said an unexploded bomb was found today in the garden of the consulate in Adana, which is 240 miles southeast of the Turkish capital of Anka1 ra. The bomb was disarmed without incident.

title: Teamsters Fund Paid Legal Fees Of 3 in Fraud Case, Report Says
description: CHICAGO, July 30 (UPI)The teameters unibn Central States pension fund pent more than $500,000 to defend three of its former officials charged with conispiring to defraud the fund, according to a report filed with the Labor Department.

title: The Center Held
description: George Plimpton writes well about sports, but so do many others. What sets him apart is his In

title: H. J. Hutchison, Lawyer, Marries Nancy Crosby
description: Nancy Porter Crosby, daughter of Helen Rees Crosby of Riverdale, the Bronx,. and Laurence Eugene Crosby of Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Hugh Joseph Hutchison. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Nelson Hutchison of Stratford, Cann.. and Winchester. N.H.

title: Yacht Australia Wins
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 30Australia beat Gretel II and won the Covernor of Rhode Island Cup today at the opening regatta of the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise. The cup event was open to all five of the foreign 12meter yachts here for the America's Cup competition; but only the two Australians accepted the invitation.

title: Jean Corley, W. H. Yankus Are Married
description: Jean Wyatt Corley, and William Henry Yankus were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Brunie in Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Charles Copenhaver. senior minister of the Reformed Church in Bronxville, performed the ceremony.

title: Therapy Is Elusive for Stubborn Inflation Psychology
description: WASHINGTONFrom the staff of Congress and from the economists at the Brookings Institution have recently come sober assessments about inflation. It is, they say, a deeply entrenched force in the American economy, and, they maintain, the Carter Administration has not come up with an antiinflation policy that is likely to make much of a difference.

title: Stamford Area Is Upgraded, With Hopes of a Ripple Effect
description: The day that suburban Stamford awoke to find it had become a city was not the day it first contemplated its modernistic skyline of office buildings, apartments and hotels. It was the day after, when it became aware of the urban blight that lay at the feet of all that new stone and steel.

title: New Receivers for Giants Cloud Robinson's Future
description: Jimmy Robinson, the Giants leading wide receiver last season, showed up at training camp a day early to watch the rookies and the free agents practice. He was scouting the opposition.

title: CRIME
description: About six years ago, Lillian O'Donnell started a series of procedurals featuring Norah Mulcahaney and her adventures in the N.Y.P.D. Whether or not Norah is going to be around in the future is anybody's guess. In AFTERSHOCK (Putnam's $7.95), O'Donnell has left her lady cop for a new heroine Mid (pronounced Mitzi) Anhalt, who works in the Crime Victims Compensation Board, an agency that helps victims of crime. Naturally she works closely with the police, so this book is also a sort of procedural.

title: Branching Out to Poor in Chicago
description: CHICAGOIt was a quiet afternoon at the storefront office of Northwest Neighborhood Legal Services. Only a halfdozen prospective clients, all of them women, all brown or black and all poor, waited in a row of chairs.

title: Herbert L. Matthews Dead at 77; Times Correspondent for Decades
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sunday, July 31 Herbert L. Matthews, who retired in 1967 after 45 years with The New York Timesmostly as a foreign correspondent and editorial board memberdied yesterday at the age of 77. He died after a short illness in the southern Australian city of Adelaide. In recent years he had made his home in the Adelaide suburb of Glenelg.

title: Jane Blalock Posts 70141, Leads by 3
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., July 30Jane Blalock was not going to play in this week's Ladies Professional Golf Association event  the $75,000 Pocono Manor Northeast tourney. It is a new tournament and Miss Blalock had made plans to take a recess prior to going to Sunningdale, England next week for the annual Colgate European.

title: Cuba Confirms 70 Typhoid Cases
description: HAVANA, July 30 (Reuters)Cuban cases of typhoid but say that the outbreak is under control. Complete eradication is foreseen by next week, the press agency Prensa Latina said yesterday.

title: Scientists Are Seeking Out Soft Underbelly of the City Pest
description: Dr. Betty Lane Farber is staying awake these nights following tagged cockroaches around the floors of the Museum of Natural History.

title: Dr. Joan E. Roberts Wed To Dr. James P. Dillon
description: In the Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary Ukrainian Catholic Church in Fresh Meadows, Queens, yesterday afternoon. Dr. Joan E. Roberts, daughter of John H. Roberts of Forest Hills , Gardens, Queens, and the late Anna Carolyn Roberts, became the bride of Dr. James P. Dillon, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Dillon of Buffalo.

title: Hannes Beckmann, 67, Artist And Professor at Dartmouth
description: Hannes Beckmann; professor of art emeritus at Dartmouth College, died Wednesday at Mary Hitchock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 67 years old.

title: Cost of Emergency Relief Soars For Worst Drought in Century
description: HOUSTON, July 28Costs of emergency drought relief are skyrocketing across the nation, straining the financial resources of national relief agencies, eroding the budgets of hundreds of communities and plunging thousands of farmers into a fight for economic survival.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Consumerism in the form of free banking services has reached its limits. Banks simply cannot continue to supply significant additional services without offsetting them by increases in revenues.

title: Women and Their Problems in Sports: Many Coaches Aren't Ready to Coach
description: When I was competing, opportunities for women in sports were limited. Today, the opportunities are countless. The expanded interest in women's athletic programs has come about partly as a result of better television, radio and magazine coverage and partly as a result of Title IX.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Those who relish being frightened by movies may be disappointed on reexamining their favorites: it's difficult to dissolve with dread a second time, and the test is probably unfair. Meanwhile, I'm told that almost nothing achieves the results of a particular training film for fledgling fathers, where the details of childbirth have prompted some punctual faintings in midreel.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: For centuries, Christmas lay ? 1,200 miles Island south of Hawaii notable as the largest atoll in the Pacific and ad a fuel atop for islandhopping American warplanes during World War IL In 1957 and 1958 the island became the focus of world attention when Britain expIoded ? bombs off its shores. It reemerged to public view in 1962 when the United States conducted atomic explosions in the vicinity.

title: ART VIEW
description: For almost as long as anyone can remember, it has been said that the arts in America are not adequately or properly supported. Likewise, it is often claimed that the arts here are insufficiently appreciated. Many reasons for this grievous condition are offered by way of explana tion, and none of them are flattering to our collective national identity. The cause of this terrible insufficiency is said to be our materialism, our philistinism, our provincialism, our politics, our economics, our preference for gadgets and mundane gratifications over things of the spirit. But whatever the specific cause may be, the established view is usually the same: we are not an esthetic nation, and we therefore starve the arts. Or, as the current jargon has it, our support system is not equal to our potential creativity.

title: Amin Accuses Officers Of Plotting Coup
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 30 (AP)President Idi Amin of Uganda has accused some army officers of collaborating with civilians to topple his military regime, the Uganda radio said today.

description: Senate

description: WASHINGTON, July 30  President Carter and Attorney General Griffin B. Bell arc expected to meet nest week to discuss the selection of a ow d:rector for the Federal Bureau of Investigation amid growing signs that they have not yet settled on a choice for the iob and that they may seek to broaden the field of candidates before making a decision.

description: JOHANNESBURG, July 30 (Reuters)Several persons were wounded by shotgun pellets today when the police fired in stonethrowing demonstrators in the black township of Soweto near here, a police spokesman said.

title: Capital Projects Periled By New Hampshire Veto
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 30 (AP)A. fiscal feud between the State Legislature, and Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr., which has already forced New Hampshire onto a temporary operating budget, now threatens to delay funding of any capital construction projects planned in the next two years.

title: Whiz Kids at Cummins Engine
description: COLUMBUS, Ind.When J. Irwin Meig, one of the most prominent industrialists in the Midwest, relinquished his 26year chairmanship of the Cummins Engine Company, there was scarcely a ripple of reaction here among the headquarters employees of the world's largest independent producer of diesel truck engines.

title: Pipeline Boom Town Settles Down and Counts Its Blessings
description: VALDEZ. Alaska, July 30With a tanker finally taking on the first oil from the transAlaska pipeline system at its terminal across Valdez Arm, this small town settled back today to contemplate the effects of the king's ransom in construction payrolls that passed through here in three years of pipeline construction.

title: Canadians Concerned at Exodus of Doctors to U.S.
description: OTTAWA, July 30Medical authorities here are concerned by a growing exodus of Canadian doctors to the United States, where they find that remuneration for physicians is higher, taxes and costs are lower and there is less official interference in the profession.

description: Odessa Elizabeth Hahn of Baltimore, widow of Theodore John Hahn, was married yesterday at the Second Presbyterian Church of Baltimore to Dr. Charles Anthony Knehr of Glen Cove, L. I., a widower. The Rev. John Galloway performed the ceremony.

title: Cindy Kanover Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kanover have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cindy Michele Kanover, to Gary Richard Schlussel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Schlussel. Both families are of Baldwin, L. I. Miss Kanover and her fianc, a graduate of the State University College at Buffalo, plan to be married in February.

title: THE MAD
description: Twentyfive years ago, little Bobby Crumb clown in Milford, Del., hid in corner of his mother's house and started studying a brandnew, 32page, fullcolor comic book called Mad. Ostensibly, the little rag was a satirical comic book that made fun of other comic books, but in reality it had different fish to fry. In a broad Bronx fashion, much like the broad Bronx personality of its founding editor, Harvey Kurtzman, Mad made fun of everything, including itself, which made into a slippery proposition right from he start

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE PRESIDENTIAL CHARACTER, by James David Barber. (PrenticeHall, $7.50.) In the five years since its publication, this brightly written psychoanalytical study of United States Presidents since Theodore Roosevelt has won a central place on the political bookshelf. This revised edition includes Jimmy Carter, categorized as activepositive; but Barber isn't quite certain whether the times are ripe for that sort.

description: Regarded in his profession as a newspaperman's newspaperman, Herbert Lionel Matthews spent much of his career reporting from war fronts and countries in turbulence. His work earned him fame as well as notoriety as he cabled his dispatches from the Spanish Civil War and tracked down Fidel Castro in Cuba's Sierra Maestra Mountains.

description: Irene Grotnes Belk of New York and Louis Dean Miltimore plan to be married Aug. 20 in the Myers Park Presbyterian Church in Charlotte, N.C.

description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Robert Homans of San Francisco and New York of the engagement of her daughter, Lucy Aldrich Homans, to Hugh Frederick Bangasser, son of Paul Edwin Bangasser of Seattle and the late Margaret Sheffield Bangasser.

title: French Cathedral Artifacts Stolen
description: LE MANS, France, July 30 (Reuters)Three alabaster statues and a 15thcentury alabaster altarpiece have been stolen from a cathedral near this northwestern French town, the police said. The altarpiece, containing five panels, was discovered in the 19th century and placed in the Rosary Chapel of the Cathedral of Notre Dame des Marais de LaFerte Bernard. The statues, each 12 inches high, were of St. Catherine and St. Margaret. A 16thcentury woodandstone statue of Our Lady of the Keys was also taken.

title: ExOfficial Says He Stole 1948 Election for Johnson
description: ALICE, Tex., July 30A former Texas ivoting official, seeking peace of mind, says he certified enough fictitious ballots to steal an election 29 years ago and launch Lyndon Johnson on the path that led to the Presidency.

description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)Almost half of the taxpayers surveyed by the Internal Revenue Service last year said they would like the deadline for filing returns extended to June 30, the agency said Thursday.

Two of the threesome's members, Bob Gilder and Jerry McGee, emerged with sixunderpar 65's and a tie for first place, while the third member, Bill Rogers, shot 66 and settled into a tie for second with John Lister.

description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 30Kash Minbar, a moody 5yearold trotter bred in New York, went the fastest mile and a half in the history of harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Cartage Company garage at 2122 North Clark Street, where a platoon from the army of George (Bugs) Moran was ceremoniously gunned down Feb. 14, 1929, in what has become known as the St. Valentine's Day Massacre, is now a vacant lot sandwiched between a senior citizens home and a fourstory stone office building.

description: WASHINGTON, July 30Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, praised President Carter today for a growing recognition of Congressional interests and a willingness to compromise.

title: Of Special Interest
description: Having been seen by some 26 million theatergoers in 22 countries around the world, the rock musical Hair, which lustily portrays the hippie movement of the 1960's, is back, as of Thursday when it begins previews at the Biltmore where it ran for four years. The intent by all those concernedbook and lyrics by Gerome Ragni and James Rado, music by Galt MacDermot and direction by Tom O'Horganis to revive it just as it was. The only catch has been in the castingthe original cast members have grown up and, in keeping with spirit of the first Hair, a whole new set of unknowns has been hired. Since the average age of the newcomers is 19, they don't remember the original Hair and so old Life magazine photos have been plastered around the rehearsal hall to give them a sense of what it was like back in the 60's when they were 9 or 10. (See Theater)

title: Sunday Observer
description: Although I don't exactly love the libomb, it comes close to my idea of what a bomb should be. First, it fulfills the human need to have a bomb. Second, of all the bombs in circulation these days, it is the one you are least likely to be assaulted with

description: Tournament bridge apart, the normal game at club leveland perhaps in the majority of home gamesis Chicago or fourdeal bridge. One of the few clubs in the Metropolitan New York area where rubber bridgewhich has the disadvantage of being unpredictable in terms of the amount of time neededis played nowadays is the Hungarian Bridge Studio, 290 E. 82d St. On the diagramed deal, NorthSouth had a partscore of 30, reducing the gamelevel for them by one trick in any denomination. This contributed to the endproduct of the auction: two notrump redoubled, one of the rarest contracts in the game.
